review_body: I had very high expectations for Peninsula Hotel. I stayed here for 4 nights with my family of 2 adults and 2 kids. Our room was big with a huge changing room/closet/make up room which I felt took up too much space. I would have preferred the extra space in the bedroom. I expected our room to be really luxurious, this being the Peninsula after all, but it was not as luxurious as I had expected. The room was still very nice but just not as nice as the Ritz Carlton or Grand Hyatt both of which I stayed at in Tokyo before. The Peninsula is located in Yurakucho so it was very convenient for shopping, eating and public transit. We spent all of time exploring Tokyo so we didn't use any of the hotel facilities. For the price of the Peninsula, there are other high end hotels available that are more luxurious and so I will choose a different one next time.

We would have checked 10 stars if the option were available.We had the pleasure of staying at the Peninsula for 7 nightslast month. This was our first visit to Japan and our first stayin a Peninsula property. Based upon our experience we hopeto return and again stay at this property. Our room was delightful. Everything you could want was where you wanted it to be. Our view was extraordinary. We enjoyed delightful breakfasts in the lower floor cafe and later on the rooftop level. We had several wonderful dinners in the lobby restaurant at our favorite table. Check in and check out was quick and friendly. Daily arrivals and departures were assisted by a friendly and helpful doorman. The lobby is grand and the live music at night delightful. However, the most memorable element of our stay was the gracious and helpful staff we encountered throughout our stay. Thank you.  . ..

The Peninsula is the Peninsula for a reason. From the moment you pull up to the door there is exceptional service. I was at the Tokyo Peninsula for 1 day on the end of my four month trip around asia and would have stayed longer but the Coronavirus had just shut down all the museums and i started my trip off in Tokyo so only needed one evening there to fly in and out of the city. I had walked by the hotel on my first stay in the city 4 months early and admired it from the outside and its location. It’s perfectly situated across the gardens and the palace and in the Ginza distract. I checked in and was treated with kindness and warmth. The concierge assisted me in making my dinner reservation for the evening. The front desk staff showed me around my amazing room. It was so luxurious and plush and comfortable. I almost wanted to stay inside the entire day in bed and to take a bath in the insane tub because it was do perfect but with just one day I wanted to explore Ginza and all its stores. When i got back to the room after a long day out the bed was perfectly turned down, slippers out, water out, and the few things I left on the bed when i rushed out where hung up. What a treat!. Also worth noting - the gym was a great place to visit before hitting a long flight in the morning. I cant wait to come back to Tokyo and visit the Peninsula again when I have more time to stay in the city.

When you add up their service, food, rooms, location, employees... it adds up to the nicest hotel I've ever stayed at. And I've stayed at a lot of nice hotels!! I was beyond impressed with everything. The rooms were huge, and so luxury down to every detail (ie: outdoor temp thermometer in the closets, nail dryer in the vanity...) and the service was amazing. Shout out to their concierge team, particularly Steve, who basically planned our entire trip. I emailed them about once a day for two weeks leading up to our stay and they set us up with amazing reservations and recommendations. The hotel is also located in the amazing Ginza district, with a ton to do in walking distance. But more than that, the basement level is actually a metro stop on the H line! So it's 3 stops away from Roppongi, where we also spent a lot of time. The staff is so accommodating, they actually walked us to the basement and helped us buy our metro tickets on the first day. Everyone was so kind! When my husband wasn't feeling well, we called the concierge and a bellman went to the pharmacy to get him some medication. Also, worth noting, the food was amazing! We ate breakfast here everyday, went to Sushi Wakon for dinner (will write a separate review on that - AMAZING) and to the Peter one afternoon for sunset views and cocktails. During this trip to Japan, we also stayed at the AMAN Kyoto and the Park Hyatt Tokyo and to be honest - the Peninsula Tokyo was our favorite hotel. 5 star everything! We can't wait to go back. Thank you for such an amazing experience!

The hotel was terrific. I am ambassador elite with Marriott, so have stayed in my fair share of nice hotels in Asia in particular. This Peninsula is a great property with a super friendly staff. The minute you walk in the lobby to check in the staff gives you their attention and takes care of your needs. The room/suite was quite big for Tokyo, clean, zero smell, and the bed/linens was extremely soft and comfortable. I slept very well. The hotel also managed to secure a reservation for 2 to Jiro's, which is a difficult reservation to get. My friend and I had to cancel due to his having to go back to the USA early, but I revived my part of the reservation and made it to Jiro's. The concierge had plenty of information about what to do in Tokyo, what sights to see, where to go, very helpful people.Overall, a top notch luxury property with first class staff from front desk, to the housekeeping especially, to concierge. Very happy with my stay. Thanks Peninsula Tokyo!

The peninsula is beautiful, and has the most engaging and hospitable staff. We arrived, bedraggled from the Shinkansen from Kyoto with my husband having suddenly hurt his back. The rooms provided his back with some well needed rest while the rest of us were so happy about the views from our adjoining rooms on the 21st floor. No details were missed...including a quick ride in the company Rolls which was so fun and was not expected!Next time we come to Japan, this will be home base!!! Thank you Peninsula...can’t wait to swim laps in that massive pool!

Staying at The Peninsula Tokyo certainly is a grand experience. You can feel this upon entering the premises. There is a great bar on the 24th floor as well. The hotel is just across the street from the Imperial Palace (which makes for a great morning run) and conveniently located near several train lines/stations. The rooms are also impeccably clean and well-appointed (they are huge, with everything you need).That said, The Peninsula is of course quite pricey. Furthermore, there is no breakfast buffet and the a la carte options are quite expensive as well.

The hotel was almost perfect, the way they study every minor details that of the interest of the guest was outstanding, although there is some minor offset in regards of limited breakfast but as I mentioned before it’s outstanding.

We were here for 3 days and it was excessively overpriced due to the holidays. We paid at least 3.5 times the cost of a regular cost for a suite. Booking nonrefundable 6 weeks early really hurt us as there was availability and a price reduction closer to our dates. Other than that, everything else was above average. I didn't quite get the luxury pampering I expected but everyone was professional and very courteous. I stayed at another 5 star hotel during my stay in Tokyo and that by far exceeded my expectations.

This is our fifth stay. We don't even bother to look at other hotel as this is the best you can find in Ginza.location:5 minute walk to Ginza Main Shopping Street, and basically the entire Ginza Shopping and restaurantRoom:Penninsula Standard is the same every country, providing you with quality Sleep and all the ammeinties.Service:Very attentive and helpful service staff. DiningBreakfast is NOT buffet. You can dine at Peter or lobby restaurantOverallWe will be back :)

The Peninsula has become our home when in Tokyo. Very convenient to Ginza and just moments from the Yurakucho station and the Yamanote line. Staff is gracious and knowledgeable. Rooms are wonderful and quiet. Hibya park across the street is very relaxing. Neighborhood has wonderful restaurants and bars. But also check out the tiny ones near the train stations. Peninsula hotels never disappoint.

I booked this hotel as a NYE gift to my parents and the experience was extraordinary. From the moment you check in, the level of hospitality is unrivalled. The staff speak impeccable English. And everyone we met, showed a level of care and hospitality that is honestly second to none. Akane Tanaka was extremely gracious with fantastic knowledge of Tokyo. Tomoyuki Nonaka at the Hei Fung Terrace could not have been more helpful in assisting us with our reservation and lunch at the fantastic Chinese restaurant. I cannot thank the team at the Peninsula enough. I've been fortunate to stay in some wonderful hotels including the usual well-known ones like the Mandarin Oriental, La Mamounia et al. But there's just something very special about the Peninsula.

Nice spacious rooms. Extraordinary staff. Extraordinary food. Extraordinary location. It was our first destination in Our honeymoon and it was simply perfect, when we arrived they gave us champagne and delicious chocolates welcoming and congratulating us for the wedding. Staff was always super attentive and they truly stick to the value of hospitality. Location is really good if you’re traveling to Tokyo because it’s near hibiya station, ginza and maronouchi. Rooms are clean and beautiful, they have huge closets, bath tub...The bed is really comfortable as well. I find really hard to find a negative detail on the experience in the peninsula Tokyo. 100/100.

Exceptional service!! We stayed in the Peninsula Tokyo for birthday celebration and the team really has surprised us!! I mentioned in the email that we like sailor moon but I really did not expect they would make a sailor moon cake for us!! Everything has been amazing during the stay Btw, it will be nice to know the name of the person who decorated the room for us!! We just couldn’t thank him/her enough!! The only downside was that we didn’t have the chance to try sushi Jiro which we were very excited about :( Will definitely come back again and hopefully can get a seat at sushi Jiro!!

The Peninsula Tokyo is an amazing hotel with an active lobby/dinning area on the ground floor. Its rooms have a comfortable size and being on the 19th floor we had a great city view. The pool and exercise area were wonderful and the view towards the Imperial Palace from the pool was unique. One minor negative is concierge desk seems understaffed as a wait was customary.

Excellent location. Loved our room, especially the awesome closet and the pool is wonderful but this property fell short in a few areas. The dining options are just strange. Breakfast buffet was served either in the Peter Bar (great view) or in a very small basement cafe with the service being a little chaotic and inattentive at times. The other option is in the lobby which is also the only reasonably priced venue for lunch and dinner. The lobby is very open, busy and loud and tends to be chilly from the front doors nearby. It’s just odd to be having dinner while luggage is rolling past and tired travelers are slogging through. The other dinner options are a ridiculously priced Chinese restaurant and a very high end sushi bar, I’m sure both excellent but over the top if you just want a casual meal.

The Peninsula Tokyo has been my haven in Tokyo for many years.Most aspects both in terms of hardware and service are in the superlative range.The location is also hard to beat with easy access to train and metro stations, Ginza shopping and dining areas, and enjoy a splendid view of Hibiya Park and Imperial ground from the hotel rooms, pool terrace and restaurants.Indulgence is an understatement and I look forward to my stay next year again.

This hotel is amazing. The rooms are so well designed and there is not a single winking light to annoy you when you sleep. The bathrooms are easy to manage with no need to wonder which is the hot and which cold. I can't think of any minus at all.

I was treated to a one-night stay at The Peninsula Tokyo for my birthday - it was a surprise right until we rolled up to the porte cochere. Having had the pleasure of staying at The Peninsula Shanghai a few years ago, I'd already been sold on the brand and consider these hotels among the finest in the world and certainly the best I've ever enjoyed. And yet The Peninsula Tokyo managed to exceed even that high standard - all in one night. As we checked in for our stay, we were informed that the hotel was aware of my special occasion and elected to upgrade our room based on availability - I didn't really know what that meant in the moment, but a standard room at Shanghai was more than enough for my stay then, and I knew anything above that would be even better. Sure enough, we soon discovered that our upgraded room was a corner Deluxe Suite, with a breathtaking view over the Imperial Palace and downtown Tokyo, complete with a sitting room, dining area, workspace, separate master bedroom, changing room, bath and shower in the marble bathroom, and even a powder room. It's important to note that without this unexpected surprise, I wouldn't have been disappointed... the service was white-glove from the taxi to the front desk, and I know a regular room would have been just as impressive, but that the hotel thought to make my one-night special event even more special was really above and beyond and deeply appreciated. As one expects from The Peninsula, the room was immaculate and spotless; even the couches were vacuumed and the doors wiped clean near the handles. I will often use sani-wipes to clean commonly-touched surfaces in hotel rooms, and I found it was almost overkill here.I also had the chance to enjoy The Peninsula Spa during my stay, and found the service and attention there to be stellar. My full-body massage was among the better I've had anywhere in the world, and the little details The Peninsula adds throughout the experience made it feel like it was truly one of the best spas in the city (which I believe it has been ranked to be in the past). The beautiful pool and gym rounded out the spa space, and the team was incredibly courteous in showing me around before my spa appointment and making sure that all of my questions were answered generally before they were asked.Check-out the next morning was smooth and effortless; the complimentary (included) breakfast served in our room was outstanding and the eggs were perfectly prepared, and temped well despite the travel from the kitchen. A taxi was waiting for us after the check-out was complete, and without my notice our bags had already been loaded into the vehicle, so all we had to do was sit and go. The concierge team followed us outside and bowed as we left - which I know is ordinary in hotels all across Japan - but still it left a great impression departing from this really extraordinary place.I'm not sure when I'll have the chance to stay at The Peninsula again - admittedly it's beyond the budget for most of our trips overall, let alone multiple nights - but when I do, I know I'll savor each moment as much as I did this time. For those who are able and wish to enjoy a truly seamless and luxurious hotel stay, this is a natural spot to consider.

This is a beautiful hotel with excellent service. We stayed here for 3 long weekends over the last fortnight, travelling around Japan during the weekdays. The lobby is lovely and the rooms 5-star. The restaurant, Peter, on the 24th floor serves good quality food and the view over the Imperial Palace and surrounding gardens is stunning - I’d definitely recommend this option (rather than the ground floor) for breakfast. (One minor request: please get a decent toaster! The regular queue at the 2 pathetic toasters, each person waiting 5 minutes to achieve a slightly off-white slice of warm bread should be a clue!). The pool and spa are also beautiful; what a luxury to relax in the large jacuzzi looking out from high up over the city. But what sets the Peninsula apart from other 5* hotels, though, is the level of service; the staff are very friendly and attentive - they can’t do enough for you. It’s not cheap, but you certainly get what you pay for!

Top notch service all round. Attentive, professional and helpful staff - always offering to go the extra mile.Rooms are well appointed and lots of extra touches - eg on request for an ironing board, board came promptly along with a basket including a cloth to cover ironing items, starch for shirts, and a water spray. The staff also made sure to check when I want the items to be removed.In-room food service is also excellent. And very well located near the financial district for a business Traveller.

The Peninsula Hotel in Tokyo should receive a 6 or 7 star rating. The hotel is far superior to all other 5 star hotels in Tokyo. The hotel is an absolute credit to the CEO or General Manager and the team of staff who have clearly been employed not just because they are qualified but because they are also well suited to their jobs and enjoy their jobs. Every staff member in this hotel delivers a perfect service and we are able to make this claim as we ate in every restaurant, even had room service breakfasts, used the concierge service and reception were a pleasure to deal with, and even down to the lady on the door, and the staff just outside the door, it was a perfect service throughout the entire hotel, which is rare to find these days. Check in:The reception staff spoke perfect English even though they are Japanese. They were so well mannered and welcoming. We arrived from a long flight and we arrived too early for check in and understood this, and were just planning on checking in and leaving our bags until check in. We actually arrived at 6.15am in the morning due to the flight arrival. To our surprise, reception said that they would escort us to our room and there was our name and gifts all set out for us. The lovely lady showed us how to operate features in the room, and actually connected our phones for us to the free internet. The gratitude we felt that a hotel actually went out of its way to allow us in to a room this early is something we will always remember. They didn't have to do this of course and we understood check in was later on.  The room:We were astounded by the room. It was on the 20th floor. It is of such high quality and has been masterfully designed. It is also large and has high ceilings with intricate detailing in the ceiling and unusual lights. The bed was a spotless king bed with high quality linen and pillows. The bedside tables are so clever, you can touch them anywhere during the night if you are wondering what time it is, and the time on the clock comes on. When you turn off the lights at bed time, the time on the clock goes off so you don't have to put a face cloth over it to cover the glare. We've all had to do that. Not in this hotel. The clock goes dark and all you do is put your hand anywhere on the table and it comes on. And its on both bedside tables so you don't have to look over your partner to see the time. The curtains and blinds are all motorised and absolutely beautiful. The carpet is of high quality. The decor in the room is sensational. The lounge was so comfortable, and the TV was perfectly positioned. There was a well set out study desk and chair with accessories and a table perfectly positioned on the window with 2 very comfortable chairs. We didn't book a suite, this is just how our room was. We booked a room that had Imperial Garden views and I believe that these rooms are located on higher floor levels. The Bathroom:The bathroom had large his and her vanities totally separate from each other but in the same bathroom with large areas so you could set your items out which we like to do. The bath was amazing with a rainfall spout and lovely cosmetics. The bathroom was all marble. The toilet was in its own area with door and NOT in the bathroom which is nice. The shower is a rainfall shower and if you don't like that, you can have a standard type of shower head if you prefer. There is a built in seat in there too. The towels are all of high quality as are the robes and slippers. The bathroom was so clean it was wonderful. The windows in the room:These are extremely high double glazing. Not all double glazing is equal. We could not hear anything outside. Our view was to the Imperial Palace Gardens.Sound Proofing:This is the ONLY hotel we have been to where sound proofing is taken seriously. When you walk into the room, they have put in during construction a sliding door that you can close off from your entry hall to the bedroom, so you don't pick up any noise from the corridors, eg people closing their doors or walking around talking. This was fantastic and a real credit to the architect of the hotel. Every hotel should be like this.The Walk in Robes:They aren't really walk in robes. Its a Walk in Room. It is so beautifully finished and even has a dressing table with chair in there, and it has lots of hanging space, lovely big draws, and if a lady wanted to paint her nails you can put your hands into a nail drying machine. The lighting is superb too and every little detail has been considered. So much space to set out your shoes and having the chair in the walk in dressing room means you can sit down and put your socks and walking shoes on if you are going out for a big day. Room Service:This is no ordinary room service.A very polite and courteous man arrives and sets up a silver service breakfast and puts the napkin on your lap and treats you like you are a king and queen. Even if you are only having cereal, and toast, the effort that goes into making your breakfast is wonderful. The Peninsula coffee was 10 out of 10 and we are very fussy when it comes to coffee and could never fault the coffee on any day. We also noticed that the breakfast was delivered at the precise time. To the minute. This must just be a co-incidence we thought. But no, it was like this every day. And every day the same respectful polite service from this gentleman who you could clearly see was so well suited to his job and took his job seriously. Also the person who answered the phone when we booked the room service was excellent. The attention to detail was evident in everything they did. The Lobby Restaurant:The food is amazing in this restaurant, it is so fresh and beautifully presented. The live entertainment provides a wonderful ambience. It is not noisy the music.The lobby Manager, Eisuke Nagano provides the guests with a 6 star dining experience. He goes above and beyond. He is so professional, highly trained and experienced, speaks excellent English, and goes out of his way to ensure you have a memorable experience. The waitress was so helpful with the wines. Nothing was of any trouble. Try this wine, have a try of this one, we want to make sure you enjoy the wine you have chosen. It was so relaxing in this lobby restaurant. It also has a cheerful atmosphere that reflects the attitude of the staff. Peter Restaurant and Bar on the top floor:If you are looking for a dining experience that is pure perfection with faultless service and stunning views and decor, try this restaurant. It was superb. The staff were the same as the rest of the hotel. Well suited to their jobs, clearly like their jobs, and ensure the guests have a memorable occasion. The menu was really excellent and there is something on that menu for everyone.The basement cafe in the hotel:We thought we were just going to a cafe, however the lunch we had was astonishing. It was absolutely beautiful and we had silver service, and impeccable service and food. It was also so well priced too. You can also go to the take away counter if you don't want to sit down in the cafe itself. The food was beautiful and so fresh. You can also watch chefs down there making food and making desserts.Concierge:So helpful and kind. They went out of their way to be helpful and also spoke very good English. The reason why we keep mentioning this is, we stayed at another 5 star hotel in Tokyo on another occasion, and the staff could hardly speak English and if they did, they didn't actually know what you were asking. At The Peninsula, the English spoken by the Japanese staff is excellent. The pool:It is so clean and has lounges all around with a peaceful ambience and lovely views. Please do not change the set up and rules for the pool. Finally a pool that is peaceful and a pleasure to be in. The standard overall:It is evident that the CEO or the General Manager, has high standards and this high standard is projected right through the hotel. The staff are also genuinely sincere and so well mannered and friendly. The CEO or General Manager should be congratulated for the standard that has been set at The Peninsula in Tokyo. Conclusion:We could not fault this hotel in any way. Even down to little things like the corridors. The corridors are so beautiful, all mood lighting with views down the centre of the building if you choose to look, with crystal hanging inside the centre. However if you didn't go over to it, you would just think it was a painting on the wall, but it was a vaulted void through the hotel all fully enclosed and very moody and romantic looking. The corridors were so quiet and no racket from cleaners. The naturally friendly attitude from the gentlemen who stand just outside the entry, were there to assist you with a taxi if you needed one, or directions, and were so well dressed and greeted you warmly every time you walked in and out with a big smile. The nice young lady on the rotating swinging door, is there to ensure you are ok with the door which automatically opens and goes around anyway, however little things like this stood out as this would be the most boring job yet she did her job with joy and smiled and greeted everyone. We would go out and come back hours later and still she was there with a big smile and so beautiful towards the Peninsula guests.This is a hotel for people who want a life time memory. This is not just a place to sleep and shower. It is an experience. Japan should be proud that it has such a high standard hotel in its capital city Tokyo. The other 5 star hotels in Tokyo don't even come close to this one. That's why if they are a 5 star then The Peninsula should easily be a 6 or 7 star. It's much better than the Burj at Dubai, which is a 6 star hotel. The hotel is also in a high class area that is very central. To The Peninsula Hotel: Thank you for providing us with an experience we will never forget. You made our trip to Japan one that we will always remember. We sincerely thank you for providing us with a beautiful room on the 20th floor at such an early hour of the morning, when we did not expect this as we all know check in is much later on. What a wonderful kind gesture to do this when we didn't even ask. Thank you.

Without a doubt one of the best hotels I've stayed in. The Tokyo Peninsula Hotel is absolutely worth the price you pay. The service is great and the rooms impress anyone. We chose this hotel for our Honeymoon as the first destination and they welcomed us with chocolates and champagne. The buffet breakfast is a delight even with Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese. The gym is very well equipped and the spa facilities are very good. The room is full of gadgets such as QI charger on each side of the bed and USB chargers. It also has a very good espresso machine. Without a doubt the best hotel in Tokyo. Staff was EXTRAORDINARY and always willing to help you, make sure to take advantage of the PenChat which will help you with reservations throughout the city. Thank you so much Peninsula Tokyo staff.

Nicely located in the heart of Tokyo's sightseeing, eating and shopping district. Rooms were nice, roomy, but slightly dated.Breakfast in the lobby was a miss experience. During a multi-day stay, there was at least one mistake on with the daily breakfast order,.. even when there was only a few other customers. The quality of food was also average to below average. Slow to fix the problems with the order as well. A few times we also heard other customers complaining about mistakes with order and slow service.Even though breakfast was a consistent bust (I would not eat there again),.. the location of the hotel was perfect to walking around the sights,.. plus the rooms were a good size and comfortable therefore 3 stars.

We were very happy with our stays in The Peninsula in Tokyo. We stayed in The Peninsula on our arrival in Tokyo and then again at the end of our Japan Trip. Our welcomes were very friendly and we were in our room quickly and with no fuss on each occasion. Everything we asked about in the hotel was efficiently handled. The location was excellent. Whilst I have no complaints about any aspect of the hotel, after just having stayed at the Four Seasons in Hong Kong, I felt that The Peninsula lacked a little personality.We ate in Sushi Wakon and Peters Bar and Grill, and enjoyed both.

This is simply the very best hotel we have ever had the pleasure of staying in. We recently stayed a total of 8 nights; 5 planned and 3 unplanned due to Typhoon Hagibis. Each and everyone of the staff members we dealt with during our stay provided impeccable and friendly service. Our room was a delight - spacious, beautifully appointed and spotlessly clean. We dined at Peter Steak & Grill and enjoyed steak so tender it really did melt in your mouth, and also Hei Fung Terrace Cantonese, The Lobby Restaurant, and The Peninsula Boutique Cafe, with all providing excellent food and service. We also enjoyed a number of evenings in Peter:Bar, with lovely views, attentive service, and delicious cocktails. As you would expect from such a high quality hotel, it is not an inexpensive option - and we did think the price for coffee in The Lobby was somewhat excessive - but overall, our stay it was worth every yen.

This is a classic (by Western terms) large hotel near the shopping area of Ginza. It has a fairly generic large lobby with a restaurant area and very pleasant staff. Our room was large, with a double bathroom and a dressing room. The furnishings were nice if unremarkable. The pool in the spa area was a good size and the steam room was lovely.As you would expect everywhere was pristine and all the staff we encountered were courteous and helpful.We were here during the typhoon and felt safe and secure throughout.In a city that can sometimes be overwhelming to a first time visitor, this hotel was a reassuringly solid and very pleasant base for our trip.

Where to begin! The front desk offers unparalleled service and were always very friendly as we came and went each day. The breakfasts were phenomenal and both visually stunning and delicious. Our room had a tremendous walk in closet which I didn’t know I would love so much but it is very nice to have with a family on an international trip.The accommodations were lovely and the bed was incredibly comfortable. Our room view of Tokyo and the bullet train below were reminiscent of a New York City skyline view. The location is perfect for high-end shopping or window shopping and walking around at night for restaurants found in the second floor and upper levels of the surrounding buildings. The restaurant in the hotel on the top floor was spectacular. The view of the imperial palace was a nice treat from our table.This is a must stay hotel if you have the means and a reason to be in Tokyo.

This was our first visit to Japan and our first stop was Tokyo...and The Peninsula Hotel. It set the bar for the rest of the trip. One of our group said it was the finest hotel he has ever stayed in...and he’s stayed in some good ones. The rooms are fabulous. Everything from the “mood lighting” to the best hotel HVAC system ever. Giant walk-in closet. Location is excellent. Service was impeccable. Highly recommended.

Five nights business trip in this hotel really made the trip so amazing. Right from the start when you checked in, all the people were very helpful with our needs. The room is very spacious and the quality of the bed and linen are second to none. Even the complimentary coffee and tea are of best quality. Kinda make you not wanting to go out. The hotel is very close to where the actions are. Great restaurants are just within walking distance. The metro station is actually attached to the hotel and the JR station is just around the corner. While cafes and convenient stores are just a step away. The concierge and the door girl are very attentive to your needs. Give you umbrella when it is raining and very quick with a nice bottle of mineral water when you come in after a run or a walk. I reckon that this is the best hotel in Tokyo by far. Will definitely bring my family here for the next Tokyo visit.

We recently spent 6 nights in Tokyo, 3 nights at Park Hyatt Shinjuku, and 3 nights at The Peninsula. The Peninsula is in a MUCH more convenient location, as others have said, and the rooms are large and very very comfortable, but I would say that Park Hyatt is more beautiful hotel. But that might just come down to preference on the style - Park Hyatt is more modern/contemporary, Peninsula is more old school, even slightly dated. So this review is mostly about Peninsula, but I can't help comparing the two slightly...Pros:Location location location! The closest station is Hibiya, but Yurakucho (more convenient in how many places you can get to from there) is just 5 mins easy walk. Under the train tracks there are many many small restaurants, so cool! Also it's just a 5-10 min walk to Ginza, or Tokyo Station. Super convenient! Also the big park across the road and Imperial Palace nearby. Unfortunately we didn't get to those this visit because it was way too hot. The room is large and comfortable, and has a separate lounge area, so it feels a bit like an apartment. Double sinks (our room at Park Hyatt only had one so we appreciated it!) in the bathroom, and the typical Peninsula lovely large dressing room with butler box. Also USB ports and wireless charger in bedside drawers was handy - this is one modernisation we really noticed and enjoyed.Service felt more personable, less stiff - AT FIRST, there were a couple of staff who really stood out as being friendly. There is a 'con' for this one as well...Lovely big Jacuzzi in pool area! I don't normally do laps in the pool, but I do love a relax in a jacuzzi!ConsI agree with other reviews, the lobby area seems odd. One day there was a wedding going on so we had to use the side entrance instead of the main entrance, and felt a bit bad walking past them in shorts.There are also people dining there, having high tea every day - and there is a dress code. So we always felt a bit awkward walking through, when we've been out exploring Tokyo all day, hot and sweaty from 40c outside and wearing shorts flip flops etcThe breakfast was lovely, but it's either taken in the lobby (weird as I said), or in the basement for the buffet - lovely buffet but the space does feel very much like a basement, not that nice.We had a drink in the bar upstairs, and it was nice enough, but nothing on the New York bar at Park Hyatt.The one thing I really didn't like, and perhaps it's a symptom of the awkwardness of the lobby - is that I felt quite uncomfortable from staff (not the personable ones, but the more formal, stuffy ones) staring when we were walking in after a long day of sight-seeing, I felt really underdressed and as it it wasn't acceptable. Maybe it was in my imagination, I didn't feel like that later dressed for dinner... But then when we checked out we asked if we could leave our bags and use the pool/spa area to freshen up later since our flight back to Australia wasn't until 11pm. The lady at reception was lovely and said of course.... but then when we came back in the afternoon (hot again as it was CRAZY hot and the day after the typhoon), the lady at the front door was quite abrupt in saying we couldn't come back in after we'd checked out - and it felt almost as if we weren't even welcome in the lobby - take our bags and go! So that wasn't a very nice feeling. Then after we pleaded and said reception told us earlier that it would be ok - she allowed us to go to reception. They sorted it out, but then when we went to the change rooms and I came out to go to a spa to meet my husband there (male/female change rooms opposite sides of the room) the lady there chased me down and I had to explain to her I'm meeting my husband - "is that ok"? She looked a bit miffed..... So I felt very unwelcome, even though we'd been there for 3 days already, and I don't think asking to freshen up before our long overnight flight after most of the day outside in extreme heat was and unreasonable request. Anyway - that feeling of discomfort and being unwelcome really put me off - we are not scruffy, but we are certainly not stuffy either. We stay in luxury hotels all the time, and I've never felt that uncomfortable. All was redeemed though when a LOVELY gentleman in the lobby area gave us advice on how best to get to the airport (given the typhoon transport delays), and chatted to us as he walked us out to the street. He was fantastic! Maybe they noticed? not sure. But the lady at the reception who greeted us when we arrived, and the gentleman who helped us at the end, could give lessons to the others on how to smile more and make people feel more comfortable.So, while it's a beautiful hotel and excellent location, we'd stay somewhere different next time.

The peninsula hotel in Tokyo is a good hotel to stay, rooms are with very good spaces and comfortable. Very good hospitality, service and staff are friendly.Prices are high around $800 per night.Breakfast menu with limited selections, because there’s no buffet.
user_name:
Khalifa A
Al Ain, United Arab Emirates

review_body: Love The Peninsula it doesn’t get any better. Location is perfect and the staff can’t wait to help you in anyway they can. The rooms are top notch with everything you need for comfort . Room service food is yummy with good presentation. It’s right across from the imperial palace with with good restaurants in the area.
user_name:
tj264
Paso Robles Wine Region, California

review_body: Stayed at the PEN. From sept. 1st to the 10th. 2019. From the moment I got off the shuttle bus, the staffed took my luggage and walked me to the check in desk. If you want to splurge they do offer car service pickup from Norita airport to hotel. Rolls Royce $640, BMW $580, Tesla S $460, Van $460 and taxi $264. I took the Limousine Bus from the airport to the PEN. Cost was 30 bucks per person. The shuttle desk was right in front, when you’re done with immigration and picking up luggage. No issues with the shuttle,A/C and comfortable. The shuttle will make about 5 stops before dropping you off at the PEN. I opted for the Tesla S from hotel to Norita airport. The driver was polite and the ride was comfortable. He got me to the airport in 1hr and 30 min. The shuttle will take about 2hours. The staffed here is top notch. The person that checked me in(sorry didn’t get her name). She welcomed me and got all my info registered in 5 min. If you used AME Platinum card. The PEN Will give you a complementary room upgrade if available? I booked a premier king room, they gave me a king room with a garden view of the imperial palace. She then walked me up to my room. She stayed a few mins. To show the room and it’s offerings. The staff ppl were fantastic and take pride in their jobs. The room also came with complementary breakfast every morning. First day of breakfast down stairs in the cafe. One gentleman with glasses I saw everyday(didn’t get his name:) he knew my name and always greeted each morning. Then 5 min later Lobby Assistant MGR( David Tao:) came over to introduce himself to me and welcome me. I didn’t expect that. He also, greeted me each morning and knew my name. WOW! There’s also a buffet downstairs, you have the option of cafe, buffet or room service. The servers were all nice and fantastic. They seem to take pride in their work. The room had fantastic view of the palace and city of Tokyo. Large walk-in closet. The room is very detailed and meticulous. It had a umbrella, flashlight, and a finger nail dryer. Bathroom has a rain shower, was fantastic. Automatic toilet that opens, closes and auto flush. The bath tub was super larger. It has a TV with plenty of controls from the tub. The bed was comfy, I slept pretty good all 9 days. A/C was great and super quiet. The lighting in the room was great too. You can dim the light at night to enjoy the view of Tokyo. The lights have 3 settings for your liking. The maid service was excellent. Everyday, it was cleaned plus every night they get the room ready for bed. Everyday they give you 4 bottles of water no charge and ice 2 times per day. They also gave me 2 glass lens cloth, the little things. Room also had a dinning table, couch to relax and a mini office. It even had a printer. Tea pot and cups if you want tea. Coffee machine. The drawers next to the bed had a wireless charger. This room had tons of gadgets and controls. Safe for valuables and laundry service. You name it this hotels got it! Only thing I thought needed upgrading was it had a old DVD player and the tv had old SVG and AV cable inputs. I couldn’t use it cause I have HDMI wires. The gym was kinda small, had a few running machines, one bike machine. Not a whole lot of weights. The infinity pool was beautiful. The resting area had a great view of Tokyo. Hotel restaurant peter located on the top floor. Hei fung terrance, Chinese restaurant and sushi wakon on the 4th floor. I didn’t try any cause there’s plenty of great food outside the hotel. The cafe also serves afternoon tea. Theirs also a cafe down stairs serves coffee and desserts after 11am. I tried it one day and it was great. Other food options if you want something different. There’s 7-11 across the street ( yes! In America 7-11 and convenience stores foods are crappy) in Japan, food it great and plenty of options at reasonable prices. Lawson’s connivence store is next to the PEN. Starbucks is also next to the PEN. Plenty of food options next to the hotel. Location is near Ginza district. Lots of high end brand name stores. There’s a subway station right underneath the hotel, Hibiya line. Yurakucho subway located block and a half from the hotel next Bic camera store. By subway, most of the popular locations are 15-30 mins away. If you need to ride the JR rail lines, it’s 15 mins. By subway to Tokyo Station. You can take taxi or hire one of their nice cars, if you’re in a hurry. Every staff member greeted me with “hello”, “good morning”, good evening”, and when you come back from a long day, “welcome home”. One of the best hotels I’ve stayed at. I’m already planning another trip here. I give you guys 10 stars if there’s a option.

Natsuko Fujiwara - Guest relationsYukari Fukasawa - Asst Front Office ManagerJoseph Lee - Hotel ManagerMartin - Asst Restaurant ManagerYes, the Peninsula is a great hotel. The rooms are large and technically superior to any hotel that I have ever stayed in. Yes, the food is great especially the eggs benedict I had every morning at the suggestion of my friend Martin. Yes, the service is first class. This should be expected from a hotel of this caliber. But, none of this makes this hotel really special. Its something else. My wife needed medical attention on our last visit while we were at the Peninsula. The team of Ms Fukasawa and Ms Fujiwara sprang into action and provided instant assistance to her need. This help was from true concern for another human being.Yes, we were guests of the hotel, but these two had a spirit of concern that transcended that fact. They both followed through with inquiry and concern up to the time of departure. We also received a personal visit from joseph Lee and an email of concern from other senior managers. In all, the whole organization threw their collective arms around us. I will always be a fan of this hotel and these people. I am not sure you can teach this kind of graciousness. It comes from somewhere other than a book. Thank you.

This hotel is worth the price! The location is terrific for using the trains, shopping and dining. Staff is terrific, helpful and knowledgeable. The hotel pool and gym is a great set up especially having jet lag. It opens at 6 am and gives you something to do for a few hours. In the afternoon it was a great place to cool off from the humidity. The rooms are beautifully appointed with great detail. Loved taking a bath with the mood lights and spa music. Such a special place. The hotel lobby has live music playing at night. The concierge got us tickets for a baseball game with a small charge. They even gave me a cake for my birthday!
user_name:
usmom
New York City, New York

review_body: Our room is perfect. King bed, coach, desk, plenty of room. The bathroom is generously sized, but the best area is the dressing room/huge closet. It is not only beautifully appointed, but large enough to keep all the luggage away from the main room. The service is impeccable, white glove, elegant. There is nothing I would improve about this hotel. I would return in a heartbeat!!

We ended up booking the Peninsula last minute after changing our mind on the area to stay for our first visit to Tokyo and we’re so glad we made the change. The hotel is close to all the main metro lines and easy walking distance to the shopping and restaurants of Ginza and Shinbashi. The room is very well appointed and large. It seems as if every detail was thought of in the design and execution of the room. The pool area was great for relaxing a bit after a busy day of touring. We stayed while the president of a country and all his senior staff were also at the hotel but we did not feel like the hotel staff ever missed a beat with us even while the president was having breakfast at the table right by us one day. While we really enjoyed everything about the hotel, the best feature was the concierge. They helped us make reservations, got us tickets to Teamlabs Borderless after it was sold out and helped us with all our questions. The concierge has a WhatsApp number and you can message them with questions or requests and they respond immediately. They also helped us ship our luggage to our next stop in Kyoto so we didn’t have to carry all our luggage on the bullet train. We will definitely stay at the Peninsula again on our next trip to Tokyo.
user_name:
Searching_4_Sunrise
New York City, New York

review_body: So I am arriving with my family for a brief visit and there were numerous and multiple restaurant and travel arrangements to be made and the concierge service was superb in handling my multiple requests. I think the legendary Peninsula service has hit its epitome with the Tokyo branch! They had clear English speaking emails and phone calls at every stage and were always so helpful that it really makes foreign luxury travel a breeze!

This is your destination. With family-friendly conditions and kind staff this is the place to stay in Tokyo.The rooms have interesting architecture, containing different pieces of art, and lots of things for people who love attention to details. You will even find a laundry “elevator” and a nail dryer in your walk-in closet and vanity.There are many things to explore in the whole hotel, like stores, the spa, different restaurants and a Rolls-Royce parked out side the hotel.When you come in the staff will always greet you by your name and are gracious. The hotel is also very conveniently located for Ginza shopping, visiting the imperial palace and practically everything in downtown Tokyo. I think my favorite part was the kind service and the artwork in the hotel. If you do come here I wish you a pleasant stay.

Nice sized rooms--we had a small sitting area, a good-sized closet with separate sides and a large bathroom with 2 sinks (on opposite sides of the room so you did not crowd each other). The first floor of the hotel has The Lobby Restaurant which is open for most of the day---they also serve afternoon tea. There is also the Peter Bar & Restaurant upstairs that has gorgeous views---great for city light views at night, as well as sunset views--in addition, you get an ideal view of the Imperial Palace Grounds---they also serve buffet breakfast there every morning. There is also a good Chinese Restaurant--Hei Fung Terrace. The location is close to upscale shopping and restaurants as well as to the train station. We found the concierge desk quite helpful. Check out my photos for more details.

Excellent experience, met by hotel manager/staff on arrival who took the time to make us feel special/welcome/walk us through the facilities. Room and service surpassed expectations. We look forward to our return visit. Big thanks to Josep, Fernando and the team.

The room was the nicest I've had in Tokyo by a wide margin. Service, especially at the front, was average. The man who checked me in was uncharacteristically rude for this level of hotel. The dining situation isn't great.

Everything about this hotel is perfection. The location is ideal. Close to upscale shopping, many restaurants and the Imperial Palace. The service from the front desk, housekeeping, bell staff was amazing. Far above and beyond. We dined at the Cantonese restaurant one evening and were not disappointed. The meal was divine and worth every penny. The rooms are thoughtfully designed with more than ample bathroom space (amazing soaking tub—complete with lovely bath salts) and a separate dressing area with vanity. Comfy beds and bedding and a sitting area, as well. I can attest to the building’s safety as we experienced an earthquake while we were there (on the 18th floor!). All we felt was a slight sway and the pendant lights began to swing slightly. It was off putting and it took us a moment to realize what was happening, but it was over as quickly as it began and there was no damage. I suppose local people are used to it. I would highly recommend this hotel and will be rebooking in my next trip to Tokyo.

excellent location; service is wonderful. we had a family trip to Tokyo for 5 nights. we immensely enjoyed our stay at the peninsula. the pool was also wonderful along with the spa with steam and sauna. the one negative thing is that the furniture in the rooms are showing their age. regardless, I was very happy with our stay. I wish they had a lounge like the Ritz Carlton.

Immaculate reception with attention to every detail. Staff represents the highest service. Very centrally located so do walk to the Imperial Gardens. Do enjoy the French toast but pass on the pancakes.

We had such a wonderful experience staying here! Service exceeds your expectations! Our bags were brought directly to our dressing room closet and set up before we arrived to room. The restaurant Peter was excellent and loved our French Maitre d! Every night when we returned our room was turned down with fresh towels, mood lighting and shades pulled. The pool was so refreshing after a warm day of sightseeing in Tokyo! Train is just walking distance from hotel. The morning buffet was beautiful. The only thing I miss was some Japanese food on morning breakfast buffet since we are in Japan it would be nice to see local culture incorporated. Highly recommend this hotel!
user_name:
Overtherainbow555
New York City, New York

review_body: You get used to excellent service as standard in Japan but even by this criterion, the Peninsula excels. The check-in is smooth and courteous, we were escorted to the lift by three people, including the Manager, and given a guided tour of our room. The selection of sweet treats was very welcome. Nothing is too much trouble for any one of the staff - we needed a large taxi to Tokyo station on our departure because of all our bags going to the airport at about 4 pm. All arranged by the concierge without any fuss, including a late checkout at 3 from one of our rooms which was a huge help. The spa is lovely and the swimming pool and hot tub overlook the approach to the Imperial Palace Gardens - the provision of all the water, towels and toiletries you could possibly need is great. The rooms are fantastic - separate walk-in wardrobe, huge bathroom and separate lounge area, as well as a very large comfortable bed. Breakfast was included and was all very nice - we chose the buffet in the basement cafe rather than the set menu in the lobby. We also had tea and cake there in the afternoon which was a lovely treat. This is a great hotel - yes, it is not cheap but it is a real treat. The facilities and service are of impeccable quality.

We had a spectacular time while here for 4 nights. The service and location of this hotel is second to none. Every encounter we had with staff was friendly, and they honestly could not have treated us better, we felt like family.Our room was very large with a luxurious bathroom and closet/dressing area. The Concierge desk was very helpful in booking restaurants and recommending tours/activities.Breakfast in the lobby was fantastic- delicious and beautifully prepared foods.The location is fantastic- so close to everything in Ginza and has a metro station in the basement.Luckily we get to return for another 4 nights following our trip to Kyoto! This is truly a special hotel, I highly recommend it.

The hotel is in the best location possible, right in front of the imperial palace. The service and attention is impeccable from the arrival to the moment you leave. Food in all the restaurants is very goodRooms need a deep update, we stayed in the 12th floor and the rooms on this floor had 90's tech and dated furniture.

My husband and I went to Tokyo for anniversary and it exceeded my expectations.The hotel is located very close to Tokyo Station and a few steps walking to Ginza.Staff is super kind and nice.Bedroom was amazing with the Imperial Gardens view.Breakfast is very good also in both spots: lobby and basement.And please do the afternoon tea at the lobby We loved each day staying here!

My two girlfriends and I spent 4 days here on our first trip to Tokyo. The service and attention to detail was second to none. Our room was very spacious and perfect for 3 people. However, If you’ve never been to Tokyo before, I would recommend really researching the attractions/areas you want to see and book your hotel based on that. Our only complaint was that The Peninsula was probably not in the best location for the typically touristic things that we did. We spent a lot of time in taxis.

I stayed at the Peninsula with a friend recently and had a perfect stay! The staff were so hospitable and friendly and went over and above to make you happy. Edith from the breakfast lounge was particularly lovely! She was so helpful and polite. Patrick also amazing and made us feel so welcome! Carlo was also very helpful behind the concierge desk with great recommendations! The housekeeping team were wonderful and so efficient! Thank you for the amazing stay i cant wait to come back!

The Peninsula oozes luxury from the moment you arrive. Maybe it’s the Rolls-Royce house car out front or maybe it’s the beautiful lobby but this place feels fancy. We stayed in the Deluxe suite and it was amazing. Panoramic views over the Imperial Palace were impressive. There were tons of over the top details that really made the hard product here amazing. There was a telescope in the living room, a massive closet, the softest robes and slippers, and even a tub with a button that dimmed the lights and played relaxing music. It felt like every detail had been gone over with a fine tooth comb. The facilities here are over the top as well. Their pool and spa facilities are amazing. Their rooftop restaurant and bar “Peter” is very cool. Great view of downtown Tokyo and the Imperial Palace as well as great food and excellent drinks. I’d say it’s an absolute must if your in Ginza and looking to grab drink. My only minor complaint was a room service breakfast I had. Everything was very good but it wasn’t up to par with the other room service meals we had in Japan. But like I said it’s my only small complaint and I wouldn’t hesitate to stay here again if I was looking for a place to stay in Ginza.

We stayed at The Peninsula for 4 nights in June and loved our stay! The Peninsula staff are very accommodating and always willing to assist. Whether it was with dinner reservations, questions/suggestions for day trips or all the special touches for our celebrations, they were always happy to help us with any request! We were impressed with Peter Restaurant on our first night, it had gorgeous views, and great food. Breakfast every morning was really great too, we opted for the Japanese breakfast a few times and also the standard Western breakfast option a few times. Our room was beautiful, and had ample space for all our items. The service at this hotel was really special, especially the concierge. They went out of their way to find suggestions for us based on our requests. The only thing I didn't necessarily love was the way the restaurant takes over the main lobby when you enter the hotel. But outside of that it was incredible. The location of the hotel is also perfect. Easy to get around, close to the subway and train stations, lots of great dining and shopping nearby- overall very close to everything! I highly recommend staying here and would absolutely come back on my next trip to Tokyo. (We stayed at a different hotel for 1 night in Shinjuku on our way back at the end of our Japan trip and I definitely think it is better to stay in the Ginza area!) Thanks to The Peninsula for making our trip to Tokyo so wonderful!

The stay at the Peninsula was perfect. The concierge was specially attentive and nice. We. had a great experience. Very close to Ginza! So perfect to walk and shop. Great restaurants also, inside the hotel and close by.
user_name:
Ninfa L
San Pedro Garza Garcia, Mexico

review_body: This is my favourite hotel in the World. I am very particular about places I stay, and the Peninsula is the top of my list for business travel. I stayed in the supposedly superior Imperial Hotel, but wasn’t impressed (smaller rooms, dated decor).Having stayed in many leading hotels of the world, this is the best and I always stay when in Tokyo. I always get the Park View rooms which face out with huge floor to ceiling windows. The Park view Room is effectively a suite it has a large bedroom/living area, with a corridor which leads to a large luxurious bathroom and large dressing room which is good for keeping luggage out the way,The house keeping service is impeccable. The staff take great care and they spend a great deal of time cleaning the rooms (which they can do at any time on demand, rather than disrupting your morning by knocking on the door).The breakfast service is exceptional, and the choices for the breakfast menu (which is included usually) are not limited. Instead of restricting items from the menu on the breakfast plan (which most hotels do - cutting out the best options usually) they give each guest a budget (about 7700 JPY per person, which is more than enough to over every option available). The location is fantastic for underground access. The hotel has its own entrance to Hibya station which is very convenient for Akihabara, Nakano, otemachi, ikebukero, asaksa etc. The hotel is also adjacent to the imperial palace and gardens in Chiyoda which is also a short walk from Ginzan and Marounouchi.The only downside I can point to is that I find the staff to be a bit too servile/over the top on occasion. Many will appreciate this, but in the UK (where I live) we don’t generally have this to the same degree. For example, I got in a lift after a cleaner also entered and she apologised profusely and started saying “oh no! Sorry sir! May I share this lift with you, Im so sorry”. Also when they come to the rooms (to deliver room service etc) they tend to hang back too much for my liking and fuss a bit too much. This is my own persona view - I suspect that such service is expected by many international travellers and may be specifically what some people enjoy about the hotel. They treat you like a celebrity.

Expensive, but really a memorable experience. The flowers in the lobby are truly works of art.Extremely helpful front desk staff. Very nice room and loved the light on the stone wall over the tub. Gorgeous.Ate in the lobby for breakfast multiple times. I only wish I could dine there more often. Great flavors, beautiful presentation.Great location for exploring the Imperial Palace and the Ginza.Very nice indoor pool that didn't even have the characteristic unpleasant odor of an indoor pool.Truly a top flight hotel

The last 4 nights of a 16 day Japan trip. Well worth the cost. Service was 1st rate. Location was in the heart of Ginza. Rooms were impeccably clean and very spacious.  Walk-in closets, large bathroom and incredible views. Staff could not be any more helpful. Truly 5 Star hotel.

We stayed in the hotel around thanksgiving time last year. I still feel bad about their services and decide I need to express my dissatisfaction. I highly suggest anyone plans to utilize hotel concierge services stay away from this hotel. The room is spacious and new, which are as expected for the price they charge. The lobby is small and overcrowded. They turn both sides of the small lobby into a restaurant, leaving only a narrow aisle leading to the front desk with limited seats for waiting. The concierge service is atrocious. They are irresponsive and make mistakes (multiple of them). Some due to disorganization from the top, some due to carelessness, some due to who knows what funny reasons I fail to think of out of normal reasoning. 1) they are irresponsive. We emailed to request reservation of restaurants. It took them a whole three days to respond, only acknowledging the email had been received without any warm greetings or action plan. I regret not canceling despite this red flag!2) they are disorganized. we had to make international phone calls to remind them to take action on a timely manner ( I don’t know who is supposed to assist whom). To their credit, they usually act immediately after the phone call. But whoever followed up obviously got totally disconnected with the last person handling the matter. They seemed to have no record of previous communications. They asked the same questions we’d answered before, they double booked restaurants already booked, etc. 3) they made us pay for their mistakes! one restaurant on our list is quite pricy and upon reservation no cancellation is allowed. So we were very careful and highlight and bold counter seats only! If counters not ok we will not reserve! And Guess what, they booked a private room for us, which offered a totally different (and much less enjoyable) experience! 4) they are just too thoughtful... one restaurant on our list is an eel specialist. We emphasized that we would order natural wild caught eel. To our surprise, when we got to the restaurant we were served with farmed eel. The restaurant called the hotel to ask if something was wrong. Yes, it turned out they made a mistake. And guess what they told us? They ordered farmed eel for us for budget control. Ha, when and where did we ever mention budget?? If they were really so thoughtful and considerate, why not just offer to compensate us for the $$$ we paid for the their mistake in 3)? 5) they are not too thoughtful. One restaurant on our list we got the contact information from the chef. So we asked them not call until a certain time because we don’t want to appear abusing the relationship. Ha, they just called, not once but twice, way ahead of time. Nice job and proactive. 6) maybe they just have no clue? One restaurant on our list we have been to many times. The hotel we usually stayed at would point that out to the restaurant, so we were always able to reserve a good time slot. But peninsula just totally ignored this background we told them, and consequently was able to only reserved a very undesirable time for us. I suspect they ignored the background because they didn’t know it could help reservation. If this is the case, it just tells how unprofessional they are. If not, it only means they are either careless to detail, or careless of their customers, or both. 7) with all the disappointments, they at least offered a joke for us to laugh at... one restaurant on our list happened to have peninsula on their blacklist (we didn’t know when we made the list). Haha, of course they didn’t tell us about that. They just said they strongly discourage us to reserve for the restaurant because of unpleasant experiences other customers had before. Hmm.

You know you love a hotel when all you can think about is how to get back there. We only had two nights at this location but it was enough to make an outstanding impression. We had a standard room with a city view; it was huge compared to normal hotel rooms and with every amenity you can think of (and even some I had never experienced before, such as the valet box and nail dryer). Service was impeccable from the doormen to the bellhops, the front desk to the concierge. There were so many refined touches. We did two of the Peninsula Academy adventures and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. Our drivers stayed with us the whole time and became an integral part of the experience. Getting a city tour in the bespoke Mini Coopers was outstanding! I can't recommend the Academy enough and hope there are more experiences available when we return. A shout-out also to the door staff and concierge; we wanted to go someplace recommended by one of the drivers but didn't realize we needed advance reservations until the gentleman escorting us to the taxi asked us if we had tickets. We didn't, but the concierge was able to get us into an alternate location and we were off. That saved us a lot of disappointment if we had shown up with our young daughter and not been able to get in. Dining was also excellent; we ate breakfast in the lobby restaurant when we arrived and subsequently had room service. Food arrived quickly, was always freshly prepared, and the table set up beautifully. Location was also great; easy walking distance to Ginza, shopping, and restaurants. What else can I say other than we can't wait to return and are already planning a much longer stay next time. P.S. We also took the green Phantom Rolls Royce out - what a fun and unique experience! If you like exceptional cars, be sure to check out the vintage Rolls parked out front.

Occasionally one gets a situation where high expectations are met by an equally high reality. For us it was The Peninsula Tokyo. We had stayed at the The Peninsula Hong Kong a couple of years ago which set the bar high but we had never been to Tokyo before so there was the question of location versus other options. The Peninsula Tokyo scored exceptional high on the that, too.To start with location, The Peninsula is in Hibiya which is on the other side of the tracks from the famed Ginza shopping district but just opposite Hibiya Park and the Imperial Gardens. That is all properly swank. The interesting bit is Yarukucho (which you could argue is the true location of the hotel). This is the bit between the hotel and the Japan Rail and Shinkansen train tracks. This area is more down market but in the best possible way. The arches under the tracks are packed with local restaurants including a German beer garden and a couple of surprisingly good Italian joints.What this also means is the entire Tokyo subway and rail systems are right there. For transportation within Tokyo and beyond, the Peninsula is unbeatable.The Peninsula Tokyo is built on a surprisingly small parcel of land but they get a lot of goodness into it. Our room was a standard king but it included a large closet and dressing room to the right as you’d walk in and large bathroom with individual his and hers vanities, a soaker tub and a shower opposite that. The room is big enough to have a sitting area in addition to the bed. And - as a personal first - the room included a combo printer, scanner, fax machine which we did actually use.The hotel has a spa and indoor salt-water infinity pool. The pool is configured for doing laps and has a beautiful view of Hibiya Park and the Imperial Gardens. Like everywhere else is the hotel, the service is extremely attentive. And, similarly, the standards of upkeep are extremely high. We watched one afternoon as five staff members determined the best way to remove scuff marks from the walls.The concierge service was absolutely exemplary. Before we arrived, they helped us secure some difficult restaurant reservations. While we were there, they helped out with an emergency dental appointment as will as some further restaurant details. The late Anthony Bourdain may have disliked the typical concierge restaurant recommendations, but that certainly would not apply here.While the Peninsula Hong Kong has pads for all of its room controls, the Tokyo hotel makes do with slightly less tech-forward controls with physicals buttons. You can still adjust the lights and open and close the blinds from the bed so there is nothing wrong with that approach. The only tech complaint I have is that the the TV has a range of analog inputs but lacks the much more useful HDMI input.The Peninsula has afternoon tea in the lobby. It may not have the line of people waiting for a seat that you’d see in Hong Kong but it is still a nice selection of savoury and sweet. The only complaint is that it took about 45 from ordering to receiving our food.The basement has one of the two restaurants that serves breakfast. What’s really interesting downstairs is that you get to watch the bakers and the chocolatiers. The baked goods are very good and the chocolates - made from Valrhona and Callebaut chocolate - are exceptionally good.A family member has some specific nut allergies so there was a question about whether or not the chocolate truffles would be OK for him. We called room service who had the chocolatiers call us and, ultimately, one of them came to our room - with extra truffles - just to make sure our question was answered satisfactorily. That’s attention to detail.Combine all of the above with Japanese hospitality and an unbeatable location, there is little to negative say about The Peninsula Tokyo.

Been staying here for 2 nights. The staff are super efficient and polite and nothing is too much trouble. The rooms are spacious and the beds super comfy. Excellent free internet too and we have 10 devices between us and no noticeable reduction in bandwidth. The bathrooms are nice and spacious too and great water pressure. The Japanese "do it all" toilets never seize to impress me. The gym has all the latest Technogym equipment and the 20M pool is long enough for me to do my laps. I would come here again. It is all I want from a hotel.

Stayed here for the 2 nights for the first time. Location is perfect as it’s walking distance to the busiest Ginza shopping district. A few subway & JR lines are easily accessible & basically lead you to everywhere in Tokyo .The room is spacious, with a huge walk in wardrobe,elegantly furnished & even there’s a Lavazza coffee maker. The staffs are extremely friendly especially those at the entrance,always greet you with a big smile whenever you approached. Definitely it is a super enjoyable & great stay , hope to stay at this hotel again soon during my next visit to Tokyo!

Hotel was very nice! Rooms were spacious, housekeeping did an Amazing job! Breakfast was tasty!l but coffee needs to be with Japanese standards! Location was greaaaat in Ginza with in walking distance good restaurants, coffee shops! Shopping malls and a park!Highly recommended.

I want to quickly share that this is perhaps the best hotel I have ever stayed at. What sets this hotel apart is the stunning level of personal service. If you are visiting Tokyo and want a sublime and luxurious stay with impeccable service, this is your place.

Stayed 4 nights at this magical hotel with the family.. Truly world class service. Rooms were beautifully done. The pool and jacuzzi were fabulous. Enjoyed the gym. Great location for walking around the Imperial Palace and access to the Ginza. I can't think of any hotel that I have ever stayed at that presented itself this well with uniformly impeccable service.If I was going to really nit pick, I would say that they could resupply the free sparkling water each day, rather than just provide that once at the beginning of the stay. Also, a couple channels in English on the TV would be greatly appreciated to be able to access when on the exercise bike. Except for these trivial items, this is one of the rare examples of getting what you pay for. Expensive, but really on top of their game.Finally, truly enjoyed the Japanese breakfast and other meals eaten at the hotel. Beautiful presentations and great flavors. Also, the flowers in the lobby were off the chart gorgeous.

We've stayed at the Peninsula a few times. I would not consider any other hotel in Tokyo. The location is perfect, within walking distance to many attractions and amazing restaurants. I especially love the fact that the hotel is not in the middle of chaos. Very quite at night, although I suppose for some people that's a negative, but you are only a few blocks away from vibrant nightlife. Best of both worlds. Staff are impeccable and helpful. While rooms could use some face lift, they are sizable and clean. I love the view of the imperial palace in the mornings. Concierge is what really knocks it out of the park. They are incredibly helpful and their suggestions are always spot on.My favorite thing to do at the hotel is using their gym, which is next to the pool. After a good work out, hit the steam and sauna rooms. Very relaxing and I've never seen more than another person in the spa. It's almost as if you have the entire place to yourself. I highly recommend the Peninsula Tokyo.
user_name:
JayC327
New York City, New York

review_body: Stayed four nights, two rooms, in this lovely, first class hotel. Both rooms were huge, beautiful and incredibly comfortable. Elegantly simple decor and every amenity possible, including valet box. Staff in all departments were polite and pleasant, smiling, and spoke very good English. Dined for breakfast and two dinners at hotel, VVG. Location close to Imperial Gardens and Ginza, quick taxi ride to many other sites and restaurants. Loved our stay here, would positively stay again!

Elegant well maintained hotel with friendly atmosphere. The breakfast area is a little odd located in the basement level but ala carte is available in the lobby area . The central rail station is close by.

The hotel is well located near the Imperial Gardens and Ginza. It is convenient especially for person who love jogging. Imperial Gardens is one of best jogging path at Tokyo. After completion of jogging, bell boy at lobby will try their best to give me two things (towel + water). It make me to feel that every jogging are perfect. Thank you for all lovely peninsula bell boy.My suite was very spacious and stylist with wonderful views of the Imperial Gardens. It is one of best hotel stay in the world. The bed is superior comfortable, the bathroom and dressing room area is great. The service is perfect at this hotel. One of the best breakfast choices is white egg omelette in the lobby. I really do not try this before around the world. It is must try item. There is my wedding anniversary stay at 2019. It make my wife to have unforgettable memory. This is the most important. You do it for me. Thank you for Peninsula Tokyo. If possible, I would like to visit this hotel every year.

Honestly, I almost cried when I had to check out after a 3 night stay. The hotel just wows you in every way. Let’s start with the check in where the staff makes you feel you are the only one that matters. Then there are the rooms which are bright, clean and very spacious...and I work for a big bank which negotiates a pretty low rate. I can only imagine what the higher priced rooms must be like.How anout the fitness center? I went down to the 6th floor to use it and - wait - there’s an indoor olympic size pool right there overlooking the city! Of course, the fitness facility is ample and immaculate.How about I tossed my shoes in the valet box to be cleaned, and they replaced the laces and made the shoes look brand new?And then the location is perfect....I could go on and on.....Let me say that a place like this just doesn’t happen. It really is a credit to the hotel management and staff for taking pride in the quality of their work and making just an average guest feel like an emperor!

We stayed here for three nights after a cruise, and the property did not disappoint. High end service from the moment they opened the door of our cab and escorted us to check in. Despite the fact that we presented ourselves at 9:30 in the morning, not only did they upgrade us to a magnificent suite, but it was ready for us and we were immediately escorted to the suite. Our luggage had already been delivered to the suite, and the suite was HUGE, with a living room with two walls of glass, facing the Imperial Gardens and Palace directly across the street. The separate bedroom area featured a large bedroom, a large dressing area with closets, and well appointed bathroom with the fully automated Japanese heated toilet/bidet, large tub at the window, and a serious rainfall shower with almost too much pressure. There was also a guest bath that we never used. The bed was extremely comfortable, with high end linens. Breakfast was included, and we took it at the lobby restaurant all three days, and the meal and service were excellent. They also have a relatively new program for suite guests that gives you access to two Mini Coopers with driver on a first come first served basis, for up to three hours per day for each day of your stay, between the hours of 9:30 am and 7:30 pm. We used the service on one day for transportation to the Robot Restaurant show, which would otherwise have been a $50 taxi ride. There are several restaurants and a bar on property, all on the expensive side. We had two cocktails at Peter's Bar on the 24th floor, and by the time the various taxes and service charges were added, it came to $48. At least there were tasty bar snacks. This is a very expensive property, but when you stay there, you do feel like you have arrived.

This hotel remains remarkable and terrific. Always superb service and the rooms are stellar. Full of cool services and gadgets. The lobby is a scene and the restaurant on the roof has one of the bets views of the Imperial Palace and grounds in Tokyo. Lobby tea is a tradition even here in Tokyo. Great location

This hotel concierge service it’s the best in the world. You don’t need to worry about anything. They have the answer for all your questions and they can arrange anything around Japan for you. I was impressed with their ability to make things work for you. The room have no doubt it’s the most comfortable and luxury you will ever find in Japan. My favorite hotel there for the 10 days that I spent. It’s worth the price you pay for it.
