this is a wonderful hotel.the reception area was prompt and ever so polite.the concvierge was spot on for all of our pretrip questions and requests.they met us at our ship disembarcation promptly and with just the right size vehicle.they accomodated us with a guide and car and even in adding an extra couple to afternoon tour and change of vehicle.We were upgraded thanks to Andrew Harper to a beautiful corner suite.separtate living room with dining area...half bath...gorgeous bathroom 2 separate sink areas with plenty of room to spread out our his and hers incidentals.the toilet area was enclosed with one of those amazing japanese toilets.There was a big separate tub, and a big stand alone shower.there was a dressing room closet.the bedroom had a very comfortable bed and black out curtains.the view in the living room was excellent.Our last morning, my husband and i went to the big indoor pool area....so nice...had lounge chairs with a view outside..a big long narrow jacussi hot tub area, as well as a big pool...comfortable water temperature so we could swim laps before long flight home.We had cocktails and dinner later in Peter..a restaurant housed in a separate elevator area on the top of the Peninsula hotel...quite a modern and nicely done restaurant.they have excellent house cocktails during Happy Hour.the dinner menu is mostly grilled...served on really handsome blackstone plates.the steak is delicious and not huge portions.you can order "up" in the beef category i.e Waygu 1 2 3 or kobe.....there are several different side sauces...one can have fish too...they offer 3 and 4 course set menus.....quite nice lovely service,beautiful view, sparkling lights in restaurant...good wine.the bellman comes right on time check out is seamless ...good location near Imperial Gardens and upscale shopping.We were very happy there.

We stayed here for 5 nights and they’re all very pleasant. The room is big enough to have a lounge area, a separate bath/shower/toilet and a dressing room. This is just a standard room by the way. The ambience is understated luxury.Service was friendly and professional. They can also recommend restaurants to try. Breakfast was basic (western or Japanese) but well done which is welcomed after several days of traditional Japanese breakfast. It’s also nice that they occupy the whole building so they have their own driveway. Not that it matters much, especially if you are taking the subway mostly. It’s just nice.Last but not the least, it’s in a great, central location. So if you are the walking type (and weather permitting), it’s a great spot to start your journey to explore Tokyo.On your way out, you might even see their old Rolls Royce!

We really enjoyed our time in this hotel. It is in a great location in Tokyo and the rooms were very large and comfortable. The food was good too. Really, I think this hotel was a good stay, but that's about it. I think for the high price I was expecting something outstanding, and perhaps my expectations were a bit too high. I had also read many reviews beforehand which named this hotel as the best in Tokyo. Would I say it was the best in my opinion? Probably not. But is it a good hotel? Yes, definitely. I would recommend this hotel to people traveling on business, as I think it would be a comfortable stay. However, I think if you are visiting to explore Japanese culture and experience Tokyo, I would probably recommend a different hotel which incorporates the culture more.
user_name:
taylexvhors
New York City, New York

review_body: It’s a peninsula hotel but really very different and worth staying if you visit Tokyo The decoration is very much Japanese influenced.one immediately feel relaxed once he enter the lobby.the rooms are one of the best designed rooms I have ever seen.every thing is well planned from the room division to the dressing room and the very cozy bathroom very big .the house keeping is doing a wonderful job .the organize everything for you and it’s very clean.the service in the lobby restaurant is very good.and attentive.The only remark the hotel have no lobby the lobby is the restaurant and sometime one feel in a train station Otherwise it’s great.

When it's New Years Eve and hotel is running full house, you know they're obviously busy. No one should have expected the experience and service received to be any different from cookie cutter robotic business hotel because they're obviously busy. Even when it's extremely expensive but you did it anyway because it's the first trip you take your newly wedded wife on her birthday. But in no way you should have hoped it to be the highlight of the trip, because they're obviously busy. You contacted hotel in advance for restaurant recommendations and in-house dinner already fully booked, they'll still ask you again in standard pre-arrival email because they're obviously busy and it's not possible for them to talk to each other. Telephone in the dressing room was covered in sticky stuff and somebody's socks were left in the dark elevator landing area for over 2 days and you didn't bother to call them because they're obviously busy. So upon check out and you were asked how the stay was, you actually think it's ok because they're obviously busy and you don't want to make them busier. Nothing is wrong, people are just doing their own job minding their own business but not yours or their colleagues' because they're obviously busy.

Good service, big rooms, decent food, excellent location and wonderful spa. We had a great stay at this hotel for over a week, the staff were friendly and the concierge was very good at getting what we wanted!

This was the second time I stayed here for work. It's location is perfect for the Chiyoda Business District and if you fancy staying near Tokyo station / Ginza shopping district.The service is impeccable and the in-room dining is pretty good (lot of late night meals for me). Their flagship restaurant Peter was okay for me - there are definitely better fine dining experiences around central Tokyo.But all in all, if you want a luxury or business stay in Tokyo CBD - this fits the bill!

We just stayed at this beautiful hotel. The service was impeccable from all members of staff. Location - It was 3 min walk from the railway and 1 min from the subway lines so very easy to get around. The precinct has amazing restaurants and bars so it is always easy to find something good to eat. 5 min walk to Ginza shops in one direction and the imperial palace and quiet parks in the other. The hotel itself is luxurious we had a suite with a connecting room taking advantage of their current family package. The rooms were connected by a private hallway with an external door to the main hallway. Everyone talks about having park views but we were in a corner suite and looked out towards Ginza and the amazing Hermes building and we could watch the Shinkansen approaching Tokyo station - we liked this view a lot. The suite is very big, has a king bed with a desk and minibar, tv in bedroom, large bathroom with tub and 2 separate sinks on opposite sides, separate shower and Japanese toilet, Bulgari toiletries, tv and radio and we had Sakura scented bath salts during our stay. There is a huge walk in robe area with another desk/dresser with built in nail dryer and in the living space there is a third desk, dining table for four, lounge and built in espresso machine and minibar. There is also a separate toilet and vanity. The second room had 2 double beds and a couch that converted into a bed, same size bathroom and walk in robe. The rooms had bathrobes as well as traditional Japanese cotton robes. Amazing hotel, amazing stay. We arrived at the end of the Sakura celebration and ate breakfast up at Peters that weekend which was fabulous with views over the imperial palace. Breakfast on other days was in the foyer or down in the cafe area but we found in room dining a good option in the large suite.

If you are planning to make an advance purchase booking at this hotel beware of hidden extra charges. I just made a reservation for three nights in October and the form said the total amount was 163,680 yen. After I submitted the reservation form a message appeared saying the 'total' didn't include taxes and an occupancy charge. I thought I would be paying approximately £1,080 for three nights but when the extra charges are added it will come to around £1,357. In fact I still don't know the exact amount they've charged me. The extra charges are contained in the form but you have to click on terms and conditions to see them. I think it is very deceptive that the 'total' figure they give you doesn't include the taxes which are considerable and the taxes aren't clearly displayed during the booking process. Now I will be stuck staying at this hotel because the charges are non-refundable but the booking experience has given me a very negative feelings about the place and I'm definitely not looking forward to staying there.

We had an incredible room. Breakfast was amazing. Service and location were great. There is a subway stop under hotel. Carlo and the other concierges were efficient and extremely nice. Would go back!!

Centrally located across from the Imperial palace and city center. Superb service, large view room with living area, walk-in closet and large bathroom. The Japanese heated toilet seat is a nice touch. Hotel entrance is a little odd where one would have to pass through the center of a restaurant to get to the check-in counter. The music balcony over that restaurant/lobby entrance with live classical music is a nice touch.

Lives up to its name. Excellent service from porter staff to front desk managers. You get what you are paying for. Recommended highly, this uber place sits on a very good location, overlooking the Imperial Palace grounds, it provides easy access to the Palace Park, and all major shopping & food belts. The spa & indoor heated pool at L6 is a must visit for those stating here, and both restaurants at the Lobby & L24 provides uber excellent foods... I especially like the high tea at the Lobby cafe. Rooms are super comfy... i only wished they had provided me with an orthopaedic pillow that i had earlier requested... else everything is almost perfect. Will come back for sure

The hotel is amazing and offers big rooms in Tokyo. I didn't like the restaurant at the lobby cause it doesn't offer the comfort of privacy and also the menu of breakfast and in-room dining don't have much variety, but all the items are provided with high quality. The location of the hotel is also perfect, walking distance from Ginza street and a metro station in the basement of the Hotel.

This is my 3rd time at the Peninsula TOKYO. I requested a view on the palace, but didn’t get it. However, we had a good upgrade to suite with nice city view.The location is great. Hibiya station is just under the hotel. Ginza is very close as well.The service is great.Their lobby is so unique and would highly recommend the afternoon tea.Highly recommend!

Great property and an amazing location , across the road from the Imperial Palace and Ginza shopping right behind you . The service in the hotel is truly amazing . The room was big , clean and beautiful . The only draw back is breakfast is a set menu and bot a large portion.

I highly recommend the Chef’s Tasting Menu this week in the lobby restaurant. I had a very relaxing evening after a hard days work in Tokyo. Lovely to come in and enjoy the soothing sounds of the three piece ensemble that plays from the balcony overlooking the lobby. I suggest a nice glass of champagne and the tasting menu. A superb way to end the day.

We stayed here for 4 nights to celebrate a key birthday having not stepped foot in Japan before. We were very very pleased with the choice. There were so many to choose from and the cost of the high end means we wanted to decide well. Couldn’t be happier. The location is wonderful, the quiet end of the shopping strip but super close, great access to trains everywhere meant we were well connected. The staff were wonderful and very very helpful. The bar restaurant (Peter) has its own lift straight to the 24thish floor and is fabulous. Something in Japan we were to prepared for was the smoking indoors (which though we dont smoke we found unusual but it is just culturally normal here so we adapted of course without a problem - the restaurant was smoke free I think (certainly not an issue on the night we went). The rooms were exceptional, all the intriguing and beguiling features that Japan seems to have mastered in “better ways to live” and was superbIn all couldnt say a word against this place and at the end of our travels now, keen to come back to this hotel!

The Peninsula wowed me. From before our arrival (when the concierge got us reservations for Saturday night dining) to the warm and gracious check-in, the staff at this hotel bent over backwards to help us with every need. Moreover, our standard guest room was huge and beautifully appointed, a perfect place to find quiet and rest after a day of walking Tokyo. Breakfast (included in our rate) was abundant and the service was impeccable - including the understanding server who helped us discreetly change tables one morning when we were seated next to a loud and boorish fellow guest. The Airport Limousine bus has a stop here, making it convenient to Narita, and the location in Ginza is wonderful - subway access under the hotel and Ginza shopping down the street. Don't hesitate to stay here - this hotel is well-worth the rate.

Beautiful property with flawless service and a staff that goes out of their way to help. I must complement the Cecilia and the concierge team - at a time when the hotel was at full occupancy, during peak Sakura season, and the concierge team was most likely overwhelmed with requests, Cecilia and team always were there to help with a smile. Reservations, recommendations and advice - flawless.The location is very convenient - Ginza offers a wide variety of dining options within a few minutes walk of the hotel. The Imperial Palace is across the street and the subway can be accessed directly from the hotel's basement. Lots of taxis available as well, if that is your preferred mode of transport. The team at the door, guiding the taxis in - wonderful. The team welcoming you into the hotel - wonderful. Housekeeping - wonderful.It is difficult to find fault with any part of my stay - I could not recommend your property more highly to friends and colleagues. One of the best properties I have stayed at - ever.Thank you

We spent 4 nights and loved our time here. The lobby is beautiful and the service is first class. The rooms are large and lovely. Having the subway directly beneath the hotel was so convenient, as was the area in which the hotel is located. We would stay here again in a heartbeat.

We loved our hotel experience. The staff was across the board exceptional. The location is ideal. Sakura afternoon tea was amazing with live music in lobby. The room was beautiful. It is pricy but you get what you pay for

I recently stayed at the Peninsula Tokyo - it did not disappoint. This review is tremendously hard to write as I do not know where to start.First off their attention to detail is second to none. I was traveling by myself- which can be challenging as a solo female especially with a language barrier. Need not worry ! They were at the airport on time- the room as requested- was in a quiet location with a fantastic view of the IMperial Palace. ( I do recommend to pay extra for this)The lay out of the room breathes calm- much need after spending 2 weeks in the Philippines working. When traveling solo I order room service a lot- perhaps this is the only area for improvement. The hot items were warm- almost cold. Perhaps reviewing this may identify areas of potential change- I also experienced this at the Peninsula Manila which I had come from as well. Did not experience this at the Peninsula Chicago when I visited last summerOtherwise I highly recommend this property and especially want to thank Noriko Murata- Guest Relations Manager. She was very helpful with all details and I hope to visit again soon.

Unfortunately expectations not met.The hotel is in a convenient location for tourists (near Ginza/shopping/restaurants). Service was poor----my husband's breakfast plate taken away even though he was not done and there was still food on it, no turndown 1 of 4 nights, front desk misleading about room upgrade availability. Other personal preference points: décor could use an uplift, we prefer white sheets (sheets were yellow/beige), coffee maker was not nespresso.
user_name:
MiffysPillowBook
New York City, New York

review_body: I have visited Tokyo probably over 20 times in the last 6 to 8 years.It is however my first stay at the Peninsula Ginza.The hotel needs little introduction as it is a very recognizable brand.I will divide my review into what I really liked and what I think can be done better (my 2 cents worth).First lets go with what I liked about it......1. Location....it is really convenient it is near the subway. It is only about 5 minutes walk to Ginza. The locale quite and away from the hussle and bussle of Ginza.2. Service..... staff were polite and always smiling .... everything at your beck and call3. Rooms..... large well appointed. My wife loved the walk in closet and vanity table.... wanted to take it home...What I thought could be better (but it may not be possible)1. View...... We had an upgrade to a room facing the palace garden, but a large office block was right in front of us so we could only see the garden at an angle.2. Lobby...whilst the lobby is nice, it is does not feel grand in a way the Peninsula Hong Kong does. All in all , Peninsula is highly recommended for their service for those wanting to stay near Ginza but not right in the middle of it.

Everything about the Peninsula Tokyo was par excellent.From the fact that there was a waste-bin at every conceivable spot in the luxuriously-appointed and spacious deluxe room - at the writing desk, to the counter near the coffee machine, to the dressing table, at each of the two wash basins in the bathroom; the corner-facing angle that the shower head was positioned at (so one doesn't get splashed with cold water when first turning on the shower); to the nail-drying blower at the dressing table; to the safe positioned at eye-level and not at knee-level; to the walk-in dresser area with ample space for placing the luggage; and a level of prompt, specific service that was always calming and satisfactory.Massive kudos too to the high standard of service and always spot-on assistance by the Concierge desk which was always manned by at least four staff (which meant that you did not have to wait in line - as has always been the case in other top-notch hotels where the Concierge desk is usually under-staffed). I'd like to offer one small observation please though - I wish the casual dining area (for breakfast, all-day dining including high tea) was not positioned right in the (premium) lobby area. While I do understand that this is in keeping with the Peninsula 'buzz' and tradition drawn from the mothership Hong Kong Peninsula - I do hope that Management will re-consider this as I found this jarring, especially when walking in from a long, tiring flight. Thank you otherwise, Peninsula Tokyo for a very memorable stay - including extending additional assistance to accept our baggage transfer upon our return from Kyoto, for our pick up enroute back to Haneda to catch our flight, even though we were no longer guests at the hotel. We will be back!

This was our first stay at a Peninsula property and we are sold! They are the definition of 5-star luxury. The staff is so attentive and responsive to any question or need. We stayed in a deluxe suite. The

Stayed 2 nights with the family. Very impressed. The view is outstanding. Perfect location. The service was excellent. The room is very nice with the comfortable bed. Very nice pool and gym. Hope to come back

Love this hotel and want to return here each time. Fascinating view, beautiful lobby (more seats can be fine here), lovely restraunt (breakfasts can be more reach, but it’s fine too), huge rooms with a great bathroom with TV sets and baths and showers the same time

The Peninsula Tokyo, like any other Peninsula Hotel, prides itself with the excellent service, spacious rooms and a wide selection of amenities. The deluxe room that we stayed in was beautiful, with spacious interiors and beautiful furnishings. The bathroom was also expansive with intelligent lighting controls and even a spa mode that enabled spa music for relaxation. Service from all of the hotel staff were faultless. I special mention to The Concierge staff and also Sofia at the front desk who all provided top notch service throughout my stay. The lobby of the hotel is beautiful however it does get crowded at times. The pool and spa facilities were luxurious and had views of the imperial gardens which we definitely enjoyed. The hotel is located in the heart of the city in Ginza, and nearby many shopping sites and famous restaurants. Overall our stay at the Peninsula was a memorable one and would definitely consider coming back in the future.

Having been to numerous Peninsula properties around the world, I was impressed with the level of service and appointment. There are many standard features - a truly phenomenal afternoon tea, room controls, and communications equipment. I stayed in a Premier Room that was much larger than I expected for typical central Tokyo rooms. I had a large bath with unique dressing room area. Views were spectacular from the 32nd floor. I walked through the park across the street on numerous occasions and took the subway (which has a station connector in the lowere level of the hotel) to many points around the city. Morning breakfast upstairs was very impressive, with large selection of global foods.

I am staying here now for work. My room is lovely (I was upgraded to a suite with a small lounge dining, dressing room and a wonderful bathroom). Went for a walk around the area as I was jet lagged. It’s a fabulous shopping area, very safe and really interesting. Had room service and the food (I ordered Chinese) was excellent. Service here is great, and the hotel feels small even if it isn’t that small. I have a nice view over some parkland and the city but in the other direction is a bustling shopping area that goes on for ages. I had a car collect me at the airport and they sent a Tesla which was nice. The only thing I would watch is the cost of pick ups etc using hotel cars, which can be really really really high. I like this hotel and unlike lots of other places I stay for business would consider staying here with my family if we did a Tokyo city break in the future. There are virtually no snacks in the room (but for seaweed crackers) which is great for me as I hate the temptation. There is a minibar with beer and sodas etc though. The TV channels are quite limited to Japanese local ones and a couple of news ones (CNN) but with WiFi being excellent here that isn’t a problem with Netflix.

The Pen sets the level quite high in Tokyo with a timeless decor and all the attentive service and well thought amenities you might think of. The Deluxe room is glorious with a decent view of the skyline. The Peter is an amazing bar and restaurant. Location is perfect to enjoy central areas such as Ginza, Yurakucho and the Imperial Palace surroundings. You feel warm welcomed and though the classic decor is a very nice attribute, the true jewel might be the flawless hospitality of the staff!

Great atmosphere, great location. (Walking distance to GINZA!!) I love the spa they have, Great service, The high tea or breakfast/brunch at lobby is exquisite. Lovely room, very relaxing after a busy day in tokyo.

They have thought of everything in this hotel. From the woman spinning the revolving door at the front entrance to the impeccable front desk staff, everything here is just polished. The room we stayed in was the best hotel room we have ever stayed in. The bed was amazingly comfortable and having the separate dressing room is lovely. The bathroom is perfect (the toilet seat even closes itself). I can't wait to come back to Tokyo to stay here again.

The Peninsula Tokyo is everything you would expect from the hotel brand. Rooms are beautiful and comfortable, service is unparalleled, and the location is great for shopping and restaurants. Fantastic option for business travel and Tokyo’s finest city hotel.

“The Peninsula stays” for us around the world is always a treat. Having stayed here in the Summer, we had to return despite higher charges during New Year.  Many reviewers have already commented on the excellent location, big room size, good service.  For us, it was the small unexpected gestures that showed the hotel staff serves from the heart. Every time whether in Summer or Winter, after our run round the imperial palace, we are always greeted with a towel and a bottle of water at the entrance. My children were pleasantly surprised at their new year’s gift to us which consisted of sake, Japanese sweets and an ornament with explanation. We also found the soft toys of our kids humorously arranged on their beds when they returned to their room. They were so overwhelmed with the gesture. The hotel provided facilities to view the first sunset in 2018 and sake and soft drinks during the viewing, it was lovely and tranquil.  Congratulations to the Peninsula staff for upholding your standards of service.  Very hard to pick another hotel to stay when we are in Tokyo!

On arrival the front desk staff were unable to issue us with a key due to the system being down, this was frustrating given that we had literally travelled around the world and were exhausted, however other than that, the hotel was spot-on with everything else!!The rooms are very well equipped and have a great spacious configuration. Everything is immaculate and feels, well “chic” is how I would describe it. Staff are amazingly friendly and eager to help.

Great location and service. Next to a park and right in ginza. Close to all shops and good restaurants. Best choice for business and leisure travel. Would highly recommend to anyone. Great swimming pool too.

With so many excellent hotels in Tokyo, everything put aside this is surely one of the best without a doubt. This being my 3rd time to Tokyo, I have stayed at a few different 5 star Luxury hotels and I have to say that this is one of my top 3 favorites. Tokyo is such a big city so location is always important to me however this is a solid central location in the city and the stay was nothing less than exceptional. Our room was so graciously upgraded upon checking in (we used an Amex Platinum as well) and the room was on a high floor with excellent views of the city with the Tokyo sky tree off in the distance. The room was nice and clean and the staff was so friendly and helpful wherever you went. The breakfast downstairs is also a great choice and I never went wrong in the 3 says we stayed. I would definitely recommend staying here at The Peninsula when visiting Tokyo for a genuinely comfortable, and luxurious stay. A stay you wish you would be enjoying longer upon checking out!

As a business man , Tokyo brings all the advantages of a city without the inconveniences, the Peninsula is where you like to be.Luxury, peaceful, soft ,warm.Well located, amazing staff, what about the concierge desk? Well ask them anything they find it for you from the classic indigo fabric store but not touristic stores, to a good restaurant. From a tempura one to the Robuchon s one !Rooms are perfectly designed with two separate doors with the corridors so not a sound can be heard ,Great and fully equipped bathrooms,Efficient room service, Every thing worth the price.Restaurants on the top floor ( not a must ) Thousands of restaurants I Tokyo Coffee shop is perfect, so to me it’s quite enough with very good food.It’s just great to be close to perfection and be humble and customer oriented.A very special place.Not show-off but perfect .

we stayed 4 nights in peninsula tokyo and had the best experience on all levels: rooms really stylish and confortable, great selection of movies, pool and vitality pool great, concierge very helpful and staff seems to genuinely care about its guests.

Pro: Beautiful Hotel, Bar, Lobby and roomGreat location for shoppingAttentive and courteous staff (check in, concierge, bell, housekeeping, Peter Bar)High tech spacious roomsCons:Shower alternated between very hot and cold every two seconds which was irritating and uncomfortableBedding could have been better (mattress also a bit hard)Not a big thing but would expect a hotel like Peninsula to have an iron and ironing board in the room but I had to call for one.Not sure if too high tech but could not figure out how to set the temperature in the room. The gadget just had button for hotter or colder and air speed but did not say what temperature the room was set at.1800 Y for a beer at Peter BarEnjoyed my stay at Peninsula Hong Kong better then Tokyo location

This was such a marvelous and a magical stay at The Peninsula. The hotel really made our stay a memorable one!! The room was really spacious. To me, I think they should be called junior suite rather than a deluxe room! The dressing room is also spacious and can fit so many luggages. The staff are absolutely the best. Helpful, kind and very respectful. The location is the best in Tokyo. It is right in Ginza and only steps away from the word’s best shopping destination. I really loved everything about the hotel and will not even think about booking a different property.

My husband and I stayed at the Peninsula Tokyo at the beginning and end of a two week trip to Japan. The room was wonderful; we had a sitting area as well as a large walk-in closet and large and beautifully appointed bathroom. The service was impeccable. The staff was extremely gracious and helpful. The location is great if you don’t have pre-booked dinner reservations. There are many great places to eat within two blocks of the hotel. The concierge recommended a sushi place which was a 5 minute walk and was delicious. Would highly recommend this hotel.

Great business hotel. The service is great and the rooms are excellent too. They are big and the beds are comfortable. The gym is a little small, but still nice. And they have a pool. The breakfast is very good. Did not like the bar on the 24th floor, due to the fact it smelled like cigar smoke.

One of the nicest hotels anywhere. A beautiful, elegant and well-designed room. There is a separate walk-in closet and a very large sitting area. The bathroom is luxurious and has all of the most modern amenities. For swimming pools with scraps the nicest urban hotel pool we have ever seen. The staff is helpful and gracious. The hotel helped to make her stay in Tokyo a memorable one.

This was our first stay in any Peninsula Hotel, and we were totally impressed - comfort, stellar service, the quality & comfort of the room, its furnishings and accessories. A total win! We also want to call out the amazing help and kindness from the concierge team of Cecilia & Rika - they really went the extra mile to make our visit special.

This hotel was really elegant and sophisticated!It had a beautiful rooftop bar with good views and nice drinks .., always very full so make sure to make reservations!The restaurant at the lobby had beautiful piano music all day long which made it a perfect setting for tea time , lunch or dinner ! The rooms where nice and big !The only thing that can get better would be breakfast because options are limited!Location is great
user_name:
Erika F
San Jose, Costa Rica

review_body: First class accommodations. The rooms are amazing. Quiet. Great views. Large and clean. For our first time to Japan it was truly amazing service. At one point I felt guilty as I leave things untidy and when we came back to the room our clothes were neatly folded and all of our toiletries were meticulously arranged. The bar and the top was really fun at night. Japan was beautiful. The people were lovely and this hotel was a terrific part of the experience.

Very very good hotel, top service.The food is really good! Great view and the location is absolutely perfect. Excellent rooms, but I really don’t like the smell of perfume when you are inside the hotel.......

We really find this to be an exceptional hotel. Our corner suite had sweeping views of the city and palace grounds, very large, and perfect in ever way. There is a big dressing room and a great bathroom as well. The gym is very good as is the room service. The location on the edge of Ginza is so convenient. The staff staff is unfailingly helpful.

Had a lovely stay at the Peninsula. The location is particularly convenient to most points in the city, close to trains and subways and shopping. My room was small (expected for a hotel in the city) but thoughtfully laid-out which made for a comfortable stay. It also had a lovely view so I would recommend trying to book a room on a higher floor to take advantage of this. Breakfast at the hotel was top notch, as well. The roof bar is pretty hilarious, extremely garish but serves a perfectly fine cocktail.

I have made at least 5 trips to the Peninsula but have not taken the time to review. However, after this visit and another wonderful experience it is time to do so. Arrived at 3:00am and there was hotel staff there to greet me and complete the check in experience in my room. Room service, valet and the overall experience at this hotel has been and continues to be the very best!!

As my important guests stayed at the Peninsula Tokyo, I had a several chances to use their cafe, and also to be able to see how they welcome the guests at the time of check in and so on but I really felt uncomfortable being with their low standard manner. The Peninsula is one of the most luxury hotel groups in the world and the staff working their should have pride serving to their guests with warm hospitalities but most of staff in Tokyo seems to have only pride without any hospitality spirit. No smile, no warm responses to the requests by the guests and so on. As one of the most prestigious hotels in Tokyo, I really felt regret with not well educated staff members. Even a Japanese guest relation manager seems that she does not know what is "Hospitality from the heart" in the service industry. The location of hotel and its design is superb!

Best hotel in Tokyo in my opinion. Very clean and have excellent service. I've stayed at other 5 stars hotel in the neighborhood and certain things doesn't comes to what this hotel have. it is located in a prime location, 10 minutes walk to the Palace, 5 mins walk to a train station. many variety restaurants and shops nearby. Hotel have different restaurants within and a chapel.
user_name:
AST1127
New York City, New York

review_body: The Peninsula has an excellent reputation and we saw it for ourselves during our 3 night stay. We also stayed at the Four Seasons and were disappointed after our experience at the Peninsula. Make sure you take some time and enjoy the pool too.

The Peninsula in Tokyo is everything you expect from the chain but the service, in particular, goes above and beyond. We brought Omiyagi (souvenirs) from the US for our friends in Japan. Airport security in the US is not fond of wrapped gifts so we did not wrap them before arriving in Japan. We asked the hotel to help and they sent someone to our room, picked up the gifts, wrapped them and returned them to our room a short time later. This is the sort of service that endears one to a hotel and we cannot wait to return.

I stayed here with my family last Christmas and it was absolutely beautiful. The location is good, great and spacious rooms (we were given adjoining rooms) and the service was exceptionally excellent as well. I hope to stay here again someday, it was just luxurious and wonderful.

The Peninsula corner suite I stayed in with my mother was divine - with a telescope for a close up view of the imperial palace. We used the spa for the best pedicure I’ve ever had in my life - a special French technique that polishes nails with mother of pearl for shine without varnish. It’s expensive but well worth it. Peter (the rooftop bar) was fun too.

Can't say enough about this hotel: well located, beautifully decorated and designed; service is outstanding. The hotel is located in Ginza- where you want to be if you're staying in Tokyo. Tokyo is like New York City on steriods. Luxury shopping at every corner, high end vertical malls sprinkled throughout the city. Phenomenal dining options within a five to ten minute walk from the hotel. Peter's restaurant at the Peninsula is also excellent (service and food) and the view and ambiance are gorgeous. The concierge staff is OUTSTANDING!! Two members of our group use a CPAP machine for sleeping. Distilled water is not readily available for purchase in Japan. The concierge staff ordered the water from Amazon and it was waiting in our room upon arrival and when we returned from Kyoto. The concierge team provided excellent suggestions for shopping and dining. Make sure you take the Japanese card telling taxi drivers to return you to the Peninsula Hotel as most drivers do not speak English and do not recognize the English name Peninsula Hotel. Downloading Google Translate is a must for travelling in Japan. The hotel lobby is beautiful and houses the dining area where you will enjoy delicious breakfast, High Tea, etc. On a cool day, the breeze from the front door can be a little chilling. Service is professional and very friendly. Two thoughts to improve breakfast service: training staff to refill coffee cups and milk and to deliver toast (hot) with the egg order, rather than coming out separately. The rooms are elegantly appointed and extremely well laid out. Our bathroom had two separate and spacious vanities (his and hers). Great make up mirror, great lighting, separate toilet and shower, big soaking tub. There is a large separate make up and closet area. King size bed and linens were very comfortable. Sofa, small table and chairs, coffee and tea machine included. We loved the intelligent layout and comfort the room provided after a long day of sightseeing. We're glad we splurged on The Peninsula. Worth every yen!

There is nothing negative to say about this hotel. It is lovely, tasteful, and elegant. More importantly, the staff are wonderful! From the doorman/woman to the front desk to the concierges, from the wait staff to the maître d’s to the housekeeping staff, we found nothing negative to say about our experience at the Peninsula. We have travelled quite extensively, notably India last January/February, and the level of service at the Peninsula is equal to the fantastic service we received throughout our stay in India (which ranked “over the top”). Japan is exceedingly expensive. At the Peninsula, we absolutely got our money’s worth. Highly recommended!!

Having stayed at the Peninsula Bangkok a couple of times my wife and i are partial to the way the Peninsula does things so this time we decided to try the Peninsula in Tokyo. We were not disappointed. From the fine amd helpful staff all the way to neat little touches like the cloth wrapping for the returned laundry and the sensor light in the bedroom it was classic Peninsula class all the way. We utilized the free Clubman limo service for 2 days and the driver/concierge Ryota Tsuchida san was particularly knowledgeable about the spots and attractions that the locals went to like Kapabashi and Ameyoko. He was also particularly patient and helpful. The lounge restaurant was a bit small but food at breakfast was ok.Rooms were pleasent and very large(especially for Tokyo) and housekeeping staff cheerful and helpful. All in i would not hesitate giving the Peninsula Tokyo a "high five" star especially considering its great location in Ginza.

My husband, baby, and I spent four nights in the Deluxe Suite of the Peninsula Hotel recently. It was a great first experience for us and we had a great view of Hibiya Park and the Imperial Palace. Unfortunately, the bathroom window faced an office building so we never opened it, but it was just something that could not be helped. Prior to arriving at the hotel, I was in contact with the concierge service about itinerary suggestions and they really came through with some great activity recommendations. They even helped us make reservations for a meal at the Kabuki-za. I was very worried about traveling with a baby but the staff at the Peninsula made my stay very easy and enjoyable. They provided great baby amenities (including a baby cot, bath tub, high chair, bib, and baby toiletries) and were very helpful in procuring a babysitter that sat for a few hours while we went to see a Kabuki performance. The housekeeping and room service team is amazing and made sure to leave a beautifully made up room everyday (sometimes twice a day). We couldn't eat at the Kyoto Tsuruya because children under 12 are not allowed but I did order one of their lunch boxes to the room. I highly recommend it! Unfortunately, the mini Cooper was never available when we needed it but taxis are always at the front door. The staff at the door and the concierge is very helpful in figuring out directions and I was provided with a detailed map and information on restaurants and other activities that we would do while at the Peninsula. Like others have mentioned, the lobby is a bit crowded and can be a little loud but did not bother me at all. The valet box was a great amenity and we used it often with laundry and receiving the newspaper. The Peninsula even helped me with sanitizing our baby bottles. I would definitely stay here again!

I've always associated Peninsula for dated obnoxious. I was so wrong.The Peninsula service is impeccable the moment you stepped in. The front desk staff will personally escort you to your room upon check in. And nothing is too much trouble for the concierge. When we asked for direction to the Hibiya station (which is located just at the basement of the hotel), the staff personally walked us to the station and even showed us how to buy our train ticket. Now that's service ! We wanted to print our tickets at the business Centre and instead, the staff suggested we forward via email to her for printing and she even helped us checked in! Wow Peninsula Tokyo is luxurious by Japanese standard. The room is equipped w spacious dressing room, separate lounge area, and a dainty dining table that gave an amazing view of the tokyo. Local restaurants, cafes and convenient stores surround the hotel and gives your ultimate flexibility when you're hungry or craved for a midnight snack In fact, you have all shopping needs fulfilled as the hotel is located amongst top brand stores, malls. My only gripe - dislike the sofa in the room that sink the moment you sit and sofa cushions smelled of dried perspiration.Otherwise, it's with a heavy heart that we check out of Peninsula. Thank you for the wonderful experience.

Incredible service that the Peninsula is known for in the heart of Tokyo. The rooms and amenities are very impressive as well as thoughtful. Loved booking through Fine Hotels & Resorts program. The standard for a traditional luxury hotel!Cons:-Restaurant when you walk into the lobby is quite strange and makes the whole space less impressive than it is- technology is a bit dated in the rooms and should come into the digital age-rooftop bar has a stunning view and a great happy hour, but it is quite dated and looks straight form the 1990s, was very smoky as well -overall very stuffy feeling, so don't stayif you like more modern relaxed luxury

Impeccable service from greetings to housekeeping and getting u a taxi.The hotel is very thoughtfully designed to impress and please the senses and satisfy all human comfort. Staff speak fluent English and are always ready to go the extra mile.Would definitely want to come back.

My visit to Tokyo started with the Rolls Royce experience. Driving from Narita airport to the hotel in luxury, and getting checked in from my room. The suite was amazing. Dressing room, bathroom, lounge and bedroom. Exceptional service in all respects. I used the laundry service to get my shoes shined. It got collected in 2min, and returned about an hour later.Breakfast in the lobby was also great. Try the Peter bar on the top floor for great views.

Absolutely amazing hotel set within 5 minute walk to the main Ginza shopping & dining district. Check in was spectacular as we were escorted straight to our room from our Tesla limousine and the staff went out of their way to make us feel welcome. The breakfast was not a buffet but it was still sufficient for us to start our day. Also, this hotel is connected to the Hibiya train station which is connected to the main Ginza subway station. Truly an iconic experience!

It's very rare that a hotel owns the whole building in the heart of Tokyo. The building connected to the Tokyo metro, although the sign of the entrance is not very easy to find when I first got there. They got one of of the best spa facilities in the would.

Staying at the hotel is a wonderful experience, where the service is second to none. Everything is done to make your stay a relaxing, stress free experience.We were collected from the airport in a Peninsula Hotel Rolls Royce, which glided effortlessly through the traffic! We were greeted at the door like old friends and escorted to our room, where the paperwork was done for us while our cases were put into our dressing room.Your room is a comfortable haven, where laundry is magically removed from the 'laundry cupboard' and returned immaculately presented the next morning in the same way. Effortless!

This was my first stay at this hotel after usually staying at another 2 blocks over. I'm glad I made the change. Staff were very welcoming, and the whole place felt fresh and luxurious.Rooms were huge. Other than the normal bedroom and bathroom, there was also a large dressing room and a sitting TV area in the bedroom.Inclusion were we delivered and free wifi came with the room.Looking for an amazing place for an evening drink, head to the special lift that takes you to level 24 - reserved solely for a bar. Lovely place to take in a Tokyo sunset

Amazing hotel, service and food. Location is perfect for shopping. Happy hour at Peters on the 24th floor is also worth visiting at least once. High end and local food are available near by. Closer the the palace gardens. Would definitely stay here again.

After arriving by cab via Tokyo Station, the door-men opened our taxi door, took charge of our bags and ushered us into check-in. They even passed our names to the front office staff for check-in.Check-in was quick and staff very friendly and smiley. It sure is nice to be welcomed to a new home, even if it's temporary, with warm hospitality. We booked through the hotel and under the promo, had an auto upgrade. We were assured of an early check-in and our room was ready for us.We were brought up to our room and familiarised with the room's many technical features, nooks and crannies. Our room had a long corridor and with large toilet on one side and a walk in wardrobe on the other.As a frequent patron of the Peninsula Hotels, the room was very familiar; It had plush carpets, warm lights, strong technology usage, and comfortable beds. Our son's bed made up and ready for occupancy. Our single beds very comfortable and soft, and we knew we were assured of good sleep. The shared table in between our beds had electrical and USB charge points. It was also quite large and could accommodate both our magazines and books. The phone and room controls were on the middle table. There's also an option for VOIP calls if you wish to make calls overseas. Curtains, master room lights and climate controls all within easy reach. There was excellent wifi connection - fast and strong signal.There's a large TV hidden behind a flat panel. There's lots on-demand movies and cable TV. Fax machine for serious workers under the TV, and a DVD player for people intent on relaxing in the room, were provided. There are connection ports to link your computer or memory stick device to the TV.Lavazza coffee making machine and tea facilities were on hand. The drinks in the fridge are chargeable. There's comfy sofa with a good-sized coffee table. Immediately behind the sofa was a small table and a pair of chairs.Walking into the toilet area, you have a glassed-in rain shower on one side, and a glassed-in toilet on the other. The usual Japanese warm toilet seat with all the usual functionalities can be enjoyed. There is a separate his and her's sinks with separate magnifying-mirror for her. A large bath tub is but into the wall and the whole marble toilet was very swish.Face towels, hand towels and bath towels are provided. There are lots of amenities from sewing kits to toothbrush, combs and shaving kits to shower gels and moisturiser.On the opposite side if the main corridor is the walk in closet. Two racks line the left and right walls, while a large make-up area for the missus sat in between. You will find the safe in here, and there are Yukutas if you feel a little more traditional. Bedroom slippers are separately packed in light cloth bags. If you inclined to bath robes, these can be found in the toilet.Beside the front door is cupboard accessed by the staff to deposit your laundry or newspapers. If you see the green light on, you can open this cupboard from your room to retrieve your items.There's a nice gym on the 6th floor, together with an indoor pool. The crew here are friendly and will provide bottled water and a towel for you when you arrive.The Peninsula Staff are all well trained and very polite. They make an extra effort make you feel appreciated. On a side note, I did some laundry in the room, and as usual used the towel to wring the wet clothes. I promptly forgot to take out the clothes from the towel roll and it was taken away by housekeeping when they came to clean the room. I called housekeeping and they launched a search for the items. They found it, laundered it and was delivered by the Assistant Housekeeping Manager. I was elated to be reunited with my gym gear, and most of all for the effort the staff made to return my items back to me.The hotel is very central to the Ginza cross walk. 500m away is the Mitsukoshi and the main shopping street in Ginza. For shoppers, this is paradise.We would highly recommend this hotel. Look for specials online or on the hotel website. You will not be disappointed.

I have traveled all over and stayed at what I thought was a top hotel, but this one takes the cake of any! The room was huge with a huge walk in closet and the view was outstanding.The staff was top shelf with exemplary courtesy and attention to every detail! Even the staff outside calling for transport was the same. On a scale of 10...... 15!

Excellent location to the Ginza shopping and restaurant area,it's only take 5 minutes walking distance .Front desk area is not so big,so you will expect a long wait for checking in.The breakfast selection are not a lot of choices if your room rate is included for the breakfast.The room size is one of the biggest in Tokyo .Also the room rate is one of the most expensive in Tokyo as well.The service overall are very good.

I stayed in a Grand Premier Park room in June which had a spectacular layout with gorgeous views. The walk-in dressing room and bathroom were very impressive too. The bar & grill called Peter on the 24th floor is well worth a visit. The pool is amazing as well. This property is conveniently located in the heart of Tokyo's business district. What stands out most at Peninsula venues compared to other luxury hotels is the impeccable service from every level top to bottom and the Peninsula Tokyo does not disappoint. My only gripe is the set menu breakfast in the lobby which I found limited and underwhelming and the seating process was confusing. Overall, I can't say enough about the consistent, professional attention the staff provides. Truly a luxury hotel.

Outstanding as expected but points to noteSuperb location just off the Imperial Palace gardens makes the hotel great base in Tokyo. All the staff and service levels are well up to expectationsThe rooms are the usual Peninsula formula with fantastic bathrooms and walk-in closets (wish we had these at home!)Somewhat disappointingly we were on the 8th floor facing away from the gardens so our view was a rather close by uninspiring grey glass office building - suggest you ask for highest floor available rooms when booking to avoid thisThe lobby area doubles up as a breakfast and lunch restaurant. The breakfasts are therefore not buffet but are set menu alternatives which frankly are very limited and somewhat uninspiring for a hotel of this price and standardAt lunch they have rather pleasant live music from a balcony above the lobby but someone needs to ask the musicians to turn the volume down a bit as on occasions it is far too loudRecommend you book the hotel SPA well in advance (before you arrive) as it seems to be quite small for a hotel of this size with very limited availability of massagesOverall we have given it 4* as for the price we should not be making the above points

Unbeatable service, and as expected by The Peninsula standard!Checkin was quick and efficient. Room is spacious - huge walk in wardrobe, big bathroom with exquisite bath tub, shower etc, immaculate living room with a self automated coffee/hot water machine!Decor is towards the more traditional end, but comfortable.Service is top notch! Anytime, any day - from front desk, to house keeping and wait staff.In-room dining was just ok. Presentation could be improved - expensive also. I suggest eating out - some amazing eateries with amazing flavours.Location is prime - close to station, and next to imperial park.

Perfect room size, well maintained property, superb bathroom, very good location (walking distance to the train station and shopping area) and really nice city view Customer service needs improvement compared to our Ritz Carlton experience.

If there is a perfect hotel, this is it. It is beautiful, has a great location and impeccable amenities and service. You can see from the pictures I posted, the lobby is gorgeous. Check in was seamless and I had 4 rooms. The hotel is right across the grounds of the Imperial Palace.When you book, you should ask whether your room faces the Palace. You should try to get a room that does. Mine did not, but I had an unbelievable suite and I was very happy. Room 2112.We had breakfast every morning. They have great menus, both Japanese and Western. Some of the kids were adventurous and enjoyed the Japanese style and some were happy with eggs and bacon. But they had choices and the quality of the food was superb. You can walk to great retail areas in addition to beautiful parts of the city. We had afternoon tea and it was delicious and served with elegance not seen much anymore. The concierge services were outstanding.The bar upstairs has some spectacular views.Very animated and crowded with good energy.Drinks were fab. Can't miss it. It seems that locals go there for the food, the drinks and the scene. I'm hoping to return for the cherry blossom season next year. I wouldn't stay anywhere else.

Loved the hotel and the location. We stayed at the Grand hyatt Roppongi for the first half of the trip before heading to Kyoto and then Peninsula at the end. Peninsula notices all the small details on your preferences and makes sure your stay is flawless. The concierge Sachiko Ozawa, and manager Noriko Murata ensured we had an amazing fifth anniversary. The detail that stood out to us was the fact they knew we were coming from Kyoto and a typhoon was approaching and emailed us to inquire if we would like to take train back to Tokyo earlier and they would have the room ready. We will return to the hotel on our next vacation in Tokyo.

The Pen Tokyo has a waiting room for those who would like to fly by helicopter but because of severe regulation, they cannot use heliport for any guests. You can see the history of airplane and aviation in Japan. 24階にはへり用の待合室がある。いつ許されるか分からない、ヘリコプター離発着の日に向けて待合室もトイレもそして壁を飾る日本の航空史の写真も全てが一見の価値ありだ！

I stayed at the Peninsula for two nights with several colleagues for a work trip. In addition to staying at the hotel, we rented a private room on the 24th floor for our business meetings both days. Overall, I found the hotel dated and foul smelling. The biggest issue, though, is the atrocious service. I had to wait an hour before my car service to the airport. I asked for a table in the cafe on the main floor, the only air-conditioned space on a muggy August day. Despite the cafe only being about three-quarters full, I was told I couldn't sit down since I didn't have a reservation. Those tables never filled - they just refused to seat me, despite having been a hotel guest. I will not stay here again.

If I ever had the fortune of being able to design my own master bedroom, I would make it exactly like the Peninsula Tokyo. I loved my room so much that I could barely be persuaded to go explore the city. The only issue I encountered was a room service delay on a night I was particularly ravenous. Everything else was perfect. Incredibly quiet, great location for business meetings and sightseeing, and fantastic, knowledgeable staff.

My wife and I travel extensively worldwide, and love the Aman, Mandarin..., but also love the Peninsula in Hong Kong and particularly the Peninsula in Bangkok... The turn off began at checkin... you have to walk through the restaurant to check in.... no really what you want to do after a long flight... noisy, people watching... lots of tourist in shorts.. wow.Then, we were shown to our suite... next to the top floor overlooking the Imperial Palace...should have been fantastic, the floor plan was great..... but the room had recently been smoked in.. which was obvious.. ( when I asked the concierge she said she could not smell anything......) -the carpet, and furnishings just felt really old and worn out... .not in a good way as in history, but in a need a change... The views are great, and the location is really good...but why spend for a high end hotel, and feel a bit cheated... .. All the electronics are also dated... these were really leading edge in the 90's... but they feel almost comical in this day and age... (I feel for them, as I do not doubt it was very, very expensive to install in its time...).. note... this is not that different from Bangkok Peninsula , but because the rugs and furnishings are spotless and flawlessly clean and fresh, it is not off putting.To put this in perspective.. we were supposed to spend a week at the Peninsula, but we checked out early and moved to the Andaz, which is new, fresh and creative.. (I never thought I would be caught dead at a Hyatt. affiliate.. but the Andaz is a different approach and the design is flawless...the Peninsula could learn a few things from their approach.. ...)

I decided to make have a quick staycation here, primarily out of curiosity. Celebrating their 10th Anniversary this month/year, the Peninsula Tokyo has definitely made a strong impression as a luxury hotel in Tokyo. Staff at the main floor are extremely accommodating for the guests needs right upon arrival, and the condition of the lobby is kept as pristine clean as the first day it opened.Within the rooms, signs of wear & tear are few and sparse (such as chipped wooden corners). Additionally, they definitely have kept up with the times with everything being automated/remotely controlled, and providing additional small details around the room (humidity, outside temp (C/F), wind direction).In terms of setting benchmarks for luxury hotels, the Peninsula Tokyo definitely has set very high bars for room services, such as ice buckets constantly being filled, and turn down service.One of the hotels advantage, may also be its disadvantage: location. Since it's located very near the heart of a shopping district, expect large amounts of foreign tourists there for the sole purpose of buying and sightseeing. My floor had occasional moments of loud chatter out in the hall, where other guests were discussing where to go for the cheapest health supplements.I had a late flight departing the day after my hotel stay, so I decided to request for a late check out. After confirmations were made, I received an email request for more details regarding my flight departure time. Much to my surprise, upon check-in, they told me that I was granted my late check-out of 7PM the following day (my flight was at 11PM). I have to give the Peninsula group a big plus for this benefit, as it would save me the hassle of checking out, going back home, then going to the airport.Overall, I would definitely like to stay in the Peninsula Tokyo (and others around the globe) in the future, and very much so recommend this hotel to anyone looking to have a relaxing place to return to after a day in Tokyo.

The peninsula tokyo is for me the best hotel of tokyo ; the 5 star service matches with the beautiful and luxury room that i had stayed in . The swimming pool and the spa were absolutely extrordinary . One bad thing the buffet breakfast on weekend , no choice , so small but tasty . However , it really worths its price .

This hotel was organised for me by my clients and they could not have chosen better! Sumptuous luxury throughout. Really well located, comfortable bed for a weary traveller and very attentive staff. The bar has a wonderful collection of fantastic Japanese whiskers - but be careful, they are not cheap!

Excellent location near the downtown financial district and only 10min from Ginza. It's situated right near by the imperial park go you can also go for jogging in a safe environment. Rooms are usually bigger than normal Japanese standard. Food is excellent but gets a bit crowded during lunch tea time. What's best about this hotel is it's excellence in service level and quality. It's highly recommended and my favorite whenever I visit Tokyo!

The Peninsula Tokyo bills itself as one of the greatest hotels in the world but it falls very short of this. When we arrived (at correct check in time) the reception desk was completely understaffed and overwhelmed. The two rooms we had booked for the night were not ready and although I had previously requested interconnecting rooms (we were travelling with our young children) we were told we would be lucky to have rooms on the same floor. My husband had an important business call to make and asked if there was anywhere quiet he go since the rooms weren't ready - we were told he could "pay" to use the business centre even though he was using his own mobile phone and laptop... Finally we got one room and then the second hours later on the same floor but at opposite ends (we had booked this accommodation 6 months in advance, it wasn't a recent booking). The rooms were fine in size, but tired and the bathroom floor had hair all over it when we arrived - it hadn't been cleaned properly. In the late afternoon I took our kids to the pool but was told "family time" finished at 6 and they weren't allowed in - there was no one else in the pool. Check out was just as hectic, there were queues of people being told their rooms weren't ready... It's a very expensive hotel for very basic service and experience. Would not go back.

Asia hotels always out do service, quality, hospitality when you compare with the hotels in the west or even dubai.. I was simply amazed by all the services, attention to detail, courteousness or pleasant staff. This hotel management has defined white glove to another level. The room i had looked over the emperors park and it was pretty large for a room in Tokyo. Fantastic stay and highly recommend, although this is prob at the higher of price ranges, but worth every penny!
user_name:
Nycnls
New York City, New York

review_body: I recently stayed at the Pensinsula Hotel. I have to say that the level of comfort, service and quality of dining at this hotel was absolutely first class!From the time you walk through the revolving door into the impressive foyer and reception area, you are thoroughly spoilt!I was lucky to have stayed in room 2020, with perfect views towards the Imperial Palace and its moat fortifications and beautiful sunsets. If you get a choice or request you need to ask for a room on any floor no.20. I chose to take breakfast in the bakery cafe in the basement of the hotel and you can watch the staff creating cakes and pastries to die for and with perfection! Spoilt for choice, I chose fresh fruit and yoghurt, scrambled eggs to die for with smoked salmon and freshly baked bread. Coffee is unlimited and in fact I had to stop the staff bringing me more! I also dined in the Cantonese/Chinese restaurant which was again, first class. In room dining was also first class, miso soup, noodles and dim sum amongst my favourites. Close to the business district, shopping and sightseeing too.

Visited the Peninsula for a very short stay of one night after a Crystal cruise. Hotel is located in a business area of this busy capital. The service is unbelievable supreme and rooms are modern and a bit small. Incredible features in the bathroom, not seen in other hotels, such as a temperature controlled toilet. The hotels has a number of shops and restaurants in the lobby, the chinese restaurant has one of the most sophisticated Cantonese dining in Tokyo, with sweeping views of the Imperial Palace Gardens. Not to be missed. It also directly connects to four train lines from basement level one making it the most accessible luxury hotel in Tokyo. Surely want to return for a few days and enjoy so much this Peninsula has to offer.

Perfecly located in Ginza; the rooms are incredible... absolutely huge and ours had a great view over the imperial palace. The spa is great, the sauna and steam room areas are lovely (and totally empty). The pool area is a bit small, but there weren't many people there when we went. The lobby is also stunning. I think what really makes the difference here is the service, particularly some of the more experienced front office staff who were really lovely.

Excellent Hotel with great staff and amenities. My wife and I traveled to Japan on our own with airline and hotel booking help from AmExp Plat. The concierge staff at the Peninsula were exceptional prior to and during our 3 night stay. I had multiple emails with them on issues relating to train travel(I was anxious!), restaurant reservations, and Sumo Tournament tickets. They were incredibly patient and helpful and with a sense of humor. Great advice on train from Narita to Tokyo and help with train tickets to next stop. I cannot recommend them enough! Because we were doing a lot of train travel we took only carry-on size luggage and backpacks which made on and off the trains easier.

very nice hotel , very well proportioned rooms with large walk in dressing room. Hard to find fault with the hotel. I travel to Tokyo regularly for business and to date this is my favourite hotel in Tokyo.

Just checked out after 5 nights at the peninsula Tokyo which was the start of our honeymoon. We stayed at the peninsula in Paris last year and while that was a brand new hotel we were still excited to stay at another location in the chain and this one, although 10 years old, did not disappoint. As expected service levels were top notch and every request was tended to with pleasure. From the second we arrived it was a slight drizzle and the service team refused to let me walk outside without being covered with an umbrella. Check in was very smooth. I booked through Amex Fine hotels and resorts and while an upgrade would have been nice it is not guaranteed and the hotel was fully booked. This wasn't a problem as the entry level rooms were a great size - complete with a dressing room and full sized bathroom with double sinks. The bed was extremely comfortable and the room controls were very easy to figure out. It even had a small living space and dining table. The hotel is connected directly to Hibiya station which made getting around very easy and the concierge was very helpful in securing dinner reservations for us. They even got us a table at Sukiyabashi Jiro which is notoriously difficult to get (please note we had to put in the request about 60 days in advance)The breakfast included each morning was great which included a Japanese option, eggs (any way you choose), French toast, a basket of pastries, OJ and coffee. Great way to start the day. We dined at Peter bar on the roof when we arrived which had phenomenal views of the city. We also dined at hei fung terrace and had a delicious lunch - expensive but worth it. Overall the staff were very well trained and spoke perfect English and helped make a great stay excellent. In 5 star hotels the nice decor and interiors are a given but it's the small things that help differentiate. (eg always giving the guests the right of way when walking in the common areas of the hotel - waiters carrying full trays of food would refuse to move until the guest walked passed them first - even if we invited them to move ahead they refused)The champagne and chocolates in our room to celebrate our honeymoon was also a nice touch!Looking forward to our next stay at a Peninsula hotel

...and so the story continues with an upgrade from the Grand Premier room to the Marunouchi Suite on the 23rd floor - my goodness, fabulous! The suite had breath taking views of the empirical gardens and all the appointments to match - you can read about those on the website, but most memorable were the convenient outlet placements for our technology, two bathrooms, so no waiting, a wonderful dressing room with vanity, plenty of closet space, and mirrors, a soaking tub with garden views, climate control that was zone sensitive, a coffee/tea machine that was self-plumbing, mini-fridges in both the living space and bedrooms, tv's in bath, bedroom, and living room, plenty of space to chill. I was most impressed with the smart design, every detail seemed anticipated and accounted for - there was nothing that I imagined that wasn't already thought about and addressed - even the flat full length wall mirror that could be adjusted to a 3-D mirror - so smart.Everything was clean and fresh in aroma - room, public areas, restaurants, even the cigar bar. The location was superb, across from the Emperial gardens for touring or walking and easy walk to Ginza for shopping and dining.I enjoyed the well appointed gym daily, alone at 4:30 am each morning (jet lag issues). Didn't use the spa or pool, but peeked in at both, which were quite lovely. There was an outdoor terrace adjacent to the pool, which I wished that I had more time to explore.We had breakfast each morning in the lobby restaurant (included with our Amex FHR program) and service was swift, warm, and accommodating. The menu was varied enough to allow me to try and enjoy something different each day. We enjoyed cocktails most nights in Peter's on the 24th floor. I liked the environment and the staff there was excellent, but I do wish they had more quarters in the hotel for relaxation.Everyone, check-in staff, transportation, concierge, housekeeping, gym, made us feel welcomed, comfortable, appreciated, and cared for - No snobbery - very different from any US experience that I've had at a Peninsula. If you have the chance, run to the Peninsula Tokyo - it was worth every penny....I requested a taxi for departure and they sent us away in the Roll - so classy!
user_name:
Advourner
New York City, New York

review_body: The location is terrible, it is a hotel which came from Hong Kong.I like the hotel in Hong Kong very much.So it is a pity if I expect a bit.Eating, every restaurant is very expensive and delicious.I would like to go again if someone will pay.

Regarding the room service the Orange juice not fresh squeezed. Coffee stale and pancakes rubber. Both arrived cold. Yuk! The service itself at the hotel is good, it's just surprising since this is a four star hotel that the food would suck.

The Peninsula delivered beyond our expectations before we had even arrived. The concierge were fantastic. They made every effort to accommodate our restaurant requests. Communication was friendly, frequent and in the end, we were able to experience two fantastic dinners as a result of their efforts. Our room was lovely. Spacious and elegantly fitted. For those who enjoy fitness, there is a great run opposite around the Imperial grounds.

My stay at the Peninsula was the perfect to my business trip in Japan. Besides my works, convenient base for exploring Tokyo with a great location on the edge of the Imperial park. The room was spacious, and very well-appointed .Service was impeccable.I like the a-la-carte breakfast. Anyways, perfect hotel experience, highly recommended!

Our family of five stayed at the Peninsula for three nights in June. Two adults and three children and we reserved two rooms next to each other. This hotel pleasantly surprised me. I thought going into it the hotel would be more of a top end business hotel but at the end of the day the Peninsula delivers as a five star elegant hotel in Tokyo that is also family friendly. If you are a bit underwhelmed by the size of the lobby when you arrive you will be awed by the size, style and amenities in your room. The pool area is beautiful with great views of the city. Hotel is in great location just right outside of Ginza and connected to train station. Most importantly service at the hotel is top notch with everyone on staff very well trained...

The Peninsula in Tokyo is my favorite business hotel in the world. The rooms are big and clean and the service is stunning. They think of everything in this hotel and are never unfriendly when you need something. I can't recommend it more.

I love the Peninsula in Tokyo. It just oozes that old-school Japanese class and luxury that you really cannot experience anywhere else. Every time I travel to Tokyo I make sure to fit in a stay at the Peninsula. It is like you are transported back in time, it is almost magical.If you're looking for modern, sleek Tokyo then you will be disappointed at the Peninsula. But if you appreciate the old school glam, you will not be disappointed.The location is great, close to all the luxury shopping. They have complimentary limousine services for suite guests. We hitched a ride on the mini coopers a few times, but we also got to ride on the Rolls Royce Phantom a few times too which was a lot of fun. Its an experience being dropped off at Tsukiji market in a rolls royce!This time our suite was high-up and corner suite view of the palaces. I love the layout of their suite. It is discreet so that if you have guests over at your suite for tea, the bedroom, dressing rooms and master bathrooms are tucked away so that guests feel comfortable. The beds are fluffy, the amenities are Oscar de la Renta. The ceilings have the traditional tatami wood patterns but the room itself is in a way mid-century modern too. Its very artistic and architectural. Plenty of charging ports everywhere.Every day we were treated to fresh juices and the daily paper delivered to our suite. We had breakfast one day at the lobby which was included in our suite price. Their pastries are just TO DIE FOR. I mean to be fair, Japan has some amazing pastries but sometimes I dream of the Peninsula's croissants and danishes while I am back home in Toronto...... The Chinese breakfast was also quite nice with the congee and condiments and dimsum. It seemed no matter the cuisine they always got it pretty spot-on. Service was spectacular every single day every single encounter. They really know how to take care of their guests to make sure you are very comfortable. We had some intricate orders for our dine-in service (i.e. I was jetlagged and wanted plain congee and hot water on the side) and no matter what we ask for it is completed meticulously and perfectly done. Our Rimowa luggage wheel broke when we checked in very late at night and we asked the hotel if they could call Rimowa to fix the wheel. We were expecting this to be done sometime the next day or the day after, but literally the hotel called us in our room (discreetly, after precisely 15 minutes to give us time to unwind but not to fall asleep) to ask us if we wanted it to be done right away that night they would do so. I mean, that kind of service you cannot find anywhere in the world!!!!! The hotel totally took care of everything from scheduling the maintenance person to come and fix the luggage, by noon the next day we had fresh wheels on our Rimowa.The concierge at The Peninsula is the only one we trust when we are in Tokyo. Their recommendations for michelin star sushi and for kobe steak have been spot on. We are foodies and we tried venturing into our own finds and we were always disappointed. The concierge suggestions have become our go-to. We even asked for a 'cheap, casual yummy okonomiyaki place" and of course, we were not disappointed this place was awe-some.At dinnertime they have live music playing in the foyer and their dinner was also pretty spectacular. We went back a year later and the remember our names and ask us if they could do anything better this time to please let them know.I love the Peninsula, I will not hesitate to go back and I always do try every time I go to Tokyo.

What a fabulous hotel!! Expected great things and it surpassed! Service is the very best. Rooms better than any I have ever seen. We had a deluxe parkview on the 19th floor and it was fabulous. More electronics and bedside controls than you can imagine. Huge bathroom with 2 big separate vanities and a huge walkin closet. Many nice architectural features that gives the hotel a special feeling. Food was excellent. Fitness center was only ok - too many tread mills and not enough machines. Free weights were good but too small an area to use them. Very nice steam and sauna. I would stay here again - hands down.

Have to say Tokyo exceeded my expectations. Very clean city, citizens dress very nice, no smoking in any public area including city streets. No loud music from cars, no horns, no sirens, absolutely quiet. Imperial palace is not open to public but what you can see is majestic. Many districts through the city. We stayed in Ginza district at the Peninsula a 5 star plus hotel. Restaurants were all amazing, expensive but decor and service best anywhere in the world. Everything about hotel inclusive of 5 star staff makes this hotel a gem. We booked the hotel transfers through hotel and the RollsRoyce was an expensive treat. We used an inclusive guide for an all day tour followed by the next day did the fish market tour as well. We were on our feet for hours made for a long day but found it very interesting. I hope to return and visit the city and other Japanese towns in a couple years.

Of the "big three hotels" in Tokyo, the Peninsula here has the best pool. Service standard as expected of the Peninsula brand. Particular high marks to Ms. Meret Brunner, who had tirelessly met all pre-arrival arrangements. Slight draw back is the lobby lounge that serves all day snacks, and including breakfast.
