The atmosphere can be rather loud and chaotic with guests largely drawn from neighboring countries and SE Asia. Also, service such as refills can be slow due to the large volumes of customers. The location of the hotel is quite convenient and side streets offer many local restaurants. Otherwise, the rooms are large, comfortable with excellent tub. Views, unfortunately pales a bit in comparison. Overall, great stay!

The Peninsula is a great hotel. I really can't say that enough. The room we got was for our honeymoon, a deluxe corner suite with a view of the Imperial Palace and the local park. They had multi-voltage plugs, and *at the time* - I believe they've removed this feature and it sucks, because it made the place even better value - had unlimited laundry and dry cleaning in the suite, all provided through a discreet cupboard you'd put the clothes in and hit a button on, and then someone would come get them and replace them. This was great, and if it's gone I'm sorry but I may be one of the types of people who got it removed by abusing it by putting in all my dirty clothes all the time. It ruled. I'm sorry.I'm gonna dig at something quickly which seems petulant, but it was poorly explained. It says "Complimentary non-alcoholic beverages from the mini-bar" but what they mean is "one refill." Any more than that and they'll charge you for them. Also, if you order a soda through room service it's 1000 yen, so $9, which is hilarious. We were picked up and dropped off at Hineda using the quite expensive Tesla Model S (their most affordable, believe it or not) car service. It's expensive, but includes porters who pick up your stuff, put it in the car, and then check you *in in your room* which is very nice after 11 hours of flying. This means they sit at your table and do everything versus at the front desk. Japanese hotels also require your passport, which is jarring but it's necessary. They also fax you stuff to your room when they can't get to you, which is weird but funny. Either way it was really nice to sit down and do this in my room after the flight considering the time difference.The hotel is gorgeous - constantly playing live music, with a great restaurant right when you get in. Room service is expensive but high quality, again as you'd expect. The staff are constantly desperate to help - they will do anything they can - and when they made a mistake on an order they rectified it immediately. They mostly speak great English, too, and the transportation desk will gladly get you a street cab and tell them, even if it's somewhere really specific, where you're going. When we visited a restaurant in an odd location they managed to sit there and tell them where to go. Better yet, when we had reservations they made for us, they printed out a guide to hand the cabbie if we were out at the time, and provide you with Japanese cards to hand to cab drivers that say (in Japanese) how to get to the hotel, and please take me there. They got me into Sushi Jiro, narisawa (we actually couldn't go and they took care of that), and Gyu-an. They made sure I had anything I needed, they helped with shopping, they were just great. You're walking distance from stores, both expensive and inexpensive, and most cab drivers know where it is. It's also pretty quiet.The Wifi was the only bad thing, and it seems strange to dedicate a line to this, but come on. It was really really slow. There were no upgrade options. Just...yeah, I don't know why. They didn't have a bluray player, but that's kinda small potatoes.The location is fantastic too - Ginza has all sorts of shops, you're in walking distance of subway stations, they'll find you a way to get to anywhere and answer any questions you have. The singular bad experience we had was bizarrely when we asked to go to Tokyo station, and 3 people literally didn't know where to take us. I don't know what happened.Price-wise, this place was really good for the money. My final bill was cheaper than expected, which happens almost never at hotels. Furthermore, if they can help they will. If you have a problem, they will come and fix it. Even if you can't get the weird opulence of unlimited laundry, if you're going to Tokyo, go here. It's great. Romantic, quiet in the room, well-placed, and luxurious. And, honestly, cheaper than 5 star hotels you'd find in the USA for way better. We stayed a week, and it was worth it.

This hotel fully met our (very high) expectations for a Pensinsula. Our room was relatively large (by Tokyo standards), nicely decorated, and extremely comfortable and quiet. The hotel's facilities (pool, gym, restaurants) are in very good condition and service is exceptional. We liked the location (great to go for a run around the emperial palace, very good access to many restaurants and Ginza).If pressed, I would say there are two areas where the hotel can improve: (1) We had daily western breakfast (travelling with a group for work). The food was good, but not particularly delicious - I would have expected a bit more. (2) The hotel is using the lobby space to operate another restaurant. As a result, there is no lobby to speak of where one could meet up or wait for others to arrive. This did not seem adequate for a hotel in this category.

As you'd expect from one of the great hotel chains of the world, the experience of staying here is second to none.The rooms have every conceivable feature you could imagine. Everything hi-tech (from the toilet seat raising as you approach it, to the electrically operated curtains, a dressing room, TV for the bath and most importantly for a hotel, a very comfortable bed!)The staff were super friendly and couldn't be more helpful.The hotel has it's own entrance to the Tube system and is very conveniently located. I'd read other reviews about there being no area in the lobby to wait for friends, and this is true, there are just two small benches outside of the cafe, but that is literally nothing in my opinion that would put you off from staying here. Sure, it's not a cheap place to stay, but it's worth every cent! We'd definitely stay here again!!

Stayed 4 days and nights at this property. I usually stay at the Park Hyatt or the Grand Hyatt or Hilton Tokyo so was looking forward to this stay. Pre-arrival communications were generally ok. Everything was arranged well before my arrival. The hotel is located at a cross junction between the Ginza area and the Imperial Palace grounds. Rooms / suites facing the Imperial Palace are the best as they provide beautiful views, although you do get the afternoon sun. This is a rather old hotel, but quite well maintained. The lobby is stunning, but could have been much better if the restaurant for breakfast was placed in a separate area. Check in was efficient. Staff at the reception and concierge were very polite and helpful in general. I booked a sort of junior suite facing the Imperial Palace Gardens. It was spacious and had sufficient space for my needs. The bed was very comfortable. Bathroom etc was spacious enough. Some wear and tear was showing, but nothing serious. Housekeeping was consistent and reliable. Breakfast was underwhelming. On the first day, they redirected me to the basement eatery, which was very cramped and served a very average buffet. On the other days, I ate in the lobby restaurant, which was ok but the selection was very limited. The gym and swimming pool (indoor) was impressive. Overall, this is a good property to stay in for the business chic traveller. Location wise, it is not that easy to get to places such as Shinjuku or Shibuya.

We loved our 8 nights at the Peninsula. Everything about our stay was perfect. Our room was large and beautiful with a great view and was very quiet. The bathroom and closet were huge. The bed was really comfortable and there was plenty of room to sit and relax. The hotel food is excellent and breakfast every morning was delicious. There is a Starbucks across the street which was perfect for my teenager who likes to sleep in. There is also a 7-11 which was perfect for picking up snacks and using the ATM. There is a subway station in the basement which makes it really easy to get around. The location is perfect (it reminds me of the upper east side of NYC) with lots of great restaurants and shopping. On Saturdays there are weddings at the hotel which are really fun to watch. In the basement there are windows where you can watch the pastry chefs and the smell is amazing. Everyone who works here is super nice and helpful. Noriko, the guest relations manger, sets the gold standard for guest relations managers!

The location is fantastic - right on the edge of Ginza and right above the Hibiya subway station and the Yurakucho Japan Rail (JR) station. Walkable to shopping, food, businesses. The service is impeccable and the rooms are quite large by Tokyo standards. Bathrooms are massive with Oscar de la Renta product. The walk-in closet is nicely laid out. Breakfast in the lobby is classy. The only downside is that our bedroom was a little dusty (lots of crevasses and wooden surfaces).

This is a beautiful hotel near the Imperial Palace, the Ginza and many train/subway lines. The service is top notch. There was a problem with our room and we were not able to check in until very late in the afternoon. To compensate, the manager offered us free dinner in their lobby restaurant. Breakfast is ordered off a menu as opposed to a buffet and is served in their lobby restaurant. The lobby is beautiful, but the public area is very small with almost nowhere to sit while waiting for someone.The room was beautiful and very comfortable.The staff greeted us everytime we came and went and were very professional.

My husband and I spent 5 nights at the Peninsula Tokyo. I cannot say enough about the great experience. The hotel was spotless, EVERY employee was friendly and nice and the concierges were SUPER helpful. We had great meal recommendations that were spot on every time. We had a room on the 8th floor and we never heard a peep from another room. If we ever return to Tokyo, the Peninsula would be first on the agenda.

Came to Tokyo for 3 days, had booked a higher category room at the Peninsula at the insistence of our friend and did so despite much higher tariffs.Check in was smooth and was escorted to our room. In a jiffy the return airport limousine was booked and sorted.The room was spacious and meticulously clean and all services asked for were provided quickly and efficiently.Breakfast was adequate and cooked to perfection service was top class. Both dinner at rooftop grill and room service were good.Enjoyed the hospitality and service, reminded me of the Oberoi level of service which is legendary.Strongly recommend the hotel and would definitely stay again at next visit to Tokyo.
user_name:
Dr Nitin V
New Delhi, India

review_body: Very spacious room from tokyo standard. Very attentive service, the front desk is very helpful in restaurant booking. I especially like the shoe return design where they won't disturb you by returning anything to your room. The only suggestion is the breakfast standard which seems to have improvement space

A Peninsula hotel never lets you down!The Tokyo Peninsula is excellent - warm and welcoming.Excellent location, excellent service, excellent rooms.Looking forward to going back to Tokyo and The Tokyo Peninsula.

the comfort of the room was outstanding. all the staff very friendly, good trained. room service food excellent. great location. the only thing i didn't like was the smell/air in the room. and we couldnt get rid of it - even with using the aircon frequently. i think its because of the carpet.

This was my second stay at Peninsula Tokyo and it was as amazing as my first time. The hotel just feels luxurious from the moment you walk in. The rooms are simply amazing and complete in every sense - they have literally thought of everything! The service, staff, check in/out, food etc. were all excellent.Sir Paul McCartney was staying at the hotel and there were crowds of people outside in the mornings and evenings but super well organized in true Japanese style and the hotel staff managed everything effortlessly. The hotel location is right opposite the Imperial Palace and on the edge of Ginza (shopping) and the main business district. Hibiya park is next to the hotel and along with the Palace grounds offers some great walking/running opportunities.
user_name:
A A
New York City, New York

review_body: Great hotel in the Ginza district. Good wifi and friendly service. The desk is good to work at and the light is sufficient as well if you want to work at your hotel room. The service is friendly and efficient. The gym is small but oke for working out. The bar at the top of the hotel is nice and offer some good selection for a quick bite. 5 stars and definitely it but like a lot of hotels in Tokyo you pay an shocking amount especially when you book late.

The rooms are big, the facilities very good. And a very nice swimming pool not crowed where you can enjoy swimming. Great view on the imperial palace for some of the rooms. The small critic is the price of the breakfast "à la carte". Pretty expensive for a normal standing meal.

From check in to check out, we were made to feel that the hotel staff was at our service. Nothing disappointed. The room was large and luxurious as was the dressing room and bath. Very comfortable bed. We were there for the Sunday breakfast buffet which was a real treat. Dining in the lobby restaurant was quite delicious and service was quite attentive. We look forward to returning!

We stayed here for 3 nights in May 2017, and even in advance of our arrival, the staff was responsive and helpful to our requests for assistance with scheduling a half-day tour and dinner reservations. The Peninsula's staff is bi-lingual, which was incredibly helpful and not taken for granted. The level of service was excellent - we even received help when stepping into a taxi with a staff member providing location instructions to the driver and offering to us guidance about the type of fare to expect. The room was lovely; the dressing room/closet alone was bigger than my living room in Manhattan. The location was perfect for us; across the street from Hibiya Park and a short walk from Ginza. Definitely recommend for a trip with friends or for business.
user_name:
KeriR1836
New York City, New York

review_body: My family are frequent guests at the Pen in HK, but this was our first visit to their Tokyo Hotel. Although the public areas of this hotel are smaller, with fewer eating and shopping options and not really a space in which to sit around and relax, we actually found the rooms to be more comfortable and generally larger than in HK, with a very large dressing room in addition to the rest of the living space. We had a spectacular view over the Imperial Palace Gardens, and the location in Ginza was extremely convenient for shopping and local transport connections. Service was perfect, and I was very grateful to housekeeping who found a diamond earring that had fallen out without my notice, and left it for me on the dressing table.

Our stay at The Peninsula began on a positive note but as the days went by their flaws began to surface and we began to question whether they still live up to their 5 star status.Let's begin with the pros:1. Front desk - upon check in we realised that our agent had made some critical mistakes during the booking and we were almost left with no room to stay in. It was not the hotel's fault but they still went out of their way to assist us and in the end they managed to settle us into the rooms without any hassle. It was really going above and beyond what was expected of their service. We were very impressed.2. Location - the hotel is conveniently located within walking distance from the busy streets of Ginza yet is located just far enough off the side so that you can enjoy a quiet night right next to the imperial gardens and palace. The hotel also sits right on top of the elevator exit of Hibiya station so travelling by metro to anywhere in Tokyo is really easy. 3. Ease of shopping - as with many other 5 star hotels in the area, most of the department stores in Ginza offer a free same day delivery of your purchases directly to your hotel. No need to carry those heavy shopping bags around town! 4. Room - needless to say, their rooms are very spacious and the layout is efficient. There are a lot of different functions available for just the curtains and mood lighting, and my daughter had a blast experimenting with all those buttons. The nail dryer next to the dressing table was a nice touch too for emergency touch ups and fixes.5. Baby amenities - we were welcomed with a basket of amenities for our baby, which included soap, lotion, bib and a towel. The crib they provided was already equipped with a bumper, small pillow and mini duvet. It was one of the most luxurious cribs we have come across so far. And onto their flaws: 1. Inconsistent housekeeping - what bothered me the most was their inconsistencies with their housekeeping standard. Though towels and bed linens were changed everyday, they did not bother to organise anything in the room like most other hotels did. Things were left scattered everywhere and not even placed aside nicely. Perhaps they were too careful not to touch my things but I just found it a bit odd for a 5 star hotel. My biggest disappointment was the last night of our stay, where I returned to my room completely exhausted to find that the crib had been left in a mess! The bumpers were off, duvet out of its cover and bed sheets undone. I was too exhausted at that point to call housekeeping to tidy up and just wanted to quickly put my baby to bed. In the end I had to fix the bed myself. 2. Non transparent charges - we tend to do a lot of shopping in Japan and almost always end up having to pack a box or two of our clothes to ship home. The boxes would be weighed by the concierge and we would know exactly what to pay for shipping. We would also have several shipping options to choose from (by sea, air, express courier etc). However this was not the case at the Peninsula. We were asked to sign a pre-approval to charge our credit card after they had figured out the charges and we had no choice on what type of freighter to use. We were also charged an extra 1500 yen handling charge for each shipment on top of the shipping fees. With other hotels we did not have to pay this extra handling fee. 3. Not enough manpower at the front entrance - I have, on several occasions found the front entrance completely without staff. We had to hail our own cabs without any assistance. This was in the afternoon. The Peninsula definitely has its ups and downs but I would probably stay somewhere else next time we're in Tokyo. With the price they're charging we definitely have many other options.

Peninsula was the best hotel during our 1.5 week trip. New, modern, large rooms. Staff is very friendly, english is no issue... felt small and intimate for large hotel. Location is perfect for tourist, Imperial Palace across the street, and Ginz shopping a block away. Other hotels, Imperial Hotel, same location, large, more like a business convention center, more Japanese oriented for language. Many restaurants, they sell out during the week.

A friend recommended this hotel. It is great and so is its location. I chose a room with views of the imperial palace. The Ginza shopping area is just two blocks away. The hotel is magnificent with 4K tv and all amenities.

Beautiful spacious room, with own dressing room and amazing bathroom.Luscious, beautiful, grand.We stayed in December just before the Christmas and from the first step it was smelling and feeling of holiday. We had beautiful high tea at the hall.

Our stay at the Peninsula was the perfect ending to our trip to Japan. A convenient base for exploring Tokyo (and beyond), with a great location on the edge of the Imperial park. The room was spacious, and very well-appointed (I believe it was a deluxe room, and it didn't seem all that much smaller than the suite we had over at the Conrad Tokyo, for sake of comparison). Service was impeccable, the spa area was absolutely wonderful - minor hiccups were the wait time at the bar (it seems very popular, and they weren't able to accommodate hotel guests right away) and the fact that the a-la-carte breakfast was good, but not amazing in our minds. Nonetheless - a near-perfect hotel experience, highly recommended!

It's not cheap but it sure is nice. Huge room, beautiful spa and pool. Location near JR, metro and shopping. Walkable to Tsukiji Fish Market.Minor things:-only two coffee packets in your room each day;-not a lot of common area in the lobby. It almost feels cramped; and-windows near the vitality pool could use a good scrubbing.Other than that, a flawless stay.

This is a very good hotel in a perfect location. Highlights include a huge beautiful room, bathroom and dressing room, lovely breakfast, fantastic pool area all set in the perfect location in the heart of Tokyo. We enjoyed the Peter Bar on the top floor though the smoking issue really needs to be addressed. We also agree with some of the other comments here that it is a shame the lobby area is filled with the restaurant and doesn't offer any lounge space. The staff were very helpful but did cause one hiccup for us. We had requested the concierge to make two very hard to get dinner reservations for us and they came through with what we had requested. When we checked in they gave us our confirmations with maps to each. On the second night we could not find the restaurant and after almost an hour searching we discovered they had given us the old address and the restaurant had relocated a year earlier. We eventually got to the right place and the restaurant was able to accommodate us despite being so late but it really caused a fair amount of stress for us. When we got back to our room that night there was a nice bottle of wine waiting for us which helped us get over our frustrations. Despite this glitch we would highly recommend this property.

The peninsula, in general, is an amazing brand. After staying in Beverly Hills, my husband and I decided we must stay here on our honeymoon in Tokyo. What a fabulous experience! The customer service could not have been better, the facilities (especially the spa and pool) are perfection. After a day of sightseeing, I was excited to come back and take a nap in our room. Definitely be sure to stop by the lobby breakfast and enjoy the expansive space :)

What a spectacular hotel. The best hotel stay I have ever had, and I've stayed at some really nice hotels. This hotel really thought of every single detail that I might need. The room is huge and not just by Tokyo standards. I loved that I had my very own powder room to get ready in. The service cannot be beat. I went to go for a run in the gym, and a hotel member walked over to me and handed me a bottle of water. The pool is impressive. I loved that the lobby had welcome music every evening. The only thing I can say is beware of the hidden service charge. The rate of the room is not a flat rate, there is a service charge on top of the room. One thing that other hotel rooms do that Peninsula does not is the extra something special during turndown service. For example a few chocolates or fruit. However, I would stay at this hotel over and over again.

This review is long overdue after staying here multiple times. We've stayed at this hotel multiple times in the basic Deluxe room, Executive Suite, and the large Deluxe suite. Location of this hotel is amazing. 10 minute walk from the glamorous Ginza and 5 minute walk from Ramen Alley for late night eats. Tons of eating and shopping options all within a few minutes of the hotel. The lobby is magnificent and always busy with people eating lunch or having tea. The Pros: All the rooms are well thought out. Screens informing you of outdoor temperature, all electronic blinds/shades, coffee machine, hot water maker. Decent closet space and good sized bathrooms even for the basic rooms. What you lose with the basic rooms is size and view (usually will be looking into another building). Basic room is bed connected to a living room area with a TV. No separate TV near the bed. Executive and Premium suites have a separate living room area with a large TV. Similar layout between the Executive and Premium Suites, the difference being the Premium Suites have gigantic living room and massive dressing room and closet area. The Cons: Service slightly varied with different level rooms. While staying in the deluxe rooms I requested a hot water maker, a basic amenity included in practically every hotel in Asia but strangely missing at the Peninsula. I was told that they had none in the hotel and would either need to call room service or use the coffee maker which was extremely awkward and slow. When I requested a hot water maker while staying in the Premium Suites, we got one delivered quickly along with fruit and juice every evening. Conclusion: I would not consider deluxe rooms to be a good value at the Peninsula. Rooms are not that much bigger than other cheaper and good quality hotels and you pay a premium to stay in a room with no view. If you can splurge for a more expensive room, the experience is quite different and the rooms are magnificent, especially those overlooking Imperial Palace.

If you want to be in and around Ginza and your budget will stretch to it, the Peninsula in Tokyo should be on your short list. Large rooms, particularly the dressing area. Fantastic service (ok, you are in Tokyo, so it's expected). Great sized bathroom; decent coffee machine in the room and a well equipped gym.Stroll out of the door and you've got some classic restaurants in under 5 mins walk (Andy's) as well as numerous other great places to eat. Metro station is close by too.I will absolutely return.

Only stayed one night and wish we had stayed longer. The service from everyone (check in, concierge, door attendants, room service, restaurant) was attentive and impeccable. The room was very comfortable and the bathroom had every possible amenity and gadget. It is very well located, in the centre of all the shops and restaurants in Ginza. Could not find any fault with any aspect, it has a superb reputation and deserves it.

Very very cool hotel, highest standard, cool rooftop bar and restaurant, fabolous view, fully recommed if you are willing to spend big money on a great room and perfect service be it room service, the concierge or anything else ...

My family and I had a wonderful stay at the Peninsula Tokyo. It is a great location, the hotel and rooms were clean and well-appointed. We traveled with a child and elderly guests and all were well-accommodated. Cannot say enough about the hotel.

Yes, it's a 5-star hotel, but came away feeling it's not up to Peninsula standards we have enjoyed in Hong Kong. While the room was spacious and pleasant, we likely won't be back. The lobby was crowded at all hours to capacity, with people waiting for tables, The front door is staffed with plenty of people, but no assistance offered with opening/revolving doors. Seemed like large number of staff at front, but no one at rear of hotel, which is more convenient from city/Tokyo station side. While there's plenty of staff, communication in English is a challenge. Waited to check in at 6pm. Waited 20 minutes after check in for unexplained reason before being shown to room. Staff is on auto-pilot. All very robotic, with little authenticity or warmth. Food on room service breakfast was pretty, but flavorless. More attention paid to appearance than taste.Pool are was too crowded on two checks, and full of loud kids. Fitness room is poorly lit, and has limited equipment, including no rowing machine.And had to wait in line for 20 minutes to check out.When paying so much per night we expect more than you'd get at a Hilton or Intercontinental. It just felt very random, not special. And way too crowded. Perhaps too popular for its own good. With 300+ rooms, I imagine it's hard to make it feel like anything more than just another big business hotel.

I have to admit that I was most worried about this hotel during our trip. I thought the hotel might be showing its age too much, but I am so glad that I was wrong. We were picked up from the airport using the hotel's Rolls Royce service, which was a beautiful way to begin our Asian adventure. As we arrived at the hotel, we were immediately whisked up to our room to complete the check-in. The service was polished and elegant, but still quite warm. We felt completely welcomed.We stayed in a Deluxe Room, and I have to say that I absolutely loved this room! The layout was so smart and efficient. I also loved the design. It was warm and modern at the same time, with just a slight Asian flare. The dressing area was so nice to accommodate our luggage and to keep organized. The room was also complete with amazing technology and smartly-designed hidden drawers to maximize space. The bed was also divine...plush pillows and crisp linens. I also really enjoyed the bathroom design; I thought it was well-designed and very functional. The location of the hotel was also perfection...so close to all the great shops and restaurants and located right on top of a subway station, so getting around was a breeze. We did not dine at the hotel, but we did have breakfast there and had drinks at the bar upstairs. The breakfast was nothing to rave about; it was to be expected. The bar was fantastic; great service and such a cool vibe.I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone who loves unfussy luxury and may be undecided as to where to stay in Tokyo!

A typical 'palace' in Tokyo with it's subsequent atmosphere. Very nicely appointed rooms and great service (although not too personalised) and mainly great location in Tokyo. I would compare that location to 'The Plaza' in NYC - it is in the middle of everywhere!Only negative would be that Peter Restaurant located on the roof was smelling of smoke. Very disturbing that people are still allowed nowadays to smoke in a restaurant - it caused us to avoid that restaurant.Other than this, definitely worth the stay!

Right in the Giza District, you can just leave the hotel and 2 min down the road you have tons of restaurants, shops etc.The rooms are very big, comfortable and tastefully decorated.Gym is small not a lot of equipment.Try their steam room and sauna, very good.Big pool to do laps.Breakfast included with the room, very nice sets and a la carte menusThe restaurant in the Hotel had a good wine selection and excellent steak options, just in case you don't have the appetite to leave your room.about 30 min ride from Haneda airport and about 1.15 min from Narita hotel.they can arrange for a taxi pick up, which they can charge to your room.staff were helpful and nice.

Location: in Ginza, by all the nice shops, brands, cafes, restaurants. It's in a prime location. And connected to the metro station (Hibiya line) from the basement (B2).Facility:not a brand new but well maintained facility; with a few restaurants, a cafe, a spa, a gym, a swimming pool, clothing and jewelry stores and a gift shop. We enjoyed a la carte breakfast in the lobby, and snacks in the cafe. Check in: smooth. Room: the room was very spacious including a walk in closet with a vanity, a bathroom with a shower and a tub, the bedroom has big windows. It was a very comfortable room; however, I thought the interiors and colors were dated. Concierge service: they are greet, they get things done the best, they got us a table at the busiest restaurant in town in such a short notice.Internet: a complimentary high speed internet throughout the facility. House keeping: on top of things. Over all: it's a more expensive hotel than most hotels in Tokyo but you are getting many things in return: location, service, cleanliness... so I highly recommend it.

Staying at The Peninsula Tokyo is just purely divine. Everything about the hotel is just excellent. Upon entering the lobby, the exquisite design is soothing that instantly clams you. The staff is efficient and welcoming. The Japanese are just polite, hospitable and no wonder they are a great nation. The rooms are big and the best part is the bed. I must say I really slept well and having breakfast in your room is the best way to start your day.

Any of the Peninsula Hotels are fabulous, including the mother lode in Hong Kong, at the tip end of Kowloon. Owned by the Kadoorie Family, whose members included knights and lords, the service at this hotel is exquisite, and a high tea in the Lobby area will put you vicariously back in London.

Afternoon Tea in the Lobby of The Peninsula Tokyo is a treat for the eyes, ears, and taste. Even with the lofty ceiling and massive chandelier above, the tea tables feel warm and welcoming with traditional Japanese instruments playing in the background. Service on the Sunday afternoon was excellent. We had no problems communicating in English. The seasonal Sakura Tea was perhaps the best themed tea we've ever been served. The detail put into each item and the flavour varieties were extraordinary. We enjoyed the complementary pink champagne. A wonderful time!

Stayed for 1 night in a standard room. The space was huge, well-equipped and beautifully designed. It was extremely comfortable and a great place to unwind / sleep after a long flight. The bathroom in particular was great. Business centre facilities were adequate for my needs (PC, web access), wifi was reliable and the hotel location was very convenient, close to my place of work and client offices. Staff very helpful and polite, as you would expect. Some minor issues, mentioning for completeness. Breakfast was a bit manic - staff looked very stressed and it took a while to get the correct order delivered. I didn't love the tea-making facilities in the room - you really feel like you're going to burn yourself trying to get the hot water into the little tea-pot (maybe that's just me). We also had drinks in Peter, the bar at the top of the hotel - bit smoky but otherwise fine for what it is.

We spent 4 nights at the Peninsula Tokyo in Feb 2017. Great room, impeccable service and convenient location within walking distance to JR and subway . Breakfast and lunch were excellent! Would definitely stay again.

The location is great and the hotel is a top hotel in Tokyo. The room is huge with an extra dressing room, a sofa area, working desk, a huge bathroom, etc. Simple what you expect of a hotel in this category.

Stayed one night. Booked through Platinum Amex so got upgraded from a standard King to at least one room category up. Very nice, Japanese decor room. King bed, sizeable seating area, large bathroom and huge closet/changing room. Service throughout the hotel was very good. Design is modern Japanese and very tasteful. Breakfast is in lobby and a la carte. Tables are far enough apart to have a breakfast meeting. Very nice roof top bar (although allows smoking), which I will review separately. Hotel is in a great location right by the park and close to the main train station, shopping area and business district. Will stay again.

We stayed in an executive suite at Peninsula Tokyo last July. The location could not be better. All the major shopping malls are within walking distance, and everything you buy at the malls could be sent to your room directly.

I came to Tokyo over Christmas New Year. I divided my time among the Mandarin Oriental and Pennisula Hotel. I stayed in suites at both Hotels. I was surprised at the lack of service of the Pennisula. When your spending over 1k a day for a room you expect top notch quality service. Here are some points:Check in - I had to wait 25 minutes. Then no one escorted me to my room. They just gave me the keys. New Year's Eve dinner - horrible. Slow service. Bad food and everyone was CHAIN SMOKING at the bar in low level ceiling room. I felt like I was at an airport Marriott. The experience was so bad I left dinner. It ruined my New Years and I also believe I got sick from the trick. Taxi - the Pennisula has a custom taxi but please be where you must order in advance. After leaving New Year's Eve I needed a ride. The car sat outside butt they would not make it worthwhile The Lobby Lounge - it is very strange that the entrance has no where to relax and sit. People enjoy. A cocktail and to read, people watch or meet friends and family. There is zero room minus a restaurant. When I met a business pattern we decided to talk in driveway because there was no space and we didn't want to order a meal. They must fix his asap. Once you realize they have no rooftop bar minus the smoke filled room, the situation gets worse The positive - a very nice pool spa area. So nice in fact I ordered room service here because it is the best place to eat in hotel. Nice same dame laundry service I have stayed at all the Pennisula and when I return to Tokyo or elsewhere I would not return here and most likely opt for mandarin orinetal or amangani. they were apologetic about. New Years but it is not enough

This hotel was the highlight of the trip, perfection. Everything is designed beautifully for functionality and comfort, and it's uber chic. Incredible attention to detail and minimalist decor showcase the spectacular view over the imperial palace. It was like looking back in time, truly a spiritual experience going to Japan and visiting the ancient temples. The Peninsula Tokyo is somewhere I will never forget and hope to visit again someday.

We first stayed at the Peninsula last year in March 2016 on our first visit to Tokyo. Returning this year we decided to stay for a night before traveling up to Niseko. Great location walking distance from the imperial place and about 4 minutes walk to the train station. It's just 30 minutes to the airport by train/ monorail so we did that and it was easy to negotiate. The hotel itself has great rooms and very friendly staff. Last year we are in the Chinese restaurant and Peter (the restaurant on the top floor) as well as spending a lot of time in the cocktail bar gazing at the view. Only criticism was the amount of smoking that goes on, but this is not a problem that is their fault - it's just not pleasant whichever restaurant you go to in Japan to return with your clothes smelling like you've been smoking yourself! Anyway back to the review of the hotel. We had an early connection so we hit the bar early on the top floor and were given a great view looking out over the Tokyo skyline. We decided to try the bar menu and it was excellent. We are back again for a few more days after skiing in Niseko before returning home, but plan to hit Peter restaurant and will say how that compares to last year then.

Stayed for 2 nights. Welcoming and very courteous staff. Clean and spacious room. Updated and modern bathroom. We enjoyed everything about our stay here! Wish we could have stayed longer. Highly recommend this hotel.

My favorite hotel in Tokyo. Great location, wonderfully luxurious and quiet. The rooms are huge and very well appointed. The living area has a sliding door to keep out any hall noises (which there are none...the place is like a vault). The bathroom is beautiful and all fixtures are very high quality. The gym is great and the pool has a stunning view of the imperial palace. A great choice for Tokyo...the best.

The Peninsula means quality, at least it should do! From the welcome outside to the in-room check inn is perfect. We also had the Rolls Royce pick up and that was lovely. Room quality was super and the beds are the best! I would really like to visit more Peninsula Properties.

Excellent hotel and service, unbeatable location... You can´t be near to Imperial Palace than in The Peninsula... walking distance to Ginza. Superb restaurants and bars. If you can stay at leats a couple of nights in this great hotel. You will not regret it.

I have gone to so many 5-star hotels, but this by far tops them all. First off, the check-in was such a breeze. After we got in the lobby, one of the staff led us to our suite and checked us in our own suite, without having to wait in the lobby. Our suite had all the amenities that we wanted, from the heated bathroom floors to the self-opening toilet seat to the push-button butt wash and bidet... the list goes on and on. Plus the location of the hotel is very central, we can just walk over to the shops and train station, etc. I will definitely stay here again when I'm in Tokyo. Truly a 5-star hotel! Worth all the money I spent. :)

Just so good. Location, staff, rooms and experience are second to none. Amazing. We also did the Pokemon experience with our children. Disney would be proud! Fantastic.One of the great hotels anywhere.

We stayed at our last trip to Japan at three different hotels, because we wanted to find out, which one is best. The first one was Shangri-La, the second one The Peninsula and the third one Mandarin Oriental. We stayed at all hotels for three days, a total of nine days. I booked all hotels through GrandLuxuryHotels and have been very pleased by their services.So the second one was the Peninsula and we looked very much forward to our stay. To make a long story short: We were disappointed. Even though the location near Imperior’s Garden ist great, we never felt at home. Entering the hotel, the hotel lobby is packed with people eating on tables all day long. Luckily for us, restaurant Peter on the 24th floor was open for breakfast during Christmas and New Eve; normally breakfast is served in the lobby… Service was so so and we cannot understand, that management allows (American) guests to join breakfast in their sweaty outfit, right after running: really disgusting. I'm a passionate runner myself, but would never allow myself to join any meal in a inappropriate dress. By the way: we booked a Deluxe Parkpark Premier Room, but looked directly into a huge, fully lit office building. After complaining, we have been told, this is park view. Strange. As a matter of fact, after our complaint, they just renamed these rooms to “premier rooms” with a new description: “views overlooking Tokyo skyline” :-)...Maybe I'm too harsh with my comments. The Peninsula is not a bad hotel. But the services provided at Shangri-La and Mandarin Oriental are much better and the rooms more cozy and luxurious for the same price.

It was difficult to choose amongst Tokyo's luxury hotels - each seems to have something to recommend it. However, we were ultimately very pleased with our choice of the Peninsula. It is ideally located in walking distance to the Ginna area as well as the Tokyo Station area and Imperial Gardens and has metro access from the basement to everywhere else. The rooms are lovely and comfortable, contemporary but not starkly minimalist, filled with technological touches which are actually useful as opposed to the trend towards technology for technology's sake. They are well designed with a large separate dressing area that is very helpful when there is more than one person getting ready at one time. The bath is spacious as well and well appointed. What truly stands out is the service which was consistently excellent. From the front desk, to room service, to housekeeping, the bell staff and the concierge, all were warm, helpful and exceedingly professional. Kudos to the Peninsula management for what is clearly superb training and kudos to the staff for taking that training and making it personal.

The Peninsula still stands out! Hard to believe it will be ten years soon...the hotel is still cutting edge in every way. The art, beautifully enigmatic and the facilities are perfection. We enjoyed a special and festive New Years Eve on the rooftop and recovered in the gorgeous spa the following day. Highly recommended for everything one could want in a luxury hotel, most importantly, consistency.
user_name:
intleq
New York City, New York

review_body: We booked here for my husband's 50th birthday. As it was a special treat we booked a suite overlooking the Imperial Palace. The suit was amazing with large windows affording a great view over the Palace. As well as a large living area there was a double dressing area, small bathroom in the corridor as well as large main bathroom with a large bath, double sinks etc. As you would expect from this calibre hotel the bed and bed linen were first class. The hotel arranged for a cake to be delivered on my husband's birthday which was a lovely touch.While there we hired the Mini Cooper with Peninsula branding to take us around Tokyo. It was such a fun and unique way to see the city. The driver was exceptionally helpful and he suggested additional places to visit en route which we never would have known about. The bar at the hotel had brilliant views over the city and very good staff. Unfortuntely Tokyo doesn't have rules against smoking though...A final mention goes to the breakfast which was simply perfect. This place has the best eggs benedict in the world. You need to ask for good tea though if you want it instead of the insipid stuff they generally serve! Overall a great visit we will remember for a long time.

Fantastic all class top notch great hotel. Big rooms. Big bath. Staff incredible. This must be one of the best hotels in Tokyo. 3 wheeler electric bikes. Super location. Discreet, quiet, peters bar is very swish and uber cool. I will happily return.

An excellent hotel with super service ,food,spa, etc. I will be back next year ! I am a frequent traveler and ...YES !!! this hotel is one of the 3 best I stayed the last 20 years!!! Congratulations to the owner , managing director and staff !!

The hotel is pretty close to perfect in terms of premises, service,, etc, but by booking through American Express platinum we got things that put us over the top. We booked a suite for $700 per night and got the 4th night free, free breakfasts, plus $300 in credits for food, drink. They supplied free overnight laundry and dry cleaning (which we used several times) , plus a free car and driver for 3 hour periods which we booked several times.  We loved our suite - spacious, well appointed, and spectacular views. Located in the Ginza with a short walk to the Imperial Palace grounds, we will definitely return.

We stayed here for six nights during our trip in Tokyo. It could be the best hotel I've stayed at. Everything was impeccable, from room to services. They seemed to be able to think of every single detail of your trip and try to take care of everything. One bonus is that the hotel's location in Ginza is perfect, it's within walking distance to multiple Tokyo metro subway lines, JR stations, Imperial palace, Hibiya park, Jiro, Bar High Five, major shopping stores, etc. When you decide to stay here, make sure to ask concierge to help you make reservations for restaurants - they were able to make reservations for us at all three restaurants we requested (Ryugin, Jiro, and Narisawa). When we arrived to check in, they gave us print outs of our full itinerary including directions to restaurants, dress codes, estimated price per person. The room we had was on the top floor with partial view of the park. It's spacious with a full couch, a small dining table by the window, and amazing bathroom with double sink, and a powder room. Definitely one of the biggest hotel rooms I've stayed at. If we come back to visit Tokyo, I'd definitely come back here.
user_name:
L H
New York City, New York

review_body: We were very happy that we chose The Peninsula Tokyo for our latest visit in Tokyo. It is flawless in its hardware and amenities. The room is spacious and clean. The layout is excellent. Kids are definitely welcome here as our little love terrorist was treated with his own teddy bear slipper, bath toy, teddy bear shaped bath sponge, kid's tooth brush with tooth paste, organic body wash, shampoo and lotion, goody bag filled with stationery, cookies, etc. Not sure what it will be in other seasons, but there was a stuffed snowman in a gift bag there welcoming our little one. The kid's breakfast is served in a very cute tray. The Peninsula Tokyo is very conveniently located. It is within walking distance to Ginza and Hibiya subway station, three stations away from Tsukiji Market. Restaurants and eateries of all sorts are all there within easy walking distance. However, there are a few improvements that I can see needed to perfect the experience. The check-in process is not as efficient as it could be especially when compared to other hotels. The staff are very friendly and pleasant. Yet, there was only 3 staff on duty during rush hour - check-in hours to service the line-up that was out in the check-in area which is tucked at the back on your left when you entered the hotel. You need to pass through the dining area first. Observing it on a different day, it could be because the staff has to escort the guests to their rooms and created an illusion of insufficient staffing for the rush hours. In any case, the entire process should be reviewed. The breakfast serving areas can be confusing. We had a later breakfast the next day we checked-in at around 9:30am, we were directed to the basement cafe for breakfast. The following morning we were up early and ready for breakfast at 8:15am. We went straight down to the basement cafe for breakfast and found that the restaurant was vacant with no staff. We went to the back preparatory area and asked if they were serving breakfast. We were told we had to go up to the lobby for breakfast. Other than the confusion, the breakfast is pretty good, especially the mango danish!

We thoroughly enjoyed our stay at this property. The location is one of the best in Tokyo. Excellent shopping and restaurants in the area. The rooms were spacious and extremely comfortable. The floors in the bathroom are heated. And as for cleaning and room service it was the best and commendable in every way. I look forward to returning to this property.

Overall I was happy with my stay at the Peninsula. In summary, for the hotels in the Nihonbashi / Marunouchi / Ginza area I would rank the Peninsula behind the Mandarin and Four Seasons but ahead of others like the Shangri La, Tokyo Station, Imperial and Palace Hotels (although the Palace is comparable).The hotel location is fantastic. Right on the edge of the Imperial Palace and Ginza. It is also a straight shot from this location to other touristy areas such as Roppongi or Shinjuku/Shibuya. I was traveling for business (although my partner was with me) and it is also very well located right by the CBD and Tokyo Station. Overall, I would say it is the best located hotel in Tokyo for both business and tourism. The rooms are nicely laid out and have a good feel. The bed is extremely comfortable. The dressing room and bathroom are nicely laid out and the general dark wooden decor has a nice homely feel. No a modern or particularly new feel to it, but nice.The pool and gym are also very good. The top floor restaurant has a nice view out over the imperial palace but a bit of a shame that the bar area doesn't share this view. The bar area is extremely smokey (which is normal for Tokyo) and the only time I went up it was too crowded for me to get a seat. The restaurant downstairs is good for breakfast but has a very limited menu for lunch. I was rushing off to meeting and wanted a quick sandwich or burger but there were hardly any choices. I was a bit surprised by this as on my last visit I recall more options.There were a couple of slight annoyances. I messaged the concierge to ask that they help me arrange a few things and the response time was very bad. I ended up speaking to the head concierge regarding this, and from then on she was extremely helpful and gave us very useful tips that would have taken a lot of time to put together, so ultimately everything was very good, but only after complaining.I had also requested a King Sized Room, but had a twin allocated when I arrived. I took some time to get this sorted, and ultimately I was able to get a great room, so I was appreciative of the front desk staff's patience with my initial annoyance at not getting the type of room I requested. Again, everything worked out well, but had some initial frustrations.Overall a pleasant stay.

The Peninsula Tokyo Hotel by far the best hotel that I have been to. The rooms are magnificent and spacious. Restaurants there are so good that I can't give a comment to not be unjustified with the restaurants and the hotel. The location of the hotel is great.

For many years I have said that the Peninsula Hotel Tokyo is the best hotel in Tokyo and possibly the very best city hotel in Asia. I have stayed at the hotel many, many times, for work and pleasure. In total, I think I have stayed in this hotel over two or three months. Overall, I love the hotel, and it remains one of my favorites in Tokyo. The rooms are spacious and comfortable. The beds are luxurious. The large bathrooms and large dressing rooms are a luxury that few hotels offer, especially in a city such as Tokyo where space is a great premium. The service in the hotel is impeccable. The food in the hotel is amazing. I love the room service be it dim sum or wagyu beef hamburger, everything is generally perfect. I have only a couple of minor comment of concern: in the past the hotel has offered fresh Japanese fruit in the room on a daily basis. When I first started coming here the hotel had fresh juices and fresh fruits in the room. This amenity was truly one of the best aspects of the hotel. We looked forward to returning home each day to the fresh Japanese seasonal fruits. However, I have just learned on this visit that the hotel has stopped this amenity!!!! I am so disappointed. This is one of the small but important things that set this hotel apartment from the many other great choices in Tokyo. Aman, Mandarin, and others are always there, but I have until today always picked the Peninsula because I know my experience will be impeccable and also enhanced by the fruits and juices and comforts that only a great hotel will provide. I am concerned about this change and it is these little things that can make all the difference. I discussed this change with management and was told this change was made recently. I hope that management will really understand that little things like this really count.

I've transited through Tokyo several times but finally visited for a few days with friends and we landed at the Peninsula... though the city is absoultey amazing in every way, I didn't want to leave the room. It's really one of the best spots I've ever stayed at and the location is superb.

Stayed there for 3 nights during the final leg of our most recent Japan holiday.Had chose the hotel on recommendation of a friend who raved about the location and the indoor pool.What I liked:a) Location - my friend is right. Location is superb. From B2 of the hotel, there is a direct passageway to the Hibiya subway station, which is served by Tokyo Metro Hibiya line, Tokyo Metro Chiyoda line and the Toei Mita Line. The Hibiya station is also connected by underground passageway to the Yurakucho station. With this connectivity, there is no need to brave the elements when one needs to use the Tokyo subway system. The Chiyoda line gets you directly and quickly to popular spots like Akasaka, Omotesando and Harajuku, while the Hibiya line gets you to Roppongi and, via transfer to Ginza line, Asakusa.The hotel is located on a corner facing the Imperial Palace and Hibiya Park, and within walking distance of Ginza and the so-called "Golden Triangle" comprising Hibiya, Marunouchi, and Yurakucho. Request for park view room especially one with a view of the Imperial Palace gardens.b) Room size and decor. The room was quite sizable by Tokyo standards. The decor is warm and soothing with the use of a lot of wood. Bathroom is spacious (liked the placement of the basins -one each on opposite sides of the bathroom), and so is the dressing room. Note: the high tech touch controls for lights and curtains may take some getting use to - especially for some older folk.c) Service - When it comes to misplaced articles, Peninsula's housekeeping is very efficient and responsive. Had misplaced a scarf during my stay. This was couriered to my home after a brief correspondence with their housekeeping coordinator. The concierge service is also quite commendable. They responded fairly promptly to our requests for restaurant and theatre bookings, and made suggestions for alternatives when our original choices were unavailable. What truly impressed was giving us a print-out of all our dining reservations during check-in, together with map/directions to the various dining venues.

I just got back from a stay in the Peninsula Tokyo, this was my third visit to Tokyo and first time stay. I can't tell you how amazing everything about our stay was. We have found our hotel in Tokyo. (Stayed in the Palace Hotel and Ritz Carlton previously.) My boyfriend visits Tokyo for work regularly so we have vowed this is our place. This is what you call a 5* hotel with the service to match - impeccable. The concierge was amazing, we did have provisional issues of them being very busy however the head concierge personally helped us with all our needs and gave me some amazing advice on different things to do in Tokyo that were slightly outside the box. The room was lovely, very big by Tokyo standards with a huge bathroom and separate dressing room. The bed... well I would say comfiest bed I have stayed in ever! I really couldn't recommend this hotel more, as soon as you enter the lobby your greeted by smiles and attentiveness, you get whisked into a taxi! The location is ideal, right next to the hustle and bustle of Ginza but looking out onto the beautiful green Palace grounds.Thank you Peninsula team, we had a great stay and we will be back.

Take a rest with a high tea at penninsula hotel. See the elegantly dressed taking high tea on a sunday afternoon.great ambience with timber structure interior in lobby where afternoon high tea is served.good coffee inspite of it being high tea. Service was excellent. Cakes yummy. The bellgirls aka bellhops at the front door push a mean door!

We stayed at Peninsula Tokyo last week before we fly back to USA. The front door service is a bit messy. When we arrived in taxi, seems people working in the front door of the hotel are confused if they need to help us with bags. And one guy just opened our taxi door, and stand there looking at his phone, and did nothing, the other guy asked us if we need our bags brought to the room?? And the guy also took our passport, and take us to front check in desks, after he looked through our passport, he hand them over to a women who will continue help us, the himself left for some other things. Odd experiences. Another odd things is on first floor, there is a resturant overtaking the majority floor of the lobby, so lobby is shrieked to a passage way to the checkin counter. There are tons of people on the first floor all the time, not a good relaxing lobby. Well, our passport finally ends in the real check in person's hands after few rounds of shuffling. The room was spacious and great! Comes with big and cool bathroom. The room has a separate living area with sofa and table which is very nice! The city view is nothing special here. The tea pots and coffee machine is unique. Beds are firm and comfy. We had fun staying in the room. Checked out swimming pool, looked great! All together was great stay, but service can be really improved at the front door.

I stayed here for 3 nights with my husband. We booked a superior room. The room was very very spacious, with a big walk in closet / dressing room area, big bathroom with double sinks.. Not side by side, but actually on different sides of the big bathroom so we didn't need to fight over countertop space to spread out our respective toiletries...! separate shower and bath and toilet area.The bedroom had a living room area (not separately partitioned) study desk and a small dining table. Well equipped with complimentary bottled water, and a lavazza coffee espresso machine. Decor is classic, nothing exciting but also equally nothing to complain about. Everything was clean and tidy, nothing was out of place. Ordered room service hot chocolate one night and it arrived surprisingly very promptly... Most hotels take at least 30 mins even just to get drinks into the room but I was pleasantly surprised with an only 15-20 mins wait. Service was excellent in this hotel...Especially the concierge service. We had emailed in advance to make restaurant bookings around town and they had done everything without mistakes and made recommendations or alternative suggestions when they felt they needed to. We were delayed and arrived late on the first night and I had sent them a quick email before boarding my delayed flight to ask if they could change my dinner booking. They had promptly checked the email and changed the booking and replied my email by the time I was on the plane! All the restaurant bookings we had made in Tokyo were printed out and maps of their locations prepared for us as soon as we arrived. Not only was the service of the concierge helpful, friendly and efficient; service at the hotel front door and reception was also flawless. Needless to say they all spoke perfect English. A helpful concierge to make bookings and recommendations is so important in a place like Tokyo, where no one speaks English to tourists! I also tried out the spa one afternoon and booked a massage. The spa was nice and clean, massage was good, service was good.. Everything you would expect in a 5 star hotel spa. Again, nothing to complain about. Only thing is the hotel lobby feels a bit cramped, as the lobby restaurant/lounge is on both sides as you enter the hotel so it doesn't leave much room for anything else.. So people waiting in the lobby all sit on two benches or stand around.. So the lobby doesn't quite feel as 5 star as it should. Nonetheless this doesn't affect the calibre of the hotel services and facilities of course. Location of this hotel is also fairly convenient- just steps away from the subway; and a short walk into the restaurant/ shopping district of Ginza. Other major shopping districts (e.g. Shibuya/ Shinjuku) is just a 15-20 min cab ride away. I would stay here again and would recommend this hotel to anyone travelling in Tokyo looking for 5 star service with no disappointments.

I stay at peninsula Tokyo quite a few times and I quite like it. The location is the key advantage of the hotel, just right behind marunochi and a step away from Ginza. The guest room is super spacious! I love it. Only one thing that I don't like about this hotel is the breakfast area because it's right there at the lobby and everyone got to walk pass. I just don't feel private there.

Arrived late on a Thursday evening after arriving late on Turkish airlines and waiting for the shuttle bus.My reservation had been a few weeks prior via HK.The room was on the 18th floor and was numbered 1808.Complete with dressing room and sitting area it was more than a hotel room it, was a suite.The management has left a signed welcome letter, chocolates and two fresh bottles of juice.Asked " if I would stay at a a Peninsula property again"? My answer is " I stay at Peninsula properties only" This was my 6th individual Peninsula.

Why choose the Peninsula for your Tokyo trip? The staff are amazing; the rooms are enormous for Tokyo; the views are magnificent; and the location is second to none. I would not hesitate to recommend this hotel to my friends and family.

The Peninsula Tokyo is known for its extraordinary rooms (spacious, top of the line technology, luxurious, amenities) and stellar location, in the heart of Ginza. However, its their Concierge staff which puts it heads above its competitors. Akin Tanaka knows all of Tokyo's little secrets and gems -- covering both high and low and exceeding our expectations.

We stayed at the Peninsula for three days in October before beginning our cruise,and were very pleasantly surprised by the luxurious rooms and the superb service.The hotel is in a great location,close to shops and restaurants and within a 20 minute walk to the train station,should you wish to take the wonderful bullet train to many of the locations available.The staff at the Peninsula were most pleasant and helpful,and went out of their way to answer any questions and fulfill and needs we might have had.Should we return to Tokyo in the future,the Peninsula will be definitely our choice of hotel once more.

The Peninsula is located in such a great part of the Ginza district. You have world class shopping, the palace grounds, train stations all within walking district. We had the pleasure of staying here as the first stop of a 3 week Asia trip and it set the bar high. The staff was attentive and personal and our room was excellent. My husband and I were celebrating a big anniversary as well as a birthday and we were indulged with wine, fruit, cake etc. in our room upon our arrival. I want to say a very warm and heartfelt thank you to the Director of Rooms, Meret Brunner, who went out of her way to get to know us and to make sure that the Peninsula Bangkok knew we were going to be guests there next. She helped make an already wonderful experience at both hotels even more so! It's that personal touch that can truly make a difference. Peninsula corporate is very lucky to have Ms Brunner ,and her counterpart in Thailand, Ms Santos-Aniban in their employ.

The location of Peninsula Tokyo is splendid, locating in the heart of Ginza with hundreds of world class shops and restaurants. The room is very comfortable, divided into sections bathroom, closet, living and bed zone. Hotel concierge always recommend you with good restaurants and able to book them for you even though some restaurants are very very difficult to make a prompt reservation. The hotel also is very convenient as it is connected to subway Ginza line. You can go anywhere around Tokyo with this subway line. Been here many times.

The Peninsula exceeded our expectations in every way. The attention to detail was impressive. The employees were kind, polite and attentive to our every little need. They were quick to acknowledge us with bows, kind words and beautiful smiles. We were in room 1313. It was located at the end of the hall far from the elevators and was very quiet. The room had a large bathroom and a separate walk-in closet that had a sitting area with mirrors. I was able to do my hair and makeup in there while my husband showered and got ready in the bathroom. There was a door that separated the bathroom and dressing area from the room, which was nice when one of us got up earlier that the other. Each night when we returned to our room, the room attendant had closed the sheers, but not the shades, so that we were greeted by a stunning view of the city lights. At bedtime, we pushed a button to lower the shades which completely blocked out any light from outside. The bar on the top floor had a breath-taking view of the city. The service was lacking (could be b/c they don't accept tips). And the smoking drove me out fairly quickly. The spa was such a treat! The service was outstanding! My massage was one of the best I've every had. My masseuse wanted to make sure that everything was just right. Go early! The relaxation room (where you wait for your masseuse) is over the top (see picture). There are beds for you to lay in and headphones to listen to music. They are separated by dividers, so it's very private.

I stay here here almost every time I come to Tokyo (which is a lot!). The reason is because the rooms are great and the location is perfect. The one complaint though is that there aren't a lot of dining options for guests. The lobby bar is always too crowded catering for the peninsula afternoon tea. It really needs somewhere for hotel guests to grab a quick bite, drink or work between/after meetings. A couple of times I've just been forced to eat in my room, due to lack of other options.

I had high hopes for the peninsula Tokyo, as I have stayed a few times in Manila Peninsula and Peninsula Hong Kong. But not only is this the most expensive average of 650 usd per night, it has the least friendly staff (they don't even greet you before you enter the elevators as you pass the front desk every time to get there.)One of the most surprisingly terrible things about this place is for a 5 star hotel it has the tightest, most congested, difficult to walk and sit lobby I have seen for hotels of this caliber. Second, for 650 usd a night no free breakfast feels like highway robbery. (They do have some sort of food truck cafè you pay for in the back entrance, does this sound 5 star?)The rooms are spacious and you have a dressing room. This is the saving grace why I didn't give it a terrible rating, and just a poor one.Overall, I would stay in the Conrad Tokyo over this place any day. Better value, friendly staff, bigger lobby, nicer rooms at the Conrad.

Loved the spacious and contemporary designed room. Nice to have the dressing room to keep your belongings out of the way.Great service by the staff.If you are interested in shopping in the Ginza area, you can easily walk from the hotel. Subway stop connected under the hotel so transportation is super convenient. Highly recommend.

The hotel is located in an excellent spot close to the JR stations and nearby there's BIC Camera where you can get all the electronics and accessories from. First I was greeted by the friendly staff on arrival and the check in was very efficient. The room was very clean and was equipped with things that you normally would need. They do have an very nice view. Very good choice to stay in Japan for tour and shopping!

My boyfriend and I were very lucky to stay at their luxury suite for one night, everything was just perfect! What impressed me most was their laundry service, I think it was the best service I have ever had. Everything was folded neatly and placed in a traditional wooden box, and they used beautiful cloth to wrap up your clothes so they were separated by layers.Their valet box was also a highlighted! We stayed at the Hong Kong Peninsular before but we preferred the valet box in Tokyo, which is bigger and easier to get / place stuffs into it. And their coffee machine is also one of the best that I have ever used. It was a Lavazza machine and the coffee was even better than nespresso. In addition, guests staying at the suites can also use their mini-cooper service once a day from 10:30am to 7pm (you can check at the Transportation counter). We booked the car to send us to Asakusa, it was really convenient and saved us a lot of time! Everyone was friendly and helpful, the location was perfect and it was near a beautiful park and Imperial Palace. We had a great time there.

Traveled here with some girl friends for some Christmas shopping. Needless to say the stay was really comfortable. Extremely helpful and friendly staff. Location was excellent and within close proximity to major shopping area. Most large department stores offer free delivery to Peninsula so you just leave your shopping and hop on to your next stop without carrying a lot of bags around you. Would love to come back again!

Well my friends ! Talk about exquisite. Reception is great with the ladies dressed as bellboys. Common you never see that ! Front desk all over you. Escorted to the room by a gentleman speaking french ( he is learning ) Wow ! The room is electronic. Anything you can think of is wired. If you want to find your way, just press every button. All the gizmos are there and more. There is a valet service ( laundry and more) with a separate little closet for pick up. You can get better than that. Bar and restaurant on the 24th floor. Of course everything is expensive, what did you expect... It is the peninsula. Oufff !

We stayed for 3 nights in this beautiful hotel. It is very well located, just walking distance from Imperial Palace and to all majör attractions. There are several nice restaurants around and the Ginza Shopping paradise is minutes away from the hotel.The room we stayed had a fabolous view of the Imperial Park. The service and the staff makes you feel at home.

Spectacular hotel. Have stayed twice in 2016 - in May and in September. This hotel is on another level and is no surprise that it regularly wins awards. Attention to detail is like no other hotel i've stayed anywhere. From the white-gloved attendant spinning the rotating entrance door, to the amazing wood sculpture in the atrium, this hotel is amazing. The rooms are at least 2x the size of typical rooms in other nice hotels and equipped with luxury items that make staying here a real treat. Full size walk-in closet, Lavazza espresso machine in the room, automation for lights, blinds, etc. were all executed to an impeccable level. The food options in the hotel itself are excellent, albeit as you would expect, not for the budget conscious. This hotel currently rates on my personal list as the best i've stayed in anywhere.

Recently visited this hotel for our honeymoon and we had the chance to try few of the Michelin restaurants in town, despite most of the top restaurants were fully booked. Thanks to the Concierge team for reserving them and the effort in promptly replying our emails. We got upgraded to the city view room facing the imperial palace. The room is spacious, especially the closet, just perfect for me and my wife. The amenities in the bathroom are well sufficient.Hotel location is just few mins walking distance from Ginza and has an easy access to subway station Hibiya and JR Yurakcho. Taxi to most part in town e.g. Shibuya/Aoyama is within 1500-2000 yen.We just love this hotel and the 5stars service. Would definitely come back again.

If you're going to propose to get married in a hotel in Tokyo, please let it be the Peninsula. With stunning views of Ginza and the Imperial Palace, the Peninsula is an oasis of perfection in the epicentre of Tokyo. The concierge's assistance to prepare long stemmed roses in the room upon arrival accompanied by a personal love note set the mood. The staff overall could not have been more polite or attentive -- even by Japanese standards and ensured all logistics went according to plan. All in all it was a magical stay.

Great location, within easy walk to Ginza and is well connected by a rail and subway. Upon arrival I was lead straight to my suite, the check in was done in my suite and it was completed in 5 mins. The room is well designed, comes with luxury amenities that pamper our stay. Staffs are friendly and efficient. Highly recommended luxury hotel in Tokyo.

We had a palace/park view room on the 20th floor. Well worth the premium. Room was very spacious and the lighting was fantastic. Service was impeccable! Only disappointment was the lobby area which was dominated by the day cafe. Had cocktails in Peter on the 24th floor. Great views of the palace in the evening.

I've stayed at the hotel a few times before for business but this was the first for a leisure trip. The location of the hotel is convenient as it is right above of the Hibiya subway station, at the end of Ginza and Marunochi area. Peninsula standards for room (very spacious for Japan standards) and facilities don't disappoint including a great pool area that overlooks the Imperial Palace crossing! Room service menu is also fantastic. The concierge service could be more proactive in providing sightseeing suggestions and options though.

We chose the Peninsula Tokyo for our recent honeymoon in Japan. We could not have been happier with our experience.We were greeted by the kind and attentive staff who informed us that because we were celebrating our honeymoon, we had been upgraded to a suite on the 23rd (top) floor. The room was spectacular. It had 10-12 foot ceilings with a view of Tokyo Bay, his and hers vanities with a TV in the bathroom, separate tub and shower, a sitting area and the closet was more of a "dressing room" with a vanity and more space than one could ever need on vacation. We took advantage of all the room had to offer, utilizing our Lavazza in room coffee maker that put out delicious coffee each morning for us. The separate tub and shower were a treat. The curtains, lights and thermostat were all controlled by a remote next to the bed. Turn down service each night consisted of slippers being placed next to the bed along with free bottles of water on each nightstand. The curtains were closed and "mood lighting" was set. The only complaint we had were the outlets - helpfully, the room was stocked with outlets that were 110v and 220v - but there were none on the nightstands for our phones. The staff was always plentiful and helpful. Everyone spoke english and we had no problems communicating. We asked the concierge desk to assist us with a dining reservation and they went above and beyond to be of service. We debated staying at various luxury hotels in Tokyo and we chose The Peninsula for it's location, which did not disappoint. Ginza is an excellent neighborhood to base yourself in for exploring Tokyo. I would compare it to staying on Rodeo Drive in Beverly Hills. There is high end shopping everywhere. Even if that isn't your taste, the hotel is walking distance from Tokyo Station and the Imperial Gardens. We walked to pretty much every meal we had during our stay. The few times we needed the subway, it was easily accessed from one of the many stations in the area. All of Tokyo is very safe but Ginza felt particularly safe. It was a truly special experience for us staying at The Peninsula Tokyo and we didn't want to leave. We felt so spoiled and enjoyed it so much. The Peninsula has a lifetime customer in us after our excellent experience at their Tokyo location, we can't wait to stay at other Peninsula properties.

Amazing service, sophisticated. Pleasant surprises at every turn. Every one in the staff is detailed oriented. I found only one negative : no lobby bar and no comfortable place in the lobby area to seat and wait. The lobby area is used up by one of their restaurants.

Definitely one of the best hotels I ever visited!!! The room was spectacular, very spacious, modern and elegant. The staff was exquisite and customer-minded. The hotel is in the city centre and you can reach everything from there. Wonderful stay!!!!!

Been staying at The Peninsula Tokyo since 2013 and this hotel has never lose her charms. Best of everything! The best locations, service,security, friendliness, cleanliness, the best room and size and even the ambience is perfect! I come to Tokyo every year and I always stay at The Peninsula. This hotel has always been my second home away from home. Always feel welcomed with that warm smile!

My fitst time to Tokyo A short but highly enjoyable stay in this amazing cityThe Peninsula hotel offers luxury and service equal to none.. you wouldn't expect anything else from the Japanese Very centrally located, a short stroll away from the famous fish markets and central park. I would definitely stay there away..
