This hotel has it allWe checked into a gorgeous suite and fell in love with the carefully thought out layoutThen we looked at the bathroomOMG!!!!I want that toiletWhen you step inside the private room the toilet lid opens!!!How does it know??This toto toilet is incredible I used every excuse to sit Room service is amazingOrder the Japanese breakfast and enjoy Hotel services were fantastic and I loved the neighborhood Excellent choice

You get what you pay for! Awesome hotel with everything you could ever want available. Never had a room with a nail dryer in the dressing room before! Excellent location in the Ginza area of Tokyo - all the top designers have stores in the vicinity.

Thank you for making our anniversary even more special!It's an excellent hotel located in a lively, central area. They allowed us an early check in (9:00am) and late check out (4:00pm) which was much needed and appreciated. We also requested a top floor room, which wasn't a problem. Overall, great service, scenic views and a bottle of champagne made our stay unforgettable.We would love to come back and would define recommend it.

I have stayed at this hotel twice now and at The Peninsular Hotel in Hong Kong and I love them, everything about this hotel screams professionalism, perfection, class, comfort and happiness. The staff are truly excellent, they are a credit to this hotel and its brand. The amenities are second to none, seeing is believing, the rooms are so modern and comfortable that when I visit I find it difficult to leave the hotel and discover Tokyo. Thank you Peninsular for another fantastic stay.

We stayed at the peninsula more than a week. We arrived midnight and the check in was smooth . The room was beautiful as My favourite colours are orange and gold and the room atmosphere combined both those colours. The bathroom was beautiful and I couldn't ask more. The hotel location in ideal for people who loves Ginza. It was walking distance almost 5 min to mitsukoshi department store. A plus point that hotel is connected to Hibiya metro line. We took the mini copper ride it was phenomenal and they offer us late check out as it was my sister birthday I appreciate it. Thank you for all peninsula team and special thanks to the manager who made my sister birthday unforgettable.

I walked for three hours to visit the imperial garden as I couldn't work out how to use the metro but I'm glad I did as I was able to explore this part of town. On my way back I passed the Peninsula hotel and so treated myself to a three course meal on the top floor restaurant with views over the garden. The staff are friendly and welcoming and the service was second to none. The portions were generous and the meal was very good value for money. I totally recommend this restaurant with lovely views of the city. You never get disappointed with the peninsula chain , I stayed at the Manila peninsula on my second leg of my Asia tour.

This hotel was really perfect on every pointRoom are very beautiful, well decoratedConcierge are very professional with great advice for every request upThe spa is wonderful and treatment are great !!!!!!I definitely found my home in Tokyo !!!!!!!

On a two day business stay, this hotel offers all you can ask for. Very nice and clean rooms, off course.very convient location next to the train station, we had and easy trip from Narita International.and great service makes this hotel a dream to stay in.Also my room had a great view over the palace.

Stayed for 5 days in July, 2016. Guest Service Manager Natsuko Fujiwara provided fabulous top notce service. On our last day of the trip, wife had a pair of jeans that she needed to return to a store couple train stations away from Ginza. We were running late for our flight, and the Ms. Fujiwara was super kind and offered to return the jeans for us, and gave us the refund. I would return just because of Ms. Fujiwara's superb service. She really sets the standard for Peninsula Tokyo. We were traveling with a 1 year old, and the hotel provided excellent baby amendities as well. Hotel location was very convenient. Overall, had a great time in Peninsula Tokyo.

In a perfect location for visiting Tokyo...just across from the Imperial Palace, the Peninsula is a welcome retreat after a day of exploring....A lovely breakfast in the lobby restaurant, with about the best French Toast ever!...Gorgeous, modern floral arrangements in the minimalist entry...glassy polished floors and attention to all details make this a perfect stay.Only problem is that the bar at the top of the hotel was packed every night, and we didn't get a chance to have a drink and drink in the magnificent view!

This hotel is one of my favorites in Tokyo. The service is excellent and location is terrific. It is right across the street from the park for the Imperial Palace, which is a great walk and tour (plan for a 4-5 mile walking day). It is also close to great shopping. The train station is connected to the hotel (subway) and that makes it easy to get anywhere. Enjoy!

You get what you pay for - and though the Peninsula isn't cheap - it is absolutely exquisite. The room was huge and lovely, the staff friendly and helpful, the food delicious. Everything about our stay was perfect. This hotel is also in a great part of town - we live in Tokyo and came here for our anniversary. We chose Ginza for the proximity to shopping and restaurants... it is also literally steps away from a major subway station. I also think this would be a great business choice, and many families at breakfast had kids. So it seems a great choice for any kind of travel.

The hotel is outstanding in many ways. It has a tradition in hosting, as it belongs to a hotel chain based in Hong Kong since 1866, so the furniture is a perfect match for a traveler that wants to feel home, well, not a common home, but in a very special home, extremely elegant in all aspects, good taste and also fabulous material for garments in all sectors. Tradition for a hotel, in this case, does not mean necessarily be truly antique, instead, it means to offer a good sense of comfort, it embraces you with warm but soft colours, every single detail has these two concepts entangled: great design / comfort. I stayed with friends, in an apartment with a view to the Imperial Palace, a few steps from the Metro, 3 minutes walk from Ginza and 5 min drive from the huge, central, Tokyo Station, where you can get trains to and fro all airports and main Shinkansen bullet train lines. It is not cheap, as you can imagine, but when you decide for a luxurious place, that's average. I found it enchanting and would recommend. The staff is also friendly, definitely hospitable and everything works out perfectly, with all necessary modern technology and life style, from Illy expresso coffee machine, to huge bath tube, to perfect blind curtains to spacious, wide, windows with a fantastic view.

I have stayed at almost all the five star hotels in Tokyo in the past. And the reason I come back to this hotel has to be the location. I can jog in the morningby the Imperial palace n Hibiya park right across the street from the hotel n it is right at the center of Ginza where all the famouse shops are and the restaurants..And if you still want to go to other places, you can get on the Hibiya line thru the basement.And all other metro lines are right next to the hotel. I think it is best to reserve park view room for it issurrounded by tall office buildings that you might get a room facingnext building. The restaurants are OK but nothing special.

From the time you arrive, during the entire stay, and when you depart the staff is a pure delight. I brought my family on a business trip and they loved the hotel, location, and kind staff. They remembered preferences, made notes of small requests and delivered on them, and said hello by name every time they saw us throughout the stay.

We had 2 large Deluxe rooms for a family of 4 and had a wonderful time for a 3 nights stay. Service was very efficient, nice and discret. Swimming pool is huge, with a very good service. The only negative point was the breakfast which is served in the Lobby where no intimacy can be found. It is more a place where a lot of people come and go. It was weird to eat in such an entrance place, but I have to admit that food quality was really excellent.Nevertheless, overall ambience is very calm and quiet. Situation is perfect for visiting many attractions and we enjoyed a lot to stay at this luxury hotel.

Was hoping to be blown away with the experience of my stay at The Peninsula Tokyo with all the reviews I was reading online. While the place was generally nice, I won't be able to say that it was an experience I will never forget. Rooms, though very clean, weren't exciting in design. The bathroom was very huge but again nothing of note. Service was good but I think I've experienced better service elsewhere. If there was one thing I will remember about my stay here was the ebi tempura I ordered for room service. That was stellar and probably the best I had in the whole of Tokyo. High standards come with the high price you pay for a stay. I spent about $600/night. I'd probably give it 5 stars if they only charged $400/night.

Always known for excellent service and attentive staff, Tokyo Peninsula did not disappoint. Our adjoining corner suite was very spacious with the best walk-in closets I've ever seen at a hotel. We would have loved more time to hang around and enjoy the luxury of the hotel but we had to sight see. Hotel in the Ginza area and close to shopping. Lucky for us, the lobby restaurant is open very early in the morning for the jet lagged as there is nothing open in the area until 11 am! Great stay, great hotel.. Peninsula every time!

Although this is not the finest Peninsula, that honor belongs to either the Hong Kong or Shanghai branches, the hotel stands on its own with excellent amenities, good food and service you expect from the Peninsula. The hotel is close to the Palace and across the street from a small relaxing park. The hotel is walking distance to the Ginza shopping district. We were in Room 1712. This is a suite with a long entrance hall, a good sized powder room and a large living room. Like all Peninsula's the room has very good electronic controls over everything from temperature to closing the curtains. The suite is decorated in muted tones of brown with traditional Japanese designs inlaid in the carpeting. The bedroom is comfortable with a large wall unit and workdesk. Bed and pillows were comfy and the room has VOIP so you can make calls anywhere in the world for free. There is a large dressing room with makeup table. The bathroom floor is heated, a nice touch and there are 2 vanities, a glassed in shower and separate toilet room with a Toto Neorest toilet. This suite does not have great views. You look 2 different directions at skyline and train tracks. Much better is a room facing the park. The rooftop restaurant is very cool. Great lighting, a wall with animated characters constantly changing and music blaring. The view was great, and the steaks were decent although the service was not attentive either at dinner or at lunch. The first floor restaurant's food was excellent both at breakfast and lunch and service much better than at the rooftop restaurant. Service from the hotel staff was uniformly excellent

The Peninsula Tokyo , truly an art Gallery, upon arrival you will be amazed by the beauty of it’s lobby. Very Friendly Staff, and they will do anything to best serve you. The hotel is very well located in an area surrounded by great stores and restaurants, the concierge team will take care of all your needs. There is a subway station inside the hotel, which is a huge plus. The inside heated swimming pool, next to the spa, is a must, as is to dine at the Restaurant Peter, at the rooftop with it’s amazing view of Tokyo and The Imperial Palace. Everything in the rooms are automated, high end technology, simply fantastic.One of the best hotels in the world that i had the pleasure to stay. I Hope to return soon.

Love this hotel. Staff were very attentive and amenities were great. Upon knowing that i have a 3yr old child with me, they prepared the room with child amenities which were very useful. Great location and excellent service.However, maybe its time to change the prams that were provided for the guests to use? The one we got was dirty and slightly faulty. (and not very user friendly as it needed a few steps to fold the pram.)Otherwise, a great experience and will come and stay again~

Just got back home last night. Stayed at Peninsula Hotel! Good ambience n excellent services! All staff can speak English well. It's one of the better locations! Shopping around n find the best Shabu Shabu at a regular price or one of the exquisite Teppanyaki in Tokyo! Truly one of the better hotels in the right location

This was or second stay in the Peninsula, and every bit as luxuriously good as the , first. This is an amazing hotel, in the best location in Tokyo, between the Ginza and the Imperial Palace. All staff are professional and attentive; during our stay, Ms Meret Brunner, Director of Rooms came by one breakfast, chatting with us and other guests. That interest in guest experience and gathering first hand impressions as part of a management role is one of the reasons the Peninsula group excels. Our ‘room’ was spacious, and on a corner of the building with lovely views in each direction. It included a large dressing room, and a sitting area as well as an ultra comfortable bed and ravishing bathroom. It is worth saying there for the bathtub alone! The pool area was a lovely respite from the heat, with well-appointed change rooms and other facilities. Breakfast in the lobby restaurant provided many options, our favourite being the granola, yoghurt and fruit. In the basement of the hotel is the amazing Peninsula Boutique & Café perfect for light lunches or sublime pastries. These can be purchased for takeout, and staff will wrap and box them with exquisite care and the requisite cutlery and tiny ice packs.One aspect of the location that we enjoyed was the proximity not only to the Imperial Palace and its gardens, but also to Hibiya Park, a lovely little oasis perfect for strolling. It packs ponds and flower beds, benches and multilevel pathways into a comparatively small space, just across the street from the hotel.

Travelled with my wife to meet our son in Tokyo for a four night stay. Outstanding service, best spa experience and Narumi is the best concierge we have ever experienced. She was just brilliant. Look forward to returning.

Having heard so much about the Peninsula Tokyo, I was a little disappointed with the hotel when I stayed there. The rooms are nice and spacious but everything feels a little dated. The lobby just does not have the grandeur of a Peninsula. The two sofas for the "waiting area" are horridly placed and hardly enough for guest use. Service was OK. We were disappointed that even though we had 4 rooms, they would not even allow late check-out (just till lunch time) for for ANY room. I do understand this is the hotel's discretion, but 1 out of 4 would have been a nice gesture. They could have been a little more generous with the drinking water given that bottled water is not expensive in Japan.

My family was lucky for upgrades the room type to be the deluxe suite, the view was amazing when we looked out of the window and the room was large. The hotel provide very high standing service, so the room always clean. Also, I liked the swimming pool provide people goggles and bathing cap, it would be convenient.Around the hotel, there have so many big shopping malls as most ladies love to go. But for me, I am very enjoyable many kinds of good taste restaurants just steps away from the hotel.For sure, I will bring my family come back again in future. 今次行程非常幸運升級了套房，房間非常之大而且景觀還非常美麗。不得不說，整個房間都很乾淨，浴巾係我暫時用過最舒服的。

I stayed at the Peninsula in Tokyo for the first time on a 3-day business trip. The hotel is centrally located, about a 15 minute walk from Tokyo Station and a 5 minute walk from the Imperial Palace. The hotel lobby is beautiful, and features a cafe/restaurant and some upscale shops. Where to start? I was upgraded to a park view suite, which had a king bed, a sitting area close to the foot of the bed, a large screen TV, huge, picture windows, and an astonishing array of electronic controls placed around the room. From the bedside phone, you can control TV, electric shades and climate/temperature. The room had a HUGE walk in closet, and a very large bathroom with a large soaker tub and a walk-in shower. The room was probably 750 sq feet in total, the views were great, all in all, as good a room as i have ever stayed in for a city hotel. The service was exceptional pretty much every way that i turned. I got an excellent restaurant recommendation exactly at the price point i wanted, superb directions when needed, a towel and bottled water when i returned from a run, etc. The staff was warm and professional. There is a complimentary fitness center at the hotel with a spectacular pool (for cooling off or for swimming laps) a large adjacent hot tub/spa and even an outdoor sitting area off of the pool. The pool area also featured a number of chaise lounge chairs for those who want to sit by the pool. I didn't use the exercise facility but it looked top-notch.The hotel is a short walk from the imperial palace, which is great for runners, as there is a 3-mile loop around the palace that is traffic free. from the hotel, around the loop and back is about 3.75 miles, with only a couple of stoplights to deal with. This is a must for any runners! All in all, just a top-notch hotel in every way -- accommodation, service, location, and i would love to go back. There is a rooftop bar and western-style grill restaurant in the hotel, but i did not get a chance to try it.
user_name:
familyfoodie1
New York City, New York

review_body: I stayed in Peninsula 6 times , I'll still come more and more in the next visits to japan , the best of everything room / lobby / spa & gym / services / friendly staff and location .Also the view toward the guardian is insane besides walking distance to metro and JR train station .

As of the writing of this review, I had previously rated 16 hotels 5-bullseyes. The Peninsula Tokyo gives me the urge to go back and downgrade each of those experiences because they cannot compare. Every single aspect of the Peninsula Tokyo, including the price, is premium. No detail is ignored and everything about the hotel is laid out in a practical and spectacular fashion. When you arrive, the first impression is a stunning lobby with giant art installations. Despite the art installations, the lobby maintained a clean look and was not cluttered. Around the corner, there is a reception area where check in occurs. I booked the hotel using Amex Fine Hotels and was explained my added benefits. A porter took my bag to the room and showed me how to use the extensive technology in the hotel room.As an aside, I typically find "smart" hotel rooms annoying and not very functional. Half the buttons dont work and you typically cant even open the shades without just ripping them open. However, every switch, button or knob in the Peninsula Tokyo was clearly labeled and very intuitive. Everything was easy to use. The Deluxe Room is sort of like a junior suite in that the main area had a bed, but also a couch and small breakfast table and desk. There was a giant walk in closet that had all the accoutrement anyone would need. Finally, the bathroom was spectacular including a tv in the mirror and the famed Japanese toilet that also served as a bidet. How this has not caught on in the United States is a mystery that needs to be immediately investigated. This hotel is also connected directly to the train station so getting around is easy. The concierge is very helpful and we used them to set up an English speaking tour that made Tokyo very accessible to a first timer. I am a huge fan of this hotel and would love to return at some point. Highly recommend.

As Annie Lennox once said, I've traveled the world and the Seven Seas, and it doesn't get much more plush, more inviting, more welcoming, and more comfortable than The Peninsula Tokyo. Forget the "Heavenly Bed" at Westin, this was the most comfortable bed ever, with a perfect comforter, down pillows, and smooth perfect white sheets. I could write volumes on the toilet alone, as being from Los Angeles, I'm not used to Japanese toilet technology. Suffice it to say, I happily spent time on the porcelain thrown, and my butt never felt better. Don't be concerned about the nonsense you'll read about the supposedly bad location. You're two blocks from the Ginza, and two blocks from multiple subway stops, and across the street from the glorious Imperial Gardens. If you don't want to pay high prices for hotel food (although the food in The Peninsula is predictably excellent), walk outside, make a left turn and walk two blocks toward the elevated train tracks, and underneath you'll find blocks of amazing and affordable restaurants, some holes in the wall, some more upscale, some offering sidewalk tables, giving you enough choices to eat for a month. And, if you just want a snack and don't even want to think about looking in the mini-bar (always good advice), there's a 7-11 a block away, which itself is fun adventure in Tokyo. The Concierge desk is super helpful, suggesting good tour companies, and another time arranging a visit to a doctor for a quickly resolved medical issue. I know some hotels are ranked higher, but to do so must be like comparing Da Vinci to Michelangelo. I had a "standard" room on the 22nd floor, and it that's "standard," the better rooms must be Buckingham Palace. I know rates vary depending on who you book with, but whatever you pay, once in the room you'll tell yourself it's worth every penny. The staff is friendly, helpfully spoke decent English, and would do anything and everything. As you can tell, I have a lot of things to say about The Peninsula Tokyo, all good. I paid a lot of money for the experience and instead of regretting it, I can't wait to go back.

Incredible room...large, spotless, perfect sheets, comfortable beds, large bathroom, excellent amenities, quick laundry service etc etc. Excellent views of the palace Gardens and easy to get to anywhere on foot and subway. Staff a little on the clinical side.

We have stayed at a few Peninsula Hotels and decided to choose this one for our trip to Japan. We really enjoyed the Peninsula in Hong Kong and have stayed there many times. The Peninsula in Tokyo itself is fairly nice but a bit dated. The decor in the room can use some updating...we stayed in a suite overlooking the Imperial Palace. The location is great, near Ginza for restaurants and other things to do. However, their concierge is terrible. They don't know anything and needed a lot of pushing just to get them to make reservations to restaurants. They made me feel like I was bothering them. Their recommendations were no good and they were terrible at coming up with any good ideas. Frankly, service level is what really set luxury hotels apart at this price point and this Peninsula's substantial failure in this area is highly disappointing. We will not be back!

Very good breakfast service, nice bar at the 24th floor. Spacious room with walk-in closet, huge bathroom. Huge swimming pool and jaccuzzi, spa treatments. Excellent service in all areas of the hotel. Helpful concierge service, free bicycles. Small shoping area.

I stayed here for two nights on business and enjoyed a comfortable stay. Location is excellent with shops and restaurants nearby. Rooms were nicely decorated and was in a good condition. Concierge service was very good and recommended good restaurants and shops. There's an ippudo ramen place nearby which was great for a quick lunch. I came back late one evening and wanted to buy some random gifts for back home so they recommended a nearby 24 hr store and only 5 mins by taxi where I found what I needed. I would stay here again if I'm ever in the area.

I travelled with a well behaved 6 year old. This hotel went out of the way to make my family but particularly my child welcome. He was super excited to get a small welcome gift in the room and loved doing the hotel quiz/treasure hunt. The hotel felt quite personal even though it was large. In a good area with great eating options. I asked for a casual restaurant suggestion and the hotel directed me to a 24 hour sushi place under the railway. We loved it. There is a muji nearby with a nice cafe and a local burger place across the road if you need to grab something really quick for a sleepy child. The hotel does a thoughtful kids breakfast.The hotel has a pool and doesn't charge any crazy fees for usage. The best thing we did in Tokyo is hire bikes with a tag a long bike from Tokyo Miracle Tours. Surprisingly easy and safe to ride bikes in Tokyo. Disneyland was a fail for us. The lines were too long.

We usually choose to stay at the Peninsula for the service and location. They also have some thing new each time for us to try. One time was ride around the neighborhood in a hotel owned Rolls Royce. This time was a ride around in their pen bikes. It is a motorized tricycle that works like a moped bike/Segway. The electric assisted pedal bike was a fun way to explore nearby sights, including the imperial palace, Tokyo station, etc. fairly quickly and enjoyably. Service is always impeccable and they always remember your preferences from your previous visits, which always makes you feel very welcome.
user_name:
fdtvfan9
New York City, New York

review_body: I really enjoyed the actual room, it was an intuitive, the bath: with the most amazing spa settings. Not to mention the best sleep I had in Japan (talk about the best pillows I have ever experienced).The bar although incredibly cool, just wasn't for me: the service was impeccibleTime to confess: i was really looking into wearing the nightwear, but I had no idea how to actually do this.Lowlights: the food and drink is a bit expensive.

This is the place I usually stay whenever I have business trip to Tokyo. It's very convenient. The subway station is just downstairs. Ginza is just 5 mins walk. The hotel itself is nice just like any other peninsula. The staff are great and helpful.

This was my first trip to Tokyo and I wanted to do it right. My wife and I booked a suite at the Peninsula. While pricey, I thought for the size of the room and comparing it to what I get in NYC, it was actually a very good value (everything if relative). Fantastic location in Ginza and very convenient to great shopping, food, museums, etc. Tip: Get the package that includes breakfast. Your choice of Western or Japanese breakfast is a no brainer (other than having two great choices). The lounge on the property, Peters, is great for a late night drink and view of the city.

I liked this hotel personally, nice room size, clean, good location. I did not have any problem dealing with the hotel staff. They response quick after I send the email to request borrow a charger before I arrive.Unfortunately, my friend who arrange diner reservation was terribly upset with the service of Peninsula.The following was what they told us:First they asked the hotel staffs to help them make restaurant reservation, but they did not do it until one of them send a complain letter through email.I am not sure was it because the complain letter. My friend receieved a kind of "warning" letter from the hotel after she tried to change her reservation second time. I was surprise to hear that and I was surprised to see the letter . yes, that's is real!!If this was the second time to change reservation, I do not think the hotel should send a letter to a client to "warn" them that they cannot be late and it was difficult to change the reservation. I would prefer the hotel staff said they can not change the reservation in person instead of send a customer a warning letter. I understand a lot of people don't like Chinese. But I and my friends are very polite, civilize and educated. This is unfair to label all Chinese as Bad clients. We are from Hong Kong ,China. We are frequent traveller, we understand how to behave when we are out of Hong Kong. the reaction of Peninsular surprised me a lot. If they hate Chinese. Please write: Chinese are not welcome in their web site. There are many places to stay in Japan.

We stayed here 4 nights. Location was excellent not just for Ginza but also access to the north (Ueno Park and Museums, Edo Museum), North West (Shinjuku, Omote-Sando, Daikanyama...) and Haneda. Subway is directly linked to hotel lobby and less than 5 min walk. We stayed at Palace Hotel last year (also 5 stars) and the subway was much further away- even tho' they had access to more lines. The rooms were very spacious, beautifully furnished and looks new. The bath had a spa button that dims the lights and provides soothing music for a relaxing soak. The auto lifting toilet seats were a nice touch still not common in other hotels.The gym was also great as it uses the latest Technogym Artis line and is linked to my own customised runs and recording (I have the same treadmill at home).Service was also excellent- more at the international standard compared to the very Japanese style at Palace (discreet but ever present). But we had to queue up at concierge on a few occasions.Would definitely return here again!

This is a great hotel in a great location -- perfect for our family vacation. I rarely use a hotel pool, but the pool/ spa was exceptional, and a nice respite from the craziness of Tokyo. We also had fun using the hotel's three wheeled bikes to tour the nearby Imperial Palace. Room service was also excellent. We'd definitely stay here again!

Stayed here three nights with my daughter in June. Very nice room; large, very comfortable. The public spaces (restaurant) are a bit small, but otherwise the hotel was great. Very good location near the palace park, Tokyo Station, a subway line, and the fish market. Overall, very good.

I traveled to Tokyo for a business trip last month and stayed at a couple different hotels. The Peninsula in Tokyo was outstanding and by far the best of the bunch. It was one of the nicest rooms I've ever stayed in. It was spacious, well appointed, spotless clean and comfortable. The service and the staff were top notch. The location of the hotel is right in the center of the action in the city. Great shopping, culture and restaurants are within walking distance. This is a must stay if you are looking for luxury accommodations in Tokyo.

I generally don't care about high end full service hotels. I don't need to be pampered. However, while I didn't take advantage of the Spa and many other things the hotel offers, the room and the service are of the highest quality. The location is also incredibly central to lots of entertainment, restaurants, shopping and business activities. It's not cheap but you do get what you pay for.

This was my second time in Tokyo on a mission to hit some Michelin starred restaurants. The first go I managed to book Narisawa, Kanda, and Mizutani. Afterwards I realized how lucky I was to manage those bookings.Second time around a friend mentioned staying at The Peninsula would help. Sure enough the concierge managed to book Jiro (not worth it), Ryu Gin, Sawada, Koyju, and Saito. Concierge was happy to help make a dent in the wallet!
user_name:
gambit76
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: This hotel was welcoming, impressive and really good quality. The room had everything you would need when visiting. The restaurants in the hotel are excellent, Peters is especially good, and as it is on the top floor you get a great view of the city. The staff could not be better, friendly and efficient.I recommend Peninsula when in Tokyo

The hotel located in heart of Tokyo in the most attractive shopping district that name Genza, the hotel is so expensive however the rooms was so fantasy that equipped with all needed, The sky bar is in the top level with amazing view and nice atmosphere, there is a nice restaurant in the ground floor that offer many tasty foods, nearby hotel a large list of restaurants and most famous shop brand.

My Family and I booked a holiday the peninsula and I enjoyed my stay the moment I set foot in the hotel!The swimming pool had music underneath the water and when we got there that was a huge bottle of champagne for my parents and chocolate for me and my brother! I really enjoyed my stay and would love to come back again!!!!

A wonderfully located Hotel with Ginza a short walk away and the out of the way local bars under the railway just at the back of the Hotel.The Hotel itself was very nicely done - not as big as many of its Five Star rivals it manages to over deliver on comfort and has some great extras like the Mini Concierge Service for those booking the Suite Experience - which we did and was a great deal.The Pool is wonderful and the bar 'Peter' a great stop for a Martini before dinner with a wonderful view over the Imperial Palace. The only thing that held me back from a Five Star Trip Advisor rating was the inability of the Hotel to find a car to take us to Narita with 18 hours notice - all hotel cars were booked and external vendors unavailable even at yen57k - we ended up taking an Uber Black - high end Limousine at Yen27k - so blessing in disguise and only needed 8mins notice!I would definitely stay at this Hotel again.

Stayed here for 5 nights for a holiday trip to Tokyo. Everything is just first class. We liked the layout of the room, the bathroom was huge (we enjoyed the high tech toilet with the automatic cover and heated seat. I guess this might be normal for a 5-star hotel in Japan). Breakfast is not a buffet but you choose from an a la carte menu, we had tried a lot of the selections since we were staying several days and everything we had was delicious. There is this hollow space in the middle of the building where they installed light sculptures which you can see from the elevator lobby, it's just impressive how they even spent for this art installation for the guests to enjoy. Service was exceptional of course.I've been to Tokyo three times now and stayed in other hotels on my other two trips. Our stay at the Peninsula Tokyo is still the best experience so far.

Impeccable hotel and service for a hotel that's in the downtown of a huge city like Tokyo. It's price is less than it should be. Everything is automatic and controlled by buttons. Every detail in the room is chosen carefully and tastefully. U can choose to play soothing music in the room and/or bathroom. Mood lights, hand sanitizer, a whole dressing/vanity room (huge) for all your stuff. The layout is perfect, the room is very spacious and clean cut! Ofcourse being in Japan, the hotel staff are the sweetest most helpful ever. There is a lovely lady at the concierge desk called Rika, so very helpful! Enjoy!

We were there for five nights seven couples that's like 35 nights given to the hotel .we got lucky to accidentally meet the general manager at check in .Ms Sophia she politely asked me if all was well and I requested her for a better view room. ..from 1710 which had a huge building in front we were moved to 1802 fabulous view. The Imperial palace grounds on one side and the Tokyo Tower on the other side . We thoroughly enjoyed our stay just because of that. The spa is to die for. The massages were outstanding . Ms orisa was amazing. The breakfast was very sumptuous and fresh yummy food .The amenities are fantastic and cleanliness was super good. Staff very polite and ever so helpful. The hotel is absolutely centrally located as Ginza is just a short walk away.Thank you Ms Sophia for making our stay superb.. A word of caution .don't book through Thomas cook india as they really gave us lousy service .charged us for luxury vacation and gave us second class treatment. Thomas crook is what I call them now.

Was here for one night on my flight to Asia.Very attentive service. Nothing is too big or too small for the hotel staff. The breakfast was good. The front desk also took care of my transportation to the airport. Everyone spoke great English, so fret not international traveler!Asian hospitality is definitely distinctive above all others.
user_name:
T767TUrobertb
New York City, New York

review_body: This was my first stay in a Peninsula property, and having worked for The Ritz-Carlton many years ago, I was not sure if it would live up to my expectations. Wow, did it ever! Service was great yet unobtrusive, and the property is absolutely stunning. It has to be the most beautiful hotel I've ever stayed in. The lobby is so beautiful, and the rooms are so perfectly thought out with every detail and luxury you could ever want. I loved the technology and organization so much I took photos of the toilet, the bathtub controls (spa setting is a must!), the coffee cabinet and the valet box and nail dryer in the closet. If you want to be spoiled, stay here! Plus, the location is fabulous - it is so quiet, yet in the middle of everything. On our last morning it rained, and we swam and sat in the jacuzzi overlooking the Imperial Palace gardens. Wow.

This is a great hotel with the renowned Peninsula tradition. From the moment you arrive you feel as if you are the only guest and the full staff is at your service. The suite we had was first class with great view on the park. We had a complimentary hotel Mini with a driver to show us around one day which was great as we used it on Sunday to tour Tokyo with little traffic. Breakfast has top choices, only service, no buffet which is an advantage as everything is quite and service was fast. The only disadvantage of this hotel is that there is no real lobby or lobby bar and the top floor bar, Peter’s, was not very friendly. The spa facilities are great and the pool is large enough with great views. The gym is well equipped. Location is excellent and very near to Tokyo station which is a big advantage for arrival and departure by air or train. We hope to be back soon.

Hotel is in an excellent location just walking distance from all the major international brands and many restaurants .... Huge hotel with good sized rooms ... Loved the walk in closet we had ... Amazing service ... I was looking for a particular brand of rice crackers I had eaten in Osaka and our amazing concierge managed to find some for me and leave it in our room while we were outside the hotel...breakfast restuarant seating was not very impressive as you are literally sitting in the reception area / lobby ... However the food selection and quality was good ... They managed some gluten free options for me as well....will definitely want to stay here the next time I am in Tokyo

The hotel is stunning. The rooms are amazing, full of really practical gadgets ( why has no one exported Japanese toilets to the UK?) the staff calmly and quietly helpful and the location is wonderful. It s very quiet but right in the centre of the action.This is the first time we have stayed at a Peninsula Hotel and I hope it won't be the last.

Had a fantastic stay at the Peninsula. Service was impeccable, as one would expect. Location was perfect -- right next to all the shopping and restaurants in Ginza, and within walking distance from Tokyo station and the business district. Experienced a small earthquake during stay, but building felt solid as a rock. Only minus was the breakfast -- it was a bit 'meh', but given all the alternative eateries around the hotel, not a big issue. Would definitely stay there again.

This is a good hotel but a few things are missing for it to be a great hotel. First the food. I don't like to have my breakfast in the lobby entrance. Secondly it is difficult to eat after 10 pm (only room service is available). The Peter bar has a great view but the deco is horrible and the seats uncomfortable. The waiters bother you every 5 mn to ask you if you want another glass. Believe me when I want another glass you'll know it...Finally I was very unhappy with the organisation of the hotel at the entrance regarding taxis. One morning I had to take a taxi and it was raining. It looked very disorganised. Everyone was run ing towards the taxi, the staff were run ing around the cars and it seemed that every body was overtaking me. There was no queue. They should do waht they do in Singapore or HK regarding taxi queues. I must say that the staff were really nice though.
user_name:
lcfb
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: This is one of the finest hotels we have ever stayed in. The staff is superb, as is the location. My only criticism is the lack of a lobby bar. I strongly disliked the bar on 24. It's Asia, and smoking is allowed, the design is not attractive, but the view is superb.

I love the Tokyo Peninsula and have stayed many times. It is simply great without being obsequious like so many other 5 star hotels. The rooms are very nice, bathroom, tub, shower excellent, concierge great, front desk nice and efficient, love the in-room coffee machine--very lux. Views special. They remember the little things like that I had a broken ankle last year, my husband's birthday, and our 10th stay. The pool is my favorite hotel pool anywhere. Lobby restaurant wonderful (try the club sandwich or hamburger for a real treat). Very wonderful experience which is why we come back every year. Well done Peninsula. I'd move in if I could.

The Peninsula hotel is certainly one that knows how to give the guests the feeling that they are special. The rooms are spacious, clean, soft while beautiful bed linens; there is all the extra amenities that one needs. Bath and shower are the best. Staff is most kind and ready to help any minute. highly recommended. however, it is very expensive.

First, let's start of with what is good about this hotel, the rooms! Lovely and cozy, modern yet not too modern for a hotel. The rooms are spacious enough to not give you a cramped feeling, with walk in closets and store suitcases, the same room had a dressing table.. So one doesn't fret about space.The power source is good and powerful so my hair appliances worked with ease and just as well as back home. Now what is not so good, the fact that there doesn't appear to be a lobby.. The breakfast area is the first thing you see when you enter the hotel and I don't like the fact that the entrance smells of food upon entering. At night it is incredibly difficult to get a meal, the last order at the restaurant/lobby area is 8, this includes tea.. My home country is 6 hours ahead, so my internal clock had to adjust incredibly fast in order for me to make sure I have enough food in me to last me the day. The room service menu is also limited past 10pm.. There is a bar area upstairs with a lovely view, but there was something lacking in the ambiance of the place, primarily that the restaurant section was closed so it was simply a bar area... During the day the hotel is situated on ginza and so there are a lot of things one can do, the back door leads to more high end shops and he main door will take you down to an abundance of other shops/restaurants/cafes.. At night the area is too abandoned as it is in a business area, so all in all, it is a good hotel but definitely has the potential to be great. If only the lobby and restaurants remained open a little later.. So that despite the haunted like streets at night.. It would feel like there is life back at the hotel at least.

A few weeks back, for my husband's meetings, once again, we stayed in our favorite hotel....The Peninsula Hotel!! Everything about this hotel spells class. Excellent room service, great staff, delicious food....you name it, they have it. Sunday brunch is a must as the views are incredible! We had the beautifully decorated corner suite with an excellent view of the Imperial Palace. It is just steps from Ginza shopping area, Where I love walking around enjoying the city. I could go on and on.....

Third Peninsula hotel I've stayed in after Manila and Paris, and cements the brand in my mind as very good but subtly inferior to MO and FS.The staff here were excellent and there is nothing to fault the place on paper. it was a very generously sized room for an entry level business booking, with separate bathroom and dressing room, and the in-room tech was well ahead of competitors, same as in Paris. Location is good and they accommodated an early 1pm check in for me with no fuss. Concierge recommended some good restaurants.But nonetheless a few observations on the negative side:- Nearly twice as many rooms as the MO ... it was full during my stay and it did feel very busy ... I saw queues to check in at one point, although there wasn't a queue when I checked in ... and to be fair there are legions of staff on hand - Lobby a bit of a disappointment with limited atmosphere because they have crammed it full of breakfast tables .... feels quite small, functional, and a touch dated with all the wood furniture- The spark for writing this review, which is something that always maddens me with hotels which have over-geared themselves to the walk-in crowd ... despite being a paying guest I was denied a table seat in the bar. To be fair the maitre d' was very good about it but the fact remained I had to wait for a walk-in customer to leave if I wanted to sit down on a proper chair. And you could tell it was geared for walk-ins because getting there meant going back down to the lobby and taking a separate lift ... you can't even get in there without starting at street level. A real pity, as it means as a guest there was no sanctuary; I am sat in my room right now writing this when I would prefer to be reading my book in the bar with a bit of ambience/atmosphere. Top top hotels in Europe always keep a few bar tables free for guests, as I have learned both to my pleasure and frustration as a guest and as a walk-in. Not so at the Pen in Tokyo. All in all it must be a very commercially successful hotel, but I would have been a bit disappointed if I'd paid my my own money to stay here, and had no better treatment than if I'd walked in off the street for a quick beer.

Cancelled hotel stay as unresponsive concierge ignored multiple emailed requests for three days. Hardly service one would expect from 5 star hotel. Only email was acknowledgement that they had received the first email and then radio silence. Well this has cost hotel several days of my business. Will be going elsewhere.
user_name:
Topcat212
New York City, New York

review_body: I have stayed in Peninsula Shanghai and in Peninsula Paris. Both were excellent from all aspects. Peninsula Tokyo does not live up to the expectations.Rooms are of average size. Nice and clean but a bit leaning toward being tired. Housekeeping is poor. I found the top rack in the bathroom where towels are kept full of dust which is astonishing at a hotel of Peninsula standards. Concierge is useless; she couldn't even inform me of the highlights of the city to see which is the most basic thing. The hotel has no lobby. Breakfast are is literally in the lobby with no privacy at all. In addition, it is small for a hotel of this size that is why they have another breakfast area on the 26th floor between 8-10 to manage the crowd. The hotel has no special restaurant. Location is good. I think it may be good for business travelers but nothing more.
user_name:
DrHabib
New York City, New York

review_body: This was our first stop on the jam-packed trip to Japan and it was a great place to start. It is a fine hotel with very good customer service. The concierge were fantastically helpful in advance of our arrival and whilst we were there. Very comfortable rooms. Superb restaurant on the top of the hotel with a wonderful view.

We love it at the Peninsula. From start to finish, wonderful.The staff were terrific, the concierge organised several first class restaurants, train tickets to Kyoto and a great private guide. All of which made our Tokyo trip perfect.Lunch and after dinner drinks at Peter also great. The room is very quiet. We preferred private breakfast in our room which was always as ordered, on time and hot.One of our favorites anywhere.

Simply an awesome hotel in a great location. Have stayed here many times before and the quality of service remains consistently high. Rooms are great and the bed is super comfortable. We had dinner at Peter's and breakfast at the lobby, both were very enjoyable.

The hotel has great location, very spacious room for family.Many restaurants selection inside the hotel. the rooms are very clean and service is excellent. Quite pricey though. I will go back there again

The view from the top floor and from the pool is absolutely breathtaking. Their concierge service is also exceptional in helping to secure restaurant reservations, especially at those that are hard to book. The staff spoke great English also. The rooms are by far the largest I've stayed at in Japan urban cities, and the beds are heavenly. The rooms can be totally blacked out for one to comfortably sleep in the next day. Its location is convenient also, right next to Ginza subway station and everywhere else is a short ride away. There is also a Lawson's convenient store right behind the hotel should you need anything in the middle of the night.

Breakfast is served in the lobby or on the 24th floor after 8:00am. Choose the 24th floor if you have the time. Breakfast is fine but the view is tremendous. You can see the full expanse of the palace grounds. Our room was excellent with large bathroom with double sinks. Service was exceptional. However, nothing can beat the greeting service that the Four Seasons offers when you arrive by train at the Marinouchi station.

Wow! what a hotel. I thought Four Seasons was the best of the best, until I stayed here. I was blown away by the staff and high tech room. It's not cheap, but you get what you pay for. extremely comfy bed, perfect location, impeccable staff and facilities. We felt a little under dressed as this was a stopover from Hawaii where our clothes weren't exactly befitting of such a high class hotel. not that it was ever a problem, but the beauty of the hotel just makes you feel like being dressed up.

A wonderful, spacious room with fantastic views of Imperial Palace. (Hotel location is a real plus.) Service discreet, attentive and impeccable. Breakfast only mediocre but afternoon tea was a real treat. It was not cheap however even at the favourable rate I enjoyed.

Exquisite smiling service and an eternal sense of bustle. Rooms very comfortable luxurious and well appointed with great views. My downers....an out of date and corporate lobby which is overdue a refurb. A more than mediocre breakfast with poor choice, bad quality toast and bacon and ready squeezed juices. Oscar de la rents toiletries add to rather old fashioned feel

Very attentive staff. Superb deluxe large room. Great bar/breakfast area on 24th floor. Very near the Ginza area with all it's buzzy shops and restaurants, a 10 minute walk.The only issue we had-we arrived via an early BA flight at 8.30am, couldn't check in till 3pm-which we knew in advance-We wanted to go out later on for a walk. In the intervening period there was no lounge area to sit in, only in the entrance lobby restaurant area. Very poor for a 5 star hotel. Apart from that issue-great place.

I have never stayed at any of the other Peninsula hotels and was curious if it was as good as they say. I have to admit it was exceptional.It's not easy to find a one room accommodation for 2 adults and 2 kids in Tokyo (outside Disneyland) - most seem to do 3 persons - but we ended up choosing this as the hotels our friends chose would not allow a family of four to be in one room. One night at the Peninsula was cheaper than 2 rooms at another hotel so we ended up choosing this.Our children were made welcome from our arrival. Service at the door smiled at them and reception was friendly and patient with 2 kids who had just come off a 10 hour flight. Our room had a stepping stool so the kids could reach the sink, children's toiletries as well as bath toys and sponges just for them. They also had their own slippers and robes as well as a welcome biscuit and chocolate which they enjoyed.The room amenities like the coffee machine and sitting room made me feel like I wasn't in Tokyo - I had stayed in some shoebox hotels before! The staff were only too happy to help and the decor is tasteful and classy. Our room was superb and flawless. I would love to stay here again. It is definitely good for families.

The hotel oozes luxury from the moment you step into the revolving door (which is operated by a bell boy so you don't have to lift a finger). It's well-situated and is near to three subway stations and a 20 minute walk from Tsukiji fish market (and about 7 stops direct to the Meiji Shrine). We splashed out for a deluxe corner room. I'm not sure it was worth it for the view which was okay but not spectacular, but it was lovely to have so much space and we felt very indulged. We loved all the gadgets in the room (I've never stayed in a hotel with a nail dryer in the room) (there's a 28 page booklet explaining how everything works). Service is what you'd expect from a hotel of the Peninsula's reputation. Breakfast was good although if you want breakfast before 8am you have to eat in the ground floor dining area and choose from a number of set menus which was a little restrictive - after 8am you can eat on the upstairs dining area which offers a self-service buffet. In the basement there are a number of shops including a lovely patisserie that does very reasonably priced set lunches - and great patisserie to eat in or take away. The airport limousine bus also picks up from the hotel which made getting to Narita very easy.

We really had great time staying in this hotel. The room was very spacious with separate dressing room and storage. There is a sliding door between the corridor and the bedroom so it is very useful when one family member is up first and can use the bathroom or get dressed without interrupting other members.The hotel staffs were very polite and helpful. Once we asked the female staff about the way to the subway, she ended up walked us there, helped us buy the ticket and waited until we entered the subway.The concierge also helped us a lot in choosing good restaurants and making reservations.The hotel is in a very good location with just a few steps walk to the heart of Ginza.Such a great hotel

What a hotel. What a city. What a culture. We couldn't have had a better time. The concierge team was amazing, setting up several great tours with the amazing guide Jolly. We learned so much in such a short trip. I want to go back with the rest of the family. Highly recommended in every way.

This has been the best well laid out room with walk- in closet and bathroom I've ever stayed in. Impeccable rooms and amazing night walk in closet space. The location was very central to sites, dining and shopping in Ginza. Pretty expensive but well worth it!

What a superb place with impeccable service, comfortable amenities, superb breakfast with top quality food. Great like cation too. Rooms are very large and full of technology. Beds are among the most comfortable you can find. I would have appreciated more members of the staff to speak english which is not always the case. Also beware to get a room with proper view. Some are facing an office building which is very close by and worse you can clearly hear the train. On the positive I recommend the cocktail bar at night which offers a good selection of original cocktails and really delicious desserts. Top mark but vigilance is required especially in light of the cost.

I have been a twice yearly visitor to this hotel since it opened 10 or so years ago and wrote that on my last visit standards had slipped. Despite thoughts to wander elsewhere, Ritz Carlton, Conrad etc, I decided to stay with the status quo and went back in mid March.I was delighted to experience the Peninsula of old. Seamless service in every aspect that one encountered. Our arrival was enhanced by the most beautiful display in the lobby of Cherry Blossom as a prelude to the upcoming holiday that is so very dear to all Japanese, Cherry Blossom week.It was an exceptional busy time in every area of the hotel, but they coped flawlessly.Congratulations to the management and staff.

Nothing but the best here at the Peninsula Tokyo. The building's architecture and finishes are sheer perfection with amazing attention to detail. Craftsmanship and tasteful blending of woods in the furniture really makes you feel you are someplace special. Lighting, plumbing and controls in the rooms are also top notch.Even more wonderful are the staff. A warm welcome and send off every time you arrive and depart; they knew us and recognized us from the first day of our stay. The same is true for the staff in the amazing bar on the 24th floor; a clear reflection of the standards set and personally practiced by executive management. Cocktails prepared to perfection, with creative offerings along side the traditional drinks, and a splendid selection of wines (including by the glass).You have read it all before in reviews of the Peninsula, but I have been so impressed that I had to add my own compliments.

Just finished an exquisite stay at the Peninsula. The room was an upgrade to a suite which was almost too wonderful to imagine. It sets a bar I am unlikely to ever top. Big, beautiful, marvelous view, gorgeous interior. And the service was equally amazing. I will return to this and to other Peninsula Hotels whenever I can. My profound thanks to the management and staff who have created this quite amazing place.

The location of this hotel is good, close to Ginza and The Imperial Palace. For me, personally, I could stay in any number of good locations in the wonderful city of Tokyo. But for me, this hotel is perfect and would override any other neighborhood I would want to stay in. There are a lot of luxury hotels in Asia, and a lot of places to spend your money. But the Peninsula in Tokyo is very special. If one were to consider how a luxury hotel is the added sum of a lot of little things--adding up service, food, and the room quality, this place is the very best ever. The staff are kind and speak very good English, the rooms have every amenity you can imagine and the food is delicious. If you swim, this place has an amazing pool for laps.  I stayed here two times in a two week stay in Japan, and I cannot say enough good things about this place. It is true five star service, as you would imagine.

Have been to Tokyo twice and stayed here both times. The rooms are excellent - spacious, with a large walk-in wardrobe and bathroom. Service is impeccable and I would highly recommend utilising the concierge for restaurant recommendations / bookings. The hotel is located in Ginza which is near the higher-end shopping and office areas so abit away from the hustle and bustle of Shibuya and Shinjuku but there are plenty of great local places to explore for food nearby (checkout the little food alleys below the railway tracks just behind the hotel) and in any case there is a subway right by the hotel. Top notch.

If you wished for everything to be perfect about a hotel, then you have arrived at nirvana here. From the arrival (the classical white uniformed pill box hatted door people) to the reception. Every single person you encounter has a smile and bows and cannot do enough to help you out. You are greeted constantly, every single grip through the lobby. The lobby is spectacular with soaring chandelier, beautiful wood trim, soft piano music throughout that is unobtrusive, and quiet diners at the coffee ship. The room is equally spectacular. There is not a single amenity that has been missed. Multiple electronic gizmos about. You can open and close the drapes from bedside and door. You can dry your nails electronically. The classical Toto toilet does everything for you, and I mean everything. The bed and the bedding are like sleeping in a womb. The air conditioning controls, bedside electronics, and lighting are all controlled from both sides of the hug king bed. I could go on and on, but the restaurants, public rooms, spa, high swimming pool, are all awesome. If you want a place to remember forever, this is it.

This is a very nice, very high end hotel. The service is incredible, the rooms are large and well appointed. The amount of electronic gadgets and buttons to accomplish just about anything is impressive: nail dryer, outdoor weather measurements, automatic window coverings, humidity settings, and many others. The rooms have very large closets that are really dressing rooms. The rooms just couldn't be nicer. The location of the hotel is excellent. It's right across the street from the Imperial Palace, on top of a subway station and next to major shopping areas. The only two downsides were: - the rooms for all their gadgets have no way to control the temperature. We got hot in the middle of the night. - the food prices are ridiculous. The restaurant charges $48 for a small bowl of ramen. $150 for a beef and rice bowl through room service. Walk 20 meters out the back of the hotel and get the same thing for $10.

My husband and I stayed 3 nights mid-March. The location is great, within walking distance of the main shops in Ginza as well as the palace grounds and next to a couple of metro lines (Hibiya station is right there). Check-in was very efficient and the gentleman did everything he could to accommodate my request for a room of a high floor. The room was fine. Bathroom was large with a tub and separate shower. Also there was an illy espresso machine and tea making facilities. The room was definitely a little dated (e.g., chenille covered loveseat that looked a little worn), but the bed was comfortable and we had a good view of the imperial grounds.There were, however, a couple of things that did not meet our expecations. There was a pool, which was nice and large. But there was a requirement to have a swim cap (provided by the hotel) even if you have your hair up and do not expect to dip your head in the water (I had never seen that before in a 5 star hotel, including others in Tokyo). More importantly, we had several pieces of misinformation from the concierge (1) we were told the wrong lunch hours for a restaurant (2) we were told that a restaurant we were going to for dinner took credit cards but in fact only took cash (we were fortunate to have taken out enough earlier that day) and this was a restaurant with a hefty $300+ per person price tag! and (3) we had the address in Japanese of a sushi restaurant recommended by a friend. The restaurant was located in a building with other establishments. We were told the wrong number of the location within the building so ended up eating at a different sushi restaurant (2 stalls down) instead of the one we had wanted to try. The one we went to was good but not the one we had wanted to try so was very disappointing...I would stay at the Tokyo Peninsula again, but just wanted to note the few things that made our stay imperfect given our expectations of the Peninsula hotels.
user_name:
MiffysPillowBook
New York City, New York

review_body: We stay 4 nights at this great hotel and it was unforgettable. Best service, excellent location, perfect rooms, what else you need? I can only say, when coming to Tokyo, try to get this hotel. Your vacations will be “enlarged”!

We stayed here recently at the start of a family vacation to Japan. I had emailed ahead of time with the concierge and they were very helpful. We were upgraded upon arrival to 1319 and 1320 (connecting). We have stayed in a lot of special hotels but this was easily in the top 3 best rooms ever. The furnishings were spotless, every need was thought of and it made it hard to leave!!!! We ate breakfast at the hotel daily. It was exquisite. The gym was small but very pretty. The Concierege made recommendations for dining in nearby Ginza. Every single interaction with staff was genuinely friendly. The location was great and we were able to walk to many sites. Easy access to subway and taxi as well.

When it comes to style preference when choosing a contemporary hotel to stay, I have to say the Peninsula Tokyo is a bit too old fashioned for our taste. Right before our three nights stay at this hotel, my husband and I actually spent five nights at Aman Tokyo so when we arrived The Peninsula we were honestly a bit let down. After the Peninsula we changed to The Andaz and we were happy again. So it's totally a personal and subjective comment about design and vibe of the hotel. Nothing bad against it.We still very much enjoyed how convenient the location was. Literally minutes walk to everything in Ginza which was actually helpful if you are crazy shoppers like us. The view from our room overlooking the park was actually pretty amazing. Service was not bad but the hotel was too crowded so staffs might not be attentive enough.

This hotel works on all levels, from start to finish. As is consistent with almost all top-tier hotels in Japan, check-in and check-out proceedings are courteous and a breeze. The room redefines standards of luxury - a comfortable bed, a walk-in wardrobe, an unintrusive means of delivering items like newspapers to your room, gigantic bathroom with a tempting bathtub, seating area and little details like a nail dryer that ladies would surely approve of. I arrived in Tokyo on a rainy evening and so had to take a cab to get here. The location itself is close enough to Tokyo station (though not if you are carrying your luggage with you, just cab it) and there are loads of izakaya joints within a 5-minute walk of the hotel.Can't wait to stay here again!

Nice large room by Tokyo standard. Traditional luxury style. Excellent service. Enjoyed in-room coffee maker. A bit disappointed with breakfast quality given the price. Location very near to Ginza. May not be that convenient if raining.

The peninsula is a very classy hotel and has the friendly service that is pretty much everywhere in Japan. We stayed for 8 nights and would have appreciated something special to recognize this but alas this did not happen.Location is very good and the breakfast is delicious with western and Japanese options. We would stay here again except for the fact we haven't tried the four seasons in Tokyo so we might give that a try and see.

This is the top property in Tokyo. Location great: it's in the heart of Tokyo facing the presidential palace.Spacious rooms, that's not a commodity in Japan!Superb service.Highly recommend it for business and personal travel.

The rooms are amazing! We are truly appreciate the flexible check in and check out time. (That's what we need the most when we travelled with young children thank you very much for being thoughtful) Staff are very attentive and helpful. Friendly to the kids as well.We will come back to Peninsula the next round we visit Tokyo-Japan.We are grateful on your dedicated service to ensure that everything is in order.

Returning to Tokyo and also returning to Peninsula Tokyo. The hotel is still great and has been well maintained through out the years. The service was impeccable we certainly have no complaints at all! Not only are the rooms spacious and clean, the walk-in closets sure provide all the space you need for as much shopping and luggage one can have!We have a toddler with us this time and the hotel has offered us a cot, duvet, pillow and also a small pack of goodies for our little one. We had a very enjoyable stay and will return soon!

No doubt this hotel is one of the best hotels if not the best. It was the first time for me to visit Tokyo and I hope it will not be the last time. I really enjoyed staying at this hotel and I am really considering coming back again and again the Well trained friendly staff made my life easy. Basically this is what I call five star hotel. The hotel is located close by a metro station and surrounded with five Star restaurants at the high-end shopping district

Although some have commented that the Peninsula lacks some of the warmth of its Hong Kong so-called Big Brother, I believe that it is a mistake to make a direct comparison. Japanese hospitality is rather more subtle and nuanced than in other cultures, and as a former resident of Tokyo I greatly appreciated the comfort and hospitality of the hotel. It was perfectly positioned for our office in Marunouchi, and offered a wonderful oasis from the busy shopping district of Ginza, which is a mere stone's throw hence. For those daring enough to eschew a taxi, the railway and underground connections are excellent, as is access to the Imperial Palace. The rooms are extremely well appointed, with both a free standing bath and separate shower, with controls for TV, radio and telephone accessible from the bath tub (a wonderful extravagance, and by no means inconvenient!). There is a dressing room, allowing one to work and dress in a separate environment to one's sleeping chamber, which is again a fabulous luxury.The quality of the fixtures and fittings is superb, as one might expect, with strong emphasis on the use of natural materials. I had a meal in the bar on the 24th floor and was equally impressed by the quality and taste of the food, as well as the choice of alcoholic refreshment on offer.Overall, for a four night stay as part of an Asian business trip, I can find little to fault. If I have the opportunity, I will stay here again.

Although it is a very good hotel in a decent location at the beginning of Ginza, I felt that the hotel lacks the special magical touch that one feels when staying at other Peninsula properties, particularly Peninsula Hon Kong and Peninsula Los Angeles where you feel as if you are entering another world. You enter the Peninsula Tokyo through an oddly set-up lobby and proceed to the busy check-in counter. The lobby is where guests have breakfast and afternoon tea but feels its in the wrong place and not very inviting. The overall feel of the lobby and rooms/ suites have a very Japanese minimalist feel but is somehow missing the Peninsula character. Staffs are adequate, but all come across as cold and does not leave guests feeling they are receiving warm and friendly service that usually defines Peninsula.Suites are spacious but the decor and set-up still gives it a rather cold feeling. Nevertheless, it was not a bad stay but we were simply not blown away as when staying at other Peninsula properties.

I had a suite at The Peninsula Tokyo, and am so glad I upgraded. Great views, spacious room, great service. The breakfast was included and was filling and fresh. The staff was so helpful, allowing me late checkout and assisting with last minute reservations as well. The one drawback was the transportation. From reading other reviews, some were picked up from Tokyo station for free (very close to the hotel). When I inquired, this was not an option. I also paid for the Rolls Royce to take me to the airport, and the drive was much shorter than anticipated (one reason I went with that car :) ). The driver and employee who met me at the hotel were both exceptional. I believe the woman who met me at the airport was Ann, and she stayed with me until I went through security. There was an issue with my airline not checking my bags to my final destination, and she spent at least 45 minutes going back and forth to get this worked out. I could not have been more appreciative for her help, especially with the language barrier.

The Penn of Tokyo is a dim shadow of her Big Brother in Hong Kong. Sadly ... as I do love this group this Tokyo felt lacking of that special feeling that the Penn provides in Kong; Chicago and Shanghai. The lobby is candidly lacking compassion as I have a 1.3 year old child and was swept to the far right corner fearing a revolution from my youngest. Anyway the rooms are best average ... Almost Spartan in design and other than a warm floor in the winter months just less than she should be. The restaurants are just average at best ... The Penn team is the best and must address the shortfalls with this hotel. Kind regards James Hornsby

We stayed twice here. 5 nights in total. Overall, not bad, but compared to other hotels at its class, a lot to be desired. Let's start with good things first:1.Lavazza coffee machine in room. Taste much better than Nespresso(used at other hotels and my home). A bit difficult to use though, especially if you try to get hot water for a pot of tea.2. Room is big for Tokyo standard. Around 50 sqm, I think. Layout has pros and cons. I like the big walking closet with table. But the toilet room and the shower room are too small to use comfortablely.Cons:1. Toiletries (shampoo, shower gel, conditioner, lotion) are made in...you know where... I would bring my own if I knew that before the trip. Or buy better one from 7-11 or other convenient store. Other hotels at this class usually use name brand such as L'Occitane or Hermes or Bvlgari. 2. Lobby layout is kind of strange. Whenever we came back from long day of sightseeing, we have to go through a crowded noisy lobby cafe and a narrow passage in front of front desk. 3. Charge 10000yen(probably plus service and tax) for child bed. It is not very kids friendly. (Unlike another hotel of the same class we stayed, free of charge)4. The room smelled strange. We stayed there twice in different rooms. Both rooms have the funny smell. Especially when we first enter the room. I don't know what is that smell??

We sent a few nights at the Peninsular hotel in September.In most ways it is what we would call an OK hotel but not up to the standard and quality of other hotels we have stayed at in the Peninsular groupFirst it is a little tired. Not much but not at the top notch level physicallyStaff while friendly and efficient were again not as good as those in other hotels in the group and in another hotel we stayed at in Tokyo.We were particularly underwhelmed with the entry to the hotel and through the lobby lounge/cafe. We are aware it is a style of entry chosen and used by the group in its hotels but in this case it dose not work as well or feel as good as other hotels in the group.The location is good but as long as you are near the subway and places to eat (and in Tokyo you would have to work hard to find an area that does not have lots of places to eat) the location should not make much differenceIn substance the Peninsular tho on the good side would mot be our first preference in Tokyo

We were upgraded on arrival to a beautiful room overlooking the palace gardens, with a fabulous dressing room I wish I could have taken with me. The room was spotless and the service was excellent, which I think is pretty much the norm in Japan (which has been one of the best places I've ever visited).There was a proper extra bed for our 11 year old with a kids snack pack, nice touch. The high tea was lovely (I thought it was better than the Peninsula Hong Kong) and the breakfast was also excellent. We also stayed at the Shangri-La in Tokyo, and to compare, this hotel had the better location and room, the Shangri-La had the best breakfast and nicest staff. I would stay at either again.

Amazing hotel with all that you would expect from a property of this star rating Excellent customer service Restaurants were very good Rooms are the best we have ever stayed in Will come back one day!

This hotel is amazing. The hotel staff is so attentive and makes your stay so enjoyable. The room was just beautiful and worth the cost. The bathtub was a great way to relax after a long day of travel. We will be sure to stay here when we return to Tokyo as well as in other cities.

Peninsula has always been an outstanding chain, and this is probably one of my favorite hotels in the world. The service is top-notch and the room is spacious enough to comfortably fit three with a rollaway - always welcome in an expensive city. The huge dressing room/closet is a particular highlight. The location is great too; two metro stations and Ginza within walking distance. Would stay again.

This was our third stay at the Peninsula but the first as a family and each time we never fail to be impressed. Despite arriving at 930am, our room was ready, complete with not just a rollaway bed which we had requested, but a proper, full-sized single bed had been set up in the room. As we were traveling with our 3 year old son, little thoughtful touches had been applied - from a mini robe and slippers, to a bath toy, a little step so he could get into the huge bathtub and bath amenities, as well as little snacks, a bib and colouring pencils and a sticker book.The room itself is huge by Tokyo standards with the walk in wardrobe one of our favourite features while the coffee machine was put to great use and there are numerous wall sockets with built in travel adapters.Location is great being on the cusp of Ginza with the Hibiya line accessible without having to step foot outside the hotel while Yurakucho JR station is only a few minutes walk away.Service is always excellent and one of the highlights of this trip was a complimentary Rolls Royce ride to Tokyo Station upon checkout.Our one small criticism would be the concierge taking around 5 days to reply after a 2nd reminder was sent when we were preparing for our trip, a similar experience to another reviewer but we have been back for our 4th stay since and look forward to our 5th!

As a regular visitor to Tokyo, there are not many hotels which can rival the Pen. The rooms are spacious and well thought out. Check in was fast and efficient. A gem. If one had to suggest an improvement is perhaps as a victim of its own success, the concierge can get overwhelmed. Time to add more resources in this area?

Peninsula is one of the best hotel chain in the world and Tokyo 's hotel is aligned with the high standards of the brand. Rooms are big, well furnished with all accessories you need: Lavazza coffee machine, colour laser printer, all pc cables, fax etc.Bathroom is huge and fantastic.Inside pool is excellent with a beautiful view of the town.Prices are very high but justified by an excellent location and services.

I stayed at the end of the year 2015 and beginning of January of 2016. I was saddened to learn that the wonderful GM of this property for over 10 years? retired that same month. I am sorry I never got to meet him to personally thank him for years of dedicated and tireless service and hospitality. This is one of my favorite hotels in the world in large part due to his attention to detail and ability to maintain consistently excellent service standards. Thank you Mr. Thompson for always writing me a personal note year after year and including a nice fruit amenity. Thank you for being such a great manager to the staff. They all miss you and learned so much from you. I really appreciated everything you did for me and my family as a guest.
This hotel is centrally located to shops, attractions, park and even the train station.The lobby is beautiful, great place to have tea time and great desserts.Staff is very knowledgeable and polite.

Service is very 'on it', particularly at the management level. That said, the hotel feels a tad inflexible...forcing the guest to conform to the way it wants to run.
