This might just be the difference between the relatively large Peninsula and more boutique-size properties in the city (like Aman and Four Seasons). The Peninsula pool is one of the nicest in the city. However, the requirement to wear bathing caps (regardless of hair length) is odd and detracts from the experience. Similarly, staff lifeguards do not allow guests enough privacy (they seem to be constantly hovering and observing--even though they are perfectly friendly). The gym is on the small side and has no windows--the Mandarin and Aman in Tokyo have much nicer ones. Finally, use of the spa facilities (such as steam and sauna) is reserved solely for treatment guests (here too I prefer Four Seasons, Mandarin and Aman). Food is quite good. Particularly enjoyed the Chinese restaurant (which has a Michelin star) and the views from the rooftop Peter Restaurant are great (although the environment is a bit cheesy). The only real negative is the lobby lounge--one of the main breakfast venues. It has no windows and is cut straight down the middle by the main circulation between main entrance and front desk. It just isn't a space that anyone would want to spend time in (if booking a breakfast-inclusive rate see if it allows for room service). The rooms are thoughtfully laid out and have great electronic touches (electronic draperies, humidity settings, mood lighting, etc). Views of the imperial gardens are superb. If using an AmEX Fine Hotel's and Resorts rate, it is interesting to note that the Peninsula is one of the few properties in Tokyo that allows for upgrades between room and suite categories. For example, unlike the Four Seasons and Mandarin, you can book a high category room and upgrade to a suite....of upgrade from a jr, suite to a deluxe suite. The deluxe suites are particularly nice corner rooms and have spectacular imperial garden views. The only downside is that the bedrooms are slightly small and the bathrooms are identical to a regular room at the hotel.

Sublime luxury in the heart of Tokyo, directly opposite to the Imperial Palace. Conveniently located a couple of steps from the Tokyo Subway and also the JR line( for foreign visitors) In the heat of Ginza, a classy area full of top draw shops, restaurants and bars! Our visit started with seamless check-in, our room was HUGE.. compared to other luxury hotels around the world, nothing was too much for the concierge, housekeeping or front desk staff. I would categorically come and stay here again when in Tokyo!Our Favorite! Thank You to everyone at the Peninsula for making our stay so memorable!

apan was the first stop on our honeymoon. The Peninsula is absolute perfection! We opted for the Rolls-Royce pick up and drop off at the airport... WOW! The service at pick up was flawless (as was the drop off service). Once we got to the hotel, they walked us directly to our room for check in rather than waiting at the check in desk. We felt like VIPs from the minute we arrived! The entire staff was incredibly professional and efficient, not to mention kind and warm at every interaction. We were accommodated in every way possible. They truly think of everything! They booked train tickets for us, reservations, kabuki theatre tickets... And had it all arranged for us when we got there. At one point my husband had asked a member of the room service staff about a particular temple. The very next morning, there was an envelope under our door with the address in Japanese as well as in for about the temple! So awesome! We're excited to go back to the Peninsula!

I had the fortunate experience of staying at this hotel for a short business trip - absolutely wonderful customer service and simply gorgeous room with outstanding view overlooking the Imperial Gardens. I wasn't thrilled with the breakfast, although fresh food and attentive staff - something was missing - fresh fruit or yogurt with the classic breakfast would have been nice. The warm friendly staff made up for the so-so breakfast. Another nice touch, the general manger of the hotel stopped by to say, hello. There's no doubt, I'd highly recommend The Peninsula Tokyo - simply exquisite!

We had a wonderful experience at The Peninsula Tokyo! Location is ideal (walking distance to Ginza, Imperial Gardens and Tsukiji fish market). The rooms are impeccable and spacious with really comfortable beds. The bathroom in the deluxe room had a shower, bathtub, 2 sinks and a separate toilet. The front desk and concierge were attentive and even ensured that a pocket WiFi package that was delivered to us at the hotel was waiting in our room upon arrival. (Highly recommend renting the pocket WiFi for ease of following google maps from your cell phone while exploring Tokyo– can be ordered through the Japan Rail Pass website). The hotel is directly connected to the Hibiya Station, which is convenient for sightseeing. Its also two blocks from the JR station and office. We took the JR Express from the airport to Tokyo station (about 1 hour) and then a taxi from the station to the hotel (less than 1000 Yen). There is a Starbucks and 7-Eleven right across the street. Don’t miss the bar (Peter) on the top floor for some great views – drinks are pricey.

The best room, the best hotel Ive ever stayed in my life, great but expensive breakfast. The hotel service was 5 stars, and the sheets and bedding was a highlight.if you are THE SHOPPING TYPE it has the best stores around and walking distance.

The Peninsula Tokyo is located near Nihonbashi, with many shopping malls and eating places. And there is a train station next to the hotel, so very convenient to move around and need not rely solely on taxi.The room I stayed was quite spacious, especially the bathroom. There is a sitting area and bathroom with both tub and standing shower. Hotel is surrounded by commercial buildings, hence there is no nice view from the room :(Hotel do not provide small electric kettle, hot water was dispensed from the coffee maker which will splatter.. Must be cautious not to be scalded. Also, he machine is very noisy when dispensing.Room seems good especially for business traveler, it even has a printer.Concierge staff was very friendly and helpful, as it was holiday peak season (26 Dec), the staff called many restaurants tried to make a dinner reservation for us. Got a very nice restaurant at Nihonbashi after many attempts.Peninsula has beautiful indoor pool, went for a walk around the amenties..However the breakfast was a disappointment, the spread was very limited and the tim sum don't taste good. The only nice food was fruit, diced japanese melon. For the price JPY4500, the breakfast really need improvement.

Could not be more pleased with the location of this hotel! Right in the middle of Ginza with all the wonderful shopping and restaurants (Sushi mecca) literally steps from the hotel entrance. It was my fist time in Tokyo and because the city is so big with so many interesting neighborhoods, I was worried about location and am beyond pleased to report that the Peninsula is a hole in one! There are cooler, more beautiful looking hotels in the 5 star category in Tokyo, I want to be very clear about this (also a bit more expensive) which I visited for drinks or dinner, like the Park Hyatt in Shibuya ("Lost in Translation") or The Aman, but their location isn't as good. So if you know you will be out exploring Tokyo all day and night, you want excellent service, large rooms and 5 star quality, then the Peninsula is your best choice in terms of all around value for the money in the luxury hotel department. Highly recommend it.

We have stayed at this hotel about 5 times now for leisure and keep returning because it is the best in Tokyo. Our flight from Australia always arrives at 5 or 6am but only once have we not been given early check in which is amazing considering we arrive at 7am! We have stayed in the deluxe room, corner deluxe room, executive suite and deluxe suite (super spacious with beautiful views over the park and palace) and all rooms are maintained impeccably with no visible wear and tear even though the hotel is now 8 years old. The rooms are completely soundproofed and the finishes are beautiful and contemporary but with a Japanese touch. We especially like the large timber sliding doors and the walk in wardrobes. And the complimentary wifi is super fast. The service is as perfect as one would expect from a 5 star hotel. All restaurant reservations made before we arrived by the concierge are detailed in an envelope with map when we arrive. The Concierge are only too happy to help with any query we had and when we recently brought our young children for the first time there were children's amenities (snack food, small bathrobes and activity books) ready for them in the hotel.The hotel is above Hibiya station which is a convenient station to start your day's journey from or a short walk from other nearby stations too e.g. Ginza. Whenever a new hotel opens in Tokyo we are tempted to try it but then decide to stay here again as we can't believe it could possibly be better!

I have stayed at the Peninsula a few times now on work trips to Tokyo. It has a very convenient location for Marunouchi where my office/clients are located. I would describe the vibe of the hotel as timeless elegance but with all the modern amenities needed by the business traveler. The rooms here are among my favorites when on the road and I can't really think of much fault with this place.

I booked two nights' stay through American Express's FHR program, and found the hotel really exceptional.I was lucky to be upgraded to an imperial garden view room, which has breath-taking view of the imperial residence of Japan: simply amazing to see such an oasis in the heart of a city like Tokyo.The breakfast is great, though with limited selection. However I would like to say that the food quality is solid. I would also love to mention the pastry: the cakes made there are simply tasty and great.The concierge team is excellent. They successfully secured spots in a world-class restaurant for my extremely-short two nights' stay: and technically there are only two time slots available as the last day of my stay is a national holiday. If you have had tried to get some reservation in the finest restaurants in Tokyo, you would understand how difficult this would be.

I booked a 15 person meeting at the Peninsula and the experience for my team could not have been better. The rooms are an absolute sanctuary, and the service impeccable. The secret compartment to exchange newspapers, room service and shoe service is representative of everything wonderful about the Peninsula. Discreet, caring, genuine and gracious. Thank you!

If you are looking for a lovely Christmas hotel, this is a really nice option in Tokyo. We were travelling at Christmas and it was such a lovely touch to see Christmas lights and festive activities at this lovely hotel.We were pleased it didn't feel like a large and busy hotel. Although I am sure it was as it was booked out when we tried to stay there on our way home. We felt the staff were friendly and helpful and spoke enough English to make themselves understood. We particularly loved the location. Ginza in fabulous. Lots of restaurants and atmosphere and very easy to get around.Also very close (a short taxi ride) to Tokyo station which is super convenient.

My family and I stayed at The Peninsula for a few days, while on a trip through China and Japan. To me it really doesn't get any better than this: beautiful hotel, great rooms and perfect location. My room didn't have a great view to the gardens, I don't know if all rooms are like this of some of the larger ones or suites do have a better view of the Iperial Palace?I read some of the earlier reviews which comment on the fact that the lobby and rooms look a bit dated... I guess beauty is in the eye of the beholder since to me the place is just the better expression of understated elegance: modern yet warm and tasteful. To some, the fact that the restaurant is smack in the middle of the lobby wight be an issue and to be fair, yes the tables and chairs seems a bit cafeteria-like, but on in great.The breakfast is served both in the lobby as a la carte, as well as in the second floor as a buffet, honestly neither was outstanding in terms of selection. For instance, in this trip I had the chance of staying at The Peninsula in Shanghai, a much better breakfast buffet...I had the chance of using the 20m pool and for those of you into running, you are steps away from the Imperial Palace loop, a great 5k to start the morning.

I have been lucky enough to stay in some incredible hotels, but this takes the cake.Best hotel in the world, for me. Service? Spectacular.Spa? Same.Rooms? Beyond compare and automated from bath to curtains, lights and everything else.Having a great bar on the roof, along with the most incredible Spa I have seen in a 'City Hotel' and this is a repeat, cannot wait - hurry to get back, hotel.Again, my favorite hotel by far.

December is my busiest traveling month, but The Peninsula Hotel in Tokyo is my favourite home away from home. My big family (of 13 kids and 8 adults) stay here every Christmas to the end of December, and our stay is 5 stars every visit. The rooms have everything that you need, and the service is exceptional. The location is great, as it's only a few minutes walk from everything you need. I can't make a single complaint about this hotel. My absolute favourite.

We loved this hotel. It has one of the best room I have ever stayed. The room looks new, clean and spacious. The overall design on this hotel is beautiful. We also loved the complimentary breakfast on 24th floor. The location is very convenient. This hotel is located near Ginza and there are two train stations near the hotel. Very satisfied and will come here again for future visit.

We came for 4 nights and had 3 rooms. The service, food and ambiance of this hotel are some of the best we have ever experienced. People could not have been more friendlier and attentive and the service level was extraordinary and we are generally a Four Seasons family. They also do not nickle and dime their customers which the Four Seasons is prone to do -wifi and the spa are free of charge.The rooms are on the older side but are immaculate and provide all the amenities needed.The food and service in the lobby restaurant was also outstanding and well priced. We were there with 4 teenagers and they had an absolute blast. We will be back.

After a stay at the Tokyo Conrad, I was not convinced that we could find a better hotel, and better service. They were that good.However, The Peninsula Tokyo might have raised the bar.From the moment one arrives, it is very evident that they are in for a different experience. Luxury, fantastic service, and a professionalism, that would be difficult to either duplicate, or exceed.Our greeting was excellent, and check-in was so simple, that it really seemed to pass, totally unnoticed.Our Corner Deluxe Room was a mini-suite, with plenty of room, and then a grand view.The bed was very comfortable, and the pillows great (unlike too many hotels).The closet was more than adequately large for our stay, and the room perfectly outfitted. We wished for nothing, beyond maybe a month at The Peninsula To

Stayed in the suite for a few days ago with my friends. The room was amazing with an amazing city view and a nice big bath. The staffs here were nice and they showed me around the room at the first day! The hotel is in a very good location which is very close to many shopping centre and restaurants.We asked them to arrange us a home service Christmas dinner which was very good value! However, we wanted to have breakfast in the hotel at our last day and was told by the staff there were not enough tables and will need to wait for quite a while if we wanted it, but they closed the restaurant upstair and did not do any business. I think it's really bad management because that was the most busy hour for breakfast and there were a lot of hotel guests here waiting and there were only like 15 tables!? They could have opened the restaurant upstair to make things more convenient for the guests. I travel a lot around the world and have been to many branded hotels and most of them have a private VIP lounge for their suite guests. This experience has actually ruined a bit of my impression on this hotel!
user_name:
Lucas W
Brighton and Hove, United Kingdom

review_body: I stayed at this hotel for three nights and wished that I could have stayed longer! Though this particular Peninsula is not as grand as other Peninsula establishments, I would say this one is the most homey and comfortable; it helps you forget that you're in the middle of the hustle and bustle that's Tokyo and rejuvenates you for whatever else Tokyo has to throw at you.Check in was quick and smooth, the staff were attentive and provided the level of service that was expected from a Peninsula hotel. Our room offered a city view of Tokyo, the colours and furnishings were very pleasant and made it really easy to unwind after a long day. I also had the chance to the gym, the equipment was new and it also had enough space for yoga. I didn't get a chance to use the pool, but it was big enough for lap swimming. In addition, this hotel is conveniently is connected to Hibiya station and walking distance from Yurakucho and Ginza station - making it very easy to travel around and sightsee Tokyo. It was a wonderful, wonderful stay. I would be back in a heartbeat!

It is a very pleasant hotel.Meals are also wonderful room service.It was stress the feeling let not room on the road.Breakfast is French toast called specialty, of course, it was delicious even Japanese.It is by all means also hotel you want to use.

Good service that bell boy can already confirm my identity as I got off from a taxi at night.Room is quite ok but the room view is not really good....facing the office building so sometimes can see the people there working when you wake up. Probably can try to book another room type so can face the park and pretty skyline.The bar on the top floor is great, really should go and try it out. Also recommend to try the breakfast on the lobby floor - taste good.However seems there are some problems in the TV... it keeps playing the hotel promotion channel and I cant watch any other channels out of this!

Stayed here for 5 nights. Pros:-Super generous room sizes. The dexlue room is almost a junior suite at other hotels, with a open plan "living area" in front of the beds, with a very big walk in closet as well as a large bathroom-Extremely attentive staff. We noticed the housekeeping staff are very observant (noticing that I actually use the ice from the ice bucket for drinking) and refilled the ice bucket every morning and evening - this may sound trivial but a lot of other 5 star properties don't really do this in my experience-Unbeatable location. The location just steps away from Ginza is simply amazing - the proximity to several metro and JR lines makes travelling on the metro less hectic as well. this is probably one of the biggest advantage I see this property has over other 5 star hotels in Tokyo-Nice fitness facilities. The pool and the jacuzzi are very well appointed and a very enjoyable place to wind down after a long dayCons:-As many other have pointed out, slightly weird lobby with the lobby lounge/restaurant on both sides making the lobby not particularly welcoming.-Fitness room/gym slightly on the small side. Steam and Sauan facilites are located in the changing room upstairs in the spa locker room area instead of the main changin facility-Wifi. Slightly on the slow side as I often experienced lags when loading Youtube videos. -Concierge. Not entirely their fault here, but there were some miscommunications regarding restaurant bookings that let to some double bookings and cancellation penalties that I had to pay as a result of the mix up. They tried very hard to retify the situation but this is perhaps the only major "fault" in this trip.Will definitely return next time and looking to make this my first choice hotel in Tokyo

Exactly how a 5 star hotel should be. Located in the heart of Tokyo, The Peninsula didn't disappoint. It is easy to get to, isn't too far from the airport and is surrounded by shops and restaurants. It's also connected to the metro station by subway so travelling around Tokyo is made super easy. The hotel is absolutely stunning itself, in fact whilst we were there there were a couple of wedding ceremonies too, easy to see, it's a great venue. The service is great, everyone from concierge to cleaning. The rooms are immaculate and comfortable. The bathroom was beautifully lavish, I remember first coming to Japan and to The Peninsula and laughing but appreciating all the functions the toilet seat has! Clean and very comfortable stay. High floor means great city views. Afternoon tea is popular at the hotel as is the bar, both great. I would highly recommend The Peninsula and will hopefully be returning in the near future :)

We (including our young children) had travelled all night from London and been looking forward to having a refresher in one of the best rooms in Tokyo. When we made the booking the hotel had kindly asked about our arrival time. To our surprise they told us the room would only be ready 3 hours later as they had to prepare the room. Taking 3 hours to get a room ready?! I advise you to arrive after 3pm!!

The rooms here are by no means cheap (although there are special offers from time to time) BUT as the old saying goes; 'You get what you pay for!'I stayed here for a week on business and it was a total pleasure.My room was luxurious, comfortable and lacked in nothing.The view from the window was a great panorama of Ginza.The staff were all courteous, friendly and helpful.Would I return? DEFINITELY!

I stayed at this hotel for 3 nights and it was just gorgeous, simply a luxury hotel by definition. The hotel lobby is warm, it has a special atmosphere and music artists play classical music live, hidden in a small retreat one floor higher, almost like not wanting to be seen but welcoming the guests with warm music.The room was very clean, with a creative design and an artistic touch, the view was also very nice, being able to see Marunouchi and the Imperial Palace from the 21st floor. My only problem was the breakfast, which was a bit over 10000 yen for 2 persons or about 15% relative to the price of the room. I just found that to be too expensive, for a pot fo coffee or tea, an egg, some bacon and a toast. For that money one can have a super-dinner in Tokyo for sure. But then again, eating breakfast at the Peninsula maybe means just this, a "naturally" overpriced breakfast. The bar at the top of the hotel, called Peter, was also very nice, but one gin & tonic is about 17 US dollars. A few drinks there and a breakfast and you might reach 30-40% of the room price.

We stayed with Peninsula four times. I think Peninsula is the most accessible luxury hotel in Tokyo. Walking distance for lots of good restaurants and shopping area. The room is spacious and the bathroom is great. And the service in Japan is always good.

This is what a 5 star hotel in Tokyo should be like. The service was impeccable and from check in things were smooth and just worked. The staff were helpful and were able to anticipate my needs without being intrusive.The rooms themselves were extremely well designed and were a blend of western and Japanese styles which I found to be very aesthetically pleasing. The Deluxe Suite was also very large, well designed and highly functional. The bed and linens were some of the best I've slept in.The hotel amenities were quite good with a very good spa and swimming pool, however the lobby cafe/restaurant could have been slightly larger.Overall a very satisfying stay and a superb hotel that I would have no trouble recommending to anyone looking for a well located, luxury hotel.

Loved our stay at The Peninsula in Tokyo. The room was beautiful and very spacious. The hotel lobby was dominated by a beautiful bamboo sculpture from artist Kaisen Hama. The lobby, concierge, door people make the hotel exude elegance. Everyone is extremely helpful. The Spa is stunning, so is the top floor restaurant.The location is very central and great. The only "not so great" point is the fact that you can have breakfast in the Lobby, which is very busy in the morning and can be a little noisy. We travelled with our children and all staff were very attentive.Really loved our stay at The Peninsula.

The hotel is conveniently situated near Ginza, across the Imperial Palace and Hibiya park. The doormen are dressed in nostalgic white uniforms and greet the guests politely. The lobby is busy with house wifes enjoying their afternoon tea while listening to live music. It gets easily over crowded. The rooms are very large with a walk-in closet with a vanity table. The bathroom in the deluxe room has a shower, bathtub and a separated toilet. The interior is serene and light. Hotel offers guests the complimentary use of tricycles to go around the park which is lots of fun. What bothered us the most is the very weak internet connection. All by all a very good experience.

Went on a family vacation last April. The room was outstanding. Comfortable beds, fine linens and HUGE storage/closet area. Separate shower and bathtub in the bathroom. Heated toilet seat w/ sensors that automatically lift the toilet seat. WOW!!! Walking distance from exclusive shopping area and train station.

Surpassed my expectations!! impeccably clean. fabulous carpets well maintained. no smell , no dust. Room service, and house keeping was marvellous. Every little detail is important. Room lay out well thought out, little details made a huge difference. The comfiest beds I ever slept on!!! Free internet . A/C super silent. Seven eleven little grocery is walking distance, Starbucks and pharmacy too in walking distance. Again fine dining is in walking distance , the most incredible shops and the Imeperial palace. Worth every yen i spent!

Spent a total of six nights over two visits to this magnificent hotel in late October, 2015. The service is six star in every way. The rooms have the finest in modern technology, have extremely comfortable beds, a huge luggage storage area, and fine bathroom amenities. The finest thing about the hotel is, however, its magnificent staff which aim to please in every way and its top notch location immediately across the street from the Emperor's Palace. It is extremely close to fine restaurants and exclusive shopping.

This is our 5th or 6th stays (can't really remember) and it was an amazing experience. The staffs were friendly, location very convenient, walking distance to Ginza, and the hotel room exudes Peninsula qualities. Really recommended to stay here.

Lovely little gem tucked away in Ginza. All the bells and whistles you would expect from a Peninsula. Great service and food. Rooms could do with a slight renovation but everything works perfectly. Great location and some excellent patisseries nearby. Amazing swimming pool.

This hotel lives up to Peninsula standards - great staff, fast check in/out, good facilities. I loved that the gym was open 24/7.Breakfast only has a la carte service which I actually prefer (compared to a buffet where the quality can vary). Staff unfailingly polite. Concierge was helpful at making reservations for us ahead of time. Hibiya station is just below the hotel. You will need to take exit A5 and follow the signs to the Peninsula, you'll cross a small path in a parking lot and arrive at the hotel elevators. I have only given 4 stars as we found the Wi-Fi slow.

Perfect hotel in Tokyo. Great rooms, spotlessly clean. Great spa/pool facilities. Can not beat this central location. Very conveniently located. Service is great, the staff really anticipate your needs.
user_name:
Masaichi H
New York City, New York

review_body: was here over the weekend with 9 of my friends. Loved the hotel as usual, walking distance to the shops in Ginza, close by the palace, great service, walk in closet the size of a room with everything you can think of that you might need in a hotel room and more (i.e. nail dryers), my friends were here for a week and I wished I could have stayed longer than the two nights I had here. The only issue I had was my experience dealing with the concierge via email, we asked for help with restaurant bookings and it took them forever to get back to us, I ended up directly myself (i.e. sushi ichi in Ginza, very good food). I had to wait one week for a reply to an email where I asked for one seat in the hotel restaurant before getting a response, and that was only after I sent a reminder query after waiting exactly one week. One of the girls in our group said maybe it was a language issue... come on, this is a Pen hotel ! We ended up using Quintessentially (a concierge service) to help us book some of our meals.Otherwise, everything else was perfect and completely fabulous.

Amazing room size and very clean. Bathroom was great!! Location was fine for us, close to train stations and taxi's on call at any time within seconds. Concierge go above and beyond for every question or request or help to find somewhere or arrange things for you and all spoke very good english. 10 / 10 overall

Started our honeymoon at the Peninsula Tokyo and couldn't have had a better experience. The service is impeccable, down to the friendly door staff and cleaning crew. The room we had was spacious, with a huge walk-in closet and incredible views of the city. You could tell by some of the amenities that it wasn't the newest room (I.e. "Fax Waiting" button by the door) but it was clean and didn't feel old at all. The location is great in the quiet neighborhood of Ginza. We were able to walk to the imperial palace, the fish market, many excellent restauraunts and many other great sights. Very cool bar at the top with great views, delicious drinks and great bar snacks. The concierge was friendly and made excellent dinner recommendations for us based on my Celiac (Gluten Free) which is hard in Japan. *only thing we thought was strange was the policy at the indoor swimming pool that all must wear swim caps.

This hotel is very luxurious and the service is great. Room is spacious, bed comfortable, bathroom is great! Very clean and very nice service! Love the Ginza neighborhood- lots of stores around and restaurants. Will definitely stay again!
user_name:
umich113
New York City, New York

review_body: The hotel is spectacular - not that we expected much else from Peninsula. Services was great. Rooms were fantastic - very spacious, dressing room, lovely views.We did find it a little awkward that breakfast was served in the hotel lobby. The only other alternative (aside from room services) was the hotel cafe, which was small and often full. In both cases the selection was limited.On the plus side; you're right in the middle of Ginza - plenty of places to shop and eat. Walking distance to Hibiya and Ginza subway stations, Yurakucho commuter train station and the main Tokyo station and Shinkansen lines.

The Peninsula in Tokyo is in an excellent location in Ginza within walking distance of many restaurants and the key department stores like Mitsukoshi and Matsuya.However the hotel itself is unspectacular. The lobby is oddly cramped with the sculpture that you see on their website sandwiched between the tea room and the main reception tucked away in a corner almost as if they were embarrassed to show it. The rooms are spacious and comfortable but looking rather tired with a lot of cherry coloured wood.They have a decent sized heated pool which was welcoming to me as I like to swim on holidays.Service is exemplary, I have to say, with one elderly member of staff walking us all the way to the subway station and even helping us buy tickets.The staff uniform in summer is oddly casual with white polo shirts and black trousers. I thought they would be more smartly dressed.

Our trip covered a lot of SE Asia and we do favor the Peninsula brand. We had a lovely deluxe room overlooking the gardens. Every amenity you could ask for was provided! Property is immaculately maintained. Service people are most helpful and all have pretty good English. Room service is quick and nicely served. Highly recommend this hotel!

Wonderful in every way - great view, high end, wonderful warm service, comfortable and lush, adds to the Tokyo experience, a real pleasure. We would expect nothing less of this hotel chain but it's a pleasure to see it done again in such a great city. Highly recommend.

Stayed here for four nights. Hotel feels very generic. Almost like a holiday inn. Stayed in a regular room. We were told at check in we could be upgraded but for a very hefty price. Furniture in the room is a bit outdated, no special amenities. Linen is nice though. Unlike the peninsula in HK there was no fresh fruit or flowers, no luxurious touch. The concierge was very helpful when my husband needed a Dr and helped us locate one immediately. The indoor pool looks like a training pool and is not beautiful in any way. Spa is nice and service was good. No hotel lobby. It is a restaurant and always full of people. Other than that, I would not highly recommend this hotel. If you have the opportunity seek another luxurious hotel. This one isn't worth your money.
user_name:
jerugirl
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed at The Peninsula Tokyo for 3 nights and it has one of the most comfortable beds of our trip!Spacious room, with seating, eating and working areas, nice bathroom and smart closet.The meet and greet service is impressive...one person from the hotel meets you at the airport and takes you to the car...a brand new Tesla, with in car wifi, fresh towels and cold water. Nice touch!We liked this hotel a lot and it should be a great option for our next Tokyo trip.

We were very impressed with our deluxe corner room which overlooked the Imperial Palace gardens. It was very spacious - the dressing room was fantastically large and the bathroom was also very roomy. The service was always impeccable, and the concierge very helpful in organising restaurant bookings.The area is very quiet and it is easy to walk to the shops in Ginza and Marunouchi.The breakfast is served in the lobby, which is a little sterile, and the food was slightly uninspiring. Given our room had a table and chairs overlooking the view, a fridge and a coffee machine, it was much more pleasant to purchase some of the amazing quality food at the food hall of the Misukoshi department store down the road and have breakfast in our room. Breakfast options outside the hotel were very limited.We had a late flight, so booked into the spa for the afternoon, which was a fantastic way to wait for our flight.

This was my second visit to the Peninsula. Out of the luxury hotels in Tokyo, it remains my favorite due to its great location and helpful concierge that has always managed to book me some of the city's best sushi yas.However, this time, a few points rubbed me the wrong way:1- Check in at 3pm is way too late, especially when you get there tired after a long trip. It is unacceptable for a five stars hotel. Especially when there is nowhere comfortable for the guest to wait as the lobby is uninviting and stuck in a corner so they'll have you wait on a bench in front of the elevators. Not exactly my idea of class...2- No electric outlet by the bedside to charge your phones or tablets, no way to connect wirelessly to the music system. In fact, no sound system other than the TV. In 2015, it feels cheap and outdated.3- Confusion from the concierge who left me an angsty message on my phone about a restaurant reservation that we had clearly cancelled. It got cleared up but still.Minor points that shouldn't detract from the fantastic location, the rooms with great beds or the pool, but at this level the experience should be flawless. Otherwise I might as well go to an Airbnb for a tiny fraction of the price.Let's hope they get back on track!

Rooms are done in Art Deco style and pretty luxurious. Closet was walk in which was nice...it even has a special delivery nook where they will drop off mail and cleaning without disturbing you, which was a nice touch. Lobby is nice but a bit crowded and breakfast in the lobby area is a little weird...but overall a pretty nice hotel...

I have visited Tokyo on numerous occations and have stayed at many different hotels. My favourite of them all is the Peninsula Hotel. I have stayed there 3 separate times and have never been dissapointed! Outstanding service, nice spacious rooms and excellent location! Highly recommended!

We stayed here for 5 nights recently, in an executive suite. This was about 1000 sq ft and exquisitely luxurious. The quality of the accommodation was exceeded by the service throughout the hotel.Breakfast and light dinners in the lobby restaurant were excellent, especially in light of jet lag (11 hour time change). The location is central, walking distance to the Imperial Palace and Ginza, convenient to Tsukiji fish market, and near the main train terminals.There is a complementary Mini-Cooper car and driver available (once daily) by reservation which we found useful. Starbucks and drug stores are nearby. Highly recommended.

During a recent trip to Japan, we stayed at several different hotels in Tokyo, and this was our least favourite. The welcome was tepid when we arrived, and our room was worn and dated in a variety of ways. The lobby cum restaurant was always over-crowded and certainly not a place where anyone would want to have a quiet meal. Very poor gym facilities as well, and overall, an indifferent service attitude throughout this property, right down to a waiter in the Georges Restaurant who bid us goodnight by saying, "Adios," as though he was a bit player in a bad movie. And this after an eye-waveringly expensive meal in a room with a very unattractive sort of 1980s disco decor. In contrast, we loved the new Andaz hotel, with its gorgeous views, excellent restaurant and lovely rooms, and also enjoyed a last night at the Imperial, which has the best service in Tokyo.
user_name:
InveterateExplorer
New York City, New York

review_body: I stayed a few years ago in the Peninsula in Beijing but was blown away by the service in Tokyo.Nothing was too much trouble for the staff, we arranged a pickup from the airport as we were arriving early in the morning, this was courteous and friendly.On arrival to the hotel we were shown to the room and checked in there our bags arriving a few minutes later.Room was spacious and had all you would expect, the hotel is close to nice shopping and restaurants and I will definitely be going back when I visit Tokyo again.

This is our second stay at the Peninsula hotel, Tokyo. The rooms are excellent with small touches e.g. ice in the ice bucket and the service is impeccable. One downside to the hotel is the limited and fixed choice for breakfast e.g. you cannot have 2 days of Japanese food as it is nearly the same. The location of the hotel is very central as a hub for 3 metro lines and the JR line as well. The hotel is surrounded by both branded shops as well as Japanese department stores which have excellent food sections in the basement. Great place to get snacks and even full meals. Around the hotel one can find 3 star michelin restaurants and really local good value places under the railway arches e.g. noodles and yakitori - skewered chicken.

I normally tend to contribute reviews after check out but todays checkin into Peninsula Tokyo turned into a big disappointment. After having seen what a fantastic job Peninsula hotels do in Europe (Paris), US (Chicago) or Asia (Hong Kong) I do blame myself for choosing this property in Tokyo (moreover that Tokyo has so many other choices / Mandarin, Grand Hyatt and 4S,...).Today, and it is a busy public holiday in Japan, it felt like checking into a Venetian or Ceasar Palace hotel in Vegas. Lack of refreshment or dining options in the afternoon. We eventually satisfied our hunger in a basement level bistro next door (which is fine but is it what you expect when staying at hotels like this that gives you ZERO in-house alternatives). Service is indeed attentative but I must say the overall impression is so far mediocre, Marriott-like yet priced as Peninsula.I feel very disappointed .. lets see how this trip turns out (3 more nights to go...)

Love this hotel. I know its expensive but its Tokyo. The rooms are spacious, clean and the bar areas a re Zen like. I enjoy staying here because of the proximity to everything (Ginzha). It may not be the best for value but you be assured of a pampered experience.

This is one of the best hotels I've had the pleasure of staying in.The staff are excellent from the moment you walk up to the building or out of your car. I also made use of the car service from Haneda airport without any issues at all. Staff were waiting for my new wife and I, quickly grabbed our bags and escorted us straight to a waiting car. Once in the chosen Tesla we had our own Wi-Fi and control of the music for the journey to the hotel, which was about 25 minutes. The driver called ahead to inform his colleagues of our arrival. Once at the hotel we were met with smiles all around and a personal welcome by the staff. We were walked straight to our room and completed the check in process in the comfort of our room. Absolutely faultless and just what I had hoped for after a long flight. Thank you!The hotel is very modern and with all the quality you'd expect from a hotel of this calibre. We stayed in a suite and the room was huge by any standards with a great view of Hibuya park and the corner of the imperial palace gardens. As mentioned previously, the location of the hotel is great as you have direct access to Hibuya metro station and can walk into the Ginza district for some shopping. We also made use of the Mini taxi service on offer which was great in getting out for dinner.I do understand the criticisms of the lobby, it can feel like you're walking through a restaurant but enough staff were always on hand to welcome you and guide you straight through to reception.All in all a fantastic stay, we hope to have the pleasure of staying here again.

We had an absolutely fabulous room and stay here. The room was huge and beautiful while being extremely functional. Very high tech - lights, curtains, and, of course, the toilet. The service was wonderful - attentive in the usual Japanese style, but also friendly.

Stayed two nights here for work. The hotel is located a few minutes walk from Ginza, so it is very close to restaurants and high-end shopping.Service was excellent during my stay. The valets were very friendly and helpful and the staff working the front desk were very friendly. I ordered room service one night and the food was excellent and the persons delivering the food were very friendly. I had zero issues with service here.The room I stayed in was a Deluxe room. It was quite spacious with a large kind bed, a couch, a small working desk, another table and chairs, a large bathroom with two sinks and a walk in closet with a seating area. The room was immaculate and everything was in absolute 100% perfect condition and working order. The bed was quite comfortable.The bathroom was quite lovely. The shower stall had wonderful high water pressure. The bath was also quite nice and very large. The towers were huge, soft and fluffy.I did not use the gym during my stay.I have only two real points of criticism. First, the hotel has no real lobby. You basically walk through a restaurant. So if you want to meet people in the "lobby" there really isn't one. Second, the internet did not work the evening I arrived but did work well the rest of my stay. I'll happily return to the Peninsula.
user_name:
adamtope23
New York City, New York

review_body: For some reason I forgot to write a review about Peninsula Tokyo until 8 months later! This is really one of the best hotels we've stayed in ever, and really lives up to the 'luxury' tag. Unlike some other luxury hotels (Shangri-la, Conrad) where you can find scuffed furniture, old style TVs, worn out carpeting, everything here is elegant, modern, and very very clean.The room is quite spacious, and the bed very comfortable. There's a good sized closet and the housekeeping staff will really arrange all your items in an organized way (unlike other hotels where all your items are left untouched and they just clean around all your stuff) and clean every inch of the room.Its location is perfect - turn left and it gets you to the Marunouchi side, turn right and you are in Ginza. The only quibble may be the small lobby or non existent lobby as it is filled with the restaurant. Will definitely stay here (if we can afford it) everytime we're in Tokyo! We were lucky to get a very good rate as the exchange rate was favorable.

Superbly located in the prestigious Business district of Marunouchi, opposite the Imperial Palace and Hibiya Park and within minutes walk of the shopping capital of GINZA.It's everything in what you need for a pleasant stay.I liked the Peninsula shop with chocolates, delicatessen, sweeties - try one Pralinès with matcha, Greentea inside, amazing. Nice prezzie, small present for family or friends. The Lobby Bar was too crowdy, from morning to evening, like a Station-hall!! But the Bar on the Top was really relaxed and fancy, open from 4pm, friendly waiting staff, especially one waiter R. from Egypt, like a Baedeker, informed me about Tokyo.

The location of the hotel is fantastic. You can walk to Ginza and Marounochi. The hotel connects directly to the Hibiya subway station. Service is impeccable, but that's the case in all the hotels in Tokyo I have ever stayed. The room is good sized, especially for Tokyo. Very comfortable bed. Spacious walk-in closet.Now the criticism.Forget working on the desk at the room. The chair is too low, so the desk comes almost up to your chest. Also the desk is tiny compared to the size of the room.The gym is an afterthought. It is small and quite low ceiling height making it claustrophobic. It is connected to the pool area, which means it is hot and humid. 20 minutes on the bike and you are absolutely soaked. Twice I told the spa reception it is too hot for a workout, but nothing changed. Also, they sell outside memberships, and if a PT is using the weights / stretching area with a client there is no space for anyone else.The lobby feels very crowded as it has been jammed with the lobby restaurant leaving no space whatsoever for a normal hotel lobby.

Located at the border of Ginza district, just in front of the Imperial Park, this is a luxury hotel. Rooms are wide, bed is superconfortable, bathroom is big and offers all amenities.Room has anything you should need. free wifi everywhere. fanstastic Spa and free swimming pool at hte 6th floor with view on the Imperial Gardens.Service level is high, cleanness at top level. Atmosphere is elegant and well balanced.Reccomended

I was very disappointed with the hotel entrance before checkin .. i felt like i just walk in to a busy restaurant and get to the cashier ...where all staff seems to be very busy and pretend to avoid eye contact.i have asked myself... is this really 5 stars? especially i just checked into another 5 stars hotel nearby 2 days ago.. the experience is totally different.so i just wish to leave the front asap to get into my room.room is great ! separated dressing room and huge bathroom with nice bathtub.gym and pool area is where you shouldnt miss at all. try a deep breath when you need to get in and out of the hotel and perhaps the funny eye rolling attitude of the hotel entrance staff. the reason is that no one knows who is the guests or who is the restaurant guests.. therefore staff seems to get tired to smile.. oh well.. forget all that people .. just straight in and out quickly .. and enjoy you roomlots of shops nearby... all in walking distance. 15 mins walk to ginza

Location - excellent for shopping at Ginza, Bic Camera (huge electronics & misc store), eating from the charismatic little eateries under the rail line, in surrounding Yurokucho building basements to fine dine in Ginza and the beautiful tree lined streets of Marunouchi. Sightseeing - excellent. Right on the outer moat of the Imperial Palace. On top of Yurokucho station with direct access to a number of the subway lines and stations. Runners - Go for a loop of the Imperial Palace any time of the day. It is a 5 km loop. It is very safe and a gravel path. Impossible to get lost and scenic. It's like Central Park in terms of being the place to run in Tokyo.Facilities - top notch. Amazing pool. Small but very high tech and well equipped fitness centre. Love the al fresco cafe with mobile coffee stand on the side of the hotel. Al fresco cafes and dinning is not common in Tokyo. Bar at Peter is very pricy but we like the view. Plenty of other options in and around Marunouchi with better views and cheaper drinks.Families - we travelled with our 2 year old but also excellent for business and couples. There was a teddy bear bath robe and matching slippers, a few healthy snacks for children, a mini carton of milk, a bip, wet wipes, a colouring in pack, kids tooth brush and bathing kit with teddy bear sponge, rubber toy and organic toiletries for our little girl. Very impressed with the attention to detail.

I stayed at the hotel with my mum in early September. The room was incredibly large with awesome view facing the Imperial Palace. I love the walk-in-closet. The staff was very professional and efficient. Also it is very conveniently located for shopping and dinning. There is a lift which connects the hotel to the nearest Metro Station - Hibya. The only fault I find is the smell of food in the lift during dinning hours. Not sure there is anything they can do about it. I won't mind staying here again.

Service was impeccable. Room was very large and the bed exquisite. Only thing i was missing were more outlets next to bed as i travel with a lot of electronic devices. The bathtube was also very nice and i've used it every day. Unfortunately i had no time to visit the spa and the pool. Public transportation is very near. Would definitely stay here again.

The Peninsula Tokyo has unbelievable service and beautiful rooms. The staff is attentive and incredibly gracious but not overwhelming. I also love where it is located - just blocks away from great restaurants and bars.

Excellent Service and Very Convenient Location for Shopping, just walk few minutes to Ginza.Deluxe Room is large not but deluxe; we also stayed in Grand Deluxe Suite with garden view ~ very large size of living area, huge bathroom and cloakroom; I always lost the direction in room.Peninsula Tokyo has a large indoor swimming pool with garden view.Must try the food in Peter Dining at Peninsula Tokyo, food was delicious with amazing city view.

This really is a great hotelService is spectacular and very Japanese efficiency, but with lovely warmth, right from time they wrestle you for your bag when you arrive, to taking you to your room, ensuring you know the hotel (in a nice way).Rooms are great, effectively a suite with walk in wardrobe and full bathroom, sep shower and lovely bathSwimming pool is 25 mts and whilst you need to wear a bathing hat, it all adds to experience and hot pool overlooks city which is greatGround floor restaurant is functional, whilst restaurant ad bar at the top is great, service, food and viewLocation is great, walking to business district, railway station and right in mix of upmarket shopsstay here and feel pampered and exeprince what hotel service is really meant to be

It's all been said, it's a fantastic hotel, the attention of the staff is incredible, the size of the room and the details in the room outstanding. The bathroom transforms into a spa by pressing a button. The amount of buttons in the room is rather unbelievable as well. It felt like home every time we came back to the hotel. Great dinner reservations through the concierge.

Service is I imleccable . The common areas are tasteful. Rooms are typical Peninsula, including the lighting ... The pool and spa areas are stunning. The bar area and restaurant and drop dead gorgeous views. You cannot go wrong.

✔️ Location is easy to get to ✔️ Lots of places to eat and shop ✔️ walking distance to Ginza✔️ Checkin is fast and smooth✔️ Room size is ok✔️ Rooms are clean and well maintained ✔️ Staff are helpful but clinical ✔️ checkout is fast ✔️ Doorman is helpful but needs to be more proactive ✔️ taxis and trains are easy to find ✔️ hotel room rate is a bit expensive ✔️ wifi is free  I would stay again but for the room rate and location there are many other options out there which make it easier to explore Tokyo overall experience is ok but not amazing for the money

Last time my family and i were in Tokyo we stayed at the four seasons and this hotel was more amazing. The rooms were great. The best bit was when tomaya yamaguchi let me on the observation deck specially for me the view was breathe taking. Would return

The Penisula Hotel is although quite pricey completely worth the money. Great service as well as spacey and modern rooms. Located by three different subway stations it's quite easy to get to. However my favorite aspect of staying at the Penisula is its perfect location right next to the imperial palace as well as the government district. The imperial palace is perfect for running or biking around in the morning. The controversial yet beautiful war shrine is within walking distance and a must see. For any Americans out there, there's also a Krispy Kreme nearby! Truly a beautiful hotel well worth the money.

The Peninsula Tokyo is a five star hotel located in Chyioda. Easy access to major attractions, landmarks and also from Airport as train and metro station are not far.The welcoming was excellent. One guy speak french and he show me all the functionality/options of my room.The room was very big, with a nice sofa in the living room, big TV, free wifi. Great bathroom with jacuzzi option and TV set.Amazing indoor heated swimming pool & spa. Also good restaurant choices (Grill, bar, Chinese & Japanese options).Cleanliness, Calm and service perfect.Worth the price and highly recommended!

Stayed for three days on a business/vacation trip. Nicely furnished,spacious room, excellent service from the staff whether requesting extra towels, laundry service or an iron to press out some travel wrinkles. If you want first class, this is the way to go.

Perhaps we were expecting too much. But I must say that our stay at the Peninsula was a little underwhelming. It looked amazing in photos and on the website but, in person, the hotel looked small and dated. The lobby was not impressive at all. And the room looked like it could do with some refreshing. It was large and the large walk-in wardrobe and bathroom was much appreciated. But it just did not have that wow factor. Maybe it did when it first opened but it really needs a makeover - and soon.I must say that the service was very good though. On the first day, we had some queries regarding the purchase of the one-day passes on the Tokyo Metro and a kindly staff member in this 50s escorted us all the way to the basement station and helped us purchase the tickets. We didn't really need him to accompany us all the way to the ticketing station but it was very nice that he did so anyway. Ironing board and an iron were brought to us quickly upon request. So, top marks for service!

Stayed here for 5 nights in March this year. This was my first time in a Peninsula hotel and I was very pleasantly surprised by the size of the deluxe room we stayed in. It was huge, with a large sitting area and a massive walk in wardrobe complete with valet box. The bed was very comfortable and the black out curtains so good that we found ourselves sleeping in late every morning. Location-wise, this was very convenient as the hotel is situated right on top of a train line, so we just had to take a lift from the lobby into the basement to get to the train station. Ginza with its many shops and amazing food halls was just a 5 minute walk away. The only thing that left me less than impressed was the concierge service. We asked for food recommendations on several occasions and found them less than helpful. They also didn't seem to know the best places to eat in the area (we would ask for specific things like a good soba restaurant, or a good teppanyaki place) and the two restaurants they recommended (which we went to) were very pricey and unmemorable. I would recommend that you do your own food research on google rather than use the concierge. Other than that though, it was a fantastic stay and we will be back.

I was staying at the Peninsula Tokyo with my family in July 2015 while on holidays. I chose Peninsula only because of their high quality standards and service. I must admit I was very disappointed with the Peninsula Tokyo. One major flaw in the hotel is that they DO NOT have a LOBBY. Its very shocking to arrive at a hotel such as Peninsula and to find out there is no LOBBY. You enter the hotel through their restaurant where they serve breakfast . I did not understand this concept and neither did I appreciate it. We had booked rooms inclusive of breakfast. However, when we went down for breakfast they informed us that we could only eat worth 4900 yen. That's all. I found this very inconvenient as they charged me over USD500 per night per room but limit my breakfast to just 4900 yen. I had to actually calculate the cost of each item from the menu I was ordering so as not to exceed 4900 yen. After expressing my disappointment to the manager, he finally agreed to allow us to eat as we like. The rooms are good . The service is good. But, I would not want to stay their again. I believe a hotel like Peninsula is expected to have a good Lobby.

Have used the bar on many occasions for both professional and personal events. The drinks and cocktails are masterfully blended and the snack menu is delicious. In the same light, the coffee lounge area on the first floor is a great place to relax and have an afternoon tea. There is often love music playing from on high. The coffee and cakes are outstanding.A little pricey, but it is the Peninsula, so that should be expected. However, the quality is what you would expect.

Hotel had everything Peninsula chain is known for, service was impeccable, second only to Peninsula Bangkok. Stayed in deluxe Corner room with view of Park, Wow! Underground train on bottom floor, so easy. Great Food.

First time in Tokyo, my family decide to stay at the Peninsula. I must say this hotel is very special. I can feel that all the staff is very warm and always put effort to make our stay a memorable one.The staff is super nice, everyone at the hotel is very helpful, from the bellman, concierge, reception, everyone.The room is spacious, with very comfortable bed. Large changing room and bathroom (yes, with sensor toilet), very nice room. Hotel location is excellent, direct access to the Hibiya Station, walking distance to the Ginza shopping area, and have the one of the nicest jogging track (the sidewalk of Imperial Palace).Special thanks to the concierge team who have helped me with the lunch/dinner recommendation. Impressive knowledge on dining experience. None of the recommendation fails. Truly recommended. Peninsula, thank you for making this stay special. We will definitely return to this hotel when in Tokyo

It's hard to keep these reviews interesting after so many repeat stays, but that's truly the beauty of this place. They have never let us down, not even once. I do have a new story to tell though. We were here with two kids (under 10), and it was a real rush to check out one day so we accidently left over the equivalent in $1000 cash on the desk! I was almost immediately informed of this later by the hotel who kept it for us until we returned a day or two later. They found it before we figured out we had left it. This is truly a testament to not just the incredibly honest and helpful staff but also the Japanese culture and people. I can't imagine many other places where something like this could happen. The service remains outstanding, the food is great, the rooms are perfect, the housekeeping standards are the highest I have ever encountered. Our only wish would be for a faster/stronger internet connection. BTW, this is also the children's favorite hotel in the world. They can't pronounce the name but they know it's their favorite, largely due to the special attention they receive here-- personalized cookies and "make your own cookie" activity, child sized robes and slippers that fit, bath toys, children's toothbrushes- they go all out here to make the kids feel at home. They are also an excellent business hotel and their spa and pool are wonderful.

My wife and I returned after a long absence and I am glad to report that the Peninsula Tokyo has maintained the sky-high standards that we remembered from before. This time we visited with two young kids, and our suite was equipped with all the necessary amenities on arrival - a large cot, bath toys, colouring books, snack hamper and even a set of tot-sized bathrobe and slippers. We had room service everyday as it was just easier with the kids, and every meal was wonderful - from the tender wagyu steaks to the ocean-fresh sashimi.The key differentiater was the wonderful service provided by the staff - no request was too small (or large) and all fulfilled with quiet efficacy and always with a smile. We did not get a chance to use the complementary house cars (which included a Rolls Royce) as they were always utilised, but I am sure that would have been a great experience.If I can point to a shortcoming, it is in the sometimes cold attitude of the concierge and transportation desk staff. When we asked for suggestions or car availability, we were met with stony faces and cursory answers - I do recall the concierge being a bit friendlier the last time ... Perhaps it was the summer heat.Overall, we had a very good time and will try and make this our base in Tokyo every time we visit. Yet again, the Peninsula has delivered on its promise of perfect luxury!

My husband and I decided to stay at the Peninsula Tokyo for the second part of our honeymoon. And let me tell you, we are so happy we did because this property is true luxury.Location: The hotel is located in the Ginza neighbourhood of Tokyo. Ginza is known for being the upscale shopping area along with amazing restaurants, coffee bars, etc. I felt that it was pretty central for all of the places we were going to.Arrival: There is a circular driveway with plenty of staff to welcome you to the property. FYI – there’s also a back door to the hotel you can enter, but there’s no staff on that side.Bellman: Inside there’s always one person at the revolving door to help you with the door and asks you if you need a taxi. Then outside, there are always 2-4 people outside the hotel to help you. They serve as greeters, bellman, help you into a taxi, and everything else.Parking: Not sure about the parking situation since we didn’t have a car.Reception/Front Desk: The front desk staff is very welcoming and armed with people. There always seemed to be 5-10 people in the reception/front desk area to not only check you in, but to say hello when you arrive back to the hotel (the elevators are right next to reception), to say good bye as you’re leaving the hotel. It’s a bit overwhelming.Lobby: The lobby is large with a walkway in the center, one of their restaurants is on both sides and a two small seating areas.Room: We had room 1211 which is a deluxe room. The room was very large with a sitting area with a couch, coffee table, desk, and a table for two to enjoy your coffee or a snack.View: We had floor to ceiling windows and views of office buildings.Bed: We had a king size bed which was very comfortable. Bathroom: The bathroom was amazing. Two separate sink areas on opposite sides, separate shower, beautiful bath tub, and of course the Toto toilet that opens from a sensor. Hair dryer: The dryer was ok. It wasn’t very strong.Products: They had Oscar de la Renta products.Coffee Maker: They had an espresso machine in the room which was part of the furniture – very sleek. The pods, creamer, etc were in a drawer next to the coffee machine.Closet: There were two closet areas – one exposed, one with a door.Safe: The safe was a large hotel safe.Control Panel: It controlled the lighting, temperature, and audio. There was also a remote for the TV.Minibar: There was a standard minibar in the room.Mirrors: There was a large full size mirror along with the multiple mirrors in the bathroom.Housekeeping: Great.Wifi: The wifi was free and the speed was good.Dining: We didn’t dine at the hotel because we made reservations off property. We did have drinks at the bar of the hotel and did pick up pastries downstairs in their café. Spa/Gym/Pool: The gym was small, but had everything you needed. The pool was AMAZING. I highly recommend going for a swim if you have time. They have everything you need and its beautiful. We didn’t go to the spa.Concierge: This is one of the areas where I expected more. They were ok, but very late in responding prior to arrival when we asked for help with reservations. It would take sometimes a week before they responded back. Style: The hotel is very Peninsula traditional.Service: Overall Amazing.Other: They had these little different things in the room that I’ve never seen at another hotel such as the nail dryer for women and also the porter box by the door where they place items in it for you instead of hanging things on your door or slipping things under your door. Would I go back? DEFINITELY! It’s now on my favourite hotels list. Everything about the property is luxury, and you can’t go wrong with The Peninsula.

Five star quality rooms, service, location, staff. Excellent food. Perfect stay. Stayed at hotel in July. Staff was attentive and unobtrusive. Housekeeping of the highest Standard. Located near Ginza and on major transportation route. Don't stay anywhere else if you have the option.

I stayed two nights with my daughter. The hotel was very easy to get to from the airport and although we arrived before the check in time they took our bags so we could go for lunch. They called as soon as the room was available. Given some of the stories about the size of rooms in Tokyo I was pleasantly surprised by the accommodation. It was large and had a separate dressing area with a large bathroom. The beds were the most comfortable I have ever stayed in and there were nice touches such as the lights on the control panels (air conditioning, lights etc) went off but were motion sensitive so they came on as soon as you reached for them. The concierge staff were fantastic with help on how to get around and maps for the different areas of Tokyo.

The Peninsula Tokyo is one of the very best hotels I stayed at, which comes as no surprise, being a Peninsula in Tokyo. The Japanese excel in service, obsession with detail and courtesy, cultural traits one would expect to peak at a Peninsula, and so they do. The hotel is a heaven of comfort, elegance and discreet luxury. The design is impeccable, the service is perfection, and the food and facilities are of the highest standard. The indoor pool, high up in the tower, had the most amazing view. All members of the hyper diligent staff speak excellent english, which in Japan is something worth noting and a definite plus.I did feel the lobby, stunning as it was, could have a cosier sitting area. Most of it is taken by the restaurant, and it does feel a bit airport like, albeit in the styliest of fashions.The location in Gynza is very convenient, and I was lucky enough to stay at one of the central suites facing the imperial palace and gardens, a mesmerizing view. The room itself was incredibly spacious, with a generous lounge and dining area, the most comfortable bed imaginable, a large walk-in closet, and the signature peninsula bathroom.All in all, faultless.

We got there at 12pm for the check in and the rooms weren't ready. I was a little annoyed since we had been traveling for hrs and had booked through Amex (and that one of the benefits), but we were able to change on the spa. The rooms are super comfortable. They gave us the upgrade, most delicious and comfortable beds. Great view, the hotel was pretty packed. The concierge service is amazing! super helpful! , they helped us make reservations on all the restaurants we wanted to go, even Jiro (we called as soon as we had the reservation on the hotel), they got us tickets for the sumo fights. Breakfast was always on time and delicious. For more pictures go to my instagram @quiwitips

We booked into a deluxe park view room for 3 nights and were in for a nice surprise. We checked in at 8am expecting to be turned away, only to find ourselves upgraded to a deluxe suite! The suite was majestic and offered panoramic views on the imperial garden - it even had a telescope in the living room! The room looked even better on the photos!Both the café and the restaurants in hotel were excellent and the Pen is conveniently situated next to Ginza and the offices and is few seconds away from the Hibiya station. It's definitely one of the best city hotels in the world.

The hotel is within walking distance to the Ginza shops. It is beautiful with an amazing lobby. All the staff are very polite and very helpful. Our room is very big - a big walk-in closet with a vanity table, a bathroom with a jacuzzi, an enclosed shower, a toilet & bidet with a door, his & hers sink, a beautiful natural wooden sliding door that leads into the sitting area & office on one side and the bed on the other. To top the beautiful and spacious room is the view of the Imperial Palace. There is no other hotel that quite gives such a grand impression. The tempura restaurant serves the best tempura we have ever eaten. We are still talking about this hotel.

The Peninsula Tokyo is a sumptuous hotel in a class all of its own. To say that the lobby is impressive doesn't do it justice. The rooms are gorgeous, the service impeccable, the food in any of the restaurants is beautifully prepared and absolutely delicious, and it's in the middle of the Ginza shopping district. There is a metro station entrance on the bottom floor exit, so you can literally go anywhere from the hotel without having to step outside. It is obvious the staff like their jobs, because when you are greeted or helped in any way, it is genuine.We have never felt so pampered nor appreciated as guests as we were at The Peninsula. I hope we get to go back the next time we are in Tokyo.

Spent a few days in Tokyo and decided on the Peninsula. Not sure I'll be able to stay anywhere else in Tokyo again.Starting with the location, the Peninsula has its very own entrance to the Tokyo metro at the Hibiya station. You can literally go directly from the airport to the hotel without having to go outside. Now that's convenience.Once inside the hotel, it's an instant transformation to a beautiful decor and ambiance. It is a Peninsula after all, so luxury is expected.We stayed in a Deluxe Park View room, and having stayed at many luxury hotels, I was instantly impressed with the originality of the design of the room, which is set up quite differently from most.You walk in to a main corridor with a his and hers walk-in closet and sitting area to one side. On the other is the bathroom, complete with a tub that doubles as a jacuzzi. Inside the main bedroom, there is a sofa, table and chairs to one end, along with a desk and work station, that serves as a living room and office, while the other side has the bed and night stands.While the room was beautiful, there is no question that it was improved by the view of the Japanese Imperial Palace. What a great way to roll into Tokyo and be able to see some major attractions directly from my room.During our two-night stay, we thoroughly enjoyed the hotel, eating breakfast here twice. We also went to the pool, hot tub, sauna area, which is a great retreat after a few days of walking around Tokyo and packing on crowded subway cars.If you have the budget for luxury hotels, and you're looking to pamper yourself during your vacation (or business trip), there's no denying that the Peninsula Tokyo should be at the top of your list.

Best hotel we have stayed in yet and we have visited many 5 star hotels in Asia, Europe and the U.S. What stands this hotel apart is the quality of service. We felt truly valued and welcomed whenever we entered the hotel from spending the day outside. There were always people greeting us. Even when we were leaving we were being paid so much attention with staff escorting us for a grand send off preceded with the respectful bows. The rooms are very spacious as well which is surprising for what you would expect in Tokyo. Location is superb- walking distance to Ginza, Tsujiki Fish Market and the Imperial Palace. Added perks to this hotel are the consideration they showed towards our two year old daughter- they had set up in our room a nappy dispenser, a welcome basket for her and a crib. If we return to Tokyo hands down we will definitely stay at the Peninsula!!

This was my first time in Tokyo, and this hotel was fabulous. We had a suite - which probably added to my love for this hotel. Everything in the room, and all the amenities, were just lovely. The swimming pool and hot tub were a wonderful way to relax after touring around Tokyo all day. The food was excellent. Staff was super attentive, and very helpful. The location was also incredibly convenient because you could access one of the train stations by going downstairs, without having to go outside. It was also across from the Ginza shopping area, and close to lots of food. We have stayed in hundreds of hotels, and many many luxury hotels. This was the best overall experience of all.

Well, the headline tries to capture it all. This property ranks among those with the finest service in Asia, reminding me of the likes of the 4 Seasons in Hong Kong, ot the Peninsula in Shanghai, other big favorites. There's an incredible amount of highly trained, competent staff, speaking good English, catering to your every need in a polite and unobtrusive way.Rooms are (very) spacious for Tokyo, with a bed to die for and great bathroom and shower.The lobby is not up to Peninsula standards, very tiny and permanently crowded. I guess the owners of the property decided to squeeze in a few more shops in the adjoining upscale mall, and this was the consequence. The lobby restaurant / breakfast area is small, many tables squeezed in, and no food on display (another space saver).One of 4 set breakfasts are brought to you table, if your breakfat is included with your room. There also are a number of a la carte options. I was not particularly impressed with the food: Ok bircher muesli (extra 14.00 USD), bland omelette with subpar sausages (suggestion: get the same supplier as the Shanghai property does), and bottled and not very good orange juice. Seriously, the Tokyo Peninsula cannot spoil their guests with some real orange juice, when they're paying 600 USD for their room? Corner cutting and hard to accept...Great bed and pillows, great bathroom and standard Oscar de la Renta Peninsula ammenities. Great walk-in closet with lots of space and the standard Peninsula Valet Box.Location is to die for, close to the Imperial Palace, Yurakucho JR Station, Hibiya and Ginza Tokyo Metro stations, Bic Camera (actually I'm not sure this is good, I spent too much time there :-)) , and the main Ginza shopping venues. Never-ending quality dinner choices and coffes shops and an extremely competent concierge desk that will cater to your culinary needs.Great base to explore Tokyo, it doesn't get any better, albeit at a price. Not recommended to orange juice lovers though.

Here on business with family tagging along. We typically stay at 5 star hotels (four seasons, ritz etc), but never at the Peninsula franchise. The Peninsula Tokyo was one of the best hotels we have been lucky to stay at. Remarkable service.....examples 1) we managed to leave a bag at Narita. The Bell man helped arrange for our bag to go through customs and be delivered and paid for.....while we were out having dinner. 2) they arranged for an extra bed for our daughter without question and made sure all extra robes and slippers showed up without asking. 3) When arranging for a taxi to the airport.....they advised on every possible option (not just the expensive ones). 4) the room sizes were exceptional and came with a top line Italian coffee brewing system. The hotel itself is gorgeous, the rooms very large and the location is just perfect (5 min walk to Ginza, Imperial Palace and Tokyo station. This hotel understands the concept of repeat business.....we will definitely be back.

Stayed 4 nights last month and had a very good experience here. Service and quality of the room does meet Peninsula standards, although it is an older hotel. The concierge, in particular, was excellent. We emailed him in advance to ask him to make a few dinner reservations for us and once we arrived, we had confirmation letters and printed maps waiting for us in our room. Lobby is always bustling but the hotel itself is located in a quiet part of Ginza, just a short walk from the subway and lots of shopping options. I would say it's a short 8-10 minute walk to the major shopping centre with Takashimaya and Matsyua department stores; also a huge Uniqlo there. Room facilities are excellent and definitely a step above some other Peninsula branches I've stayed at. There was a separate changing room / wardrobe, with a vanity table boasting a built in nail dryer (!). Huge choice of newspapers delivered to your room daily, if requested. Bathtub a good size also, with a separate shower. However, I would say that the room is showing its age, the carpet was stained in some places but overall the room was kept spotless. We also had a slight hiccup as our luggages were mixed up and sent to another room. This was fixed quickly and professionally. I also realised that I left my phone in the room after check out, and had to rush upstairs before our bus arrived - the receptionist handled this really well. I would stay here again. It's a solid and luxurious choice in Tokyo and the staff live up to Peninsula standards. Tip for those traveling from Narita Airport: the limousine bus stops right outside the hotel (and leaves right outside the airport terminal) so this is a good choice if you don't want to be burdened with carrying luggage around the subway. We bought roundtrip tickets and it took around 1.5 hours each way.

Possibly the most perfect hotel I've ever been to -- and I've been to some pretty nice ones. The room was large; King-sized bed listening a seating area with sofa, TV, coffee table. Bed was extremely comfortable. Bathroom: two separate sinks with counter space, deep rob with spa setting (bubbles plus music!), rain shower with option for hand-held spray, WC stall. And please don't think me insane if I say that I'm going to miss that toilet. For starters, when I walked into the stall, it greeted me -- by opening.
