It had warmed the seat in anticipation of my arrival. When I was done, I had my choice of carefully-aimed sprays for cleansing, air drying, and two different flush settings. The dear thing practically hugged me goodbye when we left the hotel. Across the hall from the spacious bathroom is the dressing room, with space to hang everything, enough horizontal space for two large suitcases, a dressing table with makeup mirror, and a safe big enough for a laptop, if you so desire. Umbrellas, shoe horn, slippers, robe all provided. Nice soap, shampoo, conditioner were replenished as needed. Daily newspaper was delivered inside valet box. And clean! No surface there that wasn't spotless. It's true that the restaurants and bars are very expensive, but so is the rest of the hotel — and everything else in Tokyo. We enjoyed 6 breakfasts there, and my only comment would be that the bread basket selection was not consistent each day; sometimes there was toast, sometimes not; if two people were having pastries, sometimes there was only one muffin. But a request to the waitstaff fixed that instantly. The service was impeccable; I knocked over my water glass one day (usual event for me; the notable thing was that I only did it once) and before the water dripped to the floor there were three people there mopping it up, drying off my purse, replacing the linens, checking my pulse and taking my blood pressure. (Just kidding on the last two but they would have if I'd asked, I'm pretty sure.) I want these people to live in my house. In general, the service in the hotel was excellent. Oh, and make sure to go down to the basement level during business hours; you can watch the pastry chefs work their magic. The bar is fearsomely pricy but that's what's going on here. Drinks were ¥2000 (around $17.50 when we were there) and an ice cream sundae was ¥2200. Service wasn't as good as the lobby restaurant; we had to wait about 15 minutes for our drinks, they brought a drink we hadn't ordered, and we had to lay a man-trap to get someone to give us our bill. The only real disappointment was the Chinese restaurant. There weren't many options (assuming you're not eating abalone at ¥70000. — about $640), especially for pescatarians. The fish that we did have was excellent, but a rather small portion considering the cost. The vegetable options weren't very vegetative; preserved this and bamboo fungus that. Nothing green or crunchy, as far as we could tell. Oh, and you want rice? You'll have to ask for it specially, and a small bowl of room-temperature rice will set you back ¥500 -- about $4. Each. Because you're in a country where rice is rare, expensive, and hard to come by, apparently. It wasn't even very good rice; we had better at a cheap luncheon cafe where the whole meal cost us ¥1750 (about $15.50). So — skip the Chinese restaurant.

One thing I love about Tokyo is the Peninsula hotel. At one point I in my life, I called Tokyo my home, I spoke the language with fluency, and enjoyed all the cultural intrigue that any society can provide. At the Peninsula Tokyo, you get so much of what Japan is about. Details beyond imagination, and a service oriented staff that goes beyond the call of duty to make sure your every desire is satisfied. This trip was in the Deluxe King and as you are aware, a bathtub is essential. This tub is big enough for two should you chose, but what makes it so much more enjoyable is that on the wall is a button for spa. Press this button, and the lights dim and Japanese spa music comes from the walled speakers. Serenity is discovered so simply. There is soo much - presented so simply.Thank you Peninsula staff for making my stay in Tokyo so enjoyable.
user_name:
Scot G
New York City, New York

review_body: The peninsula is represented by his hall: big, impressive and elegant. The rooms are clean, elegant and confortable. The staff is always smiling and ready to matcht your request. Please go to have your aperitive at 23rd floor: fantastc drink with an amazing view. Enjoy!

Pros:- Spacious room and bathroom- Strategic location in Ginza- Full amenitiesCons:- Room reeked of cigarettes smell, even though I was told the room was non-smoking- Lobby mixed-use with restaurant making it less exclusive and quite crowded

After staying with The Peninsula Tokyo, I started to think that I would love to stay with this chain wherever I go for a trip! When traveling with baby, it's always appreciated if the hotel provides you a little extra help. I wrote a note to them for the fact that I will be traveling with a baby, when I checked in, everything is set in my room: baby crib, baby amenity, and even a baby bath tub upon request! The baby crib is well settled and my girl had a good night sleep with it! The staff wrote to me in advance to confirm my needs and have everything ready without hassle upon my arrival. The only thing I would brought up is the check-in speed. They have a very small check-in counter, so if you check in during the peak time like me (around 330pm), you will need to line up and wait a while (20 mins and up) to finish your check in process. This is the only thing I think this hotel can make a bit of improvement. Other than that, highly recommended!
user_name:
Kristy L
Los Angeles, California, United States

review_body: Like all Peninsular hotels I have stayed in this is no exception when it comes to being beautifully appointed with wonderful rooms and staff the equal of any five star hotel in the word.In a great location near the Ginser I believe it's the best spot to stay in Tokyo.The roof top bar needs improvement and they should ban smoking. Great pool and spa area with good views

I stayed 3 times in 1 month and every stay was comfortable. I liked the spacious room with a walk-in closet. The staffs were very attentive. The room service was efficient. The location is also convenient for eating and shopping; and, also a business district.

We stayed in a Grand Deluxe Room overlooking the Imperial Gardens. It was wonderful. The room was spacious and layout was excellent, with a love seat and chair along with a small table and two chairs. A full dressing room is an incredible amenity to have. The bathroom was very large and well-appointed with two seprated sinks. There is also a tub from which one can overlook the city. Nice coffee and tea are prepared when you want to relax after a long day of being outside.The service was outstanding and certainly reinforces The Peninsula's reputation worldwide as a high-quality group. The location was convenient, with direct access to the subway system.

The room was bigger than I was expecting - the Deluxe room has a sitting room, a big bathroom and a closet area where you can put your luggage with plenty of space for making up, getting changed, etc. Room service was OK. The hotel is conveniently located near to metro stations and fairly close to Ginza. I like the hotel and think it's one of the best in Tokyo.

Well appointed room. Spotlessly clean. Staff always helpful and incredibly polite. Occupied room on 7th floor, no view but no noise. Well situated for shopping in Ginza area, also close to Hibya Park and the Imperial palace. We were traveling with a group and nothing seemed to be too much trouble. The views from the top floor bar were stunning at night. Definitely highly recommended!

If you are looking for a top top hotel in Tokyo, this is the place. 1st class service and wonderful rooms in a great location (next to Hibya Park and the Imperial Palace and just down the street from the Ginza district). A subway station connection is in the hotel (in the garage) and great local restaurants are within a few blocks away. You can walk to Kibuki-za or to Tsukiji Fish Market (a little far but my 60-year old wife jogged there every morning). The only downsides are (1) the lobby (beautiful but there is very little room to sit around and talk with a visitor) and (2) the main floor restaurant (it's really for foreigners - not much real Japanese food but you can get that three blocks away). Quiet, too. Of course, you are going to pay top dollar.

I have stayed here about 8 times now. Service is best in the world. People learned my name quite quickly. The rooms are beautiful with a sophisticated design. Separate dressing rooms, large bathroom, easy for a couple or family to share. Food is excellent. Spa is among the top in the world. We have stayed in the smallest room, which is large, and also stayed in a suite once. The location is perfect for the Imperial Palace and Shopping in Ginza. Lots of excellent eating options in the neighborhood.

What a great place to stay , from location to the moment you enter the lobby. The decor is clean and very Japanese hi-tech. The staff will greet you with a smile. They are detail oriented to the smallest thing. The spa is a must visit and the pool has a beautiful city view. . The room is spacious and so well laid out. Highly recommended

The location is just perfect. Running around the Imperial Park at dawn and night is recommended. There is so much to explore for a nature lover.The room is well decorated and equipped with hi-tech facility with panoramic view. It's is only 5 minutes waling from exclusive shops. Breakfast at the lobby restaurant is superb, both in term of service and taste, let alone decoration. I recommend gluten free set and Japanese set. Staff is very attentive to details.Staff at the gym and reception and porters are very polite, enthusiastic, efficient. I would definitely stay here again on my next visit.

Stayed here pre cruise, everything was excellent, room, front desk, restaurant and the staff are so polite and efficientAnd best for me was a beautiful pool with a good temperature and hot tub with a view

Position: very strategic in the Ginza streetHall and room: very well furnished with plenty of services. Our deluxe room was very nice and big. Wifi includedPersonnell: kind and professionalCleaniness: the hotel is very clear and the room was made up very well each day.We hadn't breakfast included.However i don't rate it five stars since one day an unpleasant smell rose from the shower sink. The reception sent in our room a plumber and the smell almost disappeared. A good stay however.

We were counting down the days to arrive at The Peninsula Hotel in Tokyo. And when we did, the hotel exceeded our expectations. The rooms, not only for Tokyo standards, are very large and comfortable. The turndown service is a nice touch with different bedside treats every night. The bathroom is classy and the music options while you're taking a bath is a very nice bonus. The check-in and check-out were efficient. And we LOVED the pool and jacuzzi. The staff lay out a towel for you as soon as you are walking into the direction of your lounger. And they immediately give you a water bottle to quench your thirst while in the pool area. Overall, all of these things were exactly what I expected of the Peninsula name. The only pitfall was the Concierge. It was very hit-or-miss. Sometimes we got a staff member that printed maps and pictures of places to go and how to get there. Other times, we got people that just mentioned where to go and I had to ask them to write the name down on a piece of paper or explain to us how to get there. It was overall very frustrating. I think that unfortunately, for a hotel of the calibre of The Peninsula, you kind-of expect perfection in all aspects of your experience. And even though I completely understand that this is a little unrealistic, I do think that something like your concierge advice is tantamount to your overall experience of your hotel stay.

We had a suite overlooking the Imperial Gardens and Palace with one of the best locations in Tokyo. Beds were superior; dressing room and bath of the highest quality; sitting room - deluxe. Excellent service throughout.

I love Ginza street. This hotel is located nearby the Ginza shopping street. The room is very spacious. The service is very nice. The surrounding area has abundant of great japanese restaurants and cafes. You can find everything you want there.

We stayed in Peninsula and it was the best experience ever. For family with kids, we need bigger space than hotels with JApan Standard. Because we need space for stroller and etc.The staff was very friendly and helpful. I didnt bring stroller so I can borrow from them. Not only stroller, they sent to my room baby chair, child crib and child amenities consisting of towel, bathsuit, tooth brush, shampoo and soap so it actully made my trip easier.It was so close to Yuraku-cho JR Station and Tokyo Station. and walking distance to Ginza. The subway station has exit directly to the hotel so it was a perfect place to stay. Will be back there again!

We've visited Tokyo more than 50 times and stayed most of the five star hotels before, four seasons, park Hyatt, ritz-Carlton,imperial hotel...etc. this is the first time we try Peninsula and I can say this is definitely the last time. This is also the first time I write hotel review on Internet. The room was nice but the service was so lame, poker face door man with no greeting when we walked out the door in the morning, and when we said we want to take the taxi of 4 major taxi companies which is most locals do, because the one we took the night before the driver made the detour, she was not happy about our requests. The last day we checked with front desk if we can have late check out, and they replied us we can late check out at 2 pm, so we went out for brunch, before we leave the hotel, we double checked with the reception again and 1:30 pm when we got back, we can't get into the room, the privacy please light was off so we went down to the front desk, they said we were already check out....what's wrong with their service???There must be something wrong with their training. The is like 3 star hotel. Won't recommend at all.

We stayed in a Grand Deluxe Room overlooking the Imperial Gardens. It was wonderful. The room layout was excellent, with a love seat and chair along with a small table and two chairs. The bed was very comfortable and light switches easy to reach near the headboard. A Grand Deluxe Room includes a full dressing room, and is an incredible amenity to have. (My wife is now figuring out how she can get one at home). The bathroom was very large and well-appointed, having two separate sinks with plenty of counter space. The shower had an optional rainfall head, which is great, however the shower is somewhat small. There is also a tub from which one can overlook the city. The service was outstanding and certainly reinforces The Peninsula's reputation worldwide as a high-quality group. The location was convenient, with direct access to the subway system.

This is my first experience with the Peninsula and it's an awesome experience. The hotel is located right next to Ginza and the imperial palace, on top of the subway station. I can get anywhere easily. Hotel staffs are friendly, room is top notch and luxury. I would definitely come back and stay here in my next visit to Tokyo.

Excellent in many ways this hotel has a way of delighting a guest like few others. On the morning of my arrival I went for a run around Imperial Gardens (its location in the heart of Ginza is one of the reasons to choose this hotel!) and upon return the staff at the door had a towel, a smile and a bottle of water at the ready)). The hotel pool is superb and offers an excellent view from the deck. A cigar smoker's paradise - a true luxury was to discover a well-stocked humidor in the bar!The room is extremely well equipped, every possible option with lighting and shades is there and is intuitive. The bathroom is a good representation of the Japanese obsession with toilet tech! It took me some time to discover the AC controls - not on the wall but on a bedside table. The laundry is delivered to a special valet box accessible directly from the hallway - so that also can be a source of confusion. One recommendation for the management would be to offer guests an explanation of all of the technology and controls available in the room on arrival.

One of the handful of “built as a hotel from the ground up” buildings in Tokyo, Peninsula has aged well as opposed to Ritz Carlton for example which is looking very worn out. I’ve been staying here several times since 2008 (probably over 10 times in aggregate and mostly in deluxe suite). For me the room design is the key here, everything just works even though several items could really use a refresh for example TV is old 720p plasma. The materials are generally of very high quality again as opposed to somewhere like Ritz. As others have pointed there are some issues such as lack of proper public spaces and chaotic breakfast etc.. Nevertheless all said and done this is still the best option in Tokyo until they build a proper Four Seasons (current one is just pathetic) or St Regis opens up or perhaps Mandarin does a renovation but until then Peninsula is still the best.

High quality rooms of a very good size, perhaps with a business rather than holiday feel.Bar on the top floor offers a good range of drinks and lovely views but often, even mostly, busy.Concierge desk helpful but somehow not great.

The room of this hotel is excellently decorated ... all furnitures and decoration are into details ... I particularly love its toilet seems enjoying in a spa ... location wise is in the heart of cbd very very convenient .... Services is also super !

Fantastic hotel with a perfect location as it is possible to go to Ginza by walk (5 minutes). The Peninsula is located in front of the Imperial Palace, a huge garden in the middle of Tokyo. The restaurant at the top, Peter, is not to be missed for the unique panorama.

My husband and I stayed at the Penisula May 11th - 14th. We had a very nice room on one of the top floors with views of the Imperial Palace. Room was spacious and bathroom large - had his and her sinks on opposite sides of bath. Location was perfect for us. We could walk almost everywhere. The only downfall was the lobby was so busy with people all the time. We checked into having lunch on the main floor one afternoon, but it seemed exceedingly pricey for what it was and then there was all the noise to deal with. There was a nice cafe on the lower level that we ate at once and it was priced well and very good. Went to the bar one night to enjoy the views of Toyko on the upper floor, but it was so smoky that we decided to leave. Enjoyed very much watching the chefs on lower level baking and cooking together - they were very professional. We were on a very long trip for over six weeks and I would say that the Penisula was good, but for some reason just didn't rock my boat like many of the other hotels did. Judie and Tim O'Brien

Just quietly it is my aim to stay in everyone of The Peninsula Hotels (shh don't tell the husband...). This was our 2nd Peninsula experience, first time with kids in tow...After staying the Peninsula Hong Kong last year I wondered if Tokyo would measure up to that amazing experience...It did...Rooms really big for Japan, staff superb, beautiful swimming pool and spa and gym (note kids only allowed to swim at certain times). We enjoyed dinner on the 24th floor at the signature restaurant Peter - brilliant (view, food, service) - very cool adjoining bar which I will sample when I go back without kids. The location of the hotel is excellent, easy walking to JR Trains, Ginza shops and the subway is directly under the hotel...

I have been fortunate to stay in quite a few very nice hotels on my travels but The Peninsula Tokyo is by far the best! Very good location - walking distance to Ginza shopping and by the Imperial palace. The rooms are great but the best thing about the hotel is the service. Exceptional is an understatement! Everyone is very friendly, helpful and respectful.The Peter bar on the top floor has amazing views.

We stayed 3 nights at Peninsula in May 2015. If you want a hotel that gives you very personal service (in English in particular) and is in a great location, I have no hesitation to recommend this hotel. It is especially good if you want a relaxing trip to Tokyo (as trips to Tokyo can be hectic as there are so many places to shop) : 1. it's within 5 minutes to the shops around Ginza. If you like good Japanese food, Ginza has so much to offer2. We flew into Haneda airport. We took the monorail to the final stop and change JR to the hotel. It took 40 min. When we left, we took a taxi and it only costs 9000 yen and 30 minutes to get there.3. You can find the big dept stores around walking distance, e.g. Tokyo Hands, Loft, Muji, O1O1, BIC camera. Tsukiji fish market is only 30 min walk or 10 min taxi from hotel. Highly recommend you go there for lunch(shops closed around 2:30pm). If you can take it, buy a Hokkaido crab for 5,000 to 9800 yen to eat at the hotel. It will be at least 3 times if you eat it at home. 4. If you are not a shopaholic, you can take a 15 min taxi to Odaba where there are many entertainment and games. 5. Breakfast at the hotel is of high quality though we don't like the coffee shop on lobby level as it's too busy with many people passing through6 You can get a drink at the top floor bar called Peter. Night time atmosphere is much better than day time.7. If you like jogging, cross the road and you can jog round the palace covering 10 km 8 We were upgraded to the executive suite which has a very big living and dining area with open view. Very functional with good technology built in. 9 don't order tea and coffee from room service as you would be disappointed with the quality after paying USD15 for a cup10 We went to a teppanyaki restaurant nearby called Ukai Tei which is excellent and you should try as it is different from normal Teppanyaki (though quite expensive. We also visited a trendy sushi place called Seamon within 10 min walk.11. If you have been to Tokyo, I would recommend you going to the new Tokyo Tower called Sky Tree. There is a very big shopping centre and it was opened in about 2012.12 don't bother spending time buying souvenir (esp food and snacks) for friends during your trip. Get it at the airport which has a very good selection. They will put it in a nice bag for you to take it on board.

Let me start by saying that Peninsula Tokyo is not a bad hotel. Not at all. It is a fine place to stay - the location is fantastic and there are all the amenities a very good hotel should have. But it also prides itself of 5 star service and charges accordingly, and so should also be compared to other hotels of its league, and I am sorry to say that it falls short. On this trip, we also stayed at Shangri-La, and if Shangri-La is the standard for this type of hotel, the Peninsula lacks far behind. The Peninsula was the 5th hotel we stayed in during our 2 weeks in Japan, and perhaps we had too high expectations, but it was the hotel we liked the least. The level of service we received during our 4 other stays was simply outstanding, and we expected Peninsula to be of the same high standards, but we were really disappointed. Good Things first:As mentioned: the location. It is fabulous. Hibiya station right under the hotel with own entrance from lobby. Lovely area around hotel (treelined streets with lovely shops, cafes and restaurants) and Ginza area a short stroll away. The view from our room over Tokyo Station area on one side and a corner of the Imperial Palace was beautiful. The room was nice - a bit "old" in the feeling. But we like quirky and modern and Peninsula is neither, so can't really complain, it is just a matter of taste.Bathroom was big - dual sinks, shower and bathtub. We LOVED that the space was divided in a bed/living room and a dressing room with lots of space for our suitcases and shopping bags and jackets, so it did not spoil the tranquility of the bed/livingroom. Access to pool is always lovely, especially when traveling with a 14 year old. And staff at pool and spa was great and not stressed like at reception.Negatives:Got a bad feeling already at checkin. The staff seems stressed and not at all warm and helpful. They say on website and emails you get in advance that they would love to help with all your plans and needs, but we felt that we were just in the intruding and when asking something we were given standard answers that we knew ourselves.The BREAKFAST! Oh my! We had breakfast included in our rate, and were a bit disappointed to learn that breakfast is served in the lobby. With people running around with suitcases and lots of noise and very stressed and not very helpful staff. It felt like dining in a mall, and I can't understand why people come in here all day for tea and drinks when there are so many other nice places. There's no view, no pleasant surroundings, just noise and lots of people. And it is expensive! 1600 yen for a cup of coffee! 1000 yen for a bowl of cornflakes (add 300 for half a banana in slices)! 1200 yen for a glass of orange juice that clearly was not freshly squeezed. I know when staying in a hotel like this the food is going to be very expensive, but most of the time you accept it because the setting is pleasant and the food is delicious. At Peninsula it is just acceptable. Not at all something that I would pay premium price for.The rest of our stay (4 days in total) we paid extra to have it served in our room - which was far better - it allowed us a view and to have breakfast in our pyjamas, which was actually very nice after 2 weeks of dressing up for breakfast.Please be aware that there are a lot of extra taxes and charges at Peninsula. We did not experience this any other place.So - will we be back? Probably not - I think we will book the Shangri-La or maybe the new Aman for future trips to Tokyo. But we will definitely miss the location. Peninsula has a lot of potential, and if I were in charge, I would look to what other hotels in the same league are offering and step it up. Fast.

We stayed 3 nights at the Peninsula in April, 2015. A brief summary of our stay - 1. Check in & check out - efficient, but slightly inflexible. We left our luggage with the hotel after 2 nights and travelled to Kyoto. We check back in to the Peninsula on our last day, we arrived at 12 noon but the staff on duty told us that she can't give us a room until 3pm and told us to get change at the fitness center. My husband had an injured ankle and was in need of some rest. The manager next to the check in staff immediately interfered and helped to arrange a room. 2. Concierge - the map they gave us for ramen was out of date, we took a taxi to find one we wanted to try but it was a building site. Then we tried to find another one, it took us over 30 mins to find. 3. Taxi arrangement at front of hotel - Inefficient and seemed lack of staff. We as a couple walked to the front of queue, there was a large group of businessmen walked right in front of us insisted that they were in front of us. No staff at hotel came to mend the queue. 4. Room - very well appointed, lovely walk in space for luggage, nice sitting area, nice bathroom. 5. Location - 5 minutes walk to Ginza and 5 minutes walk to underground train. 10 minutes taxi ride to Tokyo station which allows you to travel further afar to explore out of Tokyo.6. Gym - a bit small, pool was very nice but didn't have time to use.

I am a big fan of Peninsula, (Hong Kong, etc.), but I found this hotel way too busy and the staff seemingly stressed. The service was a bit less than personal, although totally polite. Rooms are very nice-perhaps we just wanted something with a bit more charm.

We spent 3 days at the Peninsula Hotel in Tokyo on the recommendation of a friend, and we were not disappointed. The hotel was well located, the service was excellent - very friendly and helpful at all levels - and the room was large and comfortable. We ate in the four main restaurants. These were the Cafe where we had a very good gluten-free pasta dish for lunch, and the Cafe had what looked like an excellent selection of pastries which were being enjoyed by the other guests; the Lobby where we had our Tokyo sushi meal which was very good; the Hei Fung Terrace where we had an excellent Cantonese style meal - I know it was Tokyo but the meal was really good; and the Peter Grill which was international fare which was good, but add in the view over Tokyo at night and the overall experience was very enjoyable. The hotel's location was very convenient for walking around central Tokyo - next to the Hibiya metro station, and close to the Ginza shopping area and the Imperial Palace Garden.Overall we would definitely go back to the Peninsula when in Tokyo.

We stayed in The Peninsula for 5 nights in May 2015. From check in to check out we could not fault this hotel. The property is in a great location in Ginza with lots of great dining options locally. It was my husbands birthday while we stayed and we had asked the concierge to book a special restaurant for us in advance. On arrival at the hotel we were given the restaurant booking confirmation together with a map and information sheet detailing the dress code, budget for meal etc.The room design was great and featured lots of added extras such as valet drop box and nail dryers. Also had plenty of European plugs in the room which was very convenient. Room bed and black out blinds were amazing. We slept most days till 11am!Each evening at turndown something different would be left to eat. We also received a gift of some chopsticks and chocolates and a bottle of sake for my husbands birthday. We ate twice in the hotel. Once for breakfast and once in the cafe downstairs. Both meals were great. The patisserie selection in the cafe is phenomenal. The a la carte breakfast in the lobby has lots of choice with all options covered.We laundered two items. Service was quick and efficient and they even removed a stain of spilt ramen from my white shirt!All in all we thoroughly enjoyed our stay at The Peninsula and it is deserved of its 5 star rating.

This is an amazing hotel. We had 3 nights here in a fabulous and large room on the 23rd floor that looked towards the shopping areas of Ginza. The room had a huge bathroom and also a huge dressing room. The service, food and everything about this hotel could not be faulted. Nothing is too much trouble and the staff are all very courteous. It has a subway stop in the basement and it is very handy and time efficient to get around on the local subways. Its not a long walk to the Imperial Palace and also the Maranouchi and Ginza areas.

The hotel is situated in Ginza near all the busy and luxurious brandstores. Everything was great. The view across the palace was magnificent as I stayed on higher floors. The staff were very friendly and the hotel build quality was well kept and stylish. There are many great restaurants right outside the hotel. I enjoyed this hotel very much throughout my stay. Overall, I would definitely recommend it. However, it is really expansive.

It's my third time staying at this hotel in Tokyo. I love it a lot. The design of the room is great with lots of space and privacy. The location is perfect, which is a 3 mins walk away from Ginza, which is one of Tokyo popular hangout area. The breakfast (at the lobby area) is descent, but it will be better if there are more choices. The room service has limited choices, so it forces me to look for dinner outside, which is quite easy because Ginza has many restaurants.

Stayed here with family (total 4 rooms) in May. First impression, excellent service but small lobby. people queuing up for afternoon-tea and there's not much seating area at lobby. we checked in at 4pm but one of the rooms was not yet ready. well..i know it's the golden week but it's peninsula..i expected more!room is large but little old-styled. lemme summarise below:pros:1) location is perfect, bic camera nearby..jr station..metro at basement..walking distance to chiyoda shopping centers..coffee shops around and lawson nearby..2) service - esp concierge..english level is high and definitely no lost in tokyo!cons:1) poor wifi! glad i had sim-card to use..2) poor air-con: we stayed in 4 rooms..1 room had extremely poor air contips:- bring yr own shampoo/conditioner/lotion..not 5 stars standard- ask for bottled water..

Peninsula TokyoI would rate The Peninsula Tokyo a bit over 4 circles (4.3-4.5).General Overview (I’ll go into further detail in the following pages)…......I would rate The Peninsula Tokyo a bit over 4 circles (4.3-4.5). I liked The Tokyo Peninsula. It’s a very nice hotel and we enjoyed our stay…… The Peninsula has more of an intimate feel to it compared to the opulence and grandeur of the Ritz, and perhaps this would lend itself to being a hotel well suited for couples that don’t need much public space and have the luxury of being able to dine at the hotel’s more formal restaurants The rooms are well thought out and had the best layout out of the 3 properties we stayed at while visiting Tokyo. The pool area was the nicest out of the 3 properties we stayed at while visiting Tokyo.  In-Room dining was pretty much spot on from set-up to presentation to portion size to taste. Out of 2 properties where we used room service, the Peninsula was better by far.But… I don’t love The Tokyo Peninsula. While outstanding in many aspects, there are a few areas that just don’t provide the “wow” aspect that’s expected when staying at a luxury property. Little/no public areas (i.e lobby/lounges). Lack of personalized service versus standardized professional service. Lack of oomph (but still nice overall) in breakfast selection and breakfast location. The least memorable breakfast out of the hotels we stayed at. Less than optimal views from room (at least from our particular 11th floor room). The least impressive views out of the 3 properties we stayed at while visiting Tokyo.So… I didn’t really have any problems versus perhaps my own personal preferences as to a luxury hotel given consideration of my needs (family with young children travelling for leisure).Conclusion…I certainly wouldn’t object to staying again and I would certainly recommend it to others as being worth a go (with a few caveats). In-Depth Review…Family of 4. 2 Adults (40’s), 2 daughters (7 &4). 2 week vacation in Japan for Anniversary.Check in… After 15 hours of flights we took the train from Narita and grabbed a cab at Tokyo station. Standard grab the luggage and accompany client to reception desk. The entrance has a revolving door with a lady actually rotating it by hand for clients as they come and go. Interesting touch. As others have mentioned, there is no lobby to speak of and you get to reception by walking through the middle of the lobby restaurant. I’ve seen properties with small lobbies before but this place literally had no lobby at all. While I was checking in my family had to sit on benches across from the elevator. Check-in was easy enough. Standard passport scanning, running of the credit card, and signing a couple papers. Although we arrived early (0930-1000) our room was ready and waiting (which was certainly appreciated by our tired and jetlagged family).Room… Luggage was delivered within 10-15 minutes after we arrived in our room. We had an executive suite (corner room) which gave us a bit nicer view and at 83m2, a bit extra space to stretch out as well. Views from our 11th floor room were ok but nothing spectacular. Certainly the least impressive of our 3 Tokyo hotels (Ritz 53rd floor, Shangri-La 36th floor).The room was split into 2 sections that could be separated by closing a door. The living room area with a half bath (toilet and sink) and then an area with a large dressing room leading into the dressing room, bedroom, and main bathroom.Bedroom… The bedroom itself was a bit small but still quite functional. This is the only hotel we stayed at that actually had a bedroom door. They also had another door separating the living room from the main bathroom and sleeping areas. This is of course nice when some people want to watch TV/Play and others want to sleep/take a bath in peace. This was the only hotel where we had two double beds versus a king and an extra bed in the room. If we can get both kids in the same bed, having a king and an extra bed is a bit nicer for the parents. But 2 doubles worked fine with 1 parent and 1 kid in each bed.Separate heating/ac controls for the bedroom. Nice in theory but one position up or down and it would be either too cold or too hot and never an in-between comfortable. Standard bedroom amenities. Large screen TV. Safe. Ice bucket filled nightly. Water was provided when the room was made up. I found the bedroom lighting a bit hard to figure out. It seems as if you need to turn it on at full force and hold the button to dim. Not the most practical lighting system.Dressing Room… Lots of storage space here. Plenty of hanging space. Several drawers. Without a doubt the biggest and best “closet” we had while in Japan. There is a dressing table in the dressing area. This includes a makeup mirror and a hair dryer. The laundry bags are also located in this area.Valet Box….I admit that I didn’t catch onto this one until we were leaving. In the dressing room, on the wall, there is a hidden little door. Somewhere outside the room is another little door leading to the same “box”. This is where the valet will put your morning paper. If you want your shoes shined, you put them in the box and then just push a button to call the valet. I admit to never having seen this before. This was my first time at a Peninsula and in Japan, so I’m not sure where the idea came from. Is it country? Company? Or just a once off thing imagined by whoever designed this particular property? Bathroom… Bath and half actually. The Peninsula was the only hotel we stayed in to have such an amenity and when traveling as a family a half bath is a nice touch. Standard full set of bathroom amenities such as razors, toothbrushes, cotton swabs, etc. Double sinks in the main bathroom with separate tub (with tv) and rain shower. Japanese automatic toilet. There was a window above the tub, which of course is a nice touch. Ours was even with an office building and we had a good laugh wondering what the lady in the office directly across from us would think if we just started showering in the tub without closing the shades. Living room… I liked the layout here. Divided into 3 distinct sections (nd yet somehow it never seemed overcrowded). ….1. Lounging area with couch, coffee table and chair. 2. Dining area with table and seating for four. 3. Desk area. Mini bar and coffee maker are in the cabinets above the desk area. Tea setup and ice bucket next to the desk area. Living room has separate temperature controls. A nice touch in theory but we never found the temp to be comfortable (3 was too cold, 4 was too hot).Standard Large screen TV that can be easily seen from most vantage points. Half bath (toilet and sink) in hallway leading to living room.Housekeeping…. Fast efficient service. I can’t remember a single issue. Within half an hour of arriving they brought up a couple gift baskets for the kids containing snacks, games, crayons, etc. Nice touch/ especially as the adult’s only got an apple each. Lol.). Children’s robes and slippers with a Peninsula Bear motif were provided and came in different sizes. Certainly the nicest “children’s robes we had in Japan. Certainly a nice touch.A couple local juices were brought up as a gift from the property. My wife seemed to enjoy them.Both ice buckets were filled at turndown. I once hit the “make up room” button and they were there before we left the room 5 minutes later.If I remember correctly… Bottled water was left in the living room during room cleaning. Bottled water and glasses were provided bedside during turndown. Shoe Shine/Laundry… Shoes came back nicely done with complimentary travel shoe trees inserted and Peninsula shoe bags. In a moment of temporary insanity I decided to wear white trousers on an international flight. With everything from orange juice to coffee spilled on me I was sure the pants would be done for. Happily enough, laundry had them back to me in new condition a day later.I had asked laundry as to the cost of cleaning a child’s cotton dress. They sent a guy up to quote me a price significantly lower than what was listed. Even further, when we got the dress back they had charged me even less than quoted. Laundry was covered in plastic and hung in wardrobe while we out.General Service… Service, while always professional and of high standard, was never very personal. I don’t remember anyone ever greeting me with “Good morning Mr. T. did you sleep well? What are your plans today? Can I arrange something for you?” I tend to think of it more as “on-demand” service versus “pro-active service. You contact the concierge. You contact the bell desk. You contact the spa. You contact the restaurants. Etc. As an example….To me there’s a big difference between… “Mr. T? Your car is here” (Peninsula) and “Mr. T, your car is here” (Ritz)... I prefer the later.Public Spaces…There are no real public spaces to relax or stroll about. Our first night the 7 yo couldn’t sleep at 0100 so although we knew everything would be closed, we decided to go check out the location of the hotel facilities on the lower floors. This for some reason upset security who walked us down the stairs and escorted us pretty much all the way to the guestroom elevators. The next night my 3 yo pulled the same at 0300. 0300 in the morning with a jet lagged energetic 3 year old and it’s raining outside. And your $1’000 a night hotel doesn’t have a lobby or any public space to speak of. Oh well... I guess I’m one of the few tourists that can claim the experience of strolling the Tokyo backroads at 0300 with a 3 year old in the cold windy rain. Pool…… Out of the 3 properties we stayed a in Tokyo, the Peninsula had my favorite pool area. The pool area is quite large. Done in white (cream?) with 2 story ceilings, there’s really a feeling of openness and space. Yet… There’s a huge glass waterfall that gives it all quite a relaxing ambience. While certainly practical, everything just comes together nicely here to give it a pleasant atmosphere. Kickboards, water peanuts, goggles, and children’s arm floats are available for use. The obligatory swim cap will be provided should you not have your own.Bottled water is brought to you upon arrival. Pool attendant sets up your selected sitiing area.The Jacuzzi is directly next to the pool and overlooks the city. The pool is available for children to use from 0900 (1000?)-1800. I believe they have an age limit set at 4 years old (we cheated a bit with the 3 ½ yo and either they didn’t notice or they weren’t willing to make a scene). Our first night there I had forgotten the exact Children’s restricted hours and went down with my 7 yo. a bit late. I asked if there was any way we could just go for 15-20 minutes and to their credit, the spa staff called the spa manager and he/she allowed us in for 20 minutes. Nice touch and appreciated by both papa and daughter.In room dining… Woke up from our nap late in the evening. Tried to find something decent and family friendly in Ginza. No luck. Mostly casual bar/restaurants. Time to head back to the hotel for some room service. Limited night-time menu of course… but still enough selection to meet our needs. Pasta with red sauce for the 3 yo, a burger for the 7 year old, salads & Japanese curried beef for the parents. The server set everything up perfectly on the dining room table. Presentation of food was nice. The portions all of good size (I was actually a bit jealous of my daughter’s hamburger). Standard wait time of half an hour or so. Although everyone enjoyed their meal, I thought the salads were a bit limp. I’m guessing that they tossed the salads first and then let them sit while waiting 15-20 minutes for that big burger to cook.Breakfast… We took the bed and breakfast option. This was good for the 2 adults so we needed to pay 50% for the 7 year old. The 3 year old was free. There are 2 different breakfast options. A la Carte served in the lobby restaurant on the first floor… Or ….the breakfast buffet served in the basement chocolate/souvenir shop. While both were nice enough areas to eat, I can’t say either really wowed me.As a young family, buffet seems to be the easiest method of of having breakfast while on vacation. The kids can pick and choose. There is little/no wait time. Etc. So….. I can only rate the buffet.While everything was laid out nicely and well presented, I wouldn’t call the breakfast selection overly inspired versus standard fare for international luxury hotels. Selection of fresh fruits. Selection of pastries. Cold cuts. Cheeses. Salads. A few hot dishes (French toast, sausages, potatoes, bacon and scrambled eggs). Again. It was nice. It met the standards that one would expect from a buffet breakfast at a luxury property. Everything was fresh. Everything tasted good. Service was more than acceptable if not excellent. Pleasant atmosphere. I really have no complaints, it’s just not anything to really write home about. Nothing caught my eye (& taste buds) as being unique or special to the property itself, which is a bit of a shame because the other hotels all didOne morning the server asked if my daughter wanted her apple cut. This was a nice touch. When she came back with the apple they had peeled it and arranged the pieces into a swan. Very nice touch. The basement area also has the hotel’s patisserie (bakery) and chocolate making facilities in plain view (behind glass of course). Good for a few minutes of distraction for the kids. Concierge… I didn’t have much contact with the concierge. They arranged train tickets to Kyoto (without issue) and put chocolates & and an anniversary card in my room upon request. Pre-trip requests were handled in a timely and professional manner.Bell Desk… Other than grabbing the luggage a couple times, they arranged a taxi van (not the easiest to find in Tokyo) for our departure and had it there on time. Their suggestion as to departure time was closer than mine (but I still prefer to be 15 earlier than needed versus missing the train. Lol). I had written a couple times pre-trip and they always seemed quite willing to get things done.  Misc. Areas… There is a small sand garden at the bottom of the stairway. Don’t miss the “Light Tornadoes” through the little windows as you step off the elevators onto your room floor. Hard to explain but neat nonetheless. Smoking Area… Perhaps I was misinformed but it seems that the only smoking area for regular hotel guests is right outside the front entrance. I’m not a heavy smoker but I still didn’t find this to be overly convenient.Location… If you make a right hand turn when walking out the main entrance you’ll run into a quieter neighborhood with containing a few upscale shops and restaurants. If you make a left, you’ll run into a busier area. Across the road is a 24 hr 7/11 which is handy for 7/11 type items (i.e. cigarettes). If you make a left, it’s a 3-4 block walk to the main shopping area in the Ginza district. Also along the way is Sanrioland for all your Hello Kitty needs (it’s pretty much just a store but they do carry made in Japan items that are only available in Japan).Conclusion…. I guess that’s about it. As you can see (if you actually made it this far), there are many, many spot on things when it comes to the Tokyo Peninsula. I had an overall positive experience. I really liked the whole package of the product…but… I wish there was more to it…I wish they had more of a view. I wish that there was something more to their breakfast, something special. I wish they had more space such as a real lobby or a club level lounge (which are nice when you want to get out of your room yet stay in the hotel). I wish they had the more personal service of the dedicated concierge concept. To me, it’s much nicer having someone report to you every morning versus having to chase 5 different staff members from 5 different departments and then having to check back with them, and then not being able to talk to the same person but a colleague… By time you’re done you’ve talked to 15 different people and are praying that everyone is on the same page as to times, changes, etc. So yeah. I prefer dealing with one person and letting them coordinate things. I prefer to sip coffee in the lounge while discussing transportation versus standing in line at the concierge desk. A bit over 4 circles but not a 5 in my opinion. Although I might prefer the Tokyo Ritz, I would happily stay at The Peninsula again and I would recommend it to others looking for a more subdued classic atmosphere.

I had an excellent stay at this hotel, the lobby was not as impressive but I really liked my room, the bed, the bathroom and specially the closet were really nice. The conciege service was excellent, location was excellent! Cant wait to come back! I also had free international calls from y room!

Stayed in Deluxe Room on 19/F overlooking the main street. Found bed and pillows to be overly soft, requested change in pillows on 2nd night. Only minor complaint would be breakfast at the lobby. Very busy and staff did not seem in control at times ie. forgot coffee order, ran out of carrot juice...Check out was very efficiently handled by Mio ie. addressed you by name. Overall very much "Peninsula Quality"!

This was my first time in Tokyo and having heard stories on Tokyo's space I was a bit concerned with it and I was prepared for a capsule hotel (ok, maybe not that extreme). Our room was very roomy with a small living room and table, walk-in closet and bathroom with tub, shower, japanese style toilet (weird if you are not familiar with heated, automatic, water sprinkling toilets), and double faucets which if you are travelling with your wife is very much appreciated as it significanlty contributes to peace and tranquility). We also had a view of the park on the 20th floor which is my suggestion, get a top floor with a view of the park. Definitley worth it. Staff was very very polite and despite us arriving after 14hrs from Mexico at the hotel at 9am, they were accomodating to out needs, offered to give us another room in lieu of ours which was not ready yet and were overall very pleasing and had a pleasant customer oriented attitude. What we did in the end was not take the sub-room, and went to the Spa were we had a 2 hr massage booked in advance. The Spa facilities are clean, functional, and contributing towards a good experience. The massage itself was great as well and I especially liked the availability of a safe inside your massage therapy room (not in the locker/dressing room) where you could take off and leave watches, rings, etc with full certainty for their well being. I know, you are in Tokyo and in a nice hotel, but still, it never hurts to be safe. The lobby is where you can have breakfast, aside from a buffet at the Chinese restaurant and in-room dining. Breakfast is not awesome, but it was ok, try the lychee slurpee, that was nice. Coffee is really good and you can request a to-go cup and avoid a starbucks stop as other westerners foolishly do. Do try: 1. Boutique & Cafe: Good coffee, great desserts, try the chocolate and cream ones as weel as the macarons (especially the raspberry one). 2. A ride in Peninsula's fleet: Whether you book a whole day, half a day or 1 hour as we did, a city is always better seen while on a Rolls Royce (r at least not worst). If you do not want to roll around om a Rolls all day, there is also an entrance to subway's Hibiya station right underneath the hotel which is very useful if it is raining. There are 3 lines that pass through that station and there is also the Ginza station at walking distance connecting you to more lines.You can avoid: Restaurant at the hotel: Tokyo Tsuruya. It is Kaiseki style, and although good it is not awesome both food and service wise.

Wonderful location has The Peninsula Tokyo, in front of the Imperial Palace .Behind of one of the best shopping areas in Tokyo, but it failed about not having a lounge where guest could just sit and watch people passing by or wait for friends to go out .....Confusing breakfast location shared by the lobby entrance, I felt like arriving in one of Las Vegas huge hotels when the entrance in inside the crowd.On the other hand the rooms are very spacious with excellent view.

The Peninsula Hotel, Tokyo is a very nice hotel but if this is a 5-star hotel how many stars does the Oberoi Udaivillas in Udaipur, India or the Llao Llao report in Bariloche, Argentina get? My point is it's good but not among the very best. The room we had was very good and spacious and the service and food was good. We had a very good prix fixe dinner that, for Tokyo, was very inexpensive and also very good. There are 2 things that, from my point of view, make this something less than 5-star: 1) Breakfast - the lobby breakfast is not great but there was a decent buffet in the basement for the days we were there - decent but not great 2) the lobby - this is not a pleasant place to be, particularly on the weekend when lots of people come in for afternoon tea or just to rubberneck. It's almost impossible to find a quiet spot to have a coffee. After all that, I did enjoy our stay here because it's a good hotel and very well situated for the Imperial Palace and Ginza. I'll give it 5 stars but out of 6.

We stayed in this hotel twice-in the beginning and end of our trip. On the arrival day , though my guide called a couple of times for EARLY check in from on our way from the airport, I had to wait from 11a.m till 2.30 for check in. When I told at the desk that I was so tired after flying for 10 hours from Moscow, a very young man rudely remarked " other people are waiting!" The check in time is 3 p.m. Bur I didn't like the ATTITUDE! When we came back in April at 3.00 sharp-our room wasn't ready!!! We had to wait! It's a problem the hotel should work at. I put 3 stars for service because of this and also the service at breakfast is VERY slow. Too many waiters, not well organized . The room and spa were up to the mark for the hotel of this kind.

If it's you're first time in tokyo and you just want to take things slow especially having a 2 year old toddler in tow, the Peninsula tokyo is in the center of a pleasant district where hibiya park is a stone's throw away and surrounded by a quiet neighborhood where you can leisurely take walks away from the busy crowd such as ginza or Shinjuku. It is very accessible to the metro and just a few minutes walk to ginza if you want to escape for couple time once your child is asleep. Service and staff are pleasant , hospitable and impeccable. The amenities, the lobby cafe the cocktail bar and steak dining on the top floor are indeed what makes the peninsula hotel chains The best places to stay in

I had a privilege to stay in this hotel in April 2014.Big room. Massive bathroom with automatic toilet.Highly recommend. The breakfast was the highlight.Stayed there for 3 nights. Very friendly staff and walking distance to Ginza.

We came to the hotel after staying at the Hong Kong Peninisula. We expected the same level of service and detail that we had experienced in Hong Kong at Tokyo. What a surprise! It was completely different. Staff was not friendly. We practically had to beg for water and were only given 2 small bottles to drink and for brushing teeth. No one told us about the free long distance phone calls -- I had to ask. We were supposedly given an upgrade but we couldn't tell a difference. We were given a "non-smoking" room but our first room smelled so bad and smoky we asked to be moved. The attendant said she couldn't smell anything but would see what she could do. They moved us another room with a better view (we first looked out on a construction site) and one that didn't smell. There seems to be so many options for great hotels in Tokyo, I would never recommend staying here.

Second stay at this 5 star hotel. Service is excellent. Before arrival the guest relations had made a local retail purchase and arrange train tickets - both ready on arrival and check in. I was also able to check in to my suite well ahead of the 1500 standard. I had 15+ business meetings during the 4 days stay and room service for refreshments was punctual and efficient. Taxis are always available.

I travel nearly every week for business so have stayed in many, many, 5 star hotels, but i have to say this is the BEST nights sleep I have had in any hotel anywhere.As an Architect the room to me may not be the most hip or trendy in terms of decor, but they have all of the requirements and more that you may ever need, (they still have fax machines in every room). every conceivable thing you could need is in this room.I have to in particular mention the layout and the proportions of the room which are ideal and I wish all other hotels would review this. We came to the hotel straight from snowboarding and had a ton of stuff with us including snowboards yet the generous walk-in wardrobe just absorbed all of our stuff plus all of our shopping with out it ever feeling cramped.The bathrooms are equally sized and impressive (especially for Tokyo where even in other 5 star hotels bathrooms are normally capsule hotel style).Then there is the bedroom which would be like a junior suite in other hotels, my wife had family over, but there is so much space with a sofa ad side chairs ideally placed to watch tv comfortably that they never want to leave. You can ten go to the wardrobe and get dressed in private in your own time. To say these rooms are generous is an understatement.Finally there is the service and as one would expect from the Peninsula it is stellar, no more can be said.This is my new favourite Tokyo hotel surpassing both the newly renovated Tokyu Palace Hotel and the Park Hyatt, which are both excellent hotels in their own rights..

Our room on the 22nd floor was huge, quiet, beautifully decorated, and totally comfortable, with a view of Ginza's lights. Every amenity imaginable was available. The reception staff was warm and helpful, even offering to make calls to try to recover a rain coat I probably left on the train. The hotel location is great, directly above a subway station, near a JR station, an easy walk to shopping, restaurants, convenience stores and coffee shops, and next to the quiet park. The concierge was very helpful recommending good restaurants, making reservations for us, and helping us get there. Breakfast and lunch in the lobby restaurant was tasty but expensive; the cafe and carry-out bakery on the lower level was much more reasonable and also had delicious salads and pastry.

Service level was excellent. Nothing missed as requested. From before check-in request until a late check out and even after check-out, I stay around and missed something, they are still serving me as a guest and nothing has missed. From my request for my friend to check in before my flight arrival and offered us a connecting room, this hotel is really thinking ahead for the guests before their arrival. The room is very japanese style but I remember one time I stayed there for sleeping over 12 hours and didnt want to get up. For some reasons, I want to take that bed home with me cos I finally catched up my sleeping there (that means it is quiet, no noise, no phone calling u to make up the room) and it is just wonderful. Of course, did I mention that I go shopping and shopping for a whole day after waking up ? Next to Ginza, connected to the subway station, this hotel is the great location for Tokyo shoppers....

I've stayed at so many different hotels over the years (worldwide) but have never fallen so hard and so fast in love as I have with the Peninsula Hotel.12 hours into my 1 week stay, I can easily say this is my new all-time favourite.The Hotel itself is stunningly beautiful. The rooms are very large and there are so many little details I'll probably still be discovering things on my last day (need to dry your freshly manicured nails in the very large dressing room/ walk-in closet?). Even the in-room espresso is to die for. Opted for room service on my first night after a very long flight - no matter where I've stayed I never had an in-room dining experience like this. The food was absolutely phenomenal - in fact if that was my only meal here, I'd be quite alright with that, it was THAT good.The location is perfect and the views from the room (facing the city and gardens) is like a prettier than a postcard.The service is beyond stellar...from checking in, to turn-down service, to in-room dining.It's all in the details that are raising and setting the bar to a whole new level of excellence.I may never leave :)

We had just had a stay at The Peninsula in Tokyo for one week and what a disappointment this was. Having stayed here before we came back for afternoon tea. Stood in a queue for an hour like prisoners waiting in line for food. The afternoon tea was incredibly mediocre and over in 45 minutes. We were staying at The Upper house and wow did this knock the socks off Peninsula
user_name:
alison r
Cape Town Central, South Africa

review_body: We stayed for a week. it was so homely and welcoming, our room did not have a great view and i think for the money and lenght of our stay they could have put us in a nicer room. We loved the cafe downstairs and watching the pastry chefs everyday was a treat. Peter, the restaurant is so outdated and kitsch, needs an urgent update.Everything else was perfect.
user_name:
alison r
Cape Town Central, South Africa

review_body: My wife and I have recently paid a visit at Tokyo in early April. We have chosen Peninsula as I think I am quite kinda like a "Pen-friend". We flied overnight from Hong Kong to Tokyo and arrived in Tokyo in super morning. Although we requested for early check in (they do offer and guarantee late check out at 4pm), we didn't feel optimistic as we finally arrived in the hotel at 8pm. The rooms were very full as it's Sakura Blossom season so they couldn't have room available for us which was expected. We dropped off our luggages and went to Tsukiji market as it operates early in the morning. We spent 2-3 hours there and returned to Peninsula around 11am. Lucky us, there was a room available also we got a complimentary upgrade to a room with palace view on the 23rd floor. The room is super spacious with cloakroom and huge bathroom (bathtub + shower with double basin). One day morning, we over slept till nearly 11am and were going to miss the breakfast. We called for the room service and they delivered the foods to us within 30mins. We were having our breakfast in the room and the way they served us was just like having meals in a fine dining restaurant. We enjoyed the breakfast with the view of palace. The quality and efficiency of hotel environment and staff' service is no doubt extraordinary and superb. Last but not least, their location is really convenient as it's located right above the metro station (passageway direct connected to Yurakucho station). Besides, few more metro stations of another lines are also situated nearby (within 5-10min walk). My wife and I would definitely come back. PS - You may also happen to see celebrities from HK as I did. :)

A visit to Tokyo won't be complete without a stay at Peninsula. Every aspect of this renowned residence bears the signature of top notch hotel management. I shall economise on description of rooms and facilities, as other visitors might have given ample details. I must give special mention on the outstanding service of Masuda San and Takahashi San at Concierge desk. They helped me make multiple restaurant reservations, and also provided individual maps with directions for each destination. This is what distinguishes Peninsula!

i am conflicted..the claridge's in london has always been my favorite hotel but the peninsula tokyo may just trump the claridge's. the service, the decor, the in room dining, the view, the spacious layout of the rooms, the location, the spa, the pool, i can go on and on...everything about this hotel is perfect. if i can live here, i would. there are many 5 star hotels in tokyo but you must give the peninsulal a try. they do everything just right. the service is impeccable. they will hold your bags for you if you are taking a side trip for a few days to another part of the country. everything is organized, neat, efficient. and everything in the room function properly.

Can't beat the location in Ginza, with close proximity to the JR Yurakucho station and access to the Metro (Hibiya Sta) through the hotel itself. Staff is exceptional and the room was fantastic. Huge bedroom and sitting area, loads of space for baggage. Bathroom was terrific -- great shower and magnificent tub. Wifi in the room and throughout the hotel was very fast.The gym was disappointing for a luxury hotel. Handful of circuit machines, cable machine and free weights -- but if you are serious about weight training, you will find it lacking. Several cardio machines though, and the gym never seemed to be crowded. Ginormous pool as well, so if you are into swimming laps or just splashing around, it's worth checking out.Peter's bar on the 24th floor is great for drinks and a view. Like many bars in Tokyo, you will smell a little smoky afterward. I found the lobby to be really odd -- the restaurant is right there when you walk in on either side as you are either exiting the hotel or headed to the reception desk, so it feels like you are walking through the middle of the restaurant. Overall, it was a lovely stay, but not worth the Peninsula price tag for me.

Our family stayed at the Peninsula Tokyo for 3 nights. Typical Peninsula luxury...as to be expected. No surprises. Not as amazing as some of the other Peninsula hotels we have stayed in (the one in Shanghai is just over the top!). The breakfast menu (for the included breakfast) was a bit more limited than I would have hoped. Great location. Lovely staff. Lovely spacious rooms.

Great location in Hibiya right above the subway station and about a five minute walk to the main shopping district in Ginza. Rooms are large with modern technology and comfy beds. Separate closet/dressing area is a big plus. Housekeeping staff is excellent.

This hotel not only met, but exceed our high expectations for our stay in Tokyo. Wonderful rooms with very helpful and attentive staff. The location is excellent. Just minutes away from Tokyo station, taxis at your beck and call, and a metro station in the basement. This is one of the best hotels in the world! The staff was very friendly and accomplished all of our request no questions asked. Wifi was also very fast and always up and running.

We stayed here for 3 nights at the end of a Far Eastern Cruise, and really enjoyed our stay. Our room was very luxurious with every mod con. Breakfast was included in our package & we enjoyed a delicious breakfast in the lobby restaurant every day, the service was good and all the staff were very pleasant. We ate dinner in the restaurant on the 24th floor on our first evening, mainly as it was a cold wet evening & we didn't fancy going out. It was quite expensive but the food was delicious and it was nice for a special treat. The other 2 evenings we went exploring in Ginza & found restaurants in that area. On our last day we had a quick lunch in the bakery in the basement & it was delicious.

The room category just above the standard room is extremely nice and there are many restaurant options . The roof top bar is very pleasant . The service, the facilities are all good .It is located right next to Ginza, the main high end shopping area. they dont scrimp and scrounge on water and wifi. The scale and dimension of the Hotel outside as well as the facade are not pleasing and too massive. But once inside everything is nice.

My second Peninsula stay, after Manila... well it's a superb 5* hotel, what else to say, I came to Tokyo for the city, not to stay in my hotel room lolMy room BTW, superb view on the imperial palace garden. Large bathroom with 2 sinks but the toilets are in the same room, not cool. Large dressing room.Our rate did not include breakfast, which we chose not to take in the hotel, as it is served in the cramped and noisy lobby, what a shame. And it's a la carte, not buffet, probably because lack of space.

Tokyo's most exciting luxury hotel where i am delighted to send my friends time and again.it is 24 storey high situated in financial district with great location.directly connected to subway.its second opening opens to shopping district of GINZA . .

We had very high expectations for the iconic hotel and for the most part, the Peninsula Tokyo went above and beyond. The room was very well-designed: the TV was directly facing the bed so the guests don't need to twist their necks, dining table with fork and knife in the room for the guests to enjoy the snacks, fresh fruits upon arrival, luxurious dressing room with oversize wardrobe, bathroom with double vanity and a spa-experience bathtub... and this is just to name a few. However, the kettle was not provided even though we found a teapot near the mini-bar. We called room service to bring the kettle over and it took more than half an hour for the attendant to arrive. The front desk felt understaffed to us. The iconic property had a big lobby seating all the lounge patrons, however, the reception desk was tucked into a small area. Given the number of guests checking in/out at the hotel at a given time, at times the wait time could be long. We wanted to consult the concierge regarding nearby fruit markets, and we had to wait for more than 15 minutes before we could speak with her. Overall, the Peninsula lived up to the standards and the guest room was definitely one of the best we have ever stayed in.

We visited the Peninsula Tokyo for 3 nights, April 2-5, 2015 and could not have been more pleased. We arrived Tokyo very late the first night and still had a quick, seamless check in with out any delay. The lavazza coffee makers are such a nice touch! The room was large and spacious, and laid out very well with a separate dressing area, living room area, and the most luxurious bathroom! Twin sinks, the largest bathtub with a waterfall faucet, rain shower, Oscar de la Renta toiletries. The concierge, especially Ms Harumo, took care of all of our restaurant bookings, some several months in advance. They also organized our round trip shinkansen tickets. You also could not ask for a better location and the most efficient taxi line I have ever seen. This is the only hotel I will ever stay at in Tokyo.

The Peninsula Tokyo is very luxurious and you really can't fault anything in the hotel. The staff is wonderful and very helpful. I agree with other reviews that the lobby is disappointing with no room to sit and relax, you walk right through a restaurant to get to the elevator and the front desk. I can't imagine it's nice for people eating at the restaurant either. The little things make this hotel exceptional. The floors in the bathroom are heated. The large closet and dressing room are second to none. The couch and small table for meals (already set for use) are nice. We didn't use the pool but we did take a look. You have to go through the spa to get to it and I'm not sure it's really designed for kids, which may be good for some people. The location is good. You can walk from Tokyo Station or take a taxi for around 1000 Yen. It is a short walk to Ginza and the subway and JR line are very convenient. We had room service one night. It was 'okay' nothing spectacular, but there are plenty of restaurants and bars very close to the hotel.

The Peninsula Tokyo was great just as everyone else said so I don't need to repeat those words again. We stayed there twice, most recently last week. Hotel concierge booked us a sushi restaurant. That was our one night out in town without the kids so we were quite looking forward to it. The sushi restaurant was located in Ginza and had a 48-hour cancellation policy. Our taxi driver couldn't find it and so was everyone we asked around the block. After walking in the rain for more than 30 minutes trying to find it we gave up and settled in another restaurant because the babysitter would be leaving in 1 1/2 hour and we were very cold and starving. While we were in the restaurant trying to enjoy what was left of our evening, concierge called to tell us since we didn't make it to the restaurant, we need to pay for it anyway. While I tried to explain what happened, she firmly pointed out the map they gave us had never failed before and I must had a very bad taxi driver. At the end, she "kindly" reminded me that I must go to the concierge desk on the next day to settle the bill for the original restaurant. After that we tried very hard to enjoy the rest of meal. When I went to see the concierge service to settle the bill, I said right away that I would pay for the restaurant bill as agreed but I did not appreciate the way how the concierge staff handled the entire situation. The concierge manager came after I talked to one of the staffs. The first thing she said to me was, "Did you not have a phone with you? It didn't occur to you to call us for direction?" WOW...

The rooms are beautiful, large with a separate dressing room and a bathroom that is close to perfect. The public rooms are all very pleasing spaces although the lobby can get a bit busy for my taste with a rather pricy and forgettable continental breakfast available while we waited for our room to be ready since we arrived very tearly. The service is beyond reproach and the concierge always helpful. The breakfast buffet,which was included in our room rate, is in the B1 level of the hotel and has everything one could want in a western breakfast. Unfortunately it seems that many guest are unaware of this gem in the basement. Overall the rooms are the stars of this hotel but everything else is totally satisfying.

Okay, I'm sure the rest of the hotel was great but we LOVED our room. It was so spacious it had a long HALLWAY (with the bathroom on one side and the walk-in-closet on the other) that lead to an expansive bedroom. Even though the suite was only 700 square feet, our room had a wall of windows at the far side that made the room seem enormous. Also, the designer was very smart in how they utilized every square inch to maximize comfort for the weary traveler. The bathroom was amazing! An enormous spa tub, dual sinks, shower and toilet. There was an espresso maker right in the room. Also, the subway line is right at the base of the hotel. Honestly, the hotel has a great many amenities to offer. For us, all we needed was our room. :)

I am not sure how you can fault anything at that hotel. The location is exceptional, the subway line is in the basement of the hotel, across the street from the Imperial Palace, and near a lot of good restaurants. Our room was exquisite although we had no view at all. The level of details in that room was exceptional. The beds were very comfortable and an espresso machine in our room made for an excellent night and morning. I am going to miss the deep tub and the water pressure in the shower. I am not sure how they clean the rooms or do the turn down as you never see a cart in the corridor but it is done exceptionally well and twice a day. We were quite jet lagged so we ordered room service at 2 am and the attendant spoke excellent English and the food was delicious. Our breakfast was included and delicious. Lots of choices. As many other reviewers complained about the location of the lobby restaurant, I did not dislike it at all. The only thing we did not like is that smoking is allowed at the Peter bar and we were surrounded by smoke when we went for a drink and chose to drink fast and leave. We are just no longer used to people smoking around us. And finally the service was excellent, from the front desk to the transportation desk, to the restaurant servers; everyone was so helpful. It is expensive but it's still value for money. I've stayed at equally expensive hotels in Istanbul, Hawaii and Munich for instance but I was never as wowed as I was at the Peninsula Tokyo. I am sure they work hard at it, but in my opinion it pays off. And I am not sure I can stay anywhere else in Tokyo and be happy.

The location is great, tucked between ginza, the imperial gardens and the financial district. The place looks beautiful, great art installations, generous rooms, gorgeous bath rooms, many rooms have nice views of the gardens. The gym is great, the pool looked but unfortunately I didn't have time to use it. Service was exceptional. Great choice if this hotel is within budget.
user_name:
Oliver J
New York City, New York

review_body: It seems kind of normal nowadays that luxury hotel goes through phases. Rare is the hotel that can consistently maintain a high standard and generally, they do tend to regress after several years, sometimes significantly so. Such unfortunately is the case with the Peninsula Tokyo. When it first opened nearly 9 years ago, the hotel was ground-breaking in every way with truly great wow factor in every aspects, with incomparable rooms, the finest decoration and fittings and excellent F&B and immaculate and attentive service. During it's first few years where I visited Tokyo quite often, I repeatedly patronized the hotel. Peninsula was and remained one of my favorite hotels in Tokyo until now. So what has changed in my latest stay? The hotel appears to be still popular but with a different crowd. Breakfast was set-menu only, the same every day and appallingly limited in the number of choices, in a crowded environment with tables so close to each other that I got very uncomfortable when the guest next to me start to cough and sneeze away. Whereas in the past, you get a great table if you wake up early, now, the lobby lounge, which is the only venue for breakfast is always crowded. The choices are standard fair asian or western continental or american breakfast. While they still do the omelet right, the pastries were dull, the coffee mediocre and everything else is not what it seems compared to the high standards of the past. I still recalled fondly in the past when ordering the Peninsula breakfast set, it comes with a tray that resembled the afternoon tea with bite-size pastries and sandwiches all very neatly done. Now, the servicing is just plain and uninspired. And so is the biggest problem with the hotel, the F&B. I did have a free F&B voucher courtesy of my travel agent and tried to utilized it by having dinner at the lobby restaurant. I should not have been bothered. The caesar salad was served over-flowing with dressing and taste awful while the main course, a fish dish… the less said about it the better. How can a 5-tar luxury hotel serves food of such appalling quality? It has clearly been rushed or mass produced in the kitchen with little or no care to the taste. So was the breakfast I ordered in-room and the waffles tasted so bad they were inedible. I am sure any restaurant within walking distance from the hotel will serve 10X better quality food with less than 1/2 the price. Another big problem with the hotel now is the service which has really gone downhill. Staff behavior especially at the lobby lounge during breakfast was very snotty and they seemed intended just to show how busy they are and rush to take your order than to service the customer.
