No smiles, no greetings and not even a "Good Morning". This is really ironic consider that Japanese by nature tends to be very polite and have extremely good service. Service was a bit better during other meals but still nothing special. Everything about this hotel is by the book as if they are following an instruction manual. I am guessing the hotel has lost a lot of good staff to competitors. Which brings me to the next issue, nickel and dime. I have never, I mean never ever in my 10+ years of travel ever encountered a luxury hotel that wanted to charge me for a nail cutter ( JPY1,000 ). Or ask for "delivery charges" ( JPY500 ) for in-room dinning. A strong complaint to the Manager on duty resolved the first issue but I did not bother with the second. Such behavior just annoys the guests and makes the hotel seems very small-minded and stingy. Any plus? Tthe hotel rooms are relatively well maintained and the location is still unbeatable, walking distance from Ginza and with a subway station right under the basement of the hotel. However, the glamour has faded significantly and in my opinion as a discerning traveler, I don't think this property can still be considered top end in Tokyo anymore, especially with properties like the Aman Tokyo and Andaz just opened.

First impression is last impression ! I think Tokyo has the best service ever ! This city never fails to make u happy ! The service of the hotel is beyond expectations plus the location is just excellent !! Extremely worth it .. We will definitely stay there again

A fantastic hotel located right in the centre of Tokyo's ginza district. The staff is really friendly and helpful. The rooms are just great with wide beds, nice bedding and really big bathrooms. There is a well equipped gym with a decent sized swimming pool. The view from the bar on the top floor is just breath taking.There is no breakfast buffet - you have to order from the menu. Choices are not that great if you are a vegetarian or have food allergies.

My room was huge and spacious. The bathroom was absolutely beautiful with a gorgeous kimono in the drawer.I slept very well in the hotel as it was so peaceful. The staff were super friendly and everything ran like clockwork - a very efficient hotel, which is what you need when traveling for business.
user_name:
rosyro
New York City, New York

review_body: The Peninsula Hotel is beautifully built, but in high season at least (when we were here), the hotel's service let us down. We were seated at breakfast next to a door with a cold air rushing in. We had to ask for blankets to stop from freezing.Also, a pet peeve of mine: 1) they tell you at check in that breakfast is included, 2) they bring you a bill every morning at breakfast and ask you to sign the bill but assure you it is only for accounting purposes and that it will be backed out on your final bill, and 3) then at check out they say you went over some kind of minimum that they never told you about and that you owe the overage. I am too old to have to fight these stupid fights!The hotel has a great location. Unfortunately, the bait on switch on breakfast left a bad taste in my mouth.
user_name:
silverandbluedog
New York City, New York

review_body: I cannot say anything bad about the room I stayed in at the Peninsula Tokyo because it was simply magnificent : spacious, impeccably appointed and all round comfort. What to me takes the shine out of this place is the crowded foyer, slightly chaotic check in process and lower floor rooms being overlooked by nearby office blocks. The location is good if not removed from more exciting nightlife.

Such a fantastic location with easy access to public transport and sights of interest (Imperial Palace, Ginza, Fish Market). We had a lovely room that was exceptionally well appointed on the 14th floor that was also well sound proofed. Breakfast was a choice of American style or Japanese, that was well presented and always accompanied by fantastic service. Used the concierge service for booking local restaurants which was extremely useful as many did not have the ability to book online.

This is one of the best hotels I've stayed in to date, this was my first stay in a Peninsula hotel and won't be my last, from the moment you enter through the revolving door you are greeted by welcoming and present staff, the check in desk is small and modestly placed at the rear however this all adds to the intimate and friendly feel of the hotel, while checking in you can hear the gentle music from the live piano player who is situated above the lobby.We had a deluxe city view room, which was amazing! The view through the floor to ceiling windows of the imperial palace gardens to one side and the city to the other was breath taking, as was the rest of the room. The room had a walk in wardrobe which was the size of a small room and a very large bathroom room which at the touch of a bottom turned into a private spa room complete with mood lighting and tranquil music. The only issue with the rooms were that it was a smoking room, when booking it didn't even occur to ask for a non smoking room as since the smoking ban in the UK I don't even consider asking anymore, but being a non smoker I could smell the stale smell of smoke in the room when I entered or lay on the sofa. However when I enquired with the guest relations about the smell they where more than helpful and offered to switch room, as I had unpacked and the smell seemed to disappear fast I just stayed put, so instead they sent a bottle of wine to the room when they did the turn down service, which was lovely to sip whole overlooking the city at night.The rest of the hotel was just as good as the rooms, the pool area is a great place to unwind after walking around the city, the staff bring proved you with water, towels and swimming hats ( which are mandatory in the swimming pool) but once you get over the fact you look ridiculous it ok.Peters bar in he roof has great views of the city and as you would expect from a roof bar very stylish, happy hour was between 5-7 with most drinks half price which is alway good.The hotel had a private entrance to the underground from the lobby, once you get your head around the net work is far better than a taxi, not only miles cheaper but much faster, we used an app which directs you through the system using the colours and number.All in all a great stay, amazing staff and service, if you visiting Tokyo I would highly recommend staying here. Sent from my I phone

During our first trip to Tokyo we got a super deal on this hotel from Expedia - more than 50% cheaper than other 5* hotels in Tokyo, but without any compromise on what you would expect from The Peninsula Hotel brand. This hotel is in the centre of Tokyo, in an area compared to Mayfair in London - brilliant starting point! Your every need is looked after, and they were very helpful in booking me some great Michelin Starred Sushi restaurants in the area. The room itself was incredible, huge bathroom with separate shower and bathtub and the notorious japanese automatic toilet! You also have a large space for your bags and clothes, kind of like a walk in wardrobe - fantastic when on a longer trip. The bedroom section is also very large, overall providing great value for money. There is also a subway station attached to the hotel, making the navigation of the city very easy. Even if you are not familiar with their system, the Japanese people are always willing to help! Finally, the staff are incredible here. From opening doors to delivering bags and room service - they did not accept tips, nor did they wait around to see if you would give one, they just got on with providing their service with a smile! I don't think I would stay anywhere else in Tokyo - and I will definitely be back! P.S The bar at Peter's restaurant has great views, cocktails and incredible staff too!

Strange lobby as you walk in as the check in is at the back. Room was wonderful with great views, bathrooms to die for and a walking wardrobe . Beds and pillows very comfortable with everything being automated. Service second to none. Swimming pool is. A good extra with a reasonable gym. spa looks good although I didn't try it. Really central with some great shops around the corner. Tokyo is a must and the Pen is the only place to stay.

Once again had the pleasure of staying at this wonderful hotel. The room renovations are subtle but all great improvements, new carpeting, new throw pillows etc. The service remains top rate and the food is also great. The spa is still one of the best in the city and they remain competitive by offering new services and treatments. Interestingly, they have now changed their rates to reflect demand, so a weekend treatment is much more expensive than a weekday treatment. This is still one of favorite hotels in the world due to the excellent standards they continuously meet on every stay.

One of the finest hotels I have stayed in, set in a quiet but accessible part of Tokyo above a major transit hub and very close to Tokyo Station. Everything is impeccable about this hotel; the only curious feature is the built in electronics in the gracious rooms which will need work shortly. Highly recommended.

Probably the best hotel I have ever been in. Fantastic service, fabulous room, lots of gadgets around like electric blinds, Lavazza coffee machine and the best Japanese technology toilette I saw in Japan.It is located in Ginza that has lots of places to shop and to have dinner.And the cherry: it has a direct access to the Subway! You can take an elevator and arrive to entrance of Hibya station of the Chiyoda Line.

Im at a bit of a loss to describe this hotel. Is it expensive?yes it is . Is it worth it?yes. If you have to go to Tokyo this is the place to stay. We arrive at airport and hotel pick us up( yes it is expensive) the car trip was fantastic and upon arrival at hotel we were greeted with a ton of staff , we did nothing but walk . taken straight to our room , no check in at front desk.i think our check in at our room took the whole of 5 mins.The room it self was spotless from top to bottom, it was great fun just working out all the gadgets . Not to spoil anything , just work it out when your there. breakfast was a little weird but the silver service was great. Subway under the hotel, not that you would know. the rooms are whisper quite.We are not your typical couple that look like we have money, we are more a jeans and teeshirt kind of people but we were still got treated the same as the suit and dress people.The sauna and steam rooms are great and used frequently, especially after being out in 5 deg days.The staff at Peninsula are above and beyond the best we have come across, i cant just mention any one part of them because they all do there job perfectly.I guess thats what this hotel is, Perfect. If you can afford it , stay there

I've stayed her many times (20+) and this has, hands down, the best hotel rooms of any major hotel on the planet. Large size room (would be a junior suite in a lot of hotels), great walk-in wardrobe, excellent bathroom and a high level of soundproofing (smart design includes an extra sliding door separating the bedroom from the hallway). Room service is also good and the service is up there with the best in Tokyo (although not as personal and friendly as the Four Seasons Marunouchi, which has the benefit of being small and more intimate). Only two negatives - one is that is very popular and I often have trouble getting a room (there is no "priority" for regular guests) and the restaurants are not great - the breakfast lobby room is always very busy and is in an awkward position in the lobby. The main western restaurant, Peter, changed a few years ago from being an excellent French-themed restaurant to a grill and is nothing special - it needs a rethink to match the standards of the rest of the hotel.That aside, a great option in Tokyo.

Wow hotel, very pricey but the rooms are high tech chic right down to the yr very own espresso machine. Staff are extremely respectful and always welcoming. Loved the Tokyo Joe cocktails and Japanese breakfast. Location great, 50 to 100 meters to train station, imperial gardens and ginza shopping district and the all important McDonalds for the kids general area is cough cough Rodeo expensive.

Back here for the last night of my week-long trip, and the third hotel I stayed at.Room was exactly as I remembered - very spacious and luxurious, with a great layout. Closing the large wooden sliding door would shut out the bedroom away from the bathroom and closet, and would help insulate noise. A very nice touch.Still liking the fact that the sofa and bed are in a straight line with the TV, making everything easy. One of my all-time favorite hotel bathroom designs. Everything makes perfect sense and well-thought out, with two sinks on opposite sides of the room.Hotel concierge is extremely helpful with restaurant bookings.There are two exits of the Hibiya Station right next to the hotel, so it's very convenient. It's also a very short walk from Ginza, and right in front of the Imperial Palace.

Beautiful hotel located in front of the Imperial Palace. Close walk to where the shopping is. Beautiful marble bathroom. Spacious interior with separate living and sleeping areas. Comfy beds. Only downside is no early check in whatsoever so had to wait till past 3pm to get to the room which I feel like is a little unaccommodating for the price you pay...

This was our second stay at The Peninsula, Tokyo. Staff were just as professional and the rooms just as beautiful. Housekeeping once again excel at providing impeccable and immaculate rooms that are so comfortable to stay in. Seriously, the housekeeping staff here are incredible. Our numerous requests made prior to arriving were all met including our request to have the cot for our baby placed in the walk in robe (which the same size as some Japanese hotel rooms and still had plenty or room for our luggage and a study!)I do love the in room coffee machine as good coffee in japan is hard to find. I still loved the pool and spa and the service in this area is just wonderful. In the basement there is an ATM and bakery and there is also clear windows so we can enjoy watching the pastry chefs at work. My husband and baby were sleeping one afternoon so I took my toddler down to the bakery for a treat - all the pastries and hot chocolates here were so delicious. However due to a private party, there was nowhere to sit. I felt that the cafe could have provided small tables and chairs within the cafe section or perhaps in the wide walkway outside. There could have been other options provided and I think that this should have been arranged for the inhouse guests. The lobby restaurant however were very gracious in allowing us to enjoy our goods there though. I'm sure this is not policy however I appreciate the leniency. By the afternoon we all really enjoyed walking around the Ginza and seeing the lights etc of this vibrant community. The Peninsula is expensive but it's worth it. We had just come from the JW Marriott,Seoul which has spoiled us and given us new definition of luxury - previously this hotel was the standard for me. This hotel is still exquisite though and the standards and furnishings have not slipped in the two years since our last visit. We will return again to The Peninsula.

We recently vacationed in Japan and while in Tokyo stayed at the Peninsula. The room and the service was beyond reproach. The only reason I didn't give this a 5 star is the breakfast. Do yourself a treat, stay at the hotel but eat breakfast elsewhere - there are other places close by that offer more interesting and better food and at a fraction of the price.
user_name:
harasmr
New York City, New York

review_body: I stayed at The Peninsula in early December 2014 - but haven't managed to write a review until now !From the moment you arrive this is certainly a 5 star hotel - staff are engaging, professional and very helpful - the concierge was particularly helpful about a query with one of my shopping bills at the Ginza Apple store and took it upon herself to phone the store and sort it all out, taking quite a long time on the phone (for which I felt a bit guilty, to be perfectly honest...)The rooms are very well appointed, some would describe the furniture a bit dated, but I personally feel it is fine. It is very nice to have a proper seating area in your room, all facilities were excellent, although I perhaps would expect toiletries to be of a more luxury brand - but I am clutching at straws here. The closet was really a walk-in dressing room, which was perfect, even for such a short trip as mine. As for the bathroom, cavernous and i couldn't fault it in any way. I also made use of the dry cleaning service, which was hyper efficient, as the rest of the hotel.If I haven't given this hotel a full rating is for the simple reason of their restaurant for breakfast/lunch/afternoon tea. It is literally part of the lobby, and when having breakfast I felt like I was part of the group just waiting for someone else to join them in the lobby itself, I could have join into their conversation with no effort at all! The problem, as pointed by other travellers, is that you would be at the restaurant, literally sitting at the other side of the sofas in the lobby itself - I feel this could do with re-designing for such a hotel.Room service was polite, professional and with no faults at all.All in all, I would strongly recumbent this hotel. We are travelling to Japan in May this year, as a holiday, and the Peninsula is certainly a strong contender for us to book for our stay in Tokyo.
user_name:
Flying D
Brighton and Hove, United Kingdom

review_body: This has to be one of my all time favorite hotels. It is modern built with noble materials. Lots of wood. Incredible Japanese breakfast. Moonlight lighting in the bathroom. The best was I came from Miami Basel and did not realize you were not allowed to lock your suitcase and when I went to take my bath in the moonlight lighting, you have a choice of lighting, I discovered that I could not open my luggage and had to call to the desk for sissors. The best bit is that there is a modesty door in the dressing room and they put the sissors inside and a light on so you can open the door and see no one and when you are finiished with them you just put them back through the little cabinet door and put on the light and they pick them up and you never have to be disturbed by anyone. Very Japanese, very elegant and serene. Cannot say enough good things about this hotel.

Convenient location near Imperial Palace. Large, understated and classy rooms with technologically modern facilities and amenities. Excellent service - they comply with your requests promptly and sympathetically. Main drawback is lobby is too small and somewhat unwelcoming. Dining options are limited to typical overpriced hotel restaurants, not gastronomic destinations.

One of the best hotels in Tokyo. Im lucky I work for a company that allows us stay at The Peninsula. It is truly luxurious and they make sure everything is thought of and provided for in this hotel. Located just near the Imperial Palace and a short walk to Ginza, this hotel is a great place to stay if you can afford to. The gym and spa here are good and have the equipment you need. The hotel does have hire bikes which are great to rent out if you are here over a weekend and want to see Tokyo in a different pace. Tokyo is excellent for cycling and caters well for bikes. Great places to eat nearby and the view from Peters bar located on Level 24 is brilliant in the evening.Very friendly staff!

After staying at the Ritz in Kyoto and the St. Regis in Osaka, which were outstanding, I really expected something special from the Tokyo Peninsula, but this property is really just an all around bummer. From the moment you walk in, you feel it, something is off, something is a bit ten years ago... and it only gets worse when you get to your room. there are no outlets anywhere near the bedside table, where you would need to charge your phone or iPad, but there is a built in nail dryer at the built in vanity, atop the weird, worn, dark orange wall-to-wall carpeting. The furniture is beaten and shabby, the bulbs in the ceiling are of mismatched wattage and type... but the coupe de gras is the entire cabinet below the writing desk devoted to the FAX MACHINE. the exit from the elevators is positioned in such a way that one is forced to promenade just in front of the 5 or 6 reception attendants every time you enter or exit, which causes too much forced pleasantries, it really gets old. The lobby looks great in photos, but in reality is just a big loud cafeteria, packed with aged locals and perplexed tourists. All wrong, this property has just gotten it all wrong. If I had not payed in advance I would flee with my luggage to the competing property.

I have to say peninsula Tokyo has dropped from being one of my top Tokyo hotels to the Bottom.The concierge service is ATROCIOUS. Terrible attitude with pitiful of knowledge of good restaurant recommendations. When asked to recommend restaurants that are open from 2 30 pm onwards, they recommended an unhygienic and run-down looking place which does not adhere to the normal 5 star hotel recommendation standards. This has led to a food poisoning episode. It is sad to see such a great hotel deteriorate in the span of less than 4 years. Rooms need to be redecorated and are looking very dull. It is NOTHING Like a few years ago and is totally unacceptable, not to mention utterly disappointing. Happy to leave to Aman tomorrow and try out newer hotels in Tokyo. It is extremely disappointing again that peninsula cannot keep up with their usual standards. Never RETURNING

Just returned from a two-night stay in this den of luxury. A true luxury hotel in all aspects, especially the price of extras. Breakfast is ¥4,200 a piece, and personally I feel totally overpriced for a no-buffet, set menu fare. Wishing to change all the sugary sticky buns offered, to something more healthy, like some fruit, was a bit of a fight and a struggle. I did win in the end, but I don't like that doing that... Everything in the hotel has a price, and nothing is free..Having said that, it's a gorgeous place. The hotel rooms are the best I've ever stayed in, the most comfortable bed I've ever experienced, and quiet. Typical Japanese smiles abound, and service is unparalleled. if you've got money to burn, the. You will love this place.. Sir Paul McCartney makes it his choice of residence when he's in town, and I can see why...Restaurants, food quality were all top notch. Peter Bar, is an ideal place for a cocktail or afternoon tea.. Comfortable, warm, with such a dose of sophistication.. Dinner there will be one you'll never forget... I would rank this as THE best hotel in Tokyo..

The Peninsula Tokyo is exactly what you would expect from a Peninsula hotel. The service was of the highest quality and their rooms are spacious and homey. The location is perfect in the Ginza area, next to many great restaurants. The concierge was very accommodating with our list of restaurants we wanted to eat in and places we wanted to see. The Peninsula name is always associated with luxury and this hotel does not disappoint. It lives up to its name, i highly recommend!
user_name:
Piaroj
New York City, New York

review_body: Staying in this hotel made our trip to Tokyo most memorable. The sense of arrival the moment you step into the lobby would immediately make you feel that your stay will be quite special. The elegant warm interiors complement that warm reception we experienced when we checked into the front desk and for the entire duration of our stay. The rooms are large and comfortable with the best amenities. We specially liked the bathroom with its mood light and music at a press of a button. Good food in the lobby area and friendly, efficient service. Great location to explore good food and shopping. When staying in this hotel, you simply get what you pay for.

I enjoyed my stay over there. Very friendly staff. Excellent food, location is remarkable with a very good view. Highly recommended if you are visiting for business. You will enjoy a very good sleep. Rooms are well furnished. Hotel facilities are excellent.
user_name:
houssam_sabry
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: When you want to splurge or are on an expense account, this is an excellent place to stay. Great service and location for convenient upscale shopping, dining and wandering around. Great view of the palace from our suite on a business trip and excellent in room dining for breakfast perfectly presented. The Bathroom, dressing room and amenities were all fantastic.

Fantastic hotel - delivered on all expectations. Beautiful rooms, amazing service and excellent location from which to explore Tokyo. Loved every minute, nothing too diffcult for the staff.Huge thank you to the Concierge team who helped with suggestions for restaurants and made all reservations prior to our arrival.

The whole stay was nothing less than incredible. Very modern rooms with great bathrooms, luxurious beds and nice lounge areas. Afternoon tea was the best and the concierge was extremely polite and helpful. The Rolls Royce trip was just the cherry on top.

Great hotel with good restaurants. Ginza is a high class area with great shopping and food. V.close to metro station. Very clean and friendly staff prepared to help you with your stay as much as possible. I stayed 5 nights on a business trip and occasionally went out socially. 24 hour room service which is great considering i stayed up most of the night working.

This is a case of perfectly met expectations. How, might you say, does meeting expectations result in the highest rating? Well it is a Peninsula Hotel. The expectation is excellence. And they didn't miss. Expensive? Yep. You get what you pay for. If you want me to find something to quibble about then they could have more non-machine equipment in the gym (kettle bells, pull up bar, that kind of thing). Maybe a more welcoming lobby - really no meeting or relaxing space. That's it. Nothing else that's less than perfect.Rooms? Huge, elegant, understated, comfortable, etc. etc. If you "need" more than this than you need to get your ego checked. For us mere mortals it doesn't get better.

Excellent hotel, location, and service. Pretty much everything fro the hotel management to the room service were superb. All the staff members had done everything possible to make our stay as special as possible, and they did. I cannot recommend this hotel enough. It is an equally great place for business travelers, as well as for romantic getaways. We visited Tokyo for my son's 10th B-Day, and the Peninsula staff made it really special. THANK YOU!

Conveniently located with a train station at the basement of the hotel.Excellent service and cleanliness. Nice facilities including a gym and a pool with a view.It's a bit older now, but it remains as an excellent hotel choice.

This is my second time staying here and am delighted to be back!The rooms are very large with a separate spacious walk in closet and a large bathroom with a walk in shower and large soaking tub. As one would expect in a Peninsula property, the rooms and facilities have been obviously designed with great attention to detail to ensure a comfortable stay. Service is impeccable and the concierge is extremely knowledgeable and helpful. Location could not be better with convenient access to various subway and rail lines and Ginza shopping and dining within walking distance. I cannot recommend this more highly.

Hotel location : excellent . Room cleanliness : Excellent . Bed: extremely comfy . Bathroom : Perfect . Facilities : Excellent . Service : Excellent . Value: Worth every penny .Conclusion : I will definitely stay with Penn whenever I visit Tokyo .

My husband and I stayed at this property again early November for the occasion of our anniversary and my birthday. This is our second stay after the one in March because we have found this is the prime location while visiting Tokyo. We had the same room category facing the Imperial Garden. Restaurants and shops are just steps away. Room is super clean and service is impeccable with very helpful staff. We dined at their restaurants Peter and Hei Fung Terrace again like last time. We found out that the very cute and cozy cafe at the basement offers very very good cakes, desserts, and pastas at a very reasonable price. One big surprise is the Chinese breakfast at the Lobby restaurant. You may wonder why I ordered Chinese breakfast but not the Japanese one since I was in Tokyo. Well the reason is their Japanese breakfast should no doubt be wonderful (and it is a fact), but if a hotel in Tokyo offers a totally authentic Chinese breakfast, then that would be fantastic. It passed my test for being so authentic that I found out that the chef is from Hong Kong. I can even say that this breakfast can not only match the one that I had in Hong Kong but even surpasses the standard of a certain hotel.We like to appreciate all the assistance from the hotel managers, Front Desk staff, Concierge personnels, our room attendant , etc..... Everyone of you did provide us the best service that we had a very memorable stay.We will absolutely stay at this property again on our next visit to Tokyo.

a great great hotel - quite simply one of the very best in the world - I loved EVERYTHING about it and cannot at all understand some people's criticism of the foyer/lobby which is aesthetically beautiful and a great place to take breakfast ... I congratulate everyone who designed, who manages and who works at this hotel ... I score it 99 out of 100.

Truly enjoyed staying at the Peninsula, Tokyo. The rooms were nice and spacious ( so were the bathrooms). Lots of polite staff to help you. The bar on top, Peter, was special. The breakfast was well thought of and well-served. The concierge was helpful and knowledgeable too. I would surely stay here again.

This was my first return to the Peninsula since 2011, having previously stayed 5-6 times at this wonderful property, I must say they've maintained the excellent service and kept all the hardware in excellent shape. On every stay, their concierge team never fails to impress me and this visit was no exception. From finding restaurants in the middle of a typhoon to having dog snacks ordered and delivered to the hotel, they've managed every arrangement perfectly. Our room had some issues with the internet around 1-2am. They immediately offered an alternative solution, fixed it the next day, and true to a business built on first class service, followed-up with a letter explaining the situation plus a box of chocolates. No complaints. If I must pick something to complain about, it would be that housekeeping wasn't as good as before. The room was perfectly clean, sheets done right, amenities set perfectly, but the foreign housekeeping staff somehow misses the very small details (e.g. where the teddy bear sits after turndown) which the previous Japanese staff got right. We considered staying at the Mandarin Oriental Ginza or Shangri-la Ginza, but the location just doesn't compare with The Peninsula as the prime shopping areas in Ginza are just a few minutes walk away.It may be pricey, but it's still the best in Tokyo. And wow, this is their 1000th review!

We stayed here with our kids in March 2014. Staff and rooms were fabulous,(we had two rooms at $700+per night). Airport pick ups and train drop off (for us to take bullet train to Kyoto) were all so well done. We had a wonderful view of the palace. Great location to wander, shop and explore. We were there during cherry blossom season - hotel never "felt" over crowded. We will return!

This hotel is located in the Chiyoda ward where Hibiya Park and the Imperial Palace are located. Hibiya Station (Tokyo Metro) is just beneath the hotel. The famous Ginza shopping district is a short 10 minute walk away. The beautiful Hibiya Park is also nearby and for avid runners, there’s a wonderful 5km route within the park itself. The layout for hotel lobby itself is a bit strange – you will be walking along a pathway which cuts right through the middle of the restaurant / café, which will then lead to the front desk. We would have preferred the lobby area to be more spacious and with more sitting area. However, there are only 2 sofas located along the pathway which certainly lacks privacy as the surrounding area in the restaurant / café gets pretty crowded during the busy period. Checking in was very good. The front desk staffs were efficient, polite and professional. The concierge service was top notch as they were very detailed and helpful in our queries and reservation of restaurants. The room itself was very spacious (similar in size to a junior suite) with a well-planned and practical layout. And it certainly oozes with sheer luxury and comfort. There’s a separate walk-in dressing room which is also generously sized. It comes with a nice make-up table, lots of wardrobe space, a nail-dryer device and a valet box for collection/delivery of items for even more privacy). The room also has its own living area and a small table for in-room dining. It is pretty high tech too – lightings can be adjusted (with dimming and mood control), curtains are remotely controlled, humidity level in the room is adjustable, motion detectors for the night lighting and there’s even a panel providing information on the outside temperature, wind-chill and humidity levels. The room has a spacious work area which comes equipped with quite a few charging stations and a fax/printer/scanner machine. There’s even Internet Radio and a Lavazza coffee machine. The bathroom has a separate cubicle for the WC (which is fully automated) and another cubicle for the shower together with the most inviting-looking bathtub as the centrepiece here. The bed comfort, from the mattress to the pillows and bed/pillow sheets, was very good and possibly one of the best I’ve experienced. The housekeeping service, which includes the turn-down service, was excellent - very meticulous and detailed. Laptop cables, shoes/slippers, personal toiletries etc were all rearranged. We certainly had an exceptional and outstanding stay at the Tokyo Peninsula. Highly recommended.

This is our go-to hotel in Tokyo. Location is fantastic with great subway / train connectivity (important in Tokyo). Rooms are among largest and most well-designed we have seen globally. Service is always solid. The Japanese breakfast is divine. One draw back is the lobby; it is perpetually busy and doesn't feel exclusive enough for a hotel of this caliber. The gym is also quite mediocre... But everything else is simply perfect at this beautiful property.

We stayed at the Peninsula for 4 nights in December 2014. From the moment hotel reservations were made, right to the time we checked out, I can only describe our stay as being near perfect.After our booking with the hotel was secured, I emailed the concierge team to secure restaurant reservations. Tokyo boasts a wealth of highly sought after and exclusive restaurants, sometimes seating no more than 6 or so persons at a time. I gave the concierge a list of restaurants and dates, and received prompt response that most of the restaurants I had requested only open their reservation availability a month before, but assured me that they will follow up and update me in due course. Having had bad experience with another hotel of similar callibre, I was not hopeful that they would succeed and made a note to make the reservations myself. I was pleasantly surprised to discover that to the date that the concierge team said they would get back to me, I received all my request reservation confirmations.Arriving at the Peninsula late in the evening via taxi from Haneda, we were warmly welcomed and our luggage was taken care of. Check in was swift and efficient. We were given a deluxe room with a city view, this room was very large by any standard, almost like a suite, with separate bath/toilet, and walk in dressing room (complete with nail dryer)! Through a sliding door, we access the room, king-sized bed, cosy seating area in front of the TV and a small dining table. A very tech-smart room, it has sensors for everything, lights, dimmers, mood lighting, night light were mostly motion detected. Humidity levels could be set in the room, and all controls were centralised in a panel by the bed. Another panel by the desk told us the outside temperature and humidity. Excellent level of housekeeping, very comfortable bed and duvet affording a great nights' sleep. Complimentary water, coffee/tea amenities and fruits were also provided. Despite full occupancy of the hotel, we were not disturbed in anyway.Bathroom was large and spacious, in marble and sparkling clean. Generous and well thought out toiletries. Location-wise, situated opposite the Imperial Palace, it is at the end of a busy stretch of road in Ginza, so walking out of the hotel and not being immediately met with the hustle and bustle of a large city is a joy. Free drop-off in their Rolls Royce to any destination within 1 km of the hotel is a great add on service. The Tokyo subway station Hibiya is literally at the doorstep. 3 subway lines stop at Hibiya station which makes travelling anywhere in Tokyo very easy.Would I return to this hotel? It's a definite yes!

Our stay at this hotel was a wonderful experience. The room was large by any international standards. Loved the walk-in wardrobe, complete with dressing table, and the large bathroom with heated floors. Location was also good, with shops and restaurants a stone's throw away. We had a great time, thanks to a very helpful and polite staff, and the complimentary use of their car - a Rolls Royce, no less.

Spent an evening at one of the best Chinese restaurants in Tokyo - Hei Fung at The Peninsula. Fantastic 6-course set men with their on Champagne - absolutely worth the trip!! The "birds nest" with Cray is a definere winner. Happy to give the restaurant and hotel my absolutely best recommendations.

The location of the hotel is very good. It is next to the Mtr station. The hotel is near the shopping centre. The room is very spacious and hi-tech. The service is very good. I like the hotel very much except the gym and the swimming pool are pretty small.

We stayed in peninsula Tokyo on Dec 20. We went trough mails several times to check all the facilities in the room was suitable for our baby going with us. In between we planed to visit ghibli museum, but the tickets must be taken in 3 days in the local shops after booking on line. I talked to peninsula concierge team I had trouble to make it, and they agreed to help and assign someone to take the tickets in the same day I booked them. I feel so released to stay with them. Most of their staffs were so nice, but it is really a busy hotel with lots visitors, and I would like to be more patient especially in the heavy hours.

We stayed at The Peninsula Tokyo in early Dec 2014 for our family vacation. Traveled with 2 young children. Access was convenient from Narita and to Haneda. Plenty of shops and restaurants within minutes on foot from the hotel. A small lounge area, rather than the main walkway, would be nice for resting while waiting for check-in and check-out.We really enjoyed the huge and very well-appointed room. Very comfortable; kids loved the space. The hotel was also friendly to young children although it is in the business district. We received a variety of kids' amenities and the hotel also has strollers available for loan. Service was very prompt even though there seemed to be many guests. We want to thank Housekeeping especially for retrieving our little girl's stuffed toy after we left and sending it back to us. Great service from the hotel!

We stayed six nights at The Peninsula Tokyo at the end of November in a Superior King room. We could not have been happier with the room. It was more like a junior suite, with an entry foyer and dressing area with plenty of room for luggage, a comfy sofa, table for in-room dining and a little workstation. Plenty of charging stations. An enormous, lovely bathroom with a gorgeous tub, roomy rain shower. Lots of separation. TV in the bathroom, big flat screen elegantly hidden away in the main room. Without doubt, this was the smartest smart hotel room I've ever seen. The controls were intuitive and easy to use. The lighting was splendid and easily modified to suit ones needs. Tap the bedside table in the middle of the night, and a gentle, subtle night light illuminates to help you see your way. Our room looked out on the building next door, but we didn't mind. We could see lines of people moving through two levels of train stations, which was actually interesting. The staff were professional and friendly. Housekeeping were flawless and took every effort to tidy our room twice daily. The concierge helped us make dinner reservations, prepared English and Japanese language maps for taxi drivers, and ably assisted us regarding Shinkansen and other travel issues. Doormen were constantly handing us umbrellas as we stepped outside. The location over Hibiya Station is ideal. The hotel has a nice, subtle, private entrance in the station. Hibiya is an excellent station for a home base as it connects to three good lines, but it's not as big and unmanageable as other central stations. I would not want to fight my way through Tokyo Station or Shibuya Station every day, every time I went out. Hibiya was just right. Also, joggers will love the location next door to the Imperial Palace, with one of the best jogging courses in Tokyo. Staff can give you a map. Doormen are standing by with towels on one's return. Also, it's a block away from all of the yakitori joints tucked under the railway tracks, which is great fun if you're in the mood for some grilled meat and cold beer in colorful surroundings. I agree with other reviewers who complained about the lobby sharing space with the restaurant. I wish the lobby had had a lounge area where one could sit with a drink. There is no good place to wait for someone or to meet informally. There are two small sofas in the middle of the single lobby hallway, just a place to sit for a minute while your bags are moved. We encountered a wedding in the lobby, but the happy couple marched down the aisle with some alacrity, holding us up for only a few minutes. We ate breakfast every morning in the lobby restaurant. The food and service were faultless, but I found myself wishing that the hotel had a separate restaurant area and even (gasp!) a buffet. The hotel itself is beautiful, though it was a bit formal and stuffy for my tastes. On the plus side, there aren't many too many young hipsters hanging out here. Would I return? Why, yes, I would.

I have stayed at this wonderful property dozens of times since it opened but it had been almost two years since my last visit. I was a bit surprised to be greeted by name by the doorman and front desk person despite my unusually long absence. On the other hand, it is that level of attention to detail and customer focus that have kept me coming back.In addition to the great service, the rooms are simply outstanding. Large and comfortable with a good integration of technology. A recent reviewer mentioned he thought the rooms needed "refreshing", I respectfully disagree but realize to each his own. I have noted no decline in the rooms which are head and shoulders above most of the competition of high end hotels in Tokyo. The location near Ginza and Hibiya Park is very convenient for eating, shopping and moving around the city. A morning jog around the Imperial Palace is a great way to start a day. The gym in the hotel is well equipped. I agree with the other reviewers that the lobby is a bit bizarre - not really a lobby at all more like a path through the restaurant to the check-in area with inadequate space for meeting people. That drawback is minor in my opinion. The Peninsula is a relatively small property which is a strength in that allows for better customer service. I used to stay at the Imperial nearby and always felt like I was at a bus station when checking in.When I first began staying at the Peninsula, I was traveling on a corporate expense report; I have my own company now so expenses come out of my personal bottom line but that does not deter me from staying at this property. It should be noted that this is a very high end hotel with a demanding clientele. When the standards are high it is much easier to have complaints - reviews should be read with this in mind. I have averaged 150 days of business travel a year for almost two decades, staying at this hotel feels like coming home - there aren't many places I have stayed around the world I can say that about.

I stayed at the Peninsula Tokyo once before soon after it opened and had high expectations for this visit. The hotel has a great Ginza location, with direct access to the subway station and an easy walk to great shopping. While not faded I would say that the rooms were starting to feel a little in need of a refresh, technology that was state of the art when it opened felt somewhat clumsier now compared to other slicker hotels in this range. Great service is expected and delivers here but like the decor is not quite what it was when I was last here. Housekeeping did their job well but when I recall the delight I had returning to my room on my first visit to find my phone recharger delicately coiled almost as meticulously put together as a piece of origami, I was kind of disappointed to find my charger still a mess of wires when I returned to my room each day. That said, staff are very friendly and chatty which was great. Breakfast at the hotel is OK but not amazing - there are better places nearby. Still as great as my first visit were the concierge team who had a map or recommendation for everything. Overall a good stay just not as amazing as a few years ago.

Each time I stay at a peninsula hotel I am always excited to see how good it will be compared to the last. I never feel apprehensive that it won't be up to the mark and I haven't been disappointed yet. Minor issue of a smoking room being provided was promptly sorted by one of the most polished concierges I have met, she was quite faultless throughout our stay when we encountered her. The rooms are dated by their technology but they do still provided everything and more than you need. We had a full dressing room which was amazing, bathroom was amply large with every amenity you could think of at your fingertips. Sound proofing of the room was exceptional I never heard any road noise despite being in the centre of Tokyo. Bed and linen were excellent - every morning with the blackout curtains I could have slept all day! Pros:- As mentioned above- Spa was great, sauna, spa area and relaxation room were great. Must try the blueberry juice, so delicious!- Pool and spa area were nice but the chlorine smell was quite strong when I used it.- The staff, I can't think of any staff member that wasn't warm and helpful during my stay. English was spoken well by all that I encountered.- Fantastic location, so close to the metro and walking distance to the Imperial palace.Cons:- Just two really, the overlapping dining and lobby area, such an odd concept, while we were there they used the lobby for a wedding party arrival which made it feel that other guests were invading the wedding. The other is much more minor, why does the peninsula patisserie not open till 11am?

We Booked 2 Rooms at the Peninsula for 2 nights from 22nd to 24th.Room 1 a Deluxe Corner room-69 sq metres-3 PxRoom 2 a Deluxe Room-2 Pax 54Yes the Hotel is Very Expensive by any Standard. You KNOW that before you book. I ask customers to have Caution in Bookings as many times the Service Charge-10% and VAT 8 % are NOT included in your TOTAL charges when you book online on most websites. NOR the Nightly Hotel Tax of between 100-200 YEN er night.1. FIRSTLY, the Staff are generally Excellent, and the complaint later about the Lobby does NOT reflect the staff of the Peninsula Tokyo but Reflects on Peninsula Bosses at Headquarters. BAD PLANNING of the LOBBY.(Its Virtually Non Existent)2. PLUS:The rooms are Large by any standard. Unfortunately we were facing DIRECTLY in to a Larger office Building which was pretty close.3. PLUS:The Hotel can be reached by Train accessible from Yarakucho Station.3-5 Min Walk or the Hibiya Station which is next to the Hotel.CAUTION: Don't take the Hibiya Subway if you have heavy cases as there are no Lifts. It will be easier to go to the Yarakucho Station Train. 4 NEGATIVE.a.The 2 Rooms we Booked had NO BOTTLED water. We rang and service bought some. Except the Fridge Refreshments by Payement.b.Later we discovered there were NO Toothbrush sets. We rang and got some delivered.c. No slippers were in the rooms. We called again for the 3rd time.5. The WORST FOR LAST. The People that designed the Lobby have Inconvenienced the Customers greatly and Management should think carefully and make some changes.**a) I read about wedding parties from one of the Commentaries and how they were inconvenienced, and Understood 100% what they meant by being inconvenienced.When we were making our way to Check in, we were Blocked by a couple and their wedding Party. FAIRLY LARGE as one could imagine. WE COULD NOT pass for 10 Minutes. We were not the only ones.We stood there 5 People with cases completely Blocked.SORRY Management but if you have an EVENT as an INDIVIDUAL or GROUP you SHOULD NOT Inconvenience others. Our Aunt is Mid 80s and we all had cases and had to stand therereally tired waiting for people enjoying THEIR day BUT INCONVENIENCING OTHERS.b) We went down to CHECK OUT and the Line was about 30 Long. There is Virtually No Lobby as the Reception is VERY SMALL and is Connected to the Restaurant. To associate the Peninsula Hotel with these kind of amenities is unimanigable until you experience it. Then you say you are just selling your name.MANAGEMENT Note. Not everyone of your guests is a Billionaire or Millionaire but save perhaps all year to see and Experience this "PENINSULA EXPERIENCE". Again i repeat the staff we met, and they were several were all professional and nice.

what a great hotel the staff are very helpful and will go out of there way to make sure you enjoy the stay, Rolls royce from the Airport started the holiday off to a flying start, food out of this world.greta location for shopping and sight seeing cant wait to stay their again.

This was my 1st stay in a Peninsular, we stayed 5 nights and I would rate it as one of the best hotels I have stayed in. The beds were comfortable, the room was spacious (suite) the bathrooms well appointed, the staff were impeccable, the location was excellent and close to multiple train stations and just generally everything you would expect from a property of this type.The unique offering that I REALLY appreciated being a constant traveller was HUMIDITY control in the room, no more drying out if you need to regulate temperature, this feature alone would give it 5 stars!We had a massage in the spa which was fine but expensive in a global context.Hats off for free wifi on as many devices as we have!We had room service a couple of nights and the food was excellent and the staff attentive.We also ate at the Sushi restaurant in the basement which was fine and we ate at Peter and Peter which was also very nice but it is here I found the only real negative and it was a big negative. I realise it might be a cultural thing but having smokers in the bar next to the restaurant is something from the dark ages. Even if it is cultural, being a global world-class hotel means understanding guests want to enjoy their drink and food without the noxious vapours of smokers thrown in - I'm surprised the chef even allows it to take place.Anyway if I hadn't have eaten there this hotel would be as close to perfect as you can get in a city hotel.So in short when I come back I will be staying here (just not eating in Peter and Peter)!

My husband and I have stayed in this hotel several times, when we were moving to or out of Tokyo. We have stayed in a lot of hotels in Asia and this one is by far is the best in the city. It is centrally located close to numerous shops, subway and not far from the Imperial Palace. The staff at this hotel will help you with ANYTHING, and they even take wonderful care of pets!!! We had our dog with us and they were so ready for us. They had a crate, diapers (not that he used them) and even a doggie menu!!!! With in a few hours of staying there, almost the entire staff will greet you by name when you come in and out of the hotel. Best hotel in Tokyo by far!!!

Tokyo surprised me! This City is clean, beautiful, well organized- much nicer than I imagined. The hotel sent a taxi driver to pick me up at Narita and that started the 4 day journey perfectly. That night I explored the Ginza district which is just one or two blocks east of Hotel. I walked and explored the Roppongi and Shibuya districts. Taxi back to hotel with a nightcap at the beautiful bar upstairs called Peter's. Day Two had me waking up at 7am for a run around the Imperial Garden. Since it is only 3 miles around, i ventured a second loop. At 9am I entered the Imperial Garden (free) and explored a beautiful compound of Tokyo's history. The Hotel has a beautiful pool and spa area where I ate the Peninsula Club sandwich. Next, a friend arrived and we taxi'd to the Park Hyatt Hotel but found it very large and not very intimate. Nearby there are some interesting streets with odd little japanese restaurants and bars (Albatross on the alleyway of memories mentioned in the NYTimes article). Our last day, we took the Tokyo Cruise just east of the Hotel and had lunch at Sushi Go Round next to the dock opposite the river from the new Skytree tower. Taxi's are easy to grab back to the hotel. Also, Hotel is close to the Tokyo Train Station where it is a breeze taking the Naritia Express to NRT Airport. Great hotel! Great Stay! Cant wait to come back. (Yes, the lobby is a bit squeezed in space with its tight morning breakfast.) Ask for a park view room.

I really had great stay in at the Peninsula hotel, it has great location in Ginza and the room is fantastic! The room was really clean and quite and the room area really organized in a good way, dressing room, bedroom, small living, entrance and bathroom, Also the in room dining is very nice and fast!I will never think to go anywhere else, Only PENINSULA :)
user_name:
Amooryz
Riyadh, Ar Riyad, Saudi Arabia

review_body: We really enjoyed our stay at the Peninsula. It was only a lightning visit for our anniversary and two days in Tokyo is not enough. Still, the concierge booked everything we needed (including two of the best meals we've had at local sushi restaurants) and provided sufficient direction that we got to make the most of our time there. Our room (grand deluxe) was very comfortable. Fantastic views and well appointed. My wife loved the separate change room. The restaurant Peter has great views and we had lunch and some drinks there after dinner and thought it was great both times. Staff are excellent everywhere. Breakfast has a good selection but it's served in the lobby which doesn't have enough capacity. We pre-ordered the breakfast the second day (which we rarely do) and it was delivered hot, on time, in our room which had better views anyway. I'd recommend it.The concierge also arranged for us to find the sightseeing bus, and most impressive, a place where you can get your nails painted (all the more impressive as it was a snap decision with no notice to find a booking at all). Recommended.

Tokyo has many fine hotels. The Peninsula is not only one of the newest, but undoubtedly one of the best. The rooms are modern and spacious. If it is a special occasion, I would opt for an Executive Suite, with a large reception room separate from the bedroom, a spacious dressing area, and a full bath plus a guest bath. Great for recovering from jet lag if there are two of you with different sleep patterns. The hotel has excellent on site facilities, including 4 restaurants/café, including a very good Japanese and a Chinese restaurant. The location is ideal, near the Imperial Palace, a short walk to Ginza, and designer shopping just outside the door. There is a metro station below the hotel, and a 10 minute walk to Tokyo station. Best of all, is the staff which are welcoming and very helpful. Great hotel.

It simply doesn't get any better in terms of location, service and amenities. The hotel is amazing, with the best service in Asia, or perhaps anywhere, an amazing location and great food and rooms. The Chinese restaurant: amazing; the lobby restaurant: excellent; the rooms: wonderful; the service---there is no better anywhere.

Everything you would expect from a 5 star hotel, with none of the pretension. Wonderful service in all areas, and one of the best locations for getting around the city. We walked to almost all our site seeing and otherwise used the amazing subway system which has numerous stations within close proximity. The lobby restaurant is great and the bar "Peter" is worth a visit, if you can stand the cigarette smoke. As mentioned in other reviews the concierge is outstanding and never failed us.

I had booked the Peninsula for 4 nights. The room I was given was laid out beautifully. With a wall of windows overlooking the Imperial Palace gardens I was thrilled to be there. Until I ordered Lamb Chops for dinner in the room. When they were delivered, they looked average, but when I tried to eat them, I found them to be bone, fat andbarely edible. I called for the tray to be picked up and told the young woman who came to collect the tray, I was very dissatisfied and I would probably cancel the rest of my stay because of the bad meal. A gentleman from the kitchen staff called me and offered a free cup of coffee.By then I was really upset and called the front desk to cancel.The next morning I was met by the Front Desk Manager, who apologized for the treatment I had received. I showed him the picture of the dinner I sent back to prove the source of my displeasure. The damage was done.. In apology he had me transported to another hotel in the Rolls Royce Now I will admit most everything else at that hotel was excellent. I prefer a Breakfast buffet, and a proper lobby. The Cantonese Restaurant was the best Dim Sum I have ever eaten.But "no" I won't return to the Peninsula in Tokyo.

Before staying here I had heard nothing but rave reviews about the Peninsula. I think my expectations were too high. When we arrived, the non- smoking room we booked was not available and so after insisting on a non-smoking room, they gave us one with two twin beds. The room is well appointed and very spacious but the bathrooms seem a little outdated. We had just come from the Ritz in Kyoto which was beyond amazing. The service was fine. The housekeeping staff was the most impressive. The buffet breakfast is served at the Peter, which is a lounge by night, so in the morning it smells of cigarette smoke masked by air freshener. The spread was not great. The best thing about this hotel are the views and the location. Its located very centrally, and thats saying a lot in such a huge city!

Hands down to this Beautiful hotel. Let me Start with the location, very strategic, walking distance to shopping, nice restaurants, easy to find cabs. Service is amazing, very efficient and all friendly. I truly admire their conceirge, i must say they have the best conceirge among all the hotels i have stayed. They gave me a fantastic list of restaurants from michellin rated to simple local ones and everything met my expectations. The room is so spacious, very well maintained, clean, and very classy. My favorite part is the walk in closet with a dresser for me to comfortably do my make up etc. The lobby is not grand but its very intimate and homey. I have to say it was a perfect stay!

The Peninsula is Tokyo best hotel given its location, large rooms and excellent service from checking-in to departure. Facilities are beautiful, SPA and gym are to be tried out. The staff is extremely efficient, helpful, yet friendly. What I liked was the lean luxury which make you feel always relaxed, well looked after and pampered.Peter Restaurant at the roof top is the perfect place for a business lunch and a beautiful diner after work.I was sad leaving such a nice place and will absolutely go back.

We had an amazing stay in Peninsula Hotel Tokyo which located in the center of Ginza area. The service is extremely professional and wonderful in every aspect especially concierge. We try to manage to make reservation of one Michelin rated restaurant in the area, and the concierge made every effort to help us getting the seat (even excess our expectation to find us a private room). We do enjoy the ZEN decoration of the room and great view of Imperial Palace Gardens.This is definitely the hotel we would recommend when travelling to Tokyo.

Frequent stayer at Shangri La (Tokyo) & Hyatt (Kyoto), I stayed at the Peninsula because of its availability in Tokyo downtown. The room is arguably better than Shangri La, with more detailed human interface design and is more organically pleasing. The gym is quite excellent as well, although not quite as elegantly beautiful as Shangri La. The bell staff & concierge are amazingly attentive. But it has the WORST lobby & breakfast experience, EVER. I guess it's trying to replicate the Hong Kong Peninsula, but with a much smaller area and direct path from entrance to front-desk, the lobby area looks like a night-market: loud & crowded. It's difficult for a busy business travel person to be too creative & cute for breakfast option. So to me, the hotel has to get the breakfast just about perfect. It is not, unfortunately. Ordered eggs over medium, and twice came back well done. The staff did not check back the second time to see if it's OK. I gave up, signed the bill and asked for coffee. Didn't come. Anyway, when the escalation finally ended, the duty manager came to my room to apologize & asked for second chance. You'd think the 2nd chance would be rather over-the-top breakfast. It wasn't. The lobby manager didn't even as much say hello, as if I were a stranger.The breakfast, in a way, is a interesting illustration of hotel stuck in '90s Japan: attentive service if you don't ask for anything; poor command of English; packaged granola & generic coffee. OK at a three star hotel, but not good enough amongst the elites. Herr Moesker and Yokoyama-san, I have gained even more respect for your excellence after this weekend, if that were possible :-)
user_name:
Charlie C
Los Altos, California, United States

review_body: The Peninsula is a stunning property, in a great location. The rooms are gorgeous, incredibly quiet, super comfortable jewel boxes with every mod-con you could need - all easy to work out and operate. The beds are super comfortable. Great views from most rooms. The service here is about as good as you can get, from front desk to bell captains, housekeeping and concierge. The atmosphere is one of refined elegance. The Spa was one of the best I have encountered in all of Asia. The Chinese restaurant was outstanding for dinner, albeit very expensive, as is all of the food within the hotel. The breakfast is a bit of a let down and ridiculously expensive. The quality of the food is good but there is just not enough choice. Service at breakfast, again, was superb. The odd thing is the absence of a lobby area, as it is all given over to dining, where many meetings were taking place over a meal. I would say that The Peninsula is better suited to the business traveller, however there were plenty of people staying here for holidays. Needless to say this is a very popular hotel with Americans. I did fa great deal of the people staying here rather "snooty", I'd swear some of their faces would crack if they even contemplated a smile. Both The Peninsula and the Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo suffer from this rather odd, snobby clientele. It didn't matter really, I just don't understand the lack of acknowledgement of unfriendly people. All in all though, a fantastic stay in a truly superb hotel.

Rooms are huge by Tokyo standards. All amenities of a true luxury hotel available. Service is excellent and unobtrusive. Concierge managed to book us into 3* Michelin restaurants on short notice. All of Ginza was in easy walking distance but hotel was at the good quiet end. Very convenient to take the airport limo bus to Narita - pickup at the front door!Will stay again.

Recently stayed at Peninsula Hotel Tokyo, I had a wonderful time in their perfect room, very well furnished with all technology available, everything u need is available, perfect service and a great restaurant : Peter

Pros: Location very convenient; Rooms modern and large; service very good.Cons: breakfast disappointing: poor choice and very expensive; lobby substantially non existent.If you travelling for business this place might be ok; I am more reluctant to sponsor it if you visit Tokyo for pleasure

The hotel is located in Ginza.I have stayed in this hotel on two occasion (first time in 2013, second time last June 2014).Staff is friendly & efficient. Check-in took place in less than 7 min.Rooms are spacious, comfortable and decorated with high level of luxury mix with Japanese tradition. The indoor pool offers a great view of the Imperial Palace in front of the hotel.Peters Bar on the roof top is so worth to try it. Amazing views specially in the evening.

Peninsula is well situated near Ginza area. I love the area cause you can easily walk to Ginza or Underground station from the hotel. Great Rooms, and great bathrooms. All amenities is perfect and the mattress are excellent. Its a pleasant stay. The staff are all well trained and the concierge is very helpful too. Will come back again and again.

Great position close to local trains and JR. Hotel was great, a bit unusual to have breakfast and dinner etc in the front lobby.Executive suite was spacious and a entities were wonderful. We had a room on the 22nd at the back west corner nearest the trains but they did not bother us

Stayed for 2 nights of lux. Staff friendly and helpful most enjoyable restaurant especially peters great Kobe beef. I am back next week as a guest of McClements corp. I know he will enjoy as I didTokyo us a very busy city with lots to do, with great restaurants

Peninsula Hotel The Peninsula hotel is well located on the edge of the somewhat trendy and expensive area of Ginza in central Tokyo. The location is great as you can quickly get to most places in Tokyo that you’d want to visit, whether by taxi or public transit, the latter of which is actually connected to the hotel itself at the basement level. We had a deluxe bedroom on the 16th floor, which was remarkably quiet. The windows were double paned glass with a far greater distance (10cm or 4 inches) between the two panes of glass than usual so perhaps this helped make the room very quiet. In addition we never heard our neighbours, which was a nice bonus when you’re trying to sleep or rest. We also used the fitness centre, which was pretty good and my wife used the pool and was very happy with the facilities.  The bed and the pillows were wonderfully comfortable and really helped us get a good night’s sleep. The service of the staff was generally excellent although they could use some additional training in the restaurant service area as we’d often sit there for a bit longer than was necessary in order to have something attended to like getting a refill on a drink or clearing our plates etc. The lobby had a nice feel to it with a high ceiling of about 10 meters (30 feet), however there was little room in the lobby for someone to meet you as most of the area was used for seating of the lobby area restaurant, however this was not a major issue in the scheme of things. Breakfast was served from 6AM to 11AM, which is a nice range of time for the early birds as well as the night owls among us. The food itself was quite good too and was included in our package. However, the hotel tried to charge us close to $100 for our first day’s breakfast despite the fact that we were missing the last day’s breakfast. I simply refused to pay for this as firstly breakfast was included in our rate and secondly as no one had ever advised us of the hotel’s policy on not having breakfast on your day of arrival. The wifi in the room was decent but should be faster so I think they need to address that issue. Also, one thing that bothered me was the fact that the temperature of the room automatically get’s warmer overnight, likely a cost saving measure, which caused me to have a dry throat and to become uncomfortable to fall asleep in one temperature and to wake up in another one. This too should be fixed though I suspect that the hotel does this on purpose in order to save A/C costs. All in all though a great location and a very good hotel which is clean, comfortable and a pleasure to stay at. If they make the minor improvements suggested herein it will be even that much better. I hope that this review was of help and if so would ask that you kindly indicate so by clicking the appropriate link re helpful reviews. Thank you and happy travels.

The hotel is in a relatively quiet area of Tokyo. It's beside the Imperial Palace which is a large green area in the city and an area of upmarket shops and very European style cafes. It's very near Tokyo Station and underground and overland train stations so don't worry about getting anywhere relatively easily.The bedrooms are a good size by Japanese standards and have everything that you would expect and want. There is free WiFi everywhere, which can't be said for The Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo, but more of that in my review of that hotel (which is excellent apart from the WiFi).The front of house staff are excellent, as are the many ladies on the Concierge desk. As you would expect, nothing is too much trouble and there are a number of restaurants in the hotel. Traditional Japanese, Chinese and 'Peter' the grill restaurant. Peter is one of the best designed restaurants I've been in. Interesting clusters of tables and a huge video screen currently promoting the opening of The Peninsula Paris. The food was also excellent. The downside? Well you can still smoke in some places in Japan and the Peninsula, like many other hotels, allows it in the bar at Peter. So smoke drifts across to where you are eating. The bar is also a nice place to sit and watch the views but the smoke is even stronger there.If they eliminated the smoke it would have been one of the most enjoyable meals I've had in a while.So in summary I would say that you will not be disappointed by the service, bar, choice of restaurants (and basement cafe for delicious cakes and chocolates) but the area is a bit quieter than others, the views from the hotel a bit more limited (in my experience).Still very good though. 5 stars.

This is called "five star". The service was out standing, the room was massive, nice smell, clean . It is the best hotel in the world just limited of in dining menu food. I have never been in a hotel which cares about my kid like this hotel . It is in the Ginza, 5 mins walk to the central shopping departments . I will definitely come back here again if I come back Tokyo.

I loved the 4 night stay I had recently at the Peninsula. The location is excellent with great proximity to Marunouchi, the Ginza, the Imperial Palace and Tokyo Central Train Station. You enter into a soaring public area with restaurant seating on either side and a small balcony above where live music performances was the space in sound. The room I had on the 14th floor was huge by Japanese standards. My room had a comfortable King bed, a desk work area, a small eating table with 2 chairs, full size coach and coffee table. There were numerous electronic controls built in throughout the room such as excellent lighting controls, automated shade and blind controls, weather instrumentation displays, internet radio controls and various power one connectivity outlets, all thoughtful placed. The bathroom had a glassed in toilet area with a fully automated toilet, opposite was a similar sized glassed in shower with rain head, there were two sinks and vanities as well as a large soaking tub, nice towels and toiletries. The room also had good , free wifi connectivity, a stocked mini bar and coffee service.The design of the room is very thoughtful, understated , displaying elegant Japanese design elements of horizontal wood on feature wall, sliding slab cypress wood door , combination of finished and rough stone work on the wall behind the tub with a tasteful light wash highlighting it. This room was absolutely silent and a delight to work and sleep in.There is a full service spa on site and and excellent , if expensive, top floor bar / restaurant .This is an outstanding hotels which I will certainly return to on future trips. I highly recommend The Peninsula Tokyo.
user_name:
Nova R
West Coast, Ooh, Ess, Ahh

review_body: This is an outstanding hotel. The location in Yurakucho is central and very convenient for both Marunouchi and the Ginza. The rooms are spacious with high ceilings which is often not the case in Japan. Bathrooms are also generous with two wash basins and there is a walk in closet. The beds are large and very comfortable with lovely pillows. Decor is warm and pleasantly oriental. The service is highly efficient but also friendly.

One of the most convenience & comfortable hotel in Tokyo.Builded at center of Tokyo（有楽町:yurakucho）, you can go anywhere you want to see.I tended to eat dinner in this hotel, the Robby.It's cheaper than any other same level hotel around yurakucho, but taste is quite good.And Spa is quite good.You could relax and feel like celebrity with relax music.私は東京駅、有楽町近辺の中で最も好きです（次点でフォーシーズンズです）。ロビーや最上階のレストランで食事もしましたが、非常に使いやすい、特にロビーはこの値段でこれだけの体験ができるなら最高と言っても良いです。新人の子ならここに連れてってあげると喜んでくれます。立地も東京の中心ですので、観光客にも是非、という所ですね！（英語と日本語だいぶ違ってちてすみません笑）

Stayed at the luxuriously decorated Deluxe Room for four nights. The room is huge by Tokyo standards with a living area, big bathroom and one of the biggest closets I've ever seen in a hotel room. There is also a small dining table which was convenient for in room dining. Bathroom was equipped with Oscar de la Renta amenities. There was even a built-in nail dryer in the dressing room. How convenient! Bed was very comfortable and pillows were huge. Service was outstanding from check-in right up to check-out. Upon checking in, I unpacked and laid out my toiletries and make-up items on the dressing table. When I returned to my room in the evening, housekeeping had laid a towel under all my items and arranged everything properly! They did this every day. Now that's good service.I also had lunch by myself at the boutique cafe one day and the service there was excellent too. They brought me a pillow for my back seeing that I'm expecting and even brought a stack of fashion magazines for my reading. I was really impressed with the wonderful service I was shown throughout my stay. The only thing I did not like was that there is a restaurant right smack in the middle of the lobby so each time you exit and enter, it feels as though everyone at the restaurant is staring at you. Also, breakfast is a set menu and was not very tasty. Much room for improvement there but loved everything else!

It was a fantastic stay! Flawless in all aspects. Location wise this is the best option in Tokyo! Great rooms, restaurants (mainly the Chinese) and pool! Great concierge service!!!Perfect access to the subway into one of the most useful subway lines... The only two disappointments I had were the 'smoking allowed' bar (very inappropriate) and the lack of a buffet breakfast (and expensive breakfast choices). My next stay option in Tokyo, for sure!

I can only say wow about this room. Even the basic room is spectacular with seating area, walk in closet and a wonderful bathroom. The rooftop bar is fantastic, personnel is extremely kind and friendly and the location is hard to beat. Number 1 choice in Tokyo for me.
user_name:
Thomas443
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: This an awesome hotel. I ended my honey moon here and it was perfect. It has a great bar on the top floors with a great view. It is located perfect for shopping and moving around. Great to walk around the hotel and getting a bit near by. There are some nice pastry shops near by. Service is impecable. The only thing I did not like it that the restaurant is placed in the entrance so.. you have to walk by it every time you enter or leave the hotel. It is uncomfortable for the people having their meals. Everything else is AMAZING. Pricey but worth it.

I stayed for two nights, during a business trip through Asia, and I had a very good stay . The property is very well located ( very close to Ginza district ) and well maintained, everything was quite clean and modern - my room was very spacious, with a big bathroom and nice closet. The hotel staff was very helpful and polite, the concierge helped us with good tips and also to book some nice restaurants. The swimming pool was super nice, with 20m, where you can actually exercise or just relax. Breakfast was good, but value was not great, I believe it could have a few more options ( fruits, yogurts and bakery )

Peninsula is within 5 mins walk to Ginza coupled with the convenience of the Hibiya subway located on the B2. The subway is convenient to get around and only several stops to Harajuku. Peninsula faces the Imperial Palace but it is only open for visitors twice a year. Lots of runners run around the palace. The rooms are spacious with separate walk in closet, bathroom with a deep tub and a sitting area. Everything is electronic from the toilets to the light switches. Do visit the gym and pool when you can. Peters, a bar offers nice view of the city and nice beers. Try the Nikka whiskey if you can. The lobby which cuts across the coffee house is a little weird as it doesn't offer place to hang around. The concierge service is top class and do ask them for their map of Ramen shops. The set breakfast at 4200 yen is quite pricey as you can get the same fare at one fourth of the price. Overall I love the rooms and the free wifi at the Peninsula.

The room was large, clean and had a built in espresso machine! The "twin" bed was actually a double by North American standards, so that was a very pleasant surprise. Large washroom with heated toilet seats, which felt odd at the beginning but was actually a nice touch. Very attentive and polite staff. Concierge was very helpful in recommending places to set and in booking reservations. Right beside subway station. Central location. My next time back in Tokyo I plan to stay there again.

I stayed here for one night. The room was booked through American Express Fine Hotels and the person who checked us in was very good. The room was OK and there were no bathroom amenities in the room (no bottled water either). The corridors were very warm and the room was quite noisy. The breakfast was quite bad. First the hostess tries to seat everyone close to each other and we could not talk due to a business meeting next to us that was loud.
