The service was bad -- we asked for milk for our tea and they kept bringing cream. Asked for water that we never got. The breakfast was generic and greasy. The final straw was the foreign exchange rate. We were given a $100 credit that the hotel translated to 9,600 yen -- the exchange rate was 107 yen to a dollar that day. It was a clear case of fleecing. Stay away -- Conrad Hilton and Hotel Imperial are better choices.

I have been recently in this hotel in Tokyo.Located just in front of the Imperial Palace and gardens this modern Hotel has spectacular rooms with all you need and more.Service is top level. Breakfast is high quality. you feel yourself at the center of staff attention.To be tried the swimming pool at the 6th floor, free for hotel guest offer a spectacular view on the Imperial Gardens.If you like to run there is a circuit around the Imperial Gardens that start 100 feet from the Hotel and when you are back staff is ready with water and towels. less than half a mile from Ginza shopping area you can get the best of your stay at the Peninsula bith you are in Tokyo for Business and for tourism. Not an hotel for everyday stay but if you want to add a sofisticated touch to your visit to Tokyo, this is a option i can recommend.

Ok, stayed here for four nights and overall quite good but a few comments to be made:+ awesome location, if you like Ginza. Right on top of Hibiya subway station. Perfect to explore Tokyo+ amazing rooms, fantastic electronic features, such as see wind direction, strength and temperature outside. + big walk in closet+ every room is like a suite+ fast elevators and not much walking to the room due to building design+ I did enjoy the gym and pool a lot+ concierge was pretty good with bookings and sightseeing suggestions. Now the negatives :- booked two rooms for four nights and somehow hotel put the rooms on different floors, which is a weird thing to do for a family travelling together. It took half an hour at check in to convince them that this was not appropriate. In the end they suddenly found two rooms on the same floor- dreadful lobby design. Lucky I booked without breakfast as I would have hated to spend one minute more than necessary in that dark, ugly, red carpeted hole. nevertheless it was always full of local guests- I saw a piece of fruit, at least 1.5 inch big lying around on our floor outside the lift for several days. Surprised no hotel staff saw it. Or did they just not care?- older travellers beware. The oldest person in our group had serious difficulties operating all the funky electronic gadgets. But I myself loved it- coffee machine in the room broke down. They fixed it, next day same problem..Overall a great stay, thanks to the city and the hotel location but honestly for the amount of money, and compared to other similar hotels worldwide, I would have expected better service. -

A true 5 star experience. Fantastic room. Great bathroom and walk in robe room. Hi tech everything. Great pool and spa. Exceptional service. Great location for eating out and Ginza nightlife, easy to get to from Tokyo station. Rooms not cheap but good value.

My wife and I have been staying at the Peninsula regularly since it opened. In 8 visits over 5+ years it has never been anything less than spectacular! I confess to hesitating to write this review because I fear too many people will want to stay and we won't get in at some point! The rooms are gigantic by any standard and particularly for hotels in Japan, with a separate bedroom area (with a sliding door made from an enormous wood slice of some beautiful tree) AND separate walk-in closet/dressing room and separate large bath. All the amenities you can ask for are present. Everything is super high quality (sheets, marble, etc). The views are great (we have had rooms on every side and height). The staff is unbelievable--friendly, welcoming, helpful, and super professional. Japanese hotel standards are quite high and at every price point, better than you would find elsewhere. This holds true even at the Peninsula's high rates. It is definitely "value for money." I can't adequately describe the feeling of well-being that is imparted by a stay at the Peninsula. Not just while one is there, but long after leaving when remembering the "Peninsula Experience." We are fortunate to be able to travel and stay at top hotels. The Peninsula Tokyo is by far our favorite hotel in the world.On a practical note, not only is the hotel awesome, but it is in a great location. Right above Hibiya Station (there is even an inside entrance from the hotel) with the helpful Hibiya, Chiyoda and Ginza lines, less than 2 blocks to the Yurakacho stations (JR and metro), all of Tokyo is readily accessible. Also nearby is Hibiya Park, with what seems like a festival of some kind happening every weekend. Lots of fun restaurants are also an easy walk away, as is the Ginza for shopping.Bottom line: The Peninsula Tokyo is simply the best!

I could stay at this hotel during a business trip. Huge rooms, beautifull bathroom, nice swimmingpool, A very good location above the subway. Nice shops and restaurants in immediate surrounding as is the Yamanote line

I don't give a lot of excellent reviews but this hotel is one that I must give it to. Having stayed in numerous 5* hotels over the world this is one that I keep remembering as one of my favourite ones. Service is impeccable (as is typical in japan) and the rooms are decent sized for Tokyo with plenty of amenities. Location is great being right in Ginza and just across from the imperial palace. Take a 10 min taxi at 5am to tsukiji fish market for some wonderful sushi. I will come back here on my next trip to Tokyo.

The hotel is located in a strategic position, very close to Roppongi. Everything is made with great attention to the details.The rooms are very big, with sofa, television and a coffee machine. The bathroom is wide and it has both the shower and the bath tub, double washbasin and also TV!!There are something that can be improved, in particular the restaurant which is in the middle of the lobby and you cannot feel a good privacy. I suggest to avoid the breakfast in the hotel, because it is expensive, they don't have a buffet and there is a menu à la carte. The Chinese restaurant, in the second floor of the hotel, is really good, clean and not too expensive. The staff is really nice and helpful.

Very nice Hotel but placed in a very busy and noisy area. The hotel style is a bit "old fashioned"but still it deserves "thumbs up". The service is wonderful and the staff makes you really feel at home. The amenities are high standards, rooms are spacious, when you pay the price...but the overall experience is satisfactory. Fitness room lacks equipment but the pool is nice.The lounge is very nice and the food & beverages quality are perfect. Personally I prefer the Nihonbashi area rather than the Tokyo shinkansen station.

I picked the Peninsula due it's location, size (not too big, not too small) and reputation and happy to say that it lived up to all my expectations. The room was spacious, supremely relaxing and aesthetically beautiful - a welcome place to return to after trekking the streets of Tokyo in July.

We have tried many hotels around tokyo and finally we both agreed peninsula is the best! Location is perfect for upscale shopping, restaurants , entertainment. Biggest room ,biggest walk in closet , biggest bathroom, best amenities, best value for money.

customer service - excellent - very helpful staff, reception, concierge. our room rate had breakfast - we had the option to eat in the room, which we tried for one morning while enjoying the view of the city. breakfast choice offered only three choice - japanese, light, and i think it was american. but all were very filling. even if the room rates were expensive, it is worth a try. you get what you are paying for. location - excellent - 5 to 10 min walk to shopping district.

In my book, this is the perfect hotel...great Ginza location, beautiful design, great room size, excellent service...Short distance to Tokyo station, Hibiya station, Yurakucho station or Ginxa station, everything is within short walking distance from Peninsula. It will be difficult to stay in other hotel once you experienced Peninsula Tokyo :)

Everything about our stay here was wonderful.The location is fantastic, the service wonderful, the food was great, beautiful lobby spot for a drink or afternoon tea, the concierge was extremely helpful (and sent our bags to Kyoto while we took the bullet train), we had 2 rooms for 4 nights - wonderful. All was wonderful. We have also stayed at the Ritz Carlton in Tokyo and while each spot has perks, I prefer the location of the Peninsula. (The metro is also right near the entrance so you can get around very easily).

and incredible! Super location. 500m to Yamanote line Yūrakuchō station. When I stayed there, I jog around the imperial palace in the morning. When I came back, the girl standing at the door handed me bottled water and bath towel.The room is quiet. The bathroom is extremely well equipped. You can watch TV while bathing.Highly recommended. Well worth the price.Note our room has city view. If you book a suite, you may have the palace view!

What a wonderful hotel! The rooms are beautifully designed, big and spacious, and the beds are the most comfortable in Japan. In fact so far they have the most comfortable beds with the most luxurious sheets of any hotel I've ever stayed in anywhere in the world. The concierge is brilliant and the bar on the top floor is fantastic. They have some secret beer in red and blue bottles which I tried to find some information on, but came up empty handed every time. They said in the bar that the beer is made just for them, somewhere out in the countryside, and they wouldn't even let me keep the bottle! I think the other reviews on here about the fantastic room features and the beautiful bathroom say it all, I don't need to repeat it.In Tokyo you do not need to stay anywhere else. My only criticism is the lobby is a little sterile and inappropriate in that you have to haul your luggage through the middle of everyone having heir afternoon tea. But really there is no where better to stay, top 5 star place.

In one word: WOW. This hotel knows what the word Service means. I have stayed in many 5 star hotels across the world, but the Peninsula Tokyo really beats them all in terms of service. We booked on their website where they have an offer with an automatic room upgrade (I think till the end of August) and we ended up in a lovely room with a beautiful view of the Imperial Palace park. The room was meticulously clean, the bed really comfortable and there are different types of sockets for electricity, so we did not even need to use a converter. There are coffee and tea making facilities, which I thought was nice, although I must admit that the hot water for tea from the machine did spatter a bit, so you have to be a bit careful not to burn yourself. The fruit provided each day is of an amazing quality. Yes, it may only be 3 mandarins, but the taste of them: divine! Note that fruits in Tokyo are really expensive, but the taste...The bathroom is great: the rain shower is very nice, the electronic toilet awesome and the bathtub fills up really, really quickly. When in the bathtub there is a button for relaxing music, which normally works on my nerves, but this was really nice and indeed relaxing. The only thing missing in the amenities was bath salt, which was a bit strange...The concierge service is impressive. They recommended a number of really nice restaurants, made reservations, helped with making a ferry reservation for later on during our trip, checked whether we could attend a sumo match or visit a sumo stable (unfortunately it wasn't the season) and helped us with many more things. Nothing was too much. If they could not get the answer immediately, we would find a letter in our room when we returned to the room with the answer.The location in Ginza is furthermore really good (note also that the hotel has direct access to the metro station) as it is a short walk to many sights as well as many great restaurants and shops.We liked the hotel so much, that we decided to return at the end of our trip for one last night in Tokyo. Again, a nice room and great service!Absolutely worth the money.

When I arrived at the Peninsula Tokyo at 8 PM after a very long flight, my room was still not ready for some reason. I made the booking months beforehand and this was obviously way after the official check-in times.Instead of trying to rectify this situation the receptionist asked me if I am willing to purchase an upgrade. I find it very inappropriate to put pressure on the guest in such a situation.If the Hotel screws something up and can't provide the booked room then the Hotel should rectify that with a free upgrade, not the other way around.Coincidentally I made the same experience in other 5-Star Hotels in the same area (they try to upsale upgrades when checking in) so I'm starting to believe that this is normal etiquette in those establishments. I'm not tolerating this...

We recently returned from a trip to Japan and Bali. We had stayed ina traditional Ryokan in Kyoto and splurged on a luxury hotel in Tokyo and loved it! The Peninsula is well known for luxury and service, and they proved it with our stay! We checked in and were escorted to a wonderfully spacious room. The bed, seating, area, bathroom, and room in general was exceptional. I really cannot say enough about this property. All of the staff greeted us each time we saw them and really cared that we had a great stay! I would absolutely stay here again!Location: Great location, near Tokyo station for high speed trains. The hotel actually connects to the subway, so getting around Tokyo is a breeze!Bed: Comfortable. Great linensRoom: Blackout curtains making sleeping easy! Spacious. We had a seating area as well as a dining area, which was a nice feature. The bathroom was huge and the closet/dressing area was spectacular!Restaurants: We ate at the lobby as well as Peter and had a snack from the Boutique. All were great! I would recommend afternoon tea in the lobby. The tea was great and I really enjoyed the teatime snacks.

We stayed here for only 2 nights at the end of our Japan trip. It was a magnificent end to our holiday. The staff were some of the friendliest I have ever encountered. There almost seemed to be more staff than guests! Our room was beautiful. Big bedroom/living area, huge dressing room, and a spectacular bathroom. There is a control panel next to the bed that opens and closes curtains, changes light settings, adjusts air con, you can even change the room humidity!The hotel spa, whilst not cheap, was also a luxurious treat!The hotel is close to the Ginza shopping area, and lots of eateries.I would happily stay here again!

The Pen Tokyo exceeded our expectation with spacious room and fantastic spa. We arrived at the hotel after spending at another hotel near Tokyo Bay for convention. The Pen Tokyo is in a class of its own with well planned space and a designer user friendly bathroom. The walk in closet which is great when traveling with family with loads of luggages; the enclosed vanity area was a hide out for our son to surf the net . The separation of the bedroom area from the rest with a sliding door is a clever design for added privacy. Our room faces Hibiya park and very sunny with sound proofed windows and double shades to ensure black out for total relaxation.Spa is first class- spotless, modern zen style with all the amenity. I also used the pool and it was again very enjoyable.The only odd thing is the lobby which is situated at the end of the dining area. I guess it was designed to be in line with the Hong Kong Peninsula Hotel. To return to the room, one has to pass the dining area, pass the receptionist in order to reach the elevators.Overall, we had a good stay at the Tokyo Pen and will surely give them our business if we head for Tokyo again.

I truly live the Pen in Tokyo but can't help feeling a little let down. After my most recent stay (today is my last night) i just dont know how much they value repeat business or loyal customers. I've stayed at the Pen on at least 4 occasions and just wish they had a loyalty programme like many of their competitors. Just didnt feel that special this time round - my request for high floor (made at least 6 weeks ahead) was refused, best late check out is 12:30pm (usual is 12pm), bathroom toiletries refilled and not replenished with new supplies on at least 2 days.....all in all a little disappointed. would welcome an opportunity to speak directly with Pen staff to provide feedback.

An absolute class act. I first stayed here when it had just opened and as good as it was then, now it really has developed. A true class act and one that I would very highly recommend. The pool is not as spectacular as the Park Hyatt for example but still very nice. The location is fantastic, the rooms gorgeous and the service splended.

Stayed for 2 nights with my friend while on a girls trip. Beautiful hotel, the room was big and well furnished. Love the blackout curtains. The front desk and concierge were very efficient. The hotel is in a nicer part of Ginza, away from the crowds. There are many beautiful spots just around the corner, walk around and explore. The hop on hop off bus is just 10 minutes walk away. We were looking to go to a lounge for some music one night but there was not many choices around the area. All in all a great stay, nothing really stood out and I would stay here again if I'm coming to Ginza.

I stayed at the property for three nights ( July 29th- August 1st, 2014). First, the location is next to the glittering neighbourhood of Ginza, just opposite the Imperial Palace. Very strategic. As I enter the hotel through it's revolving door, my eyes get caught by a catchy decorations, a wooden ( bamboo?) sculpture in the shape of a giant snail, that dominating the lobby area. Modern, yet traditional Japanese. Love it. The only thing that I couldn't get it, this area functioning as a coffee shop/ dining area as well. So we walk in the aisle of a dining area, until we reach to the receptionist area. A bit awkard for me.As for the room, I love the decor. It' s modern Japanese. Lots of wooden details, but still sleek and modern. Everything can be controlled by your finger tips through an electronic panel on the wall; from controlling AC, curtain, TV, lighting, telephone, etc. but the main feature that I really love is it's wardrobe area. It's a huge walk in closet! For me who can not travel lightly, it's really nice. All my stuff can be placed neatly, so it won't mess my sleeping or sitting area.Lastly, The spa, pool and gym area is superb! I love the swimming pool. The indoor area is airy with glass windows overlooking the Palace.The hotel staff are also very helpful, polite and efficient. Truly a pleasant experience to stay at Tokyo Peninsula.

It is a Peninsula like others, with RR in the front, White Glove welcoming service etc...The service is very good and the location is great if you like shopping because you will be so close to Ginza where it is the best Tokyo shopping.But other properties such as Park Hyatt, Ritz Carlton and Mandarin have much higher viewpoints offering a spectacular view of Tokyo where you can feel more of the city size and scope. At Peninsula, you will not get that feeling.If you are a Peninsula fan and do not care much about the expansive city views that high towers provide, then you will like the place for its location, pool, food and service.Note that fitness room has no windows, and very limited machines. Starbuck fan? There's a few in the area and one just on the side crossing the street.Need an ATM to get some cash? Not easy in Japan unless you find an ATM at the 7/11 and there is one at the Peninsula just underneath in the subway station.Breakfast in the lobby may be you're best meal of the day! And be there around 9, there's a wedding every morning, quite fun to watch, you'll feel like the Wedding Crashers!

This is a premiere hotel with helpful, friendly staff. They leave no stone unturned in taking care of you,!! The rooms are beautiful and large. The restaurants had amazing food and fantastic service. I stayed at many Tokyo hotels and this is by far the best!

It surpassed my expectation! Our family of four with 11 y.o and 4 y.o stayed in a Deluxe Room for 4 nights. We took advantage of their new website special offer for free room upgrade. The room was spacious. It had a separate sitting area, small dining table, spacious bathroom with separate shower, bathtub, and toilet. On the other side of the room was a very spacious walk-in closet with plenty of space/drawers to store your stuff along with the vanity table. The bed was comfortable, the shower was nice although the hair dryer could be better. Toto toilet was always fancy.Check in and out was done quickly and smoothly. Takeshi ( I think), the supervisor, was very nice and helpful. The only hiccup for us was when we first checked in, we found out there was a sofa bed in our room, so we mentioned to them we were thinking of using it, but they said they're going to charge extra fee the moment we open the sofa. It didn't make sense to us, what if we just asked for extra bed sheet or blanket and did it ourselves? But anyways, we just dropped it.We didn't get to try the Peninsula Afternoon Tea on the lobby level coz of the "bad" timing every time for us, but we tried the buffet breakfast downstairs on the basement level. Although it was delicious and definitely a better quality one out there, but I think they should offer more options/varieties for the price tag. Pastries and desserts were excellent!The gym was nice, it was an OK size, but very clean and quiet. The pool was very nice, the staff on duty were all very nice and helpful, the jacuzzi was super relaxing - it had a bench inside with all the water massage pressure where we could sit and gaze out to the window looking over the Imperial Palace garden. The sauna was amazing! One of the best I've been to, it's rated top 10 or something like that. Complimentary for hotel guests, there were a steam and dry sauna along with the amazing warm and cold herbal infused shower (4 settings)with mood lighting for before and in-between saunas. I could not have enough of the sauna!Location wise, it's about 10 minute walk to Mitsukoshi Dept Store where all the big malls are however Tokyo never sleeps, there are millions of stores, shops, restaurants, café alleys surrounded us. It all depends on what area you want to stay in/ concentrate on, as each prefecture/area has its own characteristics. Metro station is right below us if you choose to take it.Concierge was always very helpful although one particular lady, M, could tone it down a bit and learn to talk/present it differently. We asked for a restaurant recommendation once, then she replied, "Would you like the high end one or standard one?". It wasn't rude, I guess, but it took me aback for a sec. But it didn't stop there... I told her to just give me both options, 2, depending on the time, location, or so on, we'd pick as we go. Then when I asked about the difference between the 2 places, she started "lecturing" me about how the dish/cuisine is and should be "in Japan". I mean I know VERY well about that particular dish/cuisine, in Japan, but what I wanted to know was the difference about the 2 places/restaurants. She was border line rude towards the end as she irritated both me and my husband who is usually very laid back. I don't know what it was, I think it was her lecture tone. I gave her the benefit of the doubt, maybe it's cultural differences though she spoke very fluent English, but then again the rest of the concierge staff didn't talk like her. Anyways, it was a good thing she was only there once the whole time we stayed there. The rest of the hotel staff though was very polite and friendly.Overall, I'd say it was an excellent peninsula stay. I'd definitely recommend staying at The Peninsula Tokyo if you choose to stay in Ginza.

Top end hotel, friendly staff, excellent facilities, huge swimming pool, great fitness. The only negative is the lobby which is at the same time breakfast room and thus very busy and at times a bit chaotic

The Peninsular was a real oasis of comfort and style. Well place, within walking distance of the Ginza shopping area, the Imperial Palace and Hibaya Park and close to two subway stops - Hibaya and Ginza.It was hard to actually go out and explore as the hotel was so comfortable. The spa looked most inviting although I didn't actually use it.The Peter restaurant on the top floor was fabulous, with great decor, wonderful view and superb food. Shame its such a long way away.

Very pricey but was worth it. Located just a stone throw from the royal palace.Ginza which is a upmarket district is just round the corner.There is a lovely bakery at this hotel for people with sweet tooth.The decor of the reception is truly amazing.Check in was smooth and speedy. Rooms were nice and spacious with gadget all over. Really had a good time hotel and would definitely come back. Overall a fantastic hotel. Will definitely recommend especially for couples.

The Peninsula Tokyo is an outstanding hotel. The rooms are spacious and beautiful. Everything is where it should be, fully automated, and just perfect. Staff here are excellent, everything we asked for or needed was handled above and beyond our expectations. The location of the hotel is excellent, within walking distance to the Ginza Area, and 2 major metro/rail stations just outside the hotel (you can access Hibya Station directly from the hotel itself) if you want to use the excellent Tokyo underground. Taxis are generally expensive in Tokyo, and there tends to be a bit of traffic, so the metro is a great way to get around. As an FYI, taxi to/from Narita Airport is around 20,000 Yen (around $200) each way. Concierge even had PASMO cards to purchase (rechargeable cash-metro cards like UK's Oyster Card or the Korean T-Money Card). The area around the hotel is also very nice (near the Palace) and a great place to start exploring. Food at the hotel was excellent as well. Free wifi, nice spa and gym, and just a beautiful hotel overall. You will not find a hotel that does everything so well, and with killer service included. Just excellent.

My family and i Just got back from a 3 week trip to Japan.We stayed in 5 hotels during the trip.( I will also write a review on the other 4 hotels.)The Peninsula experience was the best overall. Our 5 night stay was very relaxing and of course luxurious. We took the hotel shuttle bus from Narita Airport to the hotel, and from the minute we arrived we were shown what first class service is. Our suitcases and bags were immediately put on the luggage cart trolly and taken to the front desk. Check in was smooth and fast, then we were shown to our room by a wonderful and pleasant concierge. Once in the room she dazzled us with all the amenities,electronic features and comforts which makes the whole Peninsula experience. Bathroom was amazing with the double sinks,T.V., deep bath tub and very large separate shower. Dressing room was a bonus room to have for clothes and suitcases. Room was very quiet and blackout curtains blocked the sun for a restful sleep. The beds had a typical Japanese type mattress not coil and springs that westerners are used to. I had no problem sleeping on a firm mattress.The decor was tastefully done with each room having its own piece of artwork. I should also add that the daily newspaper is left in the valet box in the dressing room. I did read in other reviews complaints of not getting the newspaper. The swimming pool is great to cool off in the hot weather. My son used it a couple of times while we were there. If you go early in the morning it is not as crowed as the afternoon gets. My husband and I checked out Peter's which is the bar on the top floor of the hotel. When we arrived it was towards the end of a happy hour. They had limited appetizers and cocktails at a reduced price. The cocktails were a little unusual but overall it was OK. The only negative comment is smoking is still allowed in many bars in Japan. Peter's is one of the bars that still allows it. Not an enjoyable experience when you are a non smoker sitting next to a chain smoker.:Maybe there should be a no smoking area of the bar to sit. Overall wonderful memorable experience at the Peninsula. I look forward to staying there again.

Stayed at a number of hotels in Tokyo and this had the best sized standard rooms yet. If you are traveling with a child and need an extra bed this will be a very good choiceAmenities and room fittings are excellentI had some initial issues at the check in (could not find my guest's booking) and some minor communication issues with the concierge but overall service was good-very good. They do seem to have a smaller concierge staff than some of the other hotels I have stayed in so some patience is encouraged. Check out was very smooth and they offered the courtesy use of their spa to freshen up pre flight post checkout which I found very considerate and convenientLocation as highlighted by other reviewers is excellent atop Hibiya station and walking distance from the shopping belt.

The Peninsula Tokyo is a true five star hotel with excellent service and facilities. We loved our room and the location and will definitely stay here again next time we are in Tokyo. Check-in was efficient, and the concierge stopped by during the process to provide information on our reservations and offer additional assistance. (Prior to the trip, the hotel was very helpful answering questions, making reservations at restaurants, etc. and always replied promptly to my emails.)The rooms here are outstanding, even the most basic ones, and are quite large, especially by Tokyo standards. The beds were comfortable, and we never heard noise from the hallway or from other rooms, even though the hotel was fully booked. Our only complaint was that the coffee/tea-making equipment didn't work properly and we couldn't get water hot enough to make a decent cup of sencha. Breakfast was included in our room rate and, while good, was nothing special. We had a drink in the bar on the top floor on evening. The view is impressive and it's a fun place to spend some time, but we found our cocktails underwhelming, particularly when compared to places like Gen Yamamoto and many places we frequent in the US. The location of the hotel is excellent; it is in Ginza, walking distance to many high-end shops and restaurants as well as the park housing the Imperial Palace. (I recommend you try some of the high end patisseries in the area such as Sadaharu Aoki-divine!) In addition, the hotel is connected via underground tunnel to the Hibiya subway station and is a 15 minute walk from Tokyo Station, where you can catch a train to the airport or a Shinkasen to other cities in Tokyo.

I love this hotel, literally everything is impeccable from the moment we arrived to checkout, perfection. We are big Starwood fans, yet, we love this Peninsula whenever we are in Tokyo. The rooms are designed with an impeccable zen decor with extra thoughtful touches everywhere and great technology features such as the Japanese toilette which we love and have in our house. The size of the room is ginormous, especially for Tokyo. We do love the palace view room, it is nice to wake up and see a patch of serene green in the middle of Ginza.The staff is beyond exceptional they truly go above and beyond to make sure all your needs are met. I'm beginning to think that they are psychic. You never have to ask twice because they remember everything!Locations is great, right in the middle of Ginza with direct subway access.The lobby is modern and tastefully dramatic, it is a pleasure to have the well curated breakfast under the statement chandelier every morning.This is a special hotel and my favorite urban hotel in Asia!

We stayed here 9 nights on our first trip to Tokyo, and could not have been happier. Check-in was fast and friendly, door-staff greeted by name on our arrival, the room was immaculate and seemed enormous, partly because of the high ceilings, and partly because it had a massive walk-in closet that was a room unto itself. The bathroom was full of gadgets, and everything was electronically controlled, including black-out shades, which came in handy for jet-lagged travelers in need of sleep. There are also plenty of outlets everywhere which I always appreciate. The whole hotel makes a very elegant, opulent but not-even-remotely-stuffy impression.But the main reason, I think, to stay here is the location: it was perfect for us. I was traveling with my mom and we had never been to Japan before, and from what I had heard from friends who had been to Tokyo I was a little bit worried it would be a bit much for her. It wasn't. The huge shopping area Ginza is right outside the door, and while there's everything there you might conceivably want, and definitely every conceivable designer, it's not as overwhelmingly bright and busy as, say, Shibuya. When we went out on our first day, it didn't feel crazy and it was nice to come back to that area in the evening after the really tourist-y spots in the city. Transportation is easy, too. Hibiya subway station is right under the hotel (the Tokyo subway system is very efficient and simple to figure out) and Tokyo Station with its bullet trains and shopping is a ten minute walk away. Also, our favorite part, the huge Imperial Gardens are right across the street, so if the city gets to be too tiring you can always escape into the green.Overall a really great experience. We're staying at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo right now, and it's good, too, but there was something special and effortless about The Peninsula. Would definitely go back.

We stayed in a suite at this hotel, and from the word go the service was impeccable. Huge room(s), great views, top restaurants inside hotel. The general manager stood in the foyer/restaurant area, at 8.00 in the morning, impeccably dressed, overseeing the scene, and unreservedly polite to all. I'm sure if I had asked he would have served me breakfast! We got a free tour of the city in the hotel's Mini Cooper. The hotel is in a good area, near The Ginza, it is handy to the train and the Imperial Palace. Not cheap, but worth it

Very good hotel. Rooms are quiet and the place is located close to many fish restaurants of Ginza area. I visited all restaurants in the hotel since my wife was on a business trip and I had a lot of free time and all of them are good. However, you of course do not need to use any of them as a great variety of good food is available in 5 minutes walk from the hotel. The bar on the top floor is also an establishment. Make sure you order champagne by bottle though - much cheaper than by glass!

My wife & I visited Tokyo, Japan for the first time last Dec. 2013 and decided to stay at this hotel. Since it was our first time, we requested for a good view. Mr. Nakamura was the one who helped us & offer us an upgrade with a minimal price. It turned out to be one of the suites overlooking the Imperial Palace which really impressed us. The location is great since it sits on top of the subway station, walking distance to Ginza, Imperial Palace, Tokyo train station etc. The service was fantastic! Every time we have a question, it seemed like the whole team in the lobby will help you or try to research the answer for you. And I am not talking about just the concierge, but it can be the person at the lobby door. In fact when we left, it looked like the whole staff at the lobby were there to help us & they all said good bye to us including Mr. Nakamura (one of the managers). The facilities were excellent & more modern that American standards. I dont have any negative to say about this hotel. We are planning to go back to Japan this year and is considering going back to this hotel again.

Luxury hotel in top location very close to the Imperial Palace and gardens, 100m away from Yamamoto line. The rooms and service are 5 stars and the service is excellent. I didn`t try the restaurants because nearby are so many choices. The concierge service is top too, they recemended a 5 star kobe meat restaurant which already knew about us when we arrived and treat us very well!!I stayed there 2 times and is my favorite hotel in Tokyo.

I stayed at this hotel with my two children, both age 12, on the front and back end of a trip around Japan in June 2014. The room had 2 double beds plus a pull out couch. It was very comfortable for three people. We had a dressing room that was a good sized room for all our luggage. The bathroom was large with a heated toilet, spa bathtub rain shower and mood lighting, tv and radio. There is an espresso maker in the room. There are also Yukata for everyone to wear! We had breakfast every morning in the lobby. Breakfast started at 6:30am which worked for us since we were pretty jet lagged. This hotel has metro station in the basement. We used it a lot to get around and it was pretty centrally located. It is also close to the Ginza shopping district and within walking distance to the Imperial Palace. You can get to Tokyo station with a short cab ride or using the metro. The service was impeccable. The food was spectacular. We ate at the Chinese restaurant twice. There is also a 7 Eleven around the corner if you need to take out money. I would recommend this hotel to anyone traveling with children. The service and the room makes the transition from a long flight and the time difference much easier to bear.

I stayed at the Peninsula for a week for business in early 2013. Where to begin: the huge stately rooms (with massive walk in closet), the amazing service and attention to detail, the sweeping views of Tokyo CBD and the imperial palace, or the crazy nice pool and decent gym. Oh, I forgot the sweeping lobby...yes it is an amazing hotel and, while expensive, more than worth the price.A word on location - it is perfect for business travelers; for casual travelers wanted the luxurious touch I would recommend the Ritz Carlton or Grand Hyatt (not as nice but much better location for going out).
user_name:
Jeremy R
New York City, New York

review_body: Stayed at the Peninsula during my recent visit to the beautiful city of Tokyo. The location of the Hotel is fantastic (sits right above the Hibya Metro Station) and bang in the centre of Tokyo City. The hotel is situated in the hustling bustling neighborhood of Chiyoda. The up market Ginza Marketplace is just a short walk away! The Lobby is small, but posh!. There was courtesy and politiness (right from the door-man to the check in desk). I was given a complimentary double upgrade as my booked room was not ready at 3PM on the check in date. Booked for a deluxe room and was provided an Executive Suite having breathtaking views of Ginza & Central Tokyo (I guess room was on the 13th Floor).My wife and my toddler accompanied me on this trip. On checking in the room, within 5 Minutes, my toddler was provided her own Bathrobe, Bath Stool, Soap, Sponge and Slippers! She was floored with being pampered like this! She never left her cute slippers till the end!Breakfast was more of a set menu rather than a buffet, but that was all we wanted! So no complaints! Extremely high tech room, completely noiseless, and we had sound sleep after our long flight from Abu Dhabi.The room was HUGE comparing to Japanese Standards!A Must visit property if you can afford it! Kudos to the team at the Peninsula!
user_name:
Bharatravels
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: The Peninsula Tokyo is my favorite city hotel in the world. It's really gorgeous, the rooms are fantastic, and the service is great. The little details at this hotel are over the top, and exceed most expectations. Location is perfect, within walking distance to yakitori alley and ginza shopping area. Also, the pool and spa is really great. I highly recommend it.

I stayed at the peninsula tokyo for the first time (for our first trip to Japan). While we were staying here, the service was just good but not excellent. I would give all the credit to Concierge. Because they have been so helpfull, arange everything from booking the restaurant to the any store location. It helped us a lot and made the first trip much more easier. But when we were cheking out, I had been so dissapointed with the bill. Which came with the price of the breakfast in every nights. So im asking the reception that our room was including breakfast, isnt it? And he said that let me check. It should be on the room information, isnt it? He then informed us that "there are exceptional items from the breakfast which is not included in the breakfast plan". Really??? And then he again said that mine breakfast had only 4 set (i just found out that there are 2 side of menu, one included with your room and another one doesnt). Then I said that "Ive never been informed by any of ur staff about this. Then he was like ok I will delete it all the items and gave us a new reciept. This shouldnt happened to the 5 stars or maybe its 4.5 stars hotel. I dont mind paying extra money to get what i want to have but this is so unusual. Or They are trying to charge more without telling customer. In overall, it was good experience but not as good as the Chain in Hongkong and Tokyo.

This hotel was lovely to stay in. The closet dressing room even had a nail varnish dryer. The bath had a waterfall type feature and you could relax watching tv. The toilet lid lifted when you went to use it and it was complete with heated seat and all the typical wash and dry features. Eating in the hotel was excellent and the kitchen was happy to help with dietary needs. There was a choice of breakfast restaurants. They serve afternoon tea too.It is well worth going up to the bar by the separate lift. The night time view over Tokyo is stunning.Whilst we were there the hotel was running speciality cocktails and teas in aid of breast cancer.We would stay here again.

stayed here for one night during the cherry blossom season. my first time at the peninsula. the service was impeccable, very professional and efficient. check in and check out were both hassle free. hotel is conveniently located. rooms are spacious but a tad dated. too many gadgets in the room, gets confusing. have to try the spa, the service is great and the massage simply fabulous. the lobby is also the all day dining / lounge so it gets a bit crowded and overwhelming when you enter the hotel. a tad short on common spaces.

It is not surprising that this Peninsula Hotel receives excellent reviews for service, as the staff here is truly outstanding. If personal service ranks high on your list for travel, you can be confident that this hotel will deliver. I would consider it a top choice for business, as the atmosphere is quite professional and the staff most attentive. We did also enjoy our holiday there - the concierge was very helpful in setting up excursions. The building itself is perfectly maintained and well appointed. It is a typical five star Peninsula - sophisticated and nicely appointed with all of the usual perks. The location is suitable for both business and leisure travel. We were upgraded to a very large suite with interesting views of the downtown area. The only drawback for me at this hotel is that the beds are very firm... which is desirable in Japan. I must say that when I casually mentioned this local preference was a little too firm for my taste, I came back at the end of the day to find a very fluffy bed awaiting me. They had piled one down comforter after another to make the bed feel like a cloud!

We stayed at the Peninsula for 9 nights and it was great. The room we had was spacious and well appointed. The housekeeping staff was outstanding.The breakfast was fine. Nothing special. The lounge upstairs was a throwback to the 80's. Really tacky.The location was fantastic. There is a subway station almost connected to the hotel.The Ginza shopping area was a few minutes walk. We found it easy to get anywhere.The concierge staff was most helpful and polite. We had a lady named Yuriko help us out quite a bit and she was great.I would certainly recommend the peninsula and would stay there again.

Just one block away to Ginza area and to shop at Bic Camera, Loft, Muji and etc. Yurakucho Station is also minutes walk from the hotel, while Hibiya Metro is just around the corner. The hotel lobby is almost all day crowded with diners. Front Office staffs and Guest Relations are very polite and service minded. Room is spacious for three of us with lots of luggage! Another nice property in Tokyo.

Stayed for 4 nights in this exquisite hotel in May. Excellent service by the staff, from the moment I stepped in all the way to my check out. Staff were always smiling and really made me feel welcome.The room was fantastic! Never imagined that I would be able to stay in such a large room in Tokyo. They called it a Deluxe room but it felt like a mini suite to me. I felt like a King staying there!

Tokyo is not my favorite city, but the Peninsula is one of my favorite big-city hotels. It is glamorous and crisp. Well located. We received a nice upgrade, and the room was very spacious, ultra comfortable and well-appointed with a spectacular view over the Imperial Gardens. Breakfast was very good and fresh. Service was spot-on -- obliging but not fawning, respectful and helpful. Like many of the 5-star hotels, it has a bit of an international feel -- not all that uniquely Japanese, but very, very nice.

Walking distance to the Ginza, the Peninsula has won me over with its beautifully thought out rooms! There is a proper seating area to watch TV, a writing desk, a small dining table too, with minibar and the requisite espresso machine. Apart from the big bathroom which had separate basin washing areas, there was also a walk in wardrobe with plenty of space for your luggage, a dressing table and believe it or not, a nail polish dryer fan! Access to the metro is very convenient as the hotel has a direct connection through its basement level. I was a bit let down by the concierge team though. With only 2 on duty, you had to wait for quite a bit to be served! And it was also not on par with the concierge team over at the Mandarin Oriental Hotel where you felt a genuine desire to help and that no question or request was too frivolous to be attended to.

Typically beautiful Peninsula property with an outstanding location across from the Imperial Palace grounds. Great staff and service with an amazing concierge desk, who booked all of our tours, and trains to/from Kyoto. The only negative is the weird lobby layout which strangely doubles as a restaurant thru which you have to walk to get to the front desk. Our room was huge by Tokyo standards with amazing views of the Imperial Palace grounds. More pics of the hotel and Tokyo...http://sfo777.com/content/peninsula-tokyoSFO777.com

This was our first experience of a Peninsula Hotel and it was everything we had hoped and expected. Complete luxury.The location of this hotel is amazing, looking onto the Imperial Palace Gardens.The hotel have their own entrance to the metro network, so transport is made very easy.Wonderful hotel in an amazing city.

The only word that comes to mind when describing the Peninsula in Tokyo - perfect! Perfect service, superior spacious rooms, amazing facilities. My husband and I stayed here in June 2014 and it was the highlight of our 2-week trip around Japan. The team at the Peninsula takes the renowned Japanese hospitality and service to another level! I would recommend this hotel to anyone who is looking for a sophisticated, high-tech hotels located at one of the best areas in Tokyo. The hotel is equipped with everything that you may need and more. Super comfortable bed, luxurious linens, huge bathrooms, stunning views of Tokyo, including the Imperial Palace. My husband and I have both traveled extensively around the world, staying at first class hotels and we both agreed that the Peninsula takes the first place for service, facilities and personal touch. Would highly recommend.

Husband and I spent two nights at the Peninsula Hotel. This is a first class hotel but it doesn't quite meet those first class expectations. It is does have an excellent location (A6 exit from nearby Metro station is very convenient). Should you have all your luggage etc, its only about $12 USD by cab from the Tokyo train station (where the Narita express is). There are also lovely Western friendly cafes and restaurants nearby on a tree lined street. Of all four hotels we stayed at in Japan, this hotel had by far the most channels available on the television in English.Our relatively minor complaints:1) The concierge desk. We asked the concierge to cancel a dinner reservation for 2 nights in the future we'd set up as it was far too late for us (9pm). We also asked for a recommendation for an earlier reservation for sushi. We needed to cancel since we still had not adjusted to the time zone as much as we'd thought. The reception at the concierge desk for this relatively simple request was chilly. She did eventually find us a great sushi restaurant but spent much of the time treated us like we are truly crazy for canceling our 9pm reservation. 2) Spotty Wifi Internet. Both hubby and I were continually dropped from the Wifi network on our iPads during simple surfing. 3) Front desk & check out. When you check in, the hotel asks at what time you'll be leaving at check out. We replied at 10:30a, well before the normal checkout. The morning of our check out we decided to leave at noon instead. We stopped by the front desk to alert the staff of our change, told her our room number and we were told that this was no problem. However at 11a when we tried to access our room, the door key was disabled and we had to go back down to the front desk and re-activate our key. This is annoying because it is well before the actual check out time of the hotel and because we had properly notified the front desk of our change. Also upon check out, the line was fairly long although it did move quickly. Give yourself a few extra minutes if checking out at noon for both the front desk and grabbing a cab.It seems silly but these minor complaints are why I'm not sure I'd stay again. We also stayed at the Conrad in Tokyo during our stay and I'd go back there (although I do think that this location is very marginally better than the Conrad). The service in general was very good but not to the exceptional standard that we'd experienced at other 5 star hotels during our stay in Japan.

We stayed at The Peninsula on August 2013 for about a week. The lobby was a bit small, but other than that everything else was excellent. Friendly staff and spacious room with all the fancy facility. Even my kids love it a lot. The bathroom is superb. They also prepared everything for my kids. Starting from toothbrushes for children to stool for them to reach the bathroom sink. We also love the spacious walking closet. We stayed in Tokyo for about a week and simply had a good and comfortable rest at The Peninsula everyday. Definitely one of my best hotel stay and will come back again.

I recently got back from Tokyo and our stay at the Peninsula was definitely a highlight of the trip. From the moment we got out of the cab to checking out of the hotel, everything was top notch and we couldn't be happier. The room wasn't ready when we arrived, so we enjoyed the tempura downstairs and it was definitely the best we have ever had and the food and service was impeccable.After a great meal, the room still wasn't quite ready because of an electrical problem, but a few moments later and we were being escorted to our room and wow what a room it was. The bellman opened the door and my mouth hit the ground I'm sure.The only downside was brunch in the bakery downstairs. The waffles were cold and a little hard, but I think that must have been a misstep because everything else was top notch and we will definitely be back when we visit Tokyo next year and the Peninsula definitely have a customer for life as this was the Best Hotel Room we have stayed at and we have stayed at some stellar resorts!

You may ask why the exit number? Because, the subway beats the taxi in this town, and this property has it's own access to the subway which is cool. The hotel overlooks the Imperial Gardens, and the view through the large floor-to-ceiling windows is impressive. Like in the Hong Kong property the restaurant is located in the lobby(small, but, elegant) at ground level, creating a welcoming, relaxing atmosphere. The rooms are large by any standard. The walk-in closet is the size of most basic Japanese hotel rooms. The shower pressure is good, the bathroom is huge. I love the dumb waiter--you don't have to interact with anyone if that is your wish; there is a sense of privacy and calm throughout this hotel. Prices are not any more than other Peninsula properties, but, the Chinese breakfast at $42 was a little disappointing, although tasty. Ginza shopping is just a few blocks away, but, the real pleasure is the street side dining, izakaya style, under the rail way, a minute's walk from the hotel, across the street. Look for the Godzilla statue and Starbucks and get munching. It's busy, loud and fun.

Yes the hotel is pricey but what a hotel it is!!! Opulence everywhere you look. Absolutely quiet in every regard (elevators, heating/cooling system, room to room insulation). Gorgeous room with more features than you could imagine - even your own work station with fax/copier/scanner. A toilet that defies description as it has more functions than I have EVER seen on a toilet including the toilet seat that raised automatically when you opened the door, a heated seat, and a triple option bidet with dryer. But the best feature of the hotel is its staff as they are all beyond courteous and helpful.The Peninsula Tokyo has spoiled us for life. Wow.

Our first stay at the Peninsula and one of our best experience's in Japan.From the beautifully designed lobby to the very spacious room overlooking the Imperial Palace grounds, this must be the top Tokyo hotel.The lobby restaurant had excellent service and a good menu of both Asian and American food..The Chinese restaurant had food better then that in a China.The Steak restaurant on the top floor had terrific views,good food and attentive service.All in all a first class luxury hotel.Expensive, but worth every dollar
user_name:
Robert S
New York City, New York

review_body: Rooms are spacious and elegant. Received upgrade to room overlooking Imperial Palace. Dressing room and bath fit for royalty. I'm hard to please and this place does everything right. Food is excellent and reasonable by Tokyo standards at the Lobby restaurant. Convenient location. Great stay!

Great location for business travellers - close to Marunouchi offices and shopping/dining in Ginza for after work. The ability to swim, gym and sauna with a view of the Palace is memorable, as is the opportunity to cross the street and join the locals running around the palace. The rooms are impeccably clean, spacious, comfortable and well appointed. Service, as expected, is exemplary.

We had a wonderful stay at the Peninsula hotel in a Tokyo. We were there a week and upgraded to a deluxe room. Well worth the extra money. The room is extremely large with a walk-in closet. The hotel is well located just a few blocks from the Ginza and only 2 blocks from a train station. The staff is exceptional. Our only negative is the price in the restaurants, way too expensive. But there are plenty of alternatives just around the corner. At least 4 Starbucks. It is a real treat to stay there.

There's a lot to love about staying at Tokyo's Peninsula Hotel. Our room was very spacious and well appointed. Convenient electronics for turning on lights and opening curtains. Very comfortable bed, pillows and linens. Comfortable robes, a huge walk in closet, convenient valet's pantry, well appointed double-sink bathroom. The sweet shop in the lower level makes amazing desserts and great macaroons. The breakfast choices include some good 'western' options which is something that is comforting to me when far from home. I especially liked the French toast. The staff are very very professional and almost always find a way to help if you ask them. The concierges give specific and helpful advice about attractions, restaurants and activities. The location is a great jumping off point for many adventures. One special treat we really liked (but wasn't really advertised): if you ask and if it is available, the hotel's posh Rolls Royce will give you a one-way ride to the fish market. Another suggestion, don't pass up on trying the pool; it is a great design and they treat you like royalty.My minor complaints don't detract from the overall experience, but are worth mentioning just for full disclosure-sake. As many other reviewers have said, the lobby restaurant is truly part of the lobby and it feels a little funny to either eat or walk through. In addition, I was not a huge fan of the hotel bar called 'Peter'. It seemed to try a little too hard to look 'cool', but this may just be a matter of taste. Besides, it has an amazing view.Overall, this hotel earns its reputation as one of the best in the world. The opportunities for pampering and luxury abound. Sometimes if you want something you have to be proactive and ask, but once you ask the answer is almost always yes.

I have written signing nothing but praise for this hotel as that is what I have experienced ever since it opened its doors back in 2007... But something isn't quite right now and this is not a isolated incident..I recently stayed in October13' and again end April 14'... On both occasions my room booking was not fulfilled as confirmed with my last booking being the worst as I was expected to take a Twin bed room even though the booking under Mr & Mrs was for a Double !!As a Centurion Member booking we used to be taken straight to our rooms to complete the signature formalities..no more does this this little nicety exist and you stand in the hustle bustle of reception awaiting your turn in line...For my April visit, we had terrible experience with the concierge desk repeatedly having to get back in touch asking if they had made the restaurant bookings we had requested.Two to three days were passing without a word on more than one occasion, which frankly I don't buy for a top class hotel.I even had to resort to calling the duty manger one day to ask just exactly what was going on !!!My suspicion is that that they are having are difficult time being overrun with Chinese visitors who are well known for their demands and intolerance...you pick up interesting tit bits from chauffeurs if you ask the right questions !!Once in the room, life at The Peninsula Tokyo is as wonderful as ever. Delightful staff, impeccable room service and a Spa of outstanding facilities and comfort.Achieving success is never easy, it comes only by hard work and striving, maintaining standards is sometimes just as difficult and it would be a great shame if this were not to be case with this lovely hotel..

Great rooms, impeccable service and ideal location overlooking Imperial Gardens and close to major attractions such as Ginza, Fish Market, Main Business district, Tokyo Station. On par with other Peninsulas!

I stayed twice in the Peninsula within 3 weeks. Once in April for 1 night and a second time in May for 8 nights. The property is very luxuriously appointed and is in the posh area of Ginza overlooking the Imperial Gardens. The hotel is very well connected through public transport and is connected to the JR lines at Yurakucho station and the subway lines at Hibiya station which is directly connected to the hotel. The rooms are very large and well appointed with seperate areas (dressing room, bathroom and bedroom/livingroom). The bathroom is very modern with a tv, spa feature (the bathroom lights are dimmed and the spa music from the Peninsula Spa is playing), rain shower and of course the famous Japanese toilets. I must say that I will fondly remember this bathroom as one of the top 3 I have seen in the world. The dressing room is large and is great to store your clothes and luggages and to keep the room tidy. The bedroom is very large and we had a nice view of the Imperial Gardens on the second stay. The beds are comfortable and the windows are soundproof. We had an issue with the airconditioning in the first room and changed our room as there was a bit of a damp smell coming from the airconditioning.However the second room was fine. Internet was very fast and useful during our stay.I really liked the sauna, steamroom and the aroma showers in the Spa area which was complimentary if you are a hote guest. I went there at least 6 times during our stay. The ambiance is very relaxing and the amenities are very high quality.The concierge desk is very helpful and their recommendations were appreciated and great. I cannot really fault the hotel for anything as it has been a great experience and I would definitely return again as the area, hotel and rooms are excellent.If you come from Narita airport there is a bus service which only costs 1000 JPY and stops around 5 minutes on foot from the hotel and was very convenient for us and you can save quite a bit of money using this option. If you enter access narita bus in to google you will find it. We used it to go to and from Narita and the bus was on time and very convenient.

A fantastic location, close to everything that counts in town and even a private entry to the tube station. Staff are absolutely faultless and always eager to help and making us feel comfortable. The room was a wonderful 54sqm, with great views on the Imperial palace and all possible amenities, including a walk in wardrobe, nail dryer (!) and a kimono to wear when inside.Coffee and tea was replenished daily, just like the numerous toiletries in the bathroom.The lobby has a buzzy feel.Would return tomorrow

We just returned from a 3 night stay and had an amazing experience. We were there for both business and pleasure. The staff and level of service was outstanding. Our suite had a fantastic view. I also visited the spa and enjoyed my massage. Our room rate included breakfast, which was very good. The location was conveniently connected to the subway/metro. It was truly superb and we hope one day to have the opportunity to return!

After staying at the Mandarin Oriental and Park Hyatt, and believe that the Peninsula is by far the best five star hotel in Tokyo. Full disclosure however is that this review is based on us upgrading to suite, which is absolutely amazing if you can afford it. Originally we had booked the the Grand Deluxe room with supposedly an amazing view of the Imperial Palace. However upon arriving we asked for the cost of an upgrade and were told that we would get a special rate of half the price it normally would be to upgrade. The one nit that I would have (which the front desk also made very clear to us) is that the suite we upgraded to has city view in the corner of the hotel facing the railway. There was also construction going on so from certain angles the was not the best. I would recommend that if you were to upgrade to a suite to make sure you are not facing the railway. On to the good stuff!RoomAbsolutely beautiful and smartly arranged room. Peninsula had a nice balance of comfortable dark woods everywhere without coming across as too business-y which was the issue I had with Mandarin Oriental. You walk into to an expansive living room with a dining table, sofa and TV. The room controls at the Peninsula were far superior than any hotel I have ever been in. Usually figuring out how to turn on the lights, close the curtains, change the temperature can be slightly confusing even at the nicest hotels. The Peninsula has clear and easy to understand labels in every room. Th curtains had double blackout blinds so when closed, absolutely no light gets in. The controls also include displays of the outside temperature including humidity and wind speed! The phones and electronics were all motion sensitive so will light up when you approach it. Everything like the coffee machine, TV in the bedroom were tucked away behind wooden shutters. When you turn left from the hallway you enter a large closet with a enormous bench for placing your luggage on top and below combined with a dressing room with a vanity table. This room leads to the larger bathroom and bedroom. BedroomOne of the most comfortable beds I've had on my entire trip. You have the option to change pillows if the ones you have are unsatisfactory. As mentioned before, the TV is tucked behind a wooden screen along with the DVD player. The windows also have double curtains keeping out all light. BathroomThere were two! One toilet in the hallway upon entering the room and one full bathroom past the dressing room. The full bathroom was wonderful with a large tub that had s stone faucet and large window overlooking the city. A separate shower had wonderful water pressure and easy to figure out and use. Plenty of towels and plenty of places to hang your towels (usually an issue at most hotels). A full drawer of amenities (sewing kit, comb, etc) all packaged in Peninsula boxes. LocationGreat location. Right in the backyard is Yakitori alley with tons of great Yakitori places. Being a night owl, it was great to find out that some of these places stay open on weekends 24x7. Further down you get into the major shopping area of Ginza. ServiceHousekeeping was great. Turn down service every day unless you have your privacy light on. They will come in and close the curtains etc. Concierge was much better than the Mandarin Oriental. I used concierge at both extensively to get restaurant reservations because many restaurants in Tokyo do not take reservations from overseas. The Peninsula concierge was efficient and presented your requests in a very clear manner versus the Mandarin Oriental sent very confusing and unclear messages. PoolOne of the best city pools I have ever been in. The pool was Olympic sized and they provide you with towels, water, and slippers upon arrival. Huge floor to ceiling windows overlooking the city with lounge chairs set up facing the window. Large hot tub is set up right next to a window so you can watch the sunset while you relax in the hot tub. Did not try the room service or the restaurants but did go upstairs to the bar which was very beautifully decorated. If you want to throw away some cash there is a watch store, Graff, and various high end clothing stores downstairs in the hotel. Overall a wonderful stay. I'd recommend this hotel to anyone.

Location - very convenient. It's connected to Metro Hibiya station exit 6 and also close to JR Yorakucho in walking distance. Surrounding with nice area and waking distance to Ginza.Room - is huge (not only for Japan standard but world standard). Very very very clean. Very nice bathroom & bath tub. Big dressing room. What I really like about this hotel is thoughtful design and privacy. There is a valet service/valet box that's useful when you are not around or ready to see anyone. A few Emergency buttons in bathroom.Nail dryer in dressing room.A bucket of Ice prepared for you everyday without asking.A powerful privacy and make up room button. Other hotels also have this but not efficient like this hotel. When you leave privacy button on. You can't even hear a bell ring. And when you press make up room. Your room will be cleaned so quick and you don't have to tell reception again. It's like someone ready to service you at all time.Service - is great. 2 thumbs up. Very attentive, polite staff. Very smart and helpful concierge persons. They are all professional.Food - is yummy!!!

We stayed for 3 nights in a deluxe room at the tail end of a whirlwind tour around Southeast Asia. Out room as at the end of a hall and was extremely quiet. We were not aware of any other guests. What we liked:* Rooms were large and spacious for a hotel in Japan* I made ample use of the dressing room. We had a lot of baggage after a few weeks on the road and I liked being able to contain things in a closed off area since our bags seemed to explode each time we unpacked* Bathrooms were huge and clean* Room was spotless* Ice was delivered every day* Black out automatic curtains helped us sleep* location was perfect for us* Staff was professional* Japanese breakfast was ample and looked forward to it everydayWhat you should know:* Drinks at the bar on top level was expensive (but of course it will be in Japan)* There is really no lobby area, so if you are meeting someone the only option for them to wait is on the few benches/sofas in front of the cafe* This is the best location for shopping * Metro/subway stop is very close by* Rooms are definitely on the higher end of the price rangeAirport Transport* On the way to the airport they offered a shuttle. This ended up being a large bus that stopped at 4-5 hotels before getting to the airport. if you are pressed for time opt for private transportation instead.

we stayed here for our second honeymoon. the service and attention to detail was stunning. made our stay very enjoyable. our deluxe room was incredible with a view of the palace. access to the trains are easy and all taxi drivers know where the peninsula is. staff are incredibly polite, accommodating and courteous. if we come back to tokyo, this hotel is the one we will be in again. highly recommended.

My husband and I just loved staying here for a few days at the Peninsula! The hotel was modern and beautiful, the location was perfect for touring the downtown area, and attached to a train stop for easy travel. -Service: The staff were so cute and so friendly! We were greeted warmly and well taken care of for the duration of our stay.-Accommodations: Our suite was spacious and absolutely beautiful. Both the bedroom and bathroom were modern with Japanese flair. The king bed was very comfortable with reading lights on each side. The bathroom was gorgeous and spacious with his and hers sinks, a large soaking tub that could fit two people, a separate shower with hidden drains, and a private toilet/ bidet room. We also had a walk-in-closet with a vanity and lots of storage space. -Dining: we enjoyed breakfast at two of the restaurants at the hotel. The one in the main lobby had a sit-down menu, and the other was more of a buffet- both were lovely and offered similar foods. The breakfast menu had many options to choose from with both traditional Japanese, and western breakfast options (granola, yogurt, eggs, toast...) One of the best things was when the chef whipped up hot chocolate drinks for us made from scratch- perhaps the best we've ever tasted!
user_name:
Madeleine M
Salt Lake City, Utah

review_body: We have recently returned from The Peninsula, Tokyo and highly recommend it. The hotel is very contemporary and timelessly elegant. While the public areas are not as large as other Peninsula properties we have stayed at, we consistently enjoyed the same level of elegance, hospitality, service and attention to detail. The foyer is beautiful and we never tired of the magnificent lighting installation and the stunning contemporary bamboo dragon sculpture. The lobby always felt refined but buzzy – just the right mix.The location near to Tokyo station and with direct undercover access to Hibiya Subway Station is extremely convenient and you are in walking distance of the Ginza department stores and other high end retailers.Our Deluxe room on the 18th floor was a total knockout – large, elegant and a perfect retreat in a very, very hectic city. A special mention must be made about the fabulous bathroom and the largest, best appointed dressing room we have ever experienced. As usual at a Peninsula Hotel – the room’s control systems were sophisticated and very easy to operate.We had a wonderful dinner at the Hei Fung Terrace which was as elegant and tasteful as we have come to expect from Peninsula Cantonese restaurants. Lunch or the a la carte breakfast in the lobby was also a polished affair. Make sure you have a drink at Peter Bar on the 24th Floor – the night time views are spectacular! In short, I would stay here again without hesitation.

We were told on arriving at the hotel that our room had a prior smoker occupy it. They could only put us in an inferior room. We opted for an inferior room after much haggling with front desk. They rewarded us with a glass of Champagne at dinner. Staff is rude. I would not stay here again. Stay at the Ritz.

The Peninsula group of hotels always features spacious rooms with walk in wardrobes,big bathrooms & rooms with exceptional attention to detail and their Tokyo property is no exception.It is situated in Hibiya,near the Imperial Palace and a 5 min stroll to Ginza.We stayed in a Deluxe Park King room and the room had a small dining table by the window overlooking Harumi Dori.We found the table particularly useful as we could buy cakes or cut fruits to eat in the room without having to order a food trolley from the room service.Only issues were the service in the hotel was a bit slow and there is only a twice daily service on the Airport Limousine service from Narita and vice versa.

Nothing special to look at from the outside but a lovely hotel on the inside , we had a deluxe park view room which was spacious and had every amenity going , my daughter loved the novelty of a toilet that massaged you and made various noises ! We tried the spa whilst here and were impressed with both of our therapists experienced hands . We had breakfast here each morning and also afternoon tea , food again was very enjoyable , the little restaurant downstairs did some lovely egg Benedict waffles .! The concierge here were lovely and so accommodating , one guy ( am really sorry can't remember name ) even used his own personal credit card to purchase us some tickets for Disney as we were having problems using ours ... Overall a lovely hotel and can totally recommend

Very warm welcome although we had to with 4 hours for our room. Beware that most Japanese hotels do not allow check in until 3pm. Our fault for not thinking about this. The hotel is ain a great location over the road from the Imperial palace but just 5 minutes walk from Ginza. We splached out with a meal in Peter the first night - Again beware that most people eat early in Japan and we had no desert due to the kitchen being closed. The meal itself was excellent though pricey. Perhaps they shoud move the breakfast service to this resteraunt as the lobby breakfast feels a bit strange. Spa was great, very good facillities and luxurious freebies!Very handy for the Bullet train, our luggage was transferred by the hotel and we walked 15 minutes to the station. All signs are now in English as were the anouncements at the station.Staff and cleanliness were very high standard.

I stayed at the Peninsula Tokyo for three days. The location was very good, the room was comfortable and upscale and all of the amenities were great. I had several meals in the restaurants and they were excellent. The internet was a little slow, which was my only real issue. the staff were friendly and helpful.

I was on a business trip to Asia and had to transit Tokyo on my way back to the US. I picked the Peninsula as it was recommended to me by seasoned business travelers but the reception I received upon my arrival left me unimpressed. The hotel is beautiful and my room had a beautiful view of the imperial palace and Tokyo skyline but the service level was lacking for a 5 star property I had asked in advance for a noon check-in and certain type of room. First I was told that I hadn't reserved the room type I had a written conformation for and then I was told that my noon check-in was not guaranteed. All this in a very hostile manner. Finally after I asked if tis was truly a 5 stat hotel in front of oter guests did the tone change! I then had to call and ask for fresh towels when hotelof tsi caliber should offer turn down service. The location isi great but next trip to Tokyo I wil stay at another property.
user_name:
Fatemeh L
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Wonderful hotel in downtown Tokyo with great views of the Imperial Palace and easy walking to Ginza. The rooms and amenities are beautiful - every need is thought of...espresso machine, nail polish dryer, make-up desk and mirrors. The staff were so friendly and great atmosphere.

My husband and I visited Tokyo, Japan, at the end of March and stayed at the Tokyo Peninsula Hotel for the first time. We did stay at several other Peninsulas and they met all our high expectations. This Tokyo property is not an exception either. The hotel has a premium location with Ginza just steps away. Several main subways have direct access to the hotel. Many major shopping departments and marvelous restaurants are just in walking distance, that include either the high end or the budget affordable eateries. Multi languages hotel staff is very friendly and provides all the adequate informations whenever needed. Rooms are on good size with a huge dressing area. Cleanliness is not a problem at all with my super picky taste. The cake shop at the basement is a must visit if you are a big dessert fan. Or even just to look at all the desserts would satisfy someone's desire.Their Chinese restaurant, Hei Fung Terrace, serves the best Chinese food in Tokyo and with a very nice ambience and elegant style.Plus, Peter serves wonderful grilled items and Peter beer is a must try since it's exclusively made in Hokkaido for this restaurant .There's only one small negative point is that breakfast at the Lobby needs some improvements on their Japanese style breakfast sets. Also the Internet connection is very slow and sometimes even disconnected in the middle of usage. I had to get up very very early to get my works done to avoid the problems.Toiletries are from Oscar de la Renta which are served at the Peninsula hotels in the very recent years!Hotel limousines are very expensive. We did order a Rolls Royce for Narita pickup but had a taxi ordered by the hotel for departure. In conclusion, we had a superb and memorable stay at this Tokyo Peninsula and plan to go back there by the end of the year.Rooms facing both the Hibiya Park and the Imperial Palace offer a wonderful view and with Skytree at the far side.

I actually don't remember the last time I stayed here but thought it was time to write a review. Service is incredible. I was working in tokyo for a while so My wife and daughter flew in to visit me in the hotel for a week. First the room is huge with a walk in closet and a massive bathroom so we all fit comfortably. I told the front desk my wife and daughter would arrive that day and the flight time. She took a cab herself to the hotel. She swears that they opened the door to the cab, told her hello mrs. Wall. Had a key ready by the time she hottie front desk and sent her to the room. We still talk about this as the pinnacle of service we have ever received. Location is great. If it is your first time in tokyo, go under the Shinkansen tracks and eat at the little isakayas next to the train. It is a cool tokyo experience.
