And the croissants are the best I had in tokyo and tokyo has great croissants

Sure this is an exceptional hotel with amazing rooms and large for Tokyo standards but the highlight was certainly the service. The breakfast area in the foyer or in the lower ground cafe is a bit odd and the food not brilliant but the staff made up for the shortcomings. Everyone from the bell staff, checkin, concierge, transport , food and beverage to house keeping deserve a mention.As a family we really enjoyed the convenience the hotel has to the Hibiya station and the proximity to both Hibiya Park and The Imperial Palace. For a city the size of Tokyo being next to a park made it refreshing and a pleasure to come back to our oasis. On the downside the gym could be better equipped or bigger, the breakfast could be a bit more fancy or extensive but overall we were very happy with our choice for Tokyo.

The Peninsular Tokyo is truly the height of service and elegance. Caveat: space is Tokyo (like in NYC) is very limited, so the rooms are NOT gigantic, but they are extremely technologically forward. There is a remote that controls all the tech and lighting in the room. The bathrooms have a full range of settings, and there is both a bathtub and shower.The Spa is very western, spacious, and the services are very good. The location is simply unmatched, right in the heart of upscale Tokyo, and you can access the trains you need to get ANYWHERE in Tokyo right FROM the hotel. There is an elevator that takes you all the way down to the subway. This hotel is also NEXT TO (like, in front of) the imperial palace in Tokyo. The hotel has a few very good restaurants and a delightful tea room. But the best thing about this hotel is the amazing service. The concierge went COMPLETELY above and beyond to provide us with everything we needed. We arrived at the Peninsula with NO PLANS, and after a talk with the concierge we had tickets to Sumo, the kabuki theater, tickets and train to Disney Tokyo (which she got by WALKING TO A CONVENIENCE STORE and buying them for us) as well as the restaurant reservations we needed. She also helped us buy bullet train tickets to Kyoto, as well as with the transportation everywhere.  Everyone in the staff, from the bellboy to the concierge, was amazing. Highly recommended.
user_name:
Alejandra F
New York City, New York

review_body: We decided on our final leg of our trip to Japan, to return to Tokyo for two nights before departing back to London. We had high hopes and the Peninsula did not disappoint, check in was a breeze and were given an incredible room overlooking the Imperial Palace Gardens. Our room was above average in size on floor 22. The amenities are luxurious, the best being the spacious separate dressing room opposite the bathroom. This was a treat to be able to offload all of our clutter and keep the rest of the room tidy.The only downside to the room is that the technology for music playing is a little outdated. No iPod dock or Sonos system. But this is me just nit picking.If you can, try and enjoy the spa which has unadulterated views of the street below. Make sure you get a lounger by the window!You will find elements of other hotels better elsewhere, but the complete package that this hotel gave us, is what won our hearts.

I had a short 3 day business trip to Tokyo and got a room at the Peninsula which was ideally located for me given proximity to work.The room and hotel are understated beauty and the service is top notch.I asked the concierge if there was any authentic Ramen nearby and they produced a map of all Ramen establishments in the district and provided their own suggestions.I had a short window of time to do some shopping and the concierge actually walked me to the shops that I wanted to go to since it was somewhat difficult to explain their location and how to get there, even on a map. What outstanding service!Then when I had to leave, I caught the Limousine Bus from another nearby hotel, the Imperial Palace due to the timing of the bus departure relative to my flight. The concierge went with me to the Imperial Palace hotel and showed me where to buy my ticket from for the Limousine Bus! Again, what exceptional service. In neither situation did I in any way suggest that I needed such assistance, they just offered, in fact insisted that they come and help me. I was truly amazed at such exceptional service.I used the pool a few times to swim laps, its a very nice pool, and very attractive.Only a few small glitches. The breakfast restaurant in the lobby of the hotel is logistically a bit awkward. I realize there is probably not much they can do about it, but its not the best set up. Also I went up to the bar for a nightcap at the end of a long day and evening and the only spot I found open was either next to a cigar smoker or at a table way off in the back, neither was appealing.All in all one of the best hotels in Tokyo and truly exceptional. I probably like the Park Hyatt a little better, partly because of the bar and lost in translation, but... this is truly a great hotel.

The Peninsula is easily the nicest hotel I have ever stayed in. It is hard to quantify since the room is not the biggest, nor is it the most high tech. However, it has a subtle beauty in which everything meshes to be perfect. Not too ostentatious, just beautiful. The dressing room is such a nice touch as it adds very useful square footage. The location is wonderful. If you feel like high-end shopping and dining, everything is just a few blocks away. If you feel like a break from the city, you can relax in Hibiya park across the street. Tokyo station is only one stop away on the JR rail. The staff is so friendly and extremely helpful. Every question I had was answered in such a thorough way. The last day, I asked for a cab to Tokyo Station (in order to take a shuttle to Narita airport). They ended up finding me a much more efficient way to get to the airport. 3 different members of the Peninsula staff were researching the best route to Narita for the given time of day. Unbelievable! We traveled with our children and upon arrival, they had treats in the room for the kids. After a long flight, the kids were so happy to have a nice, fun snack.

This is my favorite hotel in Tokyo. The location is simply perfect. I had the chance to do a morning jog around the Imperial Palace which is just across the Hotel. For all runners, this is a must-not-miss experience when you visit Tokyo. For my shopping addict wife, the Ginza district is just 2 blocks away. This is my go to hotel whenever I visit Tokyo. Not to mention the amazingly huge and beautiful room with all the fancy gadgets. I thoroughly enjoy my stay and can't wait to be back!

You will be amazed with all the gadgets in your room to make your stay inviting. Alone the heated toilet is a fine invention. With wall controls you can change heat amount, bidet amount, drying feature to name a few. As you walk into the toilet the seat will open automatically. The generous-sized tub is inviting and relating with wall fountain spout, and tv controls at you fingertips. Controls are everywhere, for your shades and curtains, for lighting, mood and bright. The bed was the most comfortable in our entire trip. The TV had the most American choices of all our hotels in Japan on our vacation. Not to say I had time to watch TV, because the outdoors beckons you to shop, and walk the garden across the street. Ginza street a brief walk away. The block behind the hotel and to the left was tree-lined and had benches, nice dining choices and shopping. Also at the back of hotel was a Peninsula food truck and outdoor seats for lunch choices. The Ginza area is nice to shop, but there is no outdoor seating -- so the street behind the Peninsula was a nice choice to sit outside and enjoy the fine Spring weather. The staff at the Peninsula is first rate, and they are ready to help your every wish. This is a fine hotel, in a great location of Tokyo, with much to do within walking distance. We were able to also walk to a location and take an open-air bus tour of the city.

Soothing design and human size - all to feel comfortable. Even the high tech rooms are easy to use and heavens of peace. The art works and general art theme are interesting, especially the "black hole" stretching over all floor to be viewed from the elevator landings.The top floor restaurant has nice views, pleasant service and comfort food options, but the smoke from the nearby bar is perceptible.The spa looks gorgeous as the large overheated (30°C) pool comes with a view. Attendants are kind but sticky and will insist you put a swimming cap, despite no such rules are posted (and according to the very kind spa manager neither enforced). This would still be acceptable if they had the correct size for my large (and bald) head, which was not the case and made me feel very uncomfortable. The next day I swam without which provoked a big fuzz. If you go there, by all means: Swim without cap and ignore the obnoxious attendants. You are at what is an international hotel brand.Possibly smoking and hysteria about hygiene are common pleas of Japan - but other properties may handle these issues better than The Peninsula.Stay rather at the Four Seasons near the main station- they have no pool, so no issues...:-).

This is one of the best hotels that I have ever stayed in. The rooms are beautiful and spacious with lots of technology/ The most welcoming and helpfu and friendly staff . We were made to feel very special. Room service breakfast was a lovely experience. My nightie was mis-placed on the last day whilst staying here and they managed to delivered it to the gate of the flight I was taking the next day from Haneda airport! Unbelievable service.The Peter bar was very good and especially when the 'happy hour' was on. as quite a few drinks and bar snacks were only about £5 Again very lovely friendly staff.We plan on another trip to Japan in the near future and this will definitely be one of the hotels we will be staying at. Can't wait to return!

arrived from south america after a long flight, great rooms, very busy in tokyo at sakura time, great location, all staff were very helpful, afternoon tea great, and topped of by drive in the rolls royce

An excellent hotel which is very conveniently located for the subway, shops and the 5km run around the perimeter of the Imperial Palace. Rooms are large and well equipped, and very high tech with a marvellous self-opening toilet seat (a real bonus for our teenage son). The service throughout is at a consistent Peninsula level. Breakfast is served in the lobby, which does lack atmosphere, and can take a while. We tried the Chinese restaurant on-site which was very good and with prices that more than matched. We did try to try Peter's on the top floor but were beaten back by the stale air and tobacco smoke and a surprisingly frosty welcome.The gym is small but OK although the equipment needed some attention. Definitely recommended.

OK. I know this is like my fifth review of this hotel but it is still number one in my opinion. Which is really incredibly hard to maintain so it deserves recognition. The service remains tops. It is always so good so to see happy, genuine smiling faces at the door and throughout the hotel. It was very busy when we stayed but that did not affect service one bit. The staff here are world class professionals. The food is always great, the rooms are always the cleanest and they really care. My only request would be that they do something to speed up the WI-FI. It's really slow.

When walking into the lobby, you will find that it is very packed and small. The front desk is tucked to the corner of the foyer and to one side of the frontdesk is another narrow passageway leading to the lift lobby to the hotel rooms. Very often, the users of these lifts will have to fight for space with the people at the front desk. One thing that guests need to be aware is the unannounced occupation of the lobby by wedding marches. The hotel does not give their guests advance warning of these events. The lobby also does not provide any proper seating in the lobby for its guests. Whilst the staff are helpful, especially the Concierge desk, the hardware of this hotel has created restrictions and hurdles to match it with other Peninsula properties. having siad the above, there is virtually nothing wrong with their rooms, which are enormous by Tokyo standard, with a lot of intelligent buttons to help your stay in their rooms an adventure and a new experience. The hotel, if it wants to equate itself with other Peninsula properties, must do something about its lobby!

The Pensinsula Hotel Tokyo is definitely a 5 rating. I stayed for 3 nights. The quality of my twin bed room was excellent. It was large and had all comfort needed (and more). The rooms are constructed with a lot of attention for details. They take it to a level I had only rarely experienced before. It even takes a day to discover all room facilities. The indirect lightning everywhere creates a cosy atmosphere.The fitness was OK. Not very large but good enough. I did not make use of the adjacent swimming pool but it looked fantastic.I really felt at home and upon returning to Tokyo would not hesitate to stay again here. Price paid was reasonable. Similar quality hotels in Europe would be priced much higher.Staff was extremely helpful and friendly. Very efficient also. Only the service at breakfast was a bit slow.

Just spent 5 nights at the excellent Peninsula.Starting with the misses: * polite, efficient but a bit chilly reception for our 11pm checkin. Surprised that no bellman or staff showed us to our room for orientation to the hotel and the room's extensive technology.* exquisite lobby had two major shortcomings: the gusty wind that covered breakfast diners when the front doors opened and the near total lack of a sitting area (two benches seating 10) to wait for friends.* Only one bar for a hotel with 5 restaurants, robbing the hotel of an intimate space for pre and post dinner relaxation. Peter Bar has a good view but a bit of a disco vibe for your hot date. Not a place to meet friends or spend time by yourself, particularly if you are a woman. The man next to us continually blew his cigar smoke in rings up to the ceiling. We had to leave.Many hits:* superb architecture and near perfect design in a beautiful luxe modern whole. Sumptuous materials complement the sophisticated modern style with Asian tones and touches.* location is incredible allowing us an easy stroll to Ginza attractions and a safe, interesting 3.6 mile jog around the Imperial Palace gardens.* wonderful dim sum lunch at the high end Chinese restaurant patronized by local high end ladies who lunch. Again, a beautiful space recalling rustic Cantonese settings. Relaxing and fun.* lobby restaurant was actually quite good for a bustling breakfast in the soaring space. Tried the Chinese, Japanese and Western breakfasts. All were terrific with excellent service.* spa and gym were superb as expected at a Peninsula. When rain interrupted our runs, the gym was a welcome home.* our deluxe room (not a suite) was one of our favorites anywhere: King bed overlooking Hibiya Park,, sitting room area with breakfast table and loveseat, enormous closet and luxurious bath with closed in shower, toilet, two sinks and dramatic central bath, technology galore. We were ready to move in and stay indefinitely. Wood features and woven cove lighted ceiling sealed us within its cozy luxury.Would come back in a moment. Add an inviting bar and attractive waiting area near the lobby and perfection would arrive.

I have stayed at the Peninsula on multiple occasions and for extended periods. This property is just fantastic - the staff go out of their way to help and I cannot speak highly enough of this hotel, it's location and the staff.

Have stayed at other Peninsula hotels, New York, Hong Kong and Bangkok, but Peninsula Tokyo is in a class of its own. The room design/facilities are fantastic, but I won't go into that as much has been said already.Housekeeping service is top class, down to the smallest details. Phone and laptop chargers left in a tangled mess were neatly rolled up, T-shirts tossed on the sofa were folded with origami precision. First night of my stay requested an extra bucket of ice, and on subsequent nights there was always 2 buckets of ice waiting when I got back to the room. Likewise, after calling once for extra drinking water, extra water was placed in my room every day.Concierge staff were exceptionally helpful and knowledgeable. Dealt with 3 different concierge staff during my stay, and all knew their stuff. One day I wanted to go shopping/walking in Shibuya, Harajuku, Shinjuku areas, but no idea where to go as was my first trip to Tokyo. Concierge took some time to draw on a map a suggested walking route, advised when best to use the subway or take a taxi, which subway exits to use, and marking which streets on the map were best for shopping, restaurants, or bars. I asked about a particular item I was interested in buying, and he immediately knew the store and marked it on the map. Seriously, if staying at the Peninsula no need to do any prior research yourself, just ask the concierges. Those guys know everything!Also, if you have breakfast included in your room rate, no need to go downstairs to the restaurant within the appointed breakfast hours, you can order it in your room at any time, which is what I did. You will be charged a service charge for this, 15% from memory, but it’s a small price to pay for the convenience of eating in your room or if you like to sleep past official breakfast hours. Wish more hotels offered this service.This is likely the best hotel I've stayed in anywhere in the world, and would happily live there full time … if only I could afford to.

An elegant hotel in the heart of Ginza. Rooms are of a generous size, and thoughtfully laid out. Excellent closet and dressing space, and opulent bathrooms with one of the best-designed long baths I've seen in a hotel. Toilets are of course top notch Japanese Gold standard. Everyone speaks good English and the Concierge staff deserve special mention. They were able to secure us bookings in several popular restaurants ahead of our arrival and had many spot-on recommendations for shopping and other sights. Subway access at the basement of the hotel made this convenient location even better.

Here's a hotel in Tokyo who knows what it's doing. Very well indeed. It needs no pomp or over-the-top grandeur to prove its worth. The Peninsula is definitely one of the best hotels I have stayed at in the last few years: the service is fantastic yet discreet, efficient and always with a smile.The location is fantastic, the rooms are beautiful, big and comfortable. You are made to feel welcome - but no-one is in your face. The food is wonderful. We travelled with our five-year-old and the smiles and little gift surprises kept coming. This is truly a wonderful hotel and I very much hope to have a chance to stay here again one day soon.

Great service, great rooms, great location. All of the most famous designers stores located around the hotel. I recommend the breakfast and dinner, "amazing and delicious food". In addition, you should not miss the spa with ultra modern treatments!!

The Peninsula tokyo is definitelly amazing. After a long flight from JFK we arrived to hotel close to midnight. the service in this hotel is upstanding ( the best). porters ready for you. efficient and quick check in. The rooms are big with a big walking closet, king size extremely confortable bed diner table, small living room, desk area with fax machiner, big flat screen tv, minivar, coffee maker . a master room control that control de humidity, moodlighting, curtains,etc. wifi is free. the bathrooms are huge with two sinks, cuzzi, shower, smart toilet( definitly high tech), bathroom tv, complimentary water, tea and umbrella. the hotel is excellent location almost in front of the imperial palace and the Ginza area. the hotel have a great and well equiped gym, big and beautiful indoor pool and an excellent spa. the restaurant in the top floor Peter is definitelly a most.

I really loved to stay for work in Tokyo thanks to this Hotel! This was my second time in Kyoda and I chose again this hotel because of the place an confortability of the hotel.Everything was so perfect; all people were so kind but not because they were obliged but because they really are kind people.Room was spectacular with an oriental style that feel you part of the Japan, I had no the opportunity to taste the cuisine but breakfast was really very good.It is expencive but at the end it is resonable if you remind that you are in the "very expencive Tokyo"...Judgement: First choice

I stayed here the month it opened and on a last minute 3 day trip last week. This review is strictly regarding my most recent stay. I have never stayed in a hotel with more complete (and sometimes complex) room electronics - a blessing most of the time. Rooms are large, comfortable, beautiful, good elevator service, quiet, and private. The front desk service is excellent, as is the bell desk. The few hick ups come in the lobby restaurant - where too much training takes place - and service and be long, slow, and uneven. Menu choices are few - breakfast is nothing more then chain average - no one really caring if toast is toast, coffee cream is fresh, refills rarely asked. It's the one area I don't get - I know they can't move it - but proper staffing and service should be expected. What they don't offer is meet and greet for the Narita Express - two other major deluxe hotels do - nor do they make sure a taxi takes a person to the correct door at Tokyo station - (actually my last driver not only took me to a very wrong entrance - but drove around a block to goose the meter - not the hotels fault - however if they offered a drop off - escort to the train service as other do this would not have happened). The location to Ginza or Palace is excellent. I would stay here again -

I have talked a leisure stay at Peninsula Hotel Tokyo. The overall of this hotel is excellent. Service, food, room are one of best hotel in Tokyo. The location is great. There is a special subway to access JR. It is very convenience. However, compared with other 5 star class hotel in the world. There are some room of improvement. e.g. At common, 5 star-class hotel will provide the fruit daily but this hotel will only give at first two days. I stay around 1 week. The damaged light at the room do not repair at several days.... It make me a little disappoint.

Peninsula Tokyo should be considered as top of the legend. This is the idea came across to my mind after staying many of top 5-star hotel in Tokyo....I spent 4 Nights in Peninsula just in Feb 2014, the first night was the most serious snow storm in the past 46-year. Thanks to the hotel location, I can avoid the traffic congestion. Hotel locates at 10 minutes from Hamamatsucho Monorail Station to Haneda Airport. Also, JR / Metro can be found by 5 minutes walk.From the room door open by a professional staff, I am surprised how spacious by their basic room. I believe it is one of the largest deluxe room in Tokyo. Every details look decent, classic. Not to mention about the bathroom and living room, the closet is wonderful. I felt easy to expend 2 XL size luggage. Their gym and swimming pool located on 6th floor is my favorite as well. Service standard is more than expectation, feel like home. Staff at Front Desk knows you name, they completed every single requests, from limousine service, restaurant reservations. Meanwhile, every staff can speak excellent English. I will definitely experience the spa for my next stay. one reminder: there is bus service from Haneda Airport to hotel. However, it is always fully booked by my experience. Book in advance or pay around JPY 7,000 per way by taxi. Also, valet parking cost a bit high at around JPY 4,000 / 24 hours.

Loved staying here. Great service of course across the board but check out that rooftop bar! The views are terrific with the double height floor to ceiling windows!! And I don't mean to be weird but the toilet in my room was pretty special too. As you open the bathroom door, the toilet lid automatically goes up, and there's a button to raise and lower the seat. My wife would have bought one on the spot!

With its white gloved valet and bellhop welcoming every guest that arrives at the Peninsula Tokyo, service and luxury begins at the doorstep. We go through the revolving doors and at once are escorted to the check-in desk. The Peninsula brand has definitely made its name from their excellent hospitality and service, but the Peninsula Tokyo takes on an innovative approach to stand out from other luxury hotels in the area. Aligned with the Japanese fascination of technology, the Peninsula Tokyo embraces this very character in the guest rooms. The room has every touch of high tech and luxury amenities that make our stay very special.The walk-in closet is spacious especially by Tokyo standards. Any hotel that adds in important details, however seemingly trivial, for female guests has a special place in my heart. At the dresser in front of the mirror is a cushioned seat for makeup application. An in-built nail dryer is also present at the side for her to paint her nails before a night out in town. As if not not pampering enough, there is also an in-built radio controls at the dresser for me to select my entertainment while I apply my makeup. Listening to a mix of J-pop and American music before a night out at Ginza- I think that's a win situation. In the closet drawer is a set of comfortable yukata (Japanese robe) for us to change into once we're back in the room.In the morning, we open our valet box to retrieve the newspapers delivered to our room, an accompaniment for our Lavazza espresso made from the machine in the room. There's a 2-seater dining table already laid with silverware and plates that we sit at every morning.The room, bathroom, and bathtub have in-built electric controls in the wall for lights, radio, and TV. In the shower, we have both rain shower and handheld shower. When the toilet bowl is not used after awhile, the seat cover automatically comes down to cover the seat. As someone approaches the toilet bowl, the sensor senses it and the seat cover automatically comes up. As part of the toilet bowl controls, one can choose if the seat itself be lifted up with the seat cover or not, once again taking into consideration if the user is female or male. There's always a fascination among T and I with how even toilet functions embrace the Japanese' love of technology. The Peninsula Tokyo takes the technology and combines it with luxury that is offered to its guests.Our bed area and sitting room are spacious for a deluxe room. The light switch on the wall illuminates when we approach so that we can actually see the switch itself when it's dark or dim. At night, the alarm and light switch on the bedside table also illuminate with a dim glow when we touch the table or put something on the table. Every evening when we return to our room, we are welcomed by the already completed turn down service with bedroom slippers and bottled water on each side of the bed.

I must commend the excellent concierge service. We wanted to try a few restaurants which were difficult to get reservations. The concierge managed to get the reservations for us and printed out the map and directions for us even before we arrived. Email replies from the concierge team was really fast. Very efficient.As expected, service was excellent. From bell service to reception to house keeping. They were all professional and pleasant.

Tokyo was the first stop on our honeymoon this January and I find it hard to imagine that there's a better property for a special vacation in all of the city. From the moment that we emerged from the subway with all of our bags, someone rushed over to help us and guide us to the lobby. I've never experienced a more hospitable and professional staff at any hotel.Our room was fantastic; coming from New York, I couldn't get over the size of that dressing room! The hi-tech lighting was pretty fun to play with too. We had a view of the Imperial Palace, which was lovely.Location was super central, you are pretty much in Ginza and you can access the subway without even stepping outside.Definitely ask for a spin (for free!) in the Rolls. You can't reserve ahead of time, but as long as no one is using it, they'll drive you to wherever you need to go within a few miles.I can't wait to see Tokyo again and I would stay nowhere else!
user_name:
julietk1985
New York City, New York

review_body: The first thing I noticed when going to the Peninsula Toyko was the service. From the bellman to the woman who holds the door or spins the revolving door to the front desk man that not only checked us in but led us to our room. During our trip we stayed at 5 different hotels (in California and Japan) and this was by the far the biggest. There were three rooms total:Bathroom: Huge bathroom with a separate glassed area for the toilet, a tub, and a shower. The shower has a rain shower head in the ceiling along with a regular shower head in the wall that's adjustable. The bath tub is terrific. It has a waterfall faucet and next to it are controls, one of which is a spa button. The spa button will dim the lights and play soothing, spa like music. The toilet has all of the buttons you'd expect from a Japanese toilet. During our stay I realized that this is pretty normal even in many public bathrooms. There is also a radio, phone, and tv as well. Walk-in closet: HUGE walk-in closet. I don't even know if I saw everything that was kind of "hidden" in the closet. But there is a vanity, lots of drawers and places to hang things, a hair dryer, and a place to put stuff for the valet so he can do dry cleaning or shoe shining. Bedroom/living space: There is a bed on one side and they laid out slippers and robe on each side of the bed. Also the phone was pretty impressive because it gave not only the time and weather but also had the time for our home, which was incredibly convenient. On the opposite side is a couch, tv, desk. mini-bar, and a small table with chairs. There were two apples with plates and silverware set up on the table. The bottled water was free and the ice bucket was filled, both were replenished whenever we left the room. There was also an espresso machine which I didn't try to use, it looked kind of complicated. There were multiple panels around the room that controlled the blinds and lighting. When the blinds were closed it was pretty much completely dark.I was impressed by how the front desk person always seemed to remember my name and everyone was very friendly. There was usually no hard time finding someone so we could ask for directions or information, many of them spoke very good English.The area around the hotel is nice, kind of posh. If you need to get your JR East Pass, I'd recommend getting it at the airport. Otherwise you need to go to the Tokyo Station, which is walkable but not too close. It's also a HUGE station and we needed to walk across it to get to the tourist center. We just had to show the guy at the desk our paperwork to show where we were going, he gave us a piece of paper and then we walked across the station to the OTHER entrance and showed the piece of paper again. Overall I loved this hotel, it was one of the nicest I've ever stayed in. Yes it's expensive and we chose to only stay there for 2 nights during the first left of our trip, but it was well worth the experience, especially if you're recovering from jet lag and end up spending a little more time in your room.

Entering the hotel's magnificent modern entrance, guests are greeted by clanging dishes and silverware. Its small lobby reception area is a circular space, about 40' in diameter, that sits in the middle of the restaurant. Not the image of luxury and class one expects at a property of this caliber.Despite being confirmed for an early check-in, we had to wait about 30 min. for a room.Our luggage had been sent ahead from Kyoto and at check-in the attentive reception clerk acknowledged it had been received. Yet it took about two hours to have it delivered to our room. (By comparison, we had made similar arrangements in Kyoto and when we arrived at our hotel room the luggage had already been delivered. This, in a hotel that was below the Penninsula's level luxury, service and expense.)The registration clerk at check-in asked which newspaper we would like in the morning, but the following day the paper was never delivered.The only two bright points were the eagerly attentive staff and the sleek modern rooms. And they deserve a star for each one. The bar on the top floor was superb and provided spectacular views of the city. The overall quality of the service, however, left a lot to be desired and certainly did not provide good value. Certainly not what one would expect from a hotel in this category.

My colleague and I were on our last day in Tokyo and were looking for a bar to cap off the trip. The roof top bar did just that. Sophisticated ambiance and good wines. I'll be sure to come back on my next visit.

Stayed here for 3 days. Huge hotel room especially by Tokyo standards. Very elegant though small lobby. Location is great and connected to subway. Only thing though is that room was not ready till 4pm.However, it was a family member's birthday and everyone (from porter to doorman to front desk) remembered! That is worth the 5 stars rating :)

On my forth trip to Tokyo and staying previously in Ritz and Four Seasons I decided to stay in Peninsula to check out other 5 star property in Tokyo and be closer to Tokyo station as I was planning several one day trips from Tokyo. Hotel is located in Ginza, right next to the imperial palace, Tokyo station, lots of nice eateries, parks and of course shopping. Check in was quick, smooth and got upgraded to deluxe park view. So far the most luxury hotel room I have stayed in. The way the room is set up, deluxe room feels like a suite. If you are gadget geek like me then this is a paradise for you. The room is completely automated from controlling humidity level in the room to internet radio of your preference. Big and separate walk in closet, huge bathroom, stone bathtub with mood lighting and spa features which was fantastic to use after long day. Pool was excellent with hot-tub looking into the imperial garden and outside balcony to chill if you get too hot. Dinning on the other hand was hit and miss. While the bar on the 24 floor was great place to end the day with a nice drink and fantastic view of Ginza, the lobby restaurant where the breakfast is served was located in the middle of lobby and the entrance to the hotel was through the restaurant which felt more like food court then restaurant of 5 star hotel. Hotel does not offer buffet breakfast, only a la cart and staff during breakfast gets busy, overworked and stressed, which resulted to take long time to get the orders. Except the breakfast (though it was not a major issue) loved my stay and had wonderful time in Peninsula. Small tip for those of you who are planing to do shopping - make sure you have your passport for tax free. Unfortunately stores require the passport and do not take photocopies. The highlight of this trip was the visit to Robot Restaurant, while the food was awful, the show was fantastic and had fun night. Must try.

Large hotel room for Tokyo standards. Elegant yet not over the top. Definitely the most comfortable hotel I have ever stayed in in Tokyo. Within walking distance of Ginza and other nice areas. Docked it one star for the insanely expensive breakfast.

We were fortunate to have a 23rd floor suite overlooking the city. The rooms are spacious and include every amenity, including a fax machine, printer and even a nail dryer to speed up manicures. The hotel itself is beautifully appointed with zen- like art, fabulous restaurants and a central location near sights and shopping. The staff is very polite and helpful. I would stay here again.

I had stayed at this hotel for two nights with a friend and I couldn’t have asked for a hotel in a better location. It is located in central Tokyo in the Marunouchi district and the Hibuya subway stop is right at the entrance of the hotel. The hotel is actually right next to a few subway and train stations so it is extremely easy to navigate to anywhere in Tokyo from this hotel. Also since the hotel is fairly well known, it’s easy to find on the city maps when trying to find your way around.I had taken the JR Narita Express from the Narita airport to the Tokyo Station and transferred there to the JR Yamanote Line to the next stop at the Yurakucho Station where I would be walking to the hotel. The Yurakucho station is right across the street from the hotel itself and I have to say that walking around with my suitcase trying to find the hotel wasn’t too horrible since it wasn’t too far away from the station.The hotel registration desk is set a little far back in the lobby of the hotel (to the left of the big eye sculpture in the lobby) and the hotel elevators are to the right of the hotel registration area. To the left of the hotel registration desk is the concierge desk and the bell desk is to the left once you enter the hotel from the front doors.When I arrived, numerous people asked to take my suitcase which was surprising as everyone wanted to be so helpful. When helped at the desk, they asked for my name and when I mentioned I was staying with my friend who had already arrived the night before, they said they already knew about me and quickly looked up the room and provided me my key. The service was amazingly top notch.The room itself was absolutely beautiful. We had a superior room and there was a huge walk-in closet with plenty of space for both of us and our bags. The closet had a vanity along with a nail dryer and safe. There is also a valet box in the closet and you could send your items down to be cleaned and delivered to your room later. Kimonos are provided along with huge fluffy white bathrobes. The spacious bathroom had two sinks and the toilet, of course, was automated. Neither of us used the huge bathtub in the bathroom but the shower was roomy. There was a rain shower head and a removable shower head but I would find out that when I used both at the same time, it was just too much water flowing at me. There is a nice coffee/espresso machine in the room and it was delicious. I usually do not have coffee every morning but for this machine, it was a shame to not do so. The hotel provided turndown service every night and the beds were extremely comfortable. The hotel internet provided was reliable and quick.I did go use the gym here and it was located on the 6th floor of the hotel. You enter at the spa area and head downstairs (and get a beautiful view of the pool area) to the gym facilities. There are many cardio machines and strength weight machines. They also have dumbbells and yoga mats to use. Cold towels and water is provided along with some fruit for nourishment. I was usually the only one using the gym when I was down there but the staff would periodically walk through to make sure the gym had enough water and was neat.There is a hotel bar/restaurant located near the top of the hotel named Peter and we went there one night for drinks and the view. It is pretty up there but as being from California, I had to adjust to having people smoke indoors next to me at the bar. Drinks were pricey as expected but it was a low-key atmosphere. For other food in the hotel, there is a restaurant in the lobby to dine at and there is a bakery/cafe on a lower level of the hotel. I stopped by the bakery but did not want anything at the time although the treats looked delicious. There is also a Citibank ATM downstairs and a business center to print items out.The hotel is across from the Imperial Palace so it’s a good location if you want to run around the area since there are many parks and walking trails right across the street. We walked to Ginza Street from our hotel once night and the Ginza corridor is nearby for many authentic Japanese restaurants.Overall, I wholeheartedly recommend this hotel as the service, location, and amenities were the best I had experienced. Any of the staff we encountered were very kind and being a business oriented hotel, there was a lot of western influence mingled with traditional culture. Everyone I had encountered spoke at least a little bit of English here so it wasn’t difficult to have help with anything you needed. Stay here and be impressed!

Perfect location, amazing ambience, the friendliest staff, the most delicious and sumptuous delicacies, truly incomparable. The Peninsula Tokyo has that grace and elegance and grandeur, truly a remarkable Peninsula trait mixed with genuine Japanese culture and values.

Across from Imperial palace grounds. Next to the Ginza business district. 2-3 minute walk to the train. All the usual Peninsula amenities. What a place. Expensive but worth it if you can afford it. Even a 7-11 across the street for late night snacks etc for cheap. The pool is nice and the hot tub has a bench in the water that is like a park bench. More comfortable. The work out room has a few dumbells, treadmills and weight machines. Water is provided and nice towels. They even give a toothbrush with toothpaste down there. Breakfast in the lobby is expensive so I would go out to eat at the many Tokyo establishments. Tsujiki market is only a 15 min walk or 5 min cab ride. Would highly recommend.

The Peninsula is one of the better appointed hotels in Tokyo. The hotel is conveniently located near all the action spots in Tokyo and you have access to the Hibiya subway station from the hotel’s basement. A walk around the Imperial Palace, nearby, would be worthwhile. The hotel is delectable with all modern conveniences, even a nail polish remover. The furniture is spacious and comfortable. The bathrooms are spacious and trendy. From the upper floors, you would get a grand view of the Imperial Palace. The food is good, if you specify your requirements. Try the dinner at the 24th floor restaurant.All in all, The Peninsula’s hardware is great but needs improvement in software.

my second stay at the pen - everything is definitely 5 star - from rooms to location. it just feels special! to improve the over experience i suggest focusing on the Concierge offering. just not that friendly and comes across as being rude on occassions.

This is an outstanding hotel, which I had the pleasure of spending 3 nights at, on business. As other reviewers have noted, the rooms are large, and the separate dressing room is wonderful. It is larger than a couple hotel rooms I have stayed in in Europe. The king size bed was luxurious, as was the bathroom, with his and her vanity units on either side of a large bath. It also featured a separate shower and of course the well-known multi-function toilet.The electronics in the room take a little getting used to. At night, touch the bedside table, and the control panel illuminates. The air conditioning system features humidity control, as well as temperature. Papers are delivered to a valet box, which illuminates when anything is deposited. This is a great idea, as it minimizes the inconvenience associated with having staff doorknock for pick up and delivery of washing, and shoes to be shined.The only reservation I have about the property is its Lobby. It is small, and has only two opposed bench seats for people to sit on. The rest of the floor space is occupied by a coffee shop/restaurant, with only a narrow thoroughfare for guests. The hotel does host a lot of weddings, apparently...there were 3 when I was there. It becomes a dysfunctional space when crowded with wedding guests, photographers etc. Otherwise, everything worked, the hotel was very quiet once you left the Lobby, and the ability to black out the room with electrically-controlled blinds and a hewn solid timber door between the bedroom and the rest of the room was much appreciated. Thoroughly recommended.

My husband was traveling for business and I decided to join him last minute. The rooms are quite large, there is a large dressing room, a living area with couch, and a wonderful bathroom with the precious Japanese toilets and double sinks.The location is also quite convenient as you will be right by the Yurakucho station and walking distance to Ginza (an upscale neighborhood with lots of shopping and dining options) as well as Hibiya Park--a great place to go to escape the concrete jungle and enjoy some green space. I did not get a chance to use the pool at the hotel, but my husband's coworker was able to use it and claimed that it was incredible!We were there for 2 nights, I would definitely go back in the future!

Our first time to Tokyo so we chose the hotel based on location and various reviews. We definitely were not disappointed. The rooms were awesome with walk in closet/dressing rooms and every electronic device you could think of and then some. The service was excellent from the front desk to the conceirge to housekeeping. If you needed something all you had to do was ask. You cannot beat the location which is right next to Ginza and best of all they have a subway station in the basement of hotel. Cannot say enough nice things about this hotel.

We used to have limited choices when it comes to very good international hotels (Imperial and Okura) in TOKYO. This one is a very welcomed addition to the category. Probably room is the best among those new comers (Ritz Carlton, Palace, etc). Lobby is small but service is always great. It has less business and more personal travelers.

Granted it is not cheap but then again there are far more expensive 5 Star Hotels in Tokyo. The value for money here is second to none. The standard category room is a huge 55m2. The rooms are beautifully appointed, massive bathroom with double sink, walk-in wadrobe/dressing room, great in room coffee maker which is very important. Comfy bed. Hotel is in a great location next to Imperial Palace and walking distance to Ginza and Marounuchi areas so handy for shopping and Tokyo Train Station if you are catching the Shinkansen Bullet Train.The only negative about this property and everyone notices is the lobby. They serve breakfast and tea here during the day and guests must walk through it to access the check-in area and the lifts, there is no traditional lobby with seats per se. The brekafast was good but service was slow for a hotel of this standard. Other than that a wonderful property, probably in my top 10 worldwide.

The design of this hotel is beautiful. Every feature, from the reception areas, the pools to the guest rooms are all beautifully done. In particular our room was stylish, comfortable and had all the latest technology and gadgets (including a heated and automatic toilet seat!). The location was great. All the taxi drivers knew exactly where to find it and easily recognised the name, which made things so much easier with the language barrier. Concierge were very helpful with all bookings, and the hotel is perfectly located to explore Ginza by foot. The gym was small with some weights but they have a pair of trainers available in each size in case you've forgotten your own!

We had stayed at several Peninsula's on our trip (all first class), but much to our regret, not at this one. My rating is based on the fact that we approached the doorman at his one, walking up from the street and asked about getting a cab. He stopped what he was doing, summoned a cab and assisted us to get in despite the fact that we were obviously not guests. This typifies what we experienced at the other locations. First class experience. If I can afford the stay, I'll stay at these when available!This location is across from the Palace grounds and about 1-2 miles from the Tokyo Tower.

Speaking of afternoon tea, a place that is famous for their iconic afternoon tea is none other than The Peninsula. A beautiful ritual steeped in tradition, afternoon tea is a signature feature at each Peninsula around the world. Before the three-tier set is served, guests will be served a choice of tea or coffee. Most certainly, tea is highly recommended and the wide range here includes the classic tea selection featuring tea from the Peninsula hotel brand, herbal tea selection as well as Harney & Sons fine tea selection. Harney & Sons is an American craft tea brand since 1983 and I enjoyed their Green Tea with Thai flavours (the Thai ingredient seemed to be lemongrass) Among the starters, the Shrimp and egg salad wrap was a moreish delight with spiced creamy mashed egg wrapped in a yellow crepe skin that surprisingly contained nostalgic taste of curry. I also like the Yuzu marinated salmon and white radish cocktail which resembled an refined pickled dish with bright sour flavours. Who says salmon must always go with cream cheese and dill? Lying besides the roasted bell pepper quiche is a Pink sandwich specially created for the Pink Breast Cancer Awareness campaign. The combination of corned beef, roasted beet and lemon cream is quite an adventurous idea that would realize its full potential if the beef had not been too sinewy. As mentioned earlier, The Peninsula Tokyo shows its support for Breast Cancer Awareness Month every October by staging "Peninsula in Pink" as part of a group-wide campaign of the Peninsula Hotels to raise both awareness and funds. A percentage of the proceeds raised goes to local breast cancer-related charities. In line with the theme of pink, the spread of desserts dominated by pink, white and red colors. Classic mousse cakes include the Raspberry and white chocolate mousse and La Foret noire (Blackforest cake) whose cherries were well soaked but not overly done to the extent of drenching the entire cake. Most European cakes that contained citrus peels tend to be extra sweet because the peels are concentrated with sugar but not for this Grapefruit pound cake. The bitterness of the peels here was forthcoming, and thus it took me some time to get accustomed to the taste. Hence, I prefer the Rhubarb tart, which has an excellent pastry base that never fails to put a smile on my face. But it was the homemade scones that I enjoyed bits by bits till the end of the course because they were simply terrific. Both the organic plain and raisin scones were those old-fashioned kinds with a sturdy wall that collapsed upon a bite. These were especially mesmerizing with the clotted cream and raspberry compote. The Afternoon Tea menu changes every season and be sure to avoid weekends and national holidays unless you do not mind queuing with the Japanese ladies. The selection might not be the most extensive one but it sure leaves one full and satisfied. And with the beautiful live piano music playing in the background, one can easily forget about the time and the busy crowds outside in Ginza. Feel free to visit my blog for full post and pictures

I really enjoyed staying in The Peninsula after having spent my previous two trips in the closeby Imperial Hotel - both hotels are high class but the rooms at The Peninsula are much more spacious and luxurious. Also it feels like it is new (compared to the somewhat outdated Imperial). A really great room size with large separate dressing room and bathroom, floor to ceiling windows, large flatscreen with seating area, convenient 110 and 200 volt outlets, comfortable beds. Breakfast area in the lobby is convenient and never too busy. Service is in all areas excellent. I also enjoyed Peters Bar and restaurant on the 24th floor with stunning views of Tokyo. So definitely a hotel to return to, one of the best I stayed in for a long time.From Narita airport easy to reach with the Limousine Bus service, reliable and relatively comfortable and at 3000 yen very reasonably priced.

This is a top hotel in a top location, just west of Ginza. It sits on top of, and has a direct entrance from, the Hibiya Metro station. The hotel is five-star Asian modern, with very large rooms. The deluxe rooms have sitting areas, huge bathrooms and dressing rooms\closets. Everything is of the highest quality. The lights, A/C, curtains, etc., are electronically controlled. The service is ultra-gracious, even by Japanese standards. Everyone we saw working at the hotel was very friendly and very competent. This was our third stay at the hotel. All three visits have been of the same quality.
user_name:
Donald C
Rancho Palos Verdes, California

review_body: This is a hotel I would choose whenever I travel to Tokyo and thus I am already quite familiar with the hotel's great location, nice room size and layout, authentic coffee in the room, relaxing bathtub and spa option, delicious breakfast (order the French toasts!) and convenient travel network (Hibiya subway station is accessible through the hotel basement and only 15 minutes from Harajuku on the Chiyoda line, while Yurakucho station of the Yamate line is only 3 minutes away!)What I didn't expect was the wonderful service that the staff was able to provide! Since there are four of us (all gals) in this group, needless to say we have quite a few boxes stuffed with omiyage (お土産). We had to call up housekeeping to give us some duct tape to seal them up. A very nice (and good looking!) gentleman came by our room with the full gear and sealed up our boxes so nicely that was totally beyond our expectation (please see attached picture). Really thumbs up for him! Then when we had to leave the hotel to head to Haneda, the hotel concierge took note of our 17 pieces of luggage and arrange a jumbo taxi for us. They also utilized FOUR bell staff to load up the vehicle in no time even though it is by no means an easy task. We just all stood by, without lifting a finger, totally awed by the professionalism and hospitality of this place I would call home in Tokyo!

Having been to The Peninsula in Hong Kong for dinner and observing the hotel, it really made me want to stay in one of their properties. Sadly it didn't live up to expectations! The reception staff are unfriendly, not particularly helpful and stoney faced. The room itself was very nice and had every mod con that you would expect. The lobby is were you have breakfast and is an uncomfortable place to sit and eat. It can get cold if you are near the door and is a very busy thoroughfare so not condusive to having a relaxed meal. The breakfast staff were shambolic - lot's of them and nobody knowing who has done what. The food served at breakfast was disappointing to say the least - if you order a bakery basket you are given 1 slice of toast, 1 croissant and 1 danish pastry per person and the orange juice is not freshly squeezed. As you can imagine it's not cheap to eat there and it feels like they are economising on what should be a substantial meal for the money you pay. The spa has nice facilities but again hugely expensive and very average treatments. Mark Holguin and Ema2006 - I agree with you you both!

Always outstanding and attentive service....Visually a big and rather corporate bland hotel but the deluxe rooms were spacious and comfortable. Very advanced bathrooms, especially the Toto toiletsGood views from the 17th floor breakfast room and a good buffet breakfast, especially from the omelette chef. Good pastries but pancakes tastelessThe swimming pool, all windows and views in the Tower, was exellent

What an amazing hotel. During check in, we were informed that we received a free upgrade and that they had confirmed my reservation with the restaurant Narisawa. The staff was very informative and incredibly nice. The room was absolutely beautiful! The room service was amazing and my boyfriend loved the hotels spa. On a side note, we were lucky enough to bump in Vera Wang in the elevator! The hotel stay was a delight from beginning to end. I would absolutely go back.
user_name:
Susana I
Stirling, New Jersey, United States

review_body: My overall stay was a disappointment with the Peninsula Tokyo. I think the hotel management is stretching themselves to compete as a full service hotel, while forgetting they are also a luxury hotel, and a small one at that. Why have wedding parties paraded through an already small lobby, ruining the already poor ambiance of the lobby restaurant? Keep your banquet business out of my dining experience!Housekeeping was poor at best. I found mold in the shower, out of reach, but clearly visible. Un replenished amenity items, I shower before dinner and would hope to have enough body shampoo for the next morning. And areas within the guest room floor hallways with obvious dust, seemingly going without cleaning for weeks.I will continue to stay a few stations away from my office under these conditions...

I loved the pool with the warm massage pool area. The buffet breakfast needs improvement but the Japanese set meal was ok. Rooms are clean and very spacious. It's good that they sepad elevators since many outsiders also go in and out of this hotel

Hotel is located in accessible areas with a good selection of restaurants, shops and attractions within a few minutes’ walk. Train station is accessible from hotel as well (accessible from basement). Rooms were well maintained, linen was good quality as well and extremely soft, sliding wooden doors and electronic curtains with big windows that overlook the city.The bathroom and amenities (including automated butt washer) were new and well looked after.Concierge weren’t as helpful but did the job on guiding us for most part. We were three adults.
user_name:
nasserfae
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed in the Peninsula with my family for two nights. We made the reservation directly through the hotel website. We arrived at 4.30pm and one of the two rooms we have booked and confirmed with the hotel, was not ready despite the fact that check in time is at 3pm. The staff at the front desk was unapologetic and told us that, unfortunately, we will have to wait. We complained and asked to talk to the manager, after half an hour, they found us a room which was slightly better than the ones we booked but the whole incident was very unpleasant and not what you need after travelling all day and paying more than $500 a night for a room. The hotel itself was nice but very expensive for what you get. Moreover, the quote you get from the hotel does not include the local taxes which add like 20% more to the price of the room. The staff, apart from the concierge and bell man, was not very helpful or friendly. The breakfast was rushed and served in the lobby. Despite the fact that the breakfast was included, they tried to charge us for the breakfast.On the whole, not a great experience. I have stayed at other hotels from the Peninsula chain, and this hotel was not what I expected from Peninsula.

This is a great hotel in Tokyo. The Rooms are enormous with a fantastic bathroom, a changing room and a very comfortable bedroom with living room facilities, from the sofa to the desk and the table next to the windows. I stayed at the peninsula 4 times in the last year and all the time it has been great. One side of the hotel rooms have the view on the imperial gardens which are at walking distance and a fantastic place where to walk or run. The only black spot is the breakfast area which is in the entrance of the hotel, but is really a minor and a subjective point.

Very nice room overlooking the park and the spa was great . Very expensive though at 700usd a night and breakfast is very weird , right in the lobby! Peters bar and restaurant was very good and great views over Tokyo . Fantastic staff , nice touches like a cold towel and bottle of water when they see you're returning to the hotel after a run

OK the hotel is far from cheap (the rooms without the park view are more "reasonably" priced) however the rooms are extremely comfortable and spacious - they each have a seating area, dressing room and superbly appointed bathroom with separate shower. Add to that an excellent location and superb service and what more do you need?

The rooms as other reviewers have already said many times are sophisticated and spacious but service is where this hotel really wins out. The staff are all incredibly polite and helpful. One of the reception staff even walked us to the subway station in order to smooth out directions. The room service food was fantastic especially the steamed shrimp dumplings. This place clearly has superb management and a highly motivated staff.

Whether on business or for pleasure, or both, the Peninsula Tokyo still exudes excellence in nearly all departments. As always the park view rooms will keep any business man or family alike extremely content, and with respect to the primary objective of all hotel rooms, the comfort level for sleeping is absolutely superb. Personally though, I feel the attention to detail is slipping, whether it be general information provided (incorrect) or the standard of service in the restaurants; removing unfinished drinks and bringing the bill when it was not requested are sure signs of poor service. The greatest disappointment is breakfast and I don't know why the hotel doesn't open up Peter for breakfast with those magnificent views and additional space. I skipped breakfast twice in 4 days due to a queue, that's the Peninsula's loss.

We loved the spacious & technology enhanced rooms at this hotel. Walking distance to Ginza & train/subway station. The restaurant on 24th floor, Peter, has great views and very good food. All of the staff spoke English & was very helpful. One note, everyone in the hotel is dressed up by American standards. No jests or visitors had jeans, caps or casual clothing. It was actually very refreshing to see how much pride they take in their appearance. Afternoon tea in the Lobby cafe was very nice. You can't get much better than this hotel.

Great location right in the middle of Ginza. Nice views of the imperial palace and park around although the bed was on a weird position plus there was a pillar right in the middle of the window and a block building right in front so there wasn't much to look at from the bed to be honest. Service was excellent and everyone spoke English. Nice breakfast but you need to keep asking for drinks etc, portions a bit stingy. Nice swimming pool and jacuzzi, great views from the terrace. Overall a great place to stay.

The Peninsula Hotel Tokyo is one of the best hotels I've ever stayed in and I've stayed in many of the top hotels in the world. The staff is here so customer service oriented. We arrived on a day where there was a typhoon so the hotel was short-staffed in some areas, such as housekeeping, so our room wasn't ready. After waiting an hour and having a meal in the lobby restaurant, the room still wasn't ready so the hotel upgraded us to an enormous suite on the 13th floor with two walls of windows, incredible views, and every comfort we could need. Oranges, rice crackers, and other food gifts were on the tables, magazines were plentiful, as were Oscar de la Renta bath amenities in both bathrooms, and even a telescope had been provided through which to view the city. The restaurants easily accommodated us even without reservations. This hotel is centrally located to shops, the subway, a short walk to the Shinkansen, and to sights like the fish market. I deserved to live permanently in the suite was so spacious and well-appointed with extremely comfortable furniture and eye-pleasing decor.

We loved this hotel. Large room, view over the Imperial Palace grounds. Super comfy bed. Nice bathroom. Very modern. Clean. Great service. Delicious room service breakfast.My only complaint was that someone stole the one nice souvenir I purchased (a hand carved leather wallet), so be sure to lock up everything. I've learned my lesson! Also, this location is very convenient.

So this is maybe my fourth or fifth review of the Peninsula Tokyo and it's still the best hotel for me in Tokyo. A lot of new inventory has cropped up and some of it is great but the Peninsula is still my favorite. Let's see if I can add anything different from the last review. First, the location is great. The location is diagonally across a little park and walking distance away from the heart of Ginza. Also, the staff remain fabulously trained on all levels. Japan in general is a super clean country but this hotel's housekeeping really takes it to a new level. I wear white socks in the room and they remain white for the whole stay. The room service is excellent and they keep expanding the menu to meet the international guest profiles. I don't think I can say anything negative. Here's a great story that kind of sums up it all up. Once, about 2-1/2 years ago, I asked that they stop delivering the newspaper so early in the morning, it comes about 4 am or so and I am a light sleeper and it woke me up to hear the valet box being opened and closed. Since then, I have NEVER had this problem again. That is really remarkable to anyone who stays in hotels often. Thank you staff of the Tokyo Peninsula!

This is a terrific hotel. The staff is terrific; the rooms are terrific, the location is terrific and it was a perfect experience. We stayed here for 8 days, and everything was spectacular. I particularly enjoyed the spa and the comfort level, on surpassed by the people-EVERYONE was so kind and accommodating. I would return without hesitation.
user_name:
ccharie
New York City, New York

review_body: Well located close to popular Ginza shopping area, also directly above Hibiya Station which is handy (take exit A6 and immediately escape the station for Peninsula luxury). Spa is good, no steam room I could find but good pool and gym. service very nice. Fitout excellent. Lower level floors don't have much outlook. Try to get a room looking over the park. Concierge very helpful.In summary a very good hotel.

Spent a couple of days in Tokyo in transition from a business trip to vacation for another week. Wanted to stay somewhere comfortable in Tokyo in a fairly central location. Chose The Peninsula, due to the reviews on Trip Advisor. I was not disappointed.First, the rooms are elegant and extremely practical. The rooms are essentially a suite of 3 rooms, living, dressing, bathroom. The furnishings and fixtures are of the highest quality and the decor is Japanese simple with luxury elegance and functionality. Colors are calming and peaceful, I felt like I was in a spa resort, not in the middle of Tokyo.Being a 5-star property, they had all of the required services and amenities you would need in such an establishment. I agree with one other reviewer, the Lobby is a little unusual. As you come through the revolving doors, an open-air restaurant is laid out on both side of the lobby, where you would imagine the front desk, etc., should be. Instead the front desk is past the restaurant just prior to the elevator banks. It isn't unattractive or a negative, but I found myself wanting a lounging area or bar area to sit around in when I wasn't in the room; a place to just relax, but in this case all of the space is used by the restaurant.Nonetheless, the hotel is located very centrally, with lots of things to do and places to eat or go within a block or less from the front door. The Ginza shopping area is literally out the door and two blocks up to the left. Very nice area. The main Tokyo station is also about a 15 minute walk from the hotel, which wasn't bad, even for a couch potato like me.All in all, this is a very special hotel, specifically because of the rooms, they are comfortable, practical and wonderfully relaxing. The technology in the room was amazing and welcomed, as I have a home automation system myself, so it was nice to have central control of the blinds, entertainment and lighting systems.Outside of the room, things are a little spread out and somewhat disconnected. The bar and another restaurant are on the 24th floor, which is a walk around the inside of the hotel to a separate bank of elevators, which to me was somewhat inconvenient; and, as mentioned, there were no comfort areas to just sit and relax.I also used the spa services, which were fantastic. Had a massage, which was a good start to my vacation. The Therapist was outstanding. The spa is very well appointed with a very nice sauna area that also has two hot/cold shower areas for dunking or being rained on in this case. it was very nice.Loved my stay.

When it comes to hotels, I sometimes think have reached the point in life where I am really not easily impressed anymore (read some of my other reviews and you will see what I mean!) but every now and again somewhere just blows you away, and that is what happened with The Peninsula Tokyo. The rooms are just outstanding; in fact it may well be the best hotel room my wife and I have ever stayed in.Sadly we only had a one night stay, our room was on the 22nd floor with great views over the Imperial Palace and grounds. The room was large and spacious, complete with sitting area. There was a great walk in robe area as well as an enormous bathroom with the shower and toilet neatly divided off behind frosted glass panels.The décor was outstanding, muted colours set off lots of use of wood, the main bedroom door was just the most amazing sliding wooden door. The technical gizmos in this room are equally amazing, there is a button for everything you can think of, and buttons for things you had not thought of – when was the last time you were in a hotel room that had a panel that included a display of outside temperature, wind speed and wind direction? I promise you, it’s true! There is also a printer/ fax machine provided.The rest of the hotel is architecturally quite interesting, one large void is cleverly put to use to display an interesting illuminated artwork. Décor is subtle, maybe a little too dark and muted for some tastes, but I liked it.We ate with friends in the ‘Peter’ restaurant on the 24th floor. It was expensive. but you are really paying for the ambiance and view, both of which are great. Service was impeccable of course, the one small minus we encountered were the arrangements for breakfast. The ground floor area used for breakfast is really not large enough to accommodate everybody at peak time. We went down at about 8.25am and it was full, we were asked to come back 15 minutes later, which we did and by then there was lots of space! Odd, but really only a small black mark given how great everything else was.Overall an outstanding hotel that totally gets my seal of approval.

For my 40th birthday, I decided to take a round the world trip, with Tokyo and the Peninsula Hotel as my first stop. Everything about the hotel experience was spectacular, particularly the hospitality from the staff.Several weeks prior to arrival I contacted the concierge team to ask for assistance with restaurant reservations, particularly for a 'special occasion' meal for my birthday. Once I had the right contact info, the team was very responsive, providing recommendations and suggestions in addition to the properties about which I had enquired. Reservations were secured, confirmations transmitted, and a nice packet of information was waiting on check-in with all the details: times, locations, maps, and descriptions.I was also pleasantly surprised that we received a room upgrade, and stayed in a beautiful suite with views of Hibiya Park, the Imperial Palace gardens, and adjacent neighborhood. There were even a selection of small-bite pastries and a bottle of wine waiting with a Happy Birthday message. Nice extra touches that made the stay that much more memorable.I love the technology integration of the Peninsula rooms, although I was disappointed not to have the ability (at least that I could discover) to dock my iPhone and access my own music through the room's speakers.As others have mentioned, the central location is very convenient from which to explore the city. The hotel was an easy taxi ride from Tokyo Station from which one can access Narita Express to the airport, and being right above the Hibiya Station subway stop the whole of the city is essentially at your doorstep. The Ginza and Marounuchi are easily explored on foot.We found the lobby breakfast to be very good - I particularly enjoyed the caramelized French Toast - as was lunch at Hei Fung Terrace. We wanted to try the bar at Peter for cocktails, but were turned away because it was full. That was about the only truly negative aspect of the stay, and did leave a bit of a bad impression mainly because there was no attempt at accommodation, simply a 'we're full' and a refusal to even be allowed to stand at the bar. It was just a very stark contrast to the "above and beyond" nature we encountered from the rest of the staff.
user_name:
crewguydc
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Staying at the Peninsula Hotel Tokyo is really an experience not to be missed. Although the hotel lobby is not very large or even considered as small, but by using it as the coffee shop and all day dining, it is also a perfect place to meet a visiting guests and friends. The croissants were really good. The rooms we stayed were just perfect. I like most, are the number of electric buttons to control the lights, the curtains and the creativity to transform the bathroom to a spa ambience, with the dimmed light and the right melody, you must try and stay at Peninsula Tokyo. I appreciate the designer who can plan all the buttons at the right places. Peninsula Tokyo, is again a hotel with a lots of convenience for transportation. The airport bus goes direct to the hotel, the Metro is right at the hotel, the JR train station is really very close by. No waiting time for taxi. Walking distance, you will be in the mecca of shopping for top branded products. But just walk toward Marunouchi and Tokyo station, you will find more variety for all classes. Or walk toward Ginza, the main street as well as the sidewalks. What you need is just the time, and some cash to enjoy it all. Try the swimming pool and spa, take rest and look at the Imperial Garden. You can close your eyes and dream you are at the palace…. About the service, I really admire the Omotenashi of Japan, service to the utmost….

overnight stay and it was wonderful. very convenient located in Hibiya, stones throw from Ginza.and right around the corner from Bic Camera Yurakucho.modern and elegant. everything is electronic, shutting curtains etc.

This hotel is fabulous, although you do pay for what you get. The room had TV and coffee facilities as well as a mini bar and safe, electric blinds and nets, electrically operated toilet in the huge bathroom, hair dryer and nail blower in the dressing room, in which were supplied dressing gowns and slippers.The Japanese breakfast was first class and the staff throughout the hotel were polite and helpful, and everywhere was exceptionally clean. The room I had did not have great views, but there are probably some that do.

Being that this was my first time to Tokyo, and we were arriving at the hotel from the long flight over, I wanted to stay a a really nice place. The Peninsula delivered. Our room was wonderful, comfortable, spacious, clean, and quiet. The pool/spa were very nice, great amenities. The upper floor bar was cool, the breakfast was delicious. It was pricey, but "when in Rome"... We took the train into Tokyo Station from the airport, then took a $7 cab the short distance to the hotel. We were able to walk the area, and hop on the metro as needed. Nice, clean area...it was a great stay. I think my only suggestion would be to have a bar/lounge at the lower/street level.

Admittedly I only passed through for a night, but during my first stay I found the Peninsula to be awkward and off-putting. The presence of the breakfast and tea lounge in the entranceway is an odd layout, and the hotel seemed overly somber in decor and lighting. I arrived late and left early, which in and of itself is not conducive to developing fully informed view. However, some months later I returned for a four-day stay (i.e. availability at other hotels over a weekend was limited) and I became a big fan. The Peninsula this time seemed to me an idyllic spot with a host of comforts I didn't previously appreciate. The rooms are spartan and modern (I had a junior suite with a nice sofa, work area) with easy to use conveniences for setting temperature, lighting and operating the shades. Plug outlets were universal, although I would have appreciated a plug next to the bed/nightstand for charging my phone nee alarm clock. The closet area is enormous with ample storage for unpacking and repacking. Services are moderately priced such as laundry, which is important to me as I dislike being nickled and dimed to death. The spa facility is truly first class with a wonderful steam/sauna facility and an ample pool for those who like to swim laps on business trips. Service is of course first class, and the location is ideal for both access to Ginza and other areas of the city. Although the food is quite good - as you would expect in any high-end hotel in Japan - I found the lack of variety in the menu disappointing. The room service is a bit short on traditional Japanese fare and lacks any asian foods (e.g. singapore noodles, a laksa or nasi goreng, perhaps a lo-mein dish or a bibimbap), while the Japanese breakfast is repetitive (i.e. same fish for three days in a row, though I am sure it was because it was in season). The western options are a bit unimaginative (i.e. I recall the international trifecta of hotel food: caesar and/or cobb salad, bolognese pasta dish and a burger among other expected fare). With such high quality establishments nearby, I wouldn't expect the hotel to stake its reputation too much on its kitchen, but with 3 am jet lag, I would have liked some more choice. But overall I find the Peninsula to be a wonderful establishment with all of the conveniences and comforts you should expect. It is both modern and classy, the staff is helpful and communicative and the services are wonderful.

Stayed for 1 night at the end of my Tokyo trip in a Deluxe room. Staff were polite and welcoming but a little surprised that they did not call me by my correct title when they checked me in. Was taken up to my room by a lovely gentlemen who carefully explained all the many techno gizmos in the room. Room was well furnished, a lovely large space, comfy sofa, big flat screen TV, separate dressing room, and lavish bathroom with separate shower and small TV (albeit a tad disappointing that I could only find Japanese channels) But it was the little extras which really made the room, more bits than any room I have ever stayed in, a traditional tea pot, headed note paper and colorful postcards, lovely bath products, an extensive amenities kit, a laundry/newspaper chute, even a peninsula cocktail stirrer!Pool and Jacuzzi was a real highlight for me especially as the room has a great view.Got a deal that included breakfast - chose Japanese breakfast which was delicious and beautifully presented.Top tip - no need to pay high end mini bar prices. Just across the road is a 7-11 which is well stocked with all the snacks and beverages (including wine and beer) that a person could wish for.

Short break without the kids...Pros:- Fantastic service- Fantastic room- Fantastic location (if you want to be in Ginza...
