Great connection to various lines)- Next to the Imperial Park (nice for a run... and upon my return, the hotel had a towel and bottle of water waiting for me at the enterance)- Lots of good Japanese food nearby... The small restaurants by the train tracks offer a good glimpse of local lifestyleCons:- The Peter bar was a tad disappointing... If only they had an outdoor area

My husband and I took a short trip to Tokyo for his 32nd birthday last May. Knowing we would not have too much time to see and do (and eat!) as much as possible, I trusted the Peninsula to point us in the right direction and provide a comfortable resting spot in between adventures.The Peninsula did not disappoint. They were able to get us a last minute table at Narisawa and also booked us into an exclusive sushi joint where we were the only westerners in the restaurant-- definitely the best sushi we ever had. They also gave us a ride to my husband's dinner in the house Rolls Royce. Our room was lovely and quiet and a nice escape from the chaos of Tokyo and the bathroom had all the bells and whistles you expect from a 5* resort in Asia. The service was superb from the front desk who were always happy to help retrieve jewelry from the safe to the spa attendants who were always ready with water to the concierge who always knew the best way to get us around the city. I should mention that one valet in the garage went out of his way to help us find the subway station when he realized we had made a wrong turn.Finally, for those of you planning a visit-- do not miss the small but excellent thalassotherapy pool in the spa.

Great place to stay for our first visit to Tokyo. Central location, right above a subway stop, beautiful, new, great service, and great views. One weird thing about the hotel is its entry lobby; we couldn't find the reception desk upon entering the hotel for the first time. The main focus of the lobby is the lobby restaurant (which is packed for afternoon tea), and this huge odd sculpture. For such a nice hotel, staff wore polo knit shirts, which (not that it impacted our stay at all!) seemed a little casual. Service was great. Rooms were beautiful, plush, and modern with high tech features and controls. We went to the Peter bar upstairs twice, and the views were beautiful (though, in my opinion, not quite as beautiful as those from the Mandarin's bar and top floors!). We could certainly highly recommend this as an amazing stay, but when we visited the Mandarin for dinner and drinks, we had a bit of hotel envy. As westerners who wanted what we imagined to be a Tokyo feel, the Mandarin seemed to fit the vibe a bit more... As you would expect with a Peninsula, the hotel has a bit more of a business vibe.
user_name:
Worktravelgal
New York City, New York

review_body: Understated, elegant design but, as with all truly exceptional hotels, it is the team that makes the difference. Helpful, genuinely friendly and all consummate professionals. And with a great sense of humor to boot! Lovely big bathroom and dressing room, rooms comfy and roomy. Perfect location. Can't recommend highly enough.

I love this hotel. Maybe one of the best ones I have ever stayed at in my life. Service is consistently incredible - I have been here several times for business. Everyone is friendly and helpful, which is so valuable when you are staying in a foreign country. The rooms are amazing. Huge, and with a walk-in closet I wish I had at home. You also have an in-room coffee/tea maker that works great, and a sitting area in front of the TV. The bed is super comfy. I also liked the automated panels for everything: lights, curtains, temperature, etc. The bathroom is really great (which sounds weird, but you will appreciate when you get there). Also, great location in Ginza and excellent concierge service. Rooms with Imperial Palace views are great.

This is my favorite hotel in the world. You can see from my profile I get around, but that superlative also includes other great hotels which I haven't reviewed, such as the Four Seasons HK, the Pierre in NYC, Park Hyatt Zurich (my #2) and others around the world. Even amongst steep competition, the Penn TKY stands alone.The rooms are extraordinary. Beautifully designed with wood and marble accents and sporting ample room by any standards, they feature an element lacking in standard luxe rooms around the world - a sofa. And not some straight back banquette or settee, but an honest-to-goodness sink into the cushions sofa. No comfy desk chair or chaise can compare with the simple pleasure of plopping down on a real sofa at the end of the day and watching a wacky Japanese game show. This alone is reason to pick the Penn over nearly every other hotel. If you have stayed at Peninsulas, you may be familiar with their exceptional, even extraordinary, control layout. Lights, temp, shades, are all controlled by easily understood switches which are in the exact places you would look for them. Outside temp and humidity is helpfully displayed in both the closet and desk areas, The bedside phone (phone*s*, actually, since there is one on each side) controls a few key items, and has a very simple alarm function. The bathroom TV and speakerphone are all controlled from both the sink area AND the tub. The walk-in closet is something to behold. Two hanging bars divided by a vanity (even a nail dryer...) with a safe you don't need to bend to get into, and a valet box into which you can dump your laundry for overnight pickup. All genius.The bathroom is gorgeous in beige marble, with a massive tub, ample shower, two sinks with plenty of space. And, brace yourself, a Toto washlet. These are standard across Japan (JAL has even installed them in Business Class Lavatories), but they will change your life. Way more practical than a bidet, and also more effective. The lid rises to greet you in the middle of the dark, dark night, beckoning you to a pre-warmed seat, and sports a odor-reducing function that actually works. I know of at least three friends who, after their Penninsula experience, have installed these in their homes. Service is exceptional, and in Japan it is tip-free. Housekeeping somehow manages to provide ice at all timesRoom service is usurous, of course, but excellent and prompt. Breakfast will run you about $25 an egg, but that's the breaks in luxe hotels. There is a 7/11 across the street if you want to save money.Location is perfect. The rooms overlook some section of the Imperial Palace or adjacent park, and the shops and restaurants of Ginza are just a few blocks away.The overall hotel is, predictably, beautiful. The public spaces are impressive and calming, and the top floor steakhouse/bar has a commanding view of the palace and skyline. The pool/spa/gym are stunning and well-staffed.Nits? Ok, if you force me to name some: no breakfast buffet, the shower door is so flush to the floor that the bathmat always gets caught, I'm too fat for the robes. Also, and this is a nit I have to pick with Japan in general, getting decaf coffee is next to impossible. The in-room Lavazza machine (genius!) is stocked nightly with both espresso and grand cafe pods, but decaf has to be ordered up from housekeeping. OK, so they show up in 2 minutes with a big smile, but i wish they would have made a note on my housekeeping form so I could get it during the regular cleaning cycle. Not a one of these little complaints amounts to anything other than a minor frustration.I know everyone wants to have their "Lost in Translation" moment at the PH across town, but for me, I'll have a drink at the PH New York bar, but I'll never leave the Peninsula.

This is the nicest hotel I've ever stayed in. The room size was excellent, the bathroom luxuriousand the closet was huge. The staff was extremely helpful and courteous. We enjoyed going down to the lower level and watching the bakers at work. It is very convenient to everything.

I always look forward to returning to this hotel. The rooms are huge and service is impeccable. Location for shopping and business also excellent. Center of Ginza is about 3 blocks away from the back the hotel. The hotel is also directly connected to Ginza underground station. Bedroom - Huge walk in closet fitted with shoe valet closet AND dryer for nails! What more do you need haha!! Bathroom has a large bathtub, I always appreciate the heated toilet seats. I also love how the amenities are hidden in the drawers, it makes everything so tidy. There is a seating area with large tv and a small table and a work desk with different types of sockets, it's so nice and comfortable I was tempted to just stay in the room and watch tv! The bed is comfortable although the pillows are a bit soft, the light and air con remote control and telephone system by the bed are motion sensored so you can adjust anything even in the dark! Our room had a view of the palace so it was really nice. The hotel lobby really doesn't do the hotel justice, it's small but the rooms are so big. The lobby lounge and Peter bar (great views) are excessively expensive but I guess this is Tokyo afterall. Breakfast is just alright. The pool is pretty big with nice views and the spa was pretty good (typical great Japanese service). They also have jogging routes around the park in front or around the palace, really nice if you are jetlagged. The hotel is connected to the Ginza underground station, you can directly take the lift down to the station which was super convenient. The Airport Limousine bus goes directly to the hotel and has a frequent schedule, however, the schedule going from hotel to Narita Airport (takes about 1.5 hours rather than the usual 1 hour as the limousine bus stops at other hotels as well) is not always every hour so you need to check and buy tickets from the transportation desk in advance. Concierge staff speaks excellent English and gave great restaurant recommendations. Reception staff always came running to help with my shopping bags, which was helpful as the elevators are always quite busy. I can't wait to return!

The Peninsula is within walking distance from Ginza shopping area. There is a passage to Hibiya subway station at the basement level of the hotel so there is no need to walk on the street during rainy or hot days.Our room is luxuriously appointed, we were especially impressed by the size of the walk in closet & the placement of the switches. All the staffs are professional & efficient. My husband had a wonderful stay at The Peninsula & will definitely be back on our next visit to Tokyo.

Love the service, the location, the gadgets, room size, bath, everything. Not to mention the automatic lift heated toilet seats and their famous lock box valet service. Exceptional, but can someone show me how to use that coffee machine?

The Peninsula has the best location of all luxury hotels of Tokyo, at intersecting point of 3 subway stations. Very spacious room well equipped, with walk-in wardrobe and large bath with twin sinks. Service is good, though as everywhere in Japan spoken English could be more fluent. Hotel amenities are complete, and the Nespresso in room is useful. The top floor bar, Peter, is beautiful. Modern Art Deco style of décor, design very functional. One of my favourite hotels of Tokyo if I want to be in Chiyoda for business, or for Ginza shopping.

I stayed here with a big group of people. My previous friend and I were upgraded to a suite. The room had a walk in closet, dresser, tub with TV, 2 sinks and was really spacious. But for $800 a night, i wouldn't expect anything less.

I had a great stay at the peninsula tokyo, compared with the other hotels i stayed in, this is one of the best. our room was so spacious and luxurious, everything that you need, including nespresso machine, TV in bathroom, comfortable bed and living area. i also loved the style and architecture of the hotel, very modern and arty, but not tacky. my only gripe would be that the pool was arther small and our room reaked of smoke even though we had requested for a non smoking. other than that, everything was wonderful. especially the location, it is walking distance to ginza, close enough but not in the center which makes it more exclusive.

Unbelievably great rooms, very generous sizes with perfect aircon, bed, facilities and a wonderful oversized bathroom with huge shower and bath, with TV and radio too. Understated in the best of ways, very clean and very comfortable, could happily spend hours just chilling in the rooms. Lovely lobby and a great place for breakfast; English, American and Japanese options all available. The highlight of the hotel is probably the staff. Super attentive, they can do anything quickly and efficiently the instant you ask, and the multiple concierges even had a little bit of humour which is unusual for Japanese when speaking English. Very resourceful, and willing to do anything for you.A major bonus about the Pen is the location too. On the edge of Ginza, there is everything from high end stores (anything from GAP to Gucci is far better than any branch you will find in the world), and useful stores such as Tokyo Hands and the wonderful Itoya stationery store. One thing that doesn't seem to be touted at all and is incredibly useful is that the hotel is actually connected to Ginza underground station; just a trip down to the basement from the lift by your room and you are straight into the station, which is perfect if you're trying to avoid taxis as Tokyo can get very pricey. Top floor bar Peter's (a bit of an ego trip - in true Penisula style the manager has a lot of influence on the hotel) is absolutely fabulous for a night cap with great cocktails, Veuve on tap and smoking (which is actually illegal on the streets immediately surrounding the hotel). The view isn't anything on the Park Hyatt - which is so worth a visit - but the bar is a cosier one than any of the other major hotels in the city. Absolutely fab stay for what was a very quick two nights, would not return anywhere else on a second trip to Tokyo! The Pen is not flashy, and doesn't have quite the same Lost in Translation aura as many of the others, but its subtlety and perfectness gives it an atmosphere of it's own.Stayed 16th - 19th August, Room 1313, many thanks to all of the staff.

We stayed here for 7 nights and had a wonderful experience. Everything about staying here was faultless including great service, a spacious and luxurious room, a great breakfast buffet which was only available during the week we were there. We liked their practice of adding a 15% service charge to the room bill so that there's no tipping of any hotel staff. The concierge desk was very helpful and the bell desk arranged for shipment of several of our bags. Several subway lines are accessed through the hotel basement and the JR train lines are only a block away. The hotel is very expensive; but given the size of the rooms, the high level of service, snd the overall level of luxury, you receive real value for your money. We would highly recommend this hotel and would stay there again.

I paid over £350 for one night and to be fair I wasn't blown away by the room but I'm just picky. Huge room by Japanese standards, comfiest beds ever, sofa, large TV etc everything you'd expect from a 5*. Extremely clean. Room service guy was very accommodating, couldn't do enough for you, but not very strong English speaker. Had a look around the rest of the hotel which was decent. Breakfast was included in my package - lovely pancakes and bacon for breakfast. Check out the patisserie floor -1 and see the staff at work.The best thing about this stay was the bathroom! Massive with such a powerful bath where I altered the lighting, watched TV and had music playing. Multitasking bathtime - you can't beat it.

Stayed in Aug 2008.This should be one of the best city hotel in Tokyo.The room was quite spacious and bathroom was very luxurious with two bowls basin.The toilette was separated from the bathtub which was preferred by the Japanese people.Electronics and facilities were all the latest model and was great design. Simple, modern designed rooms. The thing they could do better is the lobby area. Breakfast are served in the open restaurant right next to the lobby and felt like you are eating in the lobby. More privacy should be considered. They do have a great Japanese breakfast.Walking distance to Ginza.

The best hotel! I have stayed here for nine nights in Tokyo. The room is neat, clean and big compared to the standard hotels in Japan. There are separate sections for the bathroom, the dressing room and the bedroom. The bed is super comfy, with all the softest linen. Big wide screen tv is hung on the wall, good position to watch in bed and at the couch. Everything is good except a little thing which is about the bathroom kits, ie. shower gel, shampoo, conditioner and body lotion. I am not sure whether it is a policy of the hotel or not that the housekeeping staff will not fill out the bathroom kits if there are about half bottles left. Unlike the Four Seasons Hotel, they add on these kits everyday for two persons. The shower room is very nice, especially the rain shower. The water pressure is strong enough to call it a "Real Rain Shower". The Bath tub is also very comfortable and well-designed to soak your exhausted body from the tiring day. While soaking in the tub, one can watch tv as well. There are two wash basins, opposited to each other for a couple, one can put his/her own toiletries on his/her own side freely. No need to share the tiny sink space. These also are the good thing that I love about this hotel. Everyday, there will be fruits e.g. Apples, grape and sunkist oranges provided on the coffee table with a dish, the utensils and knapkin. Every night the ice bucket is filled. There is a Lavazza coffee machine with the coffee beans as well as Japanese green tea abd Japanese tea pot and teacups. Another good reason to choose the Peninsula hotel is the location, everything is nearby, only 5-10 minutes walk to the Ginza area,There is a path from the hotel connecting to the Metro, no need to walk to the road to get on the subway. Besides the bathroom kits, everything is perfect.

We stayed twice for a number nights over the past few weeks and both times we thoroughly enjoyed our stay. The rooms at the Peninsula are amongst the largest in Tokyo, ideal if you're traveling with young children.Its location in Chiyoda is very central, walking distance to Ginza for great shopping and dining and a short taxi drive from Tokyo Station and other areas in central Tokyo, so a great base to explore the city from.Besides being very spacious, both times our rooms offered nice views over the city, had block-out curtains and no noise, which is just what we needed traveling in from different time zones! Although it's a business hotel, the hotel caters very well to children. Upon arrival we had lots of welcome kids amenities including toys, kids bathroom slippers, a children's robe, little step for the bathroom as well as juice and cookies, which made our daughter feel very welcome and special. The first time we stayed we had a roll-away bed for her, the second time they used the sofa as the third bed. A nice gesture was that housekeeping would fold away the bed in the morning and come back late afternoon to make it up again, leaving you to enjoy the lounge area of your room during the day.The rooms are very high tech from the toilets to the light switches, curtains and room controls and it all works! The room even had a nail dryer, haven't seen that before! The bathroom was large, with two separate sinks, bath and rain shower. Our room also had a large dressing room, perfect to store suitcases and unpack, especially when traveling with children.The service in the hotel was excellent and very friendly. The concierge assisted us with train bookings, tickets, restaurant recommendations, and check-in and out was smooth and efficient. The hotel has a good gym, a nice spa and an indoor pool (open for children until 6pm, not sure why this is though).My only comment is the breakfast service. We had breakfast included in our room rate, but only for 2 people although our daughter stayed with us in our room which was odd and impractical. The lobby lounge is the place for a la carte breakfast and although the food is very nice, the service was slow most mornings and breakfast choices limited as the breakfasts were set menus with little flexibility. On some days the restaurant on the 2nd floor is open for breakfast as well (buffet style) but the service there was very slow and most mornings we had to ask five or six times for our coffees which then arrived after we had finished most of our meal. The buffet selection is limited compared to other high end luxury hotels.We loved our stay both times and would definitely come back to the Peninsula when we're next in Tokyo.

What I like about Peninsula Tokyo:- Big rooms with a mini lounge with sofa - Great views of the Imperial Palace- Walking distance to Ginza incl the food stalls under the railroad- HUGE bathrooms- All the electronic room control gadgets- Nice heated pool- With an extra bed we could fit 2 adults + 2 young kids- connected to subwayWhat I don't like: - Limited choice of restaurants, altho not a complain as there are plenty around- Beds not as comfortable as I would like - No kids facilites

Lovely hotel with amazing bar restaurant on the top floor with views over the whole of Tokyo. I loved staying at this hotel particularly while on business. Luxurious in every way with the bonus of a 'to die for' spa. Staff were very friendly and had great recommendations to help us enjoy Tokyo while we had some time off from work. Great spot right across the road from Imperial Palace.

The Peninsula Tokyo came with a heady reputation and having stayed at other Peninsulas around Asia, much was expected, sadly it was lacking.That is not to say it is not a good hotel, but it is not a GREAT one and with Peninusla you sometimes expect that. The rooms are ok but not great, the bar is ok but not great, service is ok but not great and the lobby is pretty mediocre. Location wise it is first class for either business or leisure with instant access to Ginza but other than that, really not as good as I would have hoped for sorry.

I stayed here for business in late July and had a wonderful time. The staff was incredibly helpful in organizing my short time in Tokyo - I wish I could have stayed longer! Upon check-in, Daisuke walked me to my room to show me how everything "worked" (yes, there was enough technology that warranted this!). Unfortunately the room key did not open the door the first few times. While otherwise frustrating, Daisuke offered to send up a free drink of my choice because he knew I was ordering room service for dinner (after arriving late in Tokyo my first night) - it was very appreciated and I loved the gesture.My room was beautiful with a huge bathroom (I love when they include TV's in there!) and of course, a technologically advanced toilet a la Tokyo.The spa / gym was very nice and well appointed, I'm sorry I didn't have time to use the pools.Room service was great and on time (their a la carte breakfast offerings were affordable considering most room service prices), and the in room espresso machine / tea was so convenient.I can't wait to stay here on my next trip to Tokyo!

The Peninsula's great reputation is not let down by the service and amenities at this conveniently located hotel set amongst parks in the Chiyoda District within a 10 minute stroll of Tokyo Central Station, a few minutes to Ginza and a step away from the Imperial Palace and Gardens.The hotel is located a step out from Hibiya subway station and, diagonally across the road, Hibiya Park is a beautiful place for a walk.The rooms are spacious and packed full of amenities to the highest quality (although the hot water machine for tea or coffee did not produce very hot water; a minor let down!).Service, from check-in, through room service to check-out was excellent and timely.The pool and spa, spotlessly clean as with most things in Japan, provided a great area to relax or exercise.All-in-all an excellent stopping or starting hotel for a trip to Japan.

Stayed here for 2 nights to end my 7 days japan trip. The rooms are big and comfortable. Like the big bathroom. Everything you expect from Pen hotel is there. Live band playing at the lobby almost all day on. Had dinner there also. Was too tired to walk after the long shopping trip. The hotel is at Ginza, just walk around 5 mins and you are at the central of all the branded shops in Ginza. No need to take any subway.

Spent three nights at this property and was so impressed with the Concierge services. They communicated beutifully with us prior to our stay, arranged for baseball tickets, provided nice commentary on restaurants we chose, and helped us make train reservations. Service was above and beyond what we expected. Room was also beautiful, spacious...and oh, those bathrooms! Would definitely recommend this property.

The service, the large smartly designed room, the spa & swimming pool..... We could not have asked for a more perfect hotel in Tokyo. From the moment you arrive, you are enveloped in luxury and treated with the utmost respect and kindness. I would not hesitate to recommend this lovely hotel!

We enjoyed the big room,friendly staff and the high quality of service during our stay in Tokyo Peninsula. The hotel is very conveniently located on Hibiya station and very close to Ginza, a prime shopping district.

The deluxe hotel room has ample space with a walk-in wardrobe, a bathroom with both shower cubicle and bathtub. The room also comes with 2 beds, a sofa and a small dining table. As expected for Tokyo there is modern amenities including a DVD player, fax machine and full gadget toilet! Service was excellent as they accommodated my request for early morning breakfast due to Ramadan. It would have been better if the hotel can cater to specific Muslim food requirements i.e. halal meat.The hotel is located close to the Imperial Palace but the room I had was facing an office block, so no view of the palace. There is staircase connecting the hotel directly to the Tokyo Metro train lines, which is quite convenient. Since I was on a business trip, the hotel is close to most of my meeting venues around Tokyo.

This hotel is incredibly luxurious and we were in love the minute we arrived.We had an entry level room type but we were not disappointed with it's size. Our bedroom was very large and opened to the lounge room with pod-coffee machine. Very large windows afforded us lovely views.Toiletries were the best we'd ever seen and there were even toiletries for our son (18mo). A cot was provided which we set by the dressing area - which meant there was a large solid sliding door separating him from us. Lighting off to the bathroom could be set low enough that this did not wake him if we needed to go to the bathroom.The hotel provided us a babysitter so we could go out.There is a tv and touch button for everything - including at the dressing area for you to have your nails dried.Breakfast was the only thing we were not thrilled about. Yes it is silver service however it is a la carte and you can't vary the choice. I do not eat egg (allergies) so requested a switch. No matter my argument at our departure/ check out I was charged handsomly for this. As it's not a buffet, had i not had the switched item I would have been hungry so I did not feel that this was fair and am still a bit annoyed about it considering how much we spent to stay at this hotel. Staff were wonderful with my son and provided drawing paper for him at breakfast.The pool area is magnificent and enormous and quiet whenever I went there. The lady in charge of goggles and hair caps was the sweetest most wonderful lady in service I think I've ever seen and I really wanted to take her home with me!

We stayed for 3 nights in July and from our welcome to our departure you couldn't ask for better facilities or service. Great is about the best descriptive term for our stay. The hotel is beautifully decorated in a way that seems to make you relax and feel comfortable as soon as you walk in. It is not a huge hotel lobby, but the decor and staff makes it very comfortable. The rooms are beautifully appointed with more gadgets and buttons that we have ever experienced, and very large by Tokyo standards. We didn't want to leave it on occasions. The staff were the most polite, respectful, kind and helpful that I have experienced, not just one or two, but all of them, I can't recall one that wasn't. Now that's amazing. Nothing was a problem, and the consierge and bell staff were great with advice and assistance given freely, joyously and they seemed to enjoy the challenge and interaction. The location is great with access to the Ginza, shopping, and plenty of bars and restaurants, and above the Metro which gives access to the rest of Tokyo. If you want a treat in Tokyo, then you can't beat the Peninsula Tokyo.

The Peninsula Tokyo service is perfect and everything you would expect from a 5 star hotel. One of the best concierges I have ever encountered anywhere . The deluxe rooms are rather large and have ample space in the living area, bathroom and dressing room- it looks exactly like the website. The automatic gadgets are convenient and touches like the mailbox for newspapers, dry cleaning, notes are well thought out. However, the only downside is the furniture which is not impressive
user_name:
Costanza1975
New York City, New York

review_body: The only downside of this hotel is the price I must say.Paid ¥30,000 per night and that's already at a discounted rate.But the location is within walking distance to the stores of Ginza,food clothes beauty products electronics you name it.The rooms are spacious with its own walk in wardrobe and its bathroom is equipped with shower,bath tub,two sinks and a cubicle for toilet.Perfect !

stayed in an excellent deluxe room with fantastic views, location is ideal for tourists. Skybar was good. we did not test the signature restaurant Peter but atmosphere seemed quite "techy". A little disappointed in the small gym, pool overall still okay. Spa did not have availability (but it was a Sunday). breakfast quality also fine but ridiculously few seats resulting in a wait irrespective of time of day. for this room price, you are surprised to be asked to wait for 10-15mins. during weekdays, breakfast is only served in the lobby which is poor. breakfast also got charged to our room despite our room rate including breakfast. concierge service was mixed (two different staff one excellent one not). overall enjoyable and good option but none off the feel cool factor like the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo or similar.

My husband and I were choosing among the Peninsula, Park Hyatt and Ritz-Carlton at Roppongi, and my Japanese colleagues said we should go with the Peninsula based off its location. I'm so glad we did; it's SO convenient to everything, from the subway station nextdoor, to Ginza shopping a short walk down the street, to the Imperial Palace Gardens just across the way. The rooms are ENORMOUS - especially in a city like Tokyo, where I've stayed in rooms (at decent hotels) comparable to closets - and come with every luxury amenity available. Service was incredibly helpful, from arranging our airport shuttle bus to letting me check out at 9pm and even shower at the spa before departing on my redeye flight. My only complaint is that the Peninsula seems to have spoiled me for all subsequent hotel stays.

The Peninsula Tokyo is top notch. Service, location, cleanliness of the rooms. All are terrific. We had adjoining suites and the rooms were spacious comfortable and clean. The pool was beautiful, the staff was helpful and helped us secure a tour guide, and the view from our room was great. Cant say enough about the location as well. Close to shopping, overlooking historical sites and parks. Just superb.

Exceptional and superb rooms make this a memorable hotel. The rooms are huge, my standard room consisted of an entrance lobby, a walk in dressing room, a bathroom with shower, bath and two sinks, and a massive bedroom split into seating area and bed and equipped with a king size bed (made to look like a single bed by the scale of the room), and three seat sofa in front of the 50in TV and hifi system. Just about every cupboard has a surprise, from a printer and scanner, to a top notch coffee machine. I was lucky enough to have a room on a high floor with a dawn view of the Imperial Palace. Very nice. Being Japan technology has pride of place, and this includes the electric toilet, which frightened the life out of me in the middle of the night by automatically raising the toilet seat as I walked towards it. I thought place was haunted. The lobby was a disappointment; arriving on foot though the hotel rear entrance I couldn't find the reception. The lobby also doubles as a coffee shop, and the source of the second disappointment, the evening meal. My crab sandwich was bland and unexceptional, and accompanied by a plateful of over cooked, nearly cold and greasy chips. A good thing I don't eat chips. Sleep in and eat out.

My husband and I stayed at the Peninsula in Tokyo for 6 nights in May 2013.Service- The service is perfect and everything you would expect from a 5 star hotel. One of the best concierges I have ever encountered anywhere is Misako who totally understood us and gave us absolutely perfect suggestions on what to do and where to eat. Public Areas- We were not at all impressed with the lobby, which like so many of the other reviewers, we found oddly shaped and awkward. There is no grand entrance and you do not feel like you are walking into a beautiful hotel like what the Peninsula should be. The pool area is also in need of an update although the service there was perfect and it has beautiful views. Room- The size of the deluxe room is huge and has ample space in the living area, bathroom and dressing room- it looks exactly like the website. The automatic gadgets are convenient and touches like the mailbox for newspapers, dry cleaning, notes are well thought out. However, the furnishings of the room, meaning the actual chairs and tables, were kind of basic.Food- We had drinks at the Peter bar one night and the expense was worth the fun atmosphere and amazing views. We had breakfast in the lobby restaurant because it was included in our room rate, but I would not otherwise spend the money to eat there since I would rate the food only slightly better than decent. We ordered an extra latte one morning and we were charged $14 plus the service charges, which is a bit insane. If you care about restaurant atmosphere, do not have lunch or dinner at the lobby restaurant because if you are going to pay that much, there are plenty of other amazing restaurants to go to- i.e. we went to Argent Aso and Yamato Tapanyaki which were both close and superb.Location- was perfect. I do not think that there is any one hotel that will be close to everything you will end up doing in Tokyo, but the Peninsula is well situated for walking to places like Ginza shopping and restaurants and the metro and trains are very easily accessible.

This hotel must have the best location in Tokyo, within easy walking distance of Ginza and Tokyo station. Rooms are great (space, quality). Pool nothing to write home about. After one bad experience with one receptionist, all other staff we fantastic and the manager went out of his way to correct the mistakes of aforementioned receptionist. The sign of a great customer service mindset. Concierge brilliant with advice and support. Only niggle is that the hotel insists it knows what you want for breakfast more than you do! Most hotels worldwide, including 5 and 6 stars I stay in for work, have acknowledged breakfast buffet is the way to go. Peninsula gives you the limited choice of 6 sets. Overall great stay, very good value for Tokyo. Firmly recommended.

I stay at the Peninsula on nearly every visit to Tokyo, always on business. The rooms are exceptional -- large, well organized, with every comfort. Great temperature control, espresso machine in the room, nice table to sit at by the picture window with the view overlooking the Imperial Palace grounds, separate very spacious dressing room, large well organized bathroom. For space and getting all the details right in the hotel room, this is the best hotel I've stayed at for business anywhere in the world. The location is also great -- a short walk to the Palace grounds, the Marunouchi business district, and Ginza. The service is also excellent. The only downsides to the hotel are 1) the lobby, which is dominated by a mediocre restaurant that is always busy, and 2) the limited selection of quality restaurants, in contrast to the Imperial or the Okura, for example. But who wants to eat in a hotel anyway when in Tokyo, the greatest dining city in the world.

One of the best hotels I have ever stayed. Everything you could think of and want in a hotel room is there for you. There are many buttons to control from your light settings, to your curtains, to the humidity of your room. The room service was twice a day, the beddings were changed daily. The room was truly beautifully designed and decorated. I loved the bathroom and the separate dressing room, both are huge. The beddings are high fine quality, it felt pampered.My daughter got her bath robe of her own size, she was pleased.The location was unbeatable, walking distance to Ginza and the hotel has direct access to the subway.The swimming pool was a big welcome to our daughter, we used it every day for the 5 days we stayed there. The rule was children could use the pool until 6pm, again I do not understand the rational behind it but grateful there is a pool that we could use.The service was as good ( or could better)as expected for the hotel in this category. The highlight of the hotel was the room and location, other aspects seemed to be less impressive, but not faulty.Some elements in the front lobby are beautiful, but it is not functional. It has no seating and no space for waiting for check-in or just hang out. The reception area was small and sometimes felt crowded, but some what efficient.The breakfast was average and the service was slow. We had to wait for about 10-15 mins for a table for the first a couple days. We had to ask for cream for our coffee, and had to ask for multiple times. We were taking time for our breakfast, so it didn't bother us much, but things like this should happen for the hotel of this level.We also had dinner in the hotel for one evening, and felt the same for the quality and service -- average and slow.We feel in love with Japan, Japanese are most graceful and polite in the world, we will definitely come back to visit it again. Will we stay here again, maybe for the room and location, but not a slum dunk. We had a lunch in Mondrian Oriental, the service was impeccable and the food was exceptional, and the the 38th floor reception area was open, and beautiful.

The Peninsula Hotel in Tokyo is amazing. When you first walk in there is a huge chandelier that is very welcoming. There is not really a lobby and there is not much sitting area either because the lobby is a more like a restaurant. Dispite the lobby almost everything else is perfect. We had purchased the deluxe room witch is the second lowest class and it was sooooooo amazing. The hotel had thought of every little detail to the room. The closet was more like another room because it had a desk in it where you can do your makeup. But what i found the most interesting was the bathroom toilet. I had counted 35 boutons on the wall in the little room with the toilet and majority of them were for the toilet. For the first two days for breakfast we went to the chinese restaurant because for the weekend there was a buffet going on in there. The waiters were still very friendly but the buffet did not have that much of a choice and the service was not quite there.The breakfast in the lobby, well at least in my opinion, was a lot better. There is a connection to the underground subway witch is very usefull. The exit is A6.Overall this was an amazing experience at this hotel and I would recommend it for couples and families with children.

Stayed for four nights as part of a longer holiday. The service was exceptional from start to finish, really made to feel genuinely welcome. The rooms feel very new and modern, and the phrase "thought of everything" could have been invented for this hotel - the rooms have a button for absolutely everything but still look elegant, refined and luxurious. Nice views of the Imperial Palace gardens too. Special mention for the concierge who came up with with last minute but fantastic dinner reservations at Kawamura (Kobe beef Teppanyaki) and Tempura Masa, both of which I would recommend highly. The hotel sits above a well connected subway station and another in the high-end shopping district of Ginza is 5mins walk which makes getting about easier. Also dined at the hotel's Chinese restaurant which is beautifully decorated although it was fairly empty so a little lacking in atmosphere though I couldn't fault the food. Didn't try the lobby bar/bistro as it seemed a little bustling as others have mentioned but the bar on the top floor is calmer. I was grateful for a very early check-in being made possible after a long flight although the hotel wasn't able to grant a late check-out as they were busy - but the spa was a very luxurious place to hang out for a couple of hours with a good pool and spotless (albeit small) changing facilities. Overall one of the finest city hotels I've stayed in - right up there with my favourite, the Oriental in Bangkok - and I wouldn't hesitate to return.

We stayed at the Peninsula as our first stop in a 40-day round the world trip. The Peninsula Hotel is top notch. The attention to detail in all activities (welcome, housekeeping, health/spa, concierge) are all exceptional. This hotel features an amazing 6th floor pool that overlooks the Imperial Palace grounds. The rooms are very comfortable and the views are nice. Breakfasts can be pricey. We only stayed for 3 nights, but could have stayed a month. A great start to our trip! Photos and more are available from our travel site review: http://roundtheworldtravelers.com/?p=1094

This hotel is fantastic. Excellent service, beautiful rooms (actually the entire hotel is beautiful), and the location is also fantastic. Easy to walk around for hours in the area. We were able to get around all of Tokyo very easily from the hotel, as it has its own entrance to a metro station. Its close to the fish market, too! So, if you're willing to brave the 4am wakeup to go see the auction, at least you wont have to travel too far to get there! I'm a big fan of the Peninsula chain in general, but the Tokyo branch takes the cake. Worth mentioning that the rooms don't have the best views of the city, but also not the worst. When we booked, we had breakfast included in our rate, and it was a pretty good breakfast with quite a few options (including Japanese breakfast). I wouldn't want to stay anywhere else in Tokyo. This hotel epitomises luxury!

Fantastic service and large rooms at this hotel near Tokyo station. It's a bit of a walk to Tokyo station if you have luggage so take a cab, if you do, but the hotel is also connected to the train station. The rooms don't have great views (I checked out other family member's rooms), but they are not bad either. The ones we stayed in looked out to the city so we were looking at a bunch of fancy office buildings. The standard rooms are large. It has a sitting area with own coffee machine and very comfortable beds. The bathroom is large and also has large closet which comes in handy for a longer stay.Service is fantastic, the staff's English is great.The coffee at the lobby was something like $15 at the foreign exchange rate back then, which I thought was ridiculous, but it is Japan after all. We had Chinese food at the restaurant which was quite average for the price. Might as well try the restaurants outside as you will be close to many great restaurants in the Yurakucho area.Would recommend this hotel to friends.

The Peninsula in Tokyo is a spectacular hotel in a great location. It is within easy walking distance of the Ginza, Hibiya Park, the Imperial Palace and the Tsukiji Fish Market and within 2-3 min of various subway stops. I can highly recommend this hotel for a short or long stay in Tokyo.The rooms are terrific. We had a standard room and still it was incredibly luxurious with a lovely seating area with large flat screen tv, a king size bed with high-end linens and a well designed bathroom with bath and shower and a separate toilet area. You really could not ask for more in terms of the room. I can only imagine and dream of what the rooms with a great view over the park would be like! Similarly the staff were helpful and friendly and welcoming. My only issue concerns the breakfast. Of course like many top hotels in Tokyo breakfast is rather expensive but as they do not have a buffet option you can only order from menu. The quality was excellent but the portions were modest and so at the price I would say it did not meet my expectations. So I would say 5* for the hotel but 4* for the breakfast, mostly due to the portions.We did enjoy a drink on the top floor bar/restaurant and the view was spectacular. Be warned that smoking is permitted so for those now unaccustomed to smoke when indoors that is certainly not so appealing. We went early enough that it was not crowded and so it was not a big hassle but I would not want to go there at peak hours.

We stayed at the Peninsula Hotel for 4 nights while visiting Tokyo. We travel a lot and have stayed at many wonderful hotels, but none can compare to the Peninsula. The staff are amazing! Many of them speak English, so communication was easy when trying to find directions, plan an outing to the Kabuki theatre, making dining reservations, etc... It is perfectly located, near the Imperial Palace. The rooms are immaculately clean and spacious. As a travel agent, I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone visiting Tokyo.

The location is great, access is convenient, rooms are spacious and clean and the service is generally excellent. The rooms in particular are practically laid out, spacious, and you have controls everywhere to adjust things from lights to curtains to the humidity of the room.The only advice I would offer is that you order room service an hour before you want to eat. I ordered what I thought to be a simple breakfast or scrambled eggs and toast and it took at least 40 mins. I was told 20-30 mins and when I called to chase up on the order I was told that i was on its way.... not be so, and I had to cancel the order and check out. This was very disappointing given its a 5 star hotel and 2 eggs and a toast really shouldnt have taken that long. Not a big deal, and thats why I maintain a 4 star rating, but when you get to this level of hotel quality, everything counts and a mishap like this ends up counting a lot.

We have stayed in this hotel with my husband 8 night during our Japan trip in May. We have also seen other hotels in the area and in other parts of town, but decided to stay here all our stay. Hotel in beautiful, service is great, prices are reasonable and you are 5 min walk to Ginza Street. Imperial palace is just across the street too. Is very centrally located, but at the same time its quite quiet area with not much traffic. Tsukiji market is also just 10 min walk. Breakfast is quite limited as its ala card, but food is very good. That probably the only thing I would change - bigger option of food for breakfast or self service.We also visited pool and spa and it was great relax after hectic day visiting sites. Highly recommended!

When we were planning this trip to Japan we were looking at western hotels in Tokyo and just for a joke we decided to see how much the Peninsula would cost. There was a special on and the room we booked was only a tiny bit more expensive than the Marriott and Hyatt rooms and, boy, what a difference. This hotel is located on the edge of the Ginza a few blocks from the Imperial Gardens. The metro lines run in the basement if you don't feel like going outside, giving you access to the entire city. Then there is the hotel. Our room was on the 23rd floor with a view into Ginza and was fascinating day or night. The room was large, comfortable with a couch to watch TV from as well as an espresso machine and iron tea pot. The breakfast included with the room had items to suit people from around the world. The baked goods and pastries were better than some we've had in Paris and came from their own pastry shop (you can watch them make the things through windows on the hall). I can't say enough about the level of service, the cleanliness, the care in decoration of the public areas and the rooms. Just about everything in this hotel was perfect. If you are planning a trip to Tokyo make sure you check the prices and available rooms here. In short, probably the best hotel we've ever stayed in in a lively and exciting location in a fascinating and high energy city.

My husband had business in tokyo and we decided to tag along and bring the children. First the room was amazing and wonderful for our family, we had a corner suite with and adjoining room. Lots of space and privacy for all! The staff was wonderful with the children and the concierge staff did amazing at scheduling and suggesting apropiate activities. the location in the center of Ginza with views of the palace was perfect. A walk to most attractions

The Peninsula Hotel in Tokyo is the hotel for us. It has outstanding service, large clean and comfortable rooms, excellent restaurants, pool, gym and SPA.We had the deluxe king suite and and the adjoining grand deluxe twin room. The rooms are exactly as pictured in the hotel photo gallery. The service is probably the best we've seen. We arrived early for check in and were comp'd the afternoon tea because our rooms were not ready. Have you ever heard of such thing? Most other hotels just make the guest wait. The afternoon tea, btw, was excellent with many choices. Prices for the rooms (for the amenities and the square footage) is significantly less than other major cities such as Paris, London, New York.

My family enjoyed a fabulous stay at the Peninsula hotel in Tokyo. The hotel was everything we imagined and more, impeccable in every respect! The rooms were spacious with every convenience to hand, the staff couldn't have been more helpful and the breakfast was amazing. The location of the hotel is fantastic overlooking the Imperial Palace and grounds, amazing views. We would have no hesitation in recommending the Peninsula Hotel and look forward to staying there again.

It's New, Very High Tech. Good location, near The Imperial Hotel. The rooms were neat, lots of buttons for everything. The only down side is there is always a line. To check in, to have lunch and to get a drink at "Peter The Bar". The Staff is very nice. One night we were turned away from "The Bar" so went over to The Imperial Hotel . No problem there. The Internet was fast and free. We booked in with AmEx so the late check out was nice. It was a bit tricky using The Airport Bus at the airport. The wait was going to be long so we took the Airport Bus to the Tokyo Train Station and got a Cab, there were men at the drop off to help. Next time we will go back to The Imperial Hotel.

We just got back from the Peninsula Tokyo Hotel. The hotel is impeccable in every way. We got a deluxe room. It was spacious, and marvellously appointed. Everything had electronic switches commands, the service was swift and impeccable, and the location convenient. We travel the world extensively, and found this hotel to be one of the best we have ever stayed with.

To get straight to the point, the rooms at the Peninsula are among the most luxurious and technology laden that we have ever stayed in, anywhere. Unless you are planning to grow tomatoes, I'm not really sure that you need to be able to control the humidity (as well as the temperature of course) in your room but maybe I'm missing something. Similarly, the wind direction and speed are not data points we ordinarily need to consider when heading out of the room but perhaps, if you have a particularly large hat for example, this information might be of some use to you. To be fair, some of the buttons do add a certain something to your experience - the mood lighting in all the rooms and the 'Spa' setting in the bathroom being particularly memorable examples - but goodness knows what would happen if there ever was a power cut.Even without the superfluous buttons, the rooms would rank as among the nicest we have ever stayed in and if it was purely for the standard of accomodation, I would not hesitate giving the Peninsula 5 stars. It also scores highly for location, being on a prime spot within walking distance of some great neighbourhoods for eating and shopping, or simply for a relaxing stroll around the Imperial Palace. Oh and the Service is great too.So what lets it down albeit just a little bit? Well, we were a little bit disappointed by the public areas, with both the cramped lobby area (packing them in for Afternoon Tea) and rather under-whelming 'Peter' the bar at the top of the building higher on cost than then they were in either space or aesthetic appeal. It's almost as if all the focus was on the incredible rooms and the other bits were added on as something of an afterthought. We've stayed at The Peninsula in Hong Kong in the past and I get that the lobby is supposed to emulate it's illustrious big brother but somehow I don't think it works here. The bar was also underwhelming compared, say, to the chic space and eye-popping views at the Mandarin Oriental.In summary, I'm really glad we stayed here and experienced the incredible room but as a place to spend some time in (outside the comfort of your own four walls) we would personally think twice about returning. I've already mentioned the place that would probably edge it and it's a close call between what are probably the best hotels in Tokyo and amongst the very best in the world. In many ways the Peninsula is a decision for the head, while the Mandarin Oriental is one for the heart.

An awesome hotel! Perfect place to start our Japan trip. Amazingly well thought out room plan with a separate dressing area, living area, comfortable beds. Can't say enough about how delightful our stay was. The housekeeping staff was discrete and the room was spotless. They actually wiped down and dried the shower to pristine condition as part of our turndown service. Totally unnecessary but showed off just how clean and well maintained the hotel is generally. Room service food (big salad!) was terrific.

Without question one of the finest hotels I've ever had the pleasure of staying ..cannot fault it at all ..the metro is under the hotel so access to everything is more than easy. The staff here are sublime, the concierge service is second to none. The location is wonderful and close to the ginza shopping area and restaurants. Yes it's highly priced but I often believe you get what you pay for and in this case it surpassed all my expectations .

This hotels seems to aim for perfection and then add some more. To start with it is a great hotel with spacious, luxurious rooms. Everything works the way it should be, or better. Everything that should be there, is there. Or more. The Peninsula always offers a bit more than expected.Service is sublime. Again they offer more than expected. When asking for directions the help doesn't point at a map, they walk you outside and put you in the right direction. When fetching a car from the garage, they also program the sat nav.The location is very convenient. It is a 2 or 3 minute walk to Ginza, a major shopping area. Whatever you want to buy or do, it's near. The hotel has its own subway station, which is very convenient. By car the hotel is easy to reach and the highway isn't too far.After four nights I could only find two points to improve: there's not a lot of stations on the television (only 33) and there's not a single vegetarian dish on the menu (but there are many good restaurants nearby that do serve vegetarian meals).

Stayed here twice over a week in Japan on business. On the plus side the property is very well located; the lobby and common parts great; rooms are very large and nicely furnished; food is well presented (albeit expensive for what it was). However, I found the service inconsistent. On the first occasion is was excellent; but the second time, I had a problem with the room they allocated me: i.e. it was a smoking room which they had "re-configured" for the night of my stay as a non smoking one (i.e. simply sprayed the room with air freshener despite having being used as a smoking room for the previous 5 years!). This was amateurish and It took some convincing to get them to change it - despite my clear preference on initial booking. For a hotel in this price bracket, this is not acceptable.

We decided to stay here for extra bucks for our 3 nights honeymoon in Tokyo, but it is all worth all the penny. The location is fantastic, connected to Hibiya train station, which is very convenient. The room is spacious, super large for a Japan size. The quality of the bedding was first class. Enjoyed the walk in wardrobe that is as big as any other hotel room in Japan.They have a heated swimming pool with very clean water (It was on December during our trip, so it was nice to swim during these times). Used this facilities and so surprised they even lend the google as well as the cap during swimming. Plenty of bottled water to give away, and very lavish changing room and shower.Service was also very great. Helped us a lot in finding ways to go to Hakone, and chose a great hotel to stay there. Able to leave our luggage while we had a short trip to other cities in Japan.Overall, this hotel has no fault. Even they found out we are on our honeymoon, and the send us a bottle of champagne and pralines to enjoy the night away.Fantastic

This hotel is exactly what you expect from a Peninsula property. The rooms are just as fabulous as they look in website photos. The furnishings are modern with a very traditional flavor. The walk-in closet and bathroom are so roomy and comfortable you won't want to check out. The main room is very nicely designed, with a desk area, a dining area, a lounging area, and the bed all comfortably arranged. The upstairs restaurant, (Jeffrey's?) had great service, great food, and great views of the Palace. The lobby restaurant is where your wife has always wanted to have afternoon tea. Frankly, I expect this hotel to be a step below the Park Hyatt, and instead I rate it a step above the Park Hyatt (which I also loved).I don't really have any negatives for this hotel. It's not cheap, but I would say it's not overpriced. The biggest downside, and I'm actually not kidding about this, is if you choose this hotel you might need to book a longer stay, because you'll really want to spend at least a day just enjoying the hotel.

This is a beautiful hotel with outstanding service. Our room was stunning with views of the Imperial Palace. The room was sleek and well appointed and I cannot speak highly enough of the overall commitment to service. The Peninsula is in a great area and is itself one of the more interesting architectural buildings in Tokyo. Great business and leisure hotel.

I'm compelled to write this review, because even two weeks after an amazing week in Tokyo, I'm still thinking about it! If you like incredible service you MUST stay here. The rooms are lovely, great view, huge walk in dressing room, the most amazing bathroom. I literally want to build a house around their bathroom.. smart toilets are the way to go.. and theirs was the best I've seen. But it was truly the concierge that made this an unforgettable vacation. I simply showed up, they did everything from making reservations for every meal (impossible to get michelin star sushi places to tiny restaurants serving amazing shabu shabu or Ramen), to arranging for sumo wrestling viewing. We just had to mention something and it was done. They even kept track of where I had eaten so I could try a new cuisine everytime. They practically planned our whole vacation! The location is perfect too. Great shopping within walking distance in Ginza.. and the subway is right under the hotel so you can get around. Loved the little "valet box' to deliver messages to the room... lots of little touches like this to make your life easier. Food is rather overpriced and just ok. The breakfast buffet was the best deal..we ate at the chinese restaurant and it was good not great. They have a nice little cafe in the basement with amazing pudding and pastries and savories... much more reasonable. If I go back to Tokyo, I wouldn't stay anywhere else...
user_name:
nytravelbabe
New York City, New York

review_body: A neat hotel in the heart of town. Typically Japanese service standards (high) and very pleasant surroundings. The staff were polite, helpful, discreet. Breakfast was the only meal we had and it was good. The rooms are pleasant, if rather too intruded by outside neon lights. You can avoid that with the several blinds choices they have...

Beautiful hotel with amazing artwork. The rooms were spacious, with a separate dressing area and bathroom. (The toilet sautés when you enter the bathroom. No kidding.) Great location for shopping, and it's right above the subway which makes it very convenient, and the concierge can help you if you need it to negotiate the trains.

This is a wonderful hotel from the beginning to the end! Ginza shopping is at your doorstep and Hibiya station immediately by the hotel makes the location unbeatable. Maranouchi is only minutes away and is extremely picturesque! Very latge rooms with walkin closet and huge bathrooms. Toilet is state of the art, other nice touches include nail dryer (!) and how they deliver the morning newpapers to a little box in room. Everything is very discrete but very efficient. Only "criticism" would be there wasnt much of a view from our room on 8/F and Concierge can be a little more friendly and personable.

Few complaints really, although perhaps lacking a little of the style of some other Peninsula hotels (e.g. the lobby feels small for a Peninsula, concierge service a little slow). But in terms of rooms and location its right up there. Really fantastic room - big, comfy, huge bathroom, slept incredibly well. Location is great, easy to get anywhere, shops galore in Ginza on your doorstep and the Imperial Palace is great for your morning run. Nice pool also. Very happy.

Great location, absolutely amazing big perfect rooms in a town where space is at a big premium. Service extremely friendly. Real indoor pool with a view and outside balcony. Only slight drawback the lobby which is small and sometimes crowded.Peninsula is usually great but with Japanese attention to details it is perfect. I will be back.

The Peninsula is in a very grown up area of Tokyo, overlooking the Imperial Palace and close to the Ginza/Maronuchi upmarket shopping area. The hotel is medium height (24 floors) with a neat area in fron with cloud pruned pine trees. The lobby area is a bit disappointing as it houses an all day restaurant (there are always people eating) and there is no where much to sit if you need to. Our rooms, however, were amazing with enormous bathrooms with a separate loo, lovely shower, a double ended bath, tv set in to the wall, two basins and so on. All marble and very well fitted. We also had a separate dressing room with dressing table and large hanging rails. In the bedroom the temperature controls were amazing with humidity control as well as heat and air con. Floor to ceiling blinds lower at the touch of a button. I could go on.Service in the hotel was top notch too. My only and very small complaint is that there is no easily accessible bar for meeting other members of the family, you had to go down in one lift and then up in another to the top floor. I imagine this is to deter the public from coming in and hanging around, but we really needed somewhere easy near the lobby to meet our friends before heading out.

This was my first stay at the Peninsula but not, I hope, my last. Although I am no stranger to luxury hotels, I have never had a room like this one. It was more like a suite that included a living room, dining area, built-in desk and entertainment console. Best of all were the huge bathroom and walk-in closet/dressing room, both of which were incredibly spacious and luxurious. Not only did the closet/dressing room have tons of space for both suitcases and clothes, but it had a dressing table where you could do your hair and makeup. In the bathroom, the expected Toto toilet was the ultra-deluxe model that raises and lowers its lid as you enter the glass booth, flushes automatically and not only washes your nether regions but dries them with warm air. I loved the double sinks, fabulous bathtub (with a beautiful limestone wall behind it) and huge shower. The only trouble with the shower was that water leaked out the door a bit. My package came with breakfast, which turned out to be any breakfast I wanted--including the delicious 4,200 yen full Japanese or Western breakfast. Delicious! The staff was friendly, professional and capable of anything--including sending my suitcase to another hotel while I traveled around on the Shinkansen.My only complaint was the spa, which though luxurious was overpriced and offered the most useless shiatsu I've ever had at (by far) the most exorbitant price. While I enjoyed chatting in Japanese with the masseuse, she did not begin to get the knots out. I had to go to Kyoto for a real shiatsu by a real professional, at less than half the price.

Married mid-age couple visiting Japan, we organised the holiday by ourselves and choosed Peninsula for the excellent reviews we found an tripadvsor. It was the first hotel during our trip and we were happy with our choice. It is a quality 5-star hotel in shopping and business district targeting mainly business travelers, the large room (with separate dressing) was very useful when carrying luggage for 3-weeks holiday. As traveller coming from Europe, do not expect however an unique unbelievable experience full of exotism (comparable with Shangri-la or Mandarin Oriental in Singapour, Hong Kong or Bangkok, for instance). The place is confortable, unbelievable clean, efficient service - we were somehow disappointed not to find too much "Japanese soul" inside.The breakfast is very basic - there are no real restaurants, just the one organised in the lobby. It is the standard for Tokyo center (hotels located in general-purpose towers, buildings are not designed as hotels, the only common spaces are the lobby, the floor with sauna, eventually the bar on the last floor etc.)The major part of the ground floor is rented to luxury "international" shops (not much interest - brands you never heard about, Italian-French-Swiss flavour quite expensive, nothing Japanese) - reminds me about Moscow.Surprisingly the lobby restaurant is always full - looks like it is a trendy place for business lunch during the week, and for rich family "dejeuner" on the weekend.Location is very convenient, direct acces (hotel underground) to Hibyia metro line and 2 min pleasant walk to Yarakucho JR station. Less than 1000 Yen (8€) by taxi to Tokyo station for Shinkansen, NEX trains etc. Plenty of restaurants around (direction to Ginza) however be careful the vaste majority close at 11pm and dont accept new customers after 10pm. Finding a place to eat becomes critical after 10pm, as restaurants are located inside the towers and dont display at street level the time of "last order" (or display in Japanese only, it is the same), means you will enter 10 buildings looking for a place to eat, it is disaster. There is a 24x7 fastfood close to hotel, we do not recommend.In conclusion, perfect base to start Tokyo discovery - no bad surprise and no stress (except issue with late dinner). Have to admit Tokyo is not a place for tourists looking for extravaganza and low-price shopping Asian-style, but for those eager to discover a sofisticated world comparable (if not superior) to Western Europe. You have to adapt to local rules, do not expect that everything is organised to satisfy your needs as a tourist.

Stayed here for 3 nights over a busy Easter long weekend.Despite full occupancy and the busy traffic the hotel and its staff never lost its composure. Everything was efficient and all service delivered with sincerity.I booked the superior room. Though that this the cheapest room, it was spacious and comfortable.Hotel is in a perfect location for me within walking distance to Ginza and the metro is just right below the hotel. Places like roppingi and ueno are on the same line.I took the hotel's bicycle and it was a treat to cycle around the palace area. Highly recommend. Had lunch at Hei Fung Terrace and enjoyed great dim sum.Unlike the grand Hyatt...the pool is free for guests and was not crowded on both occasions I visited.

This was my second stay at the Peninsula Tokyo, and again I was blown away. This hotel has replaced the Ritz Carlton Tokyo (located in Midtown/Roppongi.....also an excellent hotel with equally good service and a great location) as my go-to hotel when I'm in Tokyo. We were traveling as a big family with two adults and our children (from 4 to 12). The coner suite with a connecting room was beyond our budget, so we opted for two Deluxe Rooms right next door to each other. Both rooms were 54 sq m / 579 sq ft and generous in size, contined a a large bathroom with double sinks, a nice deep bathtub and a eparately enclosed shower stall. The changing room/wardrobe, which was directly opposite the bathroom, was huge! I'd say it was almost the same size as the bathroom and could have easily fit a roll-in bed. In one room we had a King-sized bed, and in the other we had two twins. The bedrooms are well laid-out with a loveseat sofa and a small coffe table in front of the television, and a single chair placed perpendicular to the sofa. The sofa can be converted into a bed, which was what we had asked for each night when they turned down the room. There is also a separate dining/writing table by the window with two seats on either side. THe A/C, lighting, curtain controls, and humidity settings (yes, you can control the humidity of the room!!) are all easily controlled by the night table, and even a technology-averse guy like me was able to figure out the controls easily.As I was traveling with small children, and as I had great experiences with kids at previous Peninsula hotels in the past, I asked called down to see if they had anything for children. They asked for the kids' ages, and soon enough housekeeping was ringing the doorbell and handing over kids' sized bathrobes, slippers, coloring books, etc. In the afternoon (when we weren't out exploring nearby Ginza/Marunouchi/Hibiya) they called and asked if they could deliver the kids' treats. Housekeeping brought cookies, snacks, juice, and icing pens to let the little ones "decorate" their own cookies. At turndown there was even a small stuffed animal for each child. These little details not only made my little girls ecstatic but really impressed me as well.Because the hotel is so conveniently located, and we were with wanted to hit all our favorite restaurants in Tokyo, we didn't get a chance to try many of the restaurants in the hotel. The gym is small and lacks a good view of the exterior (it would have been great to run or bike with a view of the Imperial Palace) but the indoor pool is quite nice. I would suspect that the treadmills don't get used much since a run around the Palace would be so much nicer.The service was simply amazing. The Japanese just get it, even though tipping is not customary nor expected. The combination of the Japanese hospitality and service culture with the attention to detail of the Peninsula will impress the most difficult guests. One small detail that consistently impresses me is that after my run every morning, the door-woman (is this a word?) would seem to anticipate my arrival and have a fresh towel and bottle of water ready for me as she opened the front door to welcome me back to the hotel. I'm not sure how they do it.....maybe they have staff outside looking out for guests returning to the hotel from their morning run.If I had to point to one negative thing about this hotel it's the lack of public space. If one were planing to meet someone in the lobby, there's really nowhere to wait. There isn't a quiet corner that one could sit and read or people-watch. The tables of the lobby cafe stretch out almost to the front door and makes the entrance a bit crowded, and it would have been nice if the designers had allocated some open space and quiet seating areas. In summary, this understated but well designed hotel is a great choice for the business traveler or a family on a holiday. Highly recommended.

So we have stayed at this hotel over the last 8 years or so numerous times. This is by far our favorite hotel in Tokyo. They have made some improvements since the last time we stayed last year. Now all the rooms have card keys. Also, they have reverted to Fiji water again as an amenity water. Yay! Also the spa underwent some renovations, nothing major but they also now offer oxygen facials and some other newer treatments.It's also nice to see the same staff over the years which seems to be a Peninsula trademark. Also, the same GM who is excellent at running the hotel.

The Peninsula, Tokyo greets you with white glove service from the moment you enter this splendid building until you leave. For me, it was all about the excellent service. Yes, the room was very spacious, the bathroom magnificently appointed and the hotel facilities, first rate. But at every turn, there was someone who was prepared to go way out of their way to be of service. The concierge made sure that our taxi drivers were provided with not only the address of our destination, but a printed map as well. The lobby restaurant was always bustling with a mixture of business and leisure guests and the staff always managed to accomodate us somehow. The quirky bar/restaurant atop the hotel provided great views of the city and services there were, again, perfect. The Peninsula is now my hotel of choice when visiting Tokyo. It is pricy but if you can afford it, it is worth every penny.

Having just read "The Tub"s review / oeuvre, it is with a large degree of trepidation that I add my own meagre contribution...Essentially The Peninsula is a high class hotel which charges to match its level of comfort and service. One would expect no less. On arrival we were upgraded to a spledid room with a bathroom bigger than the bedroom of the Mitsui Garden where we stayed in Kyoto. It had two vanity units, illuminated shaving mirror, television, subdued lighting controls, a huge shower cubicle and wonderful loo- the lid rose automatically as you entered and it offered the usual Japanese toilet comforts, you'll know what they are if you visit any toilet in Japan (barring the squat types).There was also a separate walk-in dressing room.The a la carte breakfast which in our case was inclusive was very good. The buffet in the Chinese restaurant was a big disappointment with empty serving dishes and no bread. What food there was was indifferent. Avoid.All staff were excellent and attentive. Would stay again at the drop of a hat if I could afford it!

Stayed here for the cherry blossom week when the hotel was completely full. This did not affect the experience very much- concierge and reception staff were very efficient. We had a great spacious room with a walk in wardrobe, a Japanese toilet and high tech controls for window blinds and air con. The hotel feels very modern and luxurious and the location is great. The spa and pool are beautiful and very relaxing. The Peter bar has good views and ok cocktails. The only issue was the breakfast. Usually one can only have a la carte breakfast at the lobby, which has limited choice and is pretty close to the front door, so it's quite cold and not really the best place to linger with a newspaper. While we were there the hotel opened their Chinese restaurant for a buffet breakfast (just for the cherry blossom week so this may account for service issues). The restaurant is pretty but breakfast selection was limited and we had to wait for our green tea to be delivered for 20-30 minutes every morning. For some reason hot drink orders were quite problematic for the staff. The restaurant also had exactly the same music every morning - small issue but it became quite annoying as we stayed for 6 nights. Overall would recommend.

We stayed at the Peninsula Tokyo for 5 days in late March 2013. We chose it because of the strong reputation of Peninsula hotels, the high TripAdvisor ranking and generally positive reviews, and the location, which appeared to be the most congenial for our purposes.Although, on the whole, we were not disappointed, I'm afraid the Peninsula Tokyo did not quite match our (admittedly high) expectations. If I were to come to Tokyo again (and I rather hope I do, as it is a wonderful city), I will most probably stay elsewhere, despite the Peninsula's many positives.LocationThe Peninsula is, in my view, the best situated luxury hotel in Tokyo. It is located at the very top of of Yurakucho St, at the corner with Hibiya Park and the Imperial Palace Gardens. Essentially it sits right at the border between the Ginza shopping district and the Marumouchi district (a mixture of office buildings and high-end boutiques, this entire neighbourhood appears to have undergone a complete revitalisation recently and is really quite pleasantly elegant). You're a short taxi ride (the basic Y710 fare) from pretty much anywhere in Ginza (including the Tsukiji fish market) and Marumouchi (including Tokyo Station). Out of similarly located luxury hotels, the Shangri-La, Four Seasons, Mandarin Oriental, and Palace hotels are all located deeper in Marumouchi, nearer (if not adjacent to) Tokyo Station, whilst the Conrad is at the very bottom end of Ginza, with views of Tokyo bay. None therefore match the 'fulcrum' location of the Peninsula. Well, other than perhaps the enormous Imperial Palace, which is a couple of blocks away, but it's looking a bit like a communist conference hall now.Conveniently, there is a dedicated hotel entrance to the Hibiya metro station (which is on, I think, three different lines, the Chiyoda, the Hibiya and some other I can't quite remember), from where you can get pretty much everywhere. Which brings me to an important point. Given the ubiquity and all-round-awesomeness of the Tokyo Metro, as well as the ease with which one can find a taxi in Tokyo (albeit at a price, not dissimilar to certain European cities), I found that location is, in fact, less of an issue than I initially envisaged.Communal SpacesThe general décor of the public spaces is, of course, elegant and understated, though, if it were me choosing this type of things (and it's probably a good thing that it isn't), I would not have opted for the 'rust' colour scheme.
