However, and this is a big however, a big big however, the principal feature of the public spaces is that, well, there aren't really any. You come in and you get straight into the Lobby restaurant (so close is the restaurant to the door that, if you sit at one of the outer tables, you get a not entirely pleasant draft when the non-revolving doors are open). The Lobby restaurant is split in the middle by a short corridor with round banquettie-ish couches on either side of the corridor (as you can see from many of the user pictures). You walk through that and the (small) Reception is on you left. Once you've walked past that you're at the lifts, with another series of very small couches facing the lifts. And that's it. Other than the round couches which split the restaurants and the small couches facing the lifts, there is literally nowhere to sit (other than at a table in the Lobby restaurant). This, I think, is a serious issue. Not serious as in Second World War serious. Perhaps a bit less than that. But serious nonetheless. It really discourages mingling/loitering, something which a hotel reception should probably not do. I do realise that the restaurant-in-the-middle-of-the-lobby thing may well be a Peninsula trademark (following on from the Hong Kong original) but, partly because of the relative small size of the Tokyo lobby and partly because, well, it's a pretty daft idea, it really doesn't translate well here.Also, the rust colour scheme, coupled with the (admittedly very nice) wood panelling, which you can see in the picture, and the lack of natural light, makes the Lobby a rather dark place. Works rather well at night, with lovely soft lightnings, but it really isn't great during the day (particularly, I would imagine, on a hot summer day).All this boggles the mind a bit. They had an entire skyscraper to play around with from scratch and this is what they have come up with – a small, dark reception with nowhere to sit in. I may not be Norman Foster (or, who knows, maybe I am) but I really don't think that's good enough.RestaurantsLobby restaurant: as above, this basically IS the lobby. Ate there for breakfast everyday, a la carte. Breakfast was excellent (though, at Y3,800 a mini bank robbery; thankfully it was 'included' in the room rate).Peter restaurant/bar: on the 24th floor. Didn't eat there (well, other than some small bites at the bar, which were rather pleasant). Very stark décor. Probably not my cup of tea. The bar faces Ginza/Hibiya Park, whilst the restaurant proper faces the much nicer Imperial Palace Gardens. Chinese restaurant on the 2nd floor. Didn't eat there either, I'm afraid. As it was high season, it was open for breakfast (as a buffet) during our stay, to relieve the pressure off the Lobby restaurant. Tried to go once but there was a queue. As a matter of principle, I don't queue for buffets. There is no doubting I have very strange principles, but I find buffets bring out the worst in people and, if one can, one should avoid them. Certainly one should never queue for them.That's it, I think. Unless I missed something, which is most likely.RoomsAside from the quite unpleasant stench of smoke, on which I will elaborate further down (my, I seem to be writing a book here; and for what, a hotel. What a sad life I lead; though probably not as sad as yours if you're still reading), the rooms are top-notch.Very spacious, with living area (at least the category we had, may have been a 'deluxe' or whatever excuse they use to charge you more money). Also bright with floor to ceiling windows overlooking Ginza/Hibiya Park (I suspect those on high floors on the opposite side of the building have a better view facing the Imperial Palace Gardens). More technology than in the Starship Enterprise, including: panels from which you can electronically control everything from the room temperature, to the TV, to the curtains, to the lights; large flat screen TV; telephones everywhere; fax/printer/scanner; sockets in European/UK/US-Japanese format; top of the range Toto washlet (including the dryer function which is just awesome); and, I kid you not, a 'nail dryer'. No dedicated iPod dock but you can request a cable with which you can connect your mp3 player to the TV which works just fine. Also, free internet access (the only one out of the four hotels we stayed at in Japan that offered it). Again, I'm still in two minds about the ubiquitous rust colour scheme, particularly for the carpet, as, like the reception area, it seemed to make the room a bit stuffy, despite the very large windows, though, arguably, that is a matter of taste.ServiceGenerally, the service was impeccable, as you would expect when combining Peninsula and Japanese in the same service formula. In particular, with one minor exception (see below), the Concierge staff were absolutely brilliant in securing restaurant reservations including at hard-to-get places like Sukobayashi Jiro in Ginza and Quintessence in Minato (the former probably the most unpleasant – and per minute by far most expensive – dining experiences in my life and the latter one of the more pleasant).However, during the course of the five days a few glitches did come up.Firstly, there was almost inevitably a short queue at reception. Despite being the spoilt brat that I time, I did not mind this too much (understanding that this was a busy period), particularly as the reception staff would deal with this very professionally and open new 'positions' whenever additional staff was available. However, again, I couldn't help but think that a bigger reception counter (and area generally) would have been more suitable for a hotel of this size (and calibre).Secondly, I believe the room category I had booked was meant to have a 'Park View'. Knowing that the hotel was located opposite the Imperial Palace Gardens, I expected 'Park View' to mean view of the Imperial Palace Gardens. Instead, what I got was 70% view of Ginza and 30% view of Hibiya Park. Now, I suppose this still qualifies as 'Park View', yet I couldn't help but feel a little bit cheated. But then again, I feel cheated very easily.Thirdly, I had booked a non-smoking room. At check-in, they advised that, whilst the room was on a smoking floor, it was, in fact, a non-smoking room. Fine, I said (I'm try to limit the amounts of hissy-fits I throw these days; emphasis on 'try'). Of course, when I walked into the room, it reeked of smoke (thankfully, it was cigar smoke, which, strangely, I find less toxic). I called reception (still trying not to throw a hissy-fit) asking for a different room. They were all booked up they said. They could see if anything was available the following day. Not wanting to go through the 'hassle' of moving rooms after having already unpacked some stuff, I told them that I would keep they room but that they should try to air it a bit or spray one of those odour repellent things that probably make the smell worse rather than better. They did, I think, but the smell remained through the stay. Perhaps I should have moved room after all. Or perhaps they shouldn't have put me in a smoking room to begin with.Fourthly, I asked Concierge to book Shinkansen tickets to Kyoto for our check-out date. This they did very efficiently, or so I thought. The day before check-out, I get a call from Concierge asking that I see them urgently. Turns out they booked the ticket for that day rather than the day after. Apparently, the person that took the booking had misunderstood (never implying that I may have been the cause of the misunderstanding, which I sure hope I wasn't). Admittedly, they did send me a couple of confirmation messages to the room with the date, which I didn't bother to read properly, thinking that it couldn't really be messed up (so, I suppose, it was partly my fault after all). In any case, they apologised, re-booked the tickets and did not charge an extra penny. All dealt with very professionally. Yet, again, I was left thinking that this sort of thing should not have happened at all at a Peninsula. Or maybe I'm being too harsh. ConclusionAll in all, the Peninsula Tokyo is undoubtedly a very good hotel ideally located but, for one reason or another, our stay was not perfect. If I were to pick the main defects, it would certainly be the lack of reception space and the smell of smoke in the room. The three point rating should be seen in context. From a general perspective, this was certainly a five star hotel with five star service. However, when judged against the very high standards one has come to expect from this type of hotels (and the price tag that comes with it), then, I'm afraid, the Peninsula Tokyo comes a bit short.Having been for lunch, tea/coffee or dinner at a number of other Tokyo hotels during our stay at the Peninsula (including the Four Seasons near the train station, the Shangri-La, the Palace Hotel, the Grand Hyatt, the Ritz-Carlton, the Park Hyatt and the Conrad), and stayed at the Mandarin Oriental for one night a few days later, were I to come to Tokyo again, I would say that I would probably choose either the Palace Hotel, as it really is a beautiful property, brand new, full of light and with a lovely terrace, facing the Imperial Palace Gardens, or the Mandarin Oriental, whose location may not be ideal, but is an absolutely stunning hotel, with breath-taking views, plenty of space to mill around, a superb bar, and excellent restaurants. Alternatively, the Conrad, which has splendid views over Hamarikyu Park and Tokyo bay, though I believe the latter comes a slightly higher price tag than the Peninsula/Palace/Mandarin Oriental. The Shangri-La also seems very nice, though perhaps a bit flashy and is right next to the station. Four Seasons is very small and feels too business-focused (also adjacent to the station). Ritz-Carlton is in Roppongi, which, although a pleasant enough area, I would still prefer to be near Ginza/Marumouchi. The Park Hyatt, although iconic, is poorly located I think, next to the municipal administrative quarters near Shinjuku. Better to just go for drinks at the New York Bar (which really is lovely) and/or dinner at at the New York Grill (which, again, is very good) - you can walk through Shinjuku beforehand which is quite an experience.

Located centrally to everything fabulous in Tokyo, our time at this hotel was spectacular! The concierge service was very helpful and the mini-coup available to our suite was also an unexpected perk. The corner view of the park and the palace was an added bonus. The only thing I didn't care for was the weird smelling shampoo and conditioner, (a minor accommodation flaw).In addition, the bar at the top of the hotel serves the best beer I have ever tasted (Peter beer, exclusively made in Hokkaido). It was a great weekend!

One of the best five star hotels I have ever stayed at (and I only stay in five star hotels).Great facilities in the room (plumbed in tea/coffee machines, printers, mood lighting, large safes etc), almost everything you might want has been thought of.Not the best breakfast in the world, but other than that, great location, great rooms, great service.Remember Rolls Royce can be used for trips less than a mile for the experience.

We had an amazing experience in this hotel. Our room was fantastic, with a view of the Imperial Palace gardens. The amenities in the room were above and beyond any luxury hotel. The room and bathroom were very spacious. The staff in the hotel were very attentive, the concierge extremely knowledgeable and helpful.

We recently stayed in a Deluxe Suite at the Peninsula Tokyo and had a wonderful experience. The service of the bellmen, front desk staff, restaurant staff and Concierge service was outstanding. It was peak cherry blossom season and the hotel appeared to be a full capacity. For this reason the Concierge staff seemed a little overwhelmed assisting guests, but were very accommodating once you were able to speak with them. The deluxe suite was absolutely fantastic. It had wonderful views of the Imperial Palace and Hibiya Park and was incredibly spacious and outfitted with amazing electronic light controls and gadgets like other Peninsula properties we have enjoyed elsewhere. I was surprised that they did not have dedicated iPhone/iPod docks but that would be my only (very mild) complaint. We also stayed in a One bedroom suite at the Four Seasons Marunouchi at the start of our trip and the Peninsula Deluxe Suite wins hands down in terms of the room design, layout and views. Both properties are excellent, but if you want superior room design, views and layout, the Peninsula has a definite edge. Rooms that do not face the park, will not have the same "wow" factor as the Park view rooms or Deluxe Suites, but I am sure they are nicely appointed.

It took me sometime to write this review because I didn't know where to start. So, I'll keep it simple as possible. I stayed at the hotel during the recent IMF World Bank meeting when the hotel and the city were "swarming" with foreign guests. The following represents service excellence at its best:- Inbound flight delayed, meeting in 1 hour - the hotel GM met me upon arrival at the hotel entrance to ensure that I breezed through check-in formalities and somebody took care of the pressing of my suit.- Room - excellent, spacious and well appointed. The toilet seat is even heated! At no time did I return to my room that it's not made up yet. This is amazing considering the hotel is full. The view from my room was to the royal palace grounds. - Butler service - they're non-intrusive but always available when you need it.- Concierge - extremely helpful.- Check out and drive back to the airport - check out was very efficient (quick) and the drive almost uneventful. - Location - central to the everywhere. I could go on and on. But bottom line is that I don't think I'll stay anywhere when I visit Tokyo, either on business or leisure.

Location, room, amenity, service, and everything else is perfect except the below. They are all minor things but you would want the hotel to be perfect when paying $500+ a night, right?- shower door doesn't close tightly, thus water leaks out on the floor. it's kind of annoying..- fitness gym is very small and packed at 6am when it's open. Wished it was open 24hrs..- hair blow dryer is powerless. it'll die soon!!- steam room temperature at the spa is too low :(- I love coffee in Japan with rich aroma, but the cafe on the 1st floor didn't have a good one. It was too acidic for me. The Lavazza in the room is MUCH better!!I've stayed twice in the past with a total of 10 nights. I'd stay there again when going back to Tokyo! It's a smaller hotel and I like the "coziness".

My only complaint about pen tokyo is during peak, the staff can get pretty frazzled. Their level of consistency on food also varies. However, this is a very minor detail. Tokyo pen is still one of the best places to stay if travelling with kids. We stayed in deluxe park view room and we were very comfortable. I had a walk-in closet, sala set, work desk, and even a small 2 seater table to enjoy my coffee. Over-all room lay-out is well conceptualized.Concierge booked us on nice dining places depending on what you want to experience. From kobe to kurobota to sashimi. Location is near ginza but can be quite a walk for kids, depending on their age.

I won't go into the quality of the rooms or location or the service because most of them would have already been addressed in the prior reviews. What put this place over the top for me was the quality of the concierge. Prior to our arrival, I had sent emails requesting perhaps 6-8 restaurant bookings - and by accounts, they weren't easy bookings to get and I had to juggle a schedule during our week stay. The emails were prompt and responsive and updates were given on which restaurants were booked and time slots available if they didn't fit my schedules. When I arrived, they printed out brochures, and I mean something concierge did themselves, with pictures of the restaurant, pin pointed on google map and directions. Plus, they had dress codes, phone numbers and opening hours as well as a summary page of my food adventure! Now that's service. I wouldn't have been able to book them myself in the first place given the language barrier and most 5 star hotels would probably book for you but it was the speed and efficiency of the service PLUS the brochures that thoroughly impressed me.

Well, i don't know how many years travelling Mt Average of Shanghai has under his belt but this undoubtedly is one of the great hotels. Not too formal, but the rooms have every switch in teh right place. Spot On.
Sincere hospitality! Attended to every one of our special requests and needs. Excellent location. We enjoyed our stay very much, as always........This is definitely our hotel of choice when in Tokyo!

Was there for a shopping and eating trip. Locationwise, this is one of the top notch. It's basically within taxi distance of everything, in case you don't want to navigate the Tokyo metro. The rooms were clean and spacious, but was also very Japanese in style. The staff was attentive, but did nothing to surprise you. I was there for 4 days and I kept seeing the same staff, but none of them remembered me or my room number. The breakfast was passable, with a set menu or Japanese or Continental breakfast. The host arranging the seating for breakfast should be better trained. He didn't know how to manage customer expectations or optimum seating arrangements. I went to the gym everyday. It was in a gloomy space above the swimming pool with no natural light. Also, it was only about 50 sm total, which means they can't offer a very complete range of equipment. At this price, I hope to be surprised and I wasn't, therefore I'll probably try another hotel in the vicinity next trip

Traveling with family in a city infamous for small hotel rooms is a challenge. I had trouble booking for our family online so I booked the old fashioned way--by phone. Over the phone we were offered 2 adjoining rooms (which must have been deluxe) for 1/2 rate for the second room. The family rate also came with a few additional perks. Breakfast in The Lobby was also included. (An aside: the breakfast was fantastic but the menu was limited. However I could probably eat that French Toast almost everyday.) The lobby with its iconic bamboo sculpture and central light feature are spectacular. The rooms were spacious with separate dressing rooms and a well appointed bathroom suite. We enjoyed sweeping views from clerestory windows on the 20th floor. The location is perfect for seeing the city sites since you can walk to the Imperial Palace and enter the Hibiya subway station directly from the hotel. It is close to Tokyo station, which served as our hub for destinations beyond Tokyo. Service was largely gracious and friendly and added to our experience. Our stay was on par with the Four Seasons which we also had the opportunity stay during this trip.

The Peninsula is synonymous with faultless anything. So all the reviews here are warranted. Choose this hotel to be pampered. We loved the way Japanese art and culture merged with the modern to give this hotel a unique and distinctive feel. We were able to further appreciate this through rental of the Eye Walk iPod from Concierge that walks you through all the art pieces around the hotel. We loved the coffee machine in our room. The pillows were phenomenal, and this hotel provided us the best sleep we've ever had in Tokyo. Service is polite, but some things do get lost in translation as some staff still struggle with English conversation. We tried to spa but because it's so popular, getting a booking for a decent hour is challenging. For those who want to keep fit, the gym offers free gymwear and shoe rental, while swimmers get free use of goggles and swim cap. Take advantage of the Imperial Palace grounds for a great run and great scenery. On a rainy day, walk down to the underground Hibiya station for a bit of shopping.

Great location. Walking distance to lots of high end stores and great restaurants. Basement 2 has access to subway. Great room service. Staff is courteous and friendly. Concierge was efficient and resourceful. Nice pool and spa. The front desk offered to upgrade me into one of their suites for a small fraction of the cost. Efficient check in process. I was up in my room in less than 10 minutes.Downside, lobby seats were just 2 benches facing each other. basically, seating 8 comfortably. If those chairs are full you'll have to sit yourself in the coffee shop tables.

There are a few odd things about this hotel. For example the in-your-face lobby lounge makes alighting from the limo and walking to reception an experience akin to a walk of shame in the school cafeteria. Equally, the thought of eating breakfast in the lobby lounge (the only on-property venue for breakfast) is an awkward one. I'm not sure many travelers want to be so 'on display' first thing of a morning? The reception desk is quite small and tucked up the back of the lobby lounge. While check-in is quick and painless it does feel a bit odd to be asked to take a seat in front of the elevator while a member of staff is summoned to escort you to your suite. These are all minor quirks that don't mean much in the grand scheme of things, but do translate to a disjointed first impression.The rooms have a slight polynesian-slash-modern-Japan feel. The ceiling in the bedroom is almost like a thatched bamboo weave and most of the fixtures including the sliding heavy door are solid wood. The natural tones are a welcome relief for the weary traveler but compared to other newer sister properties (i.e. the Peninsula Shanghai) it lacks the modern new world feeling. Our suite contained some of the usual thoughtful modern accents such as the housekeeping box (a box with a 2-way door in the dressing room with a light that tells you if something has been delivered, such as a newspaper, dry cleaning or shined shoes, but also has a button for the guest to summon the housekeeping staff to let them know you have something for them, such as laundry - all without having to interact with anyone). Nail dryer built-into the wall of the dressing room is another modern touch and likewise the mood lighting and entertainment system in the bathroom reminds you that this is a Peninsula. New accents such as a real espresso machine in the lounge room was a treat! While I love a Nespresso machine in my suite, having an old-school chrome espresso machine raring to go felt like true luxury. The bed is uber comfortable, even for an extremely fussy person like me. Each morning I awoke refreshed and rested, without any creaks in my back. The various pieces of furniture in the room mean that doing some work at the desk, sipping espresso with views over the Imperial Palace or lounging in front of the TV were all comfortable affairs and the luxury of having plenty of space to do all of that translated into a very relaxing stay indeed.As one would expect from a Peninsula in Japan, the level of service can be over-the-top. Some like that, some don't but I doubt that many could fault it. Room service offerings were thorough, the menu reads like a compendium of gourmet, so much so that I felt comfortable making up my own order without referring to the menu and simply ordering things I wanted. The resulting food and beverages arrived without fuss and again with thoughtful accents such as silverware and bone china and hand-made origami creations. Champagne was served with several complimentary accompaniments and given I was entertaining guests in the suite the staff even offered to stay and wait on us.The location is one of the truly magnificent aspects of this property, located right on the edge of Marunouchi with every imaginable boutique at your doorstep, but also just across from the Imperial Palace. WIth almost every Tokyo train and subway line right in front (or under) the building, getting around is a cinch.I loved this property, albeit not on par with the luxe of the Peninsula Shanghai, the service does exceed that of its sister. The location, the food offerings, the sumptuousness of the bed and the views make this a clear winner for accommodation in Tokyo. This is a bucket list hotel!

After um-ing and ah-ing about whether or not to splash out on a luxury stay in a city that we thought we would be out of the hotel most of the time, we finally decided to splurge. Boy are we glad we did! At the end of each day, (and sometimes in the the middle too) we were so happy to walk through the doors and return to our gorgeous room in a great location.The list of positives is endless so here are just a few:Room design - faultless. We stayed in a standard double deluxe room and they had thought of absolutely everything. Separate dressing area, bathroom with heated toilet seat, buttons for everything; there was even a spa mode in the bathroom, let me leave that a surprise though!Main bedroom area was very large with gorgeous views of the city. Again buttons for everything, lovely coffee machine, gorgeous ceiling. Really comfortable yukatan to sleep in which I'm wishing I had bought!Swimming pool: this was an urban retreat to say the least! We welcomed the use of the jacuzzi and pool everyday (even when pushed for time).Service: amazing! The staff at the pool were so efficient and helpful. Before I even sat down they had come over with water, goggles, swimcap and laid out towels :-) Staff at reception were also so helpful, even going as far as to escort us to the metro (which is directly underneath the hotel and accessible via the lift in the lobby)!The positives are endless but this review is already long enough. Only slight negatives are the breakfast which is very expensive for what you got and unflexible. We were not allowed to change anything from the set menus even of they were worth less.Peter bar has lovely decor but for a hotel of this calibre the drinks selection was not great and the bar staff were not that knowledgable (however this may have been due to a language barrier).Overall, if you are thinking of staying then based on our experience; just book it!

We visited Tokyo last year and arrived very early in the morning. We had booked 2 rooms but only one was ready. The check-in process was very efficient. When we got to the room, we found that we had been upgraded to a huge suite! It was very modern with many amenities and the technology was updated. The only downside to our experience was having to walk through the lobby which had the lounge/restaurant in it (as do all Peninsula hotels). The restaurant was very smelly and the ventilation was very limited. This made the lobby smell like food 24/7, which was not pleasant.

We booked a deluxe room and the room was big. It had a walk in closet with changing area, bathroom with separate shower and bath tub, king bed, sitting area with love seat and coffee table and a dinette table and chairs on the side. They asked if we wanted a upgrade with a charge but we were glad that we declined it b/c the room is very big and comfortable from a U.S standard .The location is in the high end area of Tokyo with access to great shopping and restaurants. We ate out the whole time we were there so we didn't have time to experience their restaurants. The lobby can be a bit of a scene with ppl having high tea in the lobby as it is one the things to do at the Peninsula.

I have stayed at the Peninsula Tokyo for 6 days. The room is excellent and well design, with a separate closet area. The location is very convenience with 3 minutes walking to ginza area.Hotel staff are trying to offer the best service. The main drawback is the concierge service which is not really up to the standard in a city like tokyo, they do not seem to be very knowledgable and take them time to understand the customer requirements.

You can't go wrong staying at Tokyo's Peninsula. The Hong Kong chain's service is world renowned, and once you've experienced it you will hesitate to call anything else "Five Star"! You will feel like a celebrity upon entering the lobby, when literally dozens of hotel employees bow and welcome you back. The cute-as-buttons bell hop women will run and get you towels and water after a morning jog around Imperial Park, right outside the hotel's front door. The answer to every request is always "certainly". Hotel rooms merge hi tech conveniences (remote control buttons for everything, outside temperature and humidity indicators, heated toilet seats) with understated Japanese esthetics (rough cypress wood doors, fresh fruit presented on traditional pottery). Our view from the 17th floor room practically allowed us to wave to the Emperor. Similar views from the expansive indoor pool, the top floor bar and restaurant, the Chinese restaurant on the second floor all inspired awe. When you finally decide, reluctantly, that you should leave the hotel and go explore Tokyo, things remain comfortable: there are three subway lines in the basement that will take you most places in central Tokyo within 30 minutes. Or you walk out the front door and find yourself in the shopping Meccas of Ginza and Marunouchi within minutes. Or you hop into a cab and, armed with impeccable directions from the best concierge team you will ever encounter, head to some magical ten seat restaurant you never thought you could get into. You shouldn't have hesitated asking though. The answer you got from the concierge was "certainly".
user_name:
trippy036
New York City, New York

review_body: Dont go there even from farPeople are rudeUneficientAnd ask u money for anything free in another placeThey speak aérage EnglishAnd dont understand at allAm use to stay in peninsula LA and hkgIls nothing compareThey just have a glamour name And they killing this name every dayJust dont goJapan is thé best city in thé worldService is gréât even at market or cheap restaurantAt peninsulaThey just dont care about customer and serviceMoney only it doesnt Work any more like thisPeninsula, do something before closing!!!!!

I have run out of nice things to say about this wonderful hotel. But it struck me walking through the front door last week that maybe the best thing about it is the bell hops, who are amazingly cute and helpful in equal parts.If we could just get off the Japanese thermos coffee with cold milk at breakfast . . .

There is a reason I have been really looking forward to going back to Tokyo for my 2nd visit, and that reason is the Peninsula Hotel. All I can say is that this hotel gets it all right, no exceptions.The suite is fantastic, large and very clean. The bedroom has a humidity control, so nice to have, and the only time I have ever seen that feature in a hotel. The bathroom is like a work of art, the marble is custom cut to fit the shower and sink together, the finish work is the best I have ever seen.Food is also excellent, both in room and at the restaurants. We dined at Peter, the French restaurant on the 24th floor. I did not see too many reviews of this restaurant, so I was a bit worried, but overall, it was excellent and the view is just amazing. The bar is fun, but they do allow smoking. Room service is the way it should be, all the plates are presented on our in-room table, all lined up exactly to face the same way. Quality was very good, if not expensive, which is no surprise.Anyway, I can't wait to go back again. This hotel not only proves that a stay can be just about perfect, but gives me some hope that I am not alone in my expectations of what a 5-Star experience should really be.

We stayed two nights in a twin room and it was a great getaway from the humid streets of Tokyo. Excellent service, you could tell the staff were proud to work there. We received a complimentary upgrade at check-in and the staff were extremely helpful to book restaurants and plan our onward service. The rooms were cozy, well spaced with walking closet and big bathroom. Great spa with swimming pool, gym and a variety of saunas.

We stayed at The Peninsula Tokyo When we lived in Tokyo. The hotel room is very specious compare to most of the hotel in Tokyo. ( hotels in Tokyo can be very tiny even though it is expensive. ) Beautiful, luxury hotel in Tokyo. loved it.

We stayed a couple of nights each at the Four Seasons and the Peninsula in Tokyo, and liked the latter more (the superb service at Four Seasons notwithstanding), due to the fab rooms.The rooms were really large, with a separate walk in closet/ dressing room (where all of our bags could be kept and clothes hung out of sight)... a seating area with a sofa and also a 2 person dining table. Loved the attention to details like the coffee machine and multi-country plug points all around (even an appropriate one in the bathroom that I could plug my hair iron into - it's amazing how many hotels don't have this!). The bathroom was large and spacious with two basins (yay!)... the bed was reallllllyy soft and comfy.The location is great - at the corner of the Imperial Gardens and Ginza... with several subway stations close by.The lobby was a bit too "happening" for my liking... pretty crowded since the cafe was in the lobby area and it certainly seemed like a popular hang out at all hours of the day.That aside, our stay was fabulous and would definitely recommend this hotel.

In the midst of city life this is an oasis. We stayed at four different hotels in our travel round Japan and it is this hotel that I will remember most fondly.Our room was modern with switches for everything but it still had a comfy relaxing feel. Also a lot bigger than we thought it would be. The dressing room was ideal because it meant we kept the cases out of view allowing the lounge/bedroom to be tidy.Went to the bar the first night. We ordered a selection of bar food thinking that they would be small tasters. What a mistake. They were full size, hillarious !The wine in the bar is eye wateringly expensive. I'd expect to pay a premium but £18 a glass was more than I expected. But what the hell, have a glass and enjoy the magnificent view.My only criticism would be that you have breakfast in what feels like the lobby. The food was nice though and the service as you would expect.

Everything one would expect from a Peninsula - excellent location, great rooms, and wonderful service (though as I was leaving, I was a bit surprised when I got my bag from the bell-desk, the person on duty did not offer to carry my bag outside). We had lunch at Peter and found the decor a bit odd - didn't have the class of a Peninsula - perhaps better at night given the dark, trying-to-be-trendy style. Overall, it is a fantastic hotel, though if you want a view of the Imperial Gardens, the nearby re-built Palace Hotel offers substantially better views (really none to speak of at the Pen).

Everything about this hotel is excellent. Subway and JR railway are all within walking distance if you need to travel. Food and shopping are all nearby. The staff are all helpful, I will always stay at this hotel even though it is quite expensive, but it is value for money.

If you are going to Tokyo then run, don't walk to The Peninsula! We have been lucky enough to stay at some of the finest properties in The America's (St Moritz NYC, Amangiri, The Mandarin in Miami) and Europe (George V, The Ritz, etc) and this property wins! The attention to detail is staggering, and the fact that staff knows you upon arrival, and can never seem to do enough just makes you never want to leave.Any serious Hotel manager should spend a couple of days here so they know what perfection is. We still can't stop talking about our brief time at this property. There is nothing more to say, because when it is done right...it is done!Thanks to the wonderful staff and management, and we look forward to coming back soon!

The rooms are spacious and exquisitely decorated in a soothing color palette. The rooms have all the features and creature comforts you could ask for with a great view of the city. I stayed for 5 nights and found the location to be perfect. You can access the nearby subway directly via a hotel underground connection. You are close to the Imperial gardens, minutes from the Ginza, and a short subway ride to the fish market. The concierge staff, notably Akane, were most helpful and spot on with restaurant recommendations. We found the staff to be courteous and very professional. Breakfast in the lobby restaurant was excellent and the breakfast in the Chinese restaurant also was exceptional. This hotel is hard to beat on any measure.

My husband and I just returned from a 6 night stay at The Peninsula Tokyo (28 December 2012 - 3 January 2013). The hotel was wonderful and the staff impeccable. DH & I joked that the housekeeping staff were ninjas, since we never saw or heard them. They were excellent at learning our schedule and handling the room while we were out. Not only do they do the daily cleaning of the room, they also return in the evenings for turn down service that includes putting out you slippers and providing complementary bottle water. It was a very nice touch. We had a Deluxe King Corner Room on the 18th floor. We had a wonderful view of the Imperial Palace and looking at Ginza. Amazing!! The rooms include yukata to sleep in, bathrobes, slippers, shampoo, conditioner, soap, shower gel, bath salts, shower cap, comb, brush, vanity kit, sewing kit, toothbrush & toothpaste, lotion, etc... Unless you require special bathroom amenities, feel free to leave your stuff at home. That will save room in you luggage for things you're going to purchase while on holiday. LOLOur room accommodations including daily breakfast. For breakfasts you have 2 options to eat either in The Lobby restaurant or the buffet breakfast. We always opted for the buffet breakfast since it had so many options. At the buffet there were fresh pastries (muffins, croissants, danishes, etc...), scrambled eggs, bacon, sausage, miso soup, fried rice, noodles, french toast, fresh fruit and many other options. And the juices were amazing! So tasty.We ate a few times at the hotel. Peter restaurant up on the 24th floor had amazing food and the views were spectacular. The Lobby restaurant was fun and quirky as it was in the lobby of the hotel. It was fun to eat and see people coming and going. And the food was great too. We only ate breakfast at the Chinese restaurant on the 2nd floor and did not eat at the basement Japanese restaurant (sushi & tempura dishes). Room service was wonderful too.If your budget is accommodating, I highly recommend going to the concierge and have them make you a reservation for Kawamura. It is a kobe beef teppan restaurant. Amazing food. They are open for lunch and dinner, with lunch being the less expensive option. Getting around town was very easy. You can walk around to all sorts of shops. Just exploring our surroundings we found amazing eateries. We don't speak any Japanese and neither did some of the restaurant staff, but it wasn't a problem at all. They all have either food models or pictures of the food, so we just pointed and indicated how many of which item. Super simple, so if you don't speak Japanese do not worry.There are 7-Eleven, Lawson and other convenience stores all over. Besides being able to get on the metro Hibiya line in the hotel basement, it is quick and easy to walk to any other metro or JR (railway) line and head all over Tokyo. Be sure to get your SUICA card at the station from the payment machines. You can add more money to it as you need to. Just FYI.There is so much do to and see in Tokyo and The Peninsula Tokyo is a great hub. It was always fun to "come home" after a fun day of walking around. We look forward to coming here again and trying other Peninsula hotels around the globe.

I stayed here for 4 nights when I came to Tokyo to celebrate New Years. The rooms are lovely. Some have views of the Imperial Palace grounds. My room had a big walk in closet. The bathroom was enormous. I had no problems with noise. The bed was comfortable.The concierge helped us make dinner reservations in advance of our arrival. This ended up being no small task because the Tokyo fish market closes for 4 days over New Years and many of the restaurants close as a result. The hotel also has a beautiful swimming pool with a waterfall. The spa is one of the best I have ever seen. I had a shiatsu massage and foot reflexology. Both were excellent. I would certainly come back here.

Just like the Hong Kong Peninsular, the hotel has this certain British colonel classy atmosphere as reflected by its employees' attitude. Yes, the bed,it must be the most comfortable bed I'd ever slept in. The hotel is just perfect, my only complaint is that the water was hot and cold while i took my shower, I am surprised that a hotel of this caliber did not install a regulator to regular hot and cold water.

Very pricey but lovely hotel and well located. Lots to see and do in Ginza. Close to lots of shopping and very good restaurants. Staff is over the top helpful. Rooms are massive with lots of amenities. Food at the restaurant is fantastic - must have the tonkatsu.

We live in Yokohama and decided to go into Tokyo for a couple of nights while my husband was away on a trip. Stayed in a deluxe park view room 18th floor. (1 adult 2 children). Cost was just over 60,000 yen a night including breakfast booked via expedia. When we arrived they charged an extra 5000 yen a night on top for another (very comfortable) bed. Breakfast was only for 2 so we had to pay for an extra child. Breakfast was inconsistent eg extra OJ offered one day but not the next, more bread one day but not the next- its 5 star so I expect the best .As I had children with me breakfast was served in what seemed like a hallway otherwise we could have eaten on the 10th floor.Room was large with a dressing room and great view. TV didnt work so had to call reception.Nice bathroom (no lock) but very cold - heating only in main room.Swimming pool is OK but we had to wear hats-as you do at most Japanese pools. A little annoying that children were not allowed in the pool after 6pm.Best thing about the hotel is the location- walking distance to Ginza/Marunouchi/Yurachuko.

We stayed at the Peninsula for a week this December. The service, as one could imagine, was impeccable. Everyone greeted you when they saw you, of course that seems also to be the Japanese custom. Our room was gorgeous, very modern, high tech and functional, overlooking the imperial palace gardens. They seemed to think about everything when they designed the room from our own personal kimonos, robes, slippers, a drawer full of toiletry supplies, a well stocked coffee/tea bar etc. The bathroom was also beautiful with the most high-tech toilet I have ever used, including a heated seat. The tub was large with a cascading water spout, and a personal tv to watch while bathing. The fitness area is also nice with several treadmills, bikes, ellipticals, (all with personal tvs), a large variety of weight machines as well as free weights. The gym gets quite busy early in the morning, as is expected. The spa looked gorgeous, albeit quite pricey.The dining area in the lobby where we had a daily breakfast was good. A selection of freshly baked in-house pastries, fresh fruit juices, choice of coffees as well as many breakfast items were offered. The service was wonderful and friendly.The concierge service was also exceptional. I used their help many times and they went out of their way to help me meet my needs. My only complaint would be that the turndown service was on the late side, about 8:00 pm. With our jetlag and busy days, we were often thinking about turning in by the time they arrived. They were always friendly and efficient when they came, and scurried about making sure they covered all their bases. A nice touch to the maid service was a piece of fruit left for us almost everyday. The asian pears were delicious!The hotel is very well situated and convenient to many areas. The trains are very close, and one line is even accessible through the basement of the hotel. I highly suggest going down to the lower level as you can watch the bakers busy through the windows making pastries, cakes and treats. Quite a show.

I would rate this hotel highly but would caveat this by saying that this hotel is more suited to travelling for business. To give context for this review, I have stayed at the following hotels in Tokyo to date: Park Hyatt (Lost in Translation hotel), Grand Hyatt Roppongi Hills, ANA Intercontinental, Ritz Carlton and the Conrad. As a business traveller I would give thus hotel a 9; as a honeymooner I would give it a 6.5 out of 10.I stayed at this hotel in September 2012 for business and was impressed by the size of the room, the layout, the lovely bathroom (with Japanese bath) and the dressing room. The hotel is clean, extremely modern and very central so easy to get to meetings in the business district, Tokyo station, Ginza, Tsukiji (fish market) and a short taxi ride to Roppongi. For those who like to exercise, the gym is comfortable, the pool very nice and more importantly you are next door to the Imperial Palace which makes for a great 30 minute running circuit. Also a bug positive is that taxis are always on standby (but then this is the case at most hotels). I can only comment on food, which was very good, in relation to the Japanese breakfasts I had.My new husband and I subsequently stayed here for our honeymoon in December 2012. I had considered the Park Hyatt but as we were only in Tokyo for 3 nights and had a lot to see, we decided it was more important to stay central as the Park Hyatt is in Shinjuku and slightly further away. We arrived at the hotel at 6.00am and were rightly told that our room would not be ready until midday. It was our own doing to arrive so early and so we were told that the only way to get a room was to pay an extra 25,000¥ for the only room available. It would have been nice to have been upgraded to this room but I appreciate that they can not do this for all guests who arrive before check-in, even if on honeymoon. Not wishing to wait for 6 hours we paid up. However, over our three day stay there was ZERO acknowledgment that we were on honeymoon which I think was poor form, particularly if you consider that the Japanese are renowned for their service and hospitality. We didn't expect much but a free drink or another acknowledgement would have been appreciated. I see a follower reviewer had a similar experience when there was no acknowledgement of his friend's birthday. When staying in a 5-star hotel charging rates north of £500 per night, small gestures are easy to organise and can have a very positive impact on guests. The food during this stay was very good (me having a great Japanese breakfast again and my husband having an omelette) although when my husband tried to order hash brown on top of his fried eggs, which were much cheaper price than the 3,800¥ set menu that was included in our rate, he was told we would be charged an extra 700¥ which again was their policy but showed their general inflexibility. The only slight negatives of the Peninsula more generally are that the restaurant is next to the lobby on the ground floor and the views from the rooms tends to overlook the road because of the hotel's location. The reason that having the restaurant next to the lobby is negative is that it is less private and unlike most other 5-star hotels in Japan, which are situated on the very high floors above offices, there is no view. The bar is on slightly higher floors but the views don't quite compare.In summary, in spite of being very satisfied with my experience when there for business, I would be inclined to stay at another hotel on my next business trip in a few months time only because I felt that the hotel was less attentive on the last trip and it would have incurred minimal effort on their part to change this.

We stayed one night at the Peninsula Tokyo. Stayed in a superior room 20th floor. View is not as nice as hoped / I was hoping lost in translation - but was actually another building quite close. I guess need to go to park Hyatt next time to check the view... The rooms are beautiful. Nothing to say. Super modern and practical. They thought about everything.Atmosphere wise feels very business like. Their pool is great and so is their spa. Of I had been on business I would have been delighted to stay here. Location: good shops are seconds away. Breakfast a bit disappointing quality of food/ service long ... and needless to say very expensive (but that's Tokyo!)

I was lucky enough to stay here for two nights in December it was fantastic. The rooms are stunning, loads of room, thoughtfully designed, quiet, comfortable and with great views. The service was faultless. Everyone knew us by name and were friendly and helpful. My only word of warning is that the Japanese restaurant in the basement is incredibly expensive - £300 for the 'cheapest' menu - and lacks atmosphere. It's really well located, a couple of minutes walk to Ginza which is a great area for shopping.

It's my second time staying at this hotel, and i will for sure stay next time! that would say it! Location is great. The view of the Imperial palace, from some rooms is stunning. the service is very good. don't miss experiencing the weddings ceremonies in the mornings! I guess they serve the best Tea Brunch in town (from 11 am).

We checked in here for the first night of our honeymoon into a King suite on a high up level with a fantastic view.Everything was perfect. The room was spacious and immaculate and the hotel provided complimentary strawberries and champayne in our room. We quickly forgot about our long journey once we were dressed in the kimonos and slippers provided in our room.Room service was prompt and delicious and the bento boxes were genuine Japanese style.We loved every moment of our stay right down to the pillows we slept on, so much so we bought 4 of them to take home with us. Best hotel we have ever stayed at.

I started my stay at the Peninsula by opting for the Rolls Royce (call for the reservations) and a driver to meet me at the station. I stayed in the deluxe suite. Check-in was made easy as it was done all in the room. No need to stand in line, the concierge met me at the car and escorted me to the room with no hassles. The customer service was top notch, as is expected from a luxory hotel in Japan. Room service was also delicious. The location is prime as you are within walking distance from attractions and all the shopping your wallet can handle in Ginza. The room offered a beautiful panoramic view of Tokyo.

I stayed on an executive floor in a double room which had separate dressing area, huge bathroom and an area to watch tv. The room and staff were all you would expect of a 5star hotel. The location is great as you can walk to business district, station, palace, nice shops and even some cheap eateries (which are great value) under the Hibya train arches. Tokyo is never cheap and neither is the hotel but I would say this is good value and fairly priced. I will deffinitely go back!

I usually make it a point to stay at the very best hotel in a foreign city. Which is why even the slightest... Slight can upset my decision for next time.Peninsula is pretty great, beautiful hotel service as you can expect in Japan.We had the concierge help us with a Michelin star dinner booking during one of the nights of our stay which was very helpful. The concierge knew there was a Guest's birthday. This is probably the second time (the other was in Kuala Lumpur) where a five star hotel didn't acknowledge a guest's birthday, with even a piece of chocolate. Especially after i had made it known the whole purpose of the four day stay was to celebrate this bday, where we allflew in from different countries to have a celebratory long weekend at Tokyo peninsula.For that reason alone I won't stay here again. People that understand five starservice and understand why they pay for it reading this might understand why that very seemingly small oversight affects my decision for next time. I am going to NYC next and have not even bothered to look at the peninsula NYC review or rates when I choosing my accommodation.

We liked our stay at the Peninsula. It is ideally situated for shopping and sightseeing. The staff are friendly and the Concierge was extremely helpful sorting out our flights and booking restuarants. It is not easy getting about without the help of the doorman who explained to the driver exactly where we wre going.

I just returned from a business trip to Tokyo, including a couple of days for sightseeting. I was extremely impressed with the Peninsula from the moment that I arrived. The service is impeccable even by the high standards one expects in Asia. The rooms are very large and layed out in a suite configuration allowing for separate sitting, dining, working and sleeping areas. The bath and closet areas were also large, and the room was nicely appointed with technology controls for lighting, window blinds, etc. I particularly liked the built in expresso maker. Fresh fruit and ice were replaced in my room each day. Good location, very close to Ginza shopping area and metro.This hotel exceeded my expectations in every way, including price. As others have mentioned, it is a bit expensive. If your rate does not include breakfast, bear in mind that a standard American/British style breakfast (eggs, ham, bread, juice, coffee) will set you back almost $50 USD per day in the lobby restaurant. The food is good, but those prices are clearly out of line. There were some other choices in the area, but not very convenient if you are on business without time to spare.

I went to this hotel for location (near my clients) and as my wife was with me near shopping. Ultimately I was astounded by the view, overlooking the royal palace and the fact I could conveniently walk everywhere I wanted to go. Rooms are fantastically equipped (baths with mood lighting and a dressing room with nail polish dryer etc), and incredibly spacious for Tokio. the staff are very helpful and I only have minor complaints- the reception area restaurant gets very busy so eating there can be a challenge, the top floor bar is very smoky and there seems to be no air cleaning sytem and do not get a hotel car to pick you up from the airport unless you have limitless wealth .

A fantastic luxury hotel in a quieter and less crazy part of town - It suited us as we arrived tired from the UK. The staff were very helpful, the room was amazing and very spacious, especially for Tokyo. A nice way to start the trip as long as you dont have to keep an eye on what you are spending - it comes at a price.

My wife and I stayed at the Peninsula Tokyo in March 2012; it was a beautiful hotel, with excellent service and in a very convenient location near the subway and JR Yamanote line. We loved the attention to detail and the fact that the room was more like a small apartment (bigger and a lot nicer than the one I had in Manhattan!), with a large dressing room and bathroom off the entry hall separated from the living/bedroom by a beautiful sliding door. We went to Tsukiji market for the tuna auction and it was only a 10 minute taxi ride from the hotel which was nice considering we had to be there before 5 am!

This is a great hotel if you are in Tokyo on holiday without children, and you have time to spend in the hotel with your partner. It's not the right hotel for a short business trip because you are unlikely to get chance to appreciate the great facilities. These include walk in wardrobes, fantastic views, separate sitting areas in the rooms, a great gym and pool with inconvenient opening hours. There is no buffet breakfast, only table service, which is fine if you have time, but not if you're on a schedule.This hotel is great, but just not good value for business travel.

Tokyo has quite a few great hotels but none are situated in the heart of Ginza the city's best shopping area except the Peninsula. This hotel is a few mins away from everything from shops to restaurants. Living there cuts costs of taxis drastically. Views of the city are stunning, some rooms even have a view of the Imperial Palace gardens. The rooms are spacious considering that hotel rooms in Tokyo are known to be small. The bathrooms have electronic bidets that open and shut automatically and have heated seats. The service is great and staff are courteous.
user_name:
Ash T
Dubai, United Arab Emirates

review_body: Stayed a night at The Peninsula on my way back frm Osaka to Frankfurt. The hotel is truly elegant, top-class standard (as good as any Four Seasons or Mandarin Oriental I've been to anywhere, and better than most) and the rooms strike the right balance between elegant, stylish, warm and welcoming. The breakfast was top notch, and the location is right on Ginza street, Tokyo's equivalent of Fifth Avenue. Highly recommended.

We loved this hotel. Great clean rooms with tons of fun amenities in the room. The room was fantastic. Beautiful decor & a fantastic view. The bathroom had a huge bathtub you could put three people in. The location in great for Ginza. Also the subway station is in the basement.When we go back to Ginza this is our home. Loved everything about this place.Staff are very nice & helpful. The front desk supervisor Mr. Morita did a great job & took care of us very nicely. Because he was so helpful & fixed a small problem very quick, we will return.Thanks Mr. Morita!!

very good service , high in quality , relaxing atmosphere , prime location , very attentive and welcoming , you feel that everyone there is ure personal buttler.however my constructive critisisim would be some facts couldnt be changed and some they need to address like ,rooms are very small and compact , the lobby isnt so spacious. yet i understand and apreciate the beauty of its design, however it tend to get over crowded in the lobby restaurant and extremely noisy which kills the family friendly scene , specially with people getting drunk (i assume ) and start laughing out loud price issue is also a concern , its too expensive , lacks the wow factorbut overall its a classy hotel

Having stayed off and on over the last 4 years I can't speak highly enough of the staff, location, services and hotel amenities. Close to Marunuchi business district, 7 min. walk to Ginza, Imperial palace across the street with Metro (subway/underground) in basement the Peninsula is nicely positioned. This is an up-to-date hotel (built in last 5 years or so) with all the gadgets you would ever want in the room (auto shading, temp control, lighting) coupled with a unique feature set that makes your stay even more pleasant. They invested in a sliding heavy wood door that separates the bedroom from the hallway to door and bathroom/separate closet area (for most rooms) which the the effect of shielding outside noise (those that travel a lot understand the noise most hotels have) and have a valet box in closet area for clothing, newspapers, etc. There is 24 hr clothing service coupled one of the most beautiful spa/pool areas you will ever see (treat yourself to a SPA visit and enjoy massage plus their various showers, steam, "quiet room". Fitness center is smallish but has top notch LifeFitness cardio plus 8 machines for all body parts.Food is outstanding but with tokyo carrying the most numerous Michelin rated restaurants that should be expected. Breakfast is in lobby....its not particularly private so if you require a more private setting for business walk two blocks down to Imperial Hotel and go to Les Saisons on 2nd floor. If you like Italian try Elio Locundo a quick 10 min. cab ride from hotel and have the sausage raviolis....small restaurant but great food, service.

My husband and I stayed at the Peninsula Tokyo for a 1.5 week vacation plus visit with extended family. The hotel room was much larger than expected, especially for Tokyo. We appreciated having a segregated dressing room to store our luggage and clothing in. The bathroom was such a pleasant surprise after a long flight from the US. The rooms were very quiet and the room darkening shades helped us to recover from jet lag when we took some extended afternoon naps. Housekeeping was top-notch with excellent attention to detail. Our room was cleaned two times per day; the initial cleaning and again at turn-down service. The staff was friendly, polite and accommodating. Room service was very good. Breakfast (included in the hotel rate) was great and offered an over abundance of food. Laundry & dry cleaning service was very good, too. The concierge was very helpful to us each time we asked for directions, particularly since we don't speak Japanese. Location was great: very close to the imperial gardens, Ginza shopping district, tokyo station, fish market, etc. We had dinner one night at Peter. The food was very good, but not my favorite meal in Tokyo, perhaps because it didn't seem to make sense to have an indulgent French meal when traveling as far as Japan. While the meal was pricey, the serving sizes were unexpectedly large. My husband and I agreed that we would not have ordered a first course had we known how large the entrees were. We returned to Peter a few times for drinks at the bar. The bar and restaurant offers excellent views of the city and is a great place for a night cap. We used the fitness center and pool facilities. The high level of service and attention to detail were apparent there, too. Didn't use the personal trainer service, but we thought about it. Same with the Spa. Nothing at the hotel is inexpensive, but the same can be said for Tokyo in general. I highly recommend the Peninsula Tokyo and will stay there again when we return.

My wife and I stayed at the Peninsula and we got off to a slow start at the hotel. Our room was not ready when we arrived and we were told that our room would not be ready until check in time which was 3:00PM. We had arrived at 2:40PM and I thought it was odd, but we went to the lobby and had some tea. At 3:00 our room was ready and it was beautiful. It was spotless and very well decorated. The hotel has a bustling lobby but our room was very quiet and we enjoyed staying there. I had read complaints about the door to the toilet being inadequate, but we did not share that complaint. Everything about the Peninsula is a statement of luxury. It is clearly a very fine hotel that has no trouble competing with the best in the world.The concierge desk was very helpful. They gave us maps, tips, instructions, told us how to conquer the metro, and made all of our dinner reservations. They could not have been nicer or more helpful. This is a very fine hotel and it is one that will satisfy the tastes and preferences of all those that are fortunate enough to stay there. If we ever find ourselves returning to Tokyo, we would be very happy to stay at the Peninsula again.

Last week we stayed a week at the Peninsula in Tokyo and this hotel is just awesome! The rooms are so spacious! The normal standard rooms are like suites. You have your own dressroom. The bath room is amazing. A bath tub and an extra shower. The bedroom has a seperate part with a sofa where you can watch tv. Everything functions either automacly (like the toilette seat going up when you approach) or via buttons. Buttons for everything! They have a verh nice pool at the 6th floor and a fittness as well. The location is super and the staff is very friendly and helpful! I loved the stay there and wish i could come back! If you have enough money to spend this is the hotel you want to stay in. Its GREAT!!!

Location is the best but the service i would expect from a luxury hotel should not be this poor. They charged me at the wrong cc and without approval. Their staff is unfriendly and lack of courtesy. Just found out my friends also complained about them.

We spent a long weekend in The Peninsula during our first trip to Tokyo in the middle of summer. Our expectations were very high, and for the most part the hotel lived up to these.Make no mistake, we would stay here again when next in Tokyo - but attention needs to be paid to consistency of quality of room service offerings (& to the prices!). If it wasn't for that aspect, would have rated a 5.Pro'sWe had the Rolls-Royce pick-up at Haneda, so transportation literally couldn't have been better. Driver was very informative and courteous. Water in the car, and iPad connected to the internet to fiddle on with.Welcome at the hotel itself was excellent, and check-in/luggage transfer was excellent at 6.30am. The lobby is a little underwhelming, but golly does the location make up for it!We stayed in a Deluxe room facing the Imperial Palace - excellent city views with greenery in the foreground. Definitely gave a sense of being in the endless sprawl that is Tokyo. It would be a ity to stay here and not have the view.The room itself had every, and I mean every, gadget you could possibly want. TV's and phones all over the place, fast wireless internet, mood lighting, touch button curtains, remote controlled everything, nail dryer in the dressing room....Beautifully designed and decorated bathroom. Great feature natural stone wall with huge tub. Separate shower and toilet. The toilet is a top of the range all-singing and dancing Japanese special. From automatic opening to deodorised wash and blowdry.Bed was huge and very comfortable.Faultless cleanliness.Excellent swimming pool with fantastic view of the Imperial Palace and nearby park. Two of the sunbeds are outside on a balcony overlooking the view. The Peninsula does pools well - take New York as another example of stunning views.ConsPrices are exhorbitant - food and spa treatments.We had three bad room service experiences in a row: getting order wrong; missing parts of the order; mediocre quality; long wait.

Perfect. Deluxe room was absoutely amazing - KatD59 described it very well. Bathroom and walk in closet are flawless - couldn't think of a tiny suggestion for improvement. Concierge was helpful in planning, directions, restaurant recommendations, printing restaurant photos, writing instructions for taxis. Included breakfast was very good. Direct access underground access to subway. Expensive, but great value.

The rooms are are some of the largest in Tokyo and the Deluxe room was more like a suite with a separate walk in closet, sitting area, tea service, cafe table, bedroom area and large spa bathroom. Floor to ceiling windows all across one wall. Some rooms overlook Imperial Gardens and have a full view of the gardens. Amazing spa bathroom....2 separate sink areas, shower, toilet room, spa tub with control for lighting, music, et more. So relaxing. Loved the large closet with dressing area and makeup mirror, safe, valet door. Needed a full orientation to the room just to understand all the controls available. Service was superb. Dining off the lobby was just fine with afternoon tea. Bakery and cafe on the lower level was great with Peninsula dessert kitchen. Wonderful swimming pool overlooking Imperial Gardens and had a great massage in the Spa. I can't think of a better place to stay in Tokyo. Will try our best to get back here!!

Well, I didnt try the restaurant but the service level and the quality of accomodation are excellent. the location is very good too either for night life or for the Maranouchi/ Otematchi business district. The hotel is also right on top of the subway station which'll take you to Roppongi Hills in 20mins bed to desk. Not quite as deluxe as the Mandarin at Nihonbashi but the location makes up for it.

Centrally located a stones throw from Hibya Metro station and the imperial palace this hotel is amazing. Attentive staff, a fabulous room and a decent gym and spa. Expensive and I guess you are paying for the 'peninsula' brand but I loved it.

We stayed here for four nights. Like others mentioned, the loction can't be better. Room is pretty with great size. Everything in the room is prefect. It's a pricey hotel so we expect the service could be better. Slow check in (it took us about 30 minutes) and luggage services. They didn't refill or replace bath and shampoo sets everyday. I think a 5 star hotel should at least refill the bath and shampoo bottles. Peninsula only provided one set (shampoo, conditioner and shower gel). For a family like us, one set was not enough for two days. When seeing the almost empty bottles, we felt not staying in a luxuary hotel. The neighborhood is great. We like the location very much though we think the service is just average. We visited Tokyo several times and this one is our top choice so far.

Stayed in the executive suite, the suite is wonderful as always with great technologies and attention to details that are already mentioned before. I just want to point out something.I used their limousine service (which is ridiculously expensive) for return airport transfer. The staffs who greeted me at the airport are nice and friendly, however, I feel that the drivers (from airport and from hotel) are somewhat cold and unfriendly, maybe it's because of their lack of english skill. I expect more from the Peninsula legendary service, but the service at the hotel cannot be faulted.Room service menu also needs an upgrade, the menu listed is not worth the expensive price and it lacks of authentic japanese food.

Overall a 5 Star Hotel, however, the restaurant / lounge ("Peter") could use some work. Located right in the middle of Tokyo - views of Palace from high floors.Checked-in late an got upgraded to a suite on the 22nd floor. Main room was maybe 25' x 12' with huge King size bed, built in desk, couch and chairs facing TV, Floor to ceiling drapes with MASSIVE ELECTRONIC controls - EVERYWHERE. 50" TV, Bamboo woven ceiling, Fax, Modem, Printer, 100 + 200 V outlets, Full Mini Bar, Internet Radio.Room was hot and humid at check-in. Couldn't figure AC controls (no specific temp numbers) so called desk and had them send up help to fix it - took to long for service to arrive - so told them to set to 21 degrees C and went to bar ("Peter"). Returned to perfect room temp and you can adjusted humidity level as well. Bathroom. Huge tub, 2 sinks on separate walls, shower, Toto (Star Trek) toilet system, 2 american style robes etc. They should move the sinks to the same wall to make the 15 x 15 room even bigger.Closet - Walk in 10 x 12 room - build in table with mirror, 2 japanese robes, Safe, Hair Dryer, Nail Dryer etc. Separate locked Valet Closet for laundry, shoe shine or package delivery. Bar/Restaurant: This was the only disappointment. We went up for drinks at midnight. we ordered to Grapefruit and Vodka - has zero vodka in either drink. Appetizers were OK - nothing special and expensive. View was mediocre and furniture looked cool - but was not comfortable.Check In/Check Out: Very efficient.

Everything about our stay was great - the rooms, service, front desk, concierge, which you can gather from other reviews ....I will therefore focus & highlight the extra touch:- Our reservation at Peninsula Tokyo was spread over two bookings because we decided to stay in Hakone for one night to properly enjoy the onsen (hot spring) and ryokan (traditional inn) experience. We had left our luggage bags at Peninsula and when we returned from Hakone to re-check in, we were pleasantly surprised to learn our bags were already in our new room. This is great initiative. - Hubby and I are food lovers and the concierge desk had really good suggestions on where we could fulfill our yakitori, okonomiyaki, unagi, sushi, ramen cravings. These suggestions were also convenient to get to. They did not push for dining within the hotel, which is something we experience in hotels in other countries. - The complimentary Rolls Royce ride (when car is available and for 2km radius) is a great service - pampers the soul and helps the wallet (cab rides in Tokyo can be hefty if you are used to New York, Shanghai, Singapore, etc prices). What shone for us was how the driver went out of his way to ensure (1) we stayed dry when we were alighting in wet weather and (2) show us the way amidst a busy Tsukiji market to a sushi chain that he had suggested in response to our one innocent question on where we could find good sushi in the market. - I was having a cold and requested for hot water. On both occasions (as we checked in twice), a hot thermos (re-boilable) flask and kettle were brought to the room within five minutes of request. I also requested for support pillows (tempur shaped), which they had and it was great for my blocked nose.- Other reviewers have also mentioned the bottled Fiji water, gym shoes, swim cap and goggles that they discreetly offer for your workout. These are really thoughtful, but I further love the "wet swimsuit dryer", "spare plastic bag", "comb" and "mouthwash" in the ladies locker room. So much thought put into considering the guests' needs, both before and after. - Coffee was great. They had the Lavazza coffee capsules, which in my opinion, taste far better than the nespresso ones. We did prefer the creme & aroma flavor than the other type which we thought tasted a bit sour. Having said that, both had strong body and did its job of perking us up in the morning.- VOIP phone: we love this feature of Internet telephony because it helps to save international call charges. The Peninsula in Shanghai offers free VOIP calls, which is fantastic. The Tokyo VOIP service comes with local call charges for international VOIP calls. Was very reasonable: just about JPY249 for a short call. Wasn't timing the clock as I was speaking to my dearest two year old back in Singapore. It probably was for around 5-10 min since she can't yet carry a good conversation!- the remote control panels on both sides of the bed (Yes, hubby and I like to lounge and laze!). Would be even greater if the blinds had remote control too :)- love the TV remote control. It is one of those that does not need you to figure out where to aim for the right spot ;D

Let me start by saying that rooms are awesome, there's incredible attention to every little bit (which extends to overall concierge service) - sadly, it's not a perfect hotel as all food is incredibly expensive and you can't get away for less than $150 per person for a meal that's not breakfast (don't breathe a sigh of relief, $80 is completely normal to start the day) and barely includes a couple dishes - and that's without alcohol! That's before adding that the food itself isn't superb. So if you stay here, I suggest you dine elsewhere.

We stayed for three nights at the end of our two weeks trip to Japan in August.The location is great to explore Tokyo particularly Ginza shops. Although arrival reception was excellent and service level in all area quite good, we could not but compare the property with the Hong Kong Peninsula where we stayed in April. Somehow it lacks the grandure of the latter,maybe its the cramped lobby restaurant that one has to pass through or the feeling that the property is trying to save money on room amenities ,although the room rate is quite pricy compared to HK Penin,room is excellent and sizable,but things like no welcome fruit basket,had to request a new shampoo set for two days in a roll and its hot in August so daily hair wash is needed.no turn down sweets.When we travel we like to experience a homely atmosphere.Breakfast like most Penin ,has very small selection.It seems here its like a business hotel or may be this is Tokyo.

We went to Tokyo with a little skepticism about staying here after reading the reviews. Yes the restaurants were a pricey, as our most good restaurants in Tokyo, yes the spa treatments could be better and are expensive, but other then that with each passing day we loved the place more and more. We were there for five nights, toured Japan for two weeks and then so happy to come back to our home at the Peninusla for another three nights. The staff there is just amazing. So friendly, so efficent, so knowledgable, it feels like you are home. The rooms are huge, modern, comfortable and a pleasure to hang out in. The swimming pool is fantastic and the people who work in the spa are so kind and helpful one can relax and feel completely taken care of. The lobby takes some getting used to with its zen simplicity, but it grows on you and works. The breakfasts is great, the coffee latte yummy, and the breads wow. Some of the luxury hotels in Tokyo have a heavy feeling to them. The Peninusla feels like and fresh. We liked it so much we enjoyed staying in our rooms even though all of Tokyo beckoned. When we did leave the location a few blocks from Ginza was ideal. We cant wait to find anotehr reason to return to the Peninusla Tokyo.

We've stayed here 3 times before but still managed to get surprised by the fantastic level of service on our recent visit. The coordination from Front Desk to concierge, to the bell boys, and even to the gym, was all incredibly smooth. For instance, on our departure, we had a midnight flight out and they kindly allowed us to use the gym facilities to freshen up before our flight after an afternoon in the hot sun. When we got to the gym in the evening, they were already expecting us, and when we got downstairs the concierge had our bags ready and a taxi waiting. All the concierges were fantastic, seamlessly booking all our restaurant reservations and on short notice getting us into 2 restaurants that usually need 1-2 months of advanced booking. Also love the detailed maps they provide for each booking. The location, in our opinion, is better than the other top hotels in the Ginza and Marunouchi area, right beside the Palace and right in the middle of Ginza, between many of the best restaurants in Tokyo and some of the best shopping. Right in front of the hotel, there is a beautiful and popular 5km jogging route around the Imperial Palace, past cherry trees and moats, and there is a map in your room of the route.The Deluxe room has a great layout, with a large walk-in closet that gets a lot of use (to drop off the shopping, try on the new stuff, etc), and a large bathroom with his & her sinks. The main room has a comfortable and usable living room area with a sofa, and cool tech like automatic curtains, espresso machine, free and fast wifi, etc. The rooms with the park view have a lovely view of the excellent imperial palace. A few other random things we love about the Peninsula Tokyo: the complimentary Rolls Royce car service (seriously, how do you top this), the gym has running shoes if you forgot yours, the pool has swimming goggles which no one ever travels with, and everything is offered to you so discretely, and quite perfectly.

This is a beautiful hotel in a very central part of Tokyo. The views from the higher rooms are pretty good (the lower rooms I suspect have pretty average views). The rooms have also got to be one of the better hotel rooms I have stayed, they are just magic. Nothing is forgotten and the design is exceptional. I didn’t eat at any of the restaurants in the hotel and the bar was closed for a private function, which I found extremely annoying (???). I did have room service and it was very average and approaching inedible…I was hungry and it was late. Now for the really bad, the staff at the hotel were lazy, unhelpful, poorly trained and worst of all argumentative?? Particularly the front desk and the concierge. It was just extremely annoying how hopeless they were. A true contrast with the Park Hyatt where I had stayed a few days earlier.
