Regardless of this I did enjoy my stay purely due to the exceptional quality of the rooms. For reference I stayed in a deluxe park view room on a high floor.

This is a hotel for which when reviewing it, the 'value' for money box can't really get checked. It's priced as it is - one of the best 5 star hotels in Tokyo. So this is not a 'value' option as such. If you can afford this, quite frankly you are in for one of the best hotel experiences anywhere in Asia. The rooms are plush, elegant, functional and extremely comfortable.The views of the Imperial Palace are stunning, especially at daybreak or sunset. The staff have two fabulous characteristics - one, they work for the Peninsula so are trained to extremely high standards. Two, they are predominantly Japanese, so you are getting some of the highest quality 'aim to please' staff on the planet.The location is great, next to the shopping and offices of Maranouchi and Ginza and both Hibiya Park and the Imperial Park. Quite frankly, every aspiring hotel chain should send its staff to this hotel - it would teach everyone a thing about excellent, discrete and incredibly polite service in a tremendous property. A colleague of mine swears by the Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo (about 1km away). I have not stayed there because although the MO may rival the Peninsula, I just doubt anything could actually beat the outstanding experience I consistently get at this truly luxury hotel. This was my 10th visit here. To me the mark of a great hotel is that every time, the service levels are so consistently good. They have yet to disappoint me.

The Peninsula Tokyo is an amazing hotel, ideally located in Ginza area.Perfect for business trips and holidays.They even have their own metro exit!This hotel is up to the Peninsula standards, with the signature control panel to control everything in your huge room. They have all the amenities you would expect from a Peninsula Hotel: Coffee machine, minibar, flat screen TV, internet connection, A/C, in room safe, etc. Bathroom are huge and beautiful. The only "disturbing" point is the toilet control panel, but it's standard in japanese luxury hotels! I will let you experience it!Regarding the lobby, I just have a comment: when you pass the rotating doors, you will have to walk a "central alley" with on your left people having their breakfast, and on your right a "waiting area" with tables and sofas. This is a little bit strange feeling. The sculpture located at the end of the alley is beautiful!Do not miss the old Rolls-Royce usually parked on the right side of the hotel. It's painted in the Peninsula signature green, a really beautiful car, in perfectly working condition!We stayed on the 20th floor, so the view was amazing! Try to get a room as high as possible.The Peninsula Tokyo is really a top hotel. They even anticipate the future, as a rooftop helipad is already built, but the access door is hidden behind the wallpaper, as it is not yet authorised to fly an helicopter in Tokyo City. All they will have to do is a small cut in the wallpaper, and they are almost ready to transfer guests directly from airport to the hotel! Wow!The concierge is really efficient and knowledgeable, providing you with any information you will need regarding the surroundings, the restaurants and bars, what to do, and so on.During our stay we experienced a major earthquake, above 5 on Richter scale. Everything was shaking, cracking... frightening experience, but the building is still in place, with no cracks anywhere. It has been designed on purpose, with a big empty area in the middle. Have look at it, though the windows on every floor, facing the elevators, you will discover a beautiful sculpture!The bar view is stunning, so feel free to get up-there in order to have a drink or two! (かんぱい, Kanpaï which means Cheers!)Enjoy your stay in this Peninsula, among the best Peninsula hotel in the world! Your standards will definitely shift to a higher level. It will be hard for other hotels to reach this level of quality, worldwide.さようなら (Sayonara, which means Good-bye!)

Family holiday - very comfortable room and amenities and an excellent bed/pillows. Spacious - separate walk in closet area and spacious bathroom. Close to Ginza - walking distance and of course close to many many restaurants. Fresh fruit platter in room. Excellent staff and service. Good for holiday if a bit pricey.

When I first got there, the first thing I could think was WOW. The lobby was wonderful, the staff were nice, and wow it was really modern. After we checked in (the staff were really nice) they took us to our room, and then they told us they upgraded our room. We were really happy. Also, what I noticed was their rooms are pretty big compared to the rooms in other hotels I stayed in Tokyo.After that, all I could think of was to just laze around in this more then perfect room. After all that though, I noticed there were kids slippers, robes, and a snack plate since when I reserved the hotel I clicked on one kid (my little brother). After that we walked around Ginza which was very nice. We shopped for a long time and we found really nice things.After that when we went back I decided to get room service. Woah, their prime rib was good and so was their service. They set the table up as if we were actually going to a restaurant. The next day was check out day and all I could think of was how I would miss this place.

I stayed here again for a couple nights last week. It is one of the best hotels in Tokyo. The room was spacious by Tokyo standard. There were a lot of nice small things to make the stay more comfortable. Free Internet, universal electrical plugs, coffee machine for coffee and instant hot water, Internet radio for channels from many countries, different light modes including a spa mode in the bathroom all helped to enhance my experience.I like particularly the large walk-in closet. We could leave our luggages open on a bench, change our clothes, dress up and make up, and pack our luggages all in the closet. There is even a box for housekeeping to leave us the morning newspaper or other things from outside the room.The hotel is close to the shopping area in Ginza, and two blocks away from a JR station to go to other areas in the city. The JR station and the subway stations are connected underground in the area with access to many buildings and department stores. The temperature was high on those days. So my strategy was to go underground at the closest subway entry/exit.

This hotel is in the Ginza district near the Imperial Palace.The neighborhood is very nice and there are an endless number of posh places to shop and outstanding places to eat within an easy walk.The lobby is nice but is a bit small for a hotel this size so its not a good place to meet and there is a restaurant that spans the lobby...very odd and noisy but the food and service are very good.The rooms are very large...even more so considering that it is Tokyo. Comfortable, quiet with plenty of room to relax or work.The location is very good in Ginza and the proximity to the Palace mean you can get out for a walk or run or just to experience something other than concrete and see a horizon.

Not cheap hotel but good location deserve some premium. The hotel the rooms are very nice in general especailly if you ask park view high level rooms. the spa is very modern fantastic swimming pool very clean and tidy, there is all you need at high standards/ Live music band at lobby male it even nicer at first arrival, you wont see a guest arriving without a happy smile in the face if you sit in the lobby nicely decorated with arts and wooden furniture. Modern and uptodate equipment at all levels makes your life easier. the rooms are fully centrally operated by single tool at bed side, It is great to have the control. Everything is ok except service can become terribly bad if you cannot overcome a huge barrier of language and be able to explain what you want how you want. We have taken breakfast for 3 consecutive days and every time it became very bad experience. Last day we had to wait for 30 minutes for wrong delivery. They misunderstand every word you say in English therefore I suggest you speak very simple English and order only by pointing out a menu item. Even with that I can assure you will suffer delays and mistakes. Other than service/language problem this hotel is very good place to stay in Tokyo

Anyone who loves shopping in Tokyo must stay at The Peninsula, which is by far, the best located hotel for convenient shopping.Granted, Shibuya has hotels too, but they are not as nice as the Pen. Rooms are luxurious, with well-thought-out amenities, and comfortable beds. Even standard rooms have a sofa and coffee-table facing a large flat-screen TV, and a roomy walk-in wardrobe with dressing table. Service is professional and friendly, and food is great, although pricey. I particularly like their Chinese restaurant, Hei Fung Terrace, and its Cantonese food and courtyard-style decor.The lobby cafe is modeled on the one in their flagship Hong Kong hotel, and has excellent live jazz music in the late afternoon.But the shopping! The hotel is located at the start of Ginza, which has been renewed and re-invigorated as a stylish shopping district. The main road is even closed to traffic on Sundays. International luxury brands are well-represented here, as well as local stores like Uniqlo (largest in the world), a new Barney's New York, which is next to Comme des Garcons' first Dover Street Market outside London. Fuddy-duddy Mitsukoshi department store has been stylishly made-over, as well as the stunning Hankyu mens store. There is a new Marui store with m10 floors of fashion and food. Top Tokyo labels like Beams, United Arrows, Estnation and Tomorrowland, all have outposts within the sidestreets that branch off the main road, and everything is within walking distance of the Peninsula, so watch your wallet!

The best thing about the Peninsula is the convenient location, and that the staff are generally pretty accomodating. For my taste, I found that there was too much furniture in the rooms- (I had a suite room) and the asthetics of the decor is not pleasing, generally-speaking. Peter Restaurant has nice city views- but is also not worth the price. Service was very slow. I would have a drink in Peter Bar (which is cheerfully decorated) and enjoy some bar food, then go out somewhere fun for dinner, such as to a local sushi bar in Tsukiji, or Two Rooms (Restaurant) in Aoyama if you'd like to enjoy Western-style (continental) fare. The spa is shockingly tiny and cramped, the gym not worth the effort. Massage treatments were average for a Peninsula Hotel (Los Angeles Penainsula is SO MUCH BETTER) and the treatments are way too expensive- even for Tokyo. I would go for an outside massage service such as Alyssa: http:massagebyalyssa.wordpress.com/ Her massage is less expensive, plus she will come to your room- allowing you to relax and fall asleep when your session is over. The bottom line is that in a city like Tokyo, the Peninsula Tokyo cannot compare to Grand Dame Hotels such as The Imperial Hotel or The Okura. Although both of those hotels have seen better days, they have excellent staff who pay atttention to every detail. I would say the only (newer ) 5-Star hotel which comes close to the service I require is the Mandarin Oriental. Lovely rooms, well-trained staff, fabulous bar with live entertainment, but the restuarants and spa are also very over-priced-- even for Tokyo.That's my two cents!
user_name:
bloggy99
New York City, New York

review_body: Great hotel (though pricy) and its location can't be faulted because of proximity to Imperial Palace, but also to the subway and the JR lines at Yurakucho. Great pool and hot tub as well, much needed after a day spent walking the city. Also try the iPod walking tour of Hibiya Park and the Imperial Palace, available from the concierge. Didn't try Peter or the other restaurants upstairs, but the lobby restaurant is very good (but expensive). Instead we ate at one of the excellent little hole-in-the-wall eateries in "Corridor Street" alongside the Shinkansen tracks nearby . Locals only (but there's an English menu), great food and very reasonable indeed. (Go down Harumi Dori street alongside the hotel, then under the railway bridge, turn right at Game! store). Also, there are loads of little restaurants in the basements of office buildings behind the hotel towards Yurakucho station. Japanese food, and also Japanese versions of Italian and Spanish food. One warning: check-in is 3pm at the Peninsula, so if you arrive early off an international flight they will try to offer you an upgrade for an immediate room. Can be an expensive extra, but worth it if the price is right.

Stayed there three nights in early July. I can only echo the raves in other reviews about the staff, location and service, but I can point out some tiny blemishes as well. Think of them as tiny spots on a million-dollar gemstone, please...* I am a big gadget fan and I still believe this room went overboard on the control panels, having more than 20 that I could count. Some consolidation via touchscreens [akin to Las Vegas CityCenter] would help.* Not sure why there was no numerical temperature setting, just a few levels of warm & cold.* The lobby area lacks a private feel. Walking out the front of the hotel feels like walking straight through a busy restaurant. I think some more dividers could help.* The pool/spa hours for families [9-6pm I was told] are not ideal. I would prefer a mixed weekly schedule so we could at least have 1 evening to swim without disrupting our sightseeing.* Elevators and some common areas were freezing cold!* Breakfast is exorbitantly expensive [at least 4000 yen a person]. We did it one morning and it was extremely good, but it is just painful to spend that much money. Even given these points, however, this is truly an amazing place to stay. Rooms feel comfortable and have an extremely well-thought-out design. You're right above Tokyo Metro and a block from the Yamanote line. Also, the pool/spa areas are stunning. We will absolutely be back.

5 star perfection. High end, plush- best accomodation we have ever stayed in. Greeted by bellman, escorted from front desk to room, given overview of room- from unique operation of coffee maker to use of blinds on windows. Staff was at our beck and call entire week. I cannot compliment this property too much!!!

Stood there 3 Months on a business trip.Service is excellent. More than excellent. The best I ever had.The room is perfect for business: printer, desk, dressing room is roomy and well-organised. The bathroom is spatious enough and has a tub and a shower. Toilets are Japanese-style.Bed: Amazinginly comfortable.Food: A bit expensive but very good. (especially the Chinese restaurant)Breakfast: Exepnsive here too but great variety of choices and options.Location: Metro very near. Near to Tokyo Station. Many restaurants nearby (and rather expensive shops)Concierge: Anways helpful. Can do anything for you.Gym and pool: gym is small but well-equipped. If you forgot your trainers, they give you some... Pool is amazing (large enough for training)Bar: OK. Nothing too fancy (Hyatt bar better). It's a smoking area.Laundry: Impeccable. They even mend your clothes for free (small holes or lost buttons...).Haven't been to the spa.To sum it up: If you can afford it, definitely go. It's beyond expectations.

A wonderful place to stay, with amazing staff who really can't do enough to make you feel welcome. Our room was stylish and comfortable and very well thought out. Everything is where you would expect it to be and we really couldn't fault anything. Pricey but worth it and we will be back.

this was my first trip to tokyo and stayed here, it really is an amazing hotel. Its just perfect. Whilst I did find things a little overpriced I presume that is just tokyo in general. other than that I really enjoyed my stay here, the staff are extremely friendly, helpful and respectful. It is also in a great location.

This is easily the best Peninsula hotel, if not the the most luxurious hotel accommodation that I've stayed. Centrally located with lots of shops and restaurants abound (including Michelin ones), walking distance to the famous fish market and wonderful base to explore the bustling Tokyo streets. The hotel was everything and more than what we expected for a Tokyo hotel as this was our second trip there. The room was large (especially by Tokyo standards), well-appointed with walk-n wardrobe/dressing tables on the right and a bathroom on the left (complete with the jacuzzi spa experience as you soak in the bath with water cascading down the walls as one dim the lights, his/her sinks, separate shower stalls). Bedroom and separate living room were tastefully decorated in warm gold hues, state of the art technology/lighting and even a mini bar for you to make your own coffee. Service wise - The staff were very helpful and professional. They gladly assisted in our dining reservations at the top restaurants prior to our trip and upon our arrival at the check-in, they even provided us with the print-out map and all the relevant details to the restaurants. Would definitely stay there again if we revisit Tokyo.

I have to admit to a bias for Japan, I love the country and business wise it's being good to me. Same as all over America, can't help but look for the best. I love both countries, so I get there looking for the best. This is the first time though I've stayed at the Peninsula in Tokyo, I've stayed at all of the Peninsula hotels apart from Manila in the last year.What can you say, great, excellent, suburb...from the airport collection to the departure...western food is good, location is perfect and being Japan you can enjoy a great nighttime walk around without any concern for your safety. If you fancy shopping it's very close although why anyone would shop in Tokyo I don't know, the shops are wonderful but the prices...ouch...Negatives, I organised a car from the airport and it was £500 each way....$750 USD. I understand it's related to the government and pushing people onto the train but it's worth knowing. Also gym is small, all good equipment but I could see it getting busy. A nice touch is the trainers (sneakers) available from the hotel in all sizes to borrow...swimming pool is great, nice setting...The staff are beyond attentive....beyond helpful..service is beyond good..Now Peninsula hotels, sort out Chicago, hire some staff, sort out the check in and Beverly Hills...seriously is that what you call a gym...isn't it the place for healthy people...Peninsula hotels need to get their cheque book out in LA and Chicago to get close to Tokyo, HK or Shanghai...

Satyed here for a week for business. I love this hotel. Rooms are enormous. Service is everything you would expect from Peninsula. Location is ideal if you are there for work. Nightlife in Ginza is right down the street. Food is great. They actually ask you if you want your bacon crispy. Pet peeve of mine when traveling is soggy bacon. They got it. If you have the means, stay here.

My wife and I stayed at the Peninsula Tokyo and were blown away with this beautifully staffed, serviced and appointed hotel. Great location - walk , buss or train - day or night shopping, sights and attractions are right on your doorstep. Literally we could shop at high end stores or mingle with the locals in the many close by shopping markets and trendy precincts with market stalls offering every thing imaginable for any budget. Just cannot describe the luxury of this place to do it justice. Beautiful huge rooms that make every night a joy to relax in and wonderful helpful staff make this hotel stand out from the rest. The in house dinning is to die for and the bar on the 24th floor is a must see - imagine drinking in the sights of Tokyo at night with glass windows framing a wall to ceiling view of the neon city pulsing below - it is truly magnificent. The bed was heaven - the bathroom is gorgeous, absolutely impeccable.The staff are first class , very helpful, incredibly polite - even with our 3 word grasp of Japanese - nothing was an issue , they know their town and will make sure you have a wonderful stay. Worth every Yen , if you can stay at the Peninsula you will not want to leave.

Located at the heart of the Tokyo city, right next to the shopping area of Ginza, it’s the best location I've stayed in Tokyo. Great Service, the concierge recommended several sushi restaurants in walking distance, they are all excellent. Wonderful view of the Palace from Grand Deluxe room, spacious bathroom and closet, complimentary shoes shining service is superb Need improvement in breakfast

Our visit to the Peninsula Tokyo marked our first stay at a Peninsula property, but it won't be our last. The building and the facilities (especially the stunning pool) are beautiful. The service was very good, but we found it a bit less warm and gracious than the Four Seasons (we also stayed at the Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi on this trip). The check-in staff are very good at their jobs: they upsold us on a room upgrade and we checked in to a lovely suite with a terrific view of Ginza and the Shinkansen tracks leading south of Tokyo. The suite had a guest bathroom, a large living room with a wall of windows, a dressing area and large bathroom and a serene, comfortable bedroom. We were fascinated by the technological aspects of the room (the coffee service, the lighting, the heating and cooling, the only-in-Japan electronic toilets) and really enjoyed trying to figure out how everything worked. The Peninsula is in a terrific location - within walking distance of a park, the Imperial Palace and gardens and lots of high-end shopping. It's a great base for exploring Tokyo and even though we had been to Tokyo before, we discovered new things on this visit and found that we appreciated Tokyo all the more. A highlight of our stay was the complimentary (with a suite) three-hour use of a chauffeur-driven Mini Cooper Clubman to take you anywhere you want to go (within a fixed radius from the hotel). Thanks to our lovely driver (who helped us map out an itinerary), we visited a museum and a park and drove around the exterior of the Imperial Gardens. We had one dinner at Peter, the oh-so-trendy restaurant on the top floor of the hotel. While the view was amazing and the service very good, the food was a bit too modish and the overall scene a bit too much for a relaxing, enjoyable meal - it felt like a nightclub/restaurant rather than a top-flight restaurant. We also had one dinner in the ground floor restaurant that takes up two sides of the entrance lobby (with a walkway in the middle). The food and service were just okay, and the placement of the restaurant in the lobby (on the way to the front desk) makes it feel a bit like you're eating in a hallway. The pool and spa is in a large two-story space with floor-to-ceiling windows that face the Imperial Gardens. The pool is large and there are plenty of chairs for seating and relaxing. The separate steam room is up a spiral staircase and down a quiet hallway. We greatly enjoyed our visit to the Peninsula Tokyo and look forward to seeing what else Peninsula has to offer in other cities - we already have reservations at the Peninsula Beverly Hills for an upcoming trip to Los Angeles. We highly recommend the Peninsula Tokyo - it's a terrific hotel.
user_name:
MJPBAF
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: My husband, our 8 year old daughter and I spent last week in Tokyo on holiday. Our overall Tokyo experience far exceeded our expectations, in part due to our stay at this world renowned hotel. This is a first class establishment in every way from the gentleman who gave us a thorough tour of our room upon check in, to the staff on hand at the pool, to the servers at breakfast and finally to the desk staff who bid us good morning and sweet dreams each day~ all in perfect English. We had a hard time leaving our room each day it was so luxurious yet cozy. The bed and bedding was ultra comfortable and there was no need to leave thanks to the bedside controls to everything in the room! Immediately after checking in we found child sized slippers and a robe along with children's bath products for our daughter. All of the special details in the rooms have been mentioned in previous reviews. The closet/dressing area, the in room coffee/tea service, the toilet gadgetry and the daily paper in our private delivery box were some of our favorite things. There is a blow dryer in the room and the bath products were wonderful. The drawer was stocked with extra toiletries (razor, hair brush, comb, tooth brushes, etc). We did have to ask for an iron but they brought it right away and left it in our room all week which we appreciated.The location is ideal, right across from Yurachuko station with plenty of great restaurants within a few minutes walk. We walked to the fish market every morning (15 minute walk) and strolled through Hibiya park right across the street. The main shops are just a few blocks away (5-10 minute walk) which was perfect for us. Breakfast was included for us and it was a treat! Many reviewers mention the lobby restaurant being front and center as strange but we didn't find it unusual at all. This was one of our best vacations yet and certainly the most memorable hotel experience to date. We couldn't find one single flaw with anything here. The elevators were always quick up to/from our 19th floor room, our room was cleaned quickly and was spotless each day and every encounter with a hotel employee was above and beyond top notch service.

first class luxury from the moment you enter! all staff were extremely attentive and responded immediately to any questions or requests. we were upgraded to a palace view room, accompanied by a very friendly and knowledgeable concierge member to our room to highlight all of the room's features as well as the incredible highlights of Tokyo's skyline in our view. Bed was the comfiest ever, bathroom amazing with the light and sound settings powered from the bath tub.

We used to live in Tokyo and we stay at the Peninsula whenever we're back (about once or twice a year). The rooms are beautiful and some of the best we've experienced. We particularly love the blinds that completely block out any light, allowing for some of the best sleep we've had in a hotel room. Service is also very good (fresh fruit in your room every day and a Lavazza coffee machine) and the location is unbeatable (within walking distance of Ginza and at least four train lines). We try to avoid having breakfast there because it's extremely expensive even for Tokyo and there are more reasonable and delicious options outside, but the restaurant is popular among locals as well.

Like all other Peninsula properties, this hotel is up there with the best city hotels in the world. It is located in a superb location. It has spacious, luxurious and very high tech rooms. The staff is attentive and they do their best to make you feel comfortable.I do not agree with some other people here who write negative reviews based on "service" or "expensive room service". I found the service to be very good, and prices reflect the city the hotel is based in and the kind of hotel Peninsula is.
I stay at the Peninsula whenever I travel to Tokyo on business. This is an exceptional hotel in all aspects. Truly second to none. FYI - The Spa is one of the best in the world.
user_name:
Stephen L
New York City, New York

review_body: When we checked in we were given a room with two full size beds, not the size bed two Americans can sleep in. When we called the front desk we were told they were sold out and could not accommodate our request. We insisted and then the manager told us they had a suite that would be at an extra charge. We looked at it and decided that it was worth the expense. There was no turn down service the first night and there was no water available. I had to ask for my water. The worst part of my hotel experience, we stayed the twice in one week and both times when the car pulled up they opened the door for my husband and the trunk for the luggage and left me sitting both times! Not once did they ever open my door! The toilets are great at the hotel and the front desk staff was friendly, but overall experience with manager was not satisfying as my husband has stayed here before and did not receive recognition for his loyalty, next time we will try the Four Seasons.

This is the hotel that has the best rooms we have ever been. The rooms have king size beds, soft pillows (we even decided to buy some pillows there to bring home), eletronic controls for everything (air conditioning, air humidity!!!, curtains, lights, tvs, water temperature, expresso cofee maker, tea, clocks, and so on). The bathrroom has a very nice and confortable bath tub, the lightning is perfect with dimmers and memories everywhere. The telephone sets light up when they sense your presence. Each room is spacious, with sofa, table and chairs, a big bathroom and a big and well furnished closet for lugagge with a big mirror. It has everytihing to make our stay very confortable. And the concierge is attentive and efficient.We loved so much to stay here.

Since our last stay a few years ago, been itching to stay again at the Peninsula Tokyo. However, prices were not cheap at all.... finally May 2012, we got a decent price with cheap air tickets, hence we stayed 3 nights at the Pen Tokyo. Everything was wonderful. Check in was fast, non smoking room requested. They had our room ready, and key was ready, and even offered us late check out if we needed. We didn't because our flight was in the middle of the afternoon. Check out is at noon.The rooms are as beautiful and well maintained as before. Quiet, clean, spacious, and the only thing I noticed was they took away the mobile phone unit that they used to have in the room for guests to take out of the hotel while sightseeing around Tokyo. Now they don't have it anymore. The only thing I didn't like was the amenities. The body gel , shampoo and conditioner didn't feel luxurious at all. Very blah. What impressed me the most was their concierge. Thank you so much again to Sanae, and Satoru, for ALL your help. Prior to our arrival, I had requested the concierge to make restaurant reservations at the top Michelin star restaurants, and some of our favorites. Many of them were already fully booked, and many changes had to be made, and I had many questions. But each email I sent out, the concierge would reply promptly, with all the answers, and always in such courteous manner and helpful manner. Without their help, our visit to Tokyo would not be the same this time.My husband and I also had a parcel delivered to the hotel, but they didn't even bother us at all, when it arrived, they just delivered it straight to our room and in the wardrobe. Airport limousine bus drops you right in front, and on the way back to Narita, picks you right in the front, and so many staff to help you with your departure.The location is unbeatable. Close to JR, Metro exit is right underneath the hotel, you don't even have to step out to the street to access. Lawson, 7-11 's are all around. Pronto, Doutour, Starbucks, are all right behind the hotel for the morning coffee fix.We are looking very forward to our next stay, hopefully very soon.

From staff, to room, to location- best hotel ever. The rooms are exceptionally furnished and thought out. Your privacy and comfort are assured. From the awesome dressing room with a weather station to prepare for your day, to the beautiful bathroom with very amenity, to the comfortable bed. All the needs for business are available, too - wi-fi, fax and printer in the room. They even deliver your paper, laundry, etc. through a small compartment in the dressing room, making sure you are never disturbed.

Location is superb, but service was inconsistent. Hence given the expensive rate you pay, there are probably better hotels.Lobby was tiny (not grand at all) and breakfast quality was average given the price you pay. Given the limited space, you end up having breakfast in the lobby next to the walkway where everyone walks by. Rooms were relatively comfortable, with modern technology and comfortable beds.
Ginza is THE place to stay at when one visits Tokyo and the Peninsula is definitely THE hotel for lodging! Everything from service to room and food quality is excellent. No compliant whatsoever.
Service is outstanding. Rooms are luxurious. Try going to Tsukiji sushi restaurant nearby for unforgettable sushi!
user_name:
CharityLiveHK
New York City, New York

review_body: The rooms are amazing, both comfortable and highly technological. Add a great location to the typical Peninsula service and you have a terrific combination.The location is excellent with close proximity to several transport networks

Fantastic hotel experience. This is the standard that hotels need to aspire to. Everything was impeccable - the doormen, the cleaners, the reception. We were here for four nights and had a suite and I never wanted to leave. Every other hotel we have stayed in since has had the impossible task of living up to the Peninsula in Tokyo, and none have managed it. I would travel back to Japan just to stay here. It is amazing.

I spent 5 nights at the Peninsula on a friend's recommendation and it was heaven. It is not often you stay at a place and not find something that is not quite to your liking but I can't fault this hotel. The location is excellent with close proximity to several transport networks (it is located onto of one subway station) and easy walking distance to fantastic shopping and a full range of restaurant. Nothing was too much effort for the staff and they all greeted you warmly with a big smile. The rooms were luxurious with spacious walk-in wardrobe and separate bathroom. The pool & spa was also a welcome oasis at the end of the day. I will definitely be returning

The Peninsula was really really nice. Spacious rooms. Service was excellent.The lobby was a little small, and the dining area kind of took over the ground level so much that there basically is no lobby/waiting area.The food in the dining area on the other hand was extremely good and a great overall value considering you're in Tokyo.Having stayed at the Ritz recently as well, the decor/style of the Ritz was more to my taste. Obviously the Ritz is in Roppongi/Akasaka so it doesn't have the convenient shopping location of Ginza.

My friend and I stayed in a Deluxe room at this amazing place for four nights recently, during a self-guided tour of Japan. It was sensational. Believe the reviews; the rooms are extraordinary, and huge for Japan. The prices match - around £7.50 for a cappuccino in the lobby cafe area....however, this is a fabulous place, a luxurious and gorgeous experience in a wonderfully central location near some of the very best bits of Tokyo, and it even has two Subway stops within a two minute walk...what more could you ask for? You could LIVE in a place like this...if your name was Branson or Lloyd Webber or some such. Just wonderful. In our info pack from the agents who organised the various hotels on our trip for us, it noted that this place had been voted the best hotel in Asia by Conde Nast and the seventh best hotel in the world. Enough said.

As we have come to appreciate, one can always count on The Peninsula for excellence: service, location, amenities, concierge services, etc. The Peninsula in the Ginza District of Tokyo is no exception. A great deal of thought has obviously gone into the location and design of the hotel. We booked through American Express' Fine Hotels & Resorts Program, which includes early arrival when possible (didn't need it), guaranteed late check-out (used it), complimentary breakfast (very nice) and upgrades when available (rec'd upgrade to cormer deluxe from deluxe room). Our room, which combined with the bathroom and dressing areas was huge, had a partial view of the Imperial Palace. The bed, as we came to realize as we stayed at other hotels in Japan, were truly comfortable. The room decor, while not cutting-edge in design per se, was very current and soothing, which after each day pounding the Tokyo pavement was much appreciated. All of the usual hoo-hah is there: dual sinks, TOTO accessories, daily newspaper of your choice, WiFi in the room. The spa/fitness area was especially nice, with a lovely steam/sauna area, accompanied by showers with interesting functions beyond the normal waterfall showerhead. The indoor pool area was also very relaxing, and they had goggles, caps -- even suits -- should you need them. For real swimmers, the pool wasn't too warm (approx. 80-82) and there was one designated lap lane; it was roughly 20 yards long. Again, after a long day of sightseeing, it was great to come back and enjoy the respite by the pool and hot tub. What perhaps didn't quite measure-up, was the entry into the hotel, which forces you to walk through the restaurant on the lobby level, split by an open area that you traverse to get to the reception area. Concierge services and the bellman are located on the entrance side of this this area, but to get to reception you have to traipse through that area. We weren't sure what was up with that design decision. However, the subway line was accessible underneath the hotel, which was definitely a plus, and there are shopping and restaurant choices galore in the Ginza District, which is relatively low-key compared to some of the more active areas of Tokyo. Overall, we very much enjoyed our stay and feel that it enhanced our Tokyo experience by allowing us to refresh in relative peace and quiet within the megapolis that is Tokyo. We are becoming fans of The Peninsula when traveling to cities that have one (e.g., really liked the Bangkok facility as well). Our stay this time was for the first four nights of a two-week pleasure trip, and we often commented thereafter on how much we enjoyed and appreciated everything about the hotel.

We spent five days at the Peninsula and I cannot imagine staying in another hotel when in Tokyo. This was a first trip to the city and I am certain to go back and this stay had something to do with it. The service was impeccable and the room felt like home. Maybe because they give you a key instead of a card to open the door, the size of the room or even the comfortable sofa in the room to relax after a day of walking. The view also was something particular. From one side, there was the imperial palace and on the other Ginza. Overall an unforgettable experience.

We stayed at this fantastic hotel for five days. The suite we stayed in was really huge, clean and bright with great views. We contacted the concierge before our arrival for sight seeing trips, Gora Kodan reservations, and dinner arrangements - they did an excellent job. The hotel is very close to lot of eating places, shops and JR train stations. We took the train to go for local sight seeing - great and memorable experience.

Room is so big, super comfort bed, with also big bathroom and closet . Walking 5mins to shopping area Ginza! Great shops and restaurant around. 3 mins walk to subway. Great service and they also have a very nice coffee machine in ur room! Must go back every time!

Hotel is fantastic with great rooms with awesome soundproofing so sleeping in the day is easy. Breakfast in the room was one of the best I've had and pickup from the airport was expensive and more than the room. However they upgraded the BMW to the Rolls so it was an experience to be savoured...want to go back..

We stayed three nights at the Peninsula in Tokyo during the month of March. The hotel is nicely located across from the Imperial Palace and a very short walk to Ginza. The hotel has an underground connection to the Hibiya station which was convenient.The room was very large and consisted of a nice seating area and a large dressing room that was completely separate from the bathroom. The dressing room had plenty of hanging space as well as space for luggage. The bathroom was nice with separate wash basins and a large soaking tub in the middle. One of the nice things about the room was that the bathroom and dressing room areas could be completely closed off from the rest of the room via a large wooden sliding door, so there was minimal disruption if someone is an early riser. The room also featured an espresso machine.We had a nice view of Ginza from our 22nd floor room, but not all rooms have decent views. And you probably shouldn't expect to face the Imperial Palace unless you're staying in a suite. I'm not 100% certain on that, but pretty sure. Some rooms will just have views of the side of the buildings across the street; we were just fortunate.Normally I'm not a big fan of the automation that hotels put in their rooms (you know the lighting controls, etc). I find them to typically be clunky and non-intuitive and more of a nuisance than anything. However, the Peninsula far exceeds any expectations in this arena - they know how to do it right. There were control panels everywhere in the room controlling everything from lighting to temperature and humidity to the curtains and shades. There was even a panel by the desk that would tell you the current outside temperature as well as windspeed and direction. You never had to look around to find a control panel as everywhere you would want one there would be one, and every one worked brilliantly - this is the kind of automation I would put in my home. There was even a button labeled "Spa" next to the tub which would dim the lights and begin playing relaxing spa-like music in the bathroom. I've included a couple of pictures of the various types of control panels.We had breakfast every morning in the Lobby Restaurant as it was included in our room rate. The breakfast food was decent, but nothing spectacular with limited selection as part of the rate. We also ate dinner a couple of nights in the same restaurant and the experience was much nicer. The food was memorably delicious, and the ambiance was enhanced with the live music being performed in the 2nd floor balcony which was clearly designed for this purpose. The only really negative thing I would have to say about the Lobby Restaurant is that it's a bit awkward as the main path from the front doors to reception/elevators goes right through the middle of the restaurant. It makes it a little odd with people continually walking back and forth and meeting up with folks near where you're dining. Having been in the Peninsula Hong Kong, I "get" what they were trying to accomplish with the Lobby Restaurant in Tokyo - it was just oddly executed, presumably due to limited space with the floor plan of the building.We had drinks one night in the Peter bar on the 24th floor, and the views were very nice.One of the things I found most interesting about this hotel was how they chose to utilize the dead space in the center of the building where no rooms or utilities would exist. They created a work of art called The Void which extends from the 8th floor up to the 23rd floor. It's a completely black space that is filled with 24 tornado-like pieces that are suspended in the vast space. Each is illuminated by strings of lights that are wrapped around them. The elevator lobby on our floor (and presumably all of them) had 3 windows that looked out in to this space, and it was very interesting. It doesn't photograph very well due to the lighting levels, but I'm sure there are pictures online of it.Overall, the stay at The Peninsula was wonderful, with one of our favorite (if not most favorite) rooms of any hotel we've stayed in.

I stayed at the Peninsula for 6-nights in April 2012 and found it to be delightful.I've stayed at the Peninsula in the US, but never in Asia. I travel in Asia extensively, and have always enjoyed the hospitality of Japan; my experience at the Peninsula in Tokyo exceeded my already high expectations.My room had a large bathroom with two sinks, a separate changing room/walk-in closet and a large bedroom with a sitting area. Unfortunately the work-area for my computer was a bit cramped, but was acceptable. Water pressure was good and the bed comfortable with drapes that kept out the sunlight.The gym was nice and had good machines and the pool (although only 20-meters) was very nice and I was able to swim laps without problems.Morning breakfast either in the lobby or the basement was good, although a bit more limited than usual for a top-end Japanese hotel.The staff was wonderful and almost all had very good English-language skills.Overall...this was an excellent hotel, in a great location (steps/elevator for the hotel goes to the Hibyia station underneath the hotel). My only quibbles would be a rather limited restaurant selection in the hotel (although plenty of restaurants abound just steps away), and a rather limted work-space.FYI....for those who are Catholic, the Franciscian Chapel has English-language masses on Sundays, and holy days (and maybe even daily mass?), which is near the Ropping Crossing station, which is only 3-4 stops on the Hiybia line from the hotel- check out the chapel's website for detailed directions (worth prining-out the first time you visit).
The rooms are amazing, both comfortable and highly technological. Add a great location to the typical Peninsula service and you have a terrific combination.
user_name:
Sanibel_Frank
New York City, New York

review_body: These guys are a mess. The left hand doesnt know what the right is doing.Wrong meals delivered by room service, took 40 minutes to get our breakfast in the restaurant, poor service, approached by staff about matters that had nothing to do with us..... we cut short our reservation and moved to the MO as quick as we could.Let me just say that I have stayed in many hotels in Tokyo and all over Japan, and I can advise that this is by far the most over rated and over priced. Both the Mandarin Oriental and Conrad are streets ahead. Regarding breakfast, there is no buffet, which is fine, however if you are on a bed and breakfast plan, you breakfast bill is limited to 3800Y ($45) which is also fine, until you realize that the (very bad) cup of cafe latte costs 1200Y !!! $15 for a cup of coffee at breakfast. ha. add a smoked salmon bagel to that at $30 and you have hit your limit. Fancy an orange juice, or anything else ? well, now you have got to pay (alot), for a breakfast that was supposed to be included in your package.Further, when you are in a bustling city like Tokyo, you are looking for your hotel to be a refuge, an island of calm. The Peninsula is not this. You enter through the main restaurant, which is almost as noisy as the streets outside.Having stayed at other top hotels in Tokyo, I know there is much better out there, and I will not stand for this nonsense. The other contenders are just so far ahead.
The service was poor and getting decent was impossible. They really need to do something about their whole Food and Beverage Department. Whoever is running it needs to be replaced.

I hope I'm lucky enough to come back here some day. Everything about the hotel is beautiful, elegant, and luxurious. The rooms are large, the bathrooms fabulous, and everything is done to the highest standard of comfort. Really, this hotel has thought of every detail.The location is wonderful, too: just opposite the Imperial Palace, a 7-minute walk from the Ginza, and a 3-minute walk from the Yamanote Line train, which seems to connect to pretty much everything. And if you need to take the subway, there's an entrance to the Hibiya Line from the basement of the hotel!We were traveling with our granchildren, 8 and 10-year-old boys, and the hotel staff could not have been more helpful and engaging. On arrival day, there was even a table set up in the boys' room with three plates; on each was a large cookie, some mini colored marshmallows, and two small tubes of frosting so that the kids could decorate their own cookies. At every encounter--with restaurant staff, front desk, and concierge--we met with warm, excellent service. Among the luxury hotels in Tokyo, I can't imagine a better choice than this.

There is no doubt that the facilities at the Peninsula are first class. The rooms are so gorgeous you almost didn't want to leave. Bathrooms were lovely, dressing area was a very nice touch, room was comfortable and extremely inviting. Being in the room was a pleasure. My only reservation is that this was obviously a touristy hotel, which is not a bad thing in and of itself, but I suppose it depends on what you would like to experience. The staff in the hotel were so used to speaking to people in English that when we used what little Japanese we knew you could see the surprise on their faces. When we asked for recommendations on where to go to eat we were directed towards Western cuisine restaurants. When we asked how to get somewhere the first question was if we were going to take a taxi. This a luxurious hotel that serves luxurious people, but if you are like me and actually would like to get down and dirty in the place you are visiting (keeping in mind how difficult it would be to get truly dirty in Tokyo) then this may not give you what you are looking for. Also, Ginza area seemed pretty quiet after the shops closed, but I may not have been looking in the right places. Again, gorgeous hotel, friendly staff, but not really for the adventurous at heart.

We stayed 3 nights at this fabulous hotel. It is a short ride from Tokyo station and located nearby great shopping and nice restaurants. The staff (particularly the concierge staff) were exceptional, helpful and friendly. The rooms are very well appointed with nice amenities and ample sized dressing area. The bed was comfortable and had plenty of pillows. My only minor disappointment was with my massage service. The prices are quite high for a 50 minute massage (which turned out to be 30 minutes after a long Q & A) and my therapist was not as skilled as I had hoped. My husband, however, had a great massage by a therapist that "went right to work" as soon as he entered the room. You must visit the spa. It is very nice treat. We will definately be back for an other stay at this wonderful hotel.

In the best three hotels in Japan.As written in the review below, the one thing The Penninsula Tokyo has over the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo and Park Hyatt Tokyo are the size of their rooms. And what a significant difference. The rooms are immeasurably large, the bathroom is like the size of a tennis court, and the walk-in dressing room is the size of most apartments! The service is impeccable, and the proximity to Ginza shopping district is a great attraction.Very hard to compare the three hotels mentioned, but a few pointers;1. The Peninsula Tokyo has much much much larger rooms.2. The service is faultless at all three hotels.3. The Peninsula Tokyo is more service by numbers, lots and lots of door staff, receptionist and management in ther lobby. The Manadarin Oriental Tokyo is more subtle. The Park Hyatt is more discreet.4. The Peninsula Hotel Tokyo has their main dining area in the middle of the lobby, and is very crowded so even for tea, be sure to book.5. The Peninsula Tokyo is in the best location for travel to most attractions in Tokyo.Truly a magnificent hotel and their limousine service to local areas is brilliant.Be sure to ask for a Peninsula Teddy Bear and go downstairs to see their chocolatier & patisserie - wow.

Stayed at the hotel for 3 nights as a part of our japan trip. The service was very personal- they upgraded us to a better view room because of our honeymoon. The room is one the best In Tokyo, we stayed at the mandarin oriental as well but nothing compares to the size of the room at the peninsula. The happy hour at Peters bar was great with beautiful views of Tokyo. Great hotel location in the heart of Ginza overlooking imperial palace and walking distance from the famous fish market. If I had to say one bad thing, it would be considering it is such a top end hotel, it only has one main restaurant. however I would definitely go back!

We stayed at the Peninsula during the Tokyo Marathon weekend. (couple with toddler) Like other reviewers, this is our favourite hotel, despite the hefty price tag.Our Top 10 list:10. Master consoles on BOTH sides of the bed. The buttons switch off completely without that irritating green electronic glow, but if you need to check the time or adjust the aircon, just nudge it/brush any button, and the buttons are illuminated. 9. It seems silly at first, but the valet box service is a great idea, allowing you to fetch your morning paper without having to open the room door in your bathrobe or pajamas. 8. Great bathtub worthy of any spa. Well-placed controls within reach of the tub.7. Great shower, with both the rain shower and hand-held options, allowing you to use both at the same time. Can't believe other 6-star hotels don't do the same. 6. Coffee machine in the room. A nice touch. 5. Great gym/pool. If you didn’t bring your gear, they will loan you workout gear in perfect condition. 4. For a business hotel, it's surprisingly good for families with kids. We arrived to find a room equiped with child-sized bathrobe, peninsula bear logo'd slippers, bath toys (starfish and bear sponge), child-safe toiletries including a cute toothbrush kit, and a plate with little Japanese biscuits set out on the low coffee table. 3. Generous room sizes meant that instead of traipsing around town all day/night, we were quite happy to enjoy our retreat. We even ate-in and bought bento boxes from Mitsukoshi's famed food hall to enjoy our 22nd floor view. And if either parent needs to make a business call, the sliding doors and separate areas allows you to section off the areas, still leaving a generous play area in the dressing room and bathroom to muck around in. 2. Convenient location – walking distance to shopping in Mitsukoshi Ginza, Tokyu Hands in Ginza, Muji/Loft. Lots of little ramen and other food shops within a 5 min walk. For greenery, the Imperial Palace and Hibiya Park are within easy reach. 1. Impeccable service. As we were there for the Tokyo Marathon, and constantly outdoors, we sometimes returned to the hotel looking wind-blown and felt slightly scruffy walking through the lobby, but the staff provided top-notch service and even lavished lots of attention on our little 2 year old toddler. Already looking forward to our next visit. Tokyo tip: Be sure to visit Mitsukoshi's food hall. it's amazing. Direct connections below the Peninsula means that if it's raining outside, you can get from your room into the food hall and back without having to step outside at all. (Hibiya line)

We love the Peninsula. We stayed many times as a family, this time with both our kids and we have stayed a couple as well as individually and every has been great. They have actually improved our stay with kids. They have always been kid friendly but this time, the amenity package for the kids in the room was really fantastic. They provided kid size toothbrushes, bath slippers, little robes, bath toys and sponges, diaper pail, super nice cribs, anything you would want for kids. They even have kids plates and things when you order room service. It's our four year old's favorite hotel in the world and she has been to the George V in Paris and other Peninsula hotels.The rooms are wonderful but the real reason we love this hotel is the staff. They are superbly trained to meet guests needs. Once I left my wedding room behind and when we called after to see if it was still there, they had found it and mailed it immediately. The room service is also excellent.

This is a beautiful oasis in Tokyo. The accomadation are spacious with the most up to date technology which controls every aspect of the room. The staff reviews how to work eveything when they bring your luggage. The closet/dressing room is very nice for getting dressed. The spa in the hotel is one of the nicest have been anywhere in the world. Service is exceptional. If you are going to Tokyo, look no further.

I have visited several times with my family - absolutely loved it. Its a special retreat for us. The rooms are magnificent, with the most comfortable beds in the world, walk in wardrobe, rock star bathrooms and living room. Staff are always super polite and attentive. Its pricey - at around ¥60,000 per night - but a wonderful experience. Stay 2 nights to really get into the groove of the place.

We've stayed in three hotels in Tokyo and this was the best hotel so far! It may be a bit pricey but it was worth it! Very big room compared to other hotels. Our room had a King sized bed and a Queen sized sofabed, a separate dressing room, and a bathroom with his/hers sinks. They have a master electronic console by the night table where you can control everything in the room (well, except the espresso machine and the valet dumbwaiter . . .) The staff are all very helpful too! When I lost a camera and couldn't even remember where I left it, the Guest Officer was able to locate it at a mall in Roppongi! Apparently, I left it in the restroom! Now that's what you call superb service! It's walking distance from the malls and it has it's own Metro exit at the basement. All in all, I would rate it a 6/5! That's how exceptional it was!

Arriving at the Peninsular you are greeted by smiling staff in white uniforms who will push open the revolving door for you to glide through. And this is pretty much the high level of service that is provided during your stay.The rooms are exceptional: large and luxurious with fantastic views over the city - make sure to get a high floor - I was on 19 and this is fine. The bathroom and of course 'Japanese loo' are great. Make sure to have a drink in the Peter bar and/or if you can afford it a meal in the Peter Restaurant - food, service, atmospher and view all superb.Breakfast is a bit of a let down if you enjoy a relaxed buffet as the breakfast menu is set - and I do mean set - we asked for margarine instead of butter but it was not available and a little 'open' as it is located between the main entrance and the reception.Hotel location is perfect as you can pop out for a much more reasonable beer in the local bars in Ginza and even a walk to the Fish Market is possible.Overall a really top quality hotel.

This hotel is the best hotel in Asia that I have experienced, based on 3 years constant travel around the region. From it's functional and compact reception area (it's not a long walk to the lifts), to the massive modern rooms (which are very clean as expected, and enough toys and electronics to keep you too busy to log on remotely and get some work done). Would definitively recommend it.

So unforgettable the experience of our stay in Peninsula. Such an amazing vacation and stay that we've got at the hotel. The Scenery was really stunning, the city is very clean. Nothing i can say bad. The room is enough for the money to be valued. The staffs are very polite, friendly and very professional as well. The foods are nice. Perfect.! i would love to come again soon.

We spent one night in the Peninsula because my husband decided to go to Tokyo a day early rather than spend my birthday eve in the sky. What an excellent choice. The hotel is beautifully situated opposite the Palace and within walking distance of Ginza and train stations. The decor is a joy and the light instalment that runs through the centre of the building will take your breath away and it is only for hotel guests. The staff were superlative in their approach to everything. They kept wishing me happy birthday which was lovely. They organised cake for breakfast! The gym and pool are excellent! I need to stop writing now as I am gushing. This is Tokyo, so the service is always going to be good, but the Peninsula takes it to a new level and make the Peninsula Hong Kong seem a little less luxurious as a result. Will we be back? Definitely.
stayed for a couple of nights - really good overall service. not cheap but worth every Yen.

Inspired by our experience at the Peninsula Hong Kong we ventured away from our regular haunt the Park Hyatt, Tokyo and gave the Peninsula a try.Verdict - Very hard to split because they are both exceptional hotels with wondeful front of house culture and service. What we liked better about the Peninsula was the location. - Right on the Ginza strip and next to the Imperial Palace Where the Emporer himself is stumped up.It was fantastic to be 2 minutes walk to the most upmarket shopping strip in Tokyo and with the Palace next door you get a great place to go for morning walks and jogs. You can do that around the Imperial Palace perimeter gardens which are right accross the road and its a great way to start the day.We had a deluxe room in the Peninsula and we were pleasantly surprised to find that it was much larger than normal hotel rooms and beautifully appointed as you would expect from the Peninsula group. As with it's sister hotel we have stayed in the front of house staff are fantastic and they have the sort of culture that really makes you feel like you are being looked after.The appointments and features in the room are those you would expect to find in a suite and the whole place just ozzes class.In the lift lobby on the high floors there is a sculpture that stretches over most of the lift lobbies housed in its own dark mysterious area with windows in each lift lobby so that you can look at the sleek illuminated shapes in the chasm in the wall outside the lift lobbies.We think the Park Hyatt and the Peninsula are definately the two top 5 star hotels in Tokyo, but we think the Peninsula gets line honors due to the unbeatable location. Like it's sister hotels, the Peninsula Tokyo has helicopter landing facilities on the roof and the Seven Seas Aviation Lounge that is directly underneath it is a really cool lounge to sit in. It is all done out aviation style and has sections of jet aircraft wings suspended from the ceiling, as well as a number of other aviation articles placed throughout the lounge. It also has a very large glassed in balcony which you can walk out on and check out Tokyo as well as the Imperial Palace grounds. - Only one problem. - Helicopters are currently forbidden from landing there due to the close proximity to the Palace ! Whoops ! someone forgot to get the permit first. We understand that the hotel is negotiating to have helicopter landing availability with the Japanese government. - In the mean time you will have to toughen up Princess and make do with a current model Rolls Royce transfer from Narita airport. BMW 7 series also available in their fleet.Peninsula Tokyo. -if you like the best there is, this is the place for you !
Stayed here over new years . The staff were fantastic, couldn't help enough . Even gotoutthe rolls to transport oversized bags to train station. Would go back any time in tokyo

I will say, I went to Tokyo last year and I still dream of this hotel! I will forever be jaded when it comes to any other place!!The staff was incredible and helpful, the room was immaculate and the location was amazing.All of the gadgets alone make it worth every penny. Heated bathroom seats, phone that acts as a central remote for every "toy" in the room, valet service from the dressing room...all of it was perfect. (If you use the bathtub, be sure to hit the "privacy" button. The lights dim and spa music turns on. Seriously.)I can go on and on. I'd love to visit this hotel again someday!

So the Pen is what it is, a great 5 star hotel brand and Tokyo lives up to every expectation.Not cheap by any means. But if you have stayed in another Pen property this is like staying with an old friend.The rooms are amazing, the service perfect and the toilet is heated.Enough said. You want a great hotel and price isn't a consideration this is a great place to stay.

I would say one of the top three best ever experiences. Everything was right about this hotel. Location, spacious rooms (probably biggest rooms in Tokyo), service, location again and value. At first I did not even bother looking at this hotel as an option expecting it to be super expansive. Really great value. I was surprised at how much cheaper this hotel was than others similar to it in Tokyo.I honestly can’t think of one bad thing to say about this hotel. Maybe a bit too crowded, especially the lobby.

Late November. The winter chill is setting in. But that also means Christmas is round the corner. The Peninsula in Tokyo is lit up. It is a beautiful building that is superbly located. Whether it's the 7-11 or the Cartier store, you can just walk it up. The Peninsula's main entrance lobby also serves as a restaurant so it gets a bit congested, but rest assured its only the entrance. Because when you walk into your room, space is not exactly the issue!The room I had had a view of the Tokyo skyline which is beautiful but the room itself is lavish. The corridor opens up to a large bathroom on the left and a walk-in closet + cupboards + dressing room. Straight ahead is a large room with two beds, a huge tv set and a bunch of sofas and a table. The quality of the stuff is top notch and the lighting is strategic. The room is designed to help you work as well as relax. The materials used are really unique and of high quality. There is an espresso machine too.The bathroom is really the place to hang out in! The super-sophisticated Japanese toilet seat has now gone one up - the lid lifts up when it senses you! What's next, I wonder. There is a small telly in the bathroom too. Two washbasins seem to be a needless extravagance, but what the hell.Breakfast is unusual in the sense it's not a buffet. You just order one of four options and they will ply you with the goodies. Sumptuous and terrific. Cribs are an overwhelming number of switches and controls - soon you just get tired of it. Other than that, the Peninsula is really a luxurious hotel and a proper indulgence.

The hospitality of the Peninsula group is very well known and their Tokyo property delivers very well. I stayed there for a week and we were looked after from the moment we arrived at the hotel till we checked out. The quality of the deluxe room was exceptional. Initially, we were allocated a 9th floor room but wanting to have a view I had to upgrade to the deluxe rooms. From the room, there is a good view of the Imperial Palace and also the New Tokyo tower. The room is filled with gadgets and buttons and came with an espresso maker. Very very handy. I always dread staying at hotels because I like to have my coffee as soon as I wake up and having the machine is a wonderful touch. And if you need extra coffee cartridges, they were delivered very quickly. a thermometer reading of the outdoor is useful when figuring out what to wear. Every night, we were given fruits and bottles of water. Bathroom is sensational. It is well designed and for the first time, I did not see any moulds in corners. I stayed at hotels from both ends of the price spectrum and price is not really an indication of whether mould will be present or not. So it is wonderful to not be anxious every time I step into the shower. The pool is very clean and the attendant provides swimming caps, thongs and goggles. It's mandatory to wear the swimming caps and it keeps the pool free from hair. The gym is well equipped for a hotel and they lend trainers to those who did not bring their own. Service was excellent and friendly and seems to be tailored for the type of guests they receive. As we are laid back, we had a few banters while I saw the same staff being uber-polite to suit wearing stiffs. Laundry was delivered in a traditional box with a cloth wrapped around it. A bit excessive but definitely nothing to fault. I love this hotel and its staff. Nothing was ever a hassle

The Peninsula Tokyo should receive a five star rating- its location, aesthetic, spacious well-appointed rooms (complete with dressing room closet), and the service level that comes with the Peninsula brand. However, I'm giving this property only four stars: execution at a property of this stature should be flawless, and during my recent stay, it was not: (1) was given a smoking room that had a horrible odor (question-> why in the 21st century do hotels keep smoking rooms??); when I asked to change, I was told the only non-smoking room available was one with two twin beds (I've seen this movie before); when I held my ground through basic logic (i.e. what global business traveler in the 21st century wants to stay at a top flight hotel surrounded by layers of smoking odor or sleep in a child's bed?), I was finally given a non-smoking king room; (2) I had asked the concierge to get me a ticket to the Narita Express, so as to save time at Tokyo Stn later that day; I was told the ticket would be waiting for me at the concierge desk and charged to my room; later in the day, when I went to claim it, a rather curt gentleman at the concierge desk insisted I go to the reception desk because I had not paid; when I relayed the earlier conversation with the concierge desk, I did not even receive an apology-> a classic case of the straight-jacket nature of service in Japan being friendly and highly efficient only so long as some perceived rule has not been broken. Staff here needs more training.

The Peninsula  is across the street from the Imperial Palace & a close walk to Ginza, great location, almost impeccable service.  Pros:1) Food-Hei Fung restaurant. I ordered Shanghai &  food.  Both were really good. The Shanghai food was surprisingly authentic although they did not have any Chinese brown  vinegar.  The Sichuan food was also decent and almost as good as Sichuan food in HK or Sichuan-Tsuruya in basement of hotel.   Food was good but not as memorable as other Kaiseki experiences.  - Peter's.  Pretty place on the top floor of the hotel.    I liked the wall with dancing figures.   The fusion food was innovative and locally inspired.    A good  place for a break if you've had too many Japanese meals in a row.  If you are here for a panoramic view, come during the day time. I had a corner table at night and unlike the Pen in HK, there was nothing to look at.  2) Conciege.  Great useful source to help arrange for booking of restaurants.  My restaurant booking confirmation came with a printed map with additional hand written instructions.  3) serenity & an urban oasis.   Despite being so close to Ginza, stylish zen rooms plus modern gym...nice comfy spacious room with inviting bathtub.  The gym was well equipped and the large pool was in a beautiful space with high ceilings.    Except on one occasion when the next roomful of  kids were awake, my room was completely peaceful and blissfully silent.  Cons.  1) Check in experience. While service here is gracious and sincere, there was a  long line for checking in--seemed to happen daily around 12 noon to 3:30 pm.    I got into the hotel at one ish but the room was not ready til past three so I ended up eating a lunch to kill time.  When I got to the reception three ish after waiting in line a 2nd time the room was still not ready so the receptionist asked if I had any plans to "go out".    I was tired but went for a walk in Ginza. Perhaps they could try in room check in, kiosk check in or mobile phone check in.      I was here for leisure but if on a biz trip I'd have been pretty irritated.  But in sum, a nice place I would not mind coming back to.

This is my second stay – 4 days this time. In September 2010, I stayed for almost 2 weeks. Both times I had a deluxe room. It has a large walk-in wardrobe and a spacious bathroom. The long bath is separated from the standing shower and there are 2 washbasin areas on opposite sites – your partner will have his/her own. A wide range of toiletries was provided – hair brush, comb, shaver, vanity set, bath salts, shaving kit, shower cap, nails set, dental kit and the usual soap, shampoo, conditioner, bath gel. The size of the bathroom as well as the walk-in wardrobe areas are the equivalent of a small room in some hotels.The bathroom and walk-in wardrobe areas are separated from the bedroom area by a sliding door. The bedroom area consists of a sofa set with a large LCD wall mounted TV, a table by the window and double or a king size bed. In the latest stay, I had a corner room – even more spacious as there is a long corridor on entering the room door before reaching the above mentioned areas. The table by the window is great place to do your work, read etc. There is also a Lavazza coffee machine in the room. Internet connectivity was a breeze – both wired and wireless. No problems at all whether in the room or in the lobby. A bottle of water is provided each evening and everything in the room can be controlled via the control panel on the bedside table.Each morning they delivered the newspaper of my choice and also an additional newspaper. These are left in a box ie they open it from outside the room to put in the papers and I pick it up by opening the box from the inside of the room – no need to open the door to get the papers. Access to the room is via a key instead of key access card. The key needs to be inserted into a slot on the elevator panel after 10pm in order to gain access to the floor where the room is. It appears quite a lot of thought had been put into the design to ensure a good stay experience in the room. Coming off a hard day’s work, shopping or tour, the room is definitely something to look forward to – very relaxing. Kudos to the hotel for the spaciousness and good design.I tried the complimentary limo service they had to bring you to places close by. As it was raining that morning, I asked for the service and was brought to my office in a Rolls Royce! Given the excellent customer service in the hotel, I was a little surprised they missed my birthday during my latest stay - nothing from the hotel to acknowledge this – not even a card. I have had hotels give me a card and even a cake in the room – a very personalized touch which was missing in Peninsula.The open concept café/dining area in the lobby did not work for me – it was weird. People were eating at tables while others were just walking by – total lack of privacy. The Peter bar at the top floor of the hotel has wonderful views.The hotel is located in close proximity to Ginza and there are lots of restaurants within a short walking distance. A little far from Tokyo station and hence the best of getting to the hotel from and to Narita is via the Airport express as it drops and picks you at the doorstep. The bus schedule is not so regular and depending on your flight timing, potentially you may have to wait an hour for the bus. The alternative is to take the Narita express from Tokyo station – a short taxi ride away costing about 700 Yen.

My room was awesome - every detail was perfect. From the gentle alarm clock linked to the "mood lighting", the expresso machine to the nail varnish dryer. I even got used to the heated toilet seat! Going back home after my business trip here was almost a wrench!

Excellent hotel, rooms spacious and very hi-tech, took a bit to figure them all out. Just across from Imperial Palace with lovely walks & gardens. Lots of restaurants nearby and an ATM in the basement beside Business centre. Great breakfasts but restaurants pricey, lots of restaurants nearby in Ginza at all prices.

thats all I can really say, Pen, never lets you down, ive stayed in all but one of their hotels and now I have stayed here, ive completed them all, this one keeps the standard. although modern, not too much like her other sister hotels, the hotel still manages to keep that charm of days gone luxury.loved it.

I fully enjoyed staying at this fabulous hotel. Across Japan, all the hotels are in general, very clean and very friendly so it is hard to rank hotels in Japan. However, I thought this hotel was beyond Japan's excellency. Service was superb, security was amazing (I thought I lost something, but that was simply my poor memory that I forgot where to put, the hotel people did all the high tech research and helped solve the mystery and found one missing in the end successfully). They always smiled with modest attitude, felt so special during my stay, Staff remembered me (because I was looking for a thing, nonetheless, it was a good feel that they talked to me and greeted friendly- making my trip more relaxing and happier). Restaurants were very nice, the top floor one was gorgeous in addition to the great view even in the restroom! Classic live music was always soothing, everything was very welcoming. In the room, there's a delivery box, it was also convenient. Whatever things should be taken care of (mail or copy), I put it in the box, quietly, someone from the hotel picked it up to get done. There was a fax machine in the room to let me know if it was processed. So high tech.... But still warm touch everywhere. When you stay, you would also enjoy the beautiful deco on the elevator hall... Simply amazing hotel (it was pricy but much superior to the similar price ranged hotels). Just wished they had a point system...
user_name:
nyay
New York City, New York

review_body: this is a fine hotel and brilliantly located in Hibiya right next to the Imperial gardens...subway is right underneath, the rooms are magnificent and the service is excellent.my gripe is that my colleauge was staying in a simiular room for 27,000 yen a night and we were in one for 73,000 - quite a big difference, evenif we got free breakfast.And on that subject, breakfast and drinks are served in the quite soulless lobby, which caters to wedding parties lining up to greet the bride and groom and who troop in all day...the lobby is the only feature of this place I would change.It really feels like an airport lounge- and as for the drinks prices- well, I suggest you BYOB or you will realy suffer.Overall, its the best place in Tokyo and for sure if you can get a deal stay here.Far better than the Four Seasons.

This is the best hotel i have stayed in in Tokyo. The rooms are luxurious - the decor was tasteful, furniture well- made Separately dressing / closet area and beautiful bathroom. The bed was very comfortable. The best part was the service - professional yet warm and attentive.

Had 4 fabulous nights at the Peninsula; it was fantastic. Of course, you pay for such service and quality, but you will certainly get it here. Somehow all the staff were even able to remember our names on site, which is pretty impressive considering the size of the hotel and number of travelers. Absolute uncompromising attention to detail.

This is an incredible hotel. The common areas and rooms are in perfect condition and service is top-notch; concierge desk was incredibly helpful -- great advice and recommendations. I have no complaints.For our family of 4 adults and 2 small children, we had two rooms: a Deluxe Corner room connected to a Deluxe room, each room with one King size bed. Both rooms were very comfortable. The connection for the rooms was through the dressing room of the non-corner room, so still very private. The amenities were as described in the TripAdvisor reviews and the hotel website. Breakfast was included in the package -- both American and Japanese breakfast was very good. For kids, the hotel provided bath toys, small robes and slippers. The pool is also very nice, free to hotel guests. Children are allowed until 6:00 pm.
