The Peninsula is conveniently located in Ginza, connected to the subway as well a quick taxi ride to Tokyo station. In addition to being close to all of the top name shops, there are lots of excellent restaurants in walking distance.I made the reservations totally through email, which was very convenient.Pros: Beautiful hotel, great conditionComfortable beds, nice bathroomsConcierge +++LocationNice breakfastCons: A bit pricey, but probably in line for this level of hotel in TokyoNext time, I would consider a package excluding breakfast and eat outI will stay at this hotel again when I return to Tokyo!

The rooms are perfect. The attention to detail amazing, right down to the soap.Beds are also comfortable.We had a standard room which was beautifully designed - separate dressing room, two sinks in bathroom, spacious bedroom split into sleeping and lounging areas.Staff od excellent service to us everything we need they supply with a warmly welcome.......

This is an amazing hotel. The room and bath were beautiful and the service was excellent (everyone spoke English). Even the breakfast was a cut above most hotels. Highly recommend if you want to splurge while in Tokyo. Be sure to walk across the street and see the Imperial Palace!

I used on a recent business trip. the hotel is set out great with some really good facilities for doing all business. very attentive staff. Rooms are great and very clean. I would even consider using for a holiday hotel as the location is great. As i have used this hotel previously my expectations were high, this time they were met with ease. I look forward to travelling back to tokyo and using this wonderful hotel again.

The rooms are wonderful. The dressing room seems what female travelers really want . . . The service is friendly and attentive. The location by the Imperial Palace and Ginza is terrific. What more do you need?

Husband always stays here on business trips and this time took me along as well. We had a standard room which was beautifully designed - separate dressing room, two sinks in bathroom, spacious bedroom split into sleeping and lounging areas. This room was designed by people who have travelled and know what travellers want. The staff are great - you can tell a hotel where people like coming to work. When the TV wasn't showing the finals of the US Tennis Open (my only gripe with the hotel) a fellow tennis fan at concierge looked up the scores and kept me informed plus threw in some tennis talk as well. I also love that whether you throw the towels in the bath or not - they all get changed. Same with the bedlinen - though I would like a topsheet but that doesn't seem to be hotel practice these days.

We stayed here in March 2011. The hotel is in a central location. The staff were very friendly and helpful. The room spacious, amazing and so clean. The swimming pool was also fantastic. We will definitely stay here next time we are in Tokyo.

Loved it. Have stayed twice. Had a corner 'room'...more like a suite. Beautiful room...stunning bathroom, separate dressing room. WOW. This is my fave Pen out of a few i have stayed in (love them all except Beijing).The pool is big, quiet...and looks out to Ginza and the Palace.You can stroll to Ginza from the hotel. Such a great location. Spa is excellent - steam, sauna, ice and other fun stuff!

I travel quite a bit but I always look forward to staying at the Peninsula Tokyo. The rooms are perfect. The attention to detail amazing, right down to the soap. The Davi glycerin soap they provide in the room is custom made for this hotel in the US, using grape skins from the Robert Mondavi winery. It really does make your skin feel younger. I like it so much that I special order it from the Tokyo Peninsula.

I have been to Tokyo many many times, and the Peninsula is the best hotel I have stayed at.The rooms are large and stylish, the beds extremely comfortable, and certain touches (the dressing area, audio in the bathroom, special delivery slot for newspapers etc.) put this hotel a cut above its competitors. It is also right in the heart of the Marunoichi district - so perfect for business, and then just a short walk to Ginza.If I have any criticism, it is that I prefer a buffet-style breakfast rather than waiter service when I am on a business trip, but that is a minor gripe.Service is exemplary - but then, this being Tokyo, I wouldn't expect anything less.

A colleague and I stayed at the Peninsula for two nights at the end of August. Rarely have I experienced such an excellent hotel in every respect; the staff are attentive and friendly without being overbearing; the rooms are spacious and well appointed with state of the art technology; the facilities are maintained to a very high standard, just to name a few benefits. It is well located and walking distance from many tourist attractions. Highly recommended

I agree with most of the reviewers that the Peninsula Tokyo is luxurious and it is a hotel you can receive superb service, but for me, it felt generic and lacked character. Free access to the pool and the gym was a plus (everything you need to use the facility you can rent for free - bathing suits, swimming cap, goggle, t-shirt & shorts, sneakers, socks, etc.) Past a couple years "gaishikei" hotels such as Ritz, Mandarin Oriental, Conrad have been very popular among Japanese (and probably foreign visitors) but I would prefer to stay at the Imperial where you feel the history and tradition and the Japanese sensitivity.

My husband and I stayed here during our house hunting trip to Tokyo and we loved every minute of it; from our room with dressing room, huge bathroom with shower AND tub, and large living room with comfy sofa and awesome bed to the penthouse restaurant and bar, with gym and spa in the middle of it. You could spend an eternity here feeling pampered and serviced the way only Japanese can do it. Great location for shopping and sightseeing too, with metro station in the basement and the emperor's garden just across the street.

Best hotel we've ever stayed at. Perfect service, wonderful rooms with heaps of space, lots of electronic gadgets (even for Japan). The full height windows provide great views ( as long as you're not facing the building right next door). Most rooms seem to have a separate 'dressing room' which is quite large and very handy. The bed was so comfortable, and lots of interesting lighting options for whatever mood you're in.The restaurant/bar upstairs is very interesting as well. Location is good, but not much in the immediate vicinity.

I have stayed at the Peninsula hotel five times now and will always come back. I am no stranger to top-notch hotels in many parts of the world and this is probably my favourite. The rooms are very comfortable and the service is beyond compare. The staff is very personable and attentive without being in-your-face. They make you feel very welcome and it would seem that they truly desire that your stay be a memorable one.If you can afford it, then by all means, stay here!

I am living now several years in Tokyo and have eaten in all 5* hotels and the ebst michelin star places in the city especially in the Peninsula, but now what The Peninsula does in their Nakadori Outlet is really great the Chef have created this really cool looking and delecious Bento Take Away Boxes only 850 for a great selection also availabe in the Street Cafe this is a super deal and very good value for money.....loved it you must try this new culinary delight in town.....MS

I stayed at the Peninsula with friends in a 2 bedroom suite - the suite was massive, with full floor to ceiling windows, and panoramic 270 degree views. The rooms were very elegantly appointed, and the beds extraordinarily comfortable. But what really made the stay special was the hospitality of the hotel staff. One example - the receptionist had overheard me mention to my friend that I neglected to bring my blackberry charger, and within a few minutes of stepping into the room, a hotel valet presented me with 2 versions of blackberry chargers... For room service afficiandos... the hotel serves an excellent burger... perfect for late night eating and hangovers...

I stayed in this hotel with my teenage son on a holiday. We had a Superior room. The location for us was excellent. Starbucks and McDonalds 3 minutes walk away for those who need them and a SevenEleven across the road (much cheaper beer than mini bar prices!). Railway station only a couple of minutes walk too. They have Citibank ATM in the basement level which is great for foreign credit cards. Excellent concierge desk. Room service quite expensive but acceptable. Lavazza coffee machine in the room, but the hot water was always luke warm - not boiling as you would get from a kettle. Size of the room was excellent - huge! Great bathroom. The pictures on their website are accurate. The little valet cupboard where you could leave laundry and receive papers was a great idea. Overall we really enjoyed our stay, but I don't think we would go back - we had a great summer deal for the room - I think normal prices would be too much though. Although Tokyo as a whole is pretty expensive....

This is an incredibly plush luxury hotel with some thoughtful, refined design and art (check out the plaster wall behind the reception desk and the beautiful sliding wooden doors in the guest rooms). Personally, it's not the sort of luxury hotel I'm dying to return to--it's a bit overstuffed and generic—I feel like I could be in Chicago. I have had much better experiences staying at the Hyatt (Park and Grand) and the Okura. I stayed in the Four Seasons Marunouchi when it forst opened and loved it (great food, interesting comfortable rooms, and bianchi bikes). If I were to stay in this part of Tokyo, I'd opt for the Four Seasons. I found the Peninsula's food particularly disappointing. I had breakfast (in the lobby and roomservice), dinner in the Chinese restaurant, and roomservice. The meals were expensive and very mediocre.If I were flying to Tokyo on business and didn't want any distractions, just an expensed burger in my room at the end of the day, this would be the place to stay. The bed is perfect and they've engineered the entire room to go black (light switches are buttons with illuminated text "Bathroom," and they stay illuminated for 30 seconds after you push the master off button and then dim to black—very thoughtful. There are some fun, silly extra's like a nail dryer in the dressing room.
user_name:
Gandaratravels
New York City, New York

review_body: This entire hotel is wonderful. The rooms are highly luxurious, the cocktail bar is amazing and the pool/spa is excellent.I definitely recommend the Peninsula Tokyo.The only thing I didn't appreciate was the regulation of having to wear an ugly swimming cap in the pool even though I wasn't putting my head under the water. This isn't ideal when you've just had a blow wave and don't want to mess up your hair under a cap when your hair is completely tied up hygienically anyway.

Stayed in this hotel for business in August 2010. Overall hotel, as impressive as Peninsula Shanghai which I stayed in July 2011. However, guest service is rather inconsistent. The hotel staff doesn't really say anything much except hello and have a nice day. Room wise, very very nice. Excellent service from room service, valet service all the way to laundries. Room service menu was rather dull. Little options to choose from, but nevertheless, pretty good. About 10 to 15 minutes of walking distance to the shopping street. Quite near the Muji store and about 15 minutes of walk to the Tokyo Station itself. It's about 3 mins walk to Yurakucho Station. The lobby is rather busy at night, so book early if you intend to have dinner there. There's a direct bus shuttle from Narita Airport to the hotel, so it's rather convenient.

The design of hotel is fantastic. Expect japanese minimal luxury. Rooms are spacious and fully equipped with anything you can imagine and even more !Restaurants, bars, spa are top level.The service is in my opinion even better than The Peninsula Hong Kong, making The Peninsula Tokyo, the best hotel in the world for service.Setting is fantastic.If you go to Tokyo don't miss this experience ! From far the best hotel in Tokyo.

Im a little bit late in moving the review from my phone to here - I stayed in Jan 2011The peninsula is the best hotel I have ever stayed in. The hotel is modern and the rooms are spacious. Location is good, close to Hibiya station, Imperial Palace and the food and shops of Ginza.ProsLarge rooms with lots of features. Black out motorised blinds, mood lighting etc.The hotel facilities lack nothing. The pool and gym are fantastic. They will lend you trainers shorts, t shirt etc. No need to take your own.Service is efficent and prompt as it should be.Bed was excellentConsWould not allow us to check in early. Agreed they don't have to, yet we were only an hour early.Japan, contary to popular belief is not expensive, this hotel though is very expensive... 100Meters away a half litre of sake, £2. In the hotel, cheapest drinks approx £9. Hotels on three sides looks out on offices.. You can see in them and vice versa, nothing much the hotel can do about this but as a consumer you should be aware unless you go for the room with the telescope, ( I forget the name of the room) you will not be looking out on the park, but rather at someones work desk.In conclusion this hotel is fantastic, pricey but fantastic. I am glad I have stayed there. I probably would not return mainly because of the price. Places like the Conrad or the Marriot are in good locations and offer an excellent hotel with rewards/loyalty programs they are also hundreds cheaper a night.

We stay in The Peninsula a month or so before the Japan earthquake. It was a wonderful stay. The rooms are amazing - they even have a special little compartment for newspapers and laundry to be delivered to u without u ever having to open your door. Food was great and service top notch.

Stayed 2 nights with our 9 month old son in December. My son slept in his crib near their window and really enjoyed the morning view from our room when all the curtains were up. Their walk in closet is a bonus so all the suitcases are not visible in sight. I think their beds are by far one of the most comfortable and we slept really well. I ordered room service for breakfast in the morning overwatching the sunrise and it was just beautiful. Can't wait to go back!

This property is absolutely fantastic... the location, service, rooms and small touches are all some of the best in the world, and members of staff obviously take a huge amount of pride in the property. I could go on for ages about why I love this hotel, but others have covered it many times before.

The Peninsula is an island of calm at the crossroads of Ginza and Otemachi. The rooms are exceptionally well appointed, and most have large dressing rooms, in addition to the double large living area and beautiful bathrooms. The living area is equipped with a large screen TV, and a very comfortable sofa. Rooms are equipped with WiFi, an espresso machine, and feel more like one's own studio apartment than an anonymous hotel room. As this is Japan, the service is impeccable, and everything is done to discreet perfection. On the downside....the lobby of the hotel also serves as the breakfast area/tearoom, so there really is no buffer between the outside world and that of the hotel, and one really feels no intimacy seated in this area. The gym is so-so, but the indoor swimming pool is great, as is the spa. The hotel's bar, Peter, is located on Level 24 and is accessible by a separate lift - the views over a darkened Tokyo (austerity measures due to energy cutbacks in the wake of the 11 March chain of disasters) are ok, and the drink prices will make your eyes water. All in all, however, this is a beautiful property and a stay here is a really treat.

Extremely comfortable, high tech rooms (you can control the humidity to the degree) with style. The service was gracious, even if some concierges were more helpful than others. The hotel features a well upkept useable gym. And the location is convenient to walk around Ginza.

After many years (10, in fact) staying at another nearby hotel, I have changed to the Peninsula. The rooms are fantastic. The staff are very attentive and the location extremely good for business in Marunouchi/Ohtemachi. Around the corner is a huge Big Camera electronics store, removing the need for visiting Akihabara. Peter’s Bar is great too, with drinks being very reasonably priced for a Tokyo 5-Start hotel. The single drawback is the lobby area which is just not very large and belittles the other features of this hotel. Having a real room key (yes – a key!) is perhaps meant to be elegant, but not nearly as convenient as having a swipe/contact card which can slip easily into a wallet or top pocket.

My family and I stayed in 2 superior rooms here late Feb 2011 for the Tokyo Marathon. Initially I was a little hesitant given the room rates but when we arrived I understood what all the raves were about and even why their prices were such. The attention to detail was incredible both in the rooms, bathrooms, amenities and service. All the staff went out of their way to be helpful so we made it a point to stop by the concierge to get all the directions, tips and information prior to going out daily.We had kids with us and there were little bathrobes and cookie decorating kits as well as bath amenities waiting for them in the room. They also loved the heated swimming pool which was off limits to children at certain times of the day to allow for adults to swim undisturbed.It is relatively close to the Imperial Palace, Ginza and the Tsukiji fish markets. For all other places, the hotel links directly to the underground subway hence very convenient for travel especially during winter or rainy days. The lobby was a little crowded with a restaurant squeezed in which removed the first impression 'grandness' you would expect. We liked their pastries at the cafe but did not enjoy breakfast at Peter's - the servings tended to be small and limited selection for breakfast buffet. The Lobby was either always full or closed so we never tried it. The Pen reminded me of the days when I could still be impressed and look forward to staying in a hotel. It really does 'spoil' its guests. Nowadays with all the cookie-cutter hotel chains, this is one that stands out in more ways than one.

We stayed here after flying in from Hong Kong where we stayed at the brilliant and virtually flawless Four Seasons HK. I had huge expectations on the Pen in Tokyo based on the reviews on this site and therefore even the slightest hiccup would lead to disappointment, and unfortunately that's what happened. First the good:The location of the hotel is simply the best - there is no better location in Tokyo for a leisure traveller. The rooms are a real treat as indicated by other reviews here and all the electronic wizardry certainly does keep one amazed and entertained. Service is also good, but not in the same league as the Four Seasons HK where we had just arrived from. ( I was never addressed by name) The beds were incredibly luxurious and the pool area was a real treat, as was the complimentary use of the hotel Rolls. The not so good:We were given a disabled room, which meant we had a modified bathroom with handles everywhere and it also meant that we only had one vanity. Whilst only a small issue, I feel that given the hotel was not full, this seemed unnecessary. At the very least reception should have made this known. On the night we arrived a asked reception a question which they could not answer and I was directed to the concierge desk where I had to repeat the question. This may seem like a small issue but I would have expected to be escorted to the concierge desk and the receptionist to have repeated my question to the concierge but this did not happen. Again, I'm only making these picky points based on other reviews on this site which indicate this property is flawless. The concierge desk is also too small and cramped given the size of the overall hotel and is only staffed by two, meaning sometimes you will need to wait for service, when in a hotel of this calibre you should never have to wait.There was only no fruit in the room, which was a strange omission. The toiletries were also not always replaced once they were used up or opened which was frustrating. Peter the restaurant is accessed via a separate elevator from the ground floor which is frustrating for guests as you have to go down them up again. The breakfast menu is very limited and the temperature of the food was lukewarm on almost all days - disappointing. I would also agree with others that the layout of the lobby is poor with those having breakfast sharing the floor with departing travellers. The rear door of the hotel is also not manned by a staff member when it really should be. Overall the hotel looks as though it's "older" than it really is, probably not helped by the red decor.Overall I enjoyed my stay but having read the reviews on this site, my expectations were so high that any slight flaw would be noted and detract from the overall experience and those flaws did exist. Look, staying here is a still a great experience, but comments like "worlds best" are simply misleading as anyone who has stayed at the Four Seasons Hong Kong will attest.

I have stayed many times at the Peninsula and am never disappointed by it. The service is the best I have ever experienced, the hotel is perfectly located and the rooms are large and full of helpful gadgets.The rooms themselves are not the most elegantly decorated I have seen, but they are very large for Tokyo and are very well equipped. The bed is exceptionally comfortable and the sheets somehow seem softer than they do in other hotels (not sure why, but consistently like this). The cupboard that you place things in for the butler is a great idea, it means anything can be returned, or taken from your room without the need to disturb you.The location couldn't be better, fronting onto the park and backing into Ginza. There are a million great places to eat and shop within a stones throw of the back door.The pool is large and has a well heated spa with windows looking out to the park.This place is perfect, nothing more to say.

In the typical grandeur of the Peninsula Group the Pen Tokyo is exquisite. The sculpture and the overhead lights in the lobby is the signature. It is small but bustling with activities and stylish people from far and near frequent this lobby and coffee shop. You can hear beautiful music coming from the balcony in the day. The rooms are clean and roomy. You can control the lights and window drapes at the tip of your fingers. The bathroom is big with the typical 2 sinks as with all the Pens. The shower and pressure is not so great but I hear this is to conserve water consumption. The room is visually pleasant in earth colours. The bed is comfortable and pillows are most suitable for me. Not so hard and not too soft. The walk in dressing area is a plus for a Japanese hotel room. It is near to all the shopping, train station and Cova is just next door. The park is opposite the hotel. Peter is a very elegant restaurant with a view. I have been back many many times.

Located at Chiyoda-Marunouchi-Ginza and by the Imperial Gardens. Its the best hotel for Marunouchi & Ginza by far.Rooms in Tokyo are small but my Deluxe Room was spacious & had everything one could possible think of needing when travelling and done with top quality & good taste. The color tones for the bedroom are restful. All electrical outlets are sufficient in quantity and well located. The dressing room is spacious and well-lit and has everything you need. The service box to leave shoes and pick up newspapers is elegant and efficient. The bathroom is well appointed and again everything works well. This is one of the best bedrooms you can ask forEverything in the hotel is perfect. There is nothing to complain of!

The thought that kept flashing on my mind as our room was swaying wildly was that "I am so glad this is the Peninsula" Up at the 18th floor the solid wooden sliding door was opening & closing wildy, the hotel was creeking loudly for a good 5 minutes and not a single damage to my room. The loudspeaker immediately went on, however, warning was in Japanese before english. Also, they sent a staff member at each floor immediately. It maybe a Japanese custom of having everybody stay put & be calm as it is safer. But after the 1st aftershock not 5 minutes after the big one the building was now shaking up & down. We choose to not follow the advise of the staff and take the emergency stairs to go to the open area which is just across the hotel.While celphone sites were all down. The Peninsula's free WIFI was a blessing as it was working 100%. The signal did not even flicker! We were able to talk to family members through facetime even.The staff were exceptional as expected. The rooms extraordinary in terms of functionality & luxury. But, the bottom line was the peace of mind that the Peninsula is probably the safest building in Tokyo. We had to sleep 2 more nights in the room. In those 2 days & nights we literally experienced over 100 aftershocks; some slight tremblings but many long and strong ones too. If it were any other hotel I would probably be sleeping at the lobby. But at the Peninsula I slept on a luxurious bed, albeit the lightest of sleeps.

We spent 9 nights at the Peninsula Tokyo in a Deluxe Park View Room with our 1 Year old daughter. The room was definitely a highlight. It was incredibly spacious and functional. The layout was different from standard hotel rooms but it really felt more suite like - you could enjoy the TV equally from the bed or the sofa and the floor to ceiling windows ran along the whole length of the room ensuring the view really is a highlight. There was a good sized dining table for two and a fabulous espresso coffee machine that we took full advantage of. The only downside was the work desk which was a little bit small but that is such a small complaint against all of the positives.As others have mentioned, the walk in closet was fantastic. There was a great dressing table and ample room for storing luggage once all the clothes were hung up. This meant that the main part of the room wasn't overflowing with luggage, strollers etc which really added to the luxurious feel of the room. It is also worth mentioning the beautifully appointed huge bathroom.The hotel made staying with a baby very easy. Our room was stocked with baby toiletries, a mini bathrobe/slippers and special snacks for our daughter. The full sized cot was comfortable and unobtrusive in our big room. The hotel staff where extremely helpful and never made us feel as though our daughter's presence was an imposition. We took advantage of the nanny service on three occasions and felt our daughter was in very safe hands. The concierge organised all of this for us (as well as dinner reservations and Disneyland tickets) and it was all seamless. We enjoyed quite a few room service meals (the joys of traveling with a little one mean you spend far more time in your room than you might otherwise). We were on a bed and breakfast rate so had the delicate and beautifully presented breakfast in the lobby each morning. It probably wasn't the greatest place for a very energetic 1 year old (given it is right in the middle of the lobby) but the staff kindly gave us crayons and colouring in sheets to keep her entertained. We also took advantage of the bakery shop in the basement - the sandwiches and pastries were delicious and we were able to enjoy the meals back in our room. The only let down was our one visit to the hotel bar. We were advised that we could only sit at the bar as all the tables near the windows were reserved - there was not one person in the bar at the time and by the time we left only one table was occupied. A slight let down after the fantastic service we had received elsewhere throughout the hotel. All in all a great stay and we look forward to returning next time we are in Tokyo.

We have stay there 5 times now in the past yers and is the only place We will stay.Pure luxury, every inch a Peninsula, one of the best on this planet, and is not to be missed. For those preferring large busy lobby, this hotel does not work for you. The service is second to none, personal and warm. There is ownership in all the staff at all levels. This is what is lacking in many 6 stars hotels. The Peninsula is so ingrained and hospitality is everywhere. This is the only place to stay, forget the rest. I am also referring to all hotels of the Peninsula group.

This is a great hotel. the rooms are about as large and attractive as I have ever seen. The entire decor is modern yet very comfortable. In addition to a very spacious bathroom, every room comes with a large dressing room / closet -- which is as large as many rooms in small 3-star hotels in Europe. The service is impeccable, but sometimes can be a bit slow (due to the time taken to ensure perfection!). the food choices tend to be pricy and somewhat limited. But overall, I think this is a terrific hotel -- i have been here more than 20 times already.

My two-day stay at The Peninsula was a dream. I chose the hotel for its proximity to my business meeting venue, but I would happily choose it again even if it were out of my way. The staff serve their guests in an outstanding team-work - I always felt that the entire team were addressing my specific needs and it allowed me to concentrate on my work. The - large - rooms are fabulous, with too many good details to mention them all. But when a hotel room is designed with a special valet box in the dressing room (allowing the valet to pick up and deliver goods without disturbing the guest by using the main door!) then you know that a lot of thinking has gone into creating an outstanding place. If you can afford the price (about 36000 JPY/night in 2011) then go and enjoy.

We had the deluxe suite and the grand deluxe room connected which i have to say was one of the most beautiful and over the top rooms with just about everything you could want. room service was great with a pretty decent selection of western and of course asian food, the pool area was great although there are a few rules (no kids after 6, you have to check in to the pool area and you must wear swimming caps) We dined at peter for breakfast which is a very nice place for breakfast some westerners may find the selection a little on the small side all in all great hotel with staff that goes out of there way.

Good location and advanced facilities.Staff are friendly, however, some of them are not trained well.We've got a discount from Japanese booking website and that was agreat value for the location.Facilities are pretty advanced.

This was truly one of the best hotels that we've stayed. We were there for a short (2-night) stay to celebrate our wedding anniversary. The hotel was a bit more business oriented, but their attention to detail and service were impeccable. We were disappointed with many of the recommendations that the hotel concierge made. For one, he failed to tell us that the fish market was closed and recommended us to make a visit there. We made a trip out there to see a deserted marketplace and wasted most of the morning. Then to try to compensate for his mistake by recommending us to a very famous place for lunch that day. The only thing it was 30 min. from the restaurant's closing time and it was supposed to take us about 20 min. to get there. All in all, it's a very good hotel, just don't rely too much on their conceirge.

In all fairness, the Peninsula is an excellent hotel in terms of its rooms, location and all its hardware. While the staff went all out to make you feel comfortable, what was lacking was that ever so slight touch that would have made it a total five-star experience.While I have gripes about the layout of the hotel eg. the extremely small lobby coupled with the morning breakfast area + how the lift lobby is directly to the side of the check-in desks, the room layouts are great as well as the amazing level of technology in-built into the rooms.The Concierge is probably the biggest issue I have with this hotel. Prior to my stay, I sent 3 repeated emails requesting for information to pre-plan my trip, and I never received a reply. This despite even making calls directly to the Peninsula reservation requesting them to forward my email to the Concierge. While in the hotel, the service was professional but the team never went the extra mile. I had planned the trip to celebrate my sister's birthday (further specified in my email), and they never told me about a promotion in Peter's (their main restaurant), and we ended up eating out elsewhere. It was a contrast to nearby Imperial Hotel, who freshly baked a Strawberry Shortcake with a delicious rose jam in 45mins as soon as they heard it was her birthday, and the bakery had ran out of cakes. Dinner at Peter's was on the disappointing side. The restaurant felt unfinshed, the music wasn't great and the food was at most, just interesting. Desserts could well be missed.Stay at the Peninsula if you were doing it for business and/ or if it was not on your tab.

We stayed at the Peninsula Tokyo for two nights after our flight from North America, and it was an oasis of comfort and elegance for all of us to adjust to the time change. The rooms are outstanding, with great attention to convenience. A walk in closet was a great idea, since it served as the "second" room so that others wouldn't be disturbed while sleeping. The bathroom was outstanding, with a separate stall for the toilet and spacious sinks, tub and shower. My wife and I brought our two young daughters. Our room was complete with robes and slippers for all of us, including a perfectly fitting set for our children as well. The staff spoke good English and were eager to help. The spa facilities were outstanding and the service immeccable. The restaurants were very good, and the bakery cafe in the lower level was a great spot to pick up a snack. When we return to Tokyo, we will definitely stay at the Peninsula, within walking distance of the Imperial Palace and the Ginza area. Our trip to Japan was really to focus on Kyoto, thus the short stay in Tokyo. We were sad to leave the Peninsula and was so tempted to extend our stay.

I loved this hotel. The staff bent over backwards to make sure that we were happy and accommodated. The location is within walking distance to shops and great restaurants (I hate to walk too far!) I loved the lobby restaurant for lunch and high tea, great place for people watching - to see and be seen. We were lucky enough to see a beautiful Japanese bride dressed in traditional garb. The concierge was great about booking us in wonderful restaurants. Great view, comfy beds, immaculate rooms, excellent spa, fabulous bathroom. I am pretty particular but really cannot find any fault with this hotel.

Visited about 6 months ago & had a fantastic stay but it was marred at the end by some inconsiderate treatment from lobby staffOn this trip the exact same situation arose and it was handled perfectly - during our visit we noticed several other guests struggling with a place to sit while they waited for the airport bus & saw them receiving the same helpful assistancemaybe the prior rough treatment was a one-off but it seems more likely the hotel is taking notes & made improvements to its service - that's a sign of a first class operation & one that has earned our repeat business . . . Christmas on the Ginza!design may be a touch stuffy but otherwise this is about as perfect as a luxury hotel can be - prices are sky high but the experience is so good it feels like a bargain

I stayed at both the Mandarin Oriental (MO) and the Peninsula (P) in Nov2010, and both were great. If I had to choose I'd probably pick the MO if they were the same price. Here is how the different attributes stack up, in my opinion:Location - P wins big, on the edge of the Imperial Gardens and Ginza. MO is a 20 min walk north from P.Rooms - P. P had much beds, bathtub and toilets (an artform in Japan). MO had much better shower and toiletries (incredible products, esp the bathsalts). The decor and layout were equally wonderful at both hotels, as were the views.Common Spaces - MO wins big. Though I am not a fan of the common MO setup of having the lobby on the top floor (requiring you to take two elevators from your room to the exit, one up to the lobby, another one down to the street), I loved the look and feel of this hotel - serene, lovely and efficient. Gorgeous views and architecture. P's setup is much more convenient, but the lobby feels small and chaotic with the restaurant planted right in the middle. Not a space where we wanted to linger in the least.  Service - MO wins big. P is fine, but MO goes above and beyond. The concierge staff at P was harried.Food - MO wins. The food at the restaurant in P's lobby was mediocre. The food in the casual cafe in the P basement is tasty but the location in the basement in not ideal. We didn't try "Peter", on the top floor of P, because the cigarette smoke was so strong.MO has five restaurants - four with incredible views, (including the all-day dining, more casual place which had a wonderful breakfast buffet) , three with Michelin stars. Gym - tie. P has a lovely pool, but the gym is small with no windows. MO's gym is bigger with great views, but no pool. Both had nice, new machines. Spa - P because of pricing. MO's is egregious, even for Tokyo.

The Peninsula is one of my favourite hotels ever! And I've stayed there multiple times over the last few years. On this trip, we stayed at the Peninsula with our 14 month old toddler. The Peninsula set up a nice cot, diaper bin and provided baby towels (one bath, and one small face towel) and toiletries. This hotel is almost perfectly located. very easy to get to Haneda Airport, and also to Tokyo Disneyland. One downside: we couldn't bring our baby to the beautiful swimming pool. there's a minimum age for the swimming pool of 4 years. that was a pity since i was well equipped with baby swim diapers and swimming gear.

It was the third and final leg of our round the world Honeymoon trip and from the moment we stepped out of the taxi to the day we left everything was absolutely perfect. What is so special about this hotel is the excellent service and wonderful staff, not forgetting the state of the art rooms and brilliant location in Tokyo. We were greeted with Champagne and strawberries and because our suite was so lovely we had room service a few nights with great views of the City . We also had breakfast at the Hotel every morning and dined at the Peter restaurant on the 24th Floor which was surprisingly good value as Tokyo is an expensive city. Another highlight was the swimming pool and spa on the 6th Floor which we made good use of. We'll never stay at a better Hotel and would love to go back some day.

The Peninsula Hotel in Tokyo provides extremely comfortable, large, tastefully furnished rooms outfitted with all the amenities you can think of, and quite a few that you haven't - a nail dryer built into the dressing table in the dressing room? It is conveniently located across the street from the Imperial Palace grounds and Hibiya Park, near many office buildings, and a short walk from the Ginza and its world class shopping and restaurants.The hotel restaurants are excellent, but pricey. Good, inexpensive fare can be found a block away where restaurants line the street along the train tracks. The spa, fitness center and swimming pool are great. Service is exceptional.The bar at Peter's, on the top floor, has a great view and a nice vibe at night, with creative, if sometimes funky, drinks.

Stayed at the Peninsula for 1 week in November. Previously stayed at the Imperial, the Park Hyatt and Four Seasons. Comparison is made against these hotels.Pros:1) The Peninsula has an excellent location, right on top of the Hibiya station and near JR lines as well as Ginza. The hotel basement connects to the Hibiya underground station. The presence of the Imperial Palace grounds makes for lovely greenery which isn't all that common in Tokyo and a pleasant jogging spot during warmer seasons.2) The fact it has it's own building rather than simply being on the top floors of an office one like a number of other 5 star hotels in Tokyo is to this traveler a plus. The ability to feel you've stepped into the "world" of your hotel from the point of entering into the ground floor door is comforting.3) The room is quite simply the best in its class I've stayed in. I stayed in a Deluxe room. Size-wise, comparable to other 5 star hotels in Tokyo but the design, layout and it being relatively new works in its favour. The high-tech gadgets of Lavazza coffee maker, automated curtains and light dimmers, fax machine etc. are standard Peninsula fare but all executed professionally. The use of plenty of phones, the Japanese luxury electronic toilet and thoughtfully planned layout of these is exceptional. Combined with good threadcount Frette bedlinen, the room is the most restful I've ever stayed in thus far. It is surprising how many high-end hotels scrimp on bedlinen etc., a strange proposition since most people will spend the most time on the bed in the room.....but happily, not the Peninsula. The valet service and valet box are excellent ideas and quite useful. The bathroom is smaller than most, as noted by previous reviews, but that is because space has been given to a walk-in wardrobe. In my opinion, the 2 combine to a bathroom/dressing area and I was not put off by this. It was a better use of space.4) The concierge service was better than any I've encountered in Tokyo. While some of the staff seemed a little harassed, given notice, they performed impeccably. All my reservations for restaurants, including some rather notoriously difficult ones were obtained and they had even went the extra mile to get the restaurants to give me private rooms at no extra cost to myself. One of their staff deserves special mention. Ms. Misako Kobayashi. While a junior concierge, she is quite simply the best concierge I have ever encountered, going out of her way to help us out of a jam we were in during our stay, even personally accompanying one of my party out of the hotel and staying back past her shift, close to midnight to ensure things went smoothly. Nothing short of amazing.Cons:Relatively minor in the scheme of things but areas that, in my opinion, can be easily corrected to turn them into clearing the best hotel in Tokyo and definitely among the best I've stayed in globally.1) The housekeeping is spotty. This is the real major letdown for the hotel really.The first night, I sent a pair of comfortable walking shoes for polishing and they were returned within an hour, but hardly cleaned, much less polished. They were scruffy and in needing of a good doing up but that was the reason I sent them. What ended up happening was I then sent across an expensive pair of lace-ups with the walking shoes and only then did they come back nice and polished, neatly placed in the shoe-bags all good hotels provide. Not exactly appropriate housekeeping.A member of my party requested for a flatsheet which was promptly provided but then subsequently removed without notice the next morning.The usual complimentary note with weather for the next day was left on the first night and then subsequently was not provided for the rest of the stay.A snack was provided on the first night but tea/snack for all subsequent days was not provided. While seemingly minor, this is a point that all good international 5 stars belabor to provide, a snack which is not repeated too frequently in the room and the lack of it in the hotel stands out.All in all, most were minor points but taken all together, did mar the experience somewhat and fall short of the luxury standards set by other top hotels. 2) The lobby is an attempt to recreate the Hongkong flagship's look, which is the presence of tea cafes as one enters with the reception tucked away in a corner and a string quartet playing. Problem is that the HK hotel has a large, wide lobby where the sense of space of the entrance to reception is not crowded out by the tea/cafe areas and plenty of sitting space is still available. A narrower, smaller space, the Tokyo Pen ends up feeling cramped and the serenity and sense of exclusiveness of the award-winning interior design is lost. Being one's first impression of the hotel, this is disappointing.The HK branch does not serve hot meals in my memory, at these lobby cafes or has a much better exhaust system because I did not encounter the smells of food in it the way I did in the Tokyo Pen. Not always the most pleasant experience.They should have moved the cafe back of the ground floor given the narrow space and saved the lobby for its usual purpose alone or at least not design it to crowd on both sides of the lobby, creating a sense of claustrophobia on staying guests needing to walk through it to get to rooms.Overall, the Tokyo Pen is a great hotel, with the fantastic rooms and wonderful concierge being assets that stand heads over their competition in town. Yes, the rooms are pricey but comparable to other 5 star hotels in Tokyo and still competitively priced compared to NY and London. Their letdowns are the spotty housekeeping with skipping of minor benefits like the afternoon snack provided by their competitors and a rather poorly laid out lobby which is detrimental to first impressions.

we booked early in the summer and found out the winter rate is cheaper and gives an upgrade and free breakfast!! Not only that, but it's cheaper than the Park Hyatt, the other glam hotel. Also use the Pasmo card for the subway. It's reloadable and can be used on most of the lines and can get you to the fancy areas like Otemosando and Roppongi.The location is fantastic and the one subway line goes into the hotel. If you walk 3 blocks south, your in the Ginza.
....and I've seen many. Great location in Ginza and to take public transport. Can even walk to train for Tokyo central and from there to narita.

We arrived at The Peninsula expecting the absolute best. We've stayed at around 6 or 7 hotels in Japan and none were as expensive as The Peninsula, so expectations were very high.I love modern design, and many Japanese hotels tick all my boxes. But The Peninsula doesn't quite work for me - and I feel kind of sad about it.We arrived at check-in, and were immediately asked if we'd like to purchase an upgrade. Sensibly I asked to see the suite they were offering - and at over £800 a night one should. And it did the trick, we were bowled over and took the large corner suite with fabulous views of the Ginza and the railways tracks with the Shinkasen hurtling past every few minutes. Blade Runner was close to becoming reality - and for me that's a good thing.I don't fault our suite at all. It was heaven - and if I could have moved in I would have. During our stay the weather wasn't that great - but that really meant enjoying the suite all the more. I think they've thought of everything - and we wanted for nothing.In retrospect I can't help but feel that being asked at check-in if we'd like to buy an upgrade a little tacky - and very un-Japanese. Yes, it worked in all our favour, but it still seems tacky.Regards design: I hated the fact that breakfast is basically at the entrance to the hotel. So you're eating while people are coming in and meeting up with business associates, or wedding parties - or whoever else wants to walk through the hotel. I think this is a badly thought out concept. On the plus side it's nice to not be dealing with the usual buffet breakfast, however, it still wasn't a good breakfast and the 'hot' food which was delivered to the table arrived luke warm. Plus, don't give guest a several slices of toast and one silly little pat of butter so they have to keep requesting more. Breakfast should (for adults) be a pleasant bit of quiet luxury time before the day gets started - no-one wants to keep asking for things by trying to catch the attention of a waiter.On the Sunday the hotel was apparently so full that they put on a buffet breakfast way up on the top floor. I was pleased about this as I knew the views would be great and we could avoid the previous days iffy food and service. However, it was a total shambles. I'm not convinced the staff were full time Peninsula employees. To be blunt we would rather have had breakfast outside the hotel.Regards design (again): the top floor bar, Peter, is great for views and has a nice atmosphere. But who designed the dreadful slippery seating? I do not tell a lie when I state people were actually making fun of the seating in the way that they were sort of pretending they were like kids again on a slide in the playground slipping off the edge.The hotel location is excellent for the subway and the Ginza. But, even if I had endless pots of money to splash out on the suite we had again, I don't think we'd stay at this particular Peninsula again. And that's a shame as I do need to go back to Japan quite a lot, and as far as we're concerned I strongly suspect we'll return to The Ritz Carlton who provided a superior service.I'm now supposed to make a decision as to whether I'd recommend this hotel to a friend. And the honest answer is, I don't know. It really depends on what you want from a hotel. I'd probably suggest staying elsewhere, but go to The Peninsula for cocktails - or, if you can afford one of the excellent suites then have a room service breakfast.

Suffice it to say that the Peninsula Tokyo redefined what I believed possible in terms of service and hospitality. Having stayed at many five-star hotels throughout the United States and parts of Europe and Australia, I would judge the Peninsula as the best hotel property I have ever visited. The level of professionalism, decorum and service offered by the staff is unheard of in many places, particularly the United States.I have stayed twice at the Peninsula, once getting a very large "Deluxe Suite" which was quite large and luxurious corner suite with an AXP upgrade, and another time in a "Deluxe Corner Room", which was the room level I booked. I can offer no criticisms of the rooms, amenities, or service throughout the stay. Critical concierge services were especially well executed. Even a scheduled transfer to the Mandarin nearby was handled flawlessly by the staff, who swept away luggage and had a car waiting with staff on the doors for my wife and I as we exited the building. The stay was perfect from end to end.

This hotel is very well located! Peninsula offers spacious rooms with all imaginable comfort. I really enjoyed the "crazy" toilets! Staff is very friendly and helpfull. Concierge gives excellent ideas for sightseeing. I enjoyed once dinning at the lobby with live jazz-music and good food - outstanding! This hotel is top!

The Peninsula is now our favortite hotel in Tokyo. I've stayed at many different properties, including the Seiyo, the Mandarin Oriental, the Four Seasons and others but the Peninsula has become a favorite for the follwing reasons: 1) Consistently excellent service. We have stayed about 6 times over the past couple of years and the staff are always knowlegeable and professional- from back of the house to front. 2) Great location 3) Beautiful and practical suites. Very spacious be any standard but especially for Tokyo. 4) The absolute best servie geared toward families and kids. They always have the nicest cribs and bedding, do special cookies and full amenities for our daughter who loves it there. This hotel is a great value. You get more than you pay for.

Were can I start this is probably one of the best hotels I have ever stayed in. What makes this hotel is its attention to detail. Everything was great from the check-in to the check-out. The location is very good, just one stop from Tokyo Station and about 3-4 minutes walk from Yurakucho station. There are many restaurants near the hotel, so if you don`t want to spend a fortune in the hotel restaurants, there are some nice places nearby. Probably the only complaint would be the hotel prices, the restaurants are very expensive but the food quality is great. The spa and pool are also great, I took my 5 year to the pool and she loved it. The pool attendants were great. The hotel rooms are very spacious and very modern. Probably one of the biggest rooms I`ve stayed in Tokyo. Overall I would recommend this hotel but bring your credit card.

My family has traveled extensively and the Peninsula Tokyo ranks as one of the best hotels we've stayed at yet. Room was fabulous; closet very spacious and bathroom incredible. Soaking tub was wonderful after a long day and hot humid temperatures in August outside. The motion activated toilet seat was a little over the top smiling here; the technology in this hotel inside the rooms is incredible. As I drink a lot of coffee, the in-room coffee-expresso maker was very much used and appreciated. We left luggage here and traveled for a few days and all was in order upon return. If we return to Toyko at some near point, we wouldn't even look at staying elsewhere. The fact that one can travel around on the subway and exit into the basement level of the hotel, just makes it even more convenient to everything.

We stay for four nights in a corner room on 22nd floor, this is the best city hotel room we stay in and everything is just perfect. The hotel is in one very good location, the service is outstanding, the room has everything a traveller need and the bed is simply the best. The chinese restaurant is very good but expensive and so do the cafe on the basement. However the breakfast is a bit disappointing for the choices are limited and the portions are small for someone coming from North America. Anyway we did enjoy our stay very much and Tokyo is our favour stop in Asia now. We hope to return soon.

Stayed here for the first time for a night. The room is spacious, and I like the layout where the living area sits between the TV and the bed, so that you're always looking straight at the TV. There is also a small table on the side for simple dining. The bathroom is large and comfortable, with dual sinks located on opposite sides. Across the corridor from the bathroom is the large walk-in closet and changing room. There is a large vanity table where ladies can sit and get ready. In addition to the standard hair dryer, they even have a built-in dryer for ladies to dry their nails after putting on polish!I went for a run around the Imperial Palace, which was just next door. Upon my return, the bellhop at the door presented me with a cold towel and a bottle of mineral water. What a great touch!

Enjoyed the stay here. Very central with great rooms. Much more stylish and modern than the typical rooms at the Imperial where I more commonly stay. Good for business or pleasure.Close to the palace for a walk and Ginza for shopping.

With the Peninsula Bangkok being my favourite hotel, my expectations of the Peninsula Tokyo were high, but I’m glad to say that I was not disappointed. The hotel lobby, though rather small, is very stylish, the rooms surprisingly spacious and elegantly furnished, the swimming pool boasts a stunning look of the Imperial Palace gardens, and the selection of restaurants is as exclusive as it is varied. I actually added Peter’s Bar and Restaurant to my list of all-time favourites as soon as I set foot in them. Not quite surprising, the bar can get very crowded at cocktail time, but the waiters are very friendly and willing to help you get a table at the window so that you can admire the cityscape at dusk, a view that should not be missed if, like me, you are a first-time visitor to Tokyo. After having enjoyed a couple of excellent white wines at the bar, my partner and I also enjoyed a superb dinner at Peter’s Restaurant. Portions, like everywhere in Tokyo, are rather small, but the quality of every single item we had was exquisite. All in all, I can highly recommend this hotel. After having seen and stayed at other five-star hotels in Tokyo, I can clearly say that The Peninsula will always be my first choice in Tokyo.

After many years (10+) staying at The Imperial Hotel, I decided to try the new and nearby Peninsula Hotel. To date, I have stayed there on four different occasions. Each time everything is so understated and well executed, it is easy to overlook just how well things are done here. They make everything appear effortless. Since my first stay they greet me by name, know that I prefer a blanket and not a duvet, understand I prefer a high floor, etc. The executive room is extremely spacious by Tokyo standards. The bed is very comfortable with good reading lights and easy to understand controls by the bed for lights, thermostat, alarm clock, and the black-out shades and sheers. The sofa and lounge chair are comfortable. There is also a small dining / work table with two chairs by the window. Flanking a large flat screen HD television is a built-in desk on one side and a cabinet on the other side which houses a coffee maker, bar and refrigerator.My only issue is with the desk. It's small and the desk chair is not very ergonomic. It's also a little low for the desk. However the rooms have wireless internet so I take my laptop to the table by the windows and work there (with a view of the Imperial Palace). I have yet to be able to print from the room's combination fax / printer, but the business center allows me to print for free.The bathroom is very well designed with a giant soaking tub and a large separate shower outfitted with both a rain-type shower head and a good hand-held spray shower. The water pressure in the shower is amazing. There are 2 vanities with sinks and the toilet is in a separate compartment. The towels are large and there are two types of robes provided.The huge walk-in closet is incredible and makes unpacking a pleasure rather than an ordeal. (An iron and ironing board would be a most welcome addition.) The closet has two walls for hanging clothes, adequate drawer space, a safe, and a dressing table and stool.The lobby restaurant is small but adequate for breakfast or lunch. It quickly fills up most days by 10am with "the ladies that lunch" crowd and remains full all day. The wester-style American breakfast is excellent, as is the coffee. There is usually live music being played from a balcony overlooking the lobby.The bar and lounge on the top floor are not quite on the level with what you saw in "Lost in Translation". Except on weekends, you can usually find a place at the bar. They have a very good bar menu for a light snack or late night meal.The health club is complimentary and while small, it is well equipped. The workout room was seldom crowded between 6:30am - 8:30am when most would be. The pool, for those that swim, is amazing with windows overlooking the Imperial Gardens across the road. I have used the services of the spa and it is very nice.The staff all through the hotel are wonderfully attentive and helpful. I commend them for the exceptional level of service, which even by Tokyo's already high standards, is top notch without being fussy.The hotel's location, between the Ginza and the Imperial Palace, is perfect for anyone having to get around the city or is looking for an interesting place to walk around and shop or sightsee.I travel to Asia frequently and the Peninsula Tokyo stands out for exceptional service, comfortable, well designed rooms, a great location, and overall great value.

An amazing hotel - the highest levels of service (door staff provided a hand towel and bottle of water as I returned from my run round the Palace (across the road) - nice touch!).The pool is great with fantastic views.The rooms are excellent - beautiful walk in wardrobe, massive bath, high tech bedroom/lounge - free wifi, electric windows, lights etc. Everything remotely controlled including a nail dryer which my wife was very excited about!This is a simply magnificent hotel and the only place to stay in Tokyo!

We stayed there for just over a week and were wowed by everything this hotel offers. They held our bags overnight while we climbed mt. Fuji, held our Sake in the fridge. They were great! The room was outstanding and the view was awesome! The bed was so comfortable, and the moment we looked lost, someone offered assistance. Great shopping in the hotel and in the area. Even better restaurants just south of the Yurachuko stop. Right across the street from the Imperial Palace and the Hibiya line. Will always stay there when I go to Tokyo.

I had the most wonderful 4 nights stay at The Peninsula Tokyo in July 2010.Room:I stayed in the smallest superior room on the 21st floor. Despite that, the room was spacious and extremely quiet. There was a seating area with dinning table for two, a king-sized bed, a lovely bathroom with his and her sinks, a dressing area and a luggage area. The room had all the basic amenities, modern technology and complimentary wi-fi. Some of the amenities I really love was the nail dryer, the mood lighting, the bathroom's spa option (lights were dimmed and music played), the beside controller (for visually everything in the room), the humidity controller, the coffee/tea making machine, the valet box (for newspapers & laundry delivery) and the cellphone for use within the hotel. The room was modern, stylish and comfortable.Service:Just like the room itself, the service of the hotel staff was perfect. Everyone was extremely polite, helpful and spoke excellent English. I was especially charmed by the housekeeping, concierge and room service staff. The concierge for example, led me all the way from the hotel lobby to the nearest subway station, instead of just giving me a map and directions like most hotels would. I also had a lovely chat with the room service staff and the housekeeping staff went out of their way to make my stay the most comfortable one.All of my needs were met and I have to admit I am very impressed with their service.Location:The hotel was right on top of a subway station (Hibiya) and within walking distance from the Ginza shopping district. A convenience store 7-11 and local fast food restaurant Freshness Burger are located across the street. Conclusion:The Peninsula Tokyo is possibly the best hotel I have ever stayed in in Tokyo. The room was perfect and the staff was incredible. The whole experience was pure luxury and I will definitely be back at this lovely hotel.

First off, all the wonderful things written in the reviews here about this hotel & the details of the rooms are absolutely true. The 22nd Century toilet seat in the bath (which, after an ill-advised late-night rice ball from the 7/11 across the street, I learned you can actually fall asleep on) & the nail dryer in the walk-in closet on their own are enough to recommend the place.Add a concierge desk that gave great guidance without ever condescending, stunning design, & a dream location & it sounds perfect. That's what made the gracelessness of the exit so jarring it made us doubt the sincerity of all the courtesy that came before - kind of like a kick in the pants & a shove out the door.Here's what happened. Generally, taking a shuttle bus to the airport is kind of low rent move, but in Tokyo, where The Peninsula car to Narita is US$650 & even minivan service is over US$200, taking the shuttle bus just means you are not totally willing to take your money, put it in a little pile, & set it on fire.So, after checking out, we sat to wait for the bus on one of the admittedly (and, in hindsight, probably intentionally) tiny & uncomfortable couches that flank the entrance corridor, carefully tucking our small carry-ons between us so that they extended into the walkway no further than our feet did. This arrangement did not work at all for the floorwalker running the lobby, who marched over & rather insistently asked to check our bags.The tone from the beginning was not of helpfulness but more like we were breaking a rule, creating a hazard, harming the aesthetics of the lobby. We politely declined as the bags were unlocked & my wife had jewelry in hers.He spun heel & he was replaced by an even unfriendlier sort, who at one point tried to carry the bags away. Mind you, the bags were not blocking the corridor & were Prada & LV duffels, not quite plastic garbage bags (if that matters).After another polite refusal, the rude dude returned again & even though the bus pick up was 10 minutes away started pointing us toward the door where a group of other "guests" who had probably been bullied out of the lobby just before us were huddled. At this point, my NY background bubbled to the surface & I proceeded to set back international relations some 70 years.In retrospect, it is clear that the lobby is not for the convenience of loitering former guests. They want to keep it pristine so the folks that have just laid down nearly a Grand a night don't sully the atmosphere for their overrated, tourist-trap cash cow "afternoon tea at The Peninsula".This is a real problem that we hope they fix because otherwise it's a fantastic hotel, truly one of the best in the world. Will consider returning but certainly not until October when flights from HK to Haneda begin & private car service should be more reasonable - definitely will not ever wait in that lobby again (which, unfortunately & infuriatingly, is exactly what they want).

The Peninsula is an exceptionally beautiful hotel, very centrally located near the Imperial Palace, the Ginza and Marunouchi. It is one of the few hotels that is free-standing, not part of a larger office building or shopping center. The rooms are beautifully appointed. We stayed in a corner suite which was over the top; however I did see a regular room and that was just as beautifully decorated. The corner suite has a large living room, separate bedroom entered through a very large dressing area, spacious bathroom, powder room, and both the living room and the bedroom have direct views of the Imperial Palace. It felt like our own apartment. The gym, which was located in the spa, had excellent equipment and was well staffed. There is a beautiful pool in the spa. All the employees that we came in contact with spoke fluent English and were very helpful. The concierge arranged a visit to the Imperial Palace (which needs to be done a day in advance), bought our train tickets to Kobe, and was very helpful with restaurant reservations.My only complaint is that on their website they mention that there is a complimentary hotel car to take you to local stops but when i asked about it on at least three different occasions, no one at the hotel seemed to know what I was talking about. The hotel should not offer something which it is not willing to provide. Other than that our stay was flawless and we would definitely choose this hotel over the other five star hotels in Tokyo (having visited most of the others).

This property, its staff and its management have set a standard for others to follow. This was our best hotel experience over many years and many locations around the world. Wonderful rooms, beautiful and serene hotel, lovely pool and spa areas and a location that cannot be beat. The staff are professional, attentive and clearly empowered to resolve any issues which you bring to their attention. I would love to stay here again and again! Other reviews have hit on the many high points of this property and were the basis for our interest in staying here. We were thrilled to find our high expectations were met and the staff was prepared to do whatever was needed to make our stay a memorable one.First class all the way. I look forward to coming back.

As you entered the Hotel, "Welcoming" the Guests ( We were a group of 20) and ushering to a room, briefing about the hotel facilities and the Room key was ready. Need not wait to fill the forms. Rather a Quick reception. The Rooms were excellent with all basic necessities. Instructions were clear. No need to call the reception for clarifications. Well organized.The Washrooms has a Sauna, Bathcube and the Toilet's with Autowash ( Real good experienece). There are seperate Gym, Sauna, Swimming facilities... Well maintained. Just lying on the bed you can control the window curtains, TV, A/c etc., ( To become too lazy) Different type of Restaurants were available. Food Quality was very good.. Especially when having breakfast, self service properly arranged in designated places, Kitchen SEE THROUGH"- U can see the hygenity mainatained..A series of Meeting room with required facilities...FANTASTIC LOCATION : near to Tokyo palace. We can have a good morning walk. Beautiful Scenary, Landscape.Chauffer driven Cars : Including Rolls RoyceExcellent Airport - Hotel transfers, Stations : Bullet train, Suburban & Airport ( Narita Express) stations are 10-15mts walk.. Tokyo is a underground city.. Stations are at various levels and you find people using the underground pathways. Takes care of weather related issues... Instructions are good..Just 5-10 mts walk from the hotel, good restaaurants available, Continental, Indian, Mughalai, Japanese etc., Ofcourse pubs and eatery joints including wayside hotels..On the whole good experience...

The Peninsula is definitely a top-notch hotel, even if you are not so techophile as to try out all the 19288473 (or so) different gimmicks they have in every room for you. The location, directly in Ginza vis-a-vis the Imperial Palace, is a huge bonus. Especially if you want to work out by circling the palace running (the premier running route in Tokyo). And still the hotel sometimes feels a little awkward with a strange lobby-cum-restaurant set-up. When you are having breakfast you are in the middle of arriving or departing guests and part of the whole hustle and bustle. Not so peaceful, really...

Travelled to Tokyo with my husband, sister-in-law & 10 week old son. Picked up from the airport in the hotel's hideously expensive but superbly beautiful Rolls Royce. First class service from the moment we entered. Perfectly located for day trip to Imperial Palace (next door) or walking distance to Subway to everywhere. English speaking staff with the Japanese service one travels to Japan for. Ginza shopping alarmingly close for my husband's liking! Turn down service beautiful. Highly recommend.

Peninsula Tokyo does not overwhelm you on initial arrival at the narrow crowded lobby which is sandwiched by tables of people having tea. It's noisy and awkwardly designed.But that is the only bad thing about the hotel - the lobby.The rooms are incredibly large for Tokyo - well designed and extremely sensitive and thoughtful. Aside from the usual plush bedsheets and comfortable beds expected from a great hotel, it has added touches. For our lowest grade superior room, they have incredible features. For example:(1) One touch spa button to dim down all lights and for spa music to play in bathroom; handsfree speakerphone next to bath. Numerous light settings.(2) a delivery hatch where you can have things delivered to your room like a mail box without you having to grab a robe before opening the door.(3) Awesome espresso machine (and it is not the normal Nespresso one)(4) Printer in the room where you can print your boarding pass or anything else pretty much.(5) Walkin closet is standard feature. (even in superior room)Service is excellent with the superb concierge making all the hard to make reservations and printing them on one sheet and handling to you at check in. Location is awesome - 10 minutes cab from Tokyo station; it is also located above both the Yurakucho station and the Hibiya station.Clearly the best rooms (comparing to other superior room (excluding suites)) we've experienced. Better than any Four Seasons, Park Hyatts we've been to. Why can't all 5 star hotel rooms be like that??

Had the best hotel experience in my life. Stay at a Deluxe Room, but I guess you get what you paid for. I feel like I am in a suite when all hotel in Tokyo are extremely tiny, but over 450sqf for Deluxe Room feel very luxurious. All hotel facilities and staff are super friendly and helpful. Complimentary use of indoor swimming pool, fitness center, and wifi internet is a big plus. Had dinner and drinks at their Lobby and worth every penny I paid. Great Location and they even have jogging map for guest around the park and the palace. Will only stay there when I am back in Tokyo!

Hotels don't get better than this. Everything is simply perfect.After having spent one night at the Imperial hotel we checked out and went to the Peninsula instead. The best decision ever.We spent three nights in a Deluxe Park View room that is very spacious, beautifully designed and offers all the technological gadgets you can wish for. Service is outstanding. The gym, pool and spa are fantastic. Just a pity that there is no natural light in the gym. The location is perfect, right on top of a metro station and only a couple of minutes to the Ginza shopping area. The hotel was completely full during our stay but the atmosphere remained very relaxed and everything worked smoothly. We had a great night in the Peter restaurant/bar. Beautiful place with a great atmosphere. The food was good (not great) but the overall package was very enjoyable. Definitely one of the best hotels in the world.

We stayed here for two nights at the end of a month long trip to Japan. We were celebrating an anniversary and I decided to surprise him with this reservation. It far exceeded all expectations. I booked a suite (they had a special - book one night and the second night was free). Worth every penny! We had a corner suite with views of the Ginza and the Imperial Palace. Nine windows, a telescope, fresh fruit every day, a deep soaking tub that was heavenly, and a box of chocolates and bottle of wine courtesy of the hotel. The bed was so comfy you felt like you were cradled the moment you lay down. The dressing room was huge with an automatic nail dryer no less. We loved the views both day and night. We arrived from Kyoto by train and took a taxi to the hotel.

The hotel room took me by surprise as it is far more spacious and more like a little apartment with luxurious features. It had a huge king-size bed, a nice sofa with TV, a changing room and an amazing bathroom with an automated Japanese toilet- one of those highlights of travelling to Japan!I would definitely keep going here- this must be one of the most spacious hotel rooms in Tokyo although the lobby and restaurant were just adequate.

My husband and I stayed at the Peninsula for a week. We loved every part of it and really could not think of a single negative. Our room was the best city hotel room we have ever stayed in- the layout is perfect. The bathroom/ dressing area is separated from the sleeping area. This was great because I always got up earlier than my husband. The closet/dressing area is awesome with a vanity in the closet and plenty of hanging room, suitcase space & shopping bag space. The bathroom has a "spa" button when pressed the lights dim and the spa music comes on! The space is perfectly set up for traveling, enough space for 2 huge suitcases, very comfortable and easy to feel at home. We had a park view which was perfect because we were lucky enough to be there during the cherry blossoms and were able to see the trees from our room at breakfast every morning. Room service was prompt, great selection and beautiful presentation. The spa was fabulous, especially the relaxation room. Did not try the indoor pool. We tried Sunday afternoon high tea- it was lovely. The lobby bar seamed to be the place to be for Tokyo's lunching ladies so it was fun to be around them- very bustling, sophisticated and high energy. Also, on the weekend there was a wedding everyday. In the basement you can get food to go- for a picnic in the gardens. We tried the rooftop lounge for lunch and drinks- great view, drinks, and delicious lunch. The hotel is 5 min walk to Ginza and the Royal Gardens- loved that. The service and staff were perfect, gracious and kind. Will definitely go back to the Peninsula next time we are in Tokyo!

Stayed on the 23rd floor...great city view. Beautiful room. Staff was excellent. Dinner at the restaurant on the top floor was also very good, and the cocktail happy hour was the best deal going. All of this being said, the hotel rate is by no means cheap: we paid around $550 a night.

We stayed for three nights at the Peninsula on a recent trip to Tokyo. The hotel is indeed impressive and probably one of the best that we've stayed in. The room are huge - even for the entry level deluxe room - which we stayed in - and we loved the modern amenities and technological gadgets that came along with it. The location is also superb - walking distance to ginza and easy accessibility to the metro and yamanote line. Breakfast in the lobby was good but a little pricey. All in all a great stay - will definitely stay here again in Tokyo ! :)

My wife and I stayed at this hotel for five nights in March with our two young children (ages 10 & 11). This hotel is in an incredible location overlooking the Imperial Palace. The staff was incredibly accomodating. My wife was ill the day we checked in and because we arrived before our room was ready, the staff provided us with another room to stay in. What a lifesaver! When our room was ready, we were upgraded to a two bedroom suite overlooking the Imperial Gardens. It even included cookies and treats for the kids! The restaurants were great. Plus, two consecutive mornings at breakfast, we were treated to a traditional Japanese wedding party coming through the lobby. What an experience.

Stayed at the Peninsula for 3 nights. The location was good, close to the station, lots of izakaya and restaurant nearby. The room was very spacious and the bed was very comfortable (especially after spending some nights sleeping on futtons at several ryokans). The bathroom was large and beautiful, equipped with a shower and a bathtub with a TV. Really love the dressing room. The bar (I think its called Peter) was great and has a good selection of sake. The view at Peter bar was also nice. The staffs were extremely helpful. All of the staffs (even the door man) spoke excellent English. They gave us several maps of Tokyo (Ginza area, general Tokyo area, Shinjuku area, etc) and clear direction. We ask them to book us some Michelin stars restaurant. They manage to book Ryugin for us (even though its quite impossible since generally you have to book this restaurant 2 months in advance). We were very lucky. The staff prints the restaurant’s map, show us the picture of the restaurant door (since the restaurant has no signage), and show our taxi driver the direction to get us there. Everything was perfect. Will definitely stay here again.

We stayed at this hotel due to its glowing reviews, and we were not disappointed. This hotel has set such a high bench mark all others seem ordinary. The lobby is most impressive and has a magnificent chandelier. Great location overlooking the Imperial Palace gardens and located in the Paris end of town, Ginza.
