Our room had every creature comfort you could ever wish for. The master control was to die for; you could even adjust the room humility. Great sound system, choice of room lighting was brilliant! The room was huge with separate dressing room and a enormous bathroom. You will get a kick out of the toilet but tend to spend a bit too long fiddling with the various controls :-) The WC was discretely separated from main bathroom) !Staff extremely helpful and polite and spoke very good English. We hired the hotel's BMW bikes so we could cover a lot of area in a much quicker time than if we had walked. The bike hire was a bit too pricey, however we had a great time. This hotel is not cheap but pretty much on par with other 5 star hotels in Tokyo, so it was well worth the money. Peter's restaurant was smokey and overpriced and nothing to write home about. Our room had just as good a view as Peter's so after dinner we purchased champagne and we enjoyed the wonderful view in private. If your not under 25, go to the restaurant downstairs for happy hour (much better value without the smokers) . Food was great, atmosphere wonderful. Highly recommended to anyone wanting to spoil themselves.

This was the last hotel we stayed in on a 3 week tour of Japan and most definitely the best. The location was great on the edge of the Imperial Palace gardens and close to all the classy shops in Ginza. The room was huge with separate dressing room and a enormous bathroom. Lots of gadgets in the room which our 14yr old son thought great fun including a toilet seat which lifted up when you walked into the loo!Staff extremely helpful and polite, and the highlight after a run around the Imperial Palace was greeted with a towel and bottle of water at the hotel door.Not a cheap option but well worth it. Only slight caveat is don't eat at the Peter restaurant overpriced and over-rated - but do go to the bar for a drink and enjoy the view

after more obsessing than i'd like to admit i finally chose peninsula for our last two nights in tokyo - thankfully it turned out to be the perfect choice! our room on the 23rd floor was over-the-top beautiful with an incredible view of the imperial palace and the city - gorgeous! unbelievable service, perfect location - the whole experience could not have been better! fantastic bar on the 24th floor - so great i didn't mind paying $18 for my cosmopolitan or $9 for my son's coke. : ) room service dinner was beautifully presented, breakfast buffet in the 2nd floor dining was excellent. one of the highlights of my 13 y.o. son's visit to tokyo was a ride in their audi R8 thanks to the kindness of one of their incredible concierges and guest services manager. we could not have had a more wonderful experience - the peninsula has got to be the best hotel in all of tokyo! some people have said they think the ritz is - i'm sure it is nice too but we walked by and didn't care for the midtown neighborhood where it is located. in contrast we loved being able to walk to the ginza neighborhood by our hotel with all of it's beautiful shops and great restaurants, and all the beautiful lights at night. peninsula was really perfect - save yourself all the obsessing i went through and stay here at least a couple of nights - you will not be disappointed!

What can I say. Prior to this trip, I'd given up on 5 star hotels, thinking all of them had impersonal, disinterested service and that the only thing they were interested in was squeezing your dollars out of you. Our stay at the Peninsula Tokyo changed my mind. Completely. Everything and everyone was excellent. The front desk took seriously our dissatisfaction with our first room. The concierge desk dealt with (almost) all of our requests for help with restaurant bookings, maps for taxi drivers, directions to places, ticket bookings with great efficiency and capability. The spa has excellent facilities and service (I went for a second treatment because it was so good and I knew I'd get nothing like it back in London). The pool is spectacularly clean. The gym is well equipped (for a hotel). Room service is good. The room itself is magnificent - spacious beyond belief (especially for a big city), with a separate walk in closet and dressing room, a nice bath (that is separate from the WC), and with great technology that they've really thought about (they have their own R&D division working out how to make guests feel more comfortable in the room - as a techie, I was impressed). Location is good for good restaurants.Negatives were very, very few. (1) The Concierge desk is a bit overwhelmed - there is often a queue (because lots of people need help in a city with language barriers) and staff get very tired towards the end of the day. It really needs to be expanded. (2) The Hei Fung Terrace restaurant was really not impressive. This needs some work. (3) The website shouldn't really sell some of their rooms as 'Park View' rooms. In truth, the Deluxe Park View rooms are directly facing a large white office building, and the view of the park is at an angle to the side. You'll only get any kind of serious view of the park if you're as far West as possible in the corridor (or, if you want a view directly over the park, if you book a Suite). If you are booking a Deluxe Park View, ask for as high a floor as possible (it goes up to 22) and ask for, e.g., 2202 or 2203 (which are as far down the corridor as possible, closer to the park).Highly recommend this hotel. I will be thinking about it with very pleasant memories and I'll definitely go back.

I stayed at the Peninsula Tokyo recently for 5 nights. It was a fantastic stay. The staff of the Peninsula are extremely friendly and polite and assisted at any moment. Getting there is Narita airport was easy. A specific Airport Limousine Bus from Narita will take you directly to the hotel within 90 mins at a cost of ¥ 3000 pp.The rooms are superbly furnish and spacious. I stayed on the 20th floor overlooking the city. Upon check-in we were asked what type of room we wished to have. We were advised that a park view room (looking over the Imperial Palace gardens) is nice during the day, but at night it is in complete darkness, so the night skyline would be a better option. We decided to take their advise and we weren't disappointed.The hotel is located above 2 metro lines (Hibiya and Chiyoda lines) and in walking distance to another (Ginza line), making it extremely easy to travel around Tokyo. The area itself is not a lively area at night - as it is mainly a shopping and financial district. However Shinjuku is only 10 mins by metro and 20 mins by taxi, so you can definitely have a lively evening out in Shinjuku and make your way back to the hotel without too much hassle.The only disappointment I had about my stay at the Peninsula Tokyo was the food standard at the Chinese restaurant on the 2nd floor. I found the food uninspiring and dull - food you would find in any mid-range city restaurant. It was certainly not worth the price. Unbeknown to me, it is actually a Michelin star restaurant, which I found out 2 days after dining there, making my experience even worse. There are much better quality (and more satisfying) restaurants close by at Marunouchi Brick Square complex - which we were recommended by the Concierge.I have now stayed at 2 Peninsula hotels - Bangkok and Tokyo - and overall find the Peninsula hotel chain one of the best (if not the best) in the world.

Where to stay in tokyo for 1 week? I perused The Peninsula, Ritz Carlton and Four Seasons. Settled on Peninsula because of its excellent reviews, as well as fabulous totally walkable location. This is not one of Tokyo's huge bottomless pit skyscraper type buildings, although it is over 20 floors.The staff was beyond compare. I have stayed in the finest hotels and The Peninsula Tokyo leaves them in the dust. The attention to detail and perfection was most appreciated. I will say this though--dining in the lobby restaurant..equiv to other hotel's regular restaurants is pricy. Breakfast for 2 of us-- fruit, toast, oatmeal and juice was $100!! Glass of ice tea was $13. We each got one, my hubby had a refill--not free--lol and bill was $39USD. Orange juice was $12USD for 4 oz little glass. Eat elsewhere.This is a wonderful hotel. You will be glad you stayed here. Forget the Ritz Tokyo , we visited friends there. It was like a zoo.

This is a fantastic hotel , good location and if you can afford it or get a deal go and stay there.We had exceptional service from booking to departure. We lost two items on leaving the plane , concierge dealt with the airline and got them delivered to our room 2 days later. We were met at door by welcoming staff , including the manager who tries to greet as many visitors as possible and was always walking around and visible to guests and staff. In room check in as we had a suite and had prebooked transport . One of the party had a birthday whilst there , and did not tell anyone BUT it was spotted from the passport and there were chocolates left on the day in room and a greeting card . Everyday there were little goodies left for us in the room . Concierge arranged with onward hotel for transports , gave advice on where to eat outside of hotel . Staff throughout hotel always polite and spoke to everyone they saw and have exceptional English skills The rooms are high tech - clean ,great coffee machine , fantastic bathrooms with underfloor heating and the usual hi- tech toilet , "dumb waiter" valet service for shoe shines/ laundry / newspapers( put your items in a box , they are collected through a secret door returned in same box later and no one disturbs you in your room ).Fax machine in the room - not that I was on business - but would be great for any one who was, also an in hotel mobile phone so if you were at the bar perhaps and a call came through to your room you could still be contacted.But very best of all in the room - THE BED - others have said it but I really would have liked to take the bed home , this was the best bed EVER . Food and service at Hei Fung Terrace is exceptional - well deserves the star , we made a mistake when ordering the wine and changing it was no problem at allPeter the bar - very trendy - very very popular , not enough seating , but staff try and accommodate and are very friendly , very trendy !Peter the restaurant - food good , but preferred Hei Fung The lobby - ALWAYS busy with ladies who lunch / afternoon teas- would be good for residents to be able to get queue priority here and at the other food and drink establishmentsRoom service food - high quality and presentation ( would be good to get breakfast in room WITHOUT the service charge if it is in room rate )Location for transport and walking is good .If we have to think of something negative - don't expect great views- it's a city centre , some rooms are overlooked by other buildings and their occupants, and because the Lobby and other restaurants are good they are popular with non residents and can get very busy .Would we go again - YES tomorrow , its a marvellous establishment and very well run .

So much praise has been lavished on this hotel but I can't help it, I need to add my two cents. The rooms were unbelievable, the pool a true oasis, but what sets this hotel apart are the staff. We found out we had a severe baggage restriction for one of our flights so with only a few hours notice we had to ship a large box of our belongings home but the concierge took care of everything. She confirmed with the airline what the situation was, sent us up boxes and labels, and then had someone come up to pick them up for shipping - that alone made the high cost of the room worth every penny. So often the so called concierge knows less about a place than I do (and all I have done is read the guidebooks and read Trip Advisor obsessively!) but these concierges were amazing. We loved every second there.
Perfect Service, beautiful rooms, nice atmosphere; expensive but well worth the money

Although pricy: around US$500-600 a night for a hotel room in central Tokyo, it is worth it once in a while.Top Location: In the Hibiya area within 5-10 minutes walk to all the department stores in Ginza, and 5 minute ride by taxi to Tsukiji, the central fish market. Very convenient. Covered walk to Hibiya metro station from B2 floor. Top service: Great Concierge. Fluent in English and attentive. Quick response to email request for restaurant bookings prior to my stay. On check-in, I was handed an envelope with confirmation of my bookings and a map location of each of the pre-booked restaurants.There was a medical emergency within a travelling member on Saturday and the receptionist was helpful with assisting us to book an appointment with a specialist doctor at a clinic two blocks away and printed a map to us for guidance. Room: Superb, reasonably large for Tokyo's standards. Free internet connection, in-room fax machine, huge walk in wardrobe. Great for business or leisure.Facilities: Indoor swimming pool heated with Jacuzzi. No chlorine smell and water salinity monitored regularly and does not irritate eyes. Goggles and Swimming Cap can be rented out for free and free mineral water replenished regularly. Spa music played inside the swimming pool, audible when submerged in water...quite an experience...The ideal pool for any hotel...Breakfast: Ordinary Japanese style breakfast. For afternoon tea, the lobby lounge is always packed and queuing required. If you stay at the hotel, you should pre-book for the experience. However, Hong Kong Peninsula is the place for the ultimate afternoon tea experience.

We stayed here twice on the same trip - 4 nights at the start and 1 final night. The hotel is amazing, everything you could ask for with huge rooms with walk in closets/dressing rooms, massive TV and huge bathroom with TV. Service was exemplary - nothing too much trouble, and they were very accommodating of our 11 month old daughter (she had her own welcome amenity pack, and monogrammed slippers!). You do get what you pay for - but it's definitely worth it. We couldn't use the pool as our daughter couldn't go in (20s + only! - a theme in Japan) but we ate in the lobby restaurant, and also used the really good value set menu in the basement gift shop/restaurant which is handy for the exit to the Hibiya subway station. The JR Yamanote line station is only a few mins away, and you're out into Ginza in 100 yards plus the imperial palace park is opposite. Food and drink is expensive (c. 1000Yen for a beer) but you expect that at a 5 star plus property. Overall, nothing to fault and would go back in a heartbeat.

This has to be one of the best hotels I have stayed, thoroughly enjoyed it here!! I would say if the price is not an issue then definitely stay here because the service is good, staff are generally friendly and helpful, and the rooms are very nice. The location is also convenient (being connected to the tube station).We also stayed in the Grand Hyatt during our time in Tokyo, (which is also good but the walk from the JR station is a bit too long and also since it's not covered you get wet on rainy days) - no such problem for the Peninsula!And we also enjoyed our time in the spa and the swimming pool, top notch service!

The Peninsula Hotel is a short walk from Tokyo station and is located closest to the JR Yurakucho Station. It is a very short walk away from the Ginza...so fantastic location! The rooms are phenomenal, very large bedroom with a separate very large walk in closet area and a separate very large bathroom. The service was very good but seemed rather cold compared to the warm service of the Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo. Breakfast was good (not great) but the afternoon tea was very, very good.

This remains a firm favourite of mine. The other opponents, Park Hyatt, Grand Hyatt, Four Seasons, Mandarin either loose on location or value. The hotel is right on top of Hibiya station and that's great if you want to go to Roppongi. Ginza and Maranouchi are just walking distance. You can use the Phantom free of charge within 2km distance. The rooms are spacious, comfy and offer nice views (even if looking at the back of buildings). Wi-fi are reliable and fast. Pools lovely and hardly ever one uses it. I booked all my restaurants through the concierge. You can count on them for unbiased and efficient advice. Highly recommended.

We booked The Peninsula Tokyo for our honeymoon and this was an excellent choice. Spent first 5 days of our stay in Japan there, then went to Kyoto and Hiroshima, to come back to The Peninsula for the last two nights. Coming back felt like coming home. The room was ready for us, our bag (we left them with the hotel) were already in the room. Nice, warm welcome.The staff, the facilities and the location were first class. The room was rather high tech (not too mention the cosmic toilets with their steering panels). The hotel pool with hot water jacuzzi and huge windows overlooking Tokyo were fantastic for relaxing after a long sightseeing day.

This hotel gets raves from all over and I can't help but join the chorus.It IS nice to write a rave review for a change. I had the 'cheapest' room in the hotel, no delux, suite nor any executive add-ons. The room was big, amazingly appointed and the bathroom alone was the size of a little bedroom. The famous 'nail dryer' was indeed on the dressing table.Service in this hotel is just divine, personal but discreet. Every little detail has been sorted out for your convenience.The Chinese restaurant is some of the best Cantonese in town. Top floor bar is classy and with a long happy hour of 700yen for perfect coctail, it's simply a luxury bargain.Spa is beautiful, they have a lovely steamroom, treatments were highly professional,(again some recession specials!), indoor pool overlooks the Imperial Palace garden. There is a beautiful sculpture in the 70m atrium of the building, that was an esthetic pleasure everytime whilst waiting for the lift.I could go on and on about the wonders of this hotel,but go find it out for yourself.Perhaps it is not for someone who seeks a trendy and hip atmosphere. What you get at the Peninsula is a sheer good old fashioned luxury. At the end, I found the price to be very reasonable, for having such service and esthetic value that money doesn't always buy.
A terrific hotel, the staff were without very friendly and extremely helpful. It is a expensive hotel but very worth it!The best hotel experience.

THey say "welcome back" evertime you walk past reception. What a delightful touch to their overall superior service. The rooms are among the best in the world. From heated toilet seats, a bidet, an elegant bath tub and separate stone shower. And that's just the bathroom! Everything is hi-tech but not without purpose. I tried to fold up the bed and fit it in my suitcase!I will with out a doubt be staying there on my return visit to Tokyo. Oh and Sanai (sp?), the concierge, is so delightful, personable, and helpful. Basically you get what you pay for!!

My family and I thoroughly enjoyed our stay at the Peninsula Tokyo. We've stayed at several other Peninsula's before, and although Peninsula Tokyo's lobby is not as grand as the others, it still is by far one of the top 3. the service, the location, the unique decor and the class that it exudes makes you feel like royalty. you really feel like you are in tokyo. don't be fooled by its tiny lobby because in tokyo this is quite common. in fact, many of the other luxury hotels in tokyo (grand hyatt, park hyatt, four season etc) are connected to malls or office buildings and so their lobbies are almost non-existent. peninsula tokyo, on the other hand, has its own 24 story building. also, there is a direct entrance to the hibiya subway line which pretty much connects to the other nice areas of tokyo, like roppongi, tsukiji etc. ginza, where peninsula is located, is by far the most up-scale neighborhood in tokyo but still manages to preserve its antiquity (the famous Imperial Palace & Garden is right across the Peninsula!) ALL IN ALL, I WOULD STAY AT THE PEN TOKYO MANY, MANY, MANY MORE TIMES! Very, very PRICEY, but definitely, definitely WORTH IT. Oh, our room was so clean, spacious and technologically advanced (think massage toilets and BILINGUAL TELEVISION!), and even equipped with daily fresh fruits and a sweets platter. We were totally spoiled but loved it! Oh, and the food at the lobby is EXCELLENT!!!!! Peters (the bar) is also breathtaking, with perhaps a view that beats Park Hyatt's.
Truely one of the best hotels in the world. Expensive but worth every cent.

We stayed at the Peninsula in October and once again in November 2009 - staying there in total 8 nights. The first 4 nights we had a Executive Suite and the second 4 nights a Deluxe Suite. As usual the service and the hotel were excellent. We enjoyed once very good dinner at Peters and occasionally the room service for breakfast or dinner. Both were very good. The rooms are really spacious and have everything you need, including a good espresso machine. They even have gadget like a memory card ready for looking at pictures direct on the TV. Sadly this didn’t work as expected and also the stereo system in the room had not a good sound setup. But everything else is just fantastic and you notice a lot of attention to details. We really loved the room plan which included a separate large dressing room and grand bathroom with a nice view from the bathtub – especially at night times. This is in any case a very nice feature of the corner rooms because they include multiple windows with overwhelming views throughout Ginza. All in all we can say that this Hotel was one of the best we have visited so far has welcomed us home already 4 times in total.

My husband and I traveled for one month throughout Asia for our honeymoon. This was the last hotel we stayed in and by far the best. I would like to replicate the closet for our home! It was amazing! The technology, service, design, food, everything was beyond any and all expectations. When we return to Japan in the future we will always be staying here...

The Peninsula group can be proud of this hotel which is truly amazing. Fantastic service from the check-in till check-out, great sky bar "Peter" on the 24th floor with amazing view over the city, a Michelin star restaurant on the 2nd floor, an exceptional Spa facility with a very large indoor swimming pool overlooking the Imperial gardens ...Rooms are fantastic, very large, with the best technology I have ever seen, even in the latest top luxury hotels worldwide.Do not go anywhere else if you go to Tokyo.

I loved staying at this hotel! It felt like ‘home’ in fact on returning to the hotel one was always greeted with a ‘welcome back’. We took advantage of the sweet dreams promotion which offered a suite for half price – and what accommodation – it was like an apartment but without a kitchen. Spacious and comfortable, attractively designed and with every possible amenity – it was very difficult to tear oneself away from it. Excellent housekeeping, linens, toiletries etc.Enjoyed very good meals and service in both Peter and Hei Fung Terrace where Kosuke Yamashita provided particularly personable and friendly service.Pre arrival, the concierge provided friendly and efficient service and throughout my stay everything worked like clockwork. Wonderful location with direct access to the Metro and an easy walk to Tokyo station (even with luggage). Convenient for all the wonderful neighbouring up market shops, the Ginza strip, Hibiya Park and the Imperial Gardens.Highly recommended!

I have just returned home after spending 4 fantastic nights at the Peninsula. After asking on the forum for the best located hotel for "seeing the sights" I was steered torwards this one. And its location is the first thing that strikes you when you arrive. It is surrounded by dozens of shops and restaurants from absolute top end to the great "locals''. It is easy walking distance to the Ginza strip and even the fish market (prob 30 mins though). There is also plenty of public transport surrounding the hotel.The hotel and service is as what most other reviewers have said. Huge, luxurious rooms, great spa facility, top restaurants and bars and amazingly attentive and friendly service. The conceirge and reservations were helpful in the weeks leading up to my stay ensuring all my room requests were met and booking a local tour for me. I couldn't fault any part of my stay. The pricing is not cheap however I booked a deluxe room through a US website (from nextag) and got a great all inclusive rate in US dollars (good for Kiwis at the moment). I don't think you could be disappointed with this hotel however at any price.We at the lobby cafe which was great and also at Peter. This had superb views over Tokyo and a nice bar. We also used a lot of the local establishments - these included an English pub, German beer house, Italian restaurant and of course lots of great tradional Japanese restaurants. All these eateries are within 5 mins.It was my first time to Tokyo and thoroughly enjoyed it. Some great highlights included Nikko temples (and bullet train ride to them), fish market, watching the All Blacks play at National Stadium, great shops at Ginza, superb food everywhere and such friendly, polite locals.The limosine bus service was super easy getting to and from the airport for first timers. The train system is pretty full on but as long as you show the locals your tickets they happily show the right direction. We survived without getting lost! The taxis are very reasonable for getting around the city and are plentiful and clean.In summary, I would rate this as the best hotel I have stayed at by far. The service levels put everywhere in my part of the world to shame. They also just seem to of thought of everything to make your stay extra luxurious in the rooms. I would highly recommend this hotel as a great base for your Tokyo experience.

Stayed at the Peninsula on two separate occasions in August with wife and two children ages 7 and 9. Great location, great rooms, great service and great amenities. Highly recommend this hotel if within your budget.

If it is within budget, I can't imagine there is a better hotel to stay at in Tokyo. The staff are incredible, the rooms are perfect, the location is brilliant, and the food, bars and facilities are all first class. I have stayed here twice for a total of 3 weeks, both times on business, and I am unable to come up with any criticism of any kind. I particularly like the location right opposite the Imperial Palace and next to all the shops in Ginza, also very close to the station for trains to the airport. The swimming pool is also worth a special mention, the pool and changing rooms are spotless with a great view, it is a fantastic place to unwind after a long day of sightseeing or at work.
